第一卷 Part I
“没有退路，没有退路。没有退路的人必须获胜，否则就是死路一条！” “No retreat, no retreat.They must conquer or die Who have no retreat!”
盖伊先生 Mr. Gay.
第一章 Chapter I
散步 Promenade
1922年10月中旬的那个重要的下午，第九代准男爵劳伦斯·蒙特爵士迎着东风翘着俊美的鼻子，迈着两条细腿疾步走下“轻蔑”俱乐部的台阶——俱乐部这一绰号出自上世纪80年代末乔治·福赛特之口。 Coming down the steps of ‘Snooks’ Club, so nicknamed by George Forsyte in the late eighties, on that momentous mid-October afternoon of 1922, Sir Lawrence Mont, ninth baronet, set his fine nose towards the east wind, and moved his thin legs with speed.
他虽出生于政治世家，却对政治不感兴趣，提起他所在的政党重夺政权的那次革命，他只是轻描淡写。 Political by birth rather than by nature, he reviewed the revolution which had restored his Party to power with a detachment not devoid of humour.
路过利姆夫俱乐部时，他想：“这次麻烦啦！ Passing the Remove Club, he thought: ‘Some sweating into shoes, there!
再也没有甜点可吃啦。 No more confectioned dishes.
山鹬没有了配料，得变口味喽！” A woodcock—without trimmings, for a change!’
在他进入“轻蔑”俱乐部之前，那些大老板和王公贵族们早已离开，因为他并不属于“想方设法捞钱，而且已经捞个够本的那帮家伙，他绝不是那种人——那帮家伙在战争刚刚结束时就丢弃家园逃之夭夭了。呸！” The captains and the kings had departed from ‘Snooks’ before he entered it, for he was not of ‘that catch-penny crew, now paid off, no sir; fellows who turned their tails on the land the moment the war was over. Pah!’
可是对过去忘事的回忆，他足足听了一个小时。他的大脑活跃地转动着，牢记往事，怀疑当下，也怀疑一切政治主张和声明。他饶有兴致地记录了这次意义重大的集会上所留下的爱国主义和个体攻击的混乱。 But for an hour he had listened to echoes, and his lively twisting mind, embedded in deposits of the past, sceptical of the present and of all political protestations and pronouncements, had recorded with amusement the confusion of patriotism and personalities left behind by the fateful gathering.
和大部分地主一样，他不相信教条。 Like most landowners, he distrusted doctrine.
如果非要说他有政治信仰的话，那就是征收小麦税了，并且就他所知，他势单力薄——但是，对他来说，选票不重要；换句话说，平民百姓的选票威胁不到他笃信的原则。 If he had a political belief, it was a tax on wheat; and so far as he could see, he was now alone in it—but then he was not seeking election; in other words, his principle was not in danger of extinction from the votes of those who had to pay for bread.
原则——他沉思着——就是钱罢了。他真希望人们不要再装作不承认这一点了！ Principles—he mused—au fond were pocket; and he wished the deuce people wouldn’t pretend they weren’t!
当然，从深层含义来讲，钱无非就是特定社会群体成员的个人利益。 Pocket, in the deep sense of that word, of course, self-interest as member of a definite community.
而当它所有的土地都荒芜，所有的船只和港口都面临被飞机炸毁的危险时，这个特定社会群体——英国民族，倒是有什么办法生存下去啊？ And how the devil was this definite community, the English nation, to exist, when all its land was going out of cultivation, and all its ships and docks in danger of destruction by aeroplanes?
在一个小时的倾听中，他希望听到有人谈及土地。 He had listened that hour past for a single mention of the land.
竟无一人谈及！ Not one!
这根本不是实用政治！ It was not practical politics!
这帮该死的家伙！ Confound the fellows!
他们不惜磨破了裤子——就为了保住席位或获得席位。 They had to wear their breeches out—keeping seats or getting them.
丝毫没考虑过子孙后代！ No connection between posteriors and posterity!
的确没有！ No, by George!
说起后代，他突然想起自己的儿媳至今还没有一点点的喜照。 Thus reminded of posterity, it occurred to him rather suddenly that his son’s wife showed no signs as yet.
两年了！ Two years!
该是要孩子的时候了。 Time they were thinking about children.
不要孩子如果成为一种习惯，对于那些有爵位或是需要产业继承人的家庭来说是相当可怕的。 It was dangerous to get into the habit of not having them, when a title and estate depended.
一丝微笑牵动了他的双唇和眉毛，那两道弯眉异常浓密。 A smile twisted his lips and eyebrows which resembled spinneys of dark pothooks.
一个漂亮的小孩，非常可爱，而且她也深知这一点啊！ A pretty young creature, most taking; and knew it, too!
有谁她不想去认识呢？ Whom was she not getting to know?
狮子、老虎、猴子和猫——她的家成了这些大小名人的动物园了。 Lions and tigers, monkeys and cats—her house was becoming quite a menagerie of more or less celebrities.
这种事情总是有种不真实的感觉！ There was a certain unreality about that sort of thing!
劳伦斯爵士站在特拉法尔加广场上的一只不列颠之狮的对面，心里想：“下次她会把这些都弄到家里去！ And opposite a British lion in Trafalgar Square Sir Lawrence thought: ‘She’ll be getting these to her house next!
她染上收藏的嗜好了。 She’s got the collecting habit.
迈克尔必须小心了——收藏家的家里肯定有一间专门放置破旧货的储藏室，而丈夫是很容易被关进去的。 Michael must look out—in a collector’s house there’s always a lumber room for old junk, and husbands are liable to get into it.
这倒提醒了我：我曾答应给她介绍一位中国公使。 That reminds me: I promised her a Chinese Minister.
好吧，如今她得等到大选过后了。” Well, she must wait now till after the General Election.’
沿着白厅大街往南走，在东方灰色的天空下，威斯敏斯特教堂的塔楼瞬间映入眼帘。 Down Whitehall, under the grey easterly sky, the towers of Westminster came for a second into view.
“那里面似乎也有种不真实的东西，”他想， ‘A certain unreality in that, too,’ he thought.
“迈克尔和他的狂热爱好！ ‘Michael and his fads!
哦，这的确是一种时尚——社会主义的原则和一个富有的妻子。 Well, it’s the fashion—Socialistic principles and a rich wife.
有所牺牲但又很安全！ Sacrifice with safety!
和平且富足！ Peace with plenty!
万能灵药——一便士十粒！ Nostrums—ten a penny!’
查林十字广场上买卖报纸的喧哗由于这次政治危机变得更加嘈杂。他穿过广场向左拐，朝丹比&温特出版社走去，他的儿子是那里的第二合伙人。 Passing the newspaper hubbub of Charing Cross, frenzied by the political crisis, he turned up to the left towards Danby and Winter, publishers, where his son was junior partner.
他已经出版了《蒙特罗斯传》一书、一部东方游记《遥远的契丹》以及《二重唱》。《二重唱》是描述格莱斯顿和迪斯雷利两个幽灵之间的幻想谈话。如今他又开始专心筹备新书了。 A new theme for a book had just begun to bend a mind which had already produced a ‘Life of Montrose,’ ‘Far Cathay,’ that work of Eastern travel, and a fanciful conversation between the shades of Gladstone and Disraeli—entitled ‘A Duet.’
他身材挺拔细长，身着阿斯特拉罕皮领外衣，瘦削的脸上留着灰白胡子，生动的浓眉下架着玳瑁边的单片眼镜。他从“轻蔑”俱乐部出来往东走，每走一步，都显得更加与众不同。 With every step taken, from ‘Snooks’ eastward, his erect thin figure in Astrakhan-collared coat, his thin grey-moustached face, and tortoise-shell rimmed monocle under the lively dark eyebrow, had seemed more rare.
在这条肮脏的后街上，车辆犹如冬天里的苍蝇一般紧挨着，人们夹着书本穿梭其中，看上去似乎很有学问。在这里，像他这样的人物极为引人注目。 It became almost a phenomenon in this dingy back street, where carts stuck like winter flies, and persons went by with books under their arms, as if educated.
快到丹比出版社时，他遇到了两位年轻人。 He had nearly reached the door of Danby’s when he encountered two young men.
其中一位很明显是他的儿子。自从结婚后，他儿子的打扮比以前讲究一些了，这会儿正吸着一支雪茄——谢天谢地——吸的不是那种没完没了的烟卷；另一位——啊，没错——是迈克尔不成气候的诗人朋友和结婚时的男傧相，他头昂得高高的，活像个油头滑脑的家伙！ One of them was clearly his son, better dressed since his marriage, and smoking a cigar—thank goodness—instead of those eternal cigarettes; the other—ah! yes—Michael’s sucking poet and best man, head in air, rather a sleek head under a velour hat!
他说道： He said:
“嗨，迈克尔！” “Ha, Michael!”
“你好，准爵爷！ “HALLO, Bart!
威尔弗里德，你认识我爸爸吧？ You know my governor, Wilfrid?
这是威尔弗里德·德赛特。 Wilfrid Desert.
准爵爷，我告诉您，他是位伟大的诗人，也是《铜币》的作者。 ‘Copper Coin’—some poet, Bart, I tell you.
您一定要读读他的作品。 You must read him.
我们准备回家了。 We’re going home.
一起走吧！” Come along!”
劳伦斯爵士与他们同行。 Sir Lawrence went along.
“‘轻蔑’俱乐部情况如何？” “What happened at ‘Snooks’?”
“国王去世。 “Le roi est mort.
工党可以开始编谎话了，迈克尔——下个月要进行大选了。” Labour can start lying, Michael—election next month.”
“威尔弗里德，准爵爷是在不了解民众的时代长大的。” “Bart was brought up, Wilfrid, in days that knew not Demos.”
“哦，德赛特先生，您觉得如今的政治现实可行吗？” “Well, Mr. Desert, do you find reality in politics now?”
“先生，您在哪些方面发现它现实可行呢？” “Do you find reality in anything, sir?”
“或许是在所得税方面。” “In income tax, perhaps.”
迈克尔咧嘴笑了。 Michael grinned.
“地位在爵士以上的人，”他说道，“单纯的信仰对他们而言根本不存在。” “Above knighthood,” he said, “there’s no such thing as simple faith.”
“假设你的朋友掌权，迈克尔——在某些方面，这其实并不是一件坏事，帮助他们发展起来——他们又能干些什么呢？ “Suppose your friends came into power, Michael—in some ways not a bad thing, help ‘em to grow up—what could they do, eh?
他们能提高国民的品位吗？ Could they raise national taste?
能取缔电影吗？ Abolish the cinema?
能教会英国人厨艺吗？ Teach English people to cook?
能阻止其他国家发动战争吗？ Prevent other countries from threatening war?
能帮我们种出我们自己吃的粮食吗？ Make us grow our own food?
能控制城市人口增长吗？ Stop the increase of town life?
他们会用毒气杀死那些滥竽充数的人吗？ Would they hang dabblers in poison gas?
他们能在战时把飞机打下来吗？ Could they prevent flying in war-time?
无论在何处，他们能削弱人们占有欲强的本性吗？ Could they weaken the possessive instinct—anywhere?
或者，除了稍微改变一点儿占有欲的问题，还能做点儿其他的什么吗？ Or do anything, in fact, but alter the incidence of possession a little?
一切党派政治都善于浮华的装饰。 All party politics are top dressing.
我们受到制定规则的人和人性的支配，并且我们经济上陷入了困境，德赛特先生。” We’re ruled by the inventors, and human nature; and we live in Queer Street, Mr. Desert.”
“我也深有同感，先生。” “Much my sentiments, sir.”
迈克尔晃了晃他手中的雪茄。 Michael flourished his cigar.
“难缠的人啊，你们二位呀！” “Bad old men, you two!”
经过纪念碑时，他们都脱下帽子。 And removing their hats, they passed the Cenotaph.
“非常有代表性——那个东西，”劳伦斯爵士说，“害怕出风头的纪念碑——这说法真准确。 “Curiously symptomatic—that thing,” said Sir Lawrence; “monument to the dread of swank—most characteristic.
说到害怕出风头——” And the dread of swank—”
“准爵爷，说下去。”迈克尔说道。 “Go on, Bart,” said Michael.
“一切优雅、博大、华丽的事物——全都消失了！ “The fine, the large, the florid—all off!
没有远见的卓识，没有宏伟的规划，没有高尚的原则，没有崇高的信仰，没有伟大的艺术——只有沉湎于小派系和穷乡僻壤里的唯美主义，和一些鼠目寸光的小人物而已。” No far-sighted views, no big schemes, no great principles, no great religion, or great art—aestheticism in cliques and backwaters, small men in small hats.”
“所以人心切慕拜伦、威尔伯福斯以及纳尔逊纪念碑。 “As panteth the heart after Byron, Wilberforce, and the Nelson Monument.
我可怜的准爵爷！ My poor old Bart!
威尔弗里德，你的看法呢？” What about it, Wilfrid?”
“是啊，德赛特先生，你是怎么看的呢？” “Yes, Mr. Desert—what about it?”
德赛特皱了皱阴沉的脸。 Desert’s dark face contracted.
“这是个自相矛盾的时代。”他说， “It’s an age of paradox,” he said.
“我们都高喊着要自由，但只有社会主义和罗马天主教会真正受益。 “We all kick up for freedom, and the only institutions gaining strength are Socialism and the Roman Catholic Church.
我们非常清楚艺术的重要性——而唯一有所发展的艺术却是电影。 We’re frightfully self-conscious about art—and the only art development is the cinema.
我们热爱和平——但我们实际为和平所做的却是造出了毒气。” We’re nuts on peace—and all we’re doing about it is to perfect poison gas.”
劳伦斯爵士挖苦地朝那个年轻人斜睨了一眼。 Sir Lawrence glanced sideways at a young man so bitter.
“迈克尔，出版社情况如何？” “And how’s publishing, Michael?”
“嗯，《铜币》正在热销，《二重唱》销量也很可观。 “Well, ‘Copper Coin’ is selling like hot cakes; and there’s quite a movement in ‘A Duet.’
像这样做个新广告如何：‘《二重唱》——作者：劳伦斯·蒙特爵士，准爵爷。 What about this for a new ad.: ‘A Duet, by Sir Lawrence Mont, Bart.
两位逝者之间有史以来最杰出的对话。’ The most distinguished Conversation ever held between the Dead.’
这样肯定能够吸引通灵人士的注意。 That ought to get the psychic.
威尔弗里德建议使用‘老夫子和迪齐——来自地狱的广播’。 Wilfrid suggested ‘G.O.M. and Dizzy—broadcasted from Hell.’
您更喜欢哪一个呢？” Which do you like best?”
然而此时，他们走到了一位警察身边，警察正举手拦住一辆运货马车，因此所有车辆和行人都停止不前了。 They had come, however, to a policeman holding up his hand against the nose of a van horse, so that everything marked time.
汽车的发动机轰轰作响，司机们面目呆滞，凝视着前方被封住的路；一个骑自行车的女孩茫然环顾四周，一手抓住那辆货车的尾部，一个青年侧坐在车上，两条腿直伸着对着她。 The engines of the cars whirred idly, their drivers’ faces set towards the space withheld from them; a girl on a bicycle looked vacantly about her, grasping the back of the van, where a youth sat sideways with his legs stretched out towards her.
劳伦斯爵士又朝年轻的德赛特瞥了一眼。 Sir Lawrence glanced again at young Desert.
一张消瘦、浅黑色的脸庞，外貌英俊，但似乎缺少点儿什么，显得有些美中不足；穿戴和举止还算得体，肯定在社交上游刃有余；不如他那个活泼的儿子那么有生气，但一样不安定，而且更多疑——不过他对事物的看法倒是相当深刻！ A thin, pale-dark face, good-looking, but a hitch in it, as if not properly timed; nothing outre in dress or manner, and yet socially at large; less vivacious than that lively rascal, his own son, but as anchorless, and more sceptical—might feel things pretty deeply, though!
警察放下了手臂。 The policeman lowered his arm.
“你参过战吧，德赛特先生？” “You were in the war, Mr. Desert?”
“是的。” “Oh, yes.”
“空军？” “Air service?”
“也在陆军干过。 “And line.
两个都干过。” Bit of both.”
“成为诗人很困难。” “Hard on a poet.”
“一点儿也不。 “Not at all.
你只有在随时有可能被炸死时，或者是住在帕特尼时，才写得出来诗。” Poetry’s only possible when you may be blown up at any moment, or when you live in Putney.”
劳伦斯爵士的眉毛扬了扬。 Sir Lawrence’s eyebrow rose.
“您请讲？” “Yes?”
“丁尼生、勃朗宁、华兹华斯、斯温伯恩——他们都能创造出诗歌，但他们却很少经历过你说的那两种生活。” “Tennyson, Browning, Wordsworth, Swinburne—they could turn it out; ils vivaient, mais si peu.”
“不是有第三种有利条件吗？” “Is there not a third condition favourable?”
“是什么呢，先生？” “And that, sir?”
“怎么说呢——和女人息息相关的大脑的兴奋吧？” “How shall I express it—a certain cerebral agitation in connection with women?”
德赛特的脸抽动了一下，似乎变得阴郁起来。 Desert’s face twitched, and seemed to darken.
迈克尔把钥匙插进他家前门的锁孔里。 Michael put his latchkey into the lock of his front door.
第二章 Chapter II
家 Home
坐落在威斯敏斯特南广场的这幢房子是“解放式”的。两年前，年轻的蒙特夫妇在西班牙度完蜜月，回到了这里。 The house in South Square, Westminster, to which the young Monts had come after their Spanish honeymoon two years before, might have been called ‘emancipated.’
设计它的那位建筑师梦想建造一幢完全古式的新房子和一幢全然一新的老房子。 It was the work of an architect whose dream was a new house perfectly old, and an old house perfectly new.
因此，这幢房子并不循规蹈矩，也不墨守结构上的陈规，但它却以惊人的速度收集了这个大都市的煤尘，连砖块也已经快赶上雷恩设计的典雅的建筑物砖块了。 It followed, therefore, no recognised style or tradition, and was devoid of structural prejudice; but it soaked up the smuts of the metropolis with such special rapidity that its stone already respectably resembled that of Wren.
房子的门窗都有圆润的穹顶。 Its windows and doors had gently rounded tops.
高斜的屋顶刷着雅致的暗红色，很有丹麦的风格，上面的两扇“玲珑小窗”从屋顶往外探，让人以为上面住着一些魁梧的仆人。 The high-sloping roof, of a fine sooty pink, was almost Danish, and two ‘ducky little windows’ looked out of it, giving an impression that very tall servants lived up there.
前门处很宽敞，装饰着金色和黑色的月桂树，门两侧各有几间房间。 There were rooms on each side of the front door, which was wide and set off by bay trees in black and gold bindings.
房子很深，宽大、典雅的楼梯从门厅尽头开始延伸，门厅很宽敞，足可以放下很多的帽子、大衣和卡片。 The house was thick through, and the staircase, of a broad chastity, began at the far end of a hall which had room for quite a number of hats and coats and cards.
房子里有四间盥洗室，却没有一间地下室。 There were four bathrooms; and not even a cellar underneath.
福赛特家族善于甄别房屋的天赋帮助他们买下了这座房子。 The Forsyte instinct for a house had co-operated in its acquisition.
索姆斯是在极为恰当的时候为女儿挑选了这幢还未装修的房子，当时通货膨胀的气泡刚被戳破，世界贸易的大气球正在漏气。 Soames had picked it up for his daughter, undecorated, at that psychological moment when the bubble of inflation was pricked, and the air escaping from the balloon of the world’s trade.
可是，弗勒早已直接跟建筑师联系了——这恰是索姆斯自己不太具备的能力——并且决定在装修她的房子时仅限于三种风格：中国式、西班牙式以及自己独特的风格。 Fleur, however, had established immediate contact with the architect—an element which Soames himself had never quite got over—and decided not to have more than three styles in her house: Chinese, Spanish, and her own.
前门左侧的房间和房子的跨度一样宽，是中国式的，镶嵌着象牙色的护墙板，铺着红棕色地板，装有中央暖气，还有雕花玻璃吊灯。 The room to the left of the front door, running the breadth of the house, was Chinese, with ivory panels, a copper floor, central heating, and cut glass lustres.
屋内挂着四幅画——都是中国国画——这是她父亲至今唯一没有尝试的画派。 It contained four pictures—all Chinese—the only school in which her father had not yet dabbled.
壁炉宽大开阔，底部镶有中国瓷砖，瓷砖上镶着中国狗的图案。 The fireplace, wide and open, had Chinese dogs with Chinese tiles for them to stand on.
丝绸以翠绿色的居多。 The silk was chiefly of jade green.
屋内有两个古色古香的黑色茶柜，它们是索姆斯从乔布森拍卖行花钱买来的——绝不是廉价品。 There were two wonderful old black tea-chests, picked up with Soames’ money at Jobson’s—not a bargain.
屋内没有钢琴，其一是因为钢琴带有西洋韵味，风格很不协调，其二是由于它占的空间太大。 There was no piano, partly because pianos were too uncompromisingly occidental, and partly because it would have taken up much room.
弗勒希望有空间来招待宾客，而不是收纳家具或者装饰品。 Fleur aimed at space-collecting people rather than furniture or bibelots.
可惜的是，从屋内两端窗户透进的光线不是中国的。 The light, admitted by windows at both ends, was unfortunately not Chinese.
有时她会站在房子中间，思量着——该如何“汇拢”她的那些客人呢；该如何使她的房间更显中国化而又不失舒适呢；该如何显得自己精通文学和政治呢；该如何接纳父亲给予自己的一切，同时还让父亲察觉不到他的兴趣已跟不上潮流呢；该如何同时抓住文坛新秀西布莉·斯旺和文学泰斗格登·明霍呢；威尔弗里德·德赛特是如何越来越迷恋她呢；她的衣着究竟应该是什么风格呢，还有迈克尔为何长着一副如此滑稽的耳朵呢。但有时她站在那里，什么也不想——只是有一点点心痛。 She would stand sometimes in the centre of this room, thinking—how to ‘bunch’ her guests, how to make her room more Chinese without making it uncomfortable; how to seem to know all about literature and politics; how to accept everything her father gave her, without making him aware that his taste had no sense of the future; how to keep hold of Sibley Swan, the new literary star, and to get hold of Gurdon Minho, the old; of how Wilfrid Desert was getting too fond of her; of what was really her style in dress; of why Michael had such funny ears; and sometimes she stood not thinking at all—just aching a little.
当那三人走进来时，弗勒正坐在一张红漆茶桌前，刚刚吃完精致的茶点。 When those three came in she was sitting before a red lacquer tea-table, finishing a very good tea.
她总是吩咐仆人把茶点早一些送过来，这样一来，她便可以独自一人悠然自得地享受“一顿美餐”，因为她还未满21岁，而这正是她记住青春岁月的大好时候。 She always had tea brought in rather early, so that she could have a good quiet preliminary ‘tuck-in’ all by herself, because she was not quite twenty-one, and this was her hour for remembering her youth.
小叮铃正踮着后脚站在她身旁，它那黄褐色的前爪搁在一把中国式的脚凳上，那扁平的黑褐色口鼻朝上仰着，望着他眼中的“果子”。 By her side Ting-a-ling was standing on his hind feet, his tawny forepaws on a Chinese footstool, his snubbed black and tawny muzzle turned up towards the fruits of his philosophy.
“好了，叮铃。 “That’ll do, Ting.
没了，宝贝！ No more, ducky!
一点儿也没有了！” NO MORE!”
小叮铃的表情仿佛回答道： The expression of Ting-a-ling answered:
“哦，那你也别吃了！ ‘Well, then, stop, too!
别再折磨我了！” Don’t subject me to torture!’
它一岁零三个月，是11个月前，迈克尔在弗勒20岁生日那天，从邦德大街的一家商店橱窗里买来的。 A year and three months old, he had been bought by Michael out of a Bond Street shop window on Fleur’s twentieth birthday, eleven months ago.
两年的婚姻生活，没有使她深栗色的短发变长，却让她那灵巧的嘴唇多了一份坚决神情，让那双白眼皮、黑睫毛、淡褐色的眼睛更加妩媚，给她的仪态平添了几分端庄和婀娜。她的胸围和臀部愈加丰满，腰身和小腿愈加纤细；她的面庞愈加清瘦，少了几分血色；她嗓音没有以前甜美了，却多了一丝柔情。 Two years of married life had not lengthened her short dark chestnut hair; had added a little more decision to her quick lips, a little more allurement to her white-lidded, dark-lashed hazel eyes, a little more poise and swing to her carriage, a little more chest and hip measurement; had taken a little from waist and calf measurement, a little colour from cheeks a little less round, and a little sweetness from a voice a little more caressing.
她从茶盘后面站起来，一语不发地伸出她那白皙而丰润的手臂。 She stood up behind the tray, holding out her white round arm without a word.
她回避了那些不必要的问候和道别。 She avoided unnecessary greetings or farewells.
她本该经常说这些话的，但使个眼色、握一下手、微微点头，似乎更能达到目的。 She would have had to say them so often, and their purpose was better served by look, pressure, and slight inclination of head to one side.
她用那只刚被紧握过的手划了个圆圈，说道： With circular movement of her squeezed hand, she said:
“坐下来吧。 “Draw up.
先生，要奶油吗？ Cream, sir?
威尔弗里德，要糖吗？ Sugar, Wilfrid?
叮铃吃的够多的了——别再喂它了！ Ting has had too much—don’t feed him!
迈克尔，递一下。 Hand things, Michael.
‘轻蔑’俱乐部开会的情况我已经全听说了。 I’ve heard all about the meeting at ‘Snooks.’
迈克尔，你不要再去为工党拉选票了——那太愚蠢了。 You’re not going to canvass for Labour, Michael—canvassing’s so silly.
如果有人来找我拉票，我会毫不犹豫地给另一方投票。” If any one canvassed me, I should vote the other way at once.”
“是呀，亲爱的。不过你可不是普通的选民啊。” “Yes, darling; but you’re not the average elector.”
弗勒看看他。 Fleur looked at him.
话里有话！ Very sweetly put!
弗勒留意到威尔弗里德咬着双唇，而劳伦斯爵士也注意到了威尔弗里德的举动。她知道她露出了一截穿着丝袜的腿，还有她桌上奶油色和黑色相间的茶杯。她对这一切都心中有数。 Conscious of Wilfrid biting his lips, of Sir Lawrence taking that in, of the amount of silk leg she was showing, of her black and cream teacups, she adjusted these matters.
她那白眼皮一翻，德赛特立刻不咬嘴唇了；她那穿丝袜的腿一动，劳伦斯爵士立刻不再看威尔弗里德了。 A flutter of her white lids—Desert ceased to bite his lips; a movement of her silk legs—Sir Lawrence ceased to look at him.
她伸手放下茶杯，说道： Holding out her cups, she said:
“我想我还不够时髦吧？” “I suppose I’m not modern enough?”
德赛特用一把光亮的小勺在他那只绘着喜鹊的茶杯里搅动着，头也不抬地说： Desert, moving a bright little spoon round in his magpie cup, said without looking up:
“你比现代人更时髦，比时髦的人更复古。” “As much more modern than the moderns, as you are more ancient.”
“注意诗律！”迈克尔说。 “‘Ware poetry!” said Michael.
待迈克尔带他父亲去参观奥布里·格林新创作的漫画时，她说： But when he had taken his father to see the new cartoons by Aubrey Greene, she said:
“威尔弗里德，你说这话是什么意思。” “Kindly tell me what you meant, Wilfrid.”
德赛特的声音似乎是强挤出来的。 Desert’s voice seemed to leap from restraint.
“这话怎么了？ “What does it matter?
我不想为此耽误时间。” I don’t want to waste time with that.”
“可是我想知道。 “But I want to know.
这话听上去像是在讽刺。” It sounded like a sneer.”
“讽刺？ “A sneer?
我说的？ From me?
弗勒！” Fleur!”
“那告诉我到底是什么意思。” “Then tell me.”
“我的意思是，你具有了他们那种不安分以及务实的定要成功的精神，但弗勒，你还具有他们所没有的东西——使人迷糊的能力。 “I meant that you have all their restlessness and practical get-thereness; but you have what they haven’t, Fleur—power to turn one’s head.
我就是被你弄迷糊的。 And mine is turned.
这点你心里明白。” You know it.”
“要是迈克尔听见这话该有何感想——出自你，他的男傧相之口？” “How would Michael like that—from YOU, his best man?”
德赛特快速走到窗边。 Desert moved quickly to the windows.
弗勒把小叮铃抱到腿上。 Fleur took Ting-a-ling on her lap.
类似的话以前也有人对她说过，但出自威尔弗里德之口，事情就变得严重了。 Such things had been said to her before; but from Wilfrid it was serious.
但想到她已经占有了他的心，自然值得高兴！ Nice to think she had his heart, of course!
只是，她究竟要把这颗心放在哪里呢，一个除她之外别人都不知道的地方？ Only, where on earth could she put it, where it wouldn’t be seen except by her?
他可是个让人猜不透的人——干些令人费解的古怪事。 He was incalculable—did strange things!
她有些害怕——不是怕他，而是害怕他那怪脾气。 She was a little afraid—not of him, but of that quality in him.
他走回到壁炉前，说： He came back to the hearth, and said:
“很丑恶，是不是？ “Ugly, isn’t it?
弗勒，把那只该死的狗放下去。我看不见你的脸了。 Put that dam’ dog down, Fleur; I can’t see your face.
你要是真心喜欢迈克尔的话——我发誓我不会这样做。但你并不喜欢他，你心里明白。” If you were really fond of Michael—I swear I wouldn’t; but you’re not, you know.”
弗勒冷冷地说： Fleur said coldly:
“你知道得太少了。我是喜欢迈克尔的。” “You know very little; I AM fond of Michael.”
德赛特急促地笑笑。 Desert gave his little jerky laugh.
“不错，但算不上爱。” “Oh yes; not the sort that counts.”
弗勒抬起头来。 Fleur looked up.
“能给人安全感，就算得上了。” “It counts quite enough to make one safe.”
“这是一朵我采不到的花。” “A flower that I can’t pick.”
弗勒点点头。 Fleur nodded.
“弗勒，你肯定吗？ “Quite sure, Fleur?
非常、非常肯定吗？” Quite, quite sure?”
弗勒凝视着他。她的眼神变得柔和了一些，她闭上那白得过分的眼皮，点了点头。 Fleur stared; her eyes softened a little, her eyelids, so excessively white, drooped over them; she nodded.
德赛特慢吞吞地说： Desert said slowly:
“一旦我相信你说的话，我就去东方。” “The moment I believe that, I shall go East.”
“东方？” “East?”
“不像上西天那样乏味，但结果是一样的——一去就再也不回来了。” “Not so stale as going West, but much the same—you don’t come back.”
弗勒心想：“东方？ Fleur thought: ‘The East?
我倒很想去东方看看！ I should love to know the East!
遗憾的是，这无法办到。 Pity one can’t manage that, too.
遗憾啊！” Pity!’
“亲爱的，你不可能把我关在你的动物园里。 “You won’t keep me in your Zoo, my dear.
我也不会在此逗留，并以残羹冷炙为生。 I shan’t hang around and feed on crumbs.
你知道我是什么感觉吗——那就意味着决裂。” You know what I feel—it means a smash of some sort.”
“这不是我的过错，是吧？” “It hasn’t been my fault, has it?”
“是你的错，是你把我招揽来的，就像你招揽着每个来到你身边的人一样。” “Yes; you’ve collected me, as you collect everybody that comes near you.”
“我不明白你的意思。” “I don’t know what you mean.”
德赛特弯腰，把她的手慢慢拉近自己的唇边。 Desert bent down, and dragged her hand to his lips.
“别生我的气，我非常难过。” “Don’t be riled with me; I’m too unhappy.”
弗勒让自己的手贴着他那炽热的嘴唇。 Fleur let her hand stay against his hot lips.
“对不起，威尔弗里德。” “Sorry, Wilfrid.”
“好吧，亲爱的。 “All right, dear.
我走了。” I’ll go.”
“那你明天来吃饭吗？” “But you’re coming to dinner tomorrow?”
德赛特激动地说： Desert said violently:
“明天？ “TO-MORROW?
上帝啊——绝不来！ Good God—no!
在你眼里我算什么？” What d’you think I’m made of?”
他甩开她的手。 He flung her hand away.
“我不喜欢见你如此粗暴，威尔弗里德。” “I don’t like violence, Wilfrid.”
“好吧，再见。我还是走吧。” “Well, good-bye; I’d better go.”
“你最好再也别来了”这句话已到嘴边，但她还是没说出口。 The words “And you’d better not come again” trembled up to her lips, but were not spoken.
如果和威尔弗里德分手——那么她的生活将失去一丝温暖。 Part from Wilfrid—life would lose a little warmth!
她挥挥手。 She waved her hand.
他走了。 He was gone.
她听到大门关上的声音。 She heard the door closing.
可怜的威尔弗里德！——一想到有一团可以暖手的火焰就令人兴奋！ Poor Wilfrid!—nice to think of a flame at which to warm her hands!
兴奋，却更令人胆战心惊！ Nice but rather dreadful!
突然，她放下小叮铃，站起来，在房间里踱起步来。 And suddenly, dropping Ting-a-ling, she got up and began to walk about the room.
明天！ To-morrow!
她结婚两周年纪念日！ Second anniversary of her wedding-day!
一想到还未实现的事，她心中不免难过。 Still an ache when she thought of what it had not been.
可是没什么时间再去想了——况且她也不愿意再去想了。 But there was little time to think—and she made less.
想了又有什么好处呢？ What good in thinking?
唯一的一种生活，充斥着人、要做的和拥有的事、想要得到的东西——这种生活唯一缺少的——一件东西，而且——对，人们即使得到它，也不会永远拥有它！ Only one life, full of people, of things to do and have, of things wanted—a life only void of—one thing, and that—well, if people had it, they never had it long!
两滴泪珠凝聚在她的眼睑上，干了，没有掉下来。 On her lids two tears, which had gathered, dried without falling.
多愁善感！ Sentimentalism!
不！ No!
这是世界上最不应该有的东西——是不可饶恕的罪过！ The last thing in the world—the unforgivable offence!
明天她该把谁安排坐在谁的身旁呢？ Whom should she put next whom tomorrow?
最重要的是，她到底找谁来填补威尔弗里德的位置呢？要是他不来的话——这个傻瓜！ And whom should she get in place of Wilfrid, if Wilfrid wouldn’t come—silly boy!
白天——晚上——有什么区别呢？ One day—one night—what difference?
谁坐在她的右边，谁又该坐在她的左边呢？ Who should sit on her right, and who on her left?
奥布里·格林和西布莉·斯旺，谁更有名一些呢？ Was Aubrey Greene more distinguished, or Sibley Swan?
他们两个人都像沃尔特·内津一样出名，还是都像查尔斯·厄普夏一样有名呢？ Were they either as distinguished as Walter Nazing or Charles Upshire?
晚宴的12人中，除了迈克尔和艾莉森·查韦尔之外，其他都是文学界和艺术界的。 Dinner of twelve, exclusively literary and artistic, except for Michael and Alison Charwell.
啊！ Ah!
艾莉森能帮她请到格登·明霍吗？——一位老派作家，一杯令人兴奋的陈年佳酿。 Could Alison get her Gurdon Minho—just one writer of the old school, one glass of old wine to mellow effervescence?
他没有在丹比&温特出版社出过书，但还是很给艾莉森面子的。 He didn’t publish with Danby and Winter; but he fed out of Alison’s hand.
她迅速走到一个陈旧的茶柜旁，打开它。 She went quickly to one of the old tea chests, and opened it.
里面是一部电话。 Inside was a telephone.
“我能和艾莉森夫人通话吗——是迈克尔·蒙特夫人……对……是你吗，艾莉森？ “Can I speak to Lady Alison—Mrs. Michael Mont... Yes... That you, Alison?...
我是弗勒啊。 Fleur speaking.
威尔弗里德明晚不来了……你能邀请格登·明霍来吗？ Wilfrid has fallen through tomorrow night... Is there any chance of your bringing Gurdon Minho?
我当然不认识他了，但他也许会感兴趣的。 I don’t know him, of course; but he might be interested.
那你试试？…… You’ll try?...
那可真让人兴奋。 That’ll be ever so delightful.
‘轻蔑’俱乐部的会议是不是很热闹？ Isn’t the ‘Snooks’ Club meeting rather exciting?
准爵爷说他们现在已经分裂了，一定要拼个你死我活……说关于明霍先生的事吧。 Bart says they’ll eat each other now they’ve split... About Mr. Minho.
今晚你能给我确切消息吗？ Could you let me know to-night?
谢谢——真是万分感激！…… Thanks—thanks awfully!...
再见！” Goodbye!”
假如明霍先生邀请不到，那么该请谁好呢？ Failing Minho, whom?
她的脑子里反复思考着通讯录中的人名。 Her mind hovered over the names in her address book.
剩下的时间不多了，必须找一个不拘礼节的人。除了艾莉森以外，迈克尔的亲戚中还没有一个人能应付西布莉·斯旺或内丝塔·戈斯，并应对他们那些刻薄话；至于福赛特家族——就更不必多说了，他们具有独特的晦涩的幽默（他们中的一些人），但他们绝不是真正时髦的人。 At so late a minute it must be some one who didn’t stand on ceremony; but except Alison, none of Michael’s relations would be safe from Sibley Swan or Nesta Gorse, and their subversive shafts; as to the Forsytes—out of the question; they had their own sub-acid humour (some of them), but they were not modern, not really modern.
此外，她对他们很看不上眼——毕竟他们已经过时了，他们属于戏剧时代，根本不懂得没有开始或结局的人生。 Besides, she saw as little of them as she could—they dated, belonged to the dramatic period, had no sense of life without beginning or end.
不！ No!
如果格登·明霍不肯来，那就得邀请一位音乐家，而他们的作品都像外科手术一样晦涩难懂。或许还是邀请一位精神分析学家更好一些。 If Gurdon Minho was a frost, it would have to be a musician, whose works were hieroglyphical with a dash of surgery; or, better, perhaps, a psycho-analyst.
她用手指一页页翻着，直到那两栏，她停了下来。 Her fingers turned the pages till she came to those two categories.
雨果·苏斯迪斯？ Hugo Solstis?
值得考虑，但是如果他要表演近期的作品，该怎么办？ A possibility; but suppose he wanted to play them something recent?
家里只有迈克尔的那架竖式大钢琴，这就意味着大家只能到他书房去了。 There was only Michael’s upright Grand, and that would mean going to his study.
还是杰拉尔德·汉克斯更适合一些——他会和内丝塔·戈斯一起讨论梦，而且，他们就是那样做了，也没有什么大不了的。 Better Gerald Hanks—he and Nesta Gorse would get off together on dreams; still, if they did, there would be no actual loss of life.
对，要是不能邀请格登·明霍，那就邀请杰拉尔德·汉克斯，他应该有空——把他的座位安排在艾莉森和内丝塔两人之间。 Yes, failing Gurdon Minho, Gerald Hanks; he would be free—and put him between Alison and Nesta.
她合上通讯录，走回到那把翠绿色的长靠椅旁边，坐在那里盯着小叮铃。 She closed the book, and, going back to her jade-green settee, sat gazing at Ting-a-ling.
小狗突出的圆眼睛也盯着她，眼睛明亮、乌黑，是她非常熟悉的眼神。 The little dog’s prominent round eyes gazed back; bright, black, very old.
弗勒心想：“我不愿意让威尔弗里德就这么离开了。” Fleur thought: ‘I DON’T want Wilfrid to drop off.’
在所有来来往往的人中，无论是在此处、他处，或是任何其他地方，她从来没有喜欢上一个人。 Among all the crowd who came and went, here, there and everywhere, she cared for nobody.
当然，应该与他们保持联系，与所有的事情保持联系！ Keep up with them, keep up with everything, of course!
这一切都非常有趣，非常有必要！ It was all frightfully amusing, frightfully necessary!
只是——只是——又怎么样呢？ Only—only—what?
有说话声！ Voices!
迈克尔和准爵爷回来了。 Michael and Bart coming back.
准爵爷已经注意到威尔弗里德的神情了。 Bart had noticed Wilfrid.
他可是一位洞悉一切的老准爵爷。 He WAS a noticing old Bart.
每当他在身旁，她就感到不大自在——他活泼但又很偏执，在他身上有某种很难改变的遗传的东西。他有点儿像小叮铃——善于识别人，还总是说她不仅情绪不稳定，还不谙世事。 She was never very comfortable when he was about—lively and twisting, but with something settled and ancestral in him; a little like Ting-a-ling—something judgmatic, ever telling her that she was fluttering and new.
他的性格已经固定不变，只能在固有的习惯约束下行动，但是他会对事情刨根问底。 He was anchored, could only move to the length of his old-fashioned cord, but he could drop on to things disconcertingly.
但她仍感觉，他是很欣赏她的——对！欣赏。 Still, he admired her, she felt—oh! yes.
哦！ Well!
他对那些漫画有什么看法呢？ What had he thought of the cartoons?
迈克尔究竟应该不应该把它们出版呢，是否该配上文字呢？ Ought Michael to publish them, and with letterpress or without?
对于这幅叫做“静物画”的立体漫画——它描绘的是政府，他是不是觉得滑稽好笑呢？——尤其是那位影射首相的“老兄”。 Didn’t he think that the cubic called ‘Still Life’—of the Government, too frightfully funny—especially the ‘old bean’ representing the Prime?
她得到的答案含糊其辞，劳伦斯爵士正在给她讲他父亲收集选举漫画的事情。 For answer she was conscious of a twisting, rapid noise; Sir Lawrence was telling her of his father’s collection of electioneering cartoons.
她从内心希望准爵爷不要向她诉说他父亲的往事；他曾经是那样高贵，但肯定也很无趣：骑马去会客，裤脚掖在靴筒里。 She did wish Bart would not tell her about his father; he had been so distinguished, and he must have been so dull, paying all his calls on horseback, with trousers strapped under his boots.
他、查尔斯·卡列布勋爵和福法侯爵可以算得上是这类“访客”中最后的三位了。 He and Lord Charles Cariboo and the Marquis of Forfar had been the last three ‘callers’ of that sort.
假如他们没有这些特征，也许早已被人遗忘了。 If only they hadn’t, they’d have been clean forgot.
她还要试穿一件衣服，此外还有14件事要处理，而雨果的音乐会在八点一刻就要开始了！ She had that dress to try, and fourteen things to see to, and Hugo’s concert began at eight-fifteen!
为什么上一代人总有那么多空闲时间呢？ Why did people of the last generation always have so much time?
就在这时，她突然往下望了望。 And, suddenly, she looked down.
小叮铃正在舔着红棕色的地板。 Ting-a-ling was licking the copper floor.
她一把抱起它：“亲爱的，脏啊，别再舔了！” She took him up: “Not that, darling; nasty!”
啊！危急解除了！ Ah! the spell was broken!
准爵爷要走了，直到最后，他还在回首往事。 Bart was going, reminiscent to the last.
她在楼梯下面等着，直到迈克尔把他送出门，把门关上后，她才又飞奔回去。 She waited at the foot of the stairs till Michael shut the door on him, then flew.
回到自己的屋里，她打开了所有的灯。 Reaching her room, she turned on all the lights.
这里是她独有的风格——有一张怎么看都不像床的床，还有很多面镜子。 Here was her own style—a bed which did not look like one, and many mirrors.
小叮铃的睡椅占据房间一角，在那里它能看见镜子反映出的三个自己。 The couch of Ting-a-ling occupied a corner, whence he could see himself in three.
她把它放下来，说：“从现在开始，安静！” She put him down, and said: “Keep quiet, now!”
对于屋里的其他几条狗，它早已丧失兴趣了；这些狗虽然跟小叮铃是同种，皮毛也一样，但它们全然没有嗅觉，也不会用舌头舔东西——拿它们没辙，他们就会模仿，极其迟钝。 His attitude to the other dogs in the room had long become indifferent; though of his own breed and precisely his colouring, they had no smell and no licking power in their tongues—nothing to be done with them, imitative creatures, incredibly unresponsive.
弗勒脱下身上的衣服，用下巴夹着那件新衣服。 Stripping off her dress, Fleur held the new frock under her chin.
“我可以吻你吗？”一个声音说道，镜中映出了她身后站着的迈克尔。 “May I kiss you?” said a voice, and there was Michael’s image behind her own reflection in the glass.
“亲爱的，没时间啦！ “My dear boy, there isn’t time!
帮我穿上它吧。” Help me with this.”
她赶紧把衣服往头上一套， She slipped the frock over her head.
“把上面的三个挂钩扣上。 “Do those three top hooks.
你觉得这衣服怎样？ How do you like it?
啊！还有——迈克尔！ Oh! and—Michael!
格登·明霍明天可能要来吃饭——而威尔弗里德不来了。 Gurdon Minho may be coming to dinner tomorrow—Wilfrid can’t.
你阅读过他的作品吗？ Have you read his things?
坐下给我讲讲他的作品吧。 Sit down and tell me something about them.
他的作品都是小说是吗？ All novels, aren’t they?
是哪一类的呢？” What sort?”
“嗯，他总是有很多素材。 “Well, he’s always had something to say.
而且他很会描写猫。 And his cats are good.
当然，他还有些浪漫。” He’s a bit romantic, of course.”
“啊！ “Oh!
我是不是说错话了？” Have I made a gaff?”
“一点儿也没说错，而且还一针见血。 “Not a bit; jolly good shot.
我们这群人的缺点是说起话来冠冕堂皇，但却言之无物。 The vice of our lot is, they say it pretty well, but they’ve nothing to say.
这样的人终究不会太长久。” They won’t last.”
“但那反倒是他们能保持长久的方法。 “But that’s just why they will last.
他们不会落伍的。” They won’t date.”
“真的吗？ “Won’t they?
我的天哪！” My gum!”
“威尔弗里德会保持长久的。” “Wilfrid will last.”
“啊！ “Ah!
威尔弗里德爱憎分明，有怜悯之心，也有欲望，至少他有时是这样的。当他拥有这些情感时，他的作品就会很精彩。 Wilfrid has emotions, hates, pities, wants; at least, sometimes; when he has, his stuff is jolly good.
否则，就是无病呻吟，无关痛痒——像其他人一样。” Otherwise, he just makes a song about nothing—like the rest.”
弗勒把她的内衣上端掖进去。 Fleur tucked in the top of her undergarment.
“但是，迈克尔，如果是这样，我们——我是请错人了。” “But, Michael, if that’s so, we—I’ve got the wrong lot.”
迈克尔咧嘴笑笑。 Michael grinned.
“亲爱的宝贝！ “My dear child!
一时之选总是对的，但你要时刻关注，及时更新。” The lot of the hour is always right; only you’ve got to watch it, and change it quick enough.”
“那你的意思是说西布莉不会持久存在？” “But d’you mean to say that Sibley isn’t going to live?”
“茜布？ “Sib?
上帝，绝不会的！” Lord, no!”
“但他很自信，他相信除他以外所有人都已死去，或正在死去。 “But he’s so perfectly sure that almost everybody else is dead or dying.
但他的确是批判的高手！” Surely he has critical genius!”
“如果我的判断力不如茜布，那我明天就离开出版社。” “If I hadn’t more judgment than Sib, I’d go out of publishing tomorrow.”
“你——比西布莉·斯旺还精明？” “You—more than Sibley Swan?”
“当然，我的判断力肯定比茜布强。 “Of course, I’ve more judgment than Sib.
咳！ Why!
茜布的判断力只是他自己书里的见解——陈词滥调，对于别人的观点一向不耐烦。 Sib’s judgment is just his opinion of Sib—common or garden impatience of any one else.
他甚至都不读别人的作品。 He doesn’t even read them.
他只是大略读一下每位作家的作品节选，然后说：‘啊！那家伙！ He’ll read one specimen of every author and say: ‘Oh! that fellow!
他是愚笨的，或者是说教的、多愁善感的、过时的、胡说八道的’——我已经听他这样说过几十遍了。 He’s dull, or he’s moral, or he’s sentimental, or he dates, or he drivels’—I’ve heard him dozens of times.
如果那些作家还在世，他就会这样说。 That’s if they’re alive.
当然，如果他们已经去世，情况就不同了。 Of course, if they’re dead, it’s different.
他总是高举和吹捧死者，他就是这样出的名。 He’s always digging up and canonising the dead; that’s how he’s got his name.
在文学界，总是有像茜布这样的人。 There’s always a Sib in literature.
总想凭借对自己的评估来获取公众信任，他就是个典型的例子。 He’s a standing example of how people can get taken at their own valuation.
但提到持久——他自然是不会的，他自始至终就没有创造才能，哪怕是歪打正着。” But as to lasting—of course he won’t; he’s never creative, even by mistake.”
弗勒已经糊涂了。 Fleur had lost the thread.
是的！ Yes!
这席话对她大有益处！ It suited her—quite a nice line!
记下来吧！ Off with it!
她必须在穿好衣服前记下这三条。 Must write those three notes before she dressed.
迈克尔继续说着。 Michael had begun again.
“记着我的忠告，弗勒。 “Take my tip, Fleur.
真正的大人物是不会滔滔不绝的——也不会拉帮结伙的——他们只是独自一人，逆水行舟。 The really big people don’t talk—and don’t bunch—they paddle their own canoes in what seem backwaters.
但那逆流恰好成为了主流。 But it’s the backwaters that make the main stream.
天啊，真是警世良言，但其实也是自相矛盾；那到底自相矛盾的话就是警世良言呢，还是警世良言就会自相矛盾呢？” By Jove, that’s a mot, or is it a bull; and are bulls mots or mots bulls?”
“迈克尔，假如你是我，你会通知弗雷德里克·威尔默下周午餐时他会遇见休伯特·马斯兰德吗？ “Michael, if you were me, would you tell Frederic Wilmer that he’ll be meeting Hubert Marsland at lunch next week?
听完这话，他是来还是不来呢？” Would it bring him or would it put him off?”
“马斯兰德是个老好人，威尔默是个十足的傻瓜——我也不清楚。” “Marsland’s rather an old duck, Wilmer’s rather an old goose—I don’t know.”
“啊！严肃点儿，迈克尔——我准备请客的事情，你从来没帮过我——从来都没有！ “Oh! do be serious, Michael—you never give me any help in arranging—No!
请别弄疼我的肩膀。” Don’t maul my shoulders please.”
“哦，亲爱的，我确实不清楚啊。 “Well, darling, I DON’T know.
对于这些事情，我可不像你那么有天赋。 I’ve no genius for such things, like you.
马斯兰德只画风车、悬崖峭壁和静物——我甚至怀疑他是否听说过未来的事情。 Marsland paints windmills, cliffs and things—I doubt if he’s heard of the future.
他简直就和马修·马里斯一样不入流。 He’s almost a Mathew Mans for keeping out of the swim.
如果你以为他愿意见到一位旋转派画家——” If you think he’d like to meet a Vertiginist—”
“我并不是问你他是否愿意遇见威尔默，我想问的是威尔默是否愿意遇见他。” “I didn’t ask you if he’d like to meet Wilmer; I asked you if Wilmer would like to meet him.”
“威尔默只会说：‘我喜欢娇小的蒙特夫人，她给我们准备美食’——你的确如此，宝贝。 “Wilmer will just say: ‘I like little Mrs. Mont, she gives deuced good grub’—and so you do, ducky.
你应该清楚旋转派画家是需要营养的，否则他的脑子会生锈。” A Vertiginist wants nourishing, you know, or it wouldn’t go to his head.”
弗勒又开始奋笔疾书，字已经很潦草了。 Fleur’s pen resumed its swift strokes, already becoming slightly illegible.
她咕哝着： She murmured:
“我想威尔弗里德会帮我的——你不必在那里；一——二——三。 “I think Wilfrid would help—you won’t be there; one—two—three.
女嘉宾是谁呢？” What women?”
“对画家而言——喜欢既漂亮又丰满的女子，而不喜欢那些有智慧的。” “For painters—pretty and plump; no intellect.”
弗勒恼怒地说着： Fleur said crossly:
“我可找不到丰满的女子，现在这种人早就绝种了。” “I can’t get them plump; they don’t go about now.”
说着，她又继续写着， And her pen flowed on:
“亲爱的威尔弗里德——周三——午餐；威尔默，休伯特·马斯兰德，还有两位女士。 “DEAR WILFRID,—Wednesday—lunch; Wilmer, Hubert Marsland, two other women.
真切恳求你助我渡过难关。 Do help me live it down.
你永远的， “Yours ever,
弗勒。” “FLEUR.”
“迈克尔，你的下巴像一把靴刷子。” “Michael, your chin is like a bootbrush.”
“不好意思，亲爱的，你的肩膀不该这么光滑。 “Sorry, old thing; your shoulders shouldn’t be so smooth.
在我们来时的路上，准爵爷给了威尔弗里德一些提示。” Bart gave Wilfrid a tip as we were coming along.”
弗勒停下笔来。 Fleur stopped writing.
“哦！” “Oh!”
“爵爷提示他，对于诗人来说，恋爱可是施展才华的绝好机会。” “Reminded him that the state of love was a good stunt for poets.”
“都说了些什么呢？” “A propos of what?”
“威尔弗里德一直在抱怨现在他创作不出来作品。” “Wilfrid was complaining that he couldn’t turn it out now.”
“胡说！ “Nonsense!
他最新的作品正是他最好的作品。” His last things are his best.”
“嗯，我也有同感。 “Well, that’s what I think.
也许他早就实践过那个提示了。 Perhaps he’s forestalled the tip.
他有没有实践过，你知道吗？” Has he, d’you know?”
弗勒转过头，望着身后的那张脸。 Fleur turned her eyes towards the face behind her shoulder.
还是那张脸——坦率真诚、不负责任，有点儿像尊农牧神像，有着尖尖的耳朵、灵巧的嘴唇和鼻孔。 No, it had its native look—frank, irresponsible, slightly faun-like, with its pointed ears, quick lips, and nostrils.
她缓缓地说： She said slowly:
“如果连你都不知道，那更没有人知道了。” “If YOU don’t know, nobody does.”
一阵鼻息声打断了迈克尔的回答。 A snuffle interrupted Michael’s answer.
是小叮铃——它身子长、个头矮，头和尾巴稍微高一些——正站在他们两个人中间，黑乎乎的脸朝上仰着。 Ting-a-ling, long, low, slightly higher at both ends, was standing between them, with black muzzle upturned.
它好像在说：“我可是纯种，就是腿短——这又有什么关系呢？” ‘My pedigree is long,’ he seemed to say; ‘but my legs are short—what about it?’
第三章 Chapter III
音乐会 Musical
依照一个伟大的并具有指导性的原则，弗勒和迈克尔·蒙特参加了雨果·苏斯迪斯的音乐会。出席这项活动不是为了娱乐，而是因为他们认识雨果。 According to a great and guiding principle, Fleur and Michael Mont attended the Hugo Solstis concert, not because they anticipated pleasure, but because they knew Hugo.
而且，他们认为，苏斯迪斯——这个混有俄罗斯与荷兰血统的英国人——是复兴英国音乐的中坚力量之一。他使英国音乐在节奏和旋律上都获得了充分的自由，又赋予了它文学和数学的魅力。 They felt, besides, that Solstis, an Englishman of Russo-Dutch extraction, was one of those who were restoring English music, giving to it a wide and spacious freedom from melody and rhythm, while investing it with literary and mathematical charms.
无论是谁参加这一流派中任何一位音乐家的音乐会，在他离开时，总要发出“有趣”的称赞。 And one never could go to a concert given by any of this school without using the word ‘interesting’ as one was coming away.
听这种复兴的英国音乐，也不可能打瞌睡。 To sleep to this restored English music, too, was impossible.
虽说弗勒是个嗜睡的人，在这种场合却从未试着瞌睡过。 Fleur, a sound sleeper, had never even tried.
迈克尔倒是打过一次瞌睡，事后却抱怨说，这就像在列日火车站打了个盹。 Michael had, and complained afterwards that it had been like a nap in Liege railway station.
这次，他们坐在特等包厢前排靠近通道的位子，这个位子似乎就是弗勒的专座。 On this occasion they occupied those gangway seats in the front row of the dress circle of which Fleur had a sort of natural monopoly.
坐在那里，雨果和其他人都能看见她参加了这次英国复兴运动。 There Hugo and the rest could see her taking her place in the English restoration movement.
而且，在那里也方便她溜到走廊里，和那些留着络腮胡的鉴赏家们互道一声“有趣”；或拿出表姐伊莫金·卡迪根送的结婚礼物——一个小金盒，抽出一支香烟，吸两口休息休息。 It was easy, too, to escape into the corridor and exchange the word ‘interesting’ with side-whiskered cognoscenti; or, slipping out a cigarette from the little gold case, wedding present of Cousin Imogen Cardigan, get a whiff or two’s repose.
坦率地说，弗勒的节奏感与生俱来，当演奏到那些冗长而“有趣”的乐章时，她仿佛对作曲家所表现的如坐针毡、坐立不安的情形感同身受，这不免让她十分难受。 To speak quite honestly, Fleur had a natural sense of rhythm which caused her discomfort during those long and ‘interesting’ passages which evidenced, as it were, the composer’s rise and fall from his bed of thorns.
她默默喜欢一支曲调，为了不失去苏斯迪斯、巴夫、博迪格尔、麦克刘易斯、克罗雷和其他英国复兴派作曲家，她永远不会承认这一点。有时，这使她那具有自虐倾向的性格压抑到了极点。 She secretly loved a tune, and the impossibility of ever confessing this without losing hold of Solstis, Baff, Birdigal, MacLewis, Clorane, and other English restoration composers, sometimes taxed to its limit a nature which had its Spartan side.
即使对迈克尔，她也不会承认。迈克尔生来不尊重别人，而战场上的生活和出版家的身份使他的这种态度更加严重，因此，每当他咕噜着：“上帝！快点儿过去吧！”或者“天啊！他这下可弄错了！”时，她就感到格外难受，尤其是她知道迈克尔实际比她更能忍耐，更有文学气质，而对舞蹈则没有她那么入迷。 Even to Michael she would not ‘confess’; and it was additionally trying when, with his native disrespect of persons, accentuated by life in the trenches and a publisher’s office, he would mutter: “Gad!Get on with it!” or: “Cripes!Ain’t he took bad!” especially as she knew that Michael was really putting up with it better than herself, having a more literary disposition, and a less dancing itch in his toes.
他们专程来听苏斯迪斯新乐曲的第一乐章——《皮埃蒙特斯克幻想曲》，该乐章以几个悠长的和弦开始。 The first movement of the new Solstis composition—‘Phantasmagoria Piemontesque’—to which they had especially come to listen, began with some drawn-out chords.
她耳边传来迈克尔的声音：“哇哦，三件家具同时在一块镶木地板上移动！” “What oh!” said Michael’s voice in her ear: “Three pieces of furniture moved simultaneously on a parquet floor!”
弗勒不禁笑了，她的婚姻并非无法忍受，她的笑容把这个秘密完全暴露了。 In Fleur’s involuntary smile was the whole secret of why her marriage had not been intolerable.
迈克尔毕竟很可爱！ After all, Michael was a dear!
他既专一又活泼，既幽默又忠诚——这一切都触动甚至是感动了她，虽然在嫁给他之前她就心有所属了。 Devotion and mercury—jesting and loyalty—combined, they piqued and touched even a heart given away before it was bestowed on him.
没有“触动”的“感动”惹人厌恶，而没有“感动”的“触动”又惹人恼怒。 ‘Touch’ without ‘pique’ would have bored; ‘pique’ without ‘touch’ would have irritated.
此刻，他处于极其有利的地位！ At this moment he was at peculiar advantage!
为了表示对雨果的尊重，他双手抓牢膝盖，双耳竖起，目光呆滞，装模作样地听着序曲。他做出的这副样子引起了弗勒的钦佩。 Holding on to his knees, with his ears standing up, eyes glassy from loyalty to Hugo, and tongue in cheek, he was listening to that opening in a way which evoked Fleur’s admiration.
这段乐曲会很“有趣”——她陷入了一种状态：外表看上去在观察，而内心却在无限遐想，最近她一直这样。 The piece would be ‘interesting’—she fell into the state of outer observation and inner calculation very usual with her nowadays.
那边坐着L. S. D.，一位更加伟大的剧作家，她还不认识他。 Over there was L.S.D., the greater dramatist; she didn’t know him—yet.
他看上去相当可怕，头发竖得直直的。 He looked rather frightening, his hair stood up so straight.
于是，她眼前浮现出一个画面：他正站在她家的红棕色地板上，身后是一幅中国画。 And her eye began picturing him on her copper floor against a Chinese picture.
啊，快看那边！ And there—yes!
是格登·明霍！ Gurdon Minho!
想不到他竟会到如此时髦的地方来！ Imagine HIS coming to anything so modern!
他的侧面颇有点儿罗马味道——奥勒利安皇帝时期的味道。 His profile WAS rather Roman—of the Aurelian period!
她把目光从那个古董身上移开，想到明晚这个时候她准会收罗到这件东西了，心里颇为高兴，一一打量了剧场里的每一个人——她可不想遗漏任何一个重要人物。 Passing on from that antique, with the pleased thought that by this time tomorrow she might have collected it, she quartered the assembly face by face—she did not want to miss any one important.
“那件家具”突然停住了。 “The furniture” had come to a sudden standstill.
“有趣！”声音从她背后传来。 “Interesting!” said a voice over her shoulder.
是奥布里·格林！ Aubrey Greene!
好像幻影一般，颇有点儿月朦胧的感觉。他柔亮的金色头发笔直地向后梳着；他淡绿色的眼眸以及他的微笑，总让她有种被“挑逗”的感觉。 Illusive, rather moonlit, with his silky fair hair brushed straight back, and his greenish eyes—his smile always made her feel that he was ‘getting’ at her.
不管怎么说，毕竟他也是个漫画家！ But, after all, he was a cartoonist!
“嗯，可不是吗？” “Yes, isn’t it?”
他转身走了。 He curled away.
他本可以多呆一会儿的。因为在博迪格尔的那几首曲子之前，其他人是不会有时间表演的！ He might have stayed a little longer—there wouldn’t be time for any one else before those songs of Birdigal’s!
现在歌唱家查尔斯·波尔斯出场了！ Here came the singer Charles Powls!
他把个子矮小的博迪格尔拖到钢琴那边，这让他看起来既壮实又能干。 How stout and efficient he looked, dragging little Birdigal to the piano.
迷人的伴奏——轻轻荡漾着，和谐悦耳！ Charming accompaniment—rippling, melodious!
这位既壮实又能干的人开始唱了。 The stout, efficient man began to sing.
怎么与伴奏如此不一样呢！ How different from the accompaniment!
这首歌的每个音调都没有打动她的交感神经。 The song hit every note just off the solar plexus.
精确地讲，没有一个音调让她感到快乐。 It mathematically prevented her from feeling pleasure.
博迪格尔创作这首歌时，一定害怕有人将之称为“声乐作品”。 Birdigal must have written it in horror of some one calling it ‘vocal.’
声乐作品！ Vocal!
弗勒知道这个词极具传染性，它会像麻疹一样迅速传遍全场，这样一来，博迪格尔就完蛋了！ Fleur knew how catching the word was; it would run like a measle round the ring, and Birdigal would be no more!
可怜的博迪格尔！ Poor Birdigal!
但是这一点很“有趣”。 But this was ‘interesting.’
这时，迈克尔也发出感叹：“上帝啊！” Only, as Michael was saying: “O, my Gawd!”
三首歌！ Three songs!
波尔斯真了不起啊——如此忠诚！ Powls was wonderful—so loyal!
没有一个音符听起来像音乐！ Never one note hit so that it rang out like music!
她的思绪跑到威尔弗里德那里去了。 Her mind fluttered off to Wilfrid.
在所有的年轻诗人中，人们给了他话语权；这给他奠定了一种地位——似乎他来自于生活而非来自文学。 To him, of all the younger poets, people accorded the right to say something; it gave him such a position—made him seem to come out of life, instead of literature.
此外，他参加过战争，是马利昂勋爵的儿子，有望凭《铜币》获得默瑟奖。 Besides, he had done things in the war, was a son of Lord Mullyon, would get the Mercer Prize probably, for ‘Copper Coin.’
如果威尔弗里德离她而去的话，那么一颗明星将会从她家的红棕色地板上空落下。 If Wilfrid abandoned her, a star would fall from the firmament above her copper floor.
他无权让她陷入困境。 He had no right to leave her in the lurch.
他必须要学会不粗鲁——不随心所欲。 He must learn not to be violent—not to think physically.
不！她决不能让威尔弗里德溜走，她也不允许自己的生活中再出现任何痛苦的事情、枯萎的感情、走不通的路以及不幸的结果。 No! she couldn’t let Wilfrid slip away; nor could she have any more sob-stuff in her life, searing passions, cul de sacs, aftermaths.
她曾经尝过这种滋味，旧伤疤还在隐隐作痛，时刻提醒着她。 She had tasted of that; a dulled ache still warned her.
博迪格尔鞠躬致谢，迈克尔说道：“出去吸口烟吧！ Birdigal was bowing, Michael saying: “Come out for a whiff!
下一个节目没什么可看的！” The next thing’s a dud!”
哦！啊！ Oh! ah!
贝多芬。 Beethoven.
可怜的老贝！ Poor old Beethoven!
早就过时了——人们从前确实很欣赏他！ So out of date—one did RATHER enjoy him!
走廊和那一边的休息室都挤满了参与复兴运动的人。 The corridor, and refectory beyond, were swarming with the restoration movement.
青年们看起来活泼而又偏执，他们彼此交流，互道“有趣”。 Young men and women with faces and heads of lively and distorted character, were exchanging the word ‘interesting.’
体态魁梧的男子们，像岿然不动的斗牛士，把过道都堵住了。 Men of more massive type, resembling sedentary matadors, blocked all circulation.
弗勒和迈克尔向前走了几步就靠墙站住了，点燃了香烟。 Fleur and Michael passed a little way along, stood against the wall, and lighted cigarettes.
弗勒的香烟包在琥珀烟嘴里，显得格外小巧玲珑，她优雅地吸着烟。 Fleur smoked hers delicately—a very little one in a tiny amber holder.
与其说她在吸烟，倒不如说她在欣赏吐出的缕缕青烟；除了这些听众外，她还要考虑其他社会领域的人——具体那个领域里会涉及什么样的人物谁也不清楚！比如，艾莉森·查韦尔的活动领域：层次广泛的政治文学。但是，正如迈克尔常说的：“类似于一种卫生制度，相信自己是世界上仅有的社会领域；可以看看他们在回忆录里是怎么写彼此的！” She had the air of admiring blue smoke rather than of making it; there were spheres to consider beyond this sort of crowd—one never knew who might be about!—the sphere, for instance, in which Alison Charwell moved, politico-literary, catholic in taste, but, as Michael always put it, “Convinced, like a sanitary system, that it’s the only sphere in the world; look at the way they all write books of reminiscence about each other!”
她始终感觉他们似乎不赞成妇女在公共场合吸烟。 They might, she always felt, disapprove of women smoking in public halls.
弗勒巧妙地同反对传统的人交往，从不忘记她至少同时属于两个世界。 Consorting delicately with iconoclasm, Fleur never forgot that her feet were in two worlds at least.
站在那里，她观察着周围的一切，突然看到一个人靠墙站着，用节目单挡着脸。 Standing there, observant of all to left and right, she noted against the wall one whose face was screened by his programme.
她心想：“是威尔弗里德，他还故意装作没看见我！” ‘Wilfrid,’ she thought, ‘and doesn’t mean to see me!’
她像一个被偷走了六便士的小孩一样，感觉十分受辱。她说道： Mortified, as a child from whom a sixpence is filched, she said:
“那是威尔弗里德！ “There’s Wilfrid!
迈克尔，请他过来！” Fetch him, Michael!”
迈克尔走过去，碰碰他的男傧相的袖子。德赛特的脸露了出来，愁容满面。 Michael crossed, and touched his best man’s sleeve; Desert’s face emerged, frowning.
她看见他耸耸肩膀，转身走入人群中去了。 She saw him shrug his shoulders, turn and walk into the throng.
迈克尔回来了。 Michael came back.
“威尔弗里德今晚闷闷不乐，说自己不适合人类社会了，真是个古怪的家伙！” “Wilfrid’s got the hump to-night; says he’s not fit for human society—queer old son!”
男人多迟钝啊！ How obtuse men were!
因为威尔弗里德是迈克尔的朋友，迈克尔就看不出来，这倒也算幸运！ Because Wilfrid was his pal, Michael did not see; and that was lucky!
这样看来，威尔弗里德真的打算避开她了！ So Wilfrid really meant to avoid her!
好吧，她倒要瞧瞧！ Well, she would see!
于是她说： And she said:
“迈克尔，我累了，咱们回家吧。” “I’m tired, Michael; let’s go home.”
他轻轻挽住她的胳膊。 His hand slid round her arm.
“对不起，宝贝，走吧！” “Sorry, old thing; come along!”
他们在一个无人注意的门口站了一会儿，望着乐队指挥伍曼士朝他的管弦乐队走去。 They stood a moment in a neglected doorway, watching Woomans, the conductor, launched towards his orchestra.
“你看他，”迈克尔说，“多像挂在意式小窗上，腿和胳膊把衣服撑得满当当的，还在那儿手舞足蹈着！ “Look at him,” said Michael; “guy hung out of an Italian window, legs and arms all stuffed and flying!
再看看这位弗莱帕凯和她弹的钢琴曲——真是一团糟！” And look at the Frapka and her piano—that’s a turbulent union!”
突然传来一阵奇怪的声音。 There was a strange sound.
“天啊，这旋律真好听！”迈克尔说道。 “Melody, by George!” said Michael.
一位服务生在他们耳边低声说：“先生，我要关门了。” An attendant muttered in their ears: “Now, sir, I’m going to shut the door.”
弗勒快速瞥了一眼L. S. D.，他坐得和他头发一样笔直，闭着眼睛。 Fleur had a fleeting view of L.S.D. sitting upright as his hair, with closed eyes.
门关上了，他们站在了外面的大厅里。 The door was shut—they were outside in the hall.
“亲爱的，在这等会儿，我去叫辆人力车。” “Wait here, darling; I’ll nick a rickshaw.”
弗勒将下巴缩进毛皮领子里。 Fleur huddled her chin in her fur.
天刮着东风，很冷。 It was easterly and cold.
有个声音在她背后说道： A voice behind her said:
“喂，弗勒，我该去东方吗？” “Well, Fleur, am I going East?”
威尔弗里德！ Wilfrid!
他的衣领竖到耳根，嘴里还叼着烟，双手插兜，眼睛直勾勾地盯着她。 His collar up to his ears, a cigarette between his lips, hands in pockets, eyes devouring.
“你真傻，威尔弗里德！” “You’re very silly, Wilfrid!”
“随你怎么想，我该去东方吗?” “Anything you like; am I going East?”
“别去，星期天上午11点，泰特美术馆见。 “No; Sunday morning—eleven o’clock at the Tate.
咱俩好好谈谈。” We’ll talk it out.”
“同意！” “Convenu!”
说完他就走了。 And he was gone.
突然就这样孤独地一个人呆在那里，弗勒第一次被现实震撼了。 Alone suddenly, like that, Fleur felt the first shock of reality.
难道威尔弗里德真的要变得难以掌控了吗？ Was Wilfrid truly going to be unmanageable?
一辆出租车停了下来，迈克尔招呼她，弗勒跨了进去。 A taxicab ground up; Michael beckoned; Fleur stepped in.
他们经过一片灯红酒绿之地，一群年轻女子正向饶有兴致的伦敦人展示巴黎裸体艺术的最高成就，这时，她感觉迈克尔正朝她凑过来。 Passing a passionately lighted oasis of young ladies displaying to the interested Londoner the acme of Parisian undress, she felt Michael incline towards her.
如果想留住威尔弗里德，她就必须对迈克尔亲热些。 If she were going to keep Wilfrid, she must be nice to Michael.
她只说： Only:
“迈克尔，你没必要在皮卡迪利广场吻我！” “You needn’t kiss me in Piccadilly Circus, Michael!”
“对不起，宝贝！ “Sorry, duckie!
我看时间还早，想带你到对面先贤祠去。” It’s a little previous—I meant to get you opposite the Partheneum.”
弗勒回想起，在他们度蜜月的头两个星期里，他一直睡在西班牙式的沙发上；他一直坚持不让她给他花钱，却总是送她他想送给她的东西，尽管她一年收入3 000镑，而他只有1200镑；在她感冒时，他又是多么担心——而且他总是会回家喝下午茶。 Fleur remembered how he had slept on a Spanish sofa for the first fortnight of their honeymoon; how he always insisted that she must not spend anything on him, but must always let him give her what he liked, though she had three thousand a year and he twelve hundred; how jumpy he was when she had a cold—and how he always came home to tea.
的确，他真的很可爱！ Yes, he was a dear!
但是，如果明天他打算去东方或者西方的话，她也会伤心吗？ But would she break her heart if he went East or West tomorrow?
她依偎在他怀里，不禁为自己的玩世不恭而惊讶。 Snuggled against him, she was surprised at her own cynicism.
门厅里有一条电话留言，写着：“请转告蒙特太太，我已邀请到格亭·明纳先生。 A telephone message written out, in the hall, ran: “Please tell Mrs. Mont I’ve got Mr. Gurding Minner.
艾莉森夫人。” Lady Alisson.”
这让人感觉踏实了。 It was restful.
一件真正的古董！ A real antique!
她打开房间里的灯，站了一会儿，欣赏着屋子。 She turned on the lights in her room, and stood for a moment admiring it.
真美啊！ Truly pretty!
房间的角落里传来一阵轻微的鼻息声——是小叮铃，在黑色垫子上的棕褐色的小家伙，像只小巧的中国狮子躺在那里一样；它纯净、淡漠，刚和广场围栏夜会了一场。 A slight snuffle from the corner—Ting-a-ling, tan on a black cushion, lay like a Chinese lion in miniature; pure, remote, fresh from evening communion with the Square railings.
“我看到你了。”弗勒说。 “I see you,” said Fleur.
小叮铃一动不动，用浑圆的黑眼睛望着女主人脱衣服。 Ting-a-ling did not stir; his round black eyes watched his mistress undress.
当她从浴室出来，它已蜷缩成一团。 When she returned from the bathroom he was curled into a ball.
弗勒心想：“奇怪！ Fleur thought: ‘Queer!
它怎么知道迈克尔不会来？” How does he know Michael won’t be coming?’
于是它钻进了弗勒那张舒适而温暖的床里，她也蜷起身子睡了。 And slipping into her well warmed bed, she too curled herself up and slept.
但是，到了深夜，她反常地醒了。 But in the night, contrary to her custom, she awoke.
叫喊声——悠长、怪异、拖曳，不知来自何处——可能来自后面河对岸的贫民窟——唤起了她在格拉纳达度蜜月时伤心刺骨的记忆——格拉纳达的屋顶下，泛起黑玉色、象牙白和金黄色；更夫的叫喊声，让她想起了乔恩信中的那些诗句： A cry—long, weird, trailing, from somewhere—the river—the slums at the back—rousing memory—poignant, aching—of her honeymoon—Granada, its roofs below, jet, ivory, gold; the watchman’s cry, the lines in Jon’s letter:
“深夜里回荡着哭泣声，从古老的沉睡的西班牙城市下传来，在她银白色的星空下黯淡。 “Voice in the night crying, down in the old sleeping Spanish City darkened under her white stars.
这声音在诉说什么——是它切肤的挥之不去的痛苦吗？ What says the voice—its clear, lingering anguish?
还是巡夜人报着他那无休止的平安？ Just the watchman, telling his dateless tale of safety?
抑或是筑路人对着明月诉说自己的心声？ Just a road-man, flinging to the moon his song?
不！ No!
这是一位被剥夺权利的人，他恋人的心正在哭泣。 ‘Tis one deprived, whose lover’s heart is weeping,
他在叫喊：‘还要多久？’” Just his cry: ‘How long?’”
是有人在叫喊，还是她在做梦？ A cry, or had she dreamed it?
乔恩、威尔弗里德、迈克尔！ Jon, Wilfrid, Michael!
她的心已疲惫不堪！ No use to have a heart!
第四章 Chapter IV
晚宴 Dining
艾莉森·查韦尔夫人出嫁前姓希思菲尔德，是第一代坎普登伯爵之女，是迈克尔的小叔叔、王室法律顾问莱昂内尔·查韦尔之妻。她是个讨人喜欢的英国女士，从小接受的是公认的社会主流思想教育。 Lady Alison Charwell, born Heathfield, daughter of the first Earl of Campden, and wife to Lionel Charwell, K.C., Michael’s somewhat young uncle, was a delightful Englishwoman brought up in a set accepted as the soul of society.
有这样一群人，他们有智慧、有活力、有品位、有财富，出身贵族并且具有政治法律的家世背景，同“轻蔑”俱乐部有联系却又不是其中的成员，也不去特权阶级常去的沉闷场所。 Full of brains, energy, taste, money, and tinctured in its politico-legal ancestry by blue blood, this set was linked to, but apart from ‘Snooks’ and the duller haunts of birth and privilege.
他们快乐、有趣、自由自在，但是据迈克尔所说：“亲爱的，他们在审美和智力上都是自命不凡的，他们自己却永远意识不到。 It was gay, charming, free-and-easy, and, according to Michael, “Snobbish, old thing, aesthetically and intellectually, but they’ll never see it.
他们自以为是上等人——机敏、健康、时尚、有教养、聪明，根本无法想象谁能比得上他们。 They think they’re the top notch—quick, healthy, up-to-date, well-bred, intelligent; they simply can’t imagine their equals.
可是，他们缺乏想象力。 But you see their imagination is deficient.
他们把真正的创造力用在钻牛角尖上。 Their really creative energy would go into a pint pot.
看看他们写的书——他们总在高谈阔论——哲学、唯心论、诗歌、垂钓以及他们自己，这就是为什么他们不到25岁就再也写不出什么了。 Look at their books—they’re always ON something—philosophy, spiritualism, poetry, fishing, themselves; why, even their sonnets dry up before they’re twenty-five.
他们事事精通，就是不懂自己圈子之外的世界。 They know everything—except mankind outside their own set.
哦！他们工作——他们筹划演出——他们不得不这样做，因为没人会比他们更有头脑、精力和情趣了。 Oh! they work—they run the show—they have to; there’s no one else with their brains, and energy, and taste.
于是，他们在自己盛大的圈子里没完没了地办演出。 But they run it round and round in their own blooming circle.
对他们而言，这就是世界——而且这个世界以后也许会更不遂人意。 It’s the world to them—and it might be worse.
他们已经给他们专属的黄金时代申请了专利。不过，自从大战以来，这种专利已经名声败坏了。” They’ve patented their own golden age; but it’s a trifle flyblown since the war.”
艾莉森·查韦尔就是这个圈子的一员，她活泼热情、爽朗大方、平易近人。她和弗勒住得很近，她家的建筑风格十分宜人，可以同伦敦任何住宅相媲美。 Alison Charwell—in and of this world, so spryly soulful, debonnaire, free, and cosy—lived within a stone’s throw of Fleur, in a house pleasant, architecturally, as any in London.
她今年40岁，生过三个孩子，风韵犹存，自内而外的充沛活力让她显得格外年轻。 Forty years old, she had three children and considerable beauty, wearing a little fine from mental and bodily activity.
尽管迈克尔好作奇谈怪论，她却很欣赏和喜欢他，因此，从一开始，她就对他在婚姻上的冒险十分好奇。 Something of an enthusiast, she was fond of Michael, in spite of his strange criticisms, so that his matrimonial venture had piqued her from the start.
弗勒天生丽质，又生性机敏，所以，她认为这个新侄媳妇值得栽培。 Fleur was dainty, had quick natural intelligence—this new niece was worth cultivation.
可是，虽然弗勒是个“可塑之才”，却很奇怪地一直未被同化，这更加激发了艾莉森夫人的好奇心。夫人习惯了上等人的小圈子，在弗勒家的红棕色地板上，和“新时代”接触，她感觉很不舒服。 But, though adaptable and assimilative, Fleur had remained curiously unassimilated; she continued to whet the curiosity of Lady Alison, accustomed to the close borough of choice spirits, and finding a certain poignancy in contact with the New Age on Fleur’s copper floor.
在那里，她被怠慢了，虽然她不太看重这些，但这却扰乱了她的思绪。 She met with an irreverence there, which, not taken too seriously, flipped her mind.
站在那块地板上，她几乎觉得自己很落伍。 On that floor she almost felt a back number.
这一切对她来说是一种刺激。 It was stimulating.
那天，她一接完弗勒打听格登·明霍的电话，便立刻给这位小说家打电话。 Receiving Fleur’s telephonic enquiry about Gurdon Minho, she had rung up the novelist.
她虽然认识他，却不太相熟。 She knew him, if not well.
似乎谁和他都不太熟，他和蔼可亲、彬彬有礼，却沉默寡言，颇有些沉闷和严肃；最令人不舒服的是他的笑容，有时讥笑嘲讽，有时却又和善亲切。 Nobody seemed to know him well; amiable, polite, silent, rather dull and austere; but with a disconcerting smile, sometimes ironical, sometimes friendly.
他的作品时而尖酸刻薄，时而多愁善感。 His books were now caustic, now sentimental.
就这两种风格，当时颇有一种把他批评得一文不值的趋势，然而他仍旧在文坛占有一席之地。 On both counts it was rather the fashion to run him down, though he still seemed to exist.
她给他打电话。 She rang him up.
她问他明天能否赏光到她年轻的侄子迈克尔·蒙特家吃饭，和年轻人交流一下。 Would he come to a dinner tomorrow at her young nephew, Michael Mont’s, and meet the younger generation?
他说当然可以，嗓门还挺高： His answer came, rather high-pitched:
“当然好啦！ “Rather!
穿正式礼服，还是一般晚礼服？” Full fig, or dinner jacket?”
“您真是太好了！知道您能出席晚宴，他们一定非常高兴。 “How awfully nice of you! they’ll be ever so pleased.
我想，穿正式礼服吧。 Full fig, I believe.
这也是他们结婚两周年纪念日。” It’s the second anniversary of their wedding.”
她挂上电话时还在想：“他一定会以他们为原型写本书的！” She hung up the receiver with the thought: ‘He must be writing a book about them!’
出于责任感，她很早就到了。 Conscious of responsibility, she arrived early.
今晚，她丈夫的法律协会有场大应酬，因此她只身前来参加弗勒的晚宴，只想着过来凑凑热闹。在为“轻蔑”的决议忙碌了一整天后，她此时感到轻松愉快。 It was a grand night at her husband’s Inn, so that she brought nothing with her but the feeling of adventure, pleasant after a day spent in fluttering over the decision at ‘Snooks’.
只有小叮铃接待了她。它背对着壁炉，只朝她瞪了一眼，就没再理会她。 She was received only by Ting-a-ling, who had his back to the fire, and took no notice beyond a stare.
她在那张翠绿色的长靠椅上坐下，说道： Sitting down on the jade green settee, she said:
“喂，你这滑稽的小家伙，都这么久了，你还不认识我吗？” “Well, you funny little creature, don’t you know me after all this time?”
小叮铃那双黑亮的眼睛似乎在说：“我知道你又来了，绝大多数事情都是这样循环往复的。 Ting-a-ling’s black shiny gaze seemed saying: “You recur here, I know; most things recur.
未来也没什么新鲜可言。” There is nothing new about the future.”
艾莉森夫人不禁陷入沉思：这就是新的一代啊！ Lady Alison fell into a train of thought: The new generation!
她是否希望自己的女儿也属于这一代呢！ Did she want her own girls to be of it!
她想同明霍先生谈谈这个话题——战前，在比奇格罗夫，他们有过一次畅谈。 She would like to talk to Mr. Minho about that—they had had a very nice talk down at Beechgroves before the war.
那是九年前了——那时西比尔只有六岁，琼才四岁！ Nine years ago—Sybil only six, Joan only four then!
光阴似箭，时过境迁！ Time went, things changed!
新的一代！ A new generation!
他们到底有什么特别的呢？ And what was the difference?
“我想我们更传统些吧!”她轻声自语道。 “I think we had more tradition!” she said to herself softly.
一阵轻微的声响让她移开了凝视着自己双脚的目光。 A slight sound drew her eyes up from contemplation of her feet.
小叮铃在炉前的地毯上来回摆弄尾巴，仿佛在表示欢迎。 Ting-a-ling was moving his tail from side to side on the hearthrug, as if applauding.
这时，她身后传来了弗勒的声音： Fleur’s voice, behind her, said:
“亲爱的，我来得太迟了。 “Well, darling, I’m awfully late.
你真是太好了，替我邀请到明霍先生。 It WAS good of you to get me Mr. Minho.
我希望他们都能遵守常规。 I do hope they’ll all behave.
不管怎样，他会坐在你和我中间，我把他安排在主座，迈克尔在末座，迈克尔两旁分别是保利娜·厄普夏和阿玛贝尔·内津。 He’ll be between you and me, anyway; I’m sticking him at the top, and Michael at the bottom, between Pauline Upshire and Amabel Nazing.
西布莉坐在你左边，奥布里坐在我右边，挨着他们的是内丝塔·戈斯和沃尔特·内津，他们对面是琳达·弗鲁和查尔斯·厄普夏。 You’ll have Sibley on your left, and I’ll have Aubrey on my right, then Nesta Gorse and Walter Nazing; opposite them Linda Frewe and Charles Upshire.
一共12个人。 Twelve.
你全都认识。 You know them all.
哦！如果内津夫妇和内丝塔在上菜的间歇吸烟，你可别见怪啊。 Oh! and you mustn’t mind if the Nazings and Nesta smoke between the courses.
阿玛贝尔可能也抽烟。 Amabel will do it.
她来自弗吉尼亚——那里的人都好抽烟。 She comes from Virginia—it’s the reaction.
我真希望她穿点儿衣服在身上，迈克尔老是说她穿上衣服是个错误；不过，明霍先生在场，气氛会有点儿紧张。 I do hope she’ll have some clothes on; Michael always says it’s a mistake when she has; but having Mr. Minoho makes one a little nervous.
你看过《恭维话》里内丝塔的那篇讽刺短文吗？ Did you see Nesta’s skit in ‘The Bouquet’?
啊，那真是太有趣了——明明指的就是L. S. D.啊！ Oh, too frightfully amusing—clearly meant for L.S.D.!
叮铃，我的叮铃，你想留在这见见所有客人吗？ Ting, my Ting, are you going to stay and see all these people?
那么，爬上来吧，不然你会被踩到的。 Well, then, get up here or you’ll be trodden on.
看它是不是中国狗？ Isn’t he Chinese?
它的确使整个房间熠熠生辉。” He does so round off the room.”
小叮铃把鼻子放在爪子上，趴在了翠绿色的靠垫中央。 Ting-a-ling laid his nose on his paws, in the centre of a jade green cushion.
“格亭·明纳先生来了！” “Mr. Gurding Minner!”
这位著名小说家脸色苍白、神态自若。 The well-known novelist looked pale and composed.
他与两个人握手，眼睛盯着小叮铃，说道： Shaking the two extended hands, he gazed at Ting-a-ling, and said:
“多可爱! “How nice!
你好吗，小家伙？” How are YOU, my little man?”
小叮铃动也不动。 Ting-a-ling did not stir.
它的沉默似乎在说：“你把我当成一只普通的英国狗了，先生！” “You take me for a common English dog, sir!” his silence seemed to say.
“沃尔特·内森夫妇到了，琳达·弗劳小姐到了。” "Mr. and Mrs. Walter Nazon, Miss Lende Frow. "
阿玛贝尔·内津先走了进来。从她美丽的头发到腰上六寸若隐若现的背部，宛如明净的雪花石膏；从膝盖以下四寸到鞋里微微露出的脚趾，则像是裹着一层布的雪花石膏。这位著名的小说家也不由得停止了与小叮铃的交流。 Amabel Nazing came first, clear alabaster from her fair hair down to the six inches of gleaming back above her waist-line, shrouded alabaster from four inches below the knee to the gleaming toes of her shoes; the eminent novelist mechanically ceased to commune with Ting-a-ling.
沃尔特·内津一路跟在妻子后面，他身材高大，从黑色的衣服里露出一小截衣领，他的脸像是从一百年前雕刻出来的，有点儿像雪莱。 Walter Nazing, who followed a long way up above his wife, had a tiny line of collar emergent from swathes of black, and a face, cut a hundred years ago, that slightly resembled Shelley’s.
他文学作品的风格有时像雪莱，有时又像马塞尔·普鲁斯特。 His literary productions were sometimes felt to be like the poetry of that bard, and sometimes like the prose of Marcel Proust.
就像迈克尔所说：“这算什么呀！” “What oh!” as Michael said.
弗勒立刻把琳达·弗鲁介绍给格登·明霍认识。对于琳达的作品，在这个客厅的客人们中，从来没有得到过统一的见解。 Linda Frewe, whom Fleur at once introduced to Gurdon Minho, was one about whose work no two people in her drawing-room ever agreed.
人们对她的两部作品《琐事》和《狂怒的西班牙绅士》，意见分歧都很大。 Her works ‘Trifles’ and ‘The Furious Don’ had quite divided all opinion.
有些人认为是上乘之作，有些人认为是胡说八道，她的作品总是会引起一场有趣的辩论——小小的疯狂到底是会加强艺术的价值，还是会贬低艺术的价值？ Genius according to some, drivel according to others, those books always roused an interesting debate whether a slight madness enhanced or diminished the value of art.
她本人对此类评论并不介怀，她只管继续创作。 She herself paid little attention to criticism—she produced.
“您就是明霍先生？ “THE Mr. Minho?
多有趣啊! How interesting!
我还没读过您的任何一部作品。” I’ve never read anything of yours.”
弗勒微微喘了口气。 Fleur gave a little gasp.
“什么——你不知道明霍先生写的猫吗？ “What—don’t you know Mr. Minho’s cats?
写得好极了。 But they’re wonderful.
明霍先生，我再介绍你认识沃尔特·内津夫人。 Mr. Minho, I do want Mrs. Walter Nazing to know you.
这位是阿玛贝尔，这位是格登·明霍先生。” Amabel—Mr. Gurdon Minho.”
“哦！ “Oh!
明霍先生，见到您真荣幸！ Mr. Minho—how perfectly lovely!
我老早就想认识您了。” I’ve wanted to know you ever since my cradle.”
弗勒听到这位小说家平静地说： Fleur heard the novelist say quietly:
“我也希望更早些认识您。”然后疑惑地走过去和刚进来的内丝塔·戈斯和西布莉·斯旺打招呼。她们两人一同进来，好像住在一起似的，边走边争论着，争论的焦点好像是L. S. D.。内丝塔因为他的作品《羽饰》而拥护他，西布莉则认为，机智已经随着复兴运动而死亡，这个人却还活着！ “I could wish it had been longer;” and passed on in doubt to greet Nesta Gorse and Sibley Swan, who came in, as if they lived together, quarrelling over L.S.D., Nesta upholding him because of his ‘panache’, Sibley maintaining that wit had died with the Restoration; this fellow was alive!
迈克尔跟在厄普夏夫妇和奥布里·格林后面一起进来，他在门厅碰见了他们。 Michael followed with the Upshires and Aubrey Greene, whom he had encountered in the hall.
宴会的客人到齐了。 The party was complete.
弗勒追求事事完美，而那天晚上有点儿噩梦的感觉。 Fleur loved perfection, and that evening was something of a nightmare.
这算成功吗？ Was it a success?
宴会上，明霍显然是最没意思的人，连艾莉森的谈吐都比他强。 Minho was so clearly the least brilliant person there; even Alison talked better.
不过，他却头脑精明。 And yet he had such a fine skull.
她真希望他不会过早离开。 She did hope he would not go away early.
只要他起身离开，门还没关严，肯定就会有人说：“出土的古董！”或“又呆又秃！”。 Some one would be almost sure to say ‘Dug up!’ or ‘Thick and bald!’ before the door closed behind him.
他忍气吞声地附和别人，试图讨好大家，或者，至少不要太招人鄙视。 He was pathetically agreeable, as if trying to be liked, or, at least, not despised too much.
当然，他脑子里的东西肯定比他讲给大家听的要多。 And there must, of course, be more in him than met the sense of hearing.
吃过蟹粉蛋奶酥后，他好像确实在和艾莉森聊天，内容全是关于年轻人的。 After the crab souffle he did seem to be talking to Alison, and all about youth.
弗勒竖起耳朵听着。 Fleur listened with one ear.
“青春年少时感觉到……生活的主流……没有得到它所向往的东西。 “Youth feels... main stream of life... not giving it what it wants.
过去和未来获得光荣……的确如此！ Past and future getting haloes... Quite!
在当代生活中，已经没有正义可言了……不……对我们只有安慰——总有一天我们都会过时，像康格里夫、斯特恩、笛福……我们还会有机会……为什么？ Contemporary life no earthly just now... No... Only comfort for us—we’ll be antiquated, some day, like Congreve, Sterne, Defoe... have our chance again... WHY?
是什么正在把他们赶出主流？ What IS driving them out of the main current?
哦！ Oh!
可能是暴饮暴食……报纸……照片。 Probably surfeit... newspapers... photographs.
不思考生活本身，只看报道……生活的复制品，一切都显得质量低劣、耸人听闻和商业化……年轻人常说：‘管它呢，让我们享受过去或未来！’” Don’t see life itself, only reports... reproductions of it; all seems shoddy, lurid, commercial... Youth says ‘Away with it, let’s have the past or the future!’”
他吃了几颗盐渍杏仁，弗勒发现他的眼神落到了阿玛贝尔·内津的上半身。 He took some salted almonds, and Fleur saw his eyes stray to the upper part of Amabel Nazing.
宴会进行到这里，谈话就像踢英式足球——没人留住球，每个人只是踢一脚出去。 Down there the conversation was like Association football—no one kept the ball for more than one kick.
球在大家之间被踢来踢去。 It shot from head to head.
而且每传过一圈之后，就有人伸手拿支烟，把一团青烟喷到那张未铺桌布的狭长的餐桌上。 And after every set of passes some one would reach out and take a cigarette, and blow a blue cloud across the unclothed refectory table.
弗勒对她这间西班牙式房间的富丽堂皇的装修风格十分欣赏——花砖地面上印着盛满各色水果的瓷器，还有精工细刻的皮革、铜制品以及挂在摩尔式长沙发上的那幅索米斯画的戈雅。 Fleur enjoyed the glow of her Spanish room—its tiled floor, richly coloured fruits in porcelain, its tooled leather, copper articles, and Soames’ Goya above a Moorish divan.
她只在球飞到她这里时，才立即用头顶过去，她并不发球。 She headed the ball promptly when it came her way, but initiated nothing.
她有眼观六路、耳听八方的本领。 Her gift was to be aware of everything at once.
在“迈克尔·蒙特夫人呈现”中，她把大家的特点全都展示出来，呈现给大家——琳达·弗鲁的才华横溢与文不对题、内丝塔·戈斯的一针见血与激励刺激，奥布里·格林不动声色的含沙射影、西布莉·斯旺天翻地覆式的出击、阿玛贝尔·内津不顾一切的美国式鲁莽、查尔斯·厄普夏奇特的奇闻轶事、沃尔特·内津颠覆性的矛盾说辞、保利娜·厄普夏批判性的论点、迈克尔心不在焉的讽刺话，还有艾莉森的见识和机敏、格登·明霍的沉默——她时刻关注着那个谈话的“球”，唯恐它落在地上不动了。 “Mrs. Michael Mont presented” the brilliant irrelevancies of Linda Frewe, the pricks and stimulations of Nesta Gorse, the moonlit sliding innuendoes of Aubrey Greene, the upturning strokes of Sibley Swan, Amabel Nazing’s little cool American audacities, Charles Upshire’s curious bits of lore, Walter Nazing’s subversive contradictions, the critical intricacies of Pauline Upshire; Michael’s happy-go-lucky slings and arrows, even Alison’s knowledgeable quickness, and Gurdon Minho’s silences—she presented them all, showed them off, keeping her eyes and ears on the ball of talk lest it should touch earth and rest.
美好的夜晚，可是——这算成功吗？ Brilliant evening; but—a success?
等到最后一位客人离去，迈克尔也去送艾莉森回家了，她坐在翠绿长椅上，想起明霍刚才那句话：“青春年少时——没有得到向往的东西。” On the jade green settee, when the last of them had gone and Michael was seeing Alison home, she thought of Minho’s ‘Youth—not getting what it wants.’
不！ No!
事情不该如此。 Things didn’t fit.
“现在事情不妥，是吗，叮铃？” “They don’t fit, do they, Ting!”
但是小叮铃已经累了，只是一只耳尖动了动。 But Ting-a-ling was tired, only the tip of one ear quivered.
弗勒靠在椅背上，叹了口气。 Fleur leaned back and sighed.
小叮铃舒展开身体，前爪趴在她的大腿上，抬头望着她。 Ting-a-ling uncurled himself, and putting his forepaws on her thigh, looked up in her face.
它似乎在说：“你看看我，我很好。 “Look at me,” he seemed to say, “I’m all right.
我得到了我所要的，我要我所得到的。 I get what I want, and I want what I get.
现在，我想去睡觉。” At present I want to go to bed.”
“但是我不想睡。”弗勒说，一动也不动。 “But I don’t,” said Fleur, without moving.
“那就抱我起来吧！”小叮铃说。 “Just take me up!” said Ting-a-ling.
弗勒说：“嗯，我想这个人不错，但不合适，叮铃。” “Well,” said Fleur, “I suppose—It’s a nice person, but not the right person, Ting.”
小叮铃在她的怀里安静下来。 Ting-a-ling settled himself on her bare arms.
“没关系的，”它好像在说， “It’s all right,” he seemed to say.
“除了在中国，此类多愁善感的感情事多的是。 “There’s a great deal too much sentiment and all that, out of China.
振作起来吧!” Come on!”
第五章 Chapter V
夏娃 Eve
尊敬的威尔弗里德·德赛特先生的寓所位于科克大街一家画廊的对面。 The Honourable Wilfrid Desert’s rooms were opposite a picture gallery off Cork Street.
他出身贵族，是本家族中唯一一位男性诗人，而且很多人都肯为其出版。他选择住在这里，不是为了舒适，而是图其隐蔽。 The only male member of the aristocracy writing verse that any one would print, he had chosen them for seclusion rather than for comfort.
然而，他的那些“破烂”摆设并不缺乏英国上流社会所富有的品位和奢华。 His ‘junk,’ however, was not devoid of the taste and luxury which overflows from the greater houses of England.
威尔弗里德搬进去的时候，曾从康沃尔贵族马利昂勋爵在汉普郡的宅邸悄悄运来了两大车的家具。 Furniture from the Hampshire seat of the Cornish nobleman, Lord Mullyon, had oozed into two vans, when Wilfrid settled in.
可是，人们很少能在他家里找到他。多半由于他飘忽不定的行踪，他在年轻一代作家中占据了相当独特的地位，人们都感觉他是稀有物种。 He was seldom to be found, however, in his nest, and was felt to be a rare bird, owing his rather unique position among the younger writers partly to his migratory reputation.
因其患有一种精神上的幽闭恐惧症，害怕人们的包围，也许就连他自己也不一定知道是在哪里消磨时间的，或是在什么地方工作的。 He himself hardly, perhaps, knew where he spent his time, or did his work, having a sort of mental claustrophobia, a dread of being hemmed in by people.
战争爆发的时候，他刚从伊顿公学毕业；战争结束时，23岁的他已经是一名舞文弄墨的青年诗人了。 When the war broke out he had just left Eton; when the war was over he was twenty-three, as old a young man as ever turned a stave.
他和迈克尔的友谊始于一家医院，两人的关系也曾一度转淡，但是在1920年又突然升温了。因为那时，迈克尔加入了位于科芬园布莱克街上的丹比&温特出版社。 His friendship with Michael, begun in hospital, had languished and renewed itself suddenly, when in 1920 Michael joined Danby and Winter, publishers, of Blake Street, Covent Garden.
这位初出茅庐的出版商的沉睡的热情被威尔弗里德的诗句激发了出来。 The scattery enthusiasm of the sucking publisher had been roused by Wilfrid’s verse.
而这位诗人正需要找家出版社当靠山。经过多次共进午餐，两人密切地探讨了这些诗歌，最终在迈克尔的坚持下，出版社做出了让步。 Hob-nobbing lunches over the poems of one in need of literary anchorage, had been capped by the firm’s surrender to Michael’s insistence.
两个人都很兴奋：威尔弗里德写成了第一本书，这也是迈克尔资助出版的第一本书。两人的这份兴奋之情在迈克尔的婚礼上达到了顶峰。 The mutual intoxication of the first book Wilfrid had written and the first book Michael had sponsored was crowned at Michael’s wedding.
伴郎！ Best man!
从那时起，威尔弗里德那颗浪子的心便有了羁绊，他开始牵挂这对新人。说句公道话，直到一个月前，他才意识到吸引自己的并非迈克尔，而是弗勒。 Since then, so far as Desert could be tied to anything, he had been tied to those two; nor, to do him justice, had he realised till a month ago that the attraction was not Michael, but Fleur.
德赛特从不开口谈论战争，想从他的嘴里得出他对战争的印象是不可能的。这种印象他也许已经总结成这样：“我在恐怖和死亡中生活了那么久；我看到人们过着那种野蛮的、非人的生活；我对任何事都彻底绝望，对各种理论、诺言、协约、道德和原则不会再抱有一丝尊重。 Desert never spoke of the war, it was not possible to learn from his own mouth an effect which he might have summed up thus: “I lived so long with horror and death; I saw men so in the raw; I put hope of anything out of my mind so utterly, that I can never more have the faintest respect for theories, promises, conventions, moralities, and principles.
当我在泥水和血水中打滚时，我恨透了那些沉湎于这些玩意的人。 I have hated too much the men who wallowed in them while I was wallowing in mud and blood.
幻想破灭了。 Illusion is off.
宗教和哲学都无法说服我——空话，全是空话。 No religion and no philosophy will satisfy me—words, all words.
我仍有感觉——并不是由于上述这些玩意产生的感觉；我发现——我仍有热情，仍旧能够咬紧牙关咧着嘴笑，也还有一些战壕里的忠诚感，但这究竟是真实的反应还是某种情结，我就不得而知了。 I have still my senses—no thanks to them; am still capable—I find—of passion; can still grit my teeth and grin; have still some feeling of trench loyalty, but whether real or just a complex, I don’t yet know.
我是个危险人物，但同那些用别人的血汗来换取各种空话、原则、理论以及具有狂热愚蠢的行为的人相比，我远不及他们危险。 I am dangerous, but not so dangerous as those who trade in words, principles, theories, and all manner of fanatical idiocy to be worked out in the blood and sweat of other men.
那场战争为我做了一件事——把人生变成了滑稽喜剧。 The war’s done one thing for me—converted life to comedy.
对它笑吧——除此以外，别无他法！” Laugh at it—there’s nothing else to do!”
周五晚上离开音乐厅后，他径直走回自己的寓所。 Leaving the concert hall on the Friday night, he had walked straight home to his rooms.
他伸直了腿，躺在一张15世纪的僧侣坐榻上——这张坐榻是用20世纪的绒毛坐垫和丝绸修复而成的，双手交叉叠放在脑后，陷入了沉思：“我不能再这样下去了。 And lying down full length on a monk’s seat of the fifteenth century, restored with down cushions and silk of the twentieth, he crossed his hands behind his head and delivered himself to these thoughts: ‘I am not going on like this.
我已经被她迷住了。 She has bewitched me.
这对她来说算不上什么。 It doesn’t mean anything to her.
但对我却意味着毁灭。 But it means hell to me.
我会在周日解决这件事——波斯是个好地方。 I’ll finish with it on Sunday—Persia’s a good place.
阿拉伯半岛是个好地方——鲜血和沙砾多的是！ Arabia’s a good place—plenty of blood and sand!
她是不会放弃任何东西的。 She’s incapable of giving anything up.
她一直费尽心思地与我纠缠！ How has she hooked herself into me!
她会用眼神、头发、走路的姿势、说话的声音，还有温情、气味、颜色等等小手段来吸引我。 By trick of eyes, and hair, by her walk, by the sound of her voice—by trick of warmth, scent, colour.
可是，她会冒上身败名裂的危险吗？不，她不会。 Fling her cap over the windmill—not she!
那怎么办？ What then?
难道要我围着她的中式壁炉和中国小狗打转，还要忍受不能亲她的痛苦和狂热吗？ Am I to hang about her Chinese fireside and her little Chinese dog; and have this ache and this fever because I can’t be kissing her?
我宁愿再到德国人的枪林弹雨中去驰骋！ I’d rather be flying again in the middle of Boche whiz-bangs!
周日！ Sunday!
女人怎么都喜欢拖拖拉拉，让痛苦的时间更久啊！ How women like to drag out agonies!
到时候只会是今天下午的情形再次上演。 It’ll be just this afternoon all over again.
‘你的友情对我而言非常珍贵，你怎么这么残忍地要走啊！ “How unkind of you to go, when your friendship is so precious to me!
留下来，做我听话的小猫吧，威尔弗里德！’ Stay, and be my tame cat, Wilfrid!”
不，亲爱的，这一次你要有大麻烦了！ No, my dear, for once you’re up against it!
同样——我也惹上麻烦了，上帝啊！……” And—so am I, by the Lord!...’
周日上午，在那个成为英国艺术品收容所的美术馆里，这两个年轻人“很凑巧”地在一幅夏娃嗅着伊甸园花香的画前相遇了。当时附近还有六个不同年纪的工匠、一个看管员和一对外地来的夫妻，这些人看起来都不像会注意观察周围的事情。 When in that gallery which extends asylum to British art, those two young people met so accidentally on Sunday morning in front of Eve smelling at the flowers of the Garden of Eden, there were present also six mechanics in various stages of decomposition, a custodian and a couple from the provinces, none of whom seemed capable of observing anything whatever.
而且那次会面是平静的。 And, indeed, that meeting was inexpressive.
两个属于幻想破灭阶级的年轻人互相谴责对方此前的行为。 Two young people, of the disillusioned class, exchanging condemnations of the past.
德赛特以他那随意的谈吐、微笑和精心剪裁的休闲着装，让人觉得他并不心痛。 Desert with his off-hand speech, his smile, his well-tailored informality, suggested no aching heart.
相比之下，还是弗勒面色更苍白，也更引人关注。 Of the two Fleur was the paler and more interesting.
德赛特不住地提醒自己：“不要煽情——只有这样才好！” Desert kept saying to himself: “No melodrama—that’s all it would be!”
而弗勒却在想：“要是我能让他保持这样平常的状态，我就不会失去他了。因为他不适当发泄一下是不会罢休的。” And Fleur was thinking: ‘If I can keep him ordinary like this, I shan’t lose him, because he’ll never go away without a proper outburst.’
直到两个人再次在那幅夏娃的画前相遇，他才说： It was not until they found themselves a second time before the Eve, that he said:
“我不明白你为什么要叫我来，弗勒。 “I don’t know why you asked me to come, Fleur.
你这是在无理取闹。 It’s playing the goat for no earthly reason.
我很理解你的心情。 I quite understand your feeling.
我只不过是你不愿失去的一件‘明朝’古玩。 I’m a bit of ‘Ming’ that you don’t want to lose.
但是这件古玩又不够好，亲爱的。仅此而已。” But it’s not good enough, my dear; and that’s all about it.”
“你太可怕了，威尔弗里德！” “How horrible of you, Wilfrid!”
“好了！ “Well!
就此分手吧！ Here we part!
伸出你的小手来。” Give us your flipper.”
他的眼睛——很美丽的眼睛——在他微笑的双唇上方显得深邃而悲哀。她结结巴巴地说： His eyes—rather beautiful—looked dark and tragic above the smile on his lips, and she said stammering:
“威尔弗里德——我——我不知道。 “Wilfrid—I—I don’t know.
我需要时间。 I want time.
我不希望你不快乐。 I can’t bear you to be unhappy.
别离开我！ Don’t go away!
也许——我也会不快乐的。我——我不知道。” Perhaps I—I shall be unhappy, too; I—I don’t know.”
德赛特心头里掠过一丝苦涩：“她不会放手的——她不知道怎么放手。” Through Desert passed the bitter thought: ‘She CAN’T let go—she doesn’t know how.’
但是他的话却很温柔：“开心一点儿，我的宝贝。半个月之后你就会把这些都忘掉的。 But he said quite softly: “Cheer up, my child; you’ll be over all that in a fortnight.
我会送你点儿东西作为补偿的。 I’ll send you something to make up.
我为什么不到中国去呢——那里和其他地方有区别吗？ Why shouldn’t I make it China—one place is as good as another?
我会送你一件真正的‘明朝’古玩，比我这件更古老。” I’ll send you a bit of real ‘Ming,’ of a better period than this.”
弗勒激动地说： Fleur said passionately:
“你这是在侮辱人！ “You’re insulting!
不要这样！” Don’t!”
“对不起。 “I beg your pardon.
我不想让你生气。” I don’t want to leave you angry.”
“你想要我怎样？” “What is it you want of me?”
“哦！不——得了！ “Oh! no—come!
这已经是第二遍了。 This is going over it twice.
何况，我从周五开始就一直在思考。 Besides, since Friday I’ve been thinking.
我什么都不要，弗勒，我只想要你的祝福和握别。 I want nothing, Fleur, except a blessing and your hand.
把手递给我！ Give it me!
快点儿！” Come on!”
弗勒把手放在自己身后。 Fleur put her hand behind her back.
这太气人了！ It was too mortifying!
他把她当作一只有收藏嗜好的冷血小猫——用爪子玩弄它不想吃的老鼠！ He took her for a cold-blooded, collecting little cat—clutching and playing with mice that she didn’t want to eat!
“你以为我是冰做的吗，”她用牙咬着上唇说，“不，我不是！” “You think I’m made of ice,” she said, and her teeth caught her upper lip: “Well, I’m not!”
德赛特看着她，眼神非常沮丧。 Desert looked at her; his eyes were very wretched.
“我并不是有意嘲弄你的自尊心，”他说， “I didn’t mean to play up your pride,” he said.
“我们丢开自尊吧，弗勒。 “Let’s drop it, Fleur.
它一点儿用处都没有。” It isn’t any good.”
弗勒转过身去，凝视着那幅画中的夏娃——这个神情放荡的女人，她无所顾忌、贪婪，正满心享受着花香！ Fleur turned and fixed her eyes on the Eve—rumbustious-looking female, care-free, avid, taking her fill of flower perfume!
我为什么就不能像她这样无所顾忌、来者不拒呢？ Why not be care-free, take anything that came along?
世上没有太多的爱情供人放弃，不闻不采。 Not so much love in the world that one could afford to pass, leaving it unsmelled, unplucked.
私奔吧！ Run away!
到东方去！ Go to the East!
当然，这些放肆的事情，她一件也不会做！ Of course, she couldn’t do anything extravagant like that!
但是，也许会——这有什么关系呢？这个男人或是那个男人，反正都不是你爱的那个人！ But, perhaps—What did it matter? one man or another, when neither did you really love!
她白净的眼睑低垂着，透过浓密的睫毛，她看到了他脸上的表情以及那比雕像还要凝固的站姿。 From under her drooped, white, dark-lashed eyelids she saw the expression on his face, and that he was standing stiller than the statues.
突然她说道：“你要是走了，你就是个傻瓜。 And suddenly she said: “You will be a fool to go.
等着！” Wait!”
然后，她没有再说一句话或是再看一眼他就走开了，撇下连气都透不过来的德赛特一个人站在那贪婪的夏娃面前。 And without another word or look, she walked away, leaving Desert breathless before the avid Eve.
第六章 Chapter VI
“老福赛特”和“老蒙特” ‘Old Forsyte’ and ‘Old Mont’
弗勒心烦意乱地走着，险些踩到一个极熟悉的人的脚。这个人面色阴沉、神情焦急地站在一幅阿尔玛·塔德玛的作品前，仿佛迷失在那涨跌不定的市场价值里。 Moving away, in the confusion of her mood, Fleur almost trod on the toes of a too-familiar figure standing before an Alma Tadema with a sort of grey anxiety, as if lost in the mutability of market values.
“爸爸! “Father!
您到城里来了？ YOU up in town?
一起吃午饭吧，我得快点儿回家。” Come along to lunch, I have to get home quick.”
她挽着父亲的手臂站在他和夏娃之间，一边引着他离开，一边想：“他看见我们了吗？ Hooking his arm and keeping between him and Eve, she guided him away, thinking: ‘Did he see us?
会不会已经看到了？” Could he have seen us?’
“你穿得够多吗？”索姆斯低声埋怨着。 “Have you got enough on?” muttered Soames.
“多得很呢！” “Heaps!”
“你们女人总是这么说。 “That’s what you women always say.
外面刮着东风，可你的脖子就那么露着！ East wind, and your neck like that!
唉，我真弄不懂。” Well, I don’t know.”
“亲爱的爸爸，您不懂，但是我懂。” “No, dear, but I do.”
那双灰色的眼睛从头到脚地打量着她。 The grey eyes appraised her from head to foot.
“你在这儿做什么？”他问道。 “What are you doing here?” he said.
弗勒心想：“感谢上帝，他没看见。 And Flour thought: ‘Thank God he didn’t see.
要是看见了，他绝不会问的。” He’d never have asked if he had.’
于是她回答说： And she answered:
“我对艺术感兴趣了，亲爱的，和您一样啊。” “I take an interest in art, darling, as well as you.”
“嗯，我现在住在格林街你姑妈那里。 “Well, I’m staying with your aunt in Green Street.
这阵东风让我的肝脏很不舒服。 This east wind has touched my liver.
你的——迈克尔最近怎么样？” How’s your—how’s Michael?”
“哦，他还好，只是有点儿提不起精神。 “Oh, he’s all right—a little cheap.
我们昨晚举办了一场宴会。” We had a dinner last night.”
结婚纪念日！ Anniversary!
福赛特一家的现实主义精神涌上他的心头，于是他凝视着她的眼睛。 The realism of a Forsyte stirred in him, and he looked under her eyes.
他把手插进外衣口袋里，说道： Thrusting his hand into his overcoat pocket, he said:
“我带了这个来给你。” “I was bringing you this.”
弗勒看到一个用粉红色的薄纸包裹着的扁平的东西。 Fleur saw a flat substance wrapped in pink tissue paper.
“亲爱的，这是什么？” “Darling, what is it?”
索姆斯把东西放回自己的口袋。 Soames put it back into his pocket.
“我们待会儿再看。 “We’ll see later.
有人来吃午饭吗？” Anybody to lunch?”
“就准爵爷一个人。” “Only Bart.”
“老蒙特！ “Old Mont!
哦，上帝！” Oh, Lord!”
“您不喜欢准爵爷吗，亲爱的？” “Don’t you like Bart, dear?”
“喜欢他？ “Like him?
我和他毫无共同语言。” He and I have nothing in common.”
“我还以为你们对事情的看法很一致呢。” “I thought you fraternised rather over the state of things.”
“他是个反动分子。”索姆斯说道。 “He’s a reactionary,” said Soames.
“那么您呢，亲爱的？” “And what are you, ducky?”
“我？ “I?
我该是什么样子的？” What should I be?”
他说着的这些话都遵从着“不承诺”的方针。他年纪越大，越觉得这一方针是明智者的唯一选择。 With these words he affirmed that policy of non-commitment which, the older he grew, the more he perceived to be the only attitude for a sensible man.
“妈妈还好吗？” “How is Mother?”
“看起来很好。 “Looks well.
我没看到她——她和她的母亲一起进城闲逛了。” I see nothing of her—she’s got her own mother down—they go gadding about.”
他从不提起弗勒的外祖母拉莫特夫人——自己的女儿越少和那些法国亲戚来往越好。 He never alluded to Madame Lamotte as Fleur’s grandmother—the less his daughter had to do with her French side, the better.
“啊！”弗勒说道， “Oh!” said Fleur.
“是叮铃和一只猫！” “There’s Ting and a cat!”
