女仆正牵着小叮铃出来透风。此时它正呼哧呼哧地抽着鼻子，试图爬上栏杆。那上面有只黑猫，背部弓起、双目圆睁。 Ting-a-ling, out for a breath of air, and tethered by a lead in the hands of a maid, was snuffling horribly and trying to climb a railing whereon was perched a black cat, all hunch and eyes.
“埃伦，把它交给我。 “Give him to me, Ellen.
亲爱的，过来找妈妈！” Come with Mother, darling!”
小叮铃还真的来了，但这只是因为它走不了。它毛发竖立，抽搭着鼻子，头扭向后面。 Ting-a-ling came, indeed, but only because he couldn’t go, bristling and snuffling and turning his head back.
“我喜欢看它不做作的样子。”弗勒说。 “I like to see him natural,” said Fleur.
“浪费钱，养这么条狗，”索姆斯评论道， “Waste of money, a dog like that,” Soames commented.
“你应该养只斗牛犬，让它睡在门厅里。 “You should have had a bull-dog and let him sleep in the hall.
夜盗多极了。 No end of burglaries.
你姑妈让人把门环都偷走了。” Your aunt had her knocker stolen.”
“就是被偷掉一百个门环，我也不会跟叮铃分离。” “I wouldn’t part with Ting for a hundred knockers.”
“总有一天会有人把它偷走的——这么个时髦的品种。” “One of these days you’ll be having HIM stolen—fashionable breed.”
弗勒打开自家的前门。 Fleur opened her front door.
“啊！”她说，“准爵爷已经到了！” “Oh!” she said, “Bart’s here, already!”
一顶锃亮的帽子挂在大理石镶板上，这块镶板是索姆斯送来的礼物，用来挂外套和防虫蛀。 A shiny hat was reposing on a marble coffer, present from Soames, intended to hold coats and discourage moth.
索姆斯把自己的帽子挂在那顶帽子旁边，然后望着它们。 Placing his hat alongside the other, Soames looked at them.
这两顶帽子实在太像了，都是高高的、昂贵的、锃亮的，连里面的商标都是一样的。 They were too similar for words, tall, high, shiny, and with the same name inside.
自从1921年大罢工和煤矿罢工失败后，他又恢复了戴“高帽子”的习惯。他的直觉告诉他，在相当长的时间内，都不会有革命浪潮了。 He had resumed the ‘tall hat’ habit after the failure of the general and coal strikes in 1921, his instinct having told him that revolution would be at a discount for some considerable period.
“这件东西，”他一边说，一边掏出那个粉红色的包裹，“我不知道你会怎么处理它，不过你先拿着吧。” “About this thing,” he said, taking out the pink parcel, “I don’t know what you’ll do with it, but here it is.”
那是一颗彩色蛋白石，雕工奇特，上面镶了一圈细钻。 It was a curiously carved and coloured bit of opal in a ring of tiny brilliants.
“哦！” “Oh!”
弗勒叫道，“多美的东西啊！” Fleur cried: “What a delicious thing!”
“浮在水面上的维纳斯，或者诸如此类的名称，”索姆斯低声说道， “Venus floating on the waves, or something,” murmured Soames.
“此物非比寻常。 “Uncommon.
你得在亮点儿的地方看它才行。” You want a strong light on it.”
“但是它好可爱。 “But it’s lovely.
我现在就要戴上它。” I shall put it on at once.”
维纳斯！ Venus!
要是爸爸已经知道的话！ If Dad had known!
她伸开双臂搂着爸爸的脖子，以此来掩饰她对这件凑巧的事情的感想。 She put her arms round his neck to disguise her sense of a propos.
索姆斯任由女儿的脸颊在自己那刮得很干净的脸上蹭来蹭去，保持着一贯的镇静。 Soames received the rub of her cheek against his own well-shaved face with his usual stillness.
既然父女俩都知道他对女儿的钟爱两倍于女儿对他的爱，又何必挑明了呢？ Why demonstrate when they were both aware that his affection was double hers?
“那就戴上吧，”他说，“咱们一起看看。” “Put it on then,” he said, “and let’s see.”
弗勒站在一面古老的亮漆镜子前，把这颗蛋白石别在自己的衣领上。 Fleur pinned it at her neck before an old lacquered mirror.
“这是件宝贝。 “It’s a jewel.
谢谢亲爱的爸爸！ Thank you, darling!
看，您的领带笔挺笔挺的。 Yes, your tie is straight.
我喜欢那上面白色的滚边。 I like that white piping.
您只能用黑色的衣服来配它。 You ought always to wear it with black.
现在，跟我来吧！” Now, come along!”
说着就把他拉进她的中国式的房间里去了。 And she drew him into her Chinese room.
里面没有人。 It was empty.
“准爵爷一定是和迈克尔在楼上，谈论他的新书。” “Bart must be up with Michael, talking about his new book.”
“他那把年纪了，还写书？”索姆斯问。 “Writing at his age?” said Soames.
“可是，亲爱的爸爸，他比您还小一岁呢。” “Well, ducky, he’s a year younger than you.”
“我又不写书。 “I don’t write.
我才不像他那么傻呢。 Not such a fool.
你有没有新交有趣的朋友呢？” Got any more newfangled friends?”
“就一个——格登·明霍，是个小说家。” “Just one—Gurdon Minho, the novelist.”
“又是一个新派作家？” “Another of the new school?”
“哦，不是，亲爱的爸爸！ “Oh, no, dear!
您一定听过格登·明霍的，他可是古董级别的。” Surely you’ve heard of Gurdon Minho; he’s older than the hills.”
“在我看来，他们都差不多。”索姆斯嘟哝着， “They’re all alike to me,” muttered Soames.
“他的名气大吗？” “Is he well thought of?”
“我想他比您挣得多。 “I should think his income is larger than yours.
他基本上是经典了——只是等待死亡罢了。” He’s almost a classic—only waiting to die.”
“我会找本他的书看看的。 “I’ll get one of his books and read it.
你说哪一本好呢？” What name did you say?”
“就格登·明霍的那本《大鱼和小鱼》吧。 “Get ‘Big and Little Fishes,’ by Gurdon Minho.
您总能记住这个书名吧，是不是？ You can remember that, can’t you?
哟，他们来了！ Oh! here they are!
迈克尔，看看爸爸给了我什么啦。” Michael, look at what Father’s given me.”
她拉着迈克尔的手，放在那颗别在衣领上的蛋白石上。 Taking his hand, she put it up to the opal at her neck.
“让他们都看看，”她心想，“我们的夫妻关系有多好。” ‘Let them both see,’ she thought, ‘what good terms we’re on.’
尽管她的父亲没有在美术馆看到她和威尔弗里德在一起，她潜意识仍在说：“增强你的声誉，将来为了这声誉，你还不知道你会需要多大的支持呢。” Though her father had not seen her with Wilfrid in the gallery, her conscience still said: “Strengthen your respectability, you don’t quite know how much support you’ll need for it in future.”
她用眼角的余光观察着那两位。 And out of the corner of her eye she watched those two.
“老蒙特”和“老福赛特”——她知道准爵爷和迈克尔谈起她父亲时是这样称呼他的——他俩一见面，总是会让她忍俊不禁，可是她从不知道为什么要笑。 The meetings between ‘Old Mont’ and ‘Old Forsyte’—as she knew Bart called her father when speaking of him to Michael—always made her want to laugh, but she never quite knew why.
准爵爷什么都知道，但是他的知识就像一本精装的书，由那颗遗留在“18世纪”的头脑严格编辑过。 Bart knew everything, but his knowledge was beautifully bound, strictly edited by a mind tethered to the ‘eighteenth century.’
而她的父亲只知道那些有利于他的事情，他的知识是本没有装订的书，而且不受编辑的限制。 Her father only knew what was of advantage to him, but the knowledge was unbound, and subject to no editorship.
如果父亲生在维多利亚晚期，甚至是在最后时期，那么只要有利可图，他都不会放弃谋利。 If he WAS late Victorian, he was not above profiting if necessary by even later periods.
“老蒙特”相信传统；“老福赛特”什么都不信。 ‘Old Mont’ had faith in tradition; ‘Old Forsyte’ none.
以弗勒的精明，早就觉察到两个老人家的不同，而且这种差异对她的父亲更有利。 Fleur’s acuteness had long perceived a difference which favoured her father.
然而，“老蒙特”的谈吐却是如此时尚、迅速、随便、饶舌，让人联想到准确的报道；而“老福赛特”说起话来却是拘谨的、实事求是的。 Yet ‘Old Mont’s’ talk was so much more up-to-date, rapid, glancing, garrulous, redolent of precise information; and ‘Old Forsyte’s’ was constricted, matter-of-fact.
要分辨出两个人中哪一个会是较好博物馆的收藏品，确实是不可能。更何况，两个人都保养得那么好！ Really impossible to tell which of the two was the better museum specimen; and both so well-preserved!
他们的确没有握手，但是索姆斯谈了天气。 They did not precisely shake hands; but Soames mentioned the weather.
然后他们四个人几乎都想立刻开始周日的午餐。在弗勒坚持不懈的努力下，这些食物终于摆脱了英国风味。 And almost at once they all four sought that Sunday food which by a sustained effort of will Fleur had at last deprived of reference to the British character.
实际上，他们吃的是龙虾冷盘、意式鸡肝煨饭、朗姆炒蛋，还有一份做得尽可能看起来像西班牙式的甜点。 They partook, in fact, of lobster cocktails, and a mere risotto of chickens’ livers, an omelette au rhum, and dessert trying to look as Spanish as it could.
“我刚才去泰特美术馆了，”弗勒说，“我真的觉得那儿让人有所感触。” “I’ve been in the Tate,” Fleur said; “I do think it’s touching.”
“感触？”索姆斯嗤了一声表示质疑。 “Touching?” queried Soames with a sniff.
“先生，弗勒的意思是，一下子看到那么多古老的英国艺术作品，就好像在看宝宝秀一样。” “Fleur means, sir, that to see so much old English art together is like looking at a baby show.”
“我不同意，”索姆斯生硬地说， “I don’t follow,” said Soames stiffly.
“那里有一些非常好的作品呢。” “There’s some very good work there.”
“但还不够成熟，先生。” “But not grown-up, sir.”
“啊！ “Ah!
你们年轻人把那些疯狂的小聪明全当成是成熟了。” You young people mistake all this crazy cleverness for maturity.”
“迈克尔不是那个意思，爸爸。 “That’s not what Michael means, Father.
英国的绘画作品的确就像是牙还没长齐的小孩。 It’s quite true that English painting has no wisdom teeth.
你一眼就能看出英国绘画和欧洲绘画的差异。” You can see the difference in a moment, between it and any Continental painting.”
“这正是我们要感谢上帝的地方。”劳伦斯爵士插嘴说， “And thank God for it!” broke in Sir Lawrence.
“这个国家的艺术之美在于它的纯朴天真。 “The beauty of this country’s art is its innocence.
从政治上来说，我们是世界上最古老的国家，而从艺术上来说，是最年轻的国家。 We’re the oldest country in the world politically, and the youngest aesthetically.
福赛特，你觉得呢？” What do you say, Forsyte?”
“对我来说，特纳足够古老、足够智慧的了。”索姆斯简短地说， “Turner is old and wise enough for me,” said Soames curtly.
“周二你去参加天佑再保险公司的董事会吗？” “Are you coming to the P.P.R.S. Board on Tuesday?”
“周二吗？ “Tuesday?
我们本打算去丛林打猎的，对吧，迈克尔？” We were going to shoot the spinneys, weren’t we, Michael?”
索姆斯哼了一声。 Soames grunted.
“我要让他们等着，”他说， “I should let them wait,” he said.
“我们要完成那个报告。” “We settle the report.”
正是在“老蒙特”的关照下，他才获得了那个生意兴隆的公司——天佑再保险公司——董事会的一个席位。说实话，这个位子他坐得并不轻松。 It was through ‘Old Mont’s’ influence that he had received a seat on the Board of that flourishing concern, the Providential Premium Reassurance Society, and, truth to tell, he was not sitting very easily in it.
尽管平均定律也许是世界上最可靠的东西，但是已经有些情况引起他的不安了。 Though the law of averages was, perhaps, the most reliable thing in the world, there were circumstances which had begun to cause him disquietude.
他定睛看看身边这家伙。 He looked round his nose.
准男爵身子薄、脑瓜尖，眉毛拧成了一团——和坐在他面前的儿子一个模样！ Light weight, this narrow-headed, twisting-eyebrowed baronet of a chap—like his son before him!
然后他突然补充道：“我并不轻松。 And he added suddenly: “I’m not easy.
要是我早知道埃尔德森那家伙大权独揽，我怀疑我还会不会进入董事会。” If I’d realised how that chap Elderson ruled the roost, I doubt if I should have come on to that Board.”
“老蒙特”脸上顿时挂不住了。 One side of ‘Old Mont’s’ face seemed to try to leave the other.
“埃尔德森！”他说， “Elderson!” he said.
“改革法案时期，他的祖父是我祖父所在党的法律顾问，帮助我祖父在有史以来最腐败的选举中获胜——每一张选票都是买来的——常常讨好所有农民的妻子。 “His grandfather was my grandfather’s parliamentary agent at the time of the Reform Bill; he put him through the most corrupt election ever fought—bought every vote—used to kiss all the farmer’s wives.
伟大的时代，福赛特，伟大的时代！” Great days, Forsyte, great days!”
“但已经过去了，”索姆斯说， “And over,” said Soames.
“我觉得我们不应该这么相信埃尔德森的判断力，我不喜欢这种国外保险。” “I don’t believe in trusting a man’s judgment as far as we trust Elderson’s; I don’t like this foreign insurance.”
“亲爱的福赛特——埃尔德森的头脑是一流的，我从小就认识他，我们一起在温切斯特读过书。” “My dear Forsyte—first-rate head, Elderson; I’ve known him all my life, we were at Winchester together.”
索姆斯发出一声深沉的声音。 Soames uttered a deep sound.
“老蒙特”的话里也有很多让他不安的理由。 In that answer of ‘Old Mont’s’ lay much of the reason for his disquietude.
董事会的所有人，看起来都像在温切斯特一起读过书似的。 On the Board they had all, as it were, been at Winchester together!
真是见鬼了！ It was the very deuce!
大家都这么体面，以至于不敢互相审查，也不敢审查大家共同的保险单。 They were all so honourable that they dared not scrutinise each other, or even their own collective policy.
他们害怕表现出对彼此的不信任，甚于害怕错误或是欺诈。 Worse than their dread of mistake or fraud was their dread of seeming to distrust each other.
这是很正常的，因为彼此不信任是一种直接的罪孽。 And this was natural, for to distrust each other was an immediate evil.
而就索姆斯所知，直接的罪孽就是人们要回避的。 And, as Soames knew, immediate evils are those which one avoids.
其实，单是从他父亲那里遗传来的秉性，已经让索姆斯的不安日益加深了。他会在夜里2点到4点间惊醒，然后他蠢蠢欲动的小担忧就会变成大恐慌，像蝴蝶一样破茧而出。 Indeed, only that tendency, inherited from his father, James, to lie awake between the hours of two and four, when the chrysalis of faint misgiving becomes so readily the butterfly of panic, had developed his uneasiness.
天佑再保险公司是这么有影响力的一家大公司，而他加入公司的时间尚短，如果就此怀疑它有问题未免显得冒昧，尤其是如果他光说有问题却找不出问题或是理由的话，他就可能得离开董事会和那一千英镑的年薪。 The P.P.R.S. was so imposing a concern, and he had been connected with it so short a time, that it seemed presumptuous to smell a rat; especially as he would have to leave the Board and the thousand a year he earned on it if he raised smell of rat without rat or reason.
但是要是真的有问题怎么办？ But what if there were a rat?
难就难在这里了！ That was the trouble!
而“老蒙特”却坐在这里谈着他的丛林打猎和他的祖父。 And here sat ‘Old Mont’ talking of his spinneys and his grandfather.
这家伙的脑瓜太小了！ The fellow’s head was too small!
然后他脑子里又涌现出一个让人压抑的念头：“在座的所有人，甚至包括我女儿在内，没有一个人会严肃对待事情。”他不吭声了。 And visited by the cheerless thought: ‘There’s nobody here, not even my own daughter, capable of taking a thing seriously,’ he kept silence.
这时，肘边的声音惊动了他。 A sound at his elbow roused him.
他和他女儿之间的椅子上的那只像“狨”一样的小狗居然坐起来了！ That marmoset of a dog, on a chair between him and his daughter, was sitting up!
这是盼着他能给点儿吃的吗？ Did it expect him to give it something?
它那双眼珠早晚有一天会掉出来的。 Its eyes would drop out one of these days.
于是他问道：“喂，你想要什么？” And he said: “Well, what do YOU want?”
看看这小畜生的那副样子，瞪着它那对靴扣般大小的眼睛！ The way the little beast stared with those boot-buttons!
“来，”他一边说，一边拿了一颗盐渍杏仁给它， “Here,” he said, offering it a salted almond.
“你不吃这些东西的。” “You don’t eat these.”
小叮铃吃了。 Ting-a-ling did.
“爸爸，它挺爱吃那个的。 “He has a passion for them, Dad.
对不对啊，小宝贝？” Haven’t you, darling?”
小叮铃抬眼望着索姆斯，从那双眼睛里，索姆斯体会到一种怪异的感觉。 Ting-a-ling turned his eyes up at Soames, through whom a queer sensation passed.
“我认为这小畜生喜欢我，”他想，“它总是看着我。” ‘Believe the little brute likes me,’ he thought, ‘he’s always looking at me.’
他用指尖碰了碰狗鼻子。 He touched the dog’s nose with the tip of his finger.
小叮铃用它那黑乎乎的卷舌头舔了他一下。 Ting-a-ling gave it a slight lick with his curly blackish tongue.
“可怜的小东西！”索姆斯不禁咕哝了一声，然后转向“老蒙特”。 “Poor fellow!” muttered Soames involuntarily, and turned to ‘Old Mont.’
“别再提我刚才的话了。” “Don’t mention what I said.”
“刚才的什么话，亲爱的福赛特？” “My dear Forsyte, what was that?”
天啊！ Good Heavens!
他居然和这样的人同在一个董事会里！ And he was on a Board with a man like this!
这人为何加入董事会——他又不在乎那点儿钱，也不想操那份心——天晓得。 What had made him come on, when he didn’t want the money, or any more worries—goodness knew.
自从他当上了董事，威妮弗雷德和家里的其他人就开始买股票来抵消他们的所得税——优先股百分之七，普通股百分之九——以此取代原先他们本该满足的稳定的百分之五。 As soon as he had become a director, Winifred and others of his family had begun to acquire shares to neutralise their income tax—seven per cent, preference—nine per cent, ordinary—instead of the steady five they ought to be content with.
你看，他一动就会有人跟着动。 There it was, he couldn’t move without people following him.
过去，在金钱的迷宫里，他一直是位非常稳妥和精确的向导！ He had always been so safe, so perfect a guide in the money maze!
他都这把年纪了还在操心！ To be worried at his time of life!
他的目光落在女儿衣领上的那颗蛋白石上，借此寻求安慰——漂亮的玩意！漂亮的脖子！ His eyes sought comfort from the opal at his daughter’s neck—pretty thing, pretty neck!
啊！ Well!
她显得很开心——已经忘记两年前的迷恋了！ She seemed happy enough—had forgotten her infatuation of two years ago!
这是件令人欣慰的事情。 That was something to be thankful for.
她现在需要的是一个孩子，这样她就能在那些时尚的骚闹中安定下来，不再纠缠于那些微不足道的作家、画家和音乐家了。 What she wanted now was a child to steady her in all this modern scrimmage of twopenny-ha’penny writers and painters and musicians.
她虽然是一个放浪不羁的人，但是小脑瓜还是挺管用的。 A loose lot, but she had a good little head on her.
要是她有孩子了，他会在赠与她的财产上再加上两万英镑。 If she had a child, he would put another twenty thousand into her settlement.
这是她母亲的一个优点——把钱管得很稳，优秀的法国方式。 That was one thing about her mother—steady in money matters, good French method.
至于弗勒——据他所知——是量入为出的。 And Fleur—so far as he knew—cut her coat according to her cloth.
他们在说什么？ What was that?
耳朵里钻进一个词——“戈雅”。 The word ‘Goya’ had caught his ear.
他的新传记要出版了吗？ New life of him coming out?
哈！ H’m!
那就更坚定了他那慢慢增强的信念——戈雅已经再次攀上顶峰。 That confirmed his slowly growing conviction that Goya had reached top point again.
“我正想着把那东西卖掉，”他一边说，一边指着那幅画， “Think I shall part with that,” he said, pointing to the picture.
“来了个阿根廷人。” “There’s an Argentine over here.”
“您要把您那幅戈雅卖掉吗，先生？” “Sell your Goya, sir?”
迈克尔说道， It was Michael speaking.
“想想人们对您的尊敬和羡慕吧！” “Think of the envy with which you’re now regarded!”
“人总不能拥有一切吧。”索姆斯说。 “One can’t have everything,” said Soames.
“我们给《新生活》做的那张复制品已经是一流的了。 “That reproduction we’ve got for ‘The New Life’ has turned out first-rate.
‘索姆斯·福赛特先生收藏’。 ‘Property of Soames Forsyte, Esquire.’
先生，无论如何，等书出来再说吧。” Let’s get the book out first, sir, anyway.”
“虚名还是实名，嗯，福赛特？” “Shadow or substance, eh, Forsyte?”
这头脑狭窄的准男爵，他是在嘲笑我吗？ Narrow-headed baronet chap—was he mocking?
“我可没有世袭的爵位。”他说。 “I’VE no family place,” he said.
“可我们有啊，先生，”迈克尔小声嘀咕，“您可以把它留给弗勒，这您知道的。” “No, but we have, sir,” murmured Michael; “you could leave it to Fleur, you know.”
“嗯，”索姆斯说，“我们还要看看这么做值不值。” “Well,” said Soames, “we shall see if that’s worth while.”
他一边说着，一边看着他女儿。 And he looked at his daughter.
弗勒难得地脸红了，抱起小叮铃，从那张西班牙式的餐桌旁站了起来。 Fleur seldom blushed, but she picked up Ting-a-ling and rose from the Spanish table.
迈克尔也跟着站起来了。 Michael followed suit.
“咖啡在另一间屋里。”他说。 “Coffee in the other room,” he said.
“老福赛特”和“老蒙特”站了起来，捋着他们的胡子。 ‘Old Forsyte’ and ‘Old Mont’ stood up, wiping their moustaches.
第七章 Chapter VII
“老蒙特”和“老福赛特” ‘Old Mont’ and ‘Old Forsyte’
天佑再保险公司的办事处离纹章院不远。 The offices of the P.P.R.S. were not far from the College of Arms.
索姆斯记得在上世纪60年代，他的叔叔斯威森在那里花了一大笔钱淘到了一个“带有三个盾形右侧扣的黑底红色”纹章和一个“纯色雉鸡”纹章。因此，他总是对这幢建筑物不屑一顾。一直到大约一年前，在鉴赏家俱乐部里，他无意间从一本书里发现了戈尔丁的名字，不禁大吃一惊。 Soames, who knew that ‘three dexter buckles on a sable ground gules’ and a ‘pheasant proper’ had been obtained there at some expense by his Uncle Swithin in the ‘sixties of the last century, had always pooh-poohed the building, until, about a year ago, he had been struck by the name Golding in a book which he had absently taken up at the Connoisseurs’ Club.
他找这本书意在证实威廉·莎士比亚的确就是爱德华·德·威尔，牛津伯爵。 The affair purported to prove that William Shakespeare was really Edward de Vere, Earl of Oxford.
伯爵的母亲来自戈尔丁家族——与索姆斯的母亲同宗！ The mother of the earl was a Golding—so was the mother of Soames!
这个巧合引起了他的兴趣，他继续阅读下去。 The coincidence struck him; and he went on reading.
尽管这本书使他对主要问题的判断仍然犹豫不定，但是却引发了他对自己是否和莎士比亚同属一个血统的明显好奇。 The tome left him with judgment suspended over the main issue, but a distinct curiosity as to whether he was not of the same blood as Shakespeare.
即使此伯爵并非彼诗人，但他还是觉得这种联系令人信服，尽管据他现在的了解，牛津伯爵是一位疑点重重的人物。 Even if the earl were not the bard, he felt that the connection could only be creditable, though, so far as he could make out, Oxford was a shady fellow.
最近，由于被任命为天佑再保险公司的董事，他隔周的星期二都要经过纹章院。他心想：“没必要在这方面花费太多，但哪天可以进去瞧瞧。” Recently appointed on the Board of the P.P.R.S., so that he passed the college every other Tuesday, he had thought: ‘Shan’t go spending a lot of money on it, but might look in one day.’
可是当他进去之后，他对一切事物的迷恋程度令人震惊。 Having looked in, it was astonishing how taken he had been by the whole thing.
追溯他母亲的家世就像进行刑事侦查——错综复杂、全面彻底、耗资甚大。 Tracing his mother had been quite like a criminal investigation, nearly as ramified and fully as expensive.
从一开始，福赛特家族倔强的脾性就使他不能放弃调查莎士比亚·德·威尔的母亲，即便她也许是旁系血统；但不幸的是，他追查到奥利弗·克伦威尔时代的一个人，那人名叫威廉·古尔丁·英格勒——管他到底可能叫什么，他几乎不敢去追究他到底姓甚名谁——就再也进行不下去了。 Having begun, the tenacity of a Forsyte could hardly bear to leave him short of the mother of Shakespeare de Vere, even though she would be collateral; unfortunately, he could not get past a certain William Gouldyng, Ingerer—whatever that might be, and he was almost afraid to enquire—of the time of Oliver Cromwell.
仍有四代人需要调查清楚，但是他已经花费不少了，而且也不再奢望能够从中获得什么重要东西了。 There were still four generations to be unravelled, and he was losing money and the hope of getting anything for it.
周二在弗勒家吃过午饭后，他在去董事会的路上经过这幢僻静的建筑时，只是斜眼瞅了瞅，原因就在于此了。 This it was which caused him to gaze askance at the retired building while passing it on his way to the Board on the Tuesday after the lunch at Fleur’s.
连续两个无眠的清晨迫使他要尽早把这些谜团解开，同时也必须要搞清楚现在自己在天佑再保险公司所处的地位。他突然想到，自己四处花钱，有可能已经在某个地方背负债务了，尽管这个可能性微乎其微，但这种压力使他那本来因为担惊受怕而饱受折磨的神经变得更加脆弱敏感。 Two more wakeful early mornings had screwed him to the pitch of bringing his doubts to a head and knowing where he stood in the matter of the P.P.R.S.; and this sudden reminder that he was spending money here, there and everywhere, when there was a possibility, however remote, of financial liability somewhere else, sharpened the edge of a nerve already stropped by misgivings.
他不坐电梯，慢慢爬了两层楼梯，此时在他脑海里已经对那些董事会的同事们做了第十五次分析。 Neglecting the lift and walking slowly up the two flights of stairs, he ‘went over’ his fellow-directors for the fifteenth time.
当然，老勋爵福坦诺能进入董事会是因为他的名声，他难得出席会议，而且最近被称作“废物”。董事长卢克·沙曼爵士似乎整天都在想着不要被人误认为是犹太人。 Old Lord Fontenoy was there for his name, of course; seldom attended, and was what they called ‘a dud’—h’m!—nowadays; the chairman, Sir Luke Sharman, seemed always to be occupied in not being taken for a Jew.
他的鼻梁直挺，可眼皮不免引人怀疑。 His nose was straight, but his eyelids gave cause for doubt.
他的姓氏没有问题，但是他的教名却让人怀疑；他的嗓音粗糙，让人放心，但他的衣着却有可疑的虚饰倾向。 His surname was impeccable, but his Christian dubious; his voice was reassuringly roughened, but his clothes had a suspicious tendency towards gloss.
整体来看，索姆斯认为这个人虽然精明，但绝不能指望他全心全意专注于其他事务。 Altogether a man who, though shrewd, could not be trusted—Soames felt—to be giving his whole mind to other business.
至于“老蒙特”——董事会里安排一个第九代准男爵有什么好处呢？ As for ‘Old Mont’—what was the good of a ninth baronet on a Board?
英国王室法律顾问盖伊·迈里克，是曾经“一起读过书”的三人中的最后一名。毫无疑问，他在法庭上表现优秀，但对于做生意可以说是既没时间又没常识！ Guy Meyricke, King’s Counsel, last of the three who had been ‘together,’ was a good man in court, no doubt, but with no time for business and no real sense of it!
剩下的是那个改变了信仰的教友派信徒，老卡思伯特·莫德吉尔——他家族的名字在上世纪一直是廉洁正直的代名词，所以如今人们依旧机械地把莫德吉尔家的人安排在董事会中——一个耳背、谨慎、干净的老人，为人温和，别无其他。 Remained that converted Quaker, old Cuthbert Mothergill—whose family name had been a by-word for successful integrity throughout the last century, so that people still put Mothergills on to boards almost mechanically—rather deaf, nice clean old chap, and quite bland, but nothing more.
毫无疑问，这群人为人诚实，但却敷衍了事。 A perfectly honest lot, no doubt, but perfunctory.
他们当中没有一个人真正把心思放在事业上！ None of them really giving their minds to the thing!
这些人都在埃尔德森的控制下，或许沙曼除外，但是他也是摇摆不定。 In Elderson’s pocket, too, except perhaps Sharman, and he on the wobble.
埃尔德森本人——是个聪明的家伙，也许还有点儿艺术家的风度，从一开始就担任总经理，业务上样样精通！ And Elderson himself—clever chap, bit of an artist, perhaps; managing director from the start, with everything at his finger-tips!
对！ Yes!
事情坏就坏在这里！ That was the mischief!
渊博的知识和多年的成功，使他具有一定的威望——他们都对他唯命是从，这不足为奇！ Prestige of superior knowledge, and years of success—they all kowtowed to him, and no wonder!
但是像他那样的人有这么一种麻烦，一旦他承认自己犯过错误，那自然就毁掉了他一贯正确的传奇。 Trouble with a man like that was that if he once admitted to having made a mistake he destroyed the legend of his infallibility.
索姆斯自己也算是个一贯正确的人，所以他深知这种不肯承认错误的抑制力是多么强大。 Soames had enough infallibility of his own to realise how powerful was its impetus towards admitting nothing.
10个月前，他来参加董事会时，似乎一切都顺风顺水，汇率跌到了谷底，大家都认为——埃尔德森一年前倡导的“国外合同再保险”政策会随着汇率上涨而变成最值得炫耀的业绩。 Ten months ago, when he had come on to the Board, everything had seemed in full sail; exchanges had reached bottom, so they all thought—the ‘reassurance of foreign contracts’ policy, which Elderson had initiated about a year before, had seemed, with rising exchanges, perhaps the brightest feather in the cap of possibility.
而如今，12个月后，索姆斯暗暗怀疑他们是否清楚自己所背负的风险——而且距离召开股东大会只剩下六周的时间了！ And now, a twelvemonth later, Soames suspected darkly that they did not know where they were—and the general meeting only six weeks off!
或许，就连埃尔德森本人都不了解事态；又或者，假如他了解，那么他就是把本应对全体董事会成员宣布的事封锁起来，让它成为秘密。 Probably not even Elderson knew; or, if he did, he was keeping knowledge which ought to belong to the whole directorate severely to himself.
他面无表情地走进董事会。 He entered the board room without a smile.
所有的人都在——甚至福坦诺勋爵和“老蒙特”也在——“老蒙特”居然放弃了打猎！ All there—even Lord Fontenoy and ‘Old Mont’—given up his spinneys, had he!
索姆斯走到火炉边的位子上坐下。 Soames took his seat at the end on the fireside.
他凝视着埃尔德森，忽然清楚地意识到这个人的地位是多么有利。同时，他也清楚地意识到了天佑再保险公司是多么不堪一击。货币忽涨忽跌，但他们从来没意识到他们肩负的债务——他们只是一味地投机。 Staring at Elderson, he saw, with sudden clearness, the strength of the fellow’s position; and, with equal clearness, the weakness of the P.P.R.S. With this rising and falling currency, they could never know exactly their liability—they were just gambling.
他一手托着下巴，听着会议内容和其他例行汇报，眼睛扫视着在场的每个人——老莫德吉尔、埃尔德森、坐在对面的蒙特、坐在上座的沙曼、福坦诺、迈里克，最后回到自己——这可是今年的一次决定性会议。 Listening to the minutes and other routine business, with his chin clasped in his hand, he let his eyes move from face to face—old Mothergill, Elderson, Mont opposite; Sharman at the head; Fontenoy, Meyricke, back to himself—decisive board of the year.
他不能，也绝不可以置身于一个模棱两可的立场了！ He could not, must not, be placed in any dubious position!
他第一次参加这样的股东大会，绝不能在面对股东时没有自己鲜明的立场。 At his first general meeting on this concern, he must not face the shareholders without knowing exactly where he stood.
他又看了埃尔德森一眼——和善的面庞，光秃的头倒是和尤利乌斯·恺撒有几分相像，表情正常，也没有过分乐观的迹象——实际上，他很像老尼古拉斯·福赛特叔叔，对于上上一代人来说，他的事迹是很好的榜样。 He looked again at Elderson—sweetish face, bald head rather like Julius Caesar’s, nothing to suggest irregularity or excessive optimism—in fact, somewhat resembling that of old Uncle Nicholas Forsyte, whose affairs had been such an example to the last generation but one.
总经理刚刚汇报完，索姆斯就将目光投在昏昏欲睡的老莫德吉尔那张红润的脸上，他说： The managing director having completed his exposition, Soames directed his gaze at the pink face of dosey old Mothergill, and said:
“我认为这些账目没有如实反映我们的实际情况。 “I’m not satisfied that these accounts disclose our true position.
董事长，我要求董事会休会至下周这个时间再继续召开。这一周内，我要求根据本财政年度还没到期的国外合同协议，做出正确详细的报告，并交给董事会的每一位成员。 I want the Board adjourned to this day week, Mr. Chairman, and during the week I want every member of the Board furnished with exact details of the foreign contract commitments which do NOT mature during the present financial year.
我还留意到那些还没到期的钱款都已合并到负债总款之中了。 I notice that those are lumped under a general estimate of liability.
我不赞同这样做。 I am not satisfied with that.
应该把那些没到期的款项分出来。” They ought to be separately treated.”
他的目光掠过埃尔德森转到“老蒙特”的脸上。他继续说：“除非欧洲大陆情况确实好转，而我认为不会有好转（恰恰相反），我敢肯定，那些协议明年就会使我们陷入经济困境。” Shifting his gaze past Elderson to the face of ‘Old Mont,’ he went on: “Unless there’s a material change for the better on the Continent, which I don’t anticipate (quite the contrary), I fully expect those commitments will put us in Queer Street next year.”
“陷入经济困境”的说法引发了大家轻微的怒火，席间传来了脚搓地声、翘着的两腿移动的声响，还有几声清喉声，这使得索姆斯心上涌起一种满足感。他扰乱了他们安于现状的打算，使他们也感受到一点点正在煎熬他的忧虑担心。 The scraping of feet, shifting of legs, clearing of throats which accompany a slight sense of outrage greeted the words ‘Queer Street’; and a sort of satisfaction swelled in Soames; he had rattled their complacency, made them feel a touch of the misgiving from which he himself was suffering.
“我们一向都把所有钱款归在一起计算的，福赛特先生。” “We have always treated our commitments under one general estimate, Mr. Forsyte.”
花言巧语的家伙！ Plausible chap!
“但我认为这是错误的。 “And to my mind wrongly.
这种国外合同业务是一种新兴业务。 This foreign contract business is a new policy.
依我看，现在我们不应该发股息，反而要把今年的利润预备着抵偿明年的某笔亏损。” For all I can tell, instead of paying a dividend, we ought to be setting this year’s profits against a certain loss next year.”
又是一阵刚才那样的骚动声。 Again that scrape and rustle.
“我亲爱的先生，这简直是荒谬！” “My dear sir, absurd!”
索姆斯犹如斗牛犬的鼻子发出呼哧呼哧的声音。 The bulldog in Soames snuffled.
“随你去说！”他说， “So you say!” he said.
“那我能看到那些详细账目吗？” “Am I to have those details?”
“当然了，董事会要看什么账目都可以。 “The Board can have what details it likes, of course.
但允许我就基本问题说明一下，这只是一种估算。 But permit me to remark on the general question that it CAN only be a matter of estimate.
估算时，我们向来都是采取保守的态度。” A conservative basis has always been adopted.”
“这是见仁见智的问题，”索姆斯说，“并且依我看，该用什么态度，这应该由董事会在认真讨论过实际数字后才决定吧。” “That is a matter of opinion,” said Soames; “and in my view it should be the Board’s opinion after very careful discussion of the actual figures.”
“老蒙特”开口了。 ‘Old Mont’ was speaking.
“我亲爱的福赛特，如果我们仔细研究每一份合同，那就得花费一周的时间，也许还不会有任何结果，我们也只是大概计算一个均值。” “My dear Forsyte, to go into every contract would take us a week, and then get us no further; we can but average it out.”
“但在这些账目里，我没有看到，”索姆斯说，“国外投资风险对本国投资风险的相关比例——这在现阶段是一个尤为关键的问题。” “What we have not got in these accounts,” said Soames, “is the relative proportion of foreign risk to home risk—in the present state of things a vital matter.”
董事长说话了。 The Chairman spoke.
“埃尔德森，我想应该不会有太大问题吧！ “There will be no difficulty about that, I imagine, Elderson!
但不管怎样，福赛特先生，我们为了预防将来可能发生的不测——尽管我们希望不会发生这样的事——而取消今年股息的发放，恐怕这不合情理吧。 But in any case, Mr. Forsyte, we should hardly be justified in penalising the present year for the sake of eventualities which we hope will not arise.”
“我不知道，”索姆斯说， “I don’t know,” said Soames.
“在这里我们是根据常识来决定方针政策的，而且我们必须有运用常识的最充分的机会。 “We are here to decide policy according to our common sense, and we must have the fullest opportunity of exercising it.
这就是我的观点。 That is my point.
我们没有足够的信息。” We have not enough information.”
那个“花言巧语的家伙”又开口了： That ‘plausible chap’ was speaking again:
“福赛特先生似乎表现出对于管理层的不信任。” “Mr. Forsyte seems to be indicating a lack of confidence in the management.”
他是在铤而走险吗？ Taking the bull by the horns—was he?
“我究竟能否获得那些信息呢？” “Am I to have that information?”
老莫德吉尔悦耳的声音划破了一片沉寂。 The voice of old Mothergill rose cosy in the silence.
“董事长，或许董事会可以休会，如果必要的话，我还会出席的。 “The Board could be adjourned, perhaps, Mr. Chairman; I could come up myself at a pinch.
我们也许都可以参加。 Possibly we could all attend.
这次情况极为特殊——我们绝对不能冒任何不必要的风险。 The times are very peculiar—we mustn’t take any unnecessary risks.
对于我们来说，国外合同方针毫无疑问是新鲜事物。 The policy of foreign contracts is undoubtedly somewhat new to us.
到目前为止，我们还没有理由对结果有所抱怨。 We have no reason so far to complain of the results.
我可以肯定地说，我们对我们总经理的判断能力绝对有信心。 And I am sure we have the utmost confidence in the judgment of our managing director.
但是，既然福赛特先生已经提出要这样一份资料，那我想我们或许应该有这样一份材料。 Still, as Mr. Forsyte has asked for this information, I think perhaps we ought to have it.
你说呢，勋爵？” What do you say, my lord?”
“下周我来不了。 “I can’t come up next week.
我同意董事长的说法，按照现在的账目，我们不能克扣今年的股息。 I agree with the chairman that on these accounts we couldn’t burke this year’s dividend.
不到万不得已，没必要草木皆兵。 No good getting the wind up before we must.
账目什么时候能有结果，埃尔德森？” When do the accounts go out, Elderson?”
“一切顺的话，本周末就有结果了。” “Normally at the end of this week.”
“现在可不是一切顺利。”索姆斯说， “These are not normal times,” said Soames.
“开诚布公地说，假如我拿不到这份材料，那我就只好提出辞职了。” “To be quite plain, unless I have that information I must tender my resignation.”
他非常了解他们脑子里都想些什么。 He saw very well what was passing in their minds.
新人总是很麻烦——他们会非常愿意接受他的辞呈的——只是在开股东大会之前出现这样的情况，不免有些尴尬，除非他们以“夫人身体欠佳”或类似令人心服口服的理由为借口，但是他会很小心避免他们利用这些借口的。 A newcomer making himself a nuisance—they would take his resignation readily—only it would look awkward just before a general meeting unless they could announce “wife’s ill-health” or something satisfactory, which he would take very good care they didn’t.
董事长冷冷地说： The chairman said coldly:
“那好吧，董事会休会，下周这个时间再召开；到时账目能有结果了吗，埃尔德森？” “Well, we will adjourn the Board to this day week; you will be able to get us those figures, Elderson?”
“肯定能。” “Certainly.”
索姆斯脑海里闪过这样一个念头：“应该请求做一次独立审查。” Into Soames’ mind flashed the thought: ‘Ought to ask for an independent scrutiny.’
但是他环顾四周。 But he looked round.
如果他打算继续留在这里的话，这样做确实有些过分了——何况他并不想辞职——毕竟，这是份好差事，一年1000英镑的收入啊！ Going too far—perhaps—if he intended to remain on the Board—and he had no wish to resign—after all, it was a big thing, and a thousand a year!
不！ No!
千万不能做得太过分！ Mustn’t overdo it!
他一边走，一边略带怀疑地品味着自己的胜利，他根本就不能确定这样做是否能给他带来好处。 Walking away, he savoured his triumph doubtfully, by no means sure that he had done any good.
他这样做只是把他们和埃尔德森更加紧密地绑在了一起。 His attitude had only closed the ‘all together’ attitude round Elderson.
他所处境地的不利因素就在于，除了疑虑的感觉外，他缺乏切实有力的证据，而且仔细考虑一下，就不难看出这纯粹是他感情用事。 The weakness of his position was that he had nothing to go on, save an uneasiness, which when examined was found to be simply a feeling that he hadn’t enough control himself.
除此以外，一个公司总不可能有两个经理吧——你必须要相信你的经理！ And yet, there couldn’t be two managers—you must trust your manager!
他背后响起了一个欢快的声音：“喂，福赛特，刚才你提到不查账就辞职时，我们真是吓了一大跳。 A voice behind him tittupped: “Well, Forsyte, you gave us quite a shock with your alternative.
我记得在董事会还是第一次发生这样的事。” First time I remember anything of the sort on that Board.”
“这个地方让人打不起精神。”索姆斯说。 “Sleepy hollow,” said Soames.
“是啊，我总是打瞌睡。 “Yes, I generally have a nap.
那里面太热了。 It gets very hot in there.
要是能到丛林里就好了。 Wish I’d stuck to my spinneys.
即使现在这么早的时候，丛林也已经长得很茂盛了。” They come high, even as early as this.”
俗不可耐，这个轻浮的准男爵！ Incurably frivolous, this tittupping baronet!
“顺便说一声，福赛特，我想说的是，面对这些现代的节制生育和其他与之相关的事情，确实使人不安啊。 “By the way, Forsyte, I wanted to say: With all this modern birth control and the rest of it, one gets uneasy.
我们不是皇室家族，但你是不是也认为该动员大家传宗接代了？” We’re not the royal family; but don’t you feel with me it’s time there was a movement in heirs?”
索姆斯有同感，但这事关他自己女儿的名声，所以他不想袒露心声。 Soames did, but he was not going to confess to anything so indelicate about his own daughter.
“时间还多着呢。”他嘀咕着。 “Plenty of time,” he muttered.
“福赛特，我不喜欢那条狗。” “I don’t like that dog, Forsyte.”
索姆斯瞪起眼睛。 Soames stared.
“狗！”他说， “Dog!” he said.
“它跟这事有什么关系？” “What’s that to do with it?”
“我希望先有孩子再养狗。 “I like a baby to come before a dog.
狗和诗人一样，会使年轻的女人分心。 Dogs and poets distract young women.
我的祖母在27岁前就已经有5个孩子了。 My grandmother had five babies before she was twenty-seven.
她是一位芒乔伊家的人，出色的芒乔伊家的后代，你记得她们吧——那七个芒乔伊姐妹——每一个都很漂亮。 She was a Montjoy; wonderful breeders, you remember them—the seven Montjoy sisters—all pretty.
老芒乔伊有47个孙儿。 Old Montjoy had forty-seven grandchildren.
福赛特，如今不可能有这样的事了。” You don’t get it nowadays, Forsyte.”
“国家人口过剩了。”索姆斯恶狠狠地说。 “Country’s over-populated,” said Soames grimly.
“多了些不该多的人——像他们那种人应该减少，而我们这种人得增加一些。 “By the wrong sort—less of them, more of ourselves.
这应该是通过立法规定的事情。” It’s almost a matter for legislation.”
“跟你儿子说去吧。”索姆斯说。 “Talk to your son,” said Soames.
“是啊！但你应该知道，他们肯定认为我们因循守旧。 “Ah! but they think us fogeys, you know.
假如我们能够说出生存的原因就好了。 If we could only point to a reason for existence.
但这很难，福赛特，难啊。” But it’s difficult, Forsyte, it’s difficult.”
“他们已经要什么有什么了。”索姆斯说。 “They’ve got everything they want,” said Soames.
“这还不够，我亲爱的福赛特，这些还不够，当今世界的形势使这些年轻人感到局促不安。 “Not enough, my dear Forsyte, not enough; the condition of the world is on the nerves of the young.
英国被打败了，他们说，欧洲完蛋了。 England’s dished, they say, Europe’s dished.
天堂完蛋了，地狱也完蛋了！ Heaven’s dished, and so is Hell!
除了空气，任何事情都没有希望了。 No future in anything but the air.
你不能在忐忑中抚养后代吧，至少，我觉得不行——困难重重啊。” You can’t breed in the air; at least, I doubt it—the difficulties are considerable.”
索姆斯哼了一声。 Soames sniffed.
“但愿新闻媒体业者能够控制那令人生厌的笔。”他说。因为最近一段时间，日报上的恐慌消息愈加减少，他也恢复了福赛特家的古老祥和的安全感。 “If only the journalists would hold their confounded pens,” he said; for, more and more of late, with the decrescendo of scare in the daily Press, he was regaining the old sound Forsyte feeling of security.
“我们只要不管欧洲的事情就好了。”他补充了一句。 “We’ve only to keep clear of Europe,” he added.
“既不介入但又保持中立！ “Keep clear and keep the ring!
福赛特，你这话算是说着了。 Forsyte, I believe you’ve hit it.
与斯堪的纳维亚、荷兰、西班牙、意大利、土耳其——所有那些我们能够通过航海到达的遥远国家保持友好关系。 Good friendly terms with Scandinavia, Holland, Spain, Italy, Turkey—all the outlying countries that we can get at by sea.
让其他国家听天由命。 And let the others dree their weirds.
这可是个好主意！” It’s an idea!”
这家伙怎么这么喋喋不休！ How the chap rattled on!
“我可不是政治家。”索姆斯说。 “I’m no politician,” said Soames.
“保持中立！ “Keep the ring!
这是个新原则。 The new formula.
这正是我们一直没有察觉而又一直在做的！ It’s what we’ve been coming to unconsciously!
至于贸易——说我们非得跟这个或那个国家进行贸易往来——都是在瞎说，我亲爱的福赛特。 And as to trade—to say we can’t do without trading with this country or with that—bunkum, my dear Forsyte.
世界很大——我们能这样做。” The world’s large—we can.”
“我一点儿也不了解此事，”索姆斯说， “I don’t know anything about that,” said Soames.
“我只知道，我们必须舍弃这个国外合同保险。” “I only know we must drop this foreign contract assurance.”
“为什么不把买卖控制在那些可控制的国家范围内呢？ “Why not confine it to the ring countries?
不是‘势力均衡’，而是‘保持中立！’ Instead of ‘balance of power,’ ‘keep the ring’!
这可是一条妙计啊！” Really, it’s an inspiration!”
一条妙计涌上心头，索姆斯匆忙地说： Thus charged with inspiration, Soames said hastily:
“在这儿跟你分手吧，我要去女儿家。” “I leave you here, I’m going to my daughter’s.”
“啊！ “Ah!
我要去儿子家。 I’m going to my son’s.
看看这些苦命的人！” Look at these poor devils!”
一群失业的人手捧钱盒子，在泰晤士河堤旁的黑衣修士桥上慢慢地走着，神情忧郁。 Down by the Embankment at Blackfriars a band of unemployed were trailing dismally with money-boxes.
“革命正在萌芽！ “Revolution in the bud!
有件事总是被忘记，福赛特，这真令人太遗憾了。” There’s one thing that’s always forgotten, Forsyte, it’s a great pity.”
“什么事？”索姆斯阴郁地说。 “What’s that?” said Soames, with gloom.
这家伙看样子要一路喋喋不休到弗勒家！ The fellow would tittup all the way to Fleur’s!
“给那些工人洗洗身，给他们穿上整洁、漂亮的工装裤，教他们像咱们这样与人交流，这样就没有等级感觉了。 “Wash the working-class, put them in clean, pleasant-coloured jeans, teach ‘em to speak like you and me, and there’d be an end of class feeling.
这完全是一个感觉问题。 It’s all a matter of the senses.
你是愿意跟一个穿着干净整齐，谈吐像你我这样的管道工助手同睡一间屋呢，还是喜欢跟一个言语粗俗，浑身散发恶臭的投机奸商同睡一起呢？ Wouldn’t you rather share a bedroom with a clean, neat-clothed plumber’s assistant who spoke and smelled like you than with a profiteer who dropped his aitches and reeked of opoponax?
你当然愿意跟前者了。” Of course you would.”
“我从来没试过，”索姆斯说，“所以我不知道。” “Never tried,” said Soames, “so don’t know.”
“实用主义者！ “Pragmatist!
但请相信我，福赛特——要是工人们能把精力转到洗澡和发音训练上，而不是就政治和经济胡言乱语，那么就会立刻实现平等。” But believe me, Forsyte—if the working class would concentrate on baths and accent instead of on their political and economic tosh, equality would be here in no time.”
“我不需要平等。”索姆斯说着，买了一张去威斯敏斯特的车票。 “I don’t want equality,” said Soames, taking his ticket to Westminster.
那个“喋喋不休”的声音一直跟随他进入地铁的电梯。 The ‘tittupping’ voice pursued him entering the tube lift.
“福赛特，我们一旦拥有了审美平等，我们就不会再要求其他任何平等了。 “Aesthetic equality, Forsyte, if we had it, would remove the wish for any other.
你遇到过幻想变成国王的穷教授吗？” Did you ever catch an impecunious professor wishing he was the King?”
“从没有。”索姆斯一边说，一边翻开报纸。 “No,” said Soames, opening his paper.
第八章 Chapter VIII
比克特 Bicket
成家立业的这两年，使迈克尔·蒙特表面上玩世不恭的性格变得多了几分稳重。 Beneath its veneer of cheerful irresponsibility, the character of Michael Mont had deepened during two years of anchorage and continuity.
他不得不顾及到周围人的事情，而且他把时间安排得满满的。 He had been obliged to think of others; and his time was occupied.
自从他向弗勒妥协的那天起，他就意识到要时时处处对弗勒忍让。他完全认同那句有一定道理的名言：“世界上既然存在亲吻别人的人，那就存在伸出面颊让别人吻的人。”他在家中事事体贴，关心家人，却似乎无法平衡他的公众角色和出版人角色。 Conscious, from the fall of the flag, that he was on sufferance with Fleur, admitting as whole the half-truth: ‘Il y a toujours un qui baise, et l’autre qui tend la joue,’ he had developed real powers of domestic consideration; and yet he did not seem to redress the balance in his public or publishing existence.
他感觉自己在处理事情上过分注重人情关系，而不是金钱。 He found the human side of his business too strong for the monetary.
然而，丹比&温特出版社还在靠他费力支撑着，而且就目前情况来看，没有丝毫破产的迹象——当初索姆斯在听了他自己女婿想要采取一些策略时，做出过这样的断言。 Danby and Winter, however, were bearing up against him, and showed, so far, no signs of the bankruptcy prophesied for them by Soames on being told of the principles which his son-inlaw intended to introduce.
迈克尔发现，出版业与其他任何行业一样，不能太循规蹈矩了。 No more in publishing than in any other walk of life was Michael finding it possible to work too much on principle.
在行动领域处处是客观事实——人、植物，还有矿物。 The field of action was so strewn with facts—human, vegetable and mineral.
就在这周二的下午，在他卖力地就蔬菜、纸张和布料的价格讨价还价过后，他竖起耳朵倾听着一个包装工人的哭诉，因为人们在他的外套口袋里发现了五本《铜币》，显然他要将它们占为己有。 On this same Tuesday afternoon, having long tussled with the price of those vegetable facts, paper and linen, he was listening with his pointed ears to the plaint of a packer discovered with five copies of ‘Copper Coin’ in his overcoat pocket, and the too obvious intention of converting them to his own use.
丹比先生已经把他解雇了——这个工人也没有否认他要把这几本书卖掉，但如果事情放在蒙特先生身上的话，他又会怎样做呢？ Mr. Danby had ‘given him the sack’—he didn’t deny that he was going to sell them, but what would Mr. Mont have done?
他欠了房租——他的妻子在肺炎初痊后要及时补充营养——他很需要钱。 He owed rent—and his wife wanted nourishing after pneumonia—wanted it bad.
“见鬼！”迈克尔想，“假若弗勒肺炎后需要补充营养，我肯定会偷走整套书换钱给她买。” ‘Dash it!’ thought Michael, ‘I’d snoop an edition to nourish Fleur after pneumonia!’
“如今物价这么高，光靠这点儿工资根本养活不了全家。 “And I can’t live on my wages with prices what they are.
蒙特先生，我真的活不下去了，快救救我吧！” I can’t, Mr. Mont, so help me!”
迈克尔在转椅上转来转去。 Michael swivelled.
“可是你想想，比克特，假如我默许了你的偷书行为，那就意味着默许所有的包装工人偷书了，如果大家都这么做，那丹比&温特出版社会怎么样？ “But look here, Bicket, if we let you snoop copies, all the packers will snoop copies; and if they do, where are Danby and Winter?
关门啦。 In the cart.
再说，出版社关门，大家去哪儿？ And, if they’re in the cart, where are all of you?
上街流浪。 In the street.
与其大家流落大街，不如你们中间的一个人去，难道不是吗？” It’s better that one of you should be in the street than that all of you should, isn’t it?”
“是啊，先生，我明白您的话——很有道理，但道理不能当饭吃，肚子吃不饱的时候，人就容易干傻事。 “Yes, sir, I quite see your point—it’s reason; but I can’t live on reason, the least thing knocks you out, when you’re on the bread line.
请您帮我求求丹比先生，让他再给我一次机会。” Ask Mr. Danby to give me another chance.”
“丹比先生总是说，包装工人的工作特别需要诚信，因为我们无法监督它。” “Mr. Danby always says that a packer’s work is particularly confidential, because it’s almost impossible to keep a check on it.”
“您说的对，先生，今后我一定记着您的话，但是看看如今普遍失业的现象，我又没有推荐信，我肯定是不可能再找到工作的。 “Yes, sir, I should feel that in future; but with all this unemployment and no reference, I’ll never get another job.
那我的妻子怎么活啊？” What about my wife?”
迈克尔听到这句话，就如同自己在说：“弗勒怎么办？” To Michael it was as if he had said “What about Fleur?”
他在屋里走来走去，年轻的比克特用忧伤的大眼睛注视着他。 He began to pace the room; and the young man Bicket looked at him with large dolorous eyes.
过了一会儿，他停了下来，双手深深地插在口袋里，耸起肩膀。 Presently he came to a standstill, with his hands deep plunged into his pockets and his shoulders hunched.
“我跟他求求情，”他说，“但我不保证他会同意，他也许会说这样做对别人不公平。 “I’ll ask him,” he said; “but I don’t believe he will; he’ll say it isn’t fair on the others.
你这次拿了五本书，情况不乐观，你清楚——这就意味着你以前干过，是不是？ You had five copies; it’s pretty stiff, you know—means you’ve had ‘em before, doesn’t it?
嗯？” What?”
“唉，蒙特先生，假如能再给我一次机会，我愿意坦白一切。 “Well, Mr. Mont, anything that’ll give me a chance, I don’t mind confessin’.
我以前的确拿过几本，但那都是为了救我妻子的命。 I have ‘ad a few previous, and it’s just about kept my wife alive.
您根本无法想象肺炎对于贫困人家意味着什么。” You’ve no idea what that pneumonia’s like for poor people.”
迈克尔用手捋着头发。 Michael pushed his fingers through his hair.
“你妻子多大了？” “How old’s your wife?”
“很年轻——刚刚20岁。” “Only a girl—twenty.”
20岁！ Twenty!
正好和弗勒同岁！ Just Fleur’s age!
“比克特，我告诉你我打算怎么做。我会把这件事告诉德赛特先生，要是他肯替你求情，也许丹比先生会同意。” “I’ll tell you what I’ll do, Bicket; I’ll put it up to Mr. Desert; if he speaks for you, perhaps it may move Mr. Danby.”
“嗯，蒙特先生，非常感谢您——您是位好人，我们都这么说。” “Well, Mr. Mont, thank you—you’re a gentleman, we all sy that.”
“啊！该死！ “Oh! hang it!
比克特，你完全是靠这五本书接济。 But look here, Bicket, you were reckoning on those five copies.
把这个拿去贴补生活吧，给你妻子买些必需品。 Take this to make up, and get your wife what’s necessary.
但你千万别告诉丹比先生。” Only for goodness’ sake don’t tell Mr. Danby.”
“蒙特先生，我肯定不会欺骗您的——先生，我绝对不会透漏半个字的。 “Mr. Mont, I wouldn’t deceive you for the world—I won’t sy a word, sir.
至于我的妻子——咳！” And my wife—well!”
一声鼻子吸溜声和一阵拖沓的脚步声过后，屋里只剩下迈克尔一人了。他双手往口袋里插得更深，肩膀耸得更高。 A sniff, a shuffle—Michael was alone, with his hands plunged deeper, his shoulders hunched higher.
突然，他笑了起来。 And suddenly he laughed.
怜悯！ Pity!
怜悯是时髦！ Pity was pop!
这一切真滑稽。 It was all dam’ funny.
比克特偷了《铜币》，他反而奖赏了他！ Here he was rewarding Bicket for snooping ‘Copper Coin!’
他忽然特别想尾随着这个小包装工，看看他究竟怎么花这两镑钱——看看那“肺炎”是真的呢，还是这个有着一双忧伤眼睛的人捏造出来的。 A sudden longing possessed him to follow the little packer and see what he did with the two pounds—see whether ‘the pneumonia’ was real or a figment of the brain behind those dolorous eyes.
可是，这不可能！ Impossible, though!
他倒是必须得给威尔弗里德打电话，请他在老丹比那里美言几句。 Instead he must ring up Wilfrid and ask him to put in a word with old Danby.
他的话不管用了。 His own word was no earthly.
他替人说情说得太多了！ He had put it in too often!
比克特！ Bicket!
人们对旁人知之甚少，生活深奥费解，是非颠倒！ Little one knew of anybody, life was deep and dark, and upside down!
诚实算什么？ What was honesty?
生活的压力与反抗的力量对抗——后者胜利了，那么这场战斗的结果才叫诚实！ Pressure of life versus power of resistance—the result of that fight, when the latter won, was honesty!
但为什么反抗呢？ But why resist?
爱人如己——但适可而止！ Love thy neighbour as thyself—but not more!
让一周赚两镑的比克特关爱他，比让一周赚二十四镑的他关爱比克特要难得多，不是吗？…… And wasn’t it a darned sight harder for Bicket on two pounds a week to love him, than for him on twenty-four pounds a week to love Bicket?...
“喂！…… “Hallo!...
威尔弗里德，是你吗？…… That you, Wilfrid?...
我是迈克尔…… Michael speaking....
我们这有个包装工人偷了几本《铜币》。 One of our packers has been sneaking copies of ‘Copper Coin.’
他已经被解雇了——真可怜！ He’s ‘got the sack’—poor devil!
我不知道你愿不愿意替他求求情——老丹比不听我的……是啊，他有一个妻子——跟弗勒同龄，他说她得了肺炎。 I wondered if you’d mind putting in a word for him—old Dan won’t listen to me... yes, got a wife—Fleur’s age; pneumonia, so he says.
无论如何下次不会再偷书了，用我和他共同的感激之情作担保——什么！…… Won’t do it again with yours anyway, insurance by common gratitude—what!...
非常感谢，老朋友，你真是太善良了——你马上就到吗？ Thanks, old man, awfully good of you—will you bob in, then?
我们一起回家吧……啊！ We can go round home together... Oh!
好啊！ Well!
你无论如何一定要来。 You’ll bob in anyway.
再见！” Aurev!”
威尔弗里德真够朋友！ Good chap, old Wilfrid!
他是真正的好朋友——打心眼里说！ Real good chap—underneath!
打心眼里说——是什么呢？ Underneath—what?
放下电话，迈尔克忽然发现一大堆有关景象、气味和声音的稿件。这些稿件与他出版社的原则相悖，所以他习惯性地立即将它们退回。 Replacing the receiver, Michael saw a sudden great cloud of sights and scents and sounds, so foreign to the principles of his firm that he was in the habit of rejecting instantaneously every manuscript which dealt with them.
战争也许“结束”了，但在威尔弗里德的内心和他本人的战争继续着。 The war might be ‘off ‘; but it was still ‘on’ within Wilfrid, and himself.
他拿起电话，说道： Taking up a tube, he spoke:
“丹比先生在吗？ “Mr. Danby in his room?
好的！ Right!
如果他要出去，请立刻通知我。”…… If he shows any signs of flitting, let me know at once.”...
迈克尔和那位年长的合伙人之间存在一定代沟，其深度不亚于两个时代的距离。不过温特先生人到中年，脾气温和，或多或少弥补了一些隔阂。 Between Michael and his senior partner a gulf was fixed, not less deep than that between two epochs, though partially filled in by Winter’s middle-age and accommodating temperament.
除了认为他永远正确之外，迈克尔对丹比先生几乎没有什么异议——菲利普·诺曼·丹比住在坎普登山上的摩天大厦，年已六十，出身名门，有着高高的前额，身材魁梧，神情坚定而又善于深思。 Michael had almost nothing against Mr. Danby except that he was always right—Philip Norman Danby, of Sky House, Campden Hill, a man of sixty and some family, with a tall forehead, a preponderance of body to leg, and an expression both steady and reflective.
或许他的眼睛长得有些太靠近了，鼻子又略微瘦削，但从他比例恰当的五官来看，他倒是位英俊的男子。 His eyes were perhaps rather close together, and his nose rather thin, but he looked a handsome piece in his well-proportioned room.
他正在埋头斟酌批阅一项广告业务，威尔弗里德·德赛特走进来，他抬头看了他一眼。 He glanced up from the formation of a correct judgment on a matter of advertisement when Wilfrid Desert came in.
“嗯，德赛特先生，有什么能为您效劳的？ “Well, Mr. Desert, what can I do for you?
请坐！” Sit down!”
德赛特没坐下，而是看看那几幅版画，看看自己的手指，又看看丹比先生，说道： Desert did not sit down, but looked at the engravings, at his fingers, at Mr. Danby, and said:
“丹比先生，我来这儿的目的就是想让您对那个包装工人高抬贵手。” “Fact is, I want you to let that packer chap off, Mr. Danby.”
“包装工人。 “Packer chap.
哦！ Oh!
啊！ Ah!
比克特。 Bicket.
我猜是蒙特告诉您的吧？” Mont told you, I suppose?”
“是啊，他的妻子年纪轻轻，得了肺炎。” “Yes; he’s got a young wife down with pneumonia.”
“德赛特先生，他们编了好多故事去哄骗我们的朋友蒙特——他心肠太软了。 “They all go to our friend Mont with some tale or other, Mr. Desert—he has a very soft heart.
但是恐怕我不能留下这个人。 But I’m afraid I can’t keep this man.
这样做后患无穷。 It’s a most insidious thing.
为了找出这个漏洞，我们已经花费很长时间了。” We’ve been trying to trace a leak for some time.”
德赛特斜倚着壁炉架，眼睛盯着炉火。 Desert leaned against the mantelpiece and stared into the fire.
“嗯，丹比先生，”他说，“你们那一代人也许喜欢文学中所具有的宽厚仁爱，但在实际生活中你们却是如此冷酷无情。 “Well, Mr. Danby,” he said, “your generation may like the soft in literature, but you’re precious hard in life.
而我们这一代人呢，虽然对文学中具有的宽厚仁爱不屑一顾，但在实际生活中却显得软弱无能。” Ours won’t look at softness in literature, but we’re a deuced sight less hard in life.”
“我可不认为这是冷酷无情，”丹比先生说，“这仅代表公正。” “I don’t think it’s hard,” said Mr. Danby, “only just.”
“您是一位公正的法官吗？” “Are you a judge of justice?”
“我希望如此。” “I hope so.”
“您去体验一下四年的地狱生活，再回来试试。” “Try four years’ hell, and have another go.”
“我确实看不出这之间有什么联系。 “I really don’t see the connection.
德赛特先生，你所体验的生活肯定是不同寻常的。” The experience you’ve been through, Mr. Desert, was bound to be warping.”
威尔弗里德转身盯着他。 Wilfrid turned and stared at him.
“请原谅我这样说话，但是坐在这里自诩公正就更不正常了。 “Forgive my saying so, but sitting here and being just is much more warping.
对于成年人来说，除了他们中的30%，生活简直就是炼狱。” Life is pretty good purgatory, to all except about thirty percent. of grown-up people.”
丹比先生笑了笑。 Mr. Danby smiled.
“没有了最起码的诚实，亲爱的年轻人，我们这一行根本维持不下去。 “We simply couldn’t conduct our business, my dear young man, without scrupulous honesty in everybody.
不区分诚实与否是很不公平的。 To make no distinction between honesty and dishonesty would be quite unfair.
这一点你应该很清楚。” You know that perfectly well.”
“丹比先生，我对任何事情都不甚了解，而且我也不信任那些标榜什么都清楚的人。” “I don’t know anything perfectly well, Mr. Danby; and I mistrust those who say they do.”
“好吧，换句话说，社会要想运作，那么每个行业就一定会有必须遵守的规章原则。” “Well, let us put it that there are rules of the game which must be observed, if society is to function at all.”
德赛特也笑了：“啊！该死的原则！ Desert smiled, too: “Oh! hang rules!
就算帮我一次。 Do it as a favour to me.
谁让我写了那本破书呢。” I wrote the rotten book.”
丹比先生的脸上仍然平静，不过他那双深陷的、聚拢的眼睛闪了闪。 No trace of struggle showed in Mr. Danby’s face; but his deep-set, close-together eyes shone a little.
“能帮您的忙是我的荣幸，但这是一个——关乎良心的问题，可以这么说。 “I should be only too glad, but it’s a matter—well, of conscience, if you like.
我不想起诉那个人。 I’m not prosecuting the man.
但是他必须得离开——仅此而已。” He must leave—that’s all.”
德赛特耸了耸肩膀。 Desert shrugged his shoulders.
“好吧，再见！”说着他走了出去。 “Well, good-bye!” and he went out.
迈克尔站在脚垫上，进退为难。 On the mat was Michael in two minds.
“怎么样？” “Well?”
“没戏。 “No go.
那个老家伙太公正了。” The old blighter’s too just.”
迈克尔挠了挠头发。 Michael stivered his hair.
“在我屋里等五分钟，我去告诉那个可怜的家伙，然后咱俩一起走。” “Wait in my room five minutes while I let the poor beggar know, then I’ll come along.”
“不，”德赛特说，“咱俩不顺道。” “No,” said Desert, “I’m going the other way.”
迈克尔跑下楼找比克特的时候，心里起了猜疑，让他困惑的并不是威尔弗里德的不顺道——他几乎总是这样——而是他说话时的语气和表情。 Not the fact that Wilfrid was going the other way—he almost always was—but something in the tone of his voice and the look on his face obsessed Michael’s imagination while he went downstairs to seek Bicket.
威尔弗里德是个古怪的家伙——一下子变得“阴郁”了！ Wilfrid was a rum chap—he went “dark” so suddenly!
到了地下车间，他问： In the nether regions he asked:
“比克特走了吗？” “Bicket gone?”
“没有，先生，他还在那里。” “No, sir, there he is.”
他站在那里，穿着一件破旧的大衣，苍白瘦长的脸上长着一双不成比例的大眼睛，肩膀耷拉着。 There he was, in his shabby overcoat, with his pale narrow face, and his disproportionately large eyes, and his sloping shoulders.
“非常抱歉，比克特，德赛特先生去替你求情了，但是很遗憾行不通。” “Sorry, Bicket, Mr. Desert has been in, but it’s no go.”
“行不通吗，先生？” “No, sir?”
“振作起来，你会找到工作的。” “Keep your pecker up, you’ll get something.”
“恐怕找不到了，先生。 “I’m afryde not, sir.
嗯，我从心里感谢您，也感谢德赛特先生。 Well, I thank you very ‘eartily; and I thank Mr. Desert.
晚安，先生，再见！” Good-night, sir; and good-bye!”
迈克尔看着他从走廊向外走去，看见他摇摇晃晃地走进一条阴暗的街道。 Michael watched him down the corridor, saw him waver into the dusky street.
“妙极了！”他说着笑了起来…… “Jolly!” he said, and laughed....
迈克尔和他那年长的合伙人对这个让人心生怜悯的故事产生的合理怀疑其实是有失公允的。 The natural suspicions of Michael and his senior partner that a tale was being pitched were not in fact justified.
无论是他的妻子，还是肺炎，都是确凿的事实。此时，比克特正摇晃着身子朝黑衣修士桥走去，他想的不是自己的堕落，也不是丹比先生在此事上坚决的态度，而是回到家里应该如何向妻子交代。 Neither the wife nor the pneumonia had been exaggerated; and wavering away in the direction of Blackfriars Bridge, Bicket thought not of his turpitude nor of how just Mr. Danby had been, but of what he should say to her.
当然，他是肯定不会告诉妻子自己因为偷窃被当场发现而被开除，他必须说是“因为顶撞领班而被解雇的”。但是如今他不应该去顶撞领班，而他又偏偏这么做了，妻子对他会有什么想法呢？ He should not, of course, tell her that he had been detected in stealing; he must say he had ‘got the sack for cheeking the foreman’; but what would she think of him for doing that, when everything as it were depended on his not cheeking the foreman?
他对妻子的爱已经到了一种忧郁的状态，以至于他每天去上班的时候，感觉自己“半个灵魂”留在了妻子躺着的那间屋里。当医生最后跟他说： This was one of those melancholy cases of such affection that he had been coming to his work day after day feeling as if he had ‘left half his guts’ behind him in the room where she lay, and when at last the doctor said to him:
“她会慢慢恢复好的，但这场疾病使她非常虚弱——你必须给她加强营养。”他的种种忧虑一下子变成了坚定的决心，不让自己再忧虑徘徊。 “She’ll get on now, but it’s left her very run down—you must feed her up,” his anxiety had hardened into a resolution to have no more.
在接下来的三周里，他一共“扔掉”18本《铜币》，包括在他大衣里发现的那5本。 In the next three weeks he had ‘pinched’ eighteen ‘Copper Coins,’ including the five found in his overcoat.
他只“选中”德赛特的书，缘于这本书“容易卖”，他现在真后悔为什么当初没有选中其他作者的书。 He had only ‘pitched on’ Mr. Desert’s book because it was ‘easy sold,’ and he was sorry now that he hadn’t pitched on some one else’s.
德赛特先生非常慷慨。 Mr. Desert had been very decent.
他在斯特兰德大街的拐角站住，数了数钱。 He stopped at the corner of the Strand, and went over his money.
加上迈克尔给的两镑钱和工资，他一共有75先令。他走进百货商店，买了一瓶肉冻和一罐加水即食的本杰牌食品。 With the two pounds given him by Michael and his wages he had seventy-five shillings in the world, and going into the Stores he bought a meat jelly and a tin of Benger’s food that could be made with water.
他口袋鼓鼓的，坐上了公共汽车，在萨里区边上他住的那条街道的拐角处下车。 With pockets bulging he took a ‘bus, which dropped him at the corner of his little street on the Surrey side.
他和妻子住在底层两间屋里，一周租金八先令，而他已经欠了三周租金了。 His wife and he occupied the two ground floor rooms, at eight shillings a week, and he owed for three weeks.
“付了吧！”他想，“住到她痊愈了再说吧。” ‘Py that!’ he thought, ‘and have a roof until she’s well.’
再说，他拿着结租金的收据和好吃的给妻子，也好帮助他说出那个消息。 It would help him over the news, too, to show her a receipt for the rent and some good food.
他们一直没有生养小孩，真是万幸！ How lucky they had been careful to have no baby!
他来到地下室。 He sought the basement.
房东太太正在洗一周堆积的衣服。 His landlady was doing the week’s washing.
她怔了一下，对他一下子那么主动地付清租金大为惊讶，接着询问了他妻子的情况。 She paused, in sheer surprise at such full and voluntary payment, and inquired after his wife.
“谢谢您，情况还不错。” “Doing nicely, thank you.”
“哦，这真让人高兴，这下你可以宽宽心了。” “Well, I’m glad of that, it must be a relief to your mind.”
“是啊。”比克特说。 “It is,” said Bicket.
房东太太心想：“他太瘦了——那双眼睛让我一下想到了没有煮过的虾。” The landlady thought: ‘He’s a thread-paper—reminds me of a shrimp before you bile it, with those eyes.’
“给你，这是收据，谢谢你。 “Here’s your receipt, and thank you.
请原谅我曾经多次催你交房租，但是日子确实难以维持啊。” Sorry to ‘ave seemed nervous about it, but times are ‘ard.”
“的确啊，”比克特说， “They are,” said Bicket.
“再见！” “So long!”
他左手拿着肉冻和收据，右手推开了房门。 With the receipt and the meat jelly in his left hand, he opened the door of his front room.
他妻子正坐在一小盆炉火的前面。 His wife was sitting before a very little fire.
她的黑色短发发梢卷曲，自生病以来已经长长了不少。当她回头冲比克特微笑时，她的头发也跟着晃动起来。 Her bobbed black hair, crinkly towards the ends, had grown during her illness; it shook when she turned her head and smiled.
对于比克特来说——这已经不是第一次了——她的微笑有些奇怪，略带忧伤，让人猜不透——好像她看到了旁人无法看到的东西。 To Bicket—not for the first time—that smile seemed queer, ‘pathetic-like,’ mysterious—as if she saw things that one didn’t see oneself.
她叫维多琳。他说：“好些吗，维？ Her name was Victorine, and he said: “Well, Vic.?
肉冻看起来不错，而且房租也结了。” This jelly’s a bit of all right, and I’ve pyde the rent.”
他坐在椅子的扶手上，维多琳把手放在他的膝盖上——苍白细长的胳膊从深色睡衣里伸出来。 He sat on the arm of the chair and she put her hand on his knee—her thin arm emerging blue-white from the dark dressing-gown.
“你怎么样，托尼？” “Well, Tony?”
她的脸——苍白消瘦，上面有一双黑色的大眼睛和两道漂亮的弯眉——是那种“从某个地方看着你，而且它看着你的时候——嗯！就看透你的心思！” Her face—thin and pale with those large dark eyes and beautifully formed eyebrows—was one that “looked at you from somewhere; and when it looked at you—well! it got you right inside!”
此时此刻她就看透了他的心思。他说：“你这会儿呼吸感觉如何？” It got him now and he said: “How’ve you been breathin’?”
“不错——比之前好多了。 “All right—much better.
再过一阵就能出门了。” I’ll soon be out now.”
比克特扭过身子，亲吻着维多琳。 Bicket twisted himself round and joined his lips to hers.
他们吻了许久，这一吻包含了以前三周他对妻子或旁人无法表示的感情。 The kiss lasted some time, because all the feelings which he had not been able to express during the past three weeks to her or to anybody, got into it.
他重新坐好，说：“有些累了，”他盯着炉火，“维，有个坏消息，我被解雇了。” He sat up again, “sort of exhausted,” staring at the fire, and said: “News isn’t bright—lost my job, Vic.”
“啊！ “Oh!
托尼！ Tony!
为什么啊？” Why?”
比克特咽了一下唾沫。 Bicket swallowed.
“因为生意惨淡，公司裁员。” “Fact is, things are slack, and they’re reducin’.”
他心里有个坚定的信念，宁愿把头放在煤气炉里自杀，也绝不能对妻子说实情。 There had surged into his mind the certainty that sooner than tell her the truth he would put his head under the gas!
“啊！亲爱的！ “Oh! dear!
那我们可怎么办啊？” What shall we do, then?”
比克特语气坚定起来。 Bicket’s voice hardened.
“别担心——我会找着工作的。”说着，他还吹起了口哨。 “Don’t you worry—I’ll get something”; and he whistled.
“但你很喜欢那份工作。” “But you liked that job.”
“是吗？ “Did I?
我喜欢那里的同事，但是至于工作嘛——嗨，那算得了什么？ I liked some o’ the fellers; but as for the job—why, what was it?
天天就是在地下室包装书本。 Wrappin’ books up in a bysement all dy long.
我们吃完饭就早点儿休息吧——我感觉现在没有工作的束缚，可以睡上一整周呢。” Let’s have something to eat and get to bed early—I feel as if I could sleep for a week, now I’m shut of it.”
她帮他做好了晚饭，他尽量避免看妻子的脸，担心那会更“让他心痛”！ Getting their supper ready with her help, he carefully did not look at her face for fear it might “get him agyne inside!”
他们是在电车上认识的，结婚刚刚一年。比克特常常感觉新奇，究竟自己身上具有什么魅力，会让妻子嫁给自己！他大她八岁，而且大战期间体检结果是丙下！ They had only been married a year, having made acquaintance on a tram, and Bicket often wondered what had made her take to him, eight years her senior and C3 during the war!
但她一定是爱他的，要不然绝不会这样望着他。 And yet she must be fond of him, or she’d never look at him as she did.
“坐下尝尝刚买的肉冻。” “Sit down and try this jelly.”
他自己吃面包抹黄油，喝可可，他很少吃其他特别的东西。 He himself ate bread and margarine and drank cocoa, he seldom had any particular appetite.
“我告诉你我喜欢什么吧？”他说，“我喜欢澳大利亚中部。 “Shall I tell you what I’d like?” he said; “I’d like Central Austrylia.
我们那儿有一本描述那个地方的书，书上说有很多人移民到那儿了。 We had a book in there about it; they sy there’s quite a movement.
我喜欢晒太阳。 I’d like some sun.
我相信，如果能多晒晒太阳，咱俩的身体肯定比现在更健康。 I believe if we ‘ad sun we’d both be twice the size we are.
维，我希望你脸上有点儿血色。” I’d like to see colour in your cheeks, Vic.”
“去那里要花多少钱呢？” “How much does it cost to get out there?”
“很多的钱，多得我们无法去，这是个难题。 “A lot more than we can ly hands on, that’s the trouble.
但我一直就想去那儿。 But I’ve been thinkin’.
英国快要衰败了。 England’s about done.
像我这样的人数不胜数。” There’s too many like me.”
“不，”维多琳说，“像你的人可不多。” “No,” said Victorine; “there aren’t enough.”
比克特看看她，然后快速将目光移向盘子。 Bicket looked at her face, then quickly at his plate.
“你怎么会喜欢我呢？” “What myde you take a fancy to me?”
“因为你凡事总为别人着想，就是这个原因。” “Because you don’t think first of yourself, that’s why.”
“在认识你之前，我是先考虑自己的。 “Used to before I knew you.
但为了你，维，我愿意做任何事情。” But I’d do anything for you, Vic.”
“吃点儿肉冻吧，特别好吃。” “Have some of this jelly, then, it’s awful good.”
比克特摇摇头。 Bicket shook his head.
“假如一觉醒来，我们已经在澳大利亚中部了，那就好了。”他说， “If we could wyke up in Central Austrylia,” he said.
“但唯一有一件事我能肯定——我们一觉醒来肯定还会在这间破旧的小屋里。 “But there’s only one thing certain, we’ll wyke up in this blighted little room.
没关系，我会找到工作的，挣够去那儿的钱的。” Never mind, I’ll get a job and earn the money yet.”
“我们能不能赌马赚钱呢？” “Could we win it on a race?”
“哦，我现在一共就有47个先令，如果我们输了，你打算住哪儿？ “Well, I’ve only got forty-seven bob all told, and if we lose it, where’ll you be?
你是知道的，你必须要多补充营养。 You’ve got to feed up, you know.
不行，我无论如何要找到一份工作。” No, I must get a job.”
“他们会为你提供一份不错的介绍信吗？会不会呢？” “They’ll give you a good recommend, won’t they?”
比克特站起来，把盘子和杯子摞起来。 Bicket rose and stacked his plate and cup.
“会的，但是那份工作不行了——干的人太多了。” “They would, but that job’s off—overstocked.”
告诉她实情吗？ Tell her the truth?
绝不！ Never!
上帝保佑！ So help him!
他躺在那张一人睡太宽、两人睡太窄的床上，她的头发几乎挨到他的嘴唇。他在心里盘算着该如何跟工会商讨，该怎样找份工作。 In their bed, one of those just too wide for one and just not wide enough for two, he lay, with her hair almost in his mouth, thinking what to say to his Union, and how to go to work to get a job.
一个小时一个小时地过去了，他思来想去，决定要破釜沉舟。 And in his thoughts as the hours drew on he burned his boats.
想要失业救济金，就得跟工会说出困难所在。 To draw his unemployment money he would have to tell his Union what the trouble was.
该死的工会！ Blow the Union!
他不想去跟他们解释情况！ He wasn’t going to be accountable to them!
他自己非常清楚为什么会去偷书，但是这跟别人没关系。当他看着妻子呼吸困难、脸色苍白、身体消瘦，那种感觉没有人能够理解。 HE knew why he’d pinched the books; but it was nobody else’s business, nobody else could understand his feelings, watching her so breathless, pale and thin.
只有依靠自己的拼搏！ Strike out for himself!
150万人都失业了！ And a million and a half out o’ work!
嗯，他们的生活还足以勉强维持两周，说不定会发生什么——他也许会拿一两个先令去冒冒险，说不定会赢钱，这谁都说不准。 Well, he had a fortnight’s keep, and something would turn up—and he might risk a bob or two and win some money, you never knew.
她翻个身继续睡着。 She turned in her sleep.
“对，”他想，“我要再拼一下……” ‘Yes,’ he thought, ‘I’d do it agyne...’
隔天，走了几个小时后，在东方灰蒙蒙的天空下，他来到了灰色的街道。透过大玻璃橱窗，他看见各种各样的水果、一束束谷物、一块块的金属和色彩艳丽的蓝蝴蝶，这一切都映衬在金色的灯光下，原来这些精心布置都是为了宣传澳大利亚。 Next day, after some hours on foot, he stood under the grey easterly sky in the grey street, before a plate-glass window protecting an assortment of fruits and sheaves of corn, lumps of metal, and brilliant blue butterflies, in the carefully golden light of advertised Australia.
比克特从来没有离开过英国半步，也很少离开伦敦，对他来说，这一切似乎意味着站在天堂之外。 To Bicket, who had never been out of England, not often out of London, it was like standing outside Paradise.
办事处的气氛可不是那般宜人，咨询费很是昂贵。但当他拿走几乎烫手的那几本宣传册子时，似乎他离天堂又近了一步——那些宣传册子真是温暖人心。 The atmosphere within the office itself was not so golden, and the money required considerable; but it brought Paradise nearer to take away pamphlets which almost burned his hands, they were so warm.
过后，他和她挤坐在一张扶椅上——瘦人的优势——仔细端详着这些带着魔力的书，啧啧惊叹。 Later, he and she, sitting in the one armchair—advantage of being thin—pored over these alchemised pages and inhaled their glamour.
“你觉得这是真的吗，托尼？” “D’you think it’s true, Tony?”
“即便只有30%是真的，对我来说也够好的了。 “If it’s thirty per cent. true it’s good enough for me.
我们必须想办法去那里。 We just must get there somehow.
亲一下。” Kiss me.”
从大街的拐角处传来了主路上电车和火车的隆隆声，屋里的窗户被强劲又干燥的东风吹得嘎吱作响。这周围的环境使他们愈发想要快些逃到那个点着煤气灯的天堂。 From around the corner in the main road the rumbling of the trams and carts, and the rattling of their window-pane in the draughty dry easterly wind increased their feeling of escape into a gas-lit Paradise.
第九章 Chapter IX
混乱 Confusion
比克特离开两个小时以后，迈克尔摇摇摆摆地回家了。 Two hours behind Bicket, Michael wavered towards home.
老丹比一如既往地正确——信不过自己店里的包装工，还是关店大吉吧！ Old Danby was right as usual—if you couldn’t trust your packers, you might shut up shop!
比克特走后，他心生疑虑了。 Away from Bicket’s eyes, he doubted.
也许这家伙根本就没有妻子！ Perhaps the chap hadn’t a wife at all!
随后，比克特的道德问题让位给了威尔弗里德的怪异举止。 Then Wilfrid’s manner usurped the place of Bicket’s morals.
最近三次会面，威尔弗里德老兄显得唐突而古怪。 Old Wilfrid had been abrupt and queer the last three times of meeting.
他是因为作诗而情绪不稳吗？ Was he boiling-up for verse?
他发现小叮铃在楼梯角那里一动不动，态度十分固执。 He found Ting-a-ling at the foot of the stairs in a conservative attitude.
它似乎在说：“没人抱我，我就不上去，平时早就有人抱我上去了！” “I am not going up,” he seemed saying, “until some one carries me—at the same time it is later than usual!”
“女主人呢，你这个传令官小畜生？” “Where’s your mistress, you heraldic little beast?”
小叮铃抽了抽鼻子。 Ting-a-ling snuffled.
它似乎在说：“如果抱我上去，我就不计较您这句话了。上楼梯太费劲了！” “I could put up with it,” he implied, “if YOU carried me—these stairs are laborious!”
迈克尔把它抱起来。 Michael took him up.
“咱们去找找她吧。” “Let’s go and find her.”
夹在比女主人更硬的手臂下，小叮铃瞪着它那黑玻璃球似的眼睛，尾巴翘起，上面的毛发微微颤动着。 Squeezed under an arm harder than his mistress’, Ting-a-ling stared as if with black-glass eyes; and the plume of his emergent tail quivered.
到了卧室，迈克尔心不在焉地把它丢下，它便垂着尾巴走到自己的角落，愤愤地蹲在那里。 In the bedroom Michael dropped him so absent-mindedly that he went to his corner plume pendent, and couched there in dudgeon.
快开饭了，弗勒还没回来！ Nearly dinner time and Fleur not in!
迈克尔把自己大概记得的她今天的日程安排回想了一遍。 Michael went over his sketchy recollection of her plans.
今天，她约了休伯特·马斯兰德和那个旋转派画家——忘了他叫什么名字了——吃午饭。 To-day she had been having Hubert Marsland and that Vertiginist—what was his name?—to lunch.
那里一定闹得乌烟瘴气，不可开交。 There would have been fumes to clear off.
旋转派画家，像牛奶一样，会在胃里制造碳酸气体！ Vertiginists—like milk—made carbonic acid gas in the lungs!
还不回来！ Still!
都7点半了！ Half-past seven!
难道今晚发生了什么事情？ What was happening to-night?
他们该不会去看L. S. D.写的那部戏了吧？ Weren’t they going to that play of L.S.D.’s?
不对呀，那是明天啊！ No—that was tomorrow!
或许没什么事？ Was there conceivably nothing?
如果这样的话，她自然会尽量缩短非应酬的时间。 If so, of course she would shorten her unoccupied time as much as possible.
他这么保守估计着。 He made that reflection humbly.
迈克尔没有任何奢望，他知道自己很普通，唯一可取之处就是活泼，当然，还有对她的爱。 Michael had no illusions, he knew himself to be commonplace, with only a certain redeeming liveliness, and, of course, his affection for her.
他甚至认为对她的爱是自己的弱点，因为爱，他总是惶恐不安，原则却又极力克制这一点。 He even recognised that his affection was a weakness, tempting him to fussy anxieties, which on principle he restrained.
比如，他会向家里的仆人科克和菲尔普斯询问她何时出去的，这就完全违背了他的原则。 To enquire, for instance, of Coaker or Philps—their man and their maid—when she had gone out, would be thoroughly against that principle.
世事就是如此，自己的事情是否值得关注，这常常让迈克尔困惑不已；可是，世事又是这样，有时，自己的事情才是唯一值得关心的。 The condition of the world was such that Michael constantly wondered if his own affairs were worth paying attention to; but then the condition of the world was also such that sometimes one’s own affairs seemed all that were worth paying attention to.
可实际上，他的事只与弗勒有关，如果他抓得太紧，又怕惹恼了她。 And yet his affairs were, practically speaking, Fleur; and if he paid too much attention to them, he was afraid of annoying her.
他走进更衣室，脱下马甲。 He went into his dressing-room and undid his waistcoat.
他心想：“不妥，如果她发现我‘穿戴整齐’，那未免做得太明显了。” ‘But no!’ he thought; ‘if she finds me “dressed” already, it’ll put too much point on it.’
所以，他又穿上马甲，又下楼去了。 So he did up his waistcoat and went downstairs again.
科克在门厅里。 Coaker was in the hall.
“先生，福赛特先生和劳伦斯爵士大约6点钟来过。 “Mr. Forsyte and Sir Lawrence looked in about six, sir.
蒙特夫人已经出去了。 Mrs. Mont was out.
您准备什么时候开饭？” What time shall I serve dinner?”
“嗯，8点15分左右吧。 “Oh! about a quarter past eight.
我想我们不会出去了。” I don’t think we’re going out.”
他走进客厅，在这间空荡荡的中国式房间里走着，拉开了窗帘。 He went into the drawing-room and passing down its Chinese emptiness, drew aside the curtain.
外面起风了，广场显得又冷又黑，于是他想：“比克特——肺炎——希望她穿那件皮大衣了。” The square looked cold and dark and draughty; and he thought: ‘Bicket—pneumonia—I hope she’s got her fur coat.’
他拿出一支烟，又放了回去。 He took out a cigarette and put it back.
如果她发现我站在窗旁，她又会认为我大惊小怪了。于是他又上楼了，看看她穿没穿皮大衣！ If she saw him at the window she would think him fussy; and he went up again to see if she had put on her fur!
小叮铃仍旧蹲在那里，以为主人回来了，立刻摇尾表示欢迎，一看不对，又失望地停住了。 Ting-a-ling, still couchant, greeted him plume dansetti arrested as at disappointment.
迈克尔打开衣橱。 Michael opened a wardrobe.
她穿了！ She had!
很好！ Good!
就在他打量衣橱时，小叮铃忽然从他身边走过，同时，响起了她的声音：“嗨，亲爱的！” He was taking a sniff round, when Ting-a-ling passed him trottant, and her voice said: “Well, my darling!”
迈克尔希望这是在叫他，立刻从衣橱门后走出来。 Wishing that he was, Michael emerged from behind the wardrobe door.
天啊！ Heaven!
她太美了，被风吹红了面颊！ She looked pretty, coloured by the wind!
他默然地站在那里，若有所思。 He stood rather wistfully silent.
“嗨，迈克尔！ “Hallo, Michael!
我回来晚了。 I’m rather late.
我去俱乐部了，走着回来的。” Been to the Club and walked home.”
迈克尔有种说不出来的感觉，他认为弗勒对自己有所保留。 Michael had a quite unaccountable feeling that there was suppression in that statement.
他也有所保留，说道：“我刚才在那儿，是看你穿没穿大衣出去，天气挺冷的。 He also suppressed, and said: “I was just looking to see that you’d got your fur, it’s beastly cold.
你父亲和准爵爷来过，没吃饭就离开了。” Your dad and Bart have been and went away fasting.”
弗勒脱下大衣，往椅子上一靠。 Fleur shed her coat and dropped into a chair.
“我累了。 “I’m tired.
迈克尔，今晚，你的耳朵竖得特别好看。” Your ears are sticking up so nicely to-night, Michael.”
迈克尔跪了下去，双手搂着她的腰。 Michael went on his knees and joined his hands behind her waist.
她审视着他，眼神奇怪，让他感到不安，还有点儿摸不着头脑。 Her eyes had a strange look, a scrutiny which held him in suspense, a little startled.
“如果你染上肺炎，”他说，“那我就完了。” “If YOU got pneumonia,” he said, “I should go clean out of curl.”
“为什么我偏要得这种病呢？” “Why on earth should I?”
“你不知道这其中的联系——没什么，你不会感兴趣的。 “You don’t know the connection—never mind, it wouldn’t interest you.
我们不出去了，是吗？” We’re not going out, are we?”
“我们当然出去了。 “Of course we are.
今天是艾莉森的每月例会啊。” It’s Alison’s monthly.”
“哦！ “Oh!
哎呀！ Lord!
如果你累了，我们可以不去。” If you’re tired we could cut that.”
“亲爱的！ “My dear!
这可不行！ Impos.!
她请了很多人来。” She’s got all sorts of people coming.”
他忍下了一句轻蔑的话，叹了口气，说道：“那好吧！ Stifling a disparagement, he sighed out: “Right-o!
穿礼服吗？” War-paint?”
“是的，还要穿白马甲。 “Yes, white waistcoat.
我喜欢看你穿白马甲。” I like you in white waistcoats.”
狡猾的小坏蛋！ Cunning little wretch?
他紧紧抱了一下她的腰，然后站起身来。 He squeezed her waist and rose.
弗勒轻轻拍了一下他的手，他感到很满足，朝更衣室走去…… Fleur laid a light stroke on his hand, and he went into his dressing-room comforted....
可是，弗勒在那里静静地坐了至少五分钟——虽然不全是挣扎的情感所致，但却是目前极其混乱的局面造成的。 But Fleur sat still for at least five minutes—not precisely ‘a prey to conflicting emotions,’ but the victim of very considerable confusion.
在刚才的一个小时里，两个男人在她面前做了同一件事情——跪在她膝前，搂住她的腰。 TWO men within the last hour had done this thing—knelt at her knees and joined their fingers behind her waist.
无疑，她去威尔弗里德家的举动过于鲁莽了。 Undoubtedly she had been rash to go to Wilfrid’s rooms.
她一到那里，就发现自己并非想要委身于肉欲。 The moment she got there she had perceived how entirely unprepared she really was to commit herself to what was physical.
他所做的也不过同迈克尔刚才一样。 True he had done no more than Michael.
可是——天哪！——她发觉自己在玩火，也意识到了他的痛苦。 But—Goodness!—she had seen the fire she was playing with, realised what torment he was in.
她告诫他，绝对不能对迈克尔透露一个字，但她的直觉告诉她，如果要他在情和义中间选一个，她毫无胜算。 She had strictly forbidden him to say a word to Michael, but intuitively she knew that in his struggle between loyalties she could rely on nothing.
她感到混乱、惊恐、还有感动，想到同时被两个男人这样深爱着，一丝愉快的暖意不由得涌上心头。她对未来也充满好奇，渴望知道结局。 Confused, startled, touched, she could not help a pleasant warmth in being so much loved by two men at once, nor an itch of curiosity about the upshot.
她不禁叹了口气。 And she sighed.
她增加了一份收藏经验——但是如何进一步增加，而不破坏整个收藏乃至收藏者，她却不知道。 She had added to her collection of experiences—but how to add further without breaking up the collection, and even perhaps the collector, she could not see.
自从上次在夏娃画像前，她对威尔弗里德说了“你要是走了，你就是个傻瓜。等着！”之后，她知道他会期待不久的将来发生什么事情。 After her words to Wilfrid before the Eve: “You will be a fool to go—wait!” she had known he would expect something before long.
他经常请她帮忙鉴定他的“旧货”。 Often he had asked her to come and pass judgment on his ‘junk.’
要是在一个月前，哪怕是一周前，她会想也不想就去了，事后还会和迈克尔讨论这些“旧货”！ A month, even a week, ago she would have gone without thinking more than twice about it, and discussed his ‘junk’ with Michael afterwards!
可是现在，她却反复考虑这件事了，一直到乌烟瘴气的午餐会上，“旋转派画家”、阿玛贝尔·内津和琳达·弗鲁的讨论提醒了她——任何性质的顾虑都是“乏味的”，各种各样的感觉才是“正事”——她可能到现在都想不明白呢。 But now she thought it over many times, and but for the fumes of lunch, and the feeling, engendered by the society of the ‘Vertiginist,’ of Amabel Nazing, of Linda Frewe, that scruples of any kind were ‘stuffy,’ sensations of all sorts ‘the thing,’ she would probably still have been thinking it over now.
大家走后，她才深吸了一口气，同时打开中国式茶柜，拿出电话听筒。 When they departed, she had taken a deep breath and her telephone receiver from the Chinese tea chest.
如果威尔弗里德五点半在家的话，她就去看他的“旧货”。 If Wilfrid were going to be in at half-past five, she would come and see his ‘junk.’
他回答道：“上帝啊！ His answer: “My God!
你会来吗？”这又让她踌躇了。 Will you?” almost gave her pause.
但是，她用“我一定要有普鲁斯特式的巴黎气派”排解了自己的踌躇，动身去了俱乐部。 But dismissing hesitation with the thought: ‘I WILL be Parisian—Proust!’ she had started for her Club.
俱乐部里没有更令她兴奋的事可做，只是在三刻钟的时间里喝了三杯茶，看了三本过期的《时装镜》，看了“三个呆坐在椅子上”的乡村会员的背影，然后特意比约定时间晚了一刻钟动身了。 Three-quarters of an hour, with no more stimulant than three cups of China tea, three back numbers of the ‘Glass of Fashion,’ three back views of country members ‘dead in chairs,’ had sent her forth a careful quarter of an hour behind her time.
他家的门敞开着，威尔弗里德站在楼顶，脸色苍白，就像饱受煎熬的幽灵。 On the top floor Wilfrid was standing in his open doorway, pale as a soul in purgatory.
他轻轻地拉牵着她的手，引她进去。 He took her hand gently, and drew her in.
弗勒有点儿激动，她想：“这事就像这样吗？ Fleur thought with a little thrill: ‘Is this what it’s like?
在斯万家里！” Du cote de chez Swann!’
她松开手，即刻开始打量那些“旧货”，着迷地一件件看起来。 Freeing her hand, she began at once to flutter round the ‘junk,’ clinging to it piece by piece.
这些古老的英国“旧货”颇有点儿庄园气息，其中还散落着几件东方或是第一帝国时期的物件，东西是某个德赛特先人的藏品，这位收藏者若不是一位流浪者，就是曾经出入法兰西宫廷的人。 Old English ‘junk’ rather manorial, with here and there an eastern or First Empire bit, collected by some bygone Desert, nomadic, or attached to the French court.
弗勒不敢坐下，怕他会顺势对自己做出越矩的行为；她也不愿意继续他们在泰特美术馆的那场激烈的谈话。 She was afraid to sit down, for fear that he might begin to follow the authorities; nor did she want to resume the intense talk of the Tate Gallery.
看“旧货”显得很安全，在他不看她的瞬间，她才瞟他一眼。 ‘Junk’ was safe, and she only looked at him in those brief intervals when he was not looking at her.
她知道自己没按照《独身女人》和阿玛贝尔·内津的方式耍手段；事实上，她明白这样离开，会一无所获。 She knew she was not playing the game according to ‘La Garconne’ and Amabel Nazing; that, indeed, she was in danger of going away without having added to her sensations.
她禁不住为威尔弗里德而忧伤；他的目光充满渴望，双唇饱含了苦涩。 And she couldn’t help being sorry for Wilfrid; his eyes yearned after her, his lips were bitter to look at.
后来，她实在看累了，就坐了下来，这时，威尔弗里德扑到她的脚旁。 When at last from sheer exhaustion of ‘junk’ she sat down, he had flung himself at her feet.
她陷入了半梦半醒的状态，用双膝顶着他的胸部，希望这种方式会尽可能安全些。她感觉到了事态的严重性——他如此不顾自己，如此迷恋她。 Half hypnotised, with her knees against his chest, as safe as she could hope for, she really felt the tragedy of it—his horror of himself, his passion for herself.
这是撕心裂肺的痛苦，这种做法不符合大家对她的期望，这种爱也不为这个时代所接受——要怎样脱身，才不会增加彼此的痛苦呢？ It was painful, deep; it did not fit in with what she had been led to expect; it was not in the period, and how—how was she to get away without more pain to him and to herself?
带着她无法回应的一吻离开后，她才意识到刚才那一刻钟才是真爱的生活，但对于自己是否喜欢这种生活，她还不确定…… When she HAD got away, with one kiss received but not answered, she realised that she had passed through a quarter of an hour of real life, and was not at all sure that she liked it....
此刻，她终于安全地呆在自己的房间里，为参加艾莉森的每月例会更衣。她很好奇，如果事情真发展到书上所写的肉欲程度，她又会作何感想呢。 But now, safe in her own room, undressing for Alison’s monthly, she felt curious as to what she would have been feeling if things had gone as far as was proper according to the authorities.
诚然，她体会到的感受还不及任何优秀的文学作品里描绘的十分之一！ Surely she had not experienced one-tenth of the thoughts or sensations that would have been assigned to her in any advanced piece of literature!
这就是幻想破灭，要不然，就是她还不完美，可弗勒无法容忍自己有任何欠缺。 It had been disillusioning, or else she was deficient, and Fleur, could not bear to feel deficient.
然后，她轻轻在肩膀扑了些粉，便把思想集中到艾莉森的每月例会上了。 And, lightly powdering her shoulders, she bent her thoughts towards Alison’s monthly.
尽管艾莉森夫人偶尔也喜欢和年轻人见见面，可像奥布里·格林和琳达·弗鲁这类人，却很少出现在她的聚会上。 Though Lady Alison enjoyed an occasional encounter with the younger generation, the Aubrey Greenes and Linda Frewes of this life were not conspicuous by their presence at her gatherings.
内丝塔·戈斯确实参加过一次，但是一个法律政客和两个文学政客同她接触后，都表示不满。 Nesta Gorse, indeed, had once attended, but one legal and two literary politicos who had been in contact with her, had complained of it afterwards.
她似乎伤了他们的自尊心。 She had, it seemed, rent little spiked holes in the garments of their self-esteem.
大家倒是十分欢迎昔日的文坛巨匠西布莉·斯旺出席例会，可是，斯旺对此类聚会不屑一顾，不愿现身。 Sibley Swan would have been welcome, for his championship of the past, but he seemed, so far, to have turned up his nose and looked down it.
当迈克尔和弗勒进去时，他们发现那里并不是知识分子的聚会，而是有知识的社交人物的聚会。这些人偶尔谈及文艺，却也显出些机敏和才华，只是正如迈克尔所说，他们幸亏是些“不干事的人”。 So it was not the intelligentsia, but just intellectual society, which was gathered there when Fleur and Michael entered, and the conversation had all the sparkle and all the ‘savoir faire’ incidental to talk about art and letters by those who—as Michael put it—“fortunately had not to faire”
“这些人全是捧场的。”他在弗勒耳边轻声低语，“就是他们这些人把艺术家和作家给捧起来的。 “All the same, these are the guys,” he muttered in Fleur’s ear, “who make the names of artists and writers.
今晚的特别节目是什么？” What’s the stunt, to-night?”
原来有一位初登伦敦社交界的女士来唱巴尔干民歌。 It appeared to be the London debut of a lady who sang Balkan folk songs.
但是，右边的角落里摆着四张桥牌桌。 But in a refuge to the right were four tables set out for bridge.
桌边坐满了人。 They were already filled.
还有些人分散站在各处，继续听歌。这其中包括格登·明霍、一位社交界的画家和他的妻子，还有一位正在找工作的雕刻家。 Among those who still stood listening, were, here and there, a Gurdon Minho, a society painter and his wife, a sculptor looking for a job.
弗勒正挤在那位画家的妻子芬特夫人和格登·明霍之间，设法脱身。 Fleur, wedged between Lady Feynte, the painter’s wife, and Gurdon Minho himself, began planning an evasion.
查尔方特先生也来了——就是他没错！ There—yes, there was Mr. Chalfont!
在艾莉森夫人的每月例会上，弗勒对社交环境极具判断力，她从来不在那些艺术家和作家身上浪费时间，因为这些人在随便什么地方都能碰到。 At Lady Alison’s, Fleur, an excellent judge of ‘milieu’ never wasted her time on artists and writers—she could meet THEM anywhere.
在这里，她凭借直觉挑选出最重要的政界和文学界的名流，然后伺机盯住他们。 Here she intuitively picked out the biggest ‘bug,’ politico-literary, and waited to pin him.
她一心想盯住查尔方特先生，却忽视了外面发生的一出闹剧。 Absorbed in the idea of pinning Mr. Chalfont, she overlooked a piece of drama passing without.
迈克尔一直站在上面的楼梯口处，没有什么心情和旁人交谈或者争论，只是靠着栏杆站着，那件白色长马甲让他看上去瘦骨嶙峋。他双手深深地插在裤兜里，望着弗勒那雪白的脖子扭来扭去，听着巴尔干民歌，脑子里却一片空白。 Michael had clung to the top of the stairway, in no mood for talk and skirmish; and, leaning against the balustrade, wasp-thin in his long white waistcoat, with hands deep thrust into his trousers’ pockets, he watched the turns and twists of Fleur’s white neck, and listened to the Balkan songs, with a sort of blankness in his brain.
一声“蒙特！”惊醒了他。 The word: “Mont!” startled him.
威尔弗里德就站在他下面。 Wilfrid was standing just below.
蒙特？ Mont?
他有两年没听到威尔弗里德这样叫他了！ He had not been that to Wilfrid for two years!
“下来。” “Come down here.”
在楼梯中间的平台上，摆有一尊前王室法律顾问莱昂内尔·查韦尔的半身雕塑，这是鲍里斯·斯特拉莫洛斯基的作品。当琼·福赛特不再支持他创作那种反映现实却无利可图的作品后，他就玩世不恭地进入了这一艺术流派。 On that half-landing was a bust of Lionel Charwell, K.C., by Boris Strumolowski, in the genre he had cynically adopted when June Forsyte gave up supporting his authentic but unrewarded genius.
这尊塑像几乎同当年在皇家艺术学院里展出的其他作品没什么区别，现在却成了查韦尔家孩子们的玩具了，他们在上面乱画胡须。 It had been almost indistinguishable from any of the other busts in that year’s Academy, and was used by the young Charwells to chalk moustaches on.
德赛特站在这尊雕像旁，靠墙倚着，眼睛闭着。 Beside this object Desert leaned against the wall with his eyes closed.
他的表情让迈克尔捉摸不透。 His face was a study to Michael.
“什么事，威尔弗里德？” “What’s wrong, Wilfrid?”
德赛特一动不动。 Desert did not move.
“我必须告诉你——我爱上弗勒了。” “You’ve got to know—I’m in love with Fleur.”
“你说什么？” “What!”
“我不想偷偷摸摸。 “I’m not going to play the snake.
我是你的情敌。 You’re up against me.
很抱歉，可情况就是这样！ Sorry, but there it is!
你尽管骂我吧！” You can let fly!”
他脸色惨白，面部肌肉抽搐着。 His face was death-pale, and its muscles twitched.
听到这些话，迈克尔头脑混乱，心乱如麻。 In Michael, it was the mind, the heart that twitched.
这一刻太可怕、太诡异、“太让人恶心”了！ What a very horrible, strange, “too beastly” moment!
这就是他的最好朋友——他的伴郎！ His best friend—his best man!
他下意识地掏出烟盒，又下意识地递给德赛特。 Instinctively he dived for his cigarette case—instinctively handed it to Desert.
两人都不由自主地取出香烟，互相点着了。 Instinctively they both took cigarettes, and lighted each other’s.
然后，迈克尔说： Then Michael said:
“弗勒——知道吗？” “Fleur—knows?”
德赛特点点头，说道：“她不知道我会和你讲——她肯定不让我告诉你。 Desert nodded: “She doesn’t know I’m telling you—wouldn’t have let me.
她没有对不起你的地方——到目前为止。” You’ve nothing against her—yet.”
然后，他继续闭着眼睛，又加了一句，“我可忍不住了。” And, still with closed eyes, he added: “I couldn’t help it.”
这正符合迈克尔的猜测！ It was Michael’s own subconscious thought!
自然！ Natural!
太自然了！ Natural!
傻瓜才看不出来这有多自然呢！ Fool not to see how natural!
接着，他内心一阵疼痛，说：“你告诉我，还算个正人君子，但——你不觉得你现在应该马上离开吗？” Then something shut-to within him, and he said: “Decent of you to tell me; but—aren’t you going to clear out?”
德赛特倚着墙，肩膀微动了一下。 Desert’s shoulders writhed against the wall.
“我之前也这样想，可现在我好像不想这样了。” “I thought so; but it seems not.”
“好像是什么意思？ “Seems?
我听糊涂了。” I don’t understand.”
“如果我知道我没有一点儿机会的话，我当然会离开——可我知道情况并非如此。”这时，他突然看着迈克尔，说道，“你看，咱们都别再伪装了。 “If I knew for certain I’d no chance—but I don’t,” and he suddenly looked at Michael: “Look here, it’s no good keeping gloves on.
我豁出去了，如果可行的话，我会从你身边抢走她。” I’m desperate, and I’ll take her from you if I can.”
“上帝啊！”迈克尔说， “Good God!” said Michael.
“太过分了！” “It’s the limit!”
“好！ “Yes!
你尽管嘀咕吧！ Rub it in!
但是，我告诉你，当想到你和她一起回家，而我却孤独一人，”他发出一声可怕的笑声，“奉劝你还是别嘀咕的好。” But, I tell you, when I think of you going home with her, and of myself,” he gave a dreadful little laugh, “I advise you NOT to rub it in.”
“嗯，”迈克尔说道，“既然这不是陀思妥耶夫斯基的小说，我也没什么好说的了。” “Well,” said Michael, “as this isn’t a Dostoievsky novel, I suppose there’s no more to be said.”
德赛特离开墙壁，把手放在那尊莱昂内尔·查韦尔的半身塑像上。 Desert moved from the wall and laid his hand on the bust of Lionel Charwell.
“至少，你应该知道我把事情告诉你，我已经无路可走了——也可能完全把路堵死了。 “You realise, at least, that I’ve gone out of my way—perhaps dished myself—by telling you.
我向来不干不宣而战的事。” I’ve not bombed without declaring war.”
“可不是。”迈克尔呆呆地说。 “No,” said Michael dully.
“你可以把我的书转给别的出版商。” “You can chuck my books over to some other publisher.”
迈克尔只是耸了耸肩。 Michael shrugged.
“那么，晚安。”德赛特说， “Good-night, then,” said Desert.
“很抱歉，失礼了。” “Sorry for being so primitive.”
迈克尔的目光直视着他的“伴郎”。 Michael looked straight into his ‘best man’s’ face.
他的表情的确痛苦而绝望。 There was no mistaking its expression of bitter despair.
他做了半个手势，“威尔弗里德，”这几个字只说了一半，然后，德赛特下楼了，他就上楼了。 He made a half-movement with his hand, uttered half the word “Wilfrid,” and, as Desert went down, he went upstairs.
迈克尔继续回到原来的位子，倚在栏杆旁，努力让自己相信人生不过是场玩笑，可他做不到。 Back in his place against the balustrade, he tried to realise that life was a laughing matter, and couldn’t.
他目前的处境需要像蛇一样狡猾、狮子一样的勇猛、鸽子一样的温柔，可是他知道自己并不具备这么高的品质。 His position required a serpent’s cunning, a lion’s courage, a dove’s gentleness: he was not conscious of possessing such proverbial qualities.
如果弗勒也能像他爱她那样深爱着他，他的确会同情威尔弗里德。 If Fleur had loved him as he loved her, he would have had for Wilfrid a real compassion.
爱上弗勒是再自然不过的事情！ It was so natural to fall in love with Fleur!
但是她不爱他——哦！不爱，她不爱他！ But she didn’t—oh! no, she didn’t!
迈克尔有个优点——如果这个算是优点的话——他对自己评价很谦虚，对朋友评价很高。 Michael had one virtue—if virtue it be—a moderate opinion of himself, a disposition to think highly of his friends.
他曾经对德赛特评价很高，而且——说来也怪！——一直到现在，他对德赛特的看法也还没有改变。 He had thought highly of Desert; and—odd!—he still did not think lowly of him.
他的这个朋友企图给他致命的一击，挑拨他们夫妻的感情——说得更明白点——煽动他妻子出轨，可他并不认为他是个无赖。 Here was his friend trying to do him mortal injury, to alienate the affection—more honestly, the toleration—of his wife; and yet he did not think him a cad.
