他知道这种宽宏大量是无济于事的。但是，对他而言，意志自由和婚姻自由的原则不只是文学上的概念，也是他天性的一部分。 Such leniency, he knew, was hopeless; but the doctrines of free-will, and free contract, were not to him mere literary conceptions, they were part of his nature.
无论强硬的办法多有用，都不符合他的原则。 To apply duress, however desirable, would not be on his cards.
当看着弗勒正对那个了不起的杰拉尔德·查尔方特施展一些小花招时，迈克尔的心被一种类似于绝望的情感蹂躏着。 And something like despair ravaged the heart of him, watching Fleur’s ingratiating little tricks with the great Gerald Chalfont.
万一她离开他，去找威尔弗里德呢！ If she left him for Wilfrid!
但是，肯定——不会——她的父亲、她的房子、她的狗、她的朋友，她——她的收藏——她不会——她无法放弃这些吧？ But surely—no—her father, her house, her dog, her friends, her—her collection of—of—she would not—could not give THEM up?
可是她如果既要这些，也要威尔弗里德呢！ But suppose she kept everything, Wilfrid included!
不，不！ No, no!
她不会这样的！ She wouldn’t!
在他天性忠诚的头脑里，这种揣测只是一闪而过。 Only for a second did that possibility blur the natural loyalty of his mind.
那么，怎么办呢？ Well, what to do?
告诉她——把事情讲清楚？ Tell her—talk the thing out?
还是静观事态发展？ Or wait and watch?
观望什么呢？ For what?
没有周密的监视，他就无从观察。 Without deliberate spying, he could not watch.
德赛特不会再来他们家了。 Desert would come to their house no more.
不行！ No!
要么开诚布公地讲出来，要么假装什么也没发生——但这就意味着今后头上要悬着一把剑，像达摩克里斯那样生活！ Either complete frankness; or complete ignoring—and that meant living with the sword of Damocles above his head!
不行！ No!
还是应该开诚布公地讲出来！ Complete frankness!
不做背地里捣鬼的事情！ And not do anything that seemed like laying a trap!
他用手抹了下湿漉漉的额头。 He passed his hand across a forehead that was wet.
他们要是在家里，远离这种嘈杂的世界和这些自命不凡的家伙，该有多好！ If only they were at home, away from that squalling and these cultivated jackanapes!
他能进去把她哄出来吗？ Could he go in and hook her out?
没有正当理由，肯定不行！ Impossible without some reason!
他努力思考，想找出个理由！ Only his brain-storm for a reason!
他必须找个理由。 He must just bite on it.
歌唱结束了。 The singing ceased.
弗勒在四处张望。 Fleur was looking round.
现在，她可能要招呼他了！ Now she would beckon!
相反，弗勒朝他这边走了过来。 On the contrary, she came towards him.
他的脑子里不由得出现了一个恶意的想法：“她一定勾引了老查尔方特！” He could not help the cynical thought: ‘She’s hooked old Chalfont!’
他爱她，也了解她的小缺点。 He loved her, but he knew her little weaknesses.
她走到他面前，拽住他的袖子。 She came up and took hold of his sleeve.
“我玩够了，迈克尔，咱们撤吧，行吗？” “I’ve had enough, Michael, let’s slip off; d’you mind?”
“赶快！”他说，“别让他们发现我们！” “Quick!” he said, “before they spot us!”
走在寒冷的室外，他在想：“现在说吗？ In the cold air outside he thought: ‘Now?
还是回家再说？” Or in her room?’
“我认为，”弗勒说，“人们对查尔方特先生的评价太高了——他只不过是个酸腐的文人。 “I think,” said Fleur, “that Mr. Chalfont is overrated—he’s nothing but a mental yawn.
他下周的明天会来吃午饭。” He’s coming to lunch tomorrow week.”
现在不说——回家再说！ Not now—in her room!
“除了艾莉森，你还想请谁与他共进午餐呢？” “Whom do you think to meet him, besides Alison?”
“爵士派的一个也不请。” “Nothing jazzy.”
“当然不请，但也必须请些有魅力的人，迈克尔。 “Of course not; but it must be somebody intriguing, Michael.
真讨厌！有时我觉得这么做真没劲。” Bother! sometimes I think it isn’t worth it.”
迈克尔的心差点儿就不跳了。 Michael’s heart stood still.
这该不会是凶兆吧？难道他所崇拜的这位社会艺术实践家的心里萌生了原始情感了？ Was that a portent—sign of ‘the primitive’ rising within his adored practitioner of social arts?
如果是一小时以前，他会这么说： An hour ago he would have said:
“宝贝，你说得对，这么做确实没什么乐趣而言！” “You’re right, my child; it jolly well isn’t!”
可现在——任何变化都不是好兆头！ But now—any sign of change was ominous!
他挽住她的手臂。 He slipped his arm in hers.
“别担心，不管怎样，我们总会找到合适的人来。” “Don’t worry, we’ll snare the just-right cuckoos, somehow.”
“要是有位中国公使就太好了。”弗勒沉思着，“加上明霍和准爵爷——四位男士，两位女士——刚刚好。 “A Chinese Minister would be perfect,” mused Fleur, “with Minho and Bart—four men—two women—cosy.
我去和准爵爷说。” I’ll talk to Bart.”
迈克尔打开他们家的前门。 Michael had opened their front door.
弗勒从他身边进去。他在外面徘徊了一会儿，望着天空中的点点繁星和一排排法国梧桐树。这时，他看到树边站着一个一动不动的人影，那人衣领遮到眼睛下面，用帽子盖住了眼睛。 She passed him; he lingered to see the stars, the plane trees, a man’s figure motionless, collared to the eyes, hatted down to them.
“威尔弗里德!”他想，“西班牙式的！ ‘Wilfrid!’ he thought: ‘Spain!
为何是西班牙式的？ Why Spain?
所有挣扎着的可怜人——爱情——该死的爱情！” And all poor devils who are in distress—the heart—oh! darn the heart!’
他关上了门。 He closed the door.
可是，随后他要打开另一扇窗，再没有比这更提不起劲的事了。 But soon he had another to open, and never with less enthusiasm.
弗勒坐在椅子扶手上，凝望着壁炉。她身穿那件淡紫色的睡衣，有时她只是为了配合屋内的色调才穿这件睡衣。 Fleur was sitting on the arm of a chair, in the dim lavender pyjamas she sometimes wore just to keep in with things, staring at the fire.
迈克尔站在那里，看看她，再看看其中一面墙镜中的自己——穿着她给买的那件黑白相间、丑角似的睡衣。 Michael stood, looking at her and at his own reflection beyond in one of the five mirrors—white and black, the pierrot pyjamas she had bought him.
“戏剧中的人物，”他想道，“戏剧中的人物！ ‘Figures in a play,’ he thought, ‘figures in a play!
这一切是真的吗？” Is it real?’
他走过去，坐在椅子另一边的扶手上。 He moved forward and sat on the chair’s other arm.
“该死！”他喃喃自语道， “Hang it!” he muttered.
“我要是安提诺乌斯就好了！” “Wish I were Antinous!”
于是，他从扶手滑进椅子里，坐在她身后，万一她不想让自己看到她的脸呢。 And he slipped from the arm into the chair, to be behind her face, if she wanted to hide it from him.
“威尔弗里德已经告诉我了。”他平静地说。 “Wilfrid’s been telling me,” he said, quietly.
总算把憋在心里的话说出来了！ Off his chest!
现在是什么状况？ What now?
他看到弗勒的脖子和脸涨得通红。 He saw the blood come flushing into her neck and cheek.
“哦！ “Oh!
什么事——‘他告诉你’是什么意思？” What business—how do you mean ‘telling you’?”
“就是说他爱上你了——没说别的——没别的事可说了，是吗？” “Just that he’s in love with you—nothing more—there’s nothing more to tell, is there?”
说着，他把脚缩到椅子里，用双手抱着膝盖。 And drawing his feet up on to the chair, he clasped his hands hard round his knees.
他已经——已经问了一个问题了！ Already—already he had asked a question!
稳住！ Bite on it!
稳住！ Bite on it!
然后他闭上了眼睛。 And he shut his eyes.
“当然。”弗勒慢条斯理地说，“当然没别的事了。 “Of course,” said Fleur, very slowly, “there’s nothing more.
如果威尔弗里德愿意这样犯傻的话。” If Wilfrid chooses to be so silly.”
愿意！ Chooses!
这个词听着这么接近“愚蠢”，似乎对一个如此执著于你的人很不公平！ The word seemed unjust to one whose own ‘silliness’ was so recent—so enduring!
而且——奇怪的是，他的心情并没因此而好起来。 And—curious! his heart wouldn’t bound.
听到这话，他本应该高兴起来的！ Surely it ought to have bounded at her words!
“那么，这就是威尔弗里德的结局了吗？” “Is that the end of Wilfrid, then?”
“结局? “The end?
我不清楚。” I don’t know.”
啊！ Ah!
当激情奔放之时，谁知道会发生什么呢？ Who knew anything—when passion was about?
“嗯。”他一边紧紧抱住自己，一边说，“别忘了我非常爱你！” “Well,” he said, holding himself hard together, “don’t forget I love you awfully!”
他看到她眼睛眨了一下，肩膀耸了耸。 He saw her eyelids flicker, her shoulders shrugging.
“我像是会忘记吗？” “Am I likely to?”
痛苦、热忱、简单——究竟是哪一种？ Bitter, cordial, simple—which?
突然间，她把双手伸过来，抓住他的耳朵。 Suddenly her hands came round and took him by the ears.
她一边紧紧捏住他的耳朵，一边低头向下看着他，哈哈一笑。 Holding them fast she looked down at him, and laughed.
可是，他的心还是没有高兴起来。 And again his heart WOULD not bound.
如果她不是牵着他的鼻子走，她——！ If she did not lead him by the nose, she—!
但他还是一把把她搂进椅子里。 But he clutched her to him in the chair.
淡紫色和黑白相间的颜色混在一起——她回应着他的吻。 Lavender and white and black confused—she returned his kiss.
可这是不是发自内心的？ But from the heart?
谁知道？ Who knew?
反正迈克尔不知道。 Not Michael.
第十章 Chapter X
一个运动家过世了 Passing of a Sportsman
见女儿不在家，索姆斯有些失落，他说道：“我等等吧。”随后，他坐在那张翠绿色长椅的中间，全然没有注意到火炉前的小叮铃。此时，它正在打盹，将阿玛贝尔·内津的那句“太机灵”的恭维给忘到脑后去了。 Soames, disappointed of his daughter, said: “I’ll wait,” and took his seat in the centre of the jade green settee, oblivious of Ting-a-ling before the fire, sleeping off the attentions of Amabel Nazing, who had found him ‘just too cunning.’
索姆斯头发灰白，神情自若。他跷起二郎腿，双目间蹙起一道皱纹。他心里想着埃尔德森、世界局势以及为何总有事情发生。 Grey and composed, with one knee over the other, and a line between his eyes, he thought of Elderson and the condition of the world, and of how there was always something.
他越想就越觉得奇怪，自己怎么会傻到加入一个与外国有合同往来的董事会。 And the more he thought, the more he wondered why he had ever been such a flat as to go on to a Board which had anything to do with foreign contracts.
所有为巩固英国财富做出贡献的19世纪的古老智慧、一切摒弃冒险主义、专注个人事业的福赛特哲学以及反对国家采取任何徒劳无益之举的民族利己主义精神，都在他心里静静翻腾着。 All the old wisdom that in the nineteenth century had consolidated British wealth, all the Forsyte philosophy of attending to one’s own business, and taking no risks, the close-fibred national individualism which refused to commit the country to chasing this wild goose or that, held within him silent demonstration.
就政治而言，英国企图影响欧洲大陆，这是犯了方针性错误；同样，就经济而言，天佑再保险公司扩展海外业务，也是犯了方针性错误。 Britain was on the wrong tack politically to try and influence the Continent, and the P.P.R.S. on the wrong tack monetarily to insure business outside Britain.
福赛特家的人都渴望延续有条不紊的个人发展道路。 The special instinct of his breed yearned for resumption of the straight and private path.
千万别干自己无法控制的事情！ Never meddle with what you couldn’t control!
“老蒙特”曾说过：“保持中立！” ‘Old Mont’ had said: “Keep the ring!”
根本没那么回事：管好自己的事！ Nothing of the sort: Mind one’s own business!
这才是真正的“法则”。 That was the real ‘formula.’
他突然觉得小腿那里有什么东西在动——小叮铃正在闻他的裤子。 He became conscious of his calf—Ting-a-ling was sniffing at his trousers.
“哦！”索姆斯说， “Oh!” said Soames.
“是你啊！” “It’s you!”
小叮铃吐着舌头，前爪搭在椅背上。 Placing his forepaws against the settee, Ting-a-ling licked the air.
“要抱你起来吗？”索尔斯说， “Pick you up?” said Soames.
“你太大了。” “You’re too long.”
他顿时有种被喜欢的感觉，丝丝暖意涌上了他的心头。 And again he felt that faint warmth of being liked.
“我身上一定有什么吸引它的地方。”他一边想，一边抓着他的后颈，把它拎到坐垫上。 ‘There’s something about me that appeals to him,’ he thought, taking him by the scruff and lifting him on to a cushion.
这小东西盯着他，似乎在说：“只有你和我。”——这条可爱的中国狗！ “You and I,” the little dog seemed saying with his stare—Chinese little object!
“我应该辞职。”索姆斯想。 ‘I shall resign,’ thought Soames.
可是，威妮弗雷德、伊莫金以及罗杰家族和尼古拉斯家族中的一些人怎么办？因为他当董事，这些人才把资金投进来的。 But what about Winifred, and Imogen, and some of the Rogers and Nicholases who had been putting money into this thing because he was a director?
他希望他们可别像一群羊似的跟在他后面。 He wished they wouldn’t follow him like a lot of sheep!
他从长椅上站起来。 He rose from the settee.
没什么好等的了，他得马上去格林街找威妮弗雷德谈谈。 It was no good waiting, he would walk on to Green Street and talk to Winifred at once.
尽管股票已经跌了一点儿，她必须再次抛出。 She would have to sell again, though the shares had dropped a bit.
然后，没与小叮铃告别，他就出去了。 And without taking leave of Ting-a-ling, he went out.
去年整整一年，他都在享受人生。 All this last year he had almost enjoyed life.
他会去某个地方走走、坐坐，总能收获某种安慰，至少一周一次。就像从前在蒂莫西家一样，这对他保持良好的精神状态大有益处。 Having somewhere to come and sit and receive a certain sympathy once at least a week, as in old days at Timothy’s, was of incalculable advantage to his spirit.
弗勒的出嫁，让他感觉心里空落落的。可是索姆斯发现，每周看一次心肝宝贝，要比她总在自己身边更好些。 In going from home Fleur had taken most of his heart with her; but Soames had found it almost an advantage to visit his heart once a week rather than to have it always about.
还有一些其他事情也让他感觉很轻松。 There were other reasons conducing to light-heartedness.
那个可恶的外国佬——普罗斯珀·普罗芳——早就不知跑到什么地方去了。自那以后，他的妻子明显比以前安分多了，也很少嘲笑别人了。 That diabolical foreign chap, Prosper Profond, had long been gone he didn’t know where, and his wife had been decidedly less restive and sarcastic ever since.
她迷上了一种叫做“库埃”的东西，身体变得结实起来。 She had taken up a thing they called Coue, and grown stouter.
她经常开车。 She used the car a great deal.
总之，她比以前更爱呆在家里了。 Altogether she was more domestic.
之后，他和画家高更和解了。高更的画作市价稍有下跌，但索姆斯认为他的作品依然值得关注，所以他又买了3幅。 Then, too, he had become reconciled to Gauguin—a little slump in that painter had convinced him that he was still worth attention, and he had bought three more.
高更的画会再次升值！ Gauguin would rise again!
索姆斯对自己追逐涨价的念头感到遗憾，自己欣赏他就可以了。 Soames almost regretted his intuition of that second coming, for he had quite taken to the chap.
他画中的色彩，你一旦看习惯了，就非常具有吸引力。 His colour, once you got used to it, was very attractive.
特别是有一幅画，高更自己认为没什么，但却有一种让人流连其中的感觉。 One picture, especially, which meant nothing so far as he could see, had a way of making you keep your eyes on it.
当索姆斯想到价格一涨他就得转手时，心里挺不是滋味的。 He even felt uneasy when he thought of having to part with the thing at an enhanced price.
但最重要的是，索姆斯一直感觉很好，安妮特给他带来了重返青春般的乐趣，食物也给他带来了极大的快乐，他全心享受着金钱带来的满足感。 But, most of all, he had been feeling so well, enjoying a recrudescence of youth in regard to Annette, taking more pleasure in what he ate, while his mind dwelt almost complacently on the state of money.
英镑升值了；工党很安静！ The pound going up in value; Labour quiet!
现在劳合·乔治下台了，保守党即将稳稳地掌几年权了。 And now they had got rid of that Jack-o’-lantern, they might look for some years of solid Conservative administration.
他一边穿过圣詹姆斯公园，朝格林街的方向走去，一边在想，他怎么会涉足一个自己无法掌控的公司——唉，真是见鬼了！ And to think, as he did, stepping across St. James’ Park towards Green Street, that he had gone and put his foot into a concern which he could not control, made him feel—well, as if the devil had been in it!
在皮卡迪利大街，他沿着公园一边蹑手蹑脚地向前走，习惯性地瞧一眼“伊昔姆”俱乐部。 In Piccadilly he moused along on the Park side, taking his customary look up at the ‘Iseeum’ Club.
俱乐部拉着窗帘，帘缝间透出狭长而舒缓的灯光。 The curtains were drawn, and chinks of light glowed, long and cosy.
这时，他想起——有人说乔治·福赛特病了。 And that reminded him—some one had said George Forsyte was ill.
是啊，他有几个月没见到他坐在这里的飘窗边了。 Certainly he had not seen him in the bay window for months past.
唉，乔治总是能吃能喝。 Well, George had always eaten and drunk too much.
他穿过马路，朝俱乐部下面走去。他突然很怀念过去，自己也莫名其妙，像是患上思乡病了——他不由地停住脚步，登上俱乐部的台阶。 He crossed over and passed beneath the Club; and a sudden feeling—he didn’t know what—a longing for his own past, a sort of nostalgia—made him stop and mount the steps.
“乔治·福赛特在俱乐部里吗？” “Mr. George Forsyte in the Club?”
头发灰白的长脸门卫瞪着他看。索姆斯早在上世纪80年代就见过他了。 The janitor stared, a grey-haired, long-faced chap, whom he had known from away back in the ‘eighties.
他说：“先生，福赛特先生的确病得很重。 “Mr. Forsyte, sir,” he said, “is very ill indeed.
他们都说他的病不会好了。” They say he won’t recover, sir.”
“什么？”索姆斯说， “What?” said Soames.
“没人和我提过啊。” “Nobody told me that.”
“他病得很重——的确很严重。 “He’s very bad—VERY bad indeed.
是心脏病。” It’s the heart.”
“心脏病！ “The heart!
他在哪儿？” Where is he?”
“在他家，先生。转过那个拐角就是了。 “At his rooms, sir; just round the corner.
他们都说，医生已经宣布放弃了。 They say the doctors have given him up.
俱乐部的人都会想念他。 He WILL be missed here.
我认识他40年了。 Forty years I’ve known him.
他是老派人，一名了不起的品酒师和评马师。 One of the old school, and a wonderful judge of wine and horses.
人们常说，没有人会永远活着，可是我从来没想过会看到他离开。 We none of us last for ever, they say, but I never thought to see HIM out.
因为他一直精力非常旺盛，先生，可这就是事实。” Bit too full-blooded, sir, and that’s a fact.”
索姆斯微微一惊，他竟然不知道乔治住在哪里，他一直以为他就安居在俱乐部上面的飘窗旁。 With a slight shock Soames realised that he had never known where George lived, so utterly anchored had he seemed to that bay window above.
“请把他寓所的门牌号告诉我。”他说。 “Just give me the number of his rooms,” he said.
“贝尔维尔街11号，先生。我真希望您能看到他好一些。 “Belville Row—No. 11, sir; I’m sure I hope you’ll find him better.
我真想听他讲笑话——真的很想听。” I shall miss his jokes—I shall, indeed.”
转过街角，进入贝尔维尔街，索姆斯快速地算了一下。 Turning the corner into Belville Row, Soames made a rapid calculation.
乔治今年66岁，只比他小一岁！ George was sixty-six, only one year younger than himself!
如果乔治真的快不行了，那太不合常理了！ If George was really in extremis it would be quite unnatural!
“是生活不节制的结果。”他想，“乔治总是寻欢作乐！ ‘Comes of not leading a careful life,’ he thought; ‘always rackety—George!
我什么时候给他立的遗嘱来着？” When was it I made his will?’
就他所知，乔治把钱都留给兄弟姐妹了——他也没别人可给了。 So far as he remembered, George had left his money to his brothers and sisters—no one else to leave it to.
骨肉亲情在索姆斯心里激荡着，这是一种家人的本能。 The feeling of kinship stirred in Soames, the instinct of family adjustment.
乔治和他向来不和——两人性格相反——可是总得为他料理后事啊，除了索姆斯，谁会做这些事呢？他一生中不是已经料理过那么多福赛特家的丧事了吗？ George and he had never got on—opposite poles of temperament—still he would have to be buried, and who would see to it if not Soames, who had seen to so many Forsyte burials in his time?
他想起乔治曾给他起过一个绰号——“殡仪事务承办人”！ He recalled the nickname George had once given him, ‘the undertaker!’
哼！ H’m!
这是因果报应！ Here was poetical justice!
贝尔维尔街！ Belville Row!
Ah!
11号——真像是单身汉的住所！ No. 11—regular bachelor-looking place!
他一边按门铃，一边在想：“女人们！” And putting his hand up to the bell, he thought: ‘Women!’
乔治一生在女人方面做了些什么？ What had George done about women all his life?
一个男子出来开门，他身着黑色燕尾服，十分沉默。 His ring was answered by a man in a black cut-away coat with a certain speechless reticence.
“我堂弟乔治·福赛特先生呢？ “My cousin, Mr. George Forsyte?
他怎么样？” How is he?”
那人抿了抿嘴唇，说： The man compressed his lips.
“恐怕过不了今晚了，先生。” “Not expected to last the night, sir.”
索姆斯感觉自己的心好像被人抓了一把。 Soames felt a little clutch beneath his Jaeger vest.
“神志清醒吗？” “Conscious?”
“清醒，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“你能把我的名片给他看看吗？ “Could you show him my card?
也许他会想见我。” He might possibly like to see me.”
“先生，您能在这儿稍等一会儿吗？” “Will you wait in here, sir?”
索姆斯走进一间低矮的房间。那房间的护墙板镶到齐胸那么高，板线以上挂着一幅幅版画。 Soames passed into a low room panelled up to the level of a man’s chest, and above that line decorated with prints.
乔治是个收藏家！ George—a collector!
索姆斯从来没想过他还有这个爱好！ Soames had never supposed he had it in him!
放眼望去，四面墙壁上既有色彩画也有黑白画，既有旧画也有新作。画的是赛马运动和职业拳击运动。 On those walls, wherever the eye roved, were prints coloured and uncoloured, old and new, depicting the sports of racing and prize-fighting!
整个红色墙壁上，几乎没有一处是空的！ Hardly an inch of the red wall space visible!
正当索姆斯想仔细看看标价时，他发现房间里不只他一个人。 About to examine them for marks of value, Soames saw that he was not alone.
一位女子正坐在火炉前面一张靠背很高的椅子里。由于灯光微弱，他看不出她的年龄。她一只手撑在椅子的扶手上，一只手拿手帕贴着脸。 A woman—age uncertain in the shaded light—was sitting in a very high-backed chair before the fire with her elbow on the arm of it, and a handkerchief held to her face.
索姆斯看着她，偷偷地抽了一下鼻子。 Soames looked at her, and his nostrils moved in a stealthy sniff.
“肯定不是女主人。”他想， ‘Not a lady,’ he thought.
“十之八九有什么关系。” ‘Ten to one but there’ll be complications.’
这时，那个穿礼服的男子低声说： The muffled voice of the cut-away man said:
“我带您进去，先生。” “I’m to take you in, sir.”
索姆斯抹了一把脸，跟在后面。 Soames passed his hand over his face and followed.
他现在走进的卧室和刚才那间形成了鲜明的对比。 The bedroom he now entered was in curious contrast.
一个大柜占据了整整一面墙，柜上只有碗厨和抽屉。 The whole of one wall was occupied by an immense piece of furniture, all cupboards and drawers.
此外，房间里只有一个摆着银制品的梳妆台、一个放在壁炉里的、开着的电暖炉，还有对面的一张床。 Otherwise there was nothing in the room but a dressing-table with silver accoutrements, an electric radiator alight in the fireplace, and a bed opposite.
壁炉上只有一幅画，索姆斯有意无意地瞥了一眼。 Over the fireplace was a single picture, at which Soames glanced mechanically.
什么？ What!
中国画！ Chinese!
画中有一只侧坐着的白毛猴子，伸出一只爪子捏着一块挤碎的水果皮。 A large whitish sidelong monkey, holding the rind of a squeezed fruit in its outstretched paw.
猴子的脸上带着胡须，正用它那棕褐色的、类似于人类的眼睛回头望着。 Its whiskered face looked back at him with brown, almost human eyes.
他这位不懂艺术的堂弟，为什么会买这件东西，还挂在正对着床的位置？ What on earth had made his inartistic cousin buy a thing like that and put it up to face his bed?
他转身看了看床上躺着的病人。 He turned and looked at the bed’s occupant.
蒙塔古·达尔蒂这样称赞过当时正值盛年的他：“他是这群人里唯一的运动健将。”而今，他却只能盖着薄被躺在那里，浮肿的身体在薄被下显现出来。 “The only sportsman of the lot,” as Montague Dartie in his prime had called him, lay with his swollen form outlined beneath a thin quilt.
那张熟悉的牛肉色的脸变得像月亮一般苍白且浮肿。那双眼睛依稀带着嘲弄人的眼神，却已是皱纹密布、黑圈重重。这一切让索姆斯大吃一惊。 It gave Soames quite a turn to see that familiar beef-coloured face pale and puffy as a moon, with dark corrugated circles round eyes which still had their japing stare.
这时，床上传来一个声音，嘶哑而低沉，仍旧带有老福赛特家的特质，说道： A voice, hoarse and subdued, but with the old Forsyte timbre, said:
“你好，索姆斯！ “Hallo, Soames!
你来给我量棺材尺寸吗？” Come to measure me for my coffin?”
索姆斯摆了摆手，让这句话过去了。看着乔治硬装出滑稽的神情，他心里很不是滋味。 Soames put the suggestion away with a movement of his hand; he felt queer looking at that travesty of George.
他们一直合不来，但是——！ They had never got on, but—!
他平缓而不动声色地说道： And in his flat, unemotional voice he said:
“好了，乔治！ “Well, George!
你会好起来的。 You’ll pick up yet.
你还没老呢。 You’re no age.
我能为你做些什么吗？” Is there anything I can do for you?”
乔治苍白的嘴唇挤出一丝笑容。 A grin twitched George’s pallid lips.
“给我立份遗嘱附录。 “Make me a codicil.
梳妆台的抽屉里有纸。” You’ll find paper in the dressing table drawer.”
索姆斯取出一张“伊昔姆”俱乐部的信纸。 Soames took out a sheet of ‘Iseeum’ Club notepaper.
他站在桌边，用尖头钢笔把遗嘱附录的开头写好，然后回头望着乔治。 Standing at the table, he inscribed the opening words of a codicil with his stylographic pen, and looked round at George.
乔治的声音虽然嘶哑，却独具吸引力。 The words came with a hoarse relish.
“我那3匹老马给小瓦尔·达尔蒂，因为他是福赛特家族里唯一懂得区分马和驴的人。” “My three screws to young Val Dartie, because he’s the only Forsyte that knows a horse from a donkey.”
他发出一阵沙哑而低沉的笑声，在索姆斯听来很是瘆人。 A throaty chuckle sounded ghastly in the ears of Soames.
“你是怎么写的？” “What have you said?”
索姆斯读道：“兹将我3匹赛马赠予我的亲戚瓦勒列斯·达尔蒂，萨塞克斯郡沃斯顿人，因他深谙识马之术。” Soames read: “I hereby leave my three racehorses to my kinsman, Valerius Dartie, of Wansdon, Sussex, because he has special knowledge of horses.”
又一阵沙哑低沉的笑声。 Again the throaty chuckle.
“你真是一个冷冰冰的家伙，索姆斯。 “You’re a dry file, Soames.
继续。 Go on.
给住在克莱尔蒙特林荫街12号的米利·莫伊尔12，000镑，免付遗产税。” To Milly Moyle, of 12, Claremont Grove, twelve thousand pounds, free of legacy duty.”
索姆斯差点儿停下来吹口哨。 Soames paused on the verge of a whistle.
就是隔壁房间里的那个女人！ The woman in the next room!
乔治那捉弄人的眼神变得阴郁忧愁起来。 The japing in George’s eyes had turned to brooding gloom.
索姆斯禁不住说了一句：“这是一大笔钱啊。” “It’s a lot of money,” Soames could not help saying.
乔治病弱的声音显得很生气。 George made a faint choleric sound.
“照这样写，否则我全都留给她。” “Write it down, or I’ll leave her the lot.”
索姆斯写下了。 Soames wrote.
“就这些吗？” “Is that all?”
“是的。 “Yes.
念一下！” Read it!”
索姆斯念了。 Soames read.
他又听到一阵低沉而嘶哑的笑声。 Again he heard that throaty chuckle.
“这是一桩自作自受的事。 “That’s a pill.
你可别把这句也写进遗嘱里。 You won’t let THAT into the papers.
叫那家伙进来，就由你俩做见证人吧。” Get that chap in, and you and he can witness.”
还没等索姆斯开门，门就开了，那个男子走了进来。 Before Soames reached the door, it was opened and the man himself came in.
“先生，那位——嗯——牧师来了。”他语气轻蔑地说， “The—er—vicar, sir,” he said in a deprecating voice, “has called.
“您愿意见他吗？” He wants to know if you would like to see him.”
乔治回过头，灰色的大眼睛转来转去。 George turned his face, his fleshy grey eyes rolled.
“替我问候他。”他说，“告诉他，我们葬礼上见。” “Give him my compliments,” he said, “and say I’ll see him at the funeral.”
男子鞠了一躬，出去了，屋里一片寂静。 With a bow the man went out, and there was silence.
乔治说：“现在，把他叫进来。 “Now,” said George, “get him in again.
我不知道什么时候就走了。” I don’t know when the flag’ll fall.”
于是索姆斯招呼那人进来。 Soames beckoned the man in.
当遗嘱附录签好字，男子出去了以后，乔治说道： When the codicil was signed and the man gone, George spoke:
“遗嘱附录放你那里，务必确保她拿到这笔钱。 “Take it, and see she gets it.
我相信你，索姆斯，你就是这一点好。” I can trust you, that’s one thing about you, Soames.”
索姆斯把遗嘱附录放进口袋里，心里很不是滋味。 Soames pocketed the codicil with a very queer sensation.
“你想再见见她吗？”他说。 “Would you like to see her again?” he said.
乔治抬头看着他，过了很久才回答： George stared up at him a long time before he answered.
“不必了。有什么用呢？ “No. What’s the good?
抽屉里有雪茄，递给我一支吧。” Give me a cigar from that drawer.”
索姆斯打开抽屉。 Soames opened the drawer.
“你可以抽烟吗？”他说。 “Ought you?” he said.
乔治咧嘴笑了笑。 George grinned.
“我平生没做过什么该做的事，现在也不打算做。 “Never in my life done what I ought; not going to begin now.
帮我把烟头剪掉吧。” Cut it for me.”
索姆斯剪掉烟头。 Soames nipped the end of the cigar.
他心想：“不能给他火柴。 ‘Shan’t give him a match,’ he thought.
我可负不起这个责任啊。” ‘Can’t take the responsibility.’
可是乔治没朝他要火柴。 But George did not ask for a match.
他静静地躺着，苍白的嘴唇含着那支没有点着的雪茄，眼睑弯成了一道弧形。 He lay quite still, the unlighted cigar between his pale lips, the curved lids down over his eyes.
“再见。”他说，“我要打个盹。” “Good-bye,” he said, “I’m going to have a snooze.”
“再见。”索姆斯说， “Good-bye,” said Soames.
“我——我希望——你——你很快就——” “I—I hope—you—you’ll soon—”
乔治又睁开那双眼睛——眼神定定的，忧伤而戏谑，它们似乎把希望和慰藉一扫而光。 George reopened his eyes—fixed, sad, jesting, they seemed to quench the shams of hope and consolation.
索姆斯急忙转身离开了。 Soames turned hastily and went out.
他感到很不舒服，不知不觉走进了刚才那间起居室。 He felt bad, and almost unconsciously turned again into the sitting-room.
那个女人依然那个姿势坐着；空气里依旧弥漫着浓重的香气。 The woman was still in the same attitude; the same florid scent was in the air.
索姆斯拿起留在那里的雨伞，走了出去。 Soames took up the umbrella he had left there, and went out.
“这是我的电话号码。”他对等在走廊里的仆人说，“有事通知我。” “This is my telephone number,” he said to the servant waiting in the corridor; “let me know.”
那个男子鞠了一躬。 The man bowed.
索姆斯走出贝尔维尔街。 Soames turned out of Belville Row.
每次与乔治分手，总是有种被嘲笑的感觉。 Never had he left George’s presence without the sense of being laughed at.
今天又被他嘲笑了吗？ Had he been laughed at now?
那个遗嘱附录是他开的最后一次玩笑吗？ Was that codicil George’s last joke?
如果今天下午他没去，乔治还会立遗嘱附录吗？把1/3的遗产留给那个高背椅子里坐着的香艳女子，而不是留给家人？ If he had not gone in this afternoon, would George ever have made it, leaving a third of his property away from his family to that florid woman in the high-backed chair?
索姆斯越想越觉得奇怪。 Soames was beset by a sense of mystery.
一个将死之人还会开玩笑吗？ How could a man joke at death’s door?
从某种程度上说，这也算是英雄所为吧。 It was, in a way, heroic.
他会葬在哪里呢？ Where would he be buried?
总会有人安排的——弗朗西或是尤斯塔斯。 Somebody would know—Francie or Eustace.
而当他们最终得知那个坐在椅子里的女人得到12，000镑，他们会作何感想呢! And what would they think when they came to know about that woman in the chair—twelve thousand pounds!
“如果能得到那幅白猿，我一定要搞到手。”他突然想到， ‘If I can get hold of that white monkey, I will,’ he thought suddenly.
“那是件好东西。” ‘It’s a good thing.’
那只白猿的眼睛，那个干瘪的水果——人的一生就是一个布满心酸的玩笑吗？乔治真的比我更深刻吗？ The monkey’s eyes, the squeezed-out fruit—was life all a bitter jest and George deeper than himself?
他按响了格林街的门铃。 He rang the Green Street bell.
达尔蒂夫人表示很抱歉，因为卡迪盖夫人刚请她去一起吃晚饭，而且牌戏四缺一，她会去凑个局。 Mrs. Dartie was very sorry, but Mrs. Cardigan had called for her to dine and make a fourth at the play.
索姆斯独自一人吃晚饭。 Soames went in to dinner alone.
他坐在那张擦得锃亮的餐桌旁，边吃边想。每到吃饭的时候，蒙塔古·达尔蒂不是在楼下睡觉，就是悄悄地溜出去了。 At the polished board below which Montague Dartie had now and again slipped, if not quite slept, he dined and brooded.
“我相信你，索姆斯，你就是这一点好。” “I can trust you, that’s one thing about you, Soames.”
这话听着很舒服，同时也刺痛了他。 The words flattered and yet stung him.
那个讥讽的玩笑开得多深刻啊！ The depths of that sardonic joke!
这会是一件震惊家族的事件，而且他还受托执行此事！ To give him a family shock and trust him to carry the shock out!
乔治居然在一个浑身散发着薄荷香气的女人身上花了12，000镑。 George had never cared twelve thousand pounds for a woman who smelled of patchouli.
不！ No!
这是对福赛特家族以及索姆斯本人的最后一次嘲弄！ It was a final gibe at his family, the Forsytes, at Soames himself!
哼！曾经伤害或嘲笑过他的人——艾琳、波辛尼、老乔利恩和小乔利恩以及现在的乔治，一个个都完蛋了。 Well! one by one those who had injured or gibed at him—Irene, Bosinney, old and young Jolyon, and now George, had met their fates.
去世的、快要去世的，或是在英属哥伦比亚的！ Dead, dying, or in British Columbia!
他仿佛又看见了他堂弟的眼睛，那双在未点着的雪茄上方的定定的、忧郁的、戏弄人的眼睛——可怜的家伙！ He saw again his cousin’s eyes above that unlighted cigar, fixed, sad, jesting—poor devil!
他站起身来，惴惴不安地拉开窗帘。 He got up from the table, and nervously drew aside the curtains.
夜色美好却寒冷。 The night was fine and cold.
人死后会怎样呢？ What happened to one—after?
乔治过去经常说他自己前世是查理二世的厨师！ George used to say that he had been Charles the Second’s cook in a former existence!
可是灵魂再生说全是胡说，是无稽之谈！ But reincarnation was all nonsense, weak-minded theorising!
不过，如果人去世后能继续存在的话，人们是很乐意继续存在的。 Still, one would be glad to hold on if one could, after one was gone.
继续存在，在弗勒身边！ Hold on, and be near Fleur!
那是什么声音？ What noise was that?
厨房里开着留声机！ Gramophone going in the kitchen!
猫不在家，老鼠就嚣张——！ When the cat was away, the mice—!
人都一样——尽其所能去得到，付出的越少越好。 People were all alike—take what they could get, and give as little as they could for it.
好吧！他想吸根烟。 Well! he would smoke a cigarette.
他借着蜡烛点着了香烟——威妮弗雷德喜欢在烛光下吃饭，这又是一种“时尚”——他又想到：“他嘴里还含着那根雪茄吗？” Lighting it at a candle—Winifred dined by candle-light, it was the ‘mode’ again—he thought: ‘Has he still got that cigar between his teeth?’
乔治，滑稽的家伙——一生都这样滑稽！ A funny fellow, George—all his days a funny fellow!
他看着一个无意形成的烟圈——颜色很蓝，他从不把烟吸进去！ He watched a ring of smoke he had made without intending to—very blue, he never inhaled!
没错！ Yes!
乔治活得太放荡了，否则他一定可以再多活20年——太放荡了！ George had lived too fast, or he would not have been dying twenty years before his lime—too fast!
嗯，它在那里，他正希望有只猫能陪他聊聊天！ Well, there it was, and he wished he had a cat to talk to!
他从壁炉上拿下一只小怪物。 He took a little monster off the mantelboard.
这是战后那年，他的外甥贝内迪克特在一个东方市场上买的。它有一双绿眼睛——“不是祖母绿，”索姆斯想，“就是块不值钱的石头！” Picked up by his nephew Benedict in an Eastern bazaar the year after the War, it had green eyes—’Not emeralds,’ thought Soames, ‘some cheap stone!’
“先生，您的电话。” “The telephone for you, sir.”
他进入门厅，拿起听筒。 He went into the hall and took up the receiver.
“喂？” “Yes?”
“福赛特先生去世了，先生——医生说他是在睡梦中走的。” “Mr. Forsyte has passed away, sir—in his sleep, the doctor says.”
“哦！”索姆斯说，“他嘴里有没有一支雪——？ “Oh!” said Soames: “Had he a cig—?
非常感谢。” Many thanks.”
他挂断了电话。 He hung up the receiver.
去世了！ Passed away!
于是，他心神不安地摸了摸胸口衣袋里的那封遗嘱附录。 And, with a nervous movement, he felt for the codicil in his breast pocket.
第十一章 Chapter XI
冒险 Venture
一周来，比克特眼睁睁地瞅着“他要找的工作”像鳗鱼一样从他面前溜走，又像燕子一样从他面前翩翩飞过，永远可望而不可即。 For a week Bicket had seen ‘the job,’ slippery as an eel, evasive as a swallow, for ever passing out of reach.
在这7天时间里，他花了一英镑维持生计，3个先令赌马，就剩下24先令了。 A pound for keep, and three shillings invested on a horse, and he was down to twenty-four bob.
外面刮的已经是西南风了，并且维多琳也已经出了一次门了。 The weather had turned sou’-westerly and Victorine had gone out for the first time.
这两件事使他放心了些，但是失业的感觉紧紧地束缚着他，单纯只是想活下去的渴望强烈得令人害怕，还有一种由于发自内心的抗争而产生的焦虑正折磨着他，啃噬着他的脑细胞。 That was something off his mind, but the cramp of the unemployed sensation, that fearful craving for the means of mere existence, a protesting, agonising anxiety, was biting into the very flesh of his spirit.
如果一周或是两周之内他还找不到工作，那就只能去济贫院或是开煤气自杀了。 If he didn’t get a job within a week or two, there would be nothing for it but the workhouse, or the gas.
“煤气，”比克特想道，“要是她愿意的话，我也没问题。 ‘The gas,’ thought Bicket, ‘if she will, I will.
我已经受够了。 I’m fed up.
毕竟，也没什么大不了的。 After all, what is it?
要是能死在她的怀里，我死而无憾。” In her arms I wouldn’t mind.’
然而，他本能地觉得把脑袋放在煤气灶下不是那么容易，于是在周一的晚上他脑中闪过一丝灵光。 Instinct, however, that it was not so easy as all that to put one’s head under the gas, gave him a brainwave that Monday night.
气球——今天在牛津街看到的那个卖气球的家伙！ Balloons—that chap in Oxford Street today!
为什么不呢？ Why not?
小赌一把的资本他还是有的，而且卖气球也不需要申请小贩许可证。 He still had the capital for a flutter in them, and no hawker’s licence needed.
后半夜，他的大脑像松鼠一样活跃，想的全都是卖彩色气球能获得的极大的、无法估量的好处，这些好处是其他生意比不了的。 His brain, working like a squirrel in the small hours, grasped the great, the incalculable advantage of coloured balloons over all other forms of commerce.
你肯定不会错过那卖气球的人的——他就在那里，谁都能看得到，面前飘荡着许多颜色亮丽的气球！ You couldn’t miss the man who sold them—there he was for every eye to see, with his many radiant circumferences dangling in front of him!
利润不会太高，他已经算过了——一个六便士的彩色气球可以赚一个便士，三个两便士的小气球也能赚一个便士。可是卖气球的人还活着，也许他还会给别人讲述他的悲惨故事，以免让人眼红他的生意。 Not much profit in them, he had gathered—a penny on a sixpenny globe of coloured air, a penny on every three small twopenny globes; still their salesman was alive, and probably had pitched him a poor tale for fear of making his profession seem too attractive.
是站在桥上，还是在交通要道上——不，还是上圣保罗教堂去！ Over the Bridge, just where the traffic—no, up by St. Paul’s!
他知道那里有一条小路，可以让他退后一两码，就像那个站在牛津街的家伙那样！ He knew a passage where he could stand back a yard or two, like that chap in Oxford Street!
但是，对睡在他身边的妻子，他什么也没说。 But to the girl sleeping beside him he said nothing.
等事情有眉目了再告诉她。 No word to her till he had thrown the die.
这意味着拿最后一点儿小钱去赌一把。 It meant gambling with his last penny.
为了能够活下去，他每天得卖掉——3打大气球和4打小气球，一周也就赚26先令，除非那个卖气球的家伙骗他。 For a bare living he would have to sell—why, three dozen big and four dozen small balloons a day would only be twenty-six shillings a week profit, unless that chap was kidding.
靠这些钱是去不了“澳大利亚”的！ Not much towards ‘Austrylia’ out of that!
再说，这也算不上是一种职业——维多琳会大吃一惊的！ And not a career—Victorine would have a shock!
但是现在成败在此一举——他必须试试，然后利用空余时间继续找工作。 But it was neck or nothing now—he must try it, and in off hours go on looking for a job.
于是，在第二天下午2点的时候，我们这位体格单薄的资本家，带着一个盛着4打大气球和7打小气球的盘子，站在了圣保罗教堂外面。他的肚子里空空如也，口袋里只剩下两先令。 Our thin capitalist, then, with four dozen big and seven dozen small on a tray, two shillings in his pocket, and little in his stomach, took his stand off St. Paul’s at two o’clock next day.
他慢慢地吹起两个大气球和三个小气球，把气球口扎紧了，让这些紫红色、绿色和蓝色的气球在自己面前飘荡。 Slowly he blew up and tied the necks of two large and three small, magenta, green and blue, till they dangled before him.
然后，他满嘴都是橡胶的味道，两眼突出，靠后站在人行道边石上，瞅着川流不息的过往人群。 Then with the smell of rubber in his nostrils, and protruding eyes, he stood back on the kerb and watched the stream go by.
看到大多数路人都会转身看看自己，他感到很是满意。 It gratified him to see that most people turned to look at him.
但是，第一个和他说话的却是一个警察，他说： But the first person to address him was a policeman, with:
“我想你不能站在这儿。” “I’m not sure you can stand there.”
比克特没有回答，他觉得自己的嗓子很干。 Bicket did not answer, his throat felt too dry.
他听人说过警察。 He had heard of the police.
难道他选错了做生意的地方？ Had he gone the wrong way to work?
他猛吸了一大口气，然后说：“给我们一个机会吧，警官。我已经一贫如洗了。 Suddenly he gulped, and said: “Give us a chance, constable; I’m right on my bones.
要是我挡着道了，您让我站哪儿都行。 If I’m in the way, I’ll stand anywhere you like.
我头一次干这个买卖。我在这个世上就剩下一个老婆和两个先令了。” This is new to me, and two bob’s all I’ve got left in the world besides a wife.”
这位大个子警察上上下下地打量了他一番。 The constable, a big man, looked him up and down.
“好吧。我们看着办吧。 “Well, we’ll see.
如果没有人反对的话，我也不会找你麻烦的。” I shan’t make trouble for you if no one objects.”
比克特满怀感激之情地望着那位警官。 Bicket’s gaze deepened thankfully.
“太谢谢您了。”他说，“拿一个给您的小孩玩去吧——让我高兴一下。” “I’m much obliged,” he said; “tyke one for your little girl—to please me.”
“我会买一个的，”那警察说，“就算给你开张了。 “I’ll buy one,” said the policeman, “and give you a start.
再过一个小时我就下班了，到时候你给我准备好就行——一个大气球，要紫红色的。” I go off duty in an hour, you ‘ave it ready—a big one, magenta.”
说完，他就走开了。 He moved away.
比克特能看见他值勤。 Bicket could see him watching.
比克特静静地站在排水沟的旁边，用那双大眼睛盯着每一位过路人的脸，还时不时紧张地用他那瘦削的手指去碰碰他的货品。 Edging into the gutter, he stood quite still; his large eyes clung to every face that passed; and, now and then, his thin fingers nervously touched his wares.
要是维多琳能看见他就好了！ If Victorine could see him!
他的精神为之一振。 All the spirit within him mounted.
天哪！他得设法摆脱这种生活，到阳光下去，过真正的生活！ By Golly! he would get out of this somehow into the sun, into a life that was a life!
他已经站了将近两个小时了，重心从一只脚换到另一只脚，卖掉了四个大气球和五个小气球——赚了六个便士——这时，索姆斯刚好路过这里。他改走这条道去天佑再保险公司董事会，是为了去教训一下那些连威廉·古尔丁·英格勒家族都不知道的家伙。 He had been standing there nearly two hours, shifting from foot to unaccustomed foot, and had sold four big and five small—sixpenny worth of profit—when Soames, who had changed his route to spite those fellows who couldn’t get past William Gouldyng Ingerer, came by on his way to the P.P.R.S. board.
他这辈子有个习惯，每逢路过圣保罗教堂，总要看上两眼。这时，一个怯生生的低语吓了他一跳：“气球，先生，最好的气球。”他四下看了看，十分惊奇地停下了脚步。 Startled by a timid murmur: “Balloon, sir, best quality,” he looked round from that contemplation of St. Paul’s which had been his lifelong habit, and stopped in sheer surprise.
“气球！”他说道， “Balloon!” he said.
“我要气球干什么？” “What should I want with a balloon?”
比克特笑了。 Bicket smiled.
那些绿色、蓝色、橙色的气球和索姆斯那副阴沉的表情实在有点儿不相称，这一点连他都能感觉出来。 Between those green and blue and orange globes and Soames’ grey self-containment there was incongruity which even he could appreciate.
“孩子们喜欢它们——不占分量，先生，放在您的马甲口袋里就行。” “Children like ‘em—no weight, sir, waistcoat pocket.”
“也许吧，”索姆斯说，“可我没有小孩。” “I daresay,” said Soames, “but I’ve no children.”
“孙儿孙女也行啊，先生。” “Grandchildren, sir.”
“也没有孙儿孙女。” “Nor any grandchildren.”
“那谢谢您了，先生。” “Thank you, sir.”
索姆斯迅速地瞥了他一眼，他惯于以此评定那些穷人的品性。 Soames gave him one of those rapid glances with which he was accustomed to gauge the character of the impecunious.
“一个可怜的、没有恶意的小东西！”他想，“喂，给我两个气球——多少钱？” ‘A poor, harmless little rat!’ he thought “Here, give me two—how much?”
“一个先令，先生，非常感谢。” “A shilling, sir, and much obliged.”
“不用找零了。”索姆斯一边说，一边匆忙地走了过去。他自己也很吃惊。 “You can keep the change,” said Soames hurriedly, and passed on, astonished.
他不明白自己究竟为什么会买这样的东西，还付了两倍以上的价钱。 Why on earth he had bought the things, and for more than double their price, he could not conceive.
他记得以前自己从没做过这样的事情。 He did not recollect such a thing having happened to him before.
太奇怪了！ Extremely peculiar!
可是他突然明白自己为什么这样做了。 And suddenly he realised why.
那个人谦卑、温驯——在共产主义大行其道的今天，这样的人值得鼓励。 The fellow had been humble, mild—to be encouraged, in these days of Communistic bravura.
这小家伙毕竟是——站在资本主义这边的，他把钱投资在这些气球上了！ After all, the little chap was—was on the side of Capital, had invested in those balloons!
做买卖了！ Trade!
然后，他再次抬眼向圣保罗大教堂望去，把那邋遢东西塞进外衣口袋里。 And, raising his eyes towards St. Paul’s again, he stuffed the nasty-feeling things down into his overcoat pocket.
有人会把这东西拿出来的，还会奇怪他怎么会有这样的东西！ Somebody would be taking them out, and wondering what was the matter with him!
得了，他还有别的事情要考虑呢！…… Well, he had other things to think of!...
而比克特则兴高采烈地目送他离开。 Bicket, however, stared after him, elated.
这两只气球获利250%以上——这感觉好极了。 Two hundred and fifty odd percent. profit on those two—that was something like.
由于从他这里路过的妇女不多，他一度有些泄气，现在则不那么难过了——毕竟，女人懂得钱的价值，她们是一个先令也不会多给的！ The feeling, that not enough women were passing him here, became less poignant—after all, women knew the value of money, no extra shillings out of them!
要是能多来几个像这样帽子锃亮的老百万富翁就好了！ If only some more of these shiny-hatted old millionaires would come along!
到6点钟的时候，比克特一共赚了3先令零8便士，其中有一半是索姆斯贡献的。他开始一边叹气一边给气球放气。他小心翼翼地把这一只只气球解开，看着这些彩色的希望一个个瘪下去，然后把它们收进托盘的抽屉里。 At six o’clock, with a profit of three and eightpence, to which Soames had contributed just half, he began to add the sighs of deflating balloons to his own; untying them with passionate care he watched his coloured hopes one by one collapse, and stored them in the drawer of his tray.
他把托盘夹在腋下，拖着疲惫的双腿，朝大桥方向走去。 Taking it under his arm, he moved his tired legs in the direction of the Bridge.
要是干上一整天的话，该能挣四五个先令的——嗯，刚好够他们活下去，也许会时来运转！ In a full day he might make four to five shillings—Well, it would just keep them alive, and something might turn up!
不管怎样，他现在是自己的主人了，无需再为老板或是工会做什么。 He was his own master, anyway, accountable neither to employer nor to union.
想到这一点，再加上他早饭过后就什么也没吃，他心里感到一阵莫名的轻松感。 That knowledge gave him a curious lightness inside, together with the fact that he had eaten nothing since breakfast.
“不知道他是不是个市议员，”他想，“据说那些市议员都是喝甲鱼汤的。” ‘Wonder if he was an alderman,’ he thought; ‘they say those aldermen live on turtle soup.’
快到家的时候，他为不知如何处理这个托盘而紧张起来。 Nearing home, he considered nervously what to do with the tray?
怎么才能不让维多琳知道他已经加入了资本家的队伍，还在排水沟旁站了一天呢？ How prevent Victorine from knowing that he had joined the ranks of Capital, and spent his day in the gutter?
真倒霉！ Ill luck!
她就站在窗口！ She was at the window!
他必须得装成一副高高兴兴的样子。 He must put a good face on it.
于是，他吹着口哨走了进去。 And he went in whistling.
“那是什么，托尼？”她指着那个托盘问道。 “What’s that, Tony?” she said, pointing to the tray.
“啊哈！ “Ah! ha!
精彩的表演——看这个！ Great stunt—this!
看这里！” Look ‘ere!”
他从托盘里拿出一个气球，吹了起来。 Taking a balloon out from the tray, he blew.
他从来没使过这么大的劲，拼命地吹着。 He blew with a desperation he had not yet put into the process.
据说这东西可以吹到周长五英尺那么大。 They said the things would swell to five feet in circumference.
不知为什么，他觉得只要能把球吹成那么大，就能让事情缓和下来。 He felt somehow that if he could get it to attain those proportions, it would soften everything.
他吹着吹着，气球已经大到遮住了维多琳，挡住了房间，直到眼前能看到的只有这个彩色的气球。 Under his breath the thing blotted out Victorine, and the room, till there was just the globe of coloured air.
他用拇指和食指捏住气球口，把它举起来，对维多琳说： Nipping its neck between thumb and finger, he held it up, and said:
“你瞧，六个便士不算贵吧，大姑娘！”说着，他从气球一侧探头望去。 “There you are; not bad value for sixpence, old girl!” and he peered round it.
天啊，她哭了！ Lord, she was crying!
他撒手放掉了那个“该死的”东西。它缓缓飘落，里面的空气慢慢漏出来，直到缩成皱巴巴的一团，落在脏兮兮的地毯上。 He let the ‘blymed’ thing go; it floated down, the air slowly evaporating till a little crinkled wreck rested on the dingy carpet.
他抓住她哭得一耸一耸的肩膀，拼命地说道： Clasping her heaving shoulders, he said desperately:
“亲爱的，振作起来，别再为了生计吵架了。 “Cheerio, my dear, don’t quarrel with bread and butter.
我会找到工作的，这只是暂时的过渡罢了。 I shall get a job, this is just to tide us over.
为了你，比这更糟糕的事，我也愿意做。 I’d do a lot worse than that for you.
好啦，好啦，把我的茶点拿来吧。一直吹这些东西，我都饿了。” Come on, and get my tea, I’m hungry, blowin’ up those things.”
她不哭了，抬起头来看看，什么也没说——那双大眼睛太神秘了！ She stopped crying, looked up, said nothing—mysterious with those big eyes!
看得出来，她肯定有心事！ You’d say she had thoughts!
但是那是什么心事，比克特却说不出来。 But what they were Bicket could not tell.
在茶点的刺激下，他对自己的新营生有了夸夸其谈的勇气了。 Under the stimulus of tea, he achieved a certain bravado about his new profession.
做自己的主人！ To be your own master!
想什么时候出去就什么时候出去，想什么时候回家就什么时候回家——要是特别开心的话，就和维躺在床上不必起来。 Go out when you liked, come home when you liked—lie in bed with Vic if he jolly well pleased.
好处可多了！ A lot in that!
于是，比克特心里涌起了一些真正英国式的想法——想要自由自在、随遇而安；不喜欢规律性的工作，喜欢拼命努力一阵子，然后懒散消闲一阵子；渴望独立自主——这可就是英国人的生活。你看那成群的小商铺、经纪人、临时工和流浪汉，随心所欲地消磨自己美好的时光，管他什么后果——这种想法是这片土地、这个民族所特有的，在撒克逊人来之前，在产生良知和勤勉之前就有了——这种想法就是相信彩色气球会先膨胀后萎缩，就是能吃到那些腌制品和味道很重但毫无营养的东西就够了——比克特享用着可口的腌鱼和浓茶时，这些想法就在他心中欢腾着。 And there rose in Bicket something truly national, something free and happy-go-lucky, resenting regular work, enjoying a spurt, and a laze-off, craving independence—something that accounted for the national life, the crowds of little shops, of middlemen, casual workers, tramps, owning their own souls in their own good time, and damning the consequences—something inherent in the land, the race, before the Saxons and their conscience and their industry came in-something that believed in swelling and collapsing coloured air, demanded pickles and high flavours without nourishment—yes, all that something exulted above Bicket’s kipper and his tea, good and strong.
他宁可卖气球，也不愿意再做一天的包装工人，可不能让维忘记这一点！ He would rather sell balloons than be a packer any day, and don’t let Vic forget it!
然后等她也能工作的时候，他们的生活就会好起来。再然后，用不了多久，他们就能攒够钱，摆脱这种生活，到蓝蝴蝶飞来的那个地方去。 And when she was able to take a job, they would get on fine, and not be long before they’d saved enough to get out of it to where those blue butterflies came from.
他还谈到了索姆斯。 And he spoke of Soames.
要是再来几个没有子女的市议员——比方说，一天来两个吧，一周就能多挣15先令的外快了。 A few more aldermen without children—say two a day, fifteen bob a week outside legitimate trade.
哦，用不了一年的工夫，他们就能弄到那笔钱了！ Why, in under a year they’d have the money!
只要离开这里，维就会像那些气球一样丰满起来。她的身体会是现在的两倍那么大，脸蛋也会红润起来，比橙色和紫红的气球还要红。 And once away, Vic would blow out like one of those balloons; she’d be twice the size, and a colour in her cheeks to lay over that orange and magenta.
比克特变得神采飞扬。 Bicket became full of air.
而那位姑娘，他的妻子，则睁着大大的眼睛看着他，什么话也没说。但是，她没有再哭。或者说，确实没有再向他——这个卖气球的——泼热水或是泼冷水。 And the girl, his wife, watched with her large eyes and spoke little; but she did not cry again, or, indeed, throw any water, warm or cold, on him who sold balloons.
第十二章 Chapter XII
数字与事实 Figures and Facts
除了老福坦诺——他出不出席都是个摆设——董事会成员再次全体莅会。索姆斯注意到埃尔德森“那家伙”的一举一动都是在刻意地讨好别人，于是为自己作了最坏的打算。 With the exception of old Fontenoy—in absence as in presence ornamental—the Board was again full; Soames, conscious of special ingratiation in the manner of ‘that chap’ Elderson, prepared himself for the worst.
数字就摆在董事们的面前，这种展示有点儿无趣，看起来就像是要说明这么一个状况：如果未来六个月里外汇市场没有发生剧烈震荡的话，那么公司的情况就还不错。 The figures were before them; a somewhat colourless show, appearing to disclose a state of things which would pass muster, if within the next six months there were no further violent disturbances of currency exchange.
公司的国内业务和国外业务的比例是七比二，看起来很合理。索姆斯发现，占据国外业务绝大比例的德国业务被并入到中间部分，即与半破产国家归在一起，而且这“半破产”还是保守的估计。 The proportion of foreign business to home business was duly expressed in terms of two to seven; German business, which constituted the bulk of the foreign, had been lumped—Soames noted—in the middle section, of countries only half bankrupt, and taken at what might be called a conservative estimate.
会场里安静极了。董事会的每个成员都在琢磨着那些数字，而索姆斯却更清楚地觉得自己陷入了两难的境地。 During the silence which reigned while each member of the Board digested the figures, Soames perceived more clearly than ever the quandary he was in.
的确，很难以这些数字为理由要求公司按照去年的业绩发放红利。 Certainly, these figures would hardly justify the foregoing of the dividend earned on the past year’s business.
但是，如果欧洲大陆再次发生经济危机，而他们又要对公司绝大部分对外业务承担责任的话，那么下一年度国内业务的盈利很可能会全赔进去，也许还不止如此。 But suppose there were another Continental crash and they became liable on the great bulk of their foreign business, it might swamp all profits on home business next year, and more besides.
此外，埃尔德森这个人也令索姆斯感到不安——至于为什么不安，他也说不清楚。也许是出于直觉，也许有些杞人忧天。 And then his uneasiness about Elderson himself—founded he could not tell on what, intuitive, perhaps silly.
“嗯，福赛特先生，”董事长说话了，“这就是那些数字。 “Well, Mr. Forsyte,” the chairman was speaking; “there are the figures.
您觉得满意吗？” Are you satisfied?”
索姆斯抬起头来，下定了决心： Soames looked up; he had taken a resolution.
“我同意发放今年的红利，但条件是从此放弃这种对外业务——完全放弃。” “I will agree to this year’s dividend on condition that we drop this foreign business in future, lock, stock and barrel.”
那位经理的眼神冷峻而机警，和索姆斯对视一眼，而后转向了董事长。 The manager’s eyes hard and bright, met his, then turned towards the chairman.
“这听起来让人觉得恐慌，”他说道，“国外业务占到今年公司利润的三分之一之多呢。” “That appears to savour of the panicky,” he said; “the foreign business is responsible for a good third of our profit this year.”
董事长貌似环顾了一下各位董事的表情，然后才说： The chairman seemed to garner the expressions of his fellow-directors, before he said:
“福赛特先生，眼下国外业务没有出现可以引起恐慌的状况。 “There is nothing in the foreign situation at the moment, Mr. Forsyte, which gives particular cause for alarm.
我承认我们应该密切关注这方面——” I admit that we should watch it closely—”
“您不能这么做。”索姆斯插话说， “You can’t,” interjected Soames.
“停战至今已经四年了，而我们对自己处境的了解并没有增加。 “Here we are four years from the Armistice, and we know no more where we stand than we did then.
要是我早意识到我们为这个业务承担的风险，我是绝对不会加入董事会的。 If I’d realised our commitment to this policy, I should never have come on the Board.
我们必须放弃这一业务方针。” We must drop it.”
“这是相当极端的看法。 “Rather an extreme view.
而且这件事也不是一时半会儿就能决定的。” And hardly a matter we can decide in a moment.”
赞同者小声嘀咕起来，再加上“那家伙”嘴上略带讽刺的表情，让索姆斯的决心动摇了。 The murmur of assent, the expression, faintly ironical, of ‘that chap’s’ lips, jolted the tenacity in Soames.
“很好！ “Very well!
除非你们准备好在报告里告知股东，说我公司将放弃国外业务，否则你们就得放弃我。 Unless you’re prepared to tell the shareholders in the report that we are dropping foreign business, you drop me.
我一定会亲自在全体股东大会上提出这个问题的。我有这个自由。” I must be free to raise the question myself at the general meeting.”
他没有错过那位经理躲躲闪闪的眼神。 He did not miss the shift and blink in the manager’s eyes.
这一下可击中要害了！ That shot had gone home!
董事长说： The Chairman said:
“你这是拿枪指着我们的脑袋啊。” “You put a pistol to our heads.”
“我这是对股东们负责，”索姆斯说，“我也会依靠他们履行我的职责。” “I am responsible to the shareholders,” said Soames, “and I shall do my duty by them.”
“我们都是这样的，福赛特先生，而且我希望大家都能尽到自己的职责。” “So we all are, Mr. Forsyte; and I hope we shall all do our duty.”
“为什么不把国外业务限定在那些小国家内呢——他们的货币不是很稳定的吗？” “Why not confine the foreign business to the small countries—their currency is safe enough?”
“老蒙特”和他那宝贝“圈子”！ ‘Old Mont,’ and his precious ‘ring!’
“不行，”索姆斯说，“我们必须退到安全线内。” “No,” said Soames, “we must go back to safety.”
“辉煌的孤立吗，福赛特？” “Splendid isolation, Forsyte?”
“在战争时期，干预是非常管用的，但是在和平年代——不论是政治还是经济——这种一手经济、一手政治的干涉是没有用的。 “Meddling was all very well in the war, but in peace—politics or business—this half-and-half interference is no good.
我们无法掌控英国以外的形势。” We can’t control the foreign situation.”
他环顾四周，马上意识到自己的话已经触动大家的心弦了。 He looked around him, and was instantly conscious that with those words he had struck a chord.
“在这个问题上我要坚持到底！”他想道。 ‘I’m going through with this!’ he thought.
“董事长先生，”——那位经理说道——“请允许我说几句，我将不胜感激。 “I should be glad, Mr. Chairman”—the manager was speaking—“if I might say a word.
那个方针是我提议的，而且我想我可以断言，到目前为止，这一方针为本公司带来的收益是很可观的。 The policy was of my initiation, and I think I may claim that it has been of substantial benefit to the Society so far.
但是，如果董事会的成员里有人如此强烈地反对继续这一方针，我当然不会强迫董事会继续推行这一方针。 When, however, a member of the Board takes so strong a view against its continuance, I certainly don’t press the Board to continue it.
由于时局是不确定的，就算我们的估计再怎么保守，风险依然是存在的。” The times ARE uncertain, and a risk, of course, is involved, however conservative our estimates.”
“他这是怎么了？”索姆斯想，“怎么突然变词了？” ‘Now why?’ thought Soames: ‘What’s he ratting for?’
“你真是太大度了，埃尔德森。董事长先生，我觉得我们这位经理可以说是太大度了。” “That’s very handsome of you, Elderson; Mr. Chairman, I think we may say that is very handsome of our manager.”
老混蛋！ Old Dosey Cosey!
大度！ Handsome!
这个老妖婆！ The old woman!
董事长那相当刺耳的声音打破了会场的沉默。 The Chairman’s rather harsh voice broke a silence.
“这是一个十分严肃的方针问题。 “This is a very serious point of policy.
我觉得如果福坦诺勋爵在场的话，就太好了。” I should have been glad to have Lord Fontenoy present.”
“如果想要我在这份报告上签名的话，”索姆斯立刻说，“今天就得定下来。 “If I am to endorse the report,” said Soames shortly, “it must be decided today.
我已经拿定主意了。 I have made up my mind.
你们想怎么办，随便。” But please yourselves.”
他之所以说最后这句话，是念在大家同事一场的情分上——被逼无奈的感觉让人很不愉快！ He threw in those last three words from a sort of fellow feeling—it was unpleasant to be dragooned!
大家沉默了片刻，然后讨论起来，就好像这种人人畅所欲言的讨论缓和了此前被迫做出决定的气氛。 A moment’s silence, and then discussion assumed that random volubility which softens a decision already forced on one.
就这么过了一刻钟之后，董事长宣布： A quarter of an hour thus passed before the Chairman said:
“那么，诸位，我们都同意在这份报告中写入这样一份声明，即鉴于欧洲大陆局势的不确定性，我公司将暂时放弃国外保险业务。” “We are agreed then, gentlemen, that the report shall contain the announcement that, in view of Continental uncertainty, we are abandoning foreign risks for the present.”
索姆斯获胜了。 Soames had won.
他觉得既轻松又困惑，独自离开了。 Relieved and puzzled, he walked away alone.
他让他们见识了自己的个性，他们对他的尊敬程度增加了，这他看得出来；但是，他们对他的好感却降低了，他们对他有没有过好感呢？——这他就不知道了！ He had shown character; their respect for him had gone up, he could see; their liking for him down, if they’d ever had any—he didn’t know!
但是埃尔德森为什么突然改词了呢？ But why had Elderson veered round?
他回想起来，就在他说要将此事提交股东大会时，那家伙冷峻的眼神突然闪烁不定起来。 He recalled the shift and blink of the fellow’s steely eyes at the idea of the question being raised at the general meeting.
他就是为这个改口的！ That had done it!
可是，为什么呢？ But why?
是因为数字作假了吗？ Were the figures faked?
当然不是！ Surely not!
在那些会计师的眼皮子底下作假，那可太难了。 That would be too difficult, in the face of the accountants.
如果说索姆斯还相信什么的话，那就是相信那些持有皇家特许状的会计师了。 If Soames had faith, it was in chartered accountants.
桑迪斯和杰文两人都是最棒的会计师。 Sandis and Jevon were tip-top people.
捏造数字是不可能的！ It couldn’t be that!
他站在人行道上抬头望去。 He glanced up from the pavement.
圣保罗教堂的圆顶在夜幕下已经模糊不清——什么都看不清了！ The dome of St. Paul’s was dim already in evening sky—nothing to be had out of it!
他迫切地想找个人聊聊，但是身边连个说话的人都没有，于是他在匆忙的人群中加快了脚步。 He felt badly in need of some one to talk to; but there was nobody; and he quickened his pace among the hurrying crowd.
他把手深深地插入外衣的口袋，突然碰到了一种异样的、黏糊糊的东西。 His hand, driven deep into his overcoat pocket, came into sudden contact with some foreign sticky substance.
“啊呀！”他想道，“是那些东西！” ‘Gracious!’ he thought: ‘those things!’
该把它们扔进水沟里吗？ Should he drop them in the gutter?
要是家里有孩子的话，就能把它们带回去了！ If only there were a child he could take them home to!
他得让安妮特跟弗勒谈谈了。 He must get Annette to speak to Fleur.
他自己多年前的亲身经历让他清楚地知道陋习会产生什么样的恶果。 He knew what came of bad habits from his own experience of long ago.
为什么他不自己去跟她谈呢？ Why shouldn’t he speak to her himself?
今晚他就住在她那里呀！ He was staying the night there!
但是他觉得很无助，不知道该怎么做。 But there came on him a helpless sense of ignorance.
这些年轻人啊！ These young people!
他们究竟是怎么想的，有什么样的感觉？ What did they really think and feel?
老蒙特是对的吗？ Was old Mont right?
难道他们除了眼前的事，对其他任何事都不感兴趣了吗，对繁衍和进化全都不相信了吗？ Had they given up interest in everything except the moment, abandoned all belief in continuity, and progress?
的确，欧洲如今负债累累。 True enough that Europe was in Queer Street.
但是看看经历过拿破仑战争后的情况。 But look at the state of things after the Napoleonic Wars.
他记不得自己的祖父“高傲的多塞特”，那个老头早在他出生前5年就去世了。但是，他却清清楚楚地记得生于1799年的安姑妈。她以前总是说：“那个可怕的波拿巴——我们总是叫他博尼，亲爱的。”她会说他的父亲怎么为他自己的钱挣到8%或是10%的利息，还会说“那些宪章运动者”给朱莉姑姑和赫斯特姑姑留下了怎样深刻的印象。这都是很久之后的事情了。 He couldn’t remember his grandfather ‘Superior Dosset,’ the old chap had died five years before he was born, but he perfectly remembered how Aunt Ann, born in 1799, used to talk about “that dreadful Bonaparte—we used to call him Boney, my dear;” of how her father could get eight or ten per cent. for his money; and of what an impression ‘those Chartists’ had made on Aunts Juley and Hester, and that was long afterwards.
然而，尽管经历了上述种种情况，但是看看维多利亚时代——一个黄金时代，有值得收藏的器物，也有值得养育的儿女！ Yet, in spite of all that, look at the Victorian era—a golden age, things worth collecting, children worth having!
为什么不再来一个这样的时代呢？ Why not again!
蒂莫西死后，统一公债几乎是接连不断地一涨再涨。 Consols had risen almost continuously since Timothy died.
就算是天堂和地狱都不存在了，都不能成为这么做的理由。他的叔叔伯伯们没有谁相信有天堂或是地狱的存在，但是他们却都发了财，也都成了家，就只有蒂莫西和斯威森没有家小。 Even if Heaven and Hell had gone, they couldn’t be the reason; none of his uncles had believed in either, and yet had all made fortunes, and all had families, except Timothy and Swithin.
不！ No!
这不可能是因为缺少天堂和地狱造成的！ It couldn’t be the want of Heaven and Hell!
那么，什么才是造成这种变化的原因呢——如果真的有变化的话？ What, then, was the reason of the change—if change there really were?
索姆斯突然明白了。 And suddenly it was revealed to Soames.
他们说话太多了——太多而且太快！ They talked too much—too much and too fast!
他们失去了对这个、那个或是其他事物的兴趣。 They got to the end of interest in this and that and the other.
他们吞噬了人生，丢掉了人生的果皮，然后——然后—— They ate life and threw away the rind, and—and—.
顺便说一下，他一定要把乔治那幅画买下来！…… By the way, he must buy that picture of George’s!...
难道这些年轻人比他们这代人想的更多吗？ Had these young folk more mind than his own generation?
如果是这样的话——又是为什么呢？ And if so—why?
是饮食造成的吗？ Was it diet?
就是上上周日弗勒给他吃的那个龙虾冷盘。 That lobster cocktail Fleur had given him the Sunday before last.
他居然把那东西吃了——那么恶心的东西！ He had eaten the thing—very nasty!
但这东西并没有使得他想要说话。 But it hadn’t made him want to talk.
不！ No!
他认为不可能是饮食造成的。 He didn’t think it could be diet.
何况——还有头脑！ Besides—Mind!
现在哪里有能媲美维多利亚时代的人——达尔文、赫胥黎、狄更斯、迪斯累里，甚至老格莱斯顿？ Where were the minds now that equalled the Victorians—Darwin, Huxley, Dickens, Disraeli, even old Gladstone?
唉，他想起以前的那些法官和律师，同现在这些同行相比，那些都是巨人了。就像他记得在他父亲詹姆斯看来，詹姆斯年轻时的那些法官和儿子索姆斯年轻时的那些法官相比的话，也是巨人一般的。 Why, he remembered judges and advocates who seemed giants compared with those of the present day, just as he remembered that the judges of James his father’s youth had seemed giants to James compared with those of Soames’ prime.
照此看来，大脑的确是逐渐退化了。 According to that, mind was steadily declining.
但是，一定还有别的什么缘故。 It must be something else.
有一种被称为心理分析的东西，根据他的理解，并没有像过去那样，把人们的行动归结为早餐吃的什么或是早晨起床时先迈出的是哪条腿，而是归结为人们已经忘却的、很早以前曾受过的精神冲击。 There was a thing they called psycho-analysis, which so far as he could understand attributed people’s action not to what they ate at breakfast, or the leg they got out of bed with, as in the good old days, but to some shock they had received in the remote past and entirely forgotten.
潜意识！ The subconscious mind!
时尚！ Fads!
流行和微生物！ Fads and microbes!
事实就是，这一代人根本没有消化能力。 The fact was this generation had no digestion.
他的父亲、他的叔叔伯伯们都曾经抱怨说自己的肝脏不好，但是他们从来没得过什么大毛病——不需要什么维生素、假牙、精神治疗、报纸、精神分析、招魂术、计划生育、整骨疗法、广播等等。 His father and his uncles had all complained of liver, but they had never had anything the matter with them—no need of any of these vitamins, false teeth, mental healing, newspapers, psycho-analysis, spiritualism, birth control, osteopathy, broadcasting, and what not.
“机器！”索姆斯想道， ‘Machines!’ thought Soames.
“就是这个——这就不足为奇了！” ‘That’s it—I shouldn’t wonder!’
如果一切都这么快速地运转的话，你还怎么能相信什么东西呢？ How could you believe in anything when everything was going round so fast?
如果你养的小鸡四下乱跑，你又怎么去数它们的数目呢？ When you couldn’t count your chickens—they ran about so?
但是，弗勒有一个很棒的小脑瓜！ But Fleur had got a good little head on her!
“是啊，”他默默地想着，“她还有一副法国牙齿，能消化任何东西。 ‘Yes,’ he mused, ‘and French teeth, she can digest anything.
两年了！ Two years!
我得在她还没有养成这个习惯之前，和她谈谈。 I’ll speak to her before she gets the habit confirmed.
她妈妈在这件事上可是够快的！” Her mother was quick enough about it!’
这时，他发现自己走到了鉴赏家俱乐部前，于是就走了进去。 And perceiving the Connoisseurs’ Club in front of him, he went in.
俱乐部的看门人从他的小隔间里走出来。 The hall porter came out of his box.
他告诉索姆斯，有位先生在等他。 A gentleman was waiting.
“哪位先生？”索姆斯侧着身问道。 “What gentleman?” said Soames, sidelong.
“先生，我想他是您的外甥，达尔蒂先生。” “I think he’s your nephew, sir, Mr. Dartie.”
“瓦尔·达尔蒂！ “Val Dartie!
哦！ H’m!
他人呢？” Where?”
“在小房间里，先生。” “In the little room, sir.”
那个小房间在走廊的末端——只有非会员才配呆在那种地方。那里毫无品味，就好像是这家俱乐部在说：“瞧瞧，非会员就是这么个待遇！” The little room—all the accommodation considered worthy of such as were not Connoisseurs—was at the end of a passage, and in no taste at all, as if the Club were saying: “See what it is not to be one of us!”
索姆斯走了进去，看到瓦尔·达尔蒂正在一边抽烟一边全神贯注地盯着这里唯一有趣的东西——壁炉上方的镜子，看镜中的自己。 Soames entered it, and saw Val Dartie smoking a cigarette and gazing with absorption at the only object of interest, his own reflection in the glass above the fire.
他每次看见自己的外甥，总免不了要想到他又要跟自己说：“索姆斯舅舅，你瞧，我又遇上麻烦了。” He never saw his nephew without wondering when he would say: “Look here, Uncle Soames, I’m up a stump.”
养赛马的！ Breeding race horses!
他们就只会有那么一个下场！ There could only be one end to that!
“怎么样？”他说道，“你还好吧？” “Well?” he said, “how are YOU?”
镜子里的那张脸转了过来，镜中映出了一个留着金黄色短发的后脑勺。 The face in the glass turned round, and became the back of a clipped sandyish head.
“哦！我很好，谢谢您！ “Oh! bobbish, thanks!
您看起来气色很好，索姆斯舅舅。 YOU look all right, Uncle Soames.
我只是想问问您：我非得接受老乔治·福赛特的那几匹驽马吗？ I just wanted to ask you: Must I take these screws of old George Forsyte’s?
它们真的很糟。” They’re dashed bad.”
“对礼物不满意吗？”索姆斯问道。 “Gift horse in the mouth?” said Soames.
“哎呀，”瓦尔说道，“可是它们实在太糟糕了，就算等我付完遗产税，把它们装在箱子里运出去卖的话，三匹加在一起也卖不了六便士。 “Well,” said Val, “but they’re SO dashed bad; by the time I’ve paid legacy duty, boxed them to a sale, and sold them, there won’t be a sixpence.
其中一匹马，一见人就会摔倒。 One of them falls down when you look at it.
另外两匹都有气喘病。 And the other two are broken-winded.
那个可怜的老头子养着它们，是因为他甩不掉它们。 The poor old boy kept them, because he couldn’t get rid of them.
它们差不多都有五百岁了。” They’re about five hundred years old.”
“我还以为你喜欢马呢。”索姆斯说道， “Thought you were fond of horses,” said Soames.
“你就不能把它们放了？” “Can’t you turn them out?”
“我是喜欢马，”瓦尔淡淡地说，“但是我也得养家糊口啊。 “Yes,” said Val, drily; “but I’ve got my living to make.
我没告诉我老婆，就是怕她会让我把它们放了。 I haven’t told my wife, for fear she should suggest that.
要是我把马卖了，我怕是做梦都会梦见它们。 I’m afraid I might see them in my dreams if I sold them.
这些马只适合养在狗窝里。 They’re only fit for the kennels.
我能不能给遗嘱执行人写信，就说我没钱，养不起它们？” Can I write to the executors and say I’m not rich enough to take them?”
“可以。”索姆斯说着，把到了嘴边的“你太太怎么样了？”的问话咽了回去。 “You can,” said Soames, and the words: “How’s your wife?” died unspoken on his lips.
她是他的仇人——小乔利恩的女儿。 She was the daughter of his enemy, young Jolyon.
虽然那家伙死了，他们之间的敌对关系却没变。 That fellow was dead, but the fact remained.
“那么，就这么办了。”瓦尔说， “I will, then,” said Val.
“他的葬礼办得怎么样了？” “How did his funeral go off?”
“非常简单——我没管这事。” “Very simple affair—I had nothing to do with it.”
办葬礼的日子已经过去了。 The days of funerals were over.
没有鲜花，没有马匹，没有羽饰——就只有一辆机动灵车和两三辆小汽车，这就是现今人们对死者的全部关照。 No flowers, no horses, no plumes—a motor hearse, a couple of cars or so, was all the attention paid nowadays to the dead.
这个时代的又一项标志！ Another sign of the times!
“我今天晚上住在格林大街。”瓦尔说道， “I’m staying the night at Green Street,” said Val.
“我想您不在那儿吧，对吗？” “I suppose you’re not there, are you?”
“不在，”索姆斯说。他外甥脸上的那种欣慰的表情没有逃出他的眼睛。 “No,” said Soames, and did not miss the relief in his nephew’s countenance.
“对了，索姆斯舅舅——您会建议我买天佑再保险公司的股票吗？” “Oh! by the way, Uncle Soames—do you advise me to buy P.P.R.S. shares?”
“正好相反。 “On the contrary.
我正准备劝你母亲抛出她的股票呢。 I’m going to advise your mother to sell.
转告你母亲，就说我明天过去。” Tell her I’m coming in tomorrow.”
“为什么？ “Why?
我原以为——” I thought—”
“不要问我为什么！”索姆斯简短地说。 “Never mind my reasons!” said Soames shortly.
“那我走了，再见！” “So long, then!”
两人冷冷地握了握手，然后索姆斯看着外甥退了出去。 Exchanging a chilly hand-shake, he watched his nephew withdraw.
再见！ So long!
这个词像布尔战争一样古老，可他就是不习惯这个词——他看不出这个词有什么意义！ An expression, old as the Boer war, that he had never got used to—meant nothing so far as he could see!
他走进了阅览室。 He entered the reading-room.
那里有几个会员，有的站着，有的坐着，索姆斯则是其中最不善交际的，于是他找了个僻静的地方，坐在一扇斜面窗户前。 A number of Connoisseurs were sitting and standing about, and Soames, least clubbable of men, sought the solitude of an embrasured window.
他坐在那里，一边用一根食指擦亮另一根食指的指甲，一边细细地品味人生。 He sat there polishing the nail of one forefinger against the back of the other, and chewing the cud of life.
人这辈子究竟有什么意义呢？ After all, what was the point of anything.
看看乔治！ There was George!
他安逸地过了一辈子——什么活也没干！ He had had an easy life—never done any work!
再看看他自己，做了那么多事情！ And here was himself, who had done a lot of work!
早晚有一天，他们也会为他送葬的，很可能也是用一辆机动的灵车！ And sooner or later they would bury him too, with a motor hearse probably!
看看他的女婿——小蒙特，满口胡言乱语——还有今天下午卖气球给他的那个脸颊瘦瘦的家伙。 And there was his son-inlaw, young Mont, full of talk about goodness knew what—and that thin-cheeked chap who had sold him the balloons this afternoon.
老福坦诺、那边那个侍者、有工作的和没工作的人、议会里的那些议员以及教堂里的牧师——他们为了什么而活着呢？ And old Fontenoy, and that waiter over there; and the out-of-works and the inworks; and those chaps in Parliament, and the parsons in their pulpits—what were they all for?
在梅普尔达勒姆那个地方有一个老园丁，日复一日地推着车修剪草坪，要是他不修剪的话，草坪会变成什么样子？ There was the old gardener down at Mapledurham pushing his roller over and over the lawn, week after week, and if he didn’t, what would the lawn be like?
这就是人生——就像园丁修剪草坪一样！ That was life—gardener rolling lawn!
假如说有另外一种人生的话——他是不会信的，但是作为讨论的基础，姑且这样假设——那种生活也一定是一样的。 Put it that there was another life—he didn’t believe it, but for the sake of argument—that life must be just the same.
有人推着车修剪草坪——使它有个草坪的样子！ Rolling lawn—to keep it lawn!
草坪能说明什么呢？ What point in lawn?
他觉得自己想得太悲观了，于是站了起来。 Conscious of pessimism, he rose.
他还是赶快回到弗勒家去吧——他们穿礼服吃晚餐！ He had better be getting back to Fleur’s—they dressed for dinner!
他想，穿礼服吃晚餐总会有什么原因的吧，但是就像草坪一样——有时不修剪——有时脱下礼服，就这么循环下去！ He supposed there was something in dressing for dinner, but it was like lawn—you came unrolled—undressed again, and so it went on!
一遍又一遍地做同样的事只是为了保持一个高度，那就是——哎呀！这些高度又是为了什么呀？ Over and over and over to keep up to a pitch, that was—ah! what WAS the pitch for?
他拐进南广场的时候，突然和一个年轻人撞在了一起。那个年轻人正在扭着脖子朝后看，像是在看着某个刚刚和他分手的什么人。 Turning into South Square, he cannoned into a young man, whose head was craned back as if looking after some one he had parted from.
索姆斯不知道自己是该道歉还是应该等着接受别人的道歉，于是索性站在那里，不动了。 Uncertain whether to apologise or to wait for an apology, Soames stood still.
那个年轻人突然说了声：“对不起，先生。”然后走开了。这是个皮肤黝黑的小伙子，穿得很整洁，脸上那贪婪渴望的神色，很明显不是因为肚子饿了。 The young man said abruptly: “Sorry, sir,” and moved on; dark, neat-looking chap with a hungry look obviously unconnected with his stomach.
索姆斯小声说了句：“没关系！” Murmuring: “Not at all!”
然后他继续朝前走去，按了按女儿家的门铃。 Soames moved forward and rang his daughter’s bell.
女儿亲自给他开的门。 She opened to him herself.
她穿着皮衣，戴着帽子——刚刚进门。 She was in hat and furs—just in.
索姆斯回想起刚才那个年轻人。 The young man recurred to Soames.
他和她是在这里分手的吗？ Had he left her there?
瞧这张脸，多漂亮啊！ What a pretty face it was!
他必须得跟她谈谈了。 He should certainly speak to her.
如果她已经开始四处寻欢作乐的话！ If she once took to gadding about!
但是，他并没有立即开口谈这事，直到快该说“晚安”的时候——那时迈克尔已经去参加一位工党候选人的政治集会去了，仿佛他找不到什么更好的事情可做似的！ He put it off, however, till he was about to say “Goodnight”—Michael having gone to the political meeting of a Labour candidate, as if he couldn’t find something better to do!
“孩子，现在你结婚都两年了，我觉得你得为将来考虑一下了。 “Now you’ve been married two years, my child, I suppose you’ll be looking towards the future.
人们说过很多关于孩子的蠢话。 There’s a great deal of nonsense talked about children.
但是这个事情其实没那么复杂。 The whole thing’s much simpler.
我希望你也是这样想的。” I hope you feel that.”
弗勒坐在长靠椅上，倚着一堆靠垫，晃着小脚。 Flour was leaning back among the cushions of the settee, swinging her foot.
她的眼神变得有些不安，但脸色并没有什么变化。 Her eyes became a little restless, but her colour did not change.
“当然啦！”她说道，“只是这事不着急啊，爸爸。” “Of course!” she said; “only there’s no hurry, Dad.”
“唉，我不明白。”索姆斯低声说， “Well, I don’t know,” Soames murmured.
“法国人和英国皇室都有一种好习惯——早点儿把这事完成。 “The French and the royal family have a very sound habit of getting it over early.
要知道，世上哪有十全十美的事情，早点儿有了孩子，才不会惹是生非。 There’s many a slip and it keeps them out of mischief.
孩子，你长得很好看——我不想看着你把时间都花在寻欢作乐上。 You’re very attractive, my child—I don’t want to see you take too much to gad-about ways.
你的朋友里可是什么样的人都有。” You’ve got all sorts of friends.”
“行。”弗勒说。 “Yes,” said Fleur.
“你和迈克尔相处得很好，是吗？” “You get on well with Michael, don’t you?”
“是啊！很好啊。” “Oh! yes.”
“嗯，那么，为什么不要孩子呢？ “Well, then, why not?
你一定还记得，你的孩子将来是会继承那个你所说的什么头衔的。” You must remember that your son will be a what-you-call-it.”
尽管他生来就不喜欢那些头衔和此类的恭维，但是说这些话的时候，他做出了让步。 In those words he compromised with his instinctive dislike of titles and flummery of that nature.
“也许不是个男孩呢。”弗勒说。 “It mightn’t be a son,” said Fleur.
“你这么年轻，很容易补救的。” “At your age that’s easily remedied.”
“啊，爸，我可不想生一堆小孩。 “Oh, I don’t want a lot, Dad.
也许生一个，也许生两个。” One, perhaps, or two.”
“好啊。”索姆斯说，“我倒更喜欢女儿，一个像——嗯，像你这样的女孩。” “Well,” said Soames, “I should almost prefer a daughter, something like—well, something like you.”
她的眼神变得柔和了，目光也不再停在一处，而是四下移动：看看老爸的脸，看看自己的脚，看看小狗，看看整个房间。 Her softened eyes flew, restive, from his face to her foot, to the dog, all over the room.
“我不明白，那是一种束缚——在某程度上，就像是自掘坟墓。” “I don’t know, it’s a tie—like digging your own grave in a way.”
“我觉得没那么严重。”索姆斯带着说服的口吻轻声说着。 “I shouldn’t put it as high as that,” murmured Soames, persuasively.
“男人都觉得不严重，爸爸。” “No man would, Dad.”
“要是没有你，你妈早就过不下去了。”他说着又想起她妈妈差点儿就不要她了——要不是他，那女人可能会把事情搞得一团糟。想到这里，他不吭声了，默默地看着那只脚晃来晃去。 “Your mother wouldn’t have got on at all without you,” and recollection of how near her mother had been to not getting on at all with her—of how, but for him, she would have made a mess of it, reduced him to silent contemplation of the restive foot.
“好了，”最后他说，“我想我以前跟你说过的。 “Well,” he said, at last, “I thought I’d mention it.
我——我一直把你的幸福放在我的心头。” I—I’ve got your happiness at heart.”
弗勒站了起来，亲了亲他的额头。 Fleur rose and kissed his forehead.
“我知道的，爸。”她说道，“我是个只为自己着想的小笨猪。 “I know, Dad,” she said: “I’m a selfish pig.
我会好好考虑一下这个问题的。 I’ll think about it.
其实，我——我也想过这个问题的。” In fact, I—I have thought about it.”
“这就对了。”索姆斯说，“这就对了！ “That’s right,” said Soames; “that’s right!
你的小脑瓜挺管用的——这让我很欣慰。 You’ve a good head on you—it’s a great consolation to me.
晚安，我亲爱的宝贝！” Goodnight, my dear!”
然后，他就上楼睡觉去了。 And he went up to his bed.
如果有什么事情是真正有意义的话，那就是传宗接代了。当然了，这件事情尚无定论。 If there was point in anything, it was in perpetuation of oneself, though, of course, that begged the question.
“我不知道，”他想道，“该不该问问她，那个年轻人是不是——” ‘Wonder,’ he thought, ‘if I ought to have asked her whether that young man—!’
可是，年轻人的事情最好还是让他们自己解决。 But young people were best left alone.
实际上，他根本不了解年轻人。 The fact was, he didn’t understand them.
他的目光落在那只纸袋上，那里面装着那些——那些他买来的东西。 His eye lighted on the paper bag containing those—those things he had bought.
他从外衣口袋里把它们拿了出来，想要扔掉——可是怎么扔呢？ He had brought them up from his overcoat to get rid of them—but how?
扔到火里的话，会有味道的。 Put into the fire, they would make a smell.
他站在梳妆台前，拿起一个气球看了看。 He stood at his dressing-table, took one up and looked at it.
天啊！ Good Lord!
突然，他拿起手绢擦了擦那个吹气口，然后开始吹了起来。 And, suddenly, rubbing the mouthpiece with his handkerchief, he began to blow the thing up.
他吹呀吹呀，直到两颊都累了才停下来，用手捏着气球口，拿出一根平日清洁牙齿用的牙线来把气球扎了起来。 He blew until his cheeks were tired, and then, nipping the aperture, took a bit of the dental cotton he used on his teeth every night and tied it up.
这就是气球了！ There the thing was!
他像个孩子一样，急忙用手把气球拍了起来。 With a pettish gesture he batted the balloon.
它飞起来了——紫红色的，那么大，飘到了他的床上。 Off it flew—purple and extravagant, alighting on his bed.
嗯！ H’m!
他把另一个气球也拿起来，同样地吹了起来。 He took up the other, and did the same to it.
紫色的和绿色的！ Purple and green!
糟了！ The deuce!
要是有人走进来看见怎么办！ If any one came in and saw!
他打开窗户，把气球一只一只地拍了出去，拍进黑暗里，然后关上了窗户。 He threw up the window, batted them, balloon after balloon, into the night, and shut the window down.
气球将在黑暗中四处飘荡。 There they’d be in the dark, floating about.
他扯动嘴角，不安地做出一个笑脸。 His lips contracted in a nervous grin.
早上，人们就会看见它们了。 People would see them in the morning.
唉！ Well!
这样的东西，还能怎么处置它们？ What else could you do with things like that?
第十三章 Chapter XIII
焦虑不安 Tenterhooks
迈克尔之所以去参加工党候选人的集会，一部分是因为他自己想去，一部分是出于对“老福赛特”的同情，他总是觉得他夺了“老福赛特”的心头爱。 Michael had gone to the Labour candidate’s meeting partly because he wanted to, and partly out of fellow feeling for ‘old Forsyte,’ whom he was always conscious of having robbed.
他的岳父一向对弗勒很好，因此只要他能办到，他就让这位“老人”单独和她呆在一起。 His father-in-law had been very decent about Fleur, and he liked the ‘old man’ to have her to himself when he could.
在一个有许多临时工而且完全没有工会会员的选区里，这次集会将令党内知识分子们能够“直抒胸臆”。 In a constituency which had much casual and no trades-union labour to speak of, the meeting would be one of those which enabled the intellectuals of the Party to get it ‘off their chests.’
由于可以“滔滔不绝”地抒发情感，获胜时也可以尽情展现优越感，人们可以在这里听到纯经济意义上的演讲。这种演讲摒弃了诸如人性之类的不可信的因素。 Sentiment being ‘slop,’ and championship mere condescension, one might look for sound economic speeches which left out discredited factors, such as human nature.
迈克尔听惯了诽谤那些由于坚持人性永恒论而反对变革的人的话，他也听惯了鄙视那些富有同情心的人的话。他知道，这种演讲应该是纯经济意义上的。 Michael was accustomed to hearing people disparaged for deprecating change because human nature was constant; he was accustomed to hearing people despised for feeling compassion; he knew that one ought to be purely economic.
不管怎样，这种演讲比北方的或者公园里的大吹大擂的演讲要好得多，因为那些演讲只会在他心中激起一种潜在的肮脏的阶级意识。 And anyway that kind of speech was preferable to the tub-thumpings of the North or of the Park, which provoked a nasty underlying class spirit in himself.
当迈克尔到达的时候，集会正热火朝天地进行着，那个候选人正在毫不客气地揭露资本主义的种种弊端，在他看来，正是资本主义导致了这场战争。 The meeting was in full swing when he arrived, the candidate pitilessly exposing the fallacies of a capitalism which, in his view, had brought on the war.
为了避免它引起另一场战争，就必须用另一种制度取代它——一种能够保证各个国家都不会贪得无厌的制度。 For fear that it should bring on another, it must be changed for a system which would ensure that nations should not want anything too much.
每一个人——这个候选人说——在每一个方面都比他所属的民族要优越，摆在他们面前的问题就是要获得一种经济条件，来让每一个人自由地发挥他与生俱来的优越性。 The individual—said the candidate—was in every respect superior to the nation of which he formed a part; and the problem before them was to secure an economic condition which would enable the individual to function freely in his native superiority.
他认为，只有这样，人们才能摆脱危害人类理智的群众运动和大众情绪。 In that way alone, he said, would they lose those mass movements and emotions which imperilled the sanity of the world.
他讲得很精彩。 He spoke well.
迈克尔一直听着，忍不住啧啧称赞，直到他发现他想到了自己、威尔弗里德和弗勒。 Michael listened, purring almost audibly, till he found that he was thinking of himself, Wilfrid and Fleur.
他能否非常自由地发挥他与生俱来的优越性，从而使自己不太需要弗勒呢？ Would he ever function so freely in a native superiority that he did not want Fleur too much?
他是否愿意这样做呢？ And did he wish to?
他不愿意。 He did not.
那样似乎就把人性引入到了那个演讲者的观点里了。 That seemed to introduce human nature into the speaker’s argument.
每一个人不都是贪得无厌的吗？ Didn’t everybody want something too much?
这不是很自然的吗？ Wasn’t it natural?
如果是这样，那岂不是始终存在一种共同的贪得无厌——诸如使自己免遭灭顶之灾的这类基本欲望的集合呢？ And if so, wouldn’t there always be a collective wanting too much—poolings of primary desire, such as the desire of keeping your own head above water?
他突然觉得那个候选人的言论忽视了问题的症结，忽略了矛盾，变成了一个吃了一顿糟糕的午餐的男人坐在扶手椅上发表的言论。 The candidate’s argument seemed to him suddenly to leave out heat, to omit friction, to be that of a man in an armchair after a poor lunch.
他聚精会神地看着演讲者那张精明的、冷漠的、令人质疑的脸。 He looked attentively at the speaker’s shrewd, dry, doubting face.
“毫无意义！”他想。 ‘No juice!’ he thought.
于是当“那个家伙”坐下之后，他就起身离开了大厅。 And when ‘the chap’ sat down, he got up and left the hall.
威尔弗里德这件事让他非常心烦意乱。 This Wilfrid business had upset him horribly.
虽然他试着将这件事抛诸脑后，虽然他试着对这件事一笑而过，但是这件事仍然不断地侵蚀着他的安全感和幸福感。 Try as he had to put it out of his mind, try as he would to laugh it off, it continued to eat into his sense of security and happiness.
妻子和最好的朋友！ Wife and best friend!
他每天说服自己一百次，让自己确信他是信任弗勒的。 A hundred times a day he assured himself that he trusted Fleur.
只是，威尔弗里德比自己更有吸引力，而弗勒应该得到一切最好的。 Only, Wilfrid was so much more attractive than himself, and Fleur deserved the best of everything.
不仅如此，想到威尔弗里德正在遭受着折磨，这也令他很难过。 Besides, Wilfrid was going through torture, and it was not a pleasant thought!
如何了结这件事，让他自己、他和她都恢复内心的平静呢？ How end the thing, restore peace of mind to himself, to him, to her?
她什么也没有对他说，他也绝不可能去问她。 She had told him nothing; and it simply was impossible to ask.
他甚至不能表现出焦虑！ No way even of showing his anxiety!
整个这件事“不能挑明”，而且在他看来，这件事不得不继续保持现有的状态。除了控制住自己的脾气，尽可能地对她好，尽量不去记恨他，没有别的办法。 The whole thing was just ‘dark,’ and, so far as he could see, would have to stay so; nothing to be done but screw the lid on tighter, be as nice as he could to her, try not to feel bitter about him.
真见鬼！ Hades!
他转过弯，沿着切尔西堤岸走着。 He turned down Chelsea Embankment.
这里的天空黑暗而宽广，繁星点点。 Here the sky was dark and wide and streaming with stars.
河面很宽阔，黑暗的河水在堤岸灯的映照下闪烁着油亮的波光。 The river wide, dark and gleaming with oily rays from the Embankment lamps.
这一切广阔的景象让他感到解脱。 The width of it all gave him relief.
去他的忧郁！ Dash the dumps!
一个愉快的、奇怪的、混乱的、甜蜜的和痛苦的世界，一种极其有趣的赌博游戏，无论当时是怎样出的牌！ A jolly, queer, muddled, sweet and bitter world; an immensely intriguing game of chance, no matter how the cards were falling at the moment!
当年在战壕里他曾经想过：“只要能从这里出去，以后什么事情我都不在乎了！” In the trenches he had thought: ‘Get out of this, and I’ll never mind anything again!’
现在他很少能记起当时想过这个了！ How seldom now he remembered thinking that!
据说，人的身体每七年更新一次。 The human body renewed itself—they said—in seven years.
再过三年，他的身体就不是战壕里的那个身体了，而是逐渐没了恐惧、永远安宁的身体。 In three years’ time his body would not be the body of the trenches, but a whole-time peace body with a fading complex.
要是弗勒能把她对威尔弗里德的看法和她对威尔弗里德所做的事情都坦白地告诉他就好了，她一定在做着什么事情！ If only Fleur would tell him quite openly what she felt, what she was doing about Wilfrid, for she must be doing something!
还有威尔弗里德的诗呢？ And Wilfrid’s verse?
他那该死的热恋会不会——如准爵爷所说——化为诗歌呢？ Would his confounded passion—as Bart suggested—flow in poetry?
如果会，那么谁会将它出版呢？ And if so, who would publish it?
真是一件痛苦的事情！ A miserable business!
唉，夜晚是美丽的，而重要的是，不要做一个贪婪的人。 Well the night was beautiful, and the great thing not to be a pig.
美丽而不贪婪！ Beauty and not being a pig!
乐观处之——除了大笑——再也没有别的什么了！ Nothing much else to it—except laughter—the comic side!
无论如何，要保持幽默感！ Keep one’s sense of humour, anyway!
于是迈克尔一边大步走在那树叶落了一半、在黑暗中像羽毛一样的法国梧桐树下，一边寻找着他的处境的可笑之处。 And Michael searched, while he strode beneath plane trees half-stripped of leaves and plume-like in the dark, for the fun in his position.
他找不出来。 He failed to find it.
似乎爱情是完全没有什么可笑之处的。 There seemed absolutely nothing funny about love.
也许有朝一日他会再次放弃爱情，但是只要她一直令他焦虑不安，他就还是放弃不了。 Possibly he might fall out of love again some day, but not so long as she kept him on her tenterhooks.
她是故意这样做的吗？ Did she do it on purpose?
绝对不是！ Never!
弗勒绝对不像那些女人。她们一直吊着丈夫的胃口，当她们想要衣服、皮草和珠宝的时候才满足他们一下。 Fleur simply could not be like those women who kept their husbands hungry and fed them when they wanted dresses, furs, jewels.
真令人恶心！ Revolting!
他来到能看见威斯敏斯特的地方。 He came in sight of Westminster.
刚刚10点半！ Only half-past ten!
他可以乘出租车到威尔弗里德的住处，然后设法把这件事向他摊牌。 Suppose he took a cab to Wilfrid’s rooms, and tried to have it out with him.
这就像是企图让钟表的指针滴滴答答地倒着走一样。 It would be like trying to make the hands of a clock move backwards to its ticking.
假如他对威尔弗里德说：“你爱弗勒——唉，别爱她了！”或者是威尔弗里德这样对他说，又有什么用呢？ What use in saying: “You love Fleur—well, don’t!” or in Wilfrid saying it to him.
“毕竟，我是第一个和弗勒好的人。”他想。 ‘After all, I was first with Fleur,’ he thought.
也许这纯属运气，但这也是事实！ Pure chance, perhaps, but fact!
啊！ Ah!
这不正是危险所在吗？ And wasn’t that just the danger?
对于她来说，他已经不再新奇了——现在她对他已经了如指掌！ He was no longer a novelty to her—nothing unexpected about him now!
而且他和她曾经无数次地一致认为，新奇是生活的调味剂，是兴趣和戏剧的本质。 And he and she had agreed times without number that novelty was the salt of life, the essence of interest and drama.
现在威尔弗里德才是新奇的！ Novelty now lay with Wilfrid!
上帝啊！ Lord!
上帝啊！ Lord!
占有者似乎在诉讼中远远不占上风！ Possession appeared far from being nine points of the law!
他从堤岸绕了一圈，朝家走去——堤岸是伦敦的一个愉快的地方、一个愉快的广场，除了这该死的感情纠葛，一切都是愉快的。 He rounded-in from the Embankment towards home—jolly part of London, jolly Square; everything jolly except just this infernal complication.
有个像大树叶一样柔软的东西轻轻地碰了他的耳朵两下。 Something, soft as a large leaf, tapped twice against his ear.
他回过头去，吃了一惊，他是在一片空地上，周围没有一棵树。 He turned, astonished; he was in empty space, no tree near.
一个圆圆的东西在黑暗中飘荡着——他伸手去抓，它上下摆动。 Floating in the darkness, a round thing—he grabbed, it bobbed.
那是什么？ What?
一只小孩子玩的气球！ A child’s balloon!
他双手把它抓住，拿到路灯下去看——他看到是绿色的。 He secured it between his hands, took it beneath a lamp-post—green, he judged.
奇怪！ Queer!
他抬头看去。 He looked up.
两个窗户里有灯光，其中一个是弗勒房间的窗户！ Two windows lighted, one of them Fleur’s!
这气球是不是就是他自己幸福的气泡，被人驱赶出来了呢？ Was this the bubble of his own happiness expelled?
神经病！ Morbid!
大笨蛋！ Silly ass!
几阵风吹来的——一件小孩子的玩具，原本系着，后来松脱了！ Some gust of wind—a child’s plaything lodged and loosened!
他小心翼翼地拿着这只气球。 He held the balloon gingerly.
他要把它带回家去给她看。 He would take it in and show it to her.
他把弹簧锁的钥匙插进门里。 He put his latch-key in the door.
门厅里一片漆黑——她已经上楼去了！ Dark in the hall—gone up!
他一边上楼，一边用手指将气球晃来晃去。 He mounted, swinging the balloon on his finger.
弗勒正站在镜子前。 Fleur was standing before a mirror.
“那是什么东西啊？”她问道。 “What on earth’s that?” she said.
血又流回到迈克尔的心里。 The blood returned to Michael’s heart.
真奇怪，他刚才多么担心这个东西会和她有关系啊！ Curious how he had dreaded its having anything to do with her!
“不知道，亲爱的，它落在了我的帽子上——一定是从天上掉下来的。” “Don’t know, darling; fell on my hat—must belong to heaven.”
说着他把它拍了起来。 And he batted it.
气球飘上去，落下来，弹了两下，晃了一会儿，就停住不动了。 The balloon floated, dropped, bounded twice, wobbled and came to rest.
“你真是个孩子，迈克尔。 “You ARE a baby, Michael.
我相信是你买的。” I believe you bought it.”
迈克尔向她走近了些，就站住不动了。 Michael came closer, and stood quite still.
“天啊！ “My hat!
爱上一个人是多么不幸啊！” What a misfortune to be in love!”
“你是这样想的！” “You think so!”
“既有吻别人的人，也有不肯把脸给人吻的人。” “Il y a toujours un qui baise, et l’autre qui ne tend pas la joue.”
“但是我愿意。” “But I do.”
“弗勒！” “Fleur!”
弗勒笑了。 Fleur smiled.
“尽情地吻吧。” “Baise away.”
迈克尔抱着她，心里想：“她征服了我——她喜欢对我怎样就怎样吧，我一点儿也弄不懂她！” Embracing her, Michael thought: ‘She holds me—does with me what she likes; I know nothing of her!’
这时响起了一阵轻微的声音——小叮铃正在嗅那只气球。 And there arose a small sound—from Ting-a-ling smelling the balloon.
第二卷 Part II
第一章 Chapter I
马克贬值 The Mark Falls
自从天佑再保险公司召开股东大会以来，索姆斯对世界局势越来越感到不安。长期以来他一直把愚蠢和这种会议联系在一起，这次大会进行过程中也充满了愚蠢的言论——董事长的无懈可击的冗长废话、两位可靠的股东的奉承话、几位不太可靠的股东的尖酸刻薄的话以及关于红利的惯常的“闲谈”。 The state of the world had been getting more and more on Soames’ nerves ever since the general meeting of the P. P. R. S. It had gone off with that fatuity long associated by him with such gatherings—a watertight rigmarole from the chairman; butter from two reliable shareholders; vinegar from shareholders not so reliable; and the usual ‘gup’ over the dividend.
他去开会时闷闷不乐，离开时更是愁容满面。 He had gone there glum, come away glummer.
一旦一个想法在索姆斯脑中形成，再要他放弃它，简直比小虫子离开奶酪还要慢。 From a notion once taken into his head Soames parted more slowly than a cheese parts from its mites.
七分之二的国外业务，几乎全部都是德国的！ Two-sevenths of foreign business, nearly all German!
而马克正在贬值！ And the mark falling!
从他决定支持分红的那个时候起，马克就开始贬值了。 It had begun to fall from the moment that he decided to support the dividend.
是什么原因呢？ And why?
会发生什么事情呢？ What was in the wind?
他一反平日的习惯，开始密切注意他读的那份报纸的政治专栏。 Contrary to his custom, he had taken to sniffing closely the political columns of his paper.
法国人——他向来不信任他们，尤其是从他第二次婚姻之后——除非他大错特错，法国人又要兴风作浪了！ The French—he had always mistrusted them, especially since his second marriage—the French were going to play old Harry, if he was not greatly mistaken!
他注意到，他们的报纸从来不放过任何一个抨击英国政策的机会，他们似乎认为总能对英国发号施令！ Their papers, he noticed, never lost a chance of having a dab at English policy; seemed to think they could always call the tune for England to pipe to!
而马克和法郎以及其他各种货币，都在贬值。 And the mark and the franc, and every other sort of money, falling.
虽然索姆斯一想到自己国家的一张纸可以买到其他国家的许多张纸就感到高兴，但是他也觉得整件事情既愚蠢又虚幻，而且他越来越清楚地知道，天佑再保险公司明年不会分红了。 And, though in Soames was that which rejoiced in the thought that one of his country’s bits of paper could buy a great quantity of other countries’ bits of paper, there was also that which felt the whole thing silly and unreal, with an ever-growing consciousness that the P. P. R. S. would pay no dividend next year.
天佑再保险公司是一家大公司，不分红是经营不善的标志，还是一个不小的标志。 The P. P. R. S. was a big concern; no dividend would be a sign, no small one, of bad management.
普天之下，能够而且应该经营得毫无实际风险的事业屈指可数，保险业就是其中之一。 Assurance was one of the few things on God’s earth which could and should be conducted without real risk.
要不是这个原因，当初他是绝不会加入这个董事会的。 But for that he would never have gone on the Board.
如今保险业并非经营得毫无实际风险，而发现这一点的人正是他自己，这真是——唉！ And to find assurance had not been so conducted and that by himself, was—well!
不管怎样，他已经让威妮弗雷德把股票卖掉了，虽然股票已经略微下跌了一些。 He had caused Winifred to sell, anyway, though the shares had already fallen slightly.
“我以为它是件好东西呢，索姆斯，”她伤心地说，“在股票上赔了钱，真讨厌！” “I thought it was such a good thing, Soames,” she had said plaintively: “it’s rather a bore, losin’ money on the shares.”
他毫不留情地回答说：“如果不卖掉，你会赔更多。” He had answered without mercy: “If you don’t sell, you’ll lose more.”
于是她把股票卖掉了。 And she had done it.
如果之前跟着他买进的罗杰和尼古拉斯两家人至今还没有卖掉股票——呃，那就是他们自己的事情了！ If the Rogers and Nicholases who had followed him into it hadn’t sold too—well, it was their look out!
他已经让威妮弗雷德提醒过他们了。 He had made Winifred warn them.
至于他自己，除了取得董事资格所必需的股份外，他一无所有，少拿一两次分红对他也没有什么损害，因为他的董事酬劳足以弥补损失，而且绰绰有余。 As for himself, he had nothing but his qualifying shares, and the missing of a dividend or two would not hurt one whose director’s fees more than compensated.
因此，与其说这是他个人的不安，还不如说是对与外国人有关的事态以及对他一贯正确的破灭所产生的愤恨。 It was not, therefore, private uneasiness so much as resentment at a state of things connected with foreigners and the slur on his infallibility.
圣诞节在梅普尔达勒姆汉静悄悄地过去了。 Christmas had gone off quietly at Mapledurham.
