他非常不喜欢圣诞节，因为他的妻子是法国人，而她的民族节日是元旦，所以他只能过圣诞节。 He abominated Christmas, and only observed it because his wife was French, and her national festival New Year’s Day.
他总不至于要过元旦，以助长外国人的观念吧。 One could not go so far as to observe that, encouraging a foreign notion.
但是过圣诞节却没有孩子在身边——他还记得自己小时候公园巷里的冬青树和金鱼草——那些家庭聚会；如果他得到的只是象征性的东西——顶针或者戒指——而不是先令，他是多么厌烦。 But Christmas with no child about—he still remembered the holly and snapdragons of Park Lane in his own childhood—the family parties; and how disgusted he had been if he got anything symbolic—the thimble, or the ring—instead of the shilling.
在公园巷，他们从来就不喜欢圣诞老人，一部分是因为他们看穿了这位老先生，一部分是因为圣诞老人一点儿也不新奇。 They had never gone in for Santa Claus at Park Lane, partly because they could see through the old gentleman, and partly because he was not at all a late thing.
他的母亲埃米莉注意到了那一点。 Emily, his mother, had seen to that.
的确如此。顺便提一下，威廉·古尔丁·英格勒这个名字，竟然难住了纹章院的那帮家伙，使索姆斯放弃了追查——继续查下去只不过是鼓励他们花他的钱，使他获得一种无法实现的感情上的满足而已。 Yes; and, by the way, that William Gouldyng, Ingerer, had so stumped those fellows at the Heralds’ College, that Soames had dropped the enquiry—it was just encouraging them to spend his money for a sentimental satisfaction which did not materialise.
“老蒙特”，这个心胸狭窄的家伙，炫耀着他的祖宗家世；越是没有祖宗家世可炫耀的人，越有理由这样做。 That narrow-headed chap, ‘Old Mont,’ peacocked about his ancestry; all the more reason for having no ancestry to peacock about.
福赛特家族和戈尔丁家族都是英国乡村的名门望族——这才是最关键的。 The Forsytes and the Goldings were good English country stock—that was what mattered.
如果弗勒和她的孩子，假如她生一个孩子，身上有法国血统——唉，现在他也无能为力啦。 And if Fleur and her child, if one came, had French blood in them—well, he couldn’t help it now.
关于是否会有一个外孙出生，索姆斯并不比10月份那时更有把握。 In regard to the coming of a grandchild, Soames knew no more than in October.
弗勒是和蒙特一家人一起过圣诞节的，但是她已经答应他，不久就会要孩子，她妈妈必须去问问情况了！ Fleur had spent Christmas with the Monts; she was promised to him, however, before long, and her mother must ask her a question or two!
天气非常暖和，索姆斯甚至乘坐方头平底船出去游钓。 The weather was extremely mild; Soames had even been out in a punt fishing.
他穿了件厚厚的外套，拖着一根钓线，去钓鲈鱼和鲦鱼，偶尔还能钓到一条拟鲤——这种鱼毫无用处，如今连仆人都不吃了！ In a heavy coat he trailed a line for perch and dace, and caught now and then a roach—precious little good, the servants wouldn’t eat them, nowadays!
他那双灰色的眼睛注视着灰色天空下那灰色的水面，脑子里却想着马克要贬值。 His grey eyes would brood over the grey water under the grey sky; and in his mind the mark would fall.
1月11日那天，当法国人出兵攻占了鲁尔区的时候，马克突然贬值了。 It fell with a bump on that eleventh of January when the French went and occupied the Ruhr.
他在吃早餐时对安妮特说：“你的国家疯了！ He said to Annette at breakfast: “Your country’s cracked!
看看现在的马克！” Look at the mark now!”
“我干吗要关心马克呢？”她边喝咖啡边回答， “What do I care about the mark?” she had answered over her coffee.
“我只关心德国人不要再闯入我的国家。 “I care that they shall not come again into my country.
我希望他们也受一点儿我们以前受过的苦！” I hope they will suffer a little what we have suffered.”
“你，”索姆斯说，“你从来没有受过什么苦。” “You,” said Soames; “you never suffered anything.”
安妮特把手放在心口上，索姆斯有时怀疑那地方是否真的有一颗心。 Annette put her hand where Soames sometimes doubted the existence of a heart.
“我这儿受过苦。”她说。 “I suffered here,” she said.
“我没有发现过。 “I didn’t notice it.
你从来没有缺少过黄油。 You never went without butter.
你认为在今后的30年里欧洲会变成什么样子！ What do you suppose Europe’s going to be like now for the next thirty years!
英国的贸易又会怎样？” How about British trade?”
“我们法国人只管眼前的事。”安妮特激动地说， “We French see before our noses,” said Annette with warmth.
“我们明白要让战败国始终处于战败国的地位，否则他们就会进行报复。 “We see that the beaten must be kept the beaten, or he will take revenge.
你们英国人太多愁善感了。” You English are so sloppy.”
“我们多愁善感？”索姆斯说， “Sloppy, are we?” said Soames.
“你说话就像个小孩一样。 “You’re talking like a child.
一个多愁善感的民族能达到我们在世界上的地位吗？” Could a sloppy people ever have reached our position in the world?”
“那是因为你们自私自利。 “That is your selfishness.
你们既冷酷无情又自私自利。” You are cold and selfish.”
“冷酷无情、自私自利和多愁善感——这有些互相矛盾啊。 “Cold, selfish and sloppy—they don’t go together.
继续说。” Try again.”
“你们的多愁善感在你们的思想和言论里。给你们带来成功的是你们的本能，而你们英国人的本能就是冷酷无情和自私自利，索姆斯。 “Your slop is in your thought and your talk; it is your instinct that gives you your success, and your English instinct is cold and selfish, Soames.
你和你们所有人都是虚伪、愚蠢和自私的混合体。” You are a mixture, all of you, of hypocrisy, stupidity and egoism.”
索姆斯拿了些果酱。 Soames took some marmalade.
“那么，”他说，“法国人又怎样呢？——愤世嫉俗、贪得无厌和睚眦必报。 “Well,” he said, “and what are the French?—cynical, avaricious and revengeful.
德国人则是感情用事、顽固任性和野蛮残忍。 And the Germans are sentimental, heady and brutal.
我们都可以互相辱骂。 We can all abuse each other.
除了避免接触之外别无他法。 There’s nothing for it but to keep clear.
但这正是你们法国人不愿意做的。” And that’s what you French won’t do.”
安妮特挺直了漂亮的身躯。 Annette’s handsome person stiffened.
“当你和一个人联系在一起的时候，就像我和你联系在一起一样，索姆斯，或者像我们法国人和德国人联系在一起一样，你必须处于支配地位，否则就处于被支配地位。” “When you are tied to a person, as I am tied to you, Soames, or as we French are tied to the Germans, it is necessary to be top dog, or to be bottom dog.”
索姆斯放下了他的烤面包。 Soames stayed his toast.
“你认为你自己在这个家里处于支配地位吗？” “Do you suppose yourself top dog in this house?”
“是的，索姆斯。” “Yes, Soames.”
“哦！ “Oh!
那么你明天可以回法国去了。” Then you can go back to France tomorrow.”
安妮特嘲弄般地扬起了眉毛。 Annette’s eyebrows rose quizzically.
“我还要再等一段时间，我的朋友，你还很年轻呢。” “I would wait a little longer, my friend; you are still too young.”
但是索姆斯已经后悔刚才说过的话了，他不希望在他这把年纪的时候还发生这样的争吵，于是他较为平静地说： But Soames had already regretted his remark; he did not wish any such disturbance at his time of life, and he said more calmly:
“妥协是人与人或国与国之间合理生存的要素。 “Compromise is the essence of any reasonable existence between individuals or nations.
我们不能每隔几年就闹一次。” We can’t have the fat thrown into the fire every few years.”
“这就是典型的英国人。”安妮特喃喃地说， “That is so English,” murmured Annette.
“我们外国人从来不知道你们英国人要做什么。 “We others never know what you English will do.
你们总是见风使舵。” You always wait to see which way the cat jumps.”
无论索姆斯多么认同这种合情合理的特性，若在平时，他一定不会承认的——承认自己见风使舵，可以说那是绝对不行的。 However deeply sympathetic with such a reasonable characteristic, Soames would have denied it at any ordinary moment—to confess to temporising was not, as it were, done.
但是，随着马克像一车砖块跌落似的贬值，他已经被激怒到出于本性地挺身而出了。 But, with the mark falling like a cartload of bricks, he was heated to the point of standing by his nature.
“我们为什么不能这样做呢？ “And why shouldn’t we?
难道非要我们卷入那些你们必须摆脱的事情里去吗！ Rushing into things that you’ll have to rush out of!
我不想争论。 I don’t want to argue.
法国人和英国人从来没有和睦相处过，而且永远不会和睦相处。” French and English never did get on, and never will.”
安妮特站了起来。 Annette rose.
“你说的是事实，我的朋友。 “You speak the truth, my friend.
协商，但并不友好。 Entente, mais pas cordiale.
你今天打算做什么？” What are you doing today?”
“到城里去。”索姆斯闷闷不乐地说， “Going up to town,” said Soames glumly.
“你的宝贝政府的复仇行为已经把经济逼入绝境了。” “Your precious Government has put business into Queer Street with a vengeance.”
“你在那儿过夜吗？” “Do you stay the night?”
“不知道。” “I don’t know.”
“再会，那么，以后再见！” “Adieu, then, jusqu’ au revoir!”
说完她就上楼去了。 And she got up.
索姆斯仍然看着他的果酱沉思——心里想着马克贬值——他很高兴看到她那漂亮的身躯离开，因为此刻他实在是不能容忍她那法国式的坏脾气。 Soames remained brooding above his marmalade—with the mark falling in his mind—glad to see the last of her handsome figure, having no patience at the moment for French tantrums.
他现在急切地渴望对某个人说“我早警告过你了”。 An irritable longing to say to somebody “I told you so” possessed him.
但是，他现在只能等，直到找到这么个人之后才能对他说。 He would have to wait, however, till he found somebody to say it to.
天气晴朗，非常暖和。他带着雨伞，以防变天，动身去了车站。 A beautiful day, quite warm; and, taking his umbrella as an assurance against change, he set out for the station.
在进城去的车厢里，人们正在谈论着鲁尔区的事情。 In the carriage going up they were talking about the Ruhr.
索姆斯不喜欢当众议论，他就用报纸遮住脸听着。 Averse from discussion in public, Soames listened from behind his paper.
大家的态度和他的态度惊人地相似。 The general sentiment was surprisingly like his own.
只要是对德国佬不利的——都对；只要是对英国贸易不利的——都错；只要对英国贸易的爱是积极的，对德国佬的恨是消极的——错多对少。 In so far as it was unpleasant for the Huns—all right; in so far as it was unpleasant for British trade—all wrong; in so far as love of British trade was active and hate of Huns now passive—more wrong than right.
一个亲法派的人说法国人不惜一切代价确保自身安全的做法是合情合理的，大家听了都反应冷淡。 A Francophil remark that the French were justified in making themselves safe at all costs, was coldly received.
在梅登黑德站上来一个人，索姆斯自然而然地把他和骚乱联系在了一起。 At Maidenhead a man got in whom Soames connected automatically with disturbance.
他的头发斑白，面色红润，眼神活跃，眉毛弯曲。还不到五分钟，他就用一种轻松愉快的声音发话了，问是否有人听说过国际联盟。 He had much grey hair, a sanguine face, lively eyes, twisting eyebrows, and within five minutes had asked in a breezy voice whether anyone had heard of the League of Nations.
索姆斯觉得自己的判断得到了证实，他从报纸的一角向外看去。 Confirmed in his estimate, Soames looked round the corner of his paper.
是的，那个家伙要开始鼓吹自己喜欢的话题了。 Yes, that chap would get off on some hobby-horse or other!
他果然开始了！ And there he went!
问题——这个新来的家伙说——不在于德国人是不是应该当头挨一棒，英国人是不是应该在口袋里大捞一把，或者法国人是不是应该在情感上宣泄一下，而在于这个世界是不是应该获得和平与友好。 The question—said the newcomer—was not whether the Germans should get one in the eye, the British one in the pocket, or the French one in the heart, but whether the world should get peace and goodwill.
索姆斯放下了报纸。 Soames lowered his paper.
如果——这个家伙说——他们想要和平，就必须放下个人利益，而去考虑集体利益。 If—this fellow said—they wanted peace, they must sink their individual interests, and think in terms of collective interest.
集体的利益就是个人的利益！ The good of all was the good of one!
索姆斯一眼就看出了破绽。 Soames saw the flaw at once.
这话也许是对的，但是个人的利益不一定是集体的利益。 That might be, but the good of one was not the good of all.
他觉得如果自己一不小心就会指出这一点的。 He felt that if he did not take care he would be pointing this out.
他和这个人素不相识，跟这种人争论毫无意义。 The man was a perfect stranger to him, and no good ever came of argument.
不幸的是，在大家都认为国际联盟“毫无希望”的时候，索姆斯的沉默似乎使那个新来的家伙把他当成了一个同情者，从而不断地向他使眼色！ Unfortunately his silence amid the general opinion that the League of Nations was ‘no earthly,’ seemed to cause the newcomer to regard him as a sympathiser; the fellow kept on throwing his eyebrows at him!
他若再拿起报纸来，就似乎显得太有针对性了，正当他的处境越来越容易让人误会的时候，火车驶入了帕丁顿车站。 To put up his paper again seemed too pointed, and his position was getting more and more false when the train ran in at Paddington.
他急忙下车，走向一辆出租车。 He hastened to a cab.
一个声音在他背后说： A voice behind him said:
“一群无药可救的人，先生，唉！ “Hopeless lot, sir, eh!
很高兴看到您能理解我的观点。” Glad to see YOU saw my point.”
“没错！”索姆斯说， “Quite!” said Soames.
“出租车！” “Taxi!”
“除非国际联盟发挥作用，否则我们全都得下地狱。” “Unless the League of Nations functions, we’re all for Gehenna.”
索姆斯转动出租车的门把手。 Soames turned the handle of the cab door.
“没错！”他又说了一句， “Quite!” he said again.
“家禽街！”然后就上了车。 “Poultry!” and got in.
他不想被人纠缠。 He was not going to be drawn.
那个家伙显然是个煽动者！ The fellow was clearly a firebrand!
在出租车里，他的烦躁程度显现出来了。 In the cab the measure of his disturbance was revealed.
他刚才说的“家禽街”，早在22年前，“福赛特、巴斯塔德和福赛特”公司就已经放弃不用这个地址了。那时他们和“卡斯考特、霍利迪和金森”公司合并，变成了“卡斯考特、金森和福赛特”公司。 He had said ‘Poultry,’ an address that ‘Forsyte, Bustard and Forsyte’ had abandoned two-and-twenty years ago when, merged with ‘Cuthcott, Holliday and Kingson,’ they became ‘Cuthcott, Kingson and Forsyte.’
纠正了地址的错误之后，他朝前坐好，心里沉思着。 Rectifying the error, he sat forward, brooding.
马克贬值！ Fall of the mark!
国家对此有着充分的准备，是的——但是下次当他们不能分红的时候，他们能指望人们对法国人的怨恨会代替对董事们的怨恨吗？ The country was sound about it, yes—but when they failed to pay the next dividend, could they rely on resentment against the French instead of against the directors?
不大可能！ Doubtful!
董事们应该预见到会发生这样的事情！ The directors ought to have seen it coming!
对其他的董事也许可以这样说，但是对他自己却不能这么说——这种政策是他本人从来没有接触过的。 That might be said of the other directors, but not of himself—here was a policy that he personally never would have touched.
要是他能把整个事情和某人探讨一下就好了——但是这种问题不是老格雷德曼力所能及的。 If only he could discuss the whole thing with some one—but old Gradman would be out of his depth in a matter of this sort.
于是，他一到自己的办公室，就有点儿不耐烦地注视着那个坐在转椅中的一成不变的老家伙。 And, on arrival at his office, he gazed with a certain impatience at that changeless old fellow, sitting in his swivel chair.
“啊！ “Ah!
索姆斯先生，我正盼着您今天早上能来呢。 Mr. Soames, I was hopin’ you might come in this morning.
有一个天佑再保险公司的年轻人来看您。他不肯说明来意，只说要单独和您见一面。 There’s a young man been round to see you from the P. P. R. S. Wouldn’t give his business, said he wanted to see you privately.
他留下了电话号码。” Left his number on the ‘phone.”
“哦！”索姆斯说。 “Oh!” said Soames.
“一个非常年轻的小伙子——在办公室工作。” “Quite a young feller—in the office.”
“他长得什么样子？” “What did he look like?”
“文雅、干净的年轻人。 “Nice, clean young man.
给我的印象非常不错——名叫巴特菲尔德。” I was quite favourably impressed—name of Butterfield.”
“那么，给他打电话，告诉他我在这儿。” “Well, ring him up, and let him know I’m here.”
说完他走到窗前，站在那里望着窗外一面光秃秃的墙壁。 And going over to the window, he stood looking out on to a perfectly blank wall.
为了适合他匿名合伙人的身份，他的房间设在后面，不受打扰。 Suited to a sleeping partner, his room was at the back, free from disturbance.
年轻人！ Young man!
这次拜访有些非同寻常！ The call was somewhat singular!
他回过头说：“等他来了，你不要走开，格雷德曼，我一点儿也不了解他。” And he said over his shoulder: “Don’t go when he comes, Gradman, I know nothing of him.”
世界改变了，逝者已逝，马克贬值了，但是格雷德曼还在那里——他是贡献与正直的化身，忠诚而又老练——一个可以依靠的人。 The world changed, people died off, the mark fell, but Gradman was there—embodiment, faithful and grey, of service and integrity—an anchor.
格雷德曼那刺耳而讨好的声音响了起来。 Gradman’s voice, grating, ingratiating, rose.
“这条法国新闻——可不太妙啊，索姆斯先生。 “This French news—it’s not nice, Mr. Soames.
他们是一帮轻率的家伙。 They’re a hasty lot.
我记得在普法战争宣战那天早上，您的父亲詹姆斯先生走进办公室——那时他正值壮年，还不到60岁，我记得。 I remember your father, Mr. James, coming into the office the morning the Franco-Prussian war was declared—quite in his prime then, hardly more than sixty, I should say.
哦，我想起了他的原话。‘你瞧，’他说，‘我早就告诉过他们要打仗了。’ Why, I recall his very words: ‘There,’ he said, ‘I told them so.’
现在他们——仍然要打。 And here they are—at it still.
事实就是，他们是猫狗不相容。” The fact is, they’re cat and dog.”
索姆斯半转过身，继续凝视着那一片空白处，沉思开了。 Soames, who had half turned, resumed his contemplation of a void.
可怜的老格雷德曼落伍了！ Poor old Gradman dated!
如果他听到他们一直在给外国生意做保险，他会怎么说呢？ What would he say when he heard that they had been insuring foreign business?
由于受到格雷德曼身上的往日情怀的感染，他的思绪突然自由翱翔起来。 Stimulated by the old-time quality of Gradman’s presence, his mind ranged with sudden freedom.
或许他自己还能再活20年吧。 He himself had another twenty years, perhaps.
到那时他会看到些什么呢？ What would he see in that time?
古老的英国最后会变成什么样子？ Where would old England be at the end of it?
“不管报纸上怎么说，我们并不像看上去的那样傻。”他想， ‘In spite of the papers, we’re not such fools as we look,’ he thought.
“要是我们能避开无谓的空谈，并且不赔本就好了！” ‘If only we can steer clear of flibberty-gibberting, and pay our way!’
“巴特菲尔德先生来了，先生。” “Mr. Butterfield, sir.”
嗬！ H’m!
这个年轻人来得可真快。 The young man had been very spry.
在格雷德曼那既直率又圆滑的招呼的掩护之下，他可以像他叔叔罗杰过去常说的那样“观察一下”。 Covered by Gradman’s bluff and greasy greeting, he “took a lunar,” as his Uncle Roger used to call it.
这个小伙子穿着一套整洁的翻领西服，手里拿着帽子，身材中等，态度谦恭。 The young fellow, in a neat suit, a turndown collar, with his hat in his hand, was a medium modest-looking chap.
索姆斯点点头。 Soames nodded.
“你想要见我？” “You want to see me?”
“我想单独见您，如果可以的话，先生。” “Alone, if I might, sir.”
“这位格雷德曼先生是我的得力助手。” “Mr. Gradman here is my right-hand man.”
格雷德曼的声音刺耳地响了起来：“你尽管说明你的来意。 Gradman’s voice purred gratingly: “You can state your business.
任何事情都不会传出去的，年轻人。” Nothing goes outside these walls, young man.”
“我在天佑再保险公司的办公室工作，先生。 “I’m in the office of the P.P.R.S., sir.
事情是这样的，我意外地得到了一些消息，我感到心里不安。 The fact is, accident has just put some information in my hands, and I’m not easy in my mind.
因为我知道您是一名律师，先生，所以我宁愿来找您，也不愿去找董事长。 Knowing you to be a solicitor, sir, I preferred to come to you, rather than go to the chairman.
作为一名律师，请您告诉我：作为公司的雇员，我的首要职责是不是要对它负责？” As a lawyer, would you tell me: Is my first duty to the Society, being in their employ?”
“当然。”索姆斯说。 “Certainly,” said Soames.
“我不喜欢这份工作，先生，而且我希望您能明白我到这里来不是出于任何个人目的——而是因为我觉得我应该这样做。” “I don’t like this job, sir, and I hope you’ll understand that I’m not here for any personal motive—it’s just because I feel I ought to.”
索姆斯一直注视着他。 Soames regarded him steadily.
虽然这个年轻人的眼睛又大又水灵，但是给他的印象却像是一条忠实的狗的眼睛。 Though large and rather swimming, the young man’s eyes impressed him by their resemblance to a dog’s.
“究竟是什么事情？”他说。 “What’s it all about?” he said.
这个年轻人舔了舔嘴唇。 The young man moistened his lips.
“是我们在德国的保险业务，先生。” “The insurance of our German business, sir.”
索姆斯那双天生就稍微有点儿尖的耳朵竖已经了起来。 Soames pricked his ears, already slightly pointed by Nature.
“这件事非常严重，”这个年轻人接着说，“我不知道这件事会对我产生什么影响，但事实是，今天早上我无意间听到一段私人谈话。” “It’s a very serious matter,” the young man went on, “and I don’t know how it’ll affect me, but the fact is, this morning I overheard a private conversation.”
“哦！”索姆斯说。 “Oh!” said Soames.
“是的，先生。 “Yes, sir.
我非常理解您的反应，但是第一句话就让我忍不住偷听下去。 I quite understand your tone, but the very first words did it.
我不能让他们知道我听到了他们的谈话。 I simply couldn’t make myself known after hearing them.
我想您会同意的，先生。” I think you’ll agree, sir.”
“谈话的人是谁？” “Who were the speakers?”
“经理和一个叫做史密斯的人——听他的口音，我猜想他的名字更像是个外国人的——他代理绝大部分的德国业务。” “The manager, and a man called Smith—I fancy by his accent his name’s a bit more foreign—who’s done most of the agenting for the German business.”
“他们谈了些什么？”索姆斯说。 “What were the words?” said Soames.
“嗯，先生，当时经理正在说话，然后这个史密斯说：‘的确如此，埃尔德森先生，但是在整个业务中我们不是白给你们佣金的，如果马克彻底完蛋了，你就得设法让你的公司赔偿我们的损失！’” “Well, sir, the manager was speaking, and then this Smith said: ‘Quite so, Mr. Elderson, but we haven’t paid you a commission on all this business for nothing; if the mark goes absolutely phut, you will have to see that your Society makes it good for us!’”
那一刻，索姆斯十分渴望吹个口哨，但是一看到格雷德曼脸上的表情，他抑制住了这种强烈的渴望。 The intense longing, which at that moment came on Soames to emit a whistle, was checked by sight of Gradman’s face.
那个老家伙的嘴在他那灰白的鸟巢似的短须里张开了，他的眼睛瞪得像哈巴狗一样，发出一声拖长的“啊——呦！” The old fellow’s mouth had opened in the nest of his grizzly short beard; his eyes stared puglike, he uttered a prolonged: “A-ow!”
“是的，”年轻人说，“真是耸人听闻！” “Yes,” said the young man, “it was a knock-out!”
“当时你在哪儿？”索姆斯厉声问道。 “Where were you?” asked Soames, sharply.
“在经理室和董事会会议室之间的走廊里。 “In the lobby between the manager’s room and the board room.
我刚在会议室整理完一些文件，出来的时候，经理室的门开着一英寸左右的缝。 I’d just come from sorting some papers in the boardroom, and the manager’s door was open an inch or so.
当然我非常熟悉他们的声音。” Of course I know the voices well.”
“后来呢？” “What after?”
“我听到埃尔德森先生说：‘嘘！ “I heard Mr. Elderson say, ‘H’ssh!
别那么大声！’于是我又溜回了会议室。 Don’t talk like that!’ and I slipped back into the board room.
我听到的已经够多了，先生，我向您保证。” I’d had more than enough, sir, I assure you.”
怀疑和猜测充斥着索姆斯的大脑。 Suspicion and surmise clogged Soames’ thinking apparatus.
这个小伙子说的是真话吗？ Was this young fellow speaking the truth?
像埃尔德森这样的人——居然冒这样大的风险！ A man like Elderson—the risk was monstrous!
那么，如果是真的，董事们的责任是什么？ And, if true, what was the directors’ responsibility?
但是证据——证据呢？ But proof—proof?
他盯着这个年轻人。年轻人看起来焦虑不安，脸色很苍白，但他的目光却很坚定。 He stared at the young man, who looked upset and pale enough, but whose eyes did not waver.
想办法诈一诈他！ Shake him if he could!
于是他厉声说： And he said sharply:
“你得注意你所说的话！ “Now mind what you’re saying!
这是非常严重的！” This is most serious!”
“我知道，先生。 “I know that, sir.
如果考虑到我个人的利益，我绝不会到这来。 If I’d consulted my own interest, I’d never have come here.
我不是一个告密的人。” I’m not a sneak.”
这些话听起来是真的，但是索姆斯没有放松警惕。 The words rang true, but Soames did not drop his caution.
“你以前在办公室出过什么问题吗？” “Ever had any trouble in the office?”
“没有，先生，您可以去查问。 “No, sir, you can make enquiry.
我没有什么针对埃尔德森先生的事情，他也没有什么针对我的事情。” I’ve nothing against Mr. Elderson, and he’s nothing against me.”
索姆斯突然想到：“天哪！ Soames thought suddenly: ‘Good heavens!
他把这件事推到我身上了，而且还有一个证人在场！ He’s shifted it on to me, and in the presence of a witness!
而这个证人又是我提供的！” And I supplied the witness!’
“依你看，”他说，“他们是不是发现了你当时在那里呢？” “Have you any reason to suppose,” he said, “that they became aware of your being there?”
“他们不会知道的，我想。” “They couldn’t have, I think.”
这个消息的含义似乎每一秒钟都让人更加担忧。 The implications of this news seemed every second more alarming.
就像命运之神，一生都以巧妙的腕力使对手无法近身，却突然被对手趁其不备刺了一剑。 It was as if Fate, kept at bay all his life by clever wrist-work, had suddenly slipped a thrust under his guard.
不管怎样，惊慌失措毫无用处——必须从容不迫地把它想清楚！ No good to get rattled, however—must think it out at leisure!
“如果有必要，你是否准备把这件事向董事会再说一遍？” “Are you prepared, if necessary, to repeat this to the Board?”
年轻人把双手紧紧地握在一起。 The young man pressed his hands together.
“哦，先生，我倒宁愿保持沉默，但如果您决定必须这么做的话，我想我一定会奉陪到底。 “Well, sir, I’d much rather have held my tongue; but if you decide it’s got to be taken up, I suppose I must go through with it now.
我是真的希望您会决定要不要管它，或许这件事不是真的——只是为什么埃尔德森先生不说：‘你这个大骗子！呢？’” I’m sure I hope you’ll decide to leave it alone; perhaps it isn’t true—only why didn’t Mr. Elderson say: ‘You ruddy liar!’?”
的确如此！ Exactly!
他为什么不说呢？ Why didn’t he?
索姆斯非常不安地咕哝了一声。 Soames gave a grunt of intense discomfort.
“还有别的吗？”他说。 “Anything more?” he said.
“没有了，先生。” “No, sir.”
“很好。 “Very well.
你没有告诉过别人吧？” You’ve not told anyone?”
“没有，先生。” “No, sir.”
“那就不要告诉别人，让我来处理吧。” “Then don’t, and leave it to me.”
“那我真的太高兴了，先生。 “I’ll be only too happy to, sir.
祝您日安！” Good-morning!”
“你也一样！” “Good-morning!”
不安——非常不安！ No—very bad morning!
虽然他对埃尔德森的预感突然得到了证实，但是他一点儿也不感到满意。 No satisfaction whatever in this sudden fulfilment of his prophetic feeling about Elderson.
一点也不！ None!
“你觉得那个小伙子怎么样，格雷德曼？ “What d’you think of that young fellow, Gradman?
他在撒谎吗？” Is he lying?”
格雷德曼仿佛从昏迷中被唤醒了一样，沉思着擦了擦他那只又大又亮的鼻子。 Thus summoned, as it were, from stupor, Gradman thoughtfully rubbed a nose both thick and shining.
“这只是一面之词，索姆斯先生，除非您能找到更多的证据。 “It’s one word against another, Mr. Soames, unless you get more evidence.
但是我看不出这个年轻人这样做能得到什么好处。” But I can’t see what the young man has to gain by it.”
“我也看不出，但是世事难料。 “Nor I; but you never know.
问题就在于要找到更多的证据。 The trouble will be to get more evidence.
没有证据我能采取行动吗？” Can I act without it?”
“这件事很微妙。”格雷德曼说。 “It’s delicate,” said Gradman.
索姆斯知道他只能依靠自己了。 And Soames knew that he was thrown back on himself.
当格雷德曼说一件事情很微妙的时候，就意味着对于这类事情他向来是惟命是从的——就连有想法都是很冒昧的！ When Gradman said a thing was delicate, it meant that it was the sort of matter on which he was accustomed to wait for orders—presumptuous even to hold opinion!
但是他有没有想法呢？ But had he got one?
哦，没有人会知道！ Well, one would never know!
这个老家伙会一直坐在那里对着这件事擦鼻子，直到上西天。 The old chap would sit and rub his nose over it till Kingdom Come.
“我不能贸然行事，”他几乎生气地说，“我还没有摸透这件事。” “I shan’t act in a hurry,” he said, almost angrily: “I can’t see to the end of this.”
那句话每时每刻都在得到证实。 Every hour confirmed that statement.
午餐时，城市俱乐部的行情收录带上显示马克仍然在贬值——跌到了一种闻所未闻的程度！ At lunch the tape of his city club showed the mark still falling—to unheard-of depths!
心里装着这件事，他简直无法想象他们怎么还能谈论高尔夫球！ How they could talk of golf, with this business on his mind, he could not imagine!
“我要去见见那个家伙，”他自言自语道， “I must go and see that fellow,” he said to himself.
“我要保持警惕。 “I shall be guarded.
或许他会露出一些破绽。” He may throw some light.”
一直等到3点钟，他才到天佑再保险公司去。 He waited until three o’clock and repaired to the P. P. R. S.
一到公司，他就找到董事会会议室。 Reaching the office, he sought the Board room.
董事长正在那里和经理开会。 The chairman was there in conference with the manager.
索姆斯静静地坐下来听着，一边听一边注视着那家伙的脸。 Soames sat down quietly to listen; and while he listened he watched that fellow’s face.
从他脸上看不出什么。 It told him nothing.
有人说你能从脸上看出人的性格，这简直是胡说八道！ What nonsense people talked when they said you could tell character from faces!
只有纯粹的白痴才能让人从脸上看出来。 Only a perfect idiot’s face could be read like that.
而眼下这个人却是一个有经验有文化的人，他熟悉商业生活和上流社会的一切规则。 And here was a man of experience and culture, one who knew every rope of business life and polite society.
他那光秃秃的头顶和整洁的面容所表现出来的忧虑，只不过是一个经营方针遭到了严重打击的人自然而然的窘迫感而已。 The hairless, neat features exhibited no more concern than the natural mortification of one whose policy had met with such a nasty knock.
马克贬值已经彻底抵消了下半年所有潜在的利润。 The drop of the mark had already wiped out any possible profit on the next half-year.
除非那该死的东西能恢复原状，否则他们就会背上一笔名存实亡的德国保险。 Unless the wretched thing recovered, they would be carrying a practically dead load of German insurance.
之前竟没有确定责任限额，这真是犯罪！ Really it was criminal that no limit of liability had been fixed!
他加入董事会的时候怎么会忽略了这一点呢？ How on earth could he ever have overlooked that when he came on the Board?
但是他也是后来才知道这件事的。 But he had only known of it afterwards.
而且谁能预见到像鲁尔事件这么疯狂的事情呢，谁又能意识到他的同事们会对这个糊涂的家伙盲目信任呢？ And who could have foreseen anything so mad as this Ruhr business, or realised the slack confidence of his colleagues in this confounded fellow?
“严重失职”这几个字像“特写镜头”一样浮现在他的眼前。 The words “gross negligence” appeared ‘close up’ before his eyes.
假如有人控告董事会怎么办！ What if an action lay against the Board!
严重失职！ Gross negligence!
以他的年龄，凭他的声望！ At his age and with his reputation!
唉！ Why!
这件事再明显不过了，由于忽略了责任限额，那家伙才拿到了他的佣金！ The thing was plain as a pikestaff; for omitting a limit of liability this chap had got his commission!
可能有10%，在整个那笔生意上——他一定已经净赚了几千镑！ Ten per cent, probably, on all that business—he must have netted thousands!
一个敢于冒那样风险的人，一定是走投无路了！ A man must be in Queer Street indeed to take a risk like that!
索姆斯意识到自己的想象没完没了，于是他站了起来，转过身去。 But conscious that his fancy was running on, Soames rose, and turned his back.
这个动作使他想到了另一个动作。 The action suggested another.
假装生气，从那个家伙的自我控制中找出一些迹象！ Simulate anger, draw some sign from that fellow’s self-control!
他又回过身来，怒气冲冲地说：“你到底是怎么搞的，经理先生，没有制定责任限额就通过了这些合同？ He turned again, and said pettishly: “What on earth were you about, Mr. Manager, when you allowed these contracts to go through without limit of liability?
像你这么有经验的人，居然干出这种事！ A man of your experience!
你的动机是什么？” What was your motive?”
那家伙眼睛稍稍一眯，嘴唇微微一抿。 A slight narrowing of the eyes, a slight compression of the lips.
他原指望“动机”这个词会起作用，但那个家伙却把它避开了。 He had relied on the word ‘motive,’ but the fellow passed it by.
“对于我们一直以来收取的如此高的保险费而言，福赛特先生，要设定责任限额是不太可能的。 “For such high premiums as we have been getting, Mr. Forsyte, a limited liability was not possible.
这是十分异常的发展情况，恐怕只能把它归结于坏运气。” This is a most outrageous development, and I’m afraid it must be considered just bad luck.”
“不幸的是，”索姆斯说，“我们将会发现，在管理得当的保险业中是不存在运气这类东西的，否则就是我大错特错了。 “Unfortunately,” said Soames, “there’s no such thing as luck in properly regulated assurance, as we shall find, or I’m much mistaken.
如果有人控告董事会严重失职，我一点儿也不感到意外！” I shouldn’t be surprised if an action lay against the Board for gross negligence!”
这下倒把董事长惹怒了！——把他惹怒了？ That had got the chairman’s goat!—Got his goat?
如今他们用的都是些什么词啊！ What expressions they used nowadays!
或者这是正话反说？ Or did it mean the opposite?
谁知道呢！ One never knew!
但是至于埃尔德森——在索姆斯看来，他只是在假装一副紧张不安的样子。 But as for Elderson—he seemed to Soames to be merely counterfeiting a certain flusteration.
试图从他那样的家伙身上套出些什么来，是白费劲了。 Futile to attempt to spring anything out of a chap like that.
如果这件事是真的，那个家伙一定彻底绝望了，肯定会铤而走险。 If the thing were true, the fellow must be entirely desperate, prepared for anything and everything.
由于对索姆斯来说，人生绝望的一面——那些迫使赌徒孤注一掷的真实的困境和难以忍受的境地——一直都被他那谨慎的天性小心翼翼地隔绝了，如果埃尔德森有罪的话，他现在简直无法想象他的心理状态和行为方式会是什么样子。 And since from Soames the desperate side of life—the real holes, the impossible positions which demand a gambler’s throw—had always been carefully barred by the habits of a prudent nature, he found it now impossible to imagine Elderson’s state of mind, or his line of conduct if he were guilty.
因为他现在能感觉到的是，那家伙可能随身带着毒药，也可能像电影里的人一样，屁股下坐着一把左轮手枪。 For all he could tell, the chap might be carrying poison about with him; might be sitting on a revolver like a fellow on the film.
整个这件事太让人不悦，太让人焦虑了，非言语所能表达。 The whole thing was too unpleasant, too worrying for words.
于是，他没有再说什么就离开了，他没有带走任何东西，只是得知了一条消息，由于马克变得一文不值，他们在德国业务上的负债总计超过20万英镑。 And without saying any more he went away, taking nothing with him but the knowledge that their total liability on this German business, with the mark valueless, was over two hundred thousand pounds.
他匆匆地估算了一下那些和他共事的董事们的财产。 He hastily reviewed the fortunes of his co-directors.
老福坦诺向来手头拮据；董事长的财产难以猜测；蒙特的财产是地皮，地皮正在贬值，并且都抵押出去了；老柯赛·莫德吉尔除了他的虚名和董事酬劳金外一无所有；迈里克一定有一大笔收入，但是来得快，去得也快，就像大多数的那些大律师，业务繁忙，而且肯定能当上法官。 Old Fontenoy was always in low water; the chairman a dark horse; Mont was in land, land right down in value, and mortgaged at that; old Cosey Mothergill had nothing but his name and his director’s fees; Meyricke must have a large income, but light come, light go, like most of those big counsel with irons in many fires and the certainty of a judgeship.
这些人之中，除了他自己，没有一个是真正富裕的人！ Not a really substantial man among the lot, except himself!
他低着头，脚步沉重地向前走着。 He ploughed his way along, head down.
上市公司！ Public companies!
荒谬的制度！ Preposterous system!
你不得不信任某一个人，然后你就落到了今天的境地！ You had to trust somebody, and there you were!
这可真可怕！ It was appalling!
“气球，先生——漂亮的颜色，可以吹出五英尺的周长。 “Balloons, sir—beautiful colours, five feet circumference.
买一个吧，先生！” Take one, gentleman!”
“上帝啊！”索姆斯说。 “Good gad!” said Soames.
好像戳破了德国业务的气泡还不够似的！ As if the pricked bubble of German business were not enough!
第二章 Chapter II
维多琳 Victorine
进入十二月以来，气球生意一直萧条——即使在圣诞节的那一周，生意也没什么起色。对于比克特夫妇来说，移居澳大利亚中部的梦想还是那么遥不可及。 All through December balloons had been slack—hardly any movement about them, even in Christmas week, and from the Bickets Central Australia was as far as ever.
维多琳的身体已经恢复得差不多了，但还是没有如期到博尼·布莱兹公司的女衬衣部报到。 The girl Victorine, restored to comparative health, had not regained her position in the blouse department of Messrs.Boney Blayds & Co.
他们给过她一些琐碎的针线活，但是最近没有什么零活。她花了很长时间，就是想要找一份相对稳定的工作。 They had given her some odd sewing, but not of late, and she had spent much time trying to get work less uncertain.
她的问题出在——一直出在——她的脸上。 Her trouble was—had always been—her face.
她的脸与众不同。 It was unusual.
人们不知道是什么使一个女孩出落成这样的。 People did not know what to make of a girl who looked like that.
为什么非要雇佣一个没有财富、地位和品味，还缺乏能力（在他们看来），但又使他们相形见绌的员工呢？ Why employ one who without qualification of wealth, rank, fashion, or ability (so far as they knew) made them feel ordinary?
因为在制作或销售衬衣时，在试穿皮鞋时，在填写信封时，在做殡仪的花圈时，或者是在维多琳感兴趣的其他行当中，兴趣爱好不是她首要考虑的——尽管它对于弗勒和迈克尔那类人是不可或缺的。 For—however essential to such as Fleur and Michael—dramatic interest was not primary in the manufacture or sale of blouses, in the fitting-on of shoes, the addressing of envelopes, making-up of funeral wreaths, or the other ambitions of Victorine.
在那双黑黑的大眼睛和沉默的双唇后面，究竟发生过什么事情呢？ Behind those large dark eyes and silent lips, what went on?
这一切使博尼·布莱兹公司和更多的商业批发公司感到一丝不安。 It worried Boney Blayds & Co., and the more wholesale firms of commerce.
但是对于出生在帕特尼镇而且生来自卑的维多琳来说，像那种需要浓妆艳抹的职业——例如电影演员或者服装模特——都是从来没有想过的。 The lurid professions—film-super, or mannequin—did not occur to one, of self-deprecating nature, born in Putney.
每天早晨，当比克特带着托盘和那些还没充气的气球离开家时，她就会站在那里一直咬着自己的手指，似乎要咬出一条摆脱这贫困生活的出路。贫困生活已经使她的丈夫骨瘦如柴，累得像只白嘴鸦，寒酸得像只秃尾巴的麻雀，而且，就算以丢掉自己社会地位为代价，也只能勉强不流落街头而已。 When Bicket had gone out of a morning with his tray and his balloons not yet blown up, she would stand biting her finger, as though to gnaw her way to some escape from this hand-to-mouth existence which kept her husband thin as a rail, tired as a rook, shabby as a tailless sparrow, and, at the expense of all caste feeling, brought them in no more than just enough to keep them living under a roof.
他们两个人心里早就明白，气球只不过是一件贩卖的礼物，靠它是没有前途的。 It had long been clear to them both that there was no future in balloons, just a cadging present.
所以维多琳沉默地压抑着，消极地积聚着一股愤恨之情。 And there smouldered in the silent, passive Victorine a fierce resentment.
她要为自己，为他，主要是为他，争取更好的生活。 She wanted better things for herself, for him, chiefly for him.
在马克惨跌的那个清晨，她穿上短款棉绒上衣，戴上那顶小圆帽（这两件可是她衣橱里剩下的最好的东西了），心里已经做了决定。 On the morning when the mark was bumping down, she was putting on her velveteen jacket and toque (best remaining items of her wardrobe), having taken a resolve.
比克特对之前那份工作只字未提，但是她已经能敏感地猜测到，他失业可能另有隐情。 Bicket never mentioned his old job, and his wife had subtly divined some cause beyond the ordinary for his loss of it.
为什么不再尝试一下呢，也许她能让比克特复职？ Why not see if she could get him taken back?
他总是说：“蒙特先生可是个好人，是社会主义者那种类型的，还参加过大战，一点儿架子也没有，平易近人。” He had often said: “Mr. Mont’s a gent and a sort o’ socialist; been through the war, too; no high-and-mighty about HIM.”
要是她能和这位非凡人物“交流”就好了！ If she could ‘get at’ this phenomenon!
蜡黄的脸上涌起了希望和勇敢带来的红晕，她不禁在斯特兰德大街的橱窗玻璃中打量着自己。 With the flush of hope and daring in her sallow cheeks, she took stock of her appearance from the window-glasses of the Strand.
喜欢色彩艳丽的人总是喜欢她那件翠绿色的短棉绒上衣，但是她的黑裙子嘛——嗯，假如她站在柜台后面的话，就不会看出它的破旧了。 Her velveteen of jade-green always pleased one who had an eye for colour, but her black skirt—well, perhaps the wear and tear of it wouldn’t show if she kept behind the counter.
她有足够的胆量和勇气说她是因为书稿来的吗？ Had she brass enough to say that she came about a manuscript?
于是她默默地演练了一番，尽力保持着那种腔调：“因为稿子的事，我想见蒙特先生，麻烦您通知一下。” And she rehearsed with silent lips, pinching her accent: “Would you ask Mr. Mont, please, if I could see him; it’s about a manuscript.”
对了！可能接待人会发问：“请问您贵姓？” Yes! and then would come the question: “What name, please?”
“比克特夫人？” “Mrs. Bicket?”
不能这么说！ Never!
“维多琳·柯林斯小姐？” “Miss Victorine Collins?”
所有的女作家应该都用自己的闺名吧。 All authoresses had maiden names.
对——就说维多琳！ Victorine—yes!
但是柯林斯呢！ But Collins!
听上去不太像。 It didn’t sound like.
也没人知道她的闺名叫什么。 And no one would know what her maiden name had been.
为什么不选个其他名字呢？ Why not choose one?
人们通常都这么干。 They often chose.
于是她思考起来。 And she searched.
意大利式的名字，就像——就像——他们刚搬进来时，女房东不是就曾经问他们：“您妻子是意大利人吗？” Something Italian, like—like—Hadn’t their landlady said to them when they came in: “Is your wife Eyetalian?”
啊！ Ah!
曼纽莉！ Manuelli!
这绝对是个纯正的意大利名字——那个在小沟街上卖冰激凌的小贩就叫这个名字。 That was certainly Italian—the ice-cream man in Little Ditch Street had it!
她边走边小声练习着。 She walked on practising beneath her breath.
只要能见到蒙特先生！ If only she could get to see this Mr. Mont!
她哆嗦着走了进去。 She entered, trembling.
一切跟她想象的一模一样，就连她保持的语气都是一样的，一直到她站在那里等着电话的回复，她的双手缩在那副很旧的手套里。 All went exactly as foreseen, even to the pinching of her accent, till she stood waiting for them to bring an answer from the speaking tube, concealing her hands in their very old gloves.
曼纽莉小姐有预约吗？ Had Miss Manuelli an appointment?
这里并没有她的稿子啊。 There was no manuscript.
“不，”维多琳说，“我还没来得及把稿子送过来。 “No,” said Victorine, “I haven’t sent it yet.
我想先见见蒙特先生。” I wanted to see him first.”
年轻的接待员盯着维多琳。 The young man at the counter was looking at her hard.
他再次拿起电话，说着。 He went again to the tube, then spoke.
“请您稍等片刻——蒙特先生的女秘书马上就过来。” “Will you wait a minute, please—Mr. Mont’s lady secretary is coming down.”
维多琳心沉了一下，把头垂在了胸前。 Victorine inclined her head towards her sinking heart.
女秘书！ A lady secretary!
这下恐怕她是见不到蒙特先生了！ She would never get there now!
与此同时，刚才编造的那个借口让她不禁担心起来。 And there came on her the sudden dread of false pretences.
但是一想到托尼还站在街角辛苦地吹着气球，卖着气球——她曾多次暗地里看见他那辛苦的样子，维多琳就不顾一切，想要拼搏一把。 But the thought of Tony standing at his corner, ballooned up to the eyes, as she had spied out more than once, fortified her desperation.
一个女声响了起来：“是曼纽莉小姐吗？ A girl’s voice said: “Miss Manuelli?
我是蒙特先生的秘书，有什么事情，也许我可以替您转达。” Mr. Mont’s secretary, perhaps you could give me a message.”
这位面色红润的女士上下打量着她。 A fresh-faced young woman’s eyes were travelling up and down her.
她尽力保持语气，说：“哦！ Pinching her accent hard, she said: “Oh!
恐怕这样不行。” I’m afraid I couldn’t do that.”
上下打量的目光停留在她的脸上。 The travelling gaze stopped at her face.
“那您跟我进来吧，我看看蒙特先生是否有时间见您。” “If you’ll come with me, I’ll see if he can see you.”
维多琳独自在一间小会客厅一动不动地等待着，过了一会儿，她看见一位年轻人探头说道： Alone in a small waiting-room, Victorine sat without movement, till she saw a young man’s face poked through the doorway, and heard the words:
“请您进来一下好吗？” “Will you come in?”
她深吸一口气，然后走进去。 She took a deep breath, and went.
来到屋里，她看了看迈克尔，又看了看秘书，再次看向迈克尔。她隐约感觉到以他的年轻、骑士风范和运动家的风度，他是不会拒绝同她进行一次私人谈话的。 Once in the presence, she looked from Michael to his secretary and back again, subtly daring his youth, his chivalry, his sportsmanship, to refuse her a private interview.
此时迈克尔脑海里突然闪现一个念头：“我猜是为了钱吧。 Through Michael passed at once the thought: ‘Money, I suppose.
但这是一张多么令人动容的脸啊！” But what an interesting face!’
秘书撇了撇嘴，离开了房间。 The secretary drew down the corners of her mouth and left the room,
“嗯，曼纽莉——呃——小姐？” “Well, Miss—er—Manuelli?”
“我不叫曼纽莉，请原谅我——我是比克特夫人，我丈夫以前一直在这工作。” “Not Manuelli, please—Mrs. Bicket; my husband used to be here.”
“什么！” “What!”
就是那个偷了《铜币》的家伙！ The chap that had snooped ‘Copper Coin!’
哎！ Phew!
比克特捏造的谎话——他的妻子——得了肺炎！ Bicket’s yarn—his wife—pneumonia!
她看上去好像确实得过肺炎。 She looked as if she might have had it.
“他常提起您，先生。 “He often spoke of you, sir.
但是，他还没有找到工作。 And, please, he hasn’t any work.
您能不能给他找份工作啊，先生？” Couldn’t you find room for him again, sir?”
迈克尔默默地站在那里。 Michael stood silent.
这位长相极其动人的女士是否知道她丈夫偷窃的事情呢？ Did this terribly interesting-looking girl know about the snooping?
“他现在只是在街头卖气球，我真不忍心看他这样。 “He just sells balloons in the street now; I can’t bear to see him.
他在圣保罗大教堂旁边卖气球，也不赚钱。我们这么拼命，就是想尽早离开这儿，到澳大利亚去。 Over by St. Paul’s he stands, and there’s no money in it; and we do so want to get out to Australia.
我知道他脾气急，为此得罪了不少人。 I know he’s very nervy, and gets wrong with people.
但是假如您同意让他重新回来工作……” But if you COULD take him back here....”
嗯！她肯定不知道！ No! she did not know!
“非常抱歉，比克特夫人。 “Very sorry, Mrs. Bicket.
我记得您的丈夫，但是我们这里没有适合他的岗位了。 I remember your husband well, but we haven’t a place for him.
您现在完全康复了吗？” Are YOU all right again?”
“哦！是的。 “Oh! yes.
只是我也不可能再找到工作了。” Except that I can’t get work again either.”
这张脸要是做封面该多好啊！ What a face for wrappers!
蒙娜丽莎型的！ Sort of Mona Lisa-ish!
斯托伯托的长篇小说！ Storbert’s novel!
哈！ Ha!
“嗯，我会和您的丈夫谈谈。 “Well, I’ll have a talk with your husband.
我不知道您是否愿意让画家做封面写生呢？ I suppose you wouldn’t like to sit to an artist for a book-wrapper?
如果您要是愿意，说不定今后可以在这一行当干。 It might lead to work in that line if you want it.
您恰巧符合我的一位朋友需要的长相类型。 You’re just the type for a friend of mine.
您听说过奥布里·格林的作品吗？” Do you know Aubrey Greene’s work?”
“没听过，先生。” “No, sir.”
“他的作品还是很不错的——实际上，在颓废艺术风格上独领风骚。 “It’s pretty good—in fact, very good in a decadent way.
您不会介意坐在那里让别人画像吧？” You wouldn’t mind sitting?”
“为了赚点儿钱，我愿意。 “I wouldn’t mind anything to save some money.
不过我还是恳请您别告诉我丈夫，别跟他提我来找过您。 But I’d rather you didn’t tell my husband I’d been to see you.
他要是知道了，会不高兴的。” He might take it amiss.”
“好的！ “All right!
就当偶遇他吧。 I’ll see him by accident.
您刚才说是在圣保罗大教堂附近吗？ Near St. Paul’s, you said?
但是比克特夫人，我们这里肯定不可能给他提供就业机会了。 But there’s no chance here, Mrs. Bicket.
况且他曾经跟我说过，他只靠这里的工资也是很难维持生计的。” Besides, he couldn’t make two ends meet on this job, he told me.”
“先生，那是在我生病的那段时期。” “When I was ill, sir.”
“当然，那是非常时期。” “Of course, that makes a difference.”
“是啊，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“嗯，我替您给格林先生写张便条。 “Well, let me write you a note to Mr. Greene.
您坐一会儿好吗？” Will you sit down a minute?”
就在她坐着等待的时候，他偷偷看了她一眼。 He stole a look at her while she sat waiting.
她那张长着一双大眼睛的蜡黄色脸蛋，再配上乌黑、发梢卷曲的短发，的确引人注目——在一般大众看来，这副长相有些太过优雅和苍白了，但是，管他呢！人们眼前不能总是那种利洁时广告女郎的蓝眼睛、淡黄色的头发和红彤彤的脸颊。 Really, her sallow, large-eyed face, with its dead-black, bobbed, frizzy-ended hair, was extraordinarily interesting—a little too refined and anaemic for the public; but, dash it all! the public couldn’t always have its Reckitt’s blue eyes, corn-coloured hair, and poppy cheeks.
“就大众品味来讲，”他写着，“她算不上一个美人，但她气质独特，会自成一种风格，就像比尔兹利或达纳画笔下的人物。 “She’s not a peach,” he wrote, “on the main tree of taste; but so striking in her way that she really might become a type, like Beardsley’s or Dana’s.”
她拿着便条离开后，迈克尔按铃叫秘书进来。 When she had taken the note and gone, he rang for his secretary.
“佩伦小姐，她没有从我这里拿走半点儿好处。 “No, Miss Perren, she didn’t take anything off me.
这可是个特例，不是吗？” But some type, eh?”
“我原以为您愿意见她呢。 “I thought you’d like to see her.
她不是女作家，对吗？” She wasn’t an authoress, was she?”
“根本不是。” “Far from it.”
“嗯，我希望她已经得到她希望得到的东西了。” “Well, I hope she got what she wanted.”
迈克尔咧嘴笑笑。 Michael grinned.
“一部分，佩伦小姐——得到一部分。 “Partly, Miss Perren—partly.
你认为我是一个大傻瓜，对不对？” You think I’m an awful fool, don’t you?”
“我绝不会这样认为的，但是我觉得您的心肠太软了。” “I’m sure I don’t; but I think you’re too soft-hearted.”
迈克尔用手指捋了捋头发。 Michael ran his fingers through his hair.
“假如你听说我做成了一笔生意，你会感到惊讶吗？” “Would it surprise you to hear that I’ve done a stroke of business?”
“肯定会的，蒙特先生。” “Yes, Mr. Mont.”
“那我就不告诉你了。 “Then I won’t tell you what it is.
等你不再撅嘴了，我们继续把那封给我父亲的关于《二重唱》的信写完：‘我们很遗憾，以现在这种经营状况，我们无法重印那两个老家伙之间的对话，在这本书上我们已经赔钱了！’ When you’ve done pouting, go on with that letter to my father about ‘Duet’: ‘We are sorry to say that in the present state of the trade we should not be justified in reprinting the dialogue between those two old blighters; we have already lost money by it!’
当然你得婉转地表达这个意思。 You must translate, of course.
现在想想我们能不能说一些使老人高兴的话？ Now can we say something to cheer the old boy up?
这么说怎么样？ How about this?
‘等到法国人恢复了神志，鸟儿开始歌唱——总之，等到春天来了——我们希望重新考虑这件事，根据——根据’——呃——什么呢，佩伦小姐？” ‘When the French have recovered their wits, and the birds begin to sing—in short, when spring comes—we hope to reconsider the matter in the light of—of’—er—what, Miss Perren?”
“‘根据到时的具体情况。’ “‘The experience we shall have gained.’
我可以省去那几句关于法国人和鸟儿的句子吗？” Shall I leave out about the French and the birds?”
“好的！ “Excellent!
‘您忠诚的，丹比&温特出版社。’ ‘Yours faithfully, Danby and Winter.’
那本书在这里出版，你难道不认为这是不体面的裙带关系吗，佩伦小姐？” Don’t you think it was a scandalous piece of nepotism bringing the book here at all, Miss Perren?”
“什么是‘裙带关系’？” “What is ‘nepotism’?”
“沾你儿子的光。 “Taking advantage of your son.
他从来没有从他的任何一本书上赚过钱。” He’s never made a sixpence by any of his books.”
“蒙特先生，他是一位了不起的作家。” “He’s a very distinguished writer, Mr. Mont.”
“但是我们为‘了不起’付出了代价。 “And we pay for the distinction.
他是位善良的老准爵爷。 Well, he’s a good old Bart.
午饭前就处理这些事吧，好好吃顿午餐吧。 That’s all before lunch, and mind you have a good one.
那位女士的身材挺出众的，是不是？ That girl’s figure wasn’t usual either, was it?
她很瘦，但是站得笔直。 She’s thin, but she stands up straight.
佩伦小姐，有个问题我一直想问，为什么那些时髦女性走路时总喜欢把头往前伸，让身子形成一条曲线呢？ There’s a question I always want to ask, Miss Perren: Why do modern girls walk in a curve with their heads poked forward?
她们不可能都长成那个模样。” They can’t all be built like that.”
女秘书脸红了。 The secretary’s cheeks brightened.
“蒙特先生，这是有原因的。” “There IS a reason, Mr. Mont.”
“真的！ “Good!
什么原因？” What is it?”
女秘书的脸继续红着。 The secretary’s cheeks continued to brighten.
“我实在不知道我是否能——” “I don’t really know whether I can—”
“哦！对不起。 “Oh! sorry.
我问我妻子好了。 I’ll ask my wife.
不过她的身板也挺得笔直。” Only she’s quite straight herself.”
“嗯，蒙特先生，是这样的，您看：她们不喜欢有东西在——后面，但是，当然，她们后面肯定是有东西的，所以除非她们把胸部收进去，把头伸在前面，她们不可能达到预计效果。 “Well, Mr. Mont, it’s this, you see: They aren’t supposed to have anything be—behind, and, of course, they have, and they can’t get the proper effect unless they curve their chests in and poke their heads forward.
穿着时髦的人和模特都这样。＂ It’s the fashion-plates and mannequins that do it.”
“我明白了，”迈克尔说，“谢谢你，佩伦小姐，你真是太好了。 “I see,” said Michael; “thank you, Miss Perren; awfully good of you.
那样子让人难以接受，是不是？” It’s the limit, isn’t it?”
“是，我自己不那样。” “Yes, I don’t hold with it, myself.”
“不，你一点儿也不那样！” “No, quite!”
女秘书低下眼皮，走了出去。 The secretary lowered her eyelids and withdrew.
迈克尔坐下，在那张吸墨水纸上画了一张脸。 Michael sat down and drew a face on his blotting-paper.
那不是维多琳的脸…… It was not Victorine’s....
维多琳拿着写给奥布里·格林的那张便条，像往常一样，用一杯咖啡和一点儿油酥蛋糕当午餐，就乘地铁去了切尔西。 Armed with the note to Aubrey Greene, Victorine had her usual lunch, a cup of coffee and a bit of heavy cake, and took the tube towards Chelsea.
虽然比克特复职的事没办成，但是那位先生和蔼可亲，使她受到鼓舞。 She had not succeeded, but the gentleman had been friendly and she felt cheered.
画室门口，一个年轻人正把钥匙插进门锁里——一个没戴帽子、看着挺机灵的小伙子，穿着一身烟灰色哈里斯粗花呢制服，显得很雅致，光亮的头发漂亮地朝后梳着，声音非常柔和。 At the studio door was a young man inserting a key—very elegant in smoke-grey Harris tweeds, a sliding young man with no hat, beautifully brushed-back bright hair, and a soft voice.
“是模特吗？”他说。 “Model?” he said.
“是的，先生。 “Yes, sir, please.
蒙特先生让我捎一张便条。” I have a note for you from Mr. Mont.”
“迈克尔？ “Michael?
进来吧。” Come in.”
维多琳随他走进去。 Victorine followed him in.
屋内是一片海绿色，房子很高，屋顶有许多椽子和一扇天窗，墙上挂着许多素描和画像，而且看起来它们就像要滑落到地板上了。 It was ‘not half’ sea-green in there; a high room with rafters and a top light, and lots of pictures and drawings on the walls, and as if they had slipped off on to the floor.
画架上的一幅画令维多琳感到不安，画的是两位裸体妇人，她们的衣服滑落在一旁。 A picture on an easel of two ladies with their clothes sliding down troubled Victorine.
此时，她注意到那位先生正用像墙壁一样的海绿色的眼睛上下打量着自己。 She became conscious of the gentleman’s eyes, sea-green like the walls, sliding up and down her.
“我要开始画了，您可以坐好吗？”他问。 “Will you sit for anything?” he asked.
维多琳机械地回答：“可以，先生。” Victorine answered mechanically: “Yes, sir.”
“您不介意把帽子摘了吧？” “Do you mind taking your hat off?”
维多琳摘下帽子，把头发抖开。 Victorine took off the toque, and shook out her hair.
“啊！”先生说道， “Ah!” said the gentleman.
“我觉得奇怪。” “I wonder.”
维多琳不知道他奇怪什么。 Victorine wondered what.
“坐在台子上，好吗？” “Just sit down on the dais, will you?”
维多琳迟疑地朝四周环顾。 Victorine looked about her, uncertain.
一丝微笑好像飞过他的前额，掠过他那光亮的头发。 A smile seemed to fly up his forehead and over his slippery bright hair.
“这是您第一次试画吗？” “This is your first shot, then?”
“是的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“那更好。” “All the better.”
说着他用手指指那个小平台。 And he pointed to a small platform.
维多琳坐在平台上的一把黑色橡木椅子上。 Victorine sat down on it in a black oak chair.
“您看上去感觉好像有些冷。” “You look cold.”
“是的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
他朝橱柜走去，拿了两个盛着棕色液体的小杯回来。 He went to a cupboard and returned with two small glasses of a brown fluid.
“喝杯柑曼怡吧？” “Have a Grand Marnier?”
她看他一饮而尽，于是自己也喝干了。 She noticed that he tossed his off in one gulp, and did the same.
这酒甘甜浓郁，很好喝，让她大吸一口气。 It was sweet, strong, very nice, and made her gasp.
“抽支烟。” “Take a cigarette.”
维多琳从他递过来的烟盒里拿了一支，把它放在嘴里。 Victorine took one from a case he handed, and put it between her lips.
他点着烟。 He lit it.
又是一个微笑掠过他的前额。 And again a smile slid up away over the top of his head.
“您抽吧，”他说， “You draw it in,” he said.
“您是哪里人？” “Where were you born?”
“帕特尼人，先生。” “In Putney, sir.”
“很有意思。 “That’s very interesting.
只要静静地坐那儿一会。 Just sit still a minute.
不像拔牙那么糟，只是坐的时间有些长。 It’s not as bad as having a tooth out, but it takes longer.
关键是要保持清醒。” The great thing is to keep awake.”
“好的，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
他拿了一张大纸和一块黑颜色的东西，开始画了起来。 He took a large piece of paper and a bit of dark stuff, and began to draw.
“告诉我，”他说，“您贵姓——” “Tell me,” he said, “Miss—”
“柯林斯，先生，——维多琳·柯林斯。” “Collins, sir—Victorine Collins.”
她本能地说出了自己结婚之前的名字。 Some instinct made her give her maiden name.
这个习惯倒是很符合职业化的要求。 It seemed somehow more professional.
“您没有固定工作？” “Are you at large?”
他停顿了一下，微笑再一次掠过光亮的头发，“还是您有其他职业？” He paused, and again the smile slid up over his bright hair: “Or have you any other occupation?”
“目前没有，先生。 “Not at present, sir.
我已经结婚了，就这些。” I’m married, but nothing else.”
从这之后，那位先生沉默了许久。 For some time after that the gentleman was silent.
她看着他看一眼自己，在纸上画一笔，然后再看一眼，觉得很有意思。 It was interesting to see him, taking a look, making a stroke on the paper, taking another look.
看了有几百次，就画了几百笔。 Hundreds of looks, hundreds of strokes.
最后他说：“好了！ At last he said: “All right!
现在我们歇会儿吧。 Now we’ll have a rest.
柯林斯小姐，是上帝派您来到这儿的。 Heaven sent you here, Miss Collins.
过来暖暖身子吧。” Come and get warm.”
维多琳走到壁炉旁。 Victorine approached the fire.
“您了解表现主义吗？” “Do you know anything about expressionism?”
“不，先生。” “No, sir.”
“嗯，表现主义就是不考虑外在事物，除非外在事物能够表现出内心的东西。 “Well, it means not troubling about the outside except in so far as it expresses the inside.
您明白了吗？” Does that convey anything to you?”
“不明白，先生。” “No, sir.”
“没关系！ “Quite!
我记得您曾经说过，愿意坐着让我给您画一张裸身像？” I think you said you’d sit for the—er—altogether?”
维多琳注视着面前这位既聪明又圆滑的先生。 Victorine regarded the bright and sliding gentleman.
她没理解他的意思，但是她隐约感觉他指的是某种不同寻常的东西。 She did not know what he meant, but she felt that he meant something out of the ordinary.
“先生，裸身像是什么？” “Altogether what, sir?”
“就是裸体画。” “Nude.”
“哦！” “Oh!”
她垂下眼睛，然后抬头朝两位妇人滑落的衣服望去。 She cast her eyes down, then raised them to the sliding clothes of the two ladies.
“跟那种一样？” “Like that?”
“不是，我不想用立体派的手法来画您。” “No, I shouldn’t be treating you cubistically.”
她那张蜡黄色的脸上慢慢地泛起了一丝红晕。 A slow flush was burning out the sallow in her cheeks.
她慢吞吞地说： She said slowly:
“这样的画法是不是能挣更多的钱？” “Does it mean more money?”
“是啊，最起码翻一倍——或更多。 “Yes, half as much again—more perhaps.
我不勉强您。 I don’t want you to if you’d rather not.
您自己认真考虑一下，下次来的时候告诉我。” You can think it over and let me know next time.”
她再次抬起眼睛，说：“谢谢您，先生。” She raised her eyes again, and said: “Thank you, sir.”
“好！ “Righto!
就是别再叫我‘先生’了。” Only please don’t ‘sir’ me.”
维多琳笑了。 Victorine smiled.
这是她第一次做出这么反常的表情，却似乎产生了奇特的功效。 It was the first time she had achieved this functional disturbance, and it seemed to have a strange effect.
他匆忙地说：“上帝啊！ He said hurriedly: “By George!
柯林斯小姐，当您微笑时，我就从印象派角度来观察您。 When you smile, Miss Collins, I see you impressionistically.
如果您感觉休息得差不多了，请再坐回那里。” If you’ve rested, sit up there again.”
维多琳走了回去。 Victorine went back.
年轻人又拿了一张新的画纸。 The gentleman took a fresh piece of paper.
“您能不能想一些高兴的事，使您一直保持微笑呢？” “Can you think of anything that will keep you smiling?”
她摇摇头。 She shook her head.
确实如此。 That was a fact.
“一件高兴的事都没有？ “Nothing comic at all?
打个比方，我猜，您不爱您的丈夫吧？” I suppose you’re not in love with your husband, for instance?”
“哦！爱呀。” “Oh! yes.”
“对呀，就想想这些。” “Well, try that.”
维多琳试着那样做，但她眼前只是浮现出托尼卖气球的场景。 Victorine tried that, but she could only see Tony selling his balloons.
“感觉不对，”年轻人说， “That won’t do,” said the gentleman.
“别想他了。 “Don’t think of him!
您看没看过《牧神的午后》？” Did you ever see ‘L’apres midi d’un Faune’?”
“没有，先生。” “No, sir.”
“嗯，我有个主意。 “Well, I’ve got an idea.
《林中仙女的午后时光》。 ‘L’apres midi d’une Dryade.’
关于裸体画的事您不必在意。 About the nude you really needn’t mind.
它跟个人完全无关。 It’s quite impersonal.
想想那是艺术，想想一天15个先令。 Think of art, and fifteen bob a day.
尼金斯基的每个角度，我都画过！” Shades of Nijinsky, I see the whole thing!”
他说话这段时间，他的眼睛一直在她身上不停打量，他手里的铅笔在纸上忽上忽下。 All the time that he was talking his eyes were sliding off and on to her, and his pencil off and on to the paper.
一种影响力开始在维多琳心中起了作用。 A sort of infection began to ferment within Victorine.
一天15个先令。 Fifteen shillings a day!
蓝色蝴蝶！ Blue butterflies!
一阵沉默。 There was a profound silence.
他的眼睛和手一起一落地忙着。 His eyes and hand slid off and on.
维多琳脸上浮现出一抹淡淡的微笑——此时此刻她心里正盘算着自己能挣多少钱呢。 A faint smile had come on Victorine’s face—she was adding up the money she might earn.
终于，他的手和眼睛不再移动了，之后他站在那里端详着那幅画。 At last his eyes and hand ceased moving, and he stood looking at the paper.
“柯林斯小姐，今天就到这里吧。 “That’s all for today, Miss Collins.
我得再仔细酝酿一下。 I’ve got to think it out.
您给我留下您的地址好吗？” Will you give me your address?”
维多琳脑子快速转动了一下。 Victorine thought rapidly.
“不好意思，先生，还是请您把信寄到邮局，我自己去领。 “Please, sir, will you write to me at the post office.
我不想让我丈夫知道我在——我在——” I don’t want my husband to know that I’m—I’m—”
“与艺术打交道？ “Affiliated to art?
嗯！ Well!
邮局的名字？” Name of post office?”
维多琳把邮局名称给了他，然后戴上帽子。 Victorine gave it and resumed her hat.
“一个半小时，五个先令，谢谢您。 “An hour and a half, five shillings, thank you.
明天两点半，柯林斯小姐——别再叫我先生了。” And tomorrow, at half-past two, Miss Collins—not ‘sir.’”
“是，先——，谢谢您。” “Yes, s—, thank you.”
维多琳在一月的寒风中等着公共汽车。在她看来，裸体似乎是不太可能实现的。 Waiting for her ‘bus in the cold January air, the altogether appeared to Victorine improbable.
赤身裸体地坐在一位陌生男人面前！ To sit in front of a strange gentleman in her skin!
要是托尼知道了！ If Tony knew!
她那蜡黄的脸颊上又泛起了一丝红晕。 The slow flush again burned up the sallow in her cheeks.
她上了公共汽车。 She climbed into the ‘bus.
但是15个先令啊！ But fifteen shillings!
一周六天——啊，那就是四镑十先令啊！ Six days a week—why, it would be four pound ten!
只要四个月就能赚到他们去澳大利亚的路费了。 In four months she could earn their passage out.
从放在那里的那些画像来看，肯定有不少人在干这一行。 Judging by the pictures in there, lots must be doing it.
绝不能让托尼知道，就连别人给她画脸这件事也不能让他知道。 Tony must know nothing, not even that she was sitting for her face.
他异常敏感，而且很爱她！ He was all nerves, and that fond of her!
他会胡思乱想的，她曾经听他说过，那些艺术家就像猫一样。 He would imagine things; she had heard him say those artists were just like cats.
不过画画的那位年轻人倒是很正派，虽然他看起来对任何事情都不屑一顾。 But that gentleman had been very nice, though he did seem as if he were laughing at everything.
她真希望他把那幅画给自己看看。 She wished he had shown her the drawing.
也许有一天，她能在展览会上看见自己的画像。 Perhaps she would see herself in an exhibition some day.
但是不穿衣服——哦！ But without—oh!
这时她突然想到：“我要是再多吃点儿，我也会像那幅画上的女子那样漂亮的！” And suddenly she thought: ‘If I ate a bit more, I’d look nice like that, too!’
似乎是要躲避这个大胆的想法，她抬起头，望着对面的那张脸。 And as if to escape from the daring of that thought, she stared up into the face opposite.
那张脸双下巴、冷静、光滑、红润，一双灵敏的眼睛也在注视着她。 It had two chins, was calm and smooth and pink, with light eyes staring back at her.
人们都在思考，但你说不出他们都在思考什么！ People had thoughts, but you couldn’t tell what they were!
于是奥布里·格林渴望的那种微笑悄悄浮上他模特的脸庞。 And the smile which Aubrey Greene desired crept out on his model’s face.
第三章 Chapter III
迈克尔的游历和言论 Michael Walks and Talks
迈克尔画的那张脸从描绘维多琳开始，到以描绘弗勒收尾。 The face Michael drew began by being Victorine’s, and ended by being Fleur’s.
假如弗勒身体站得笔直，那她在道德上又是否同样正直呢？ If physically Fleur stood up straight, was she morally as erect?
这种想法一出现，总是让他觉得自己很龌龊。 This was the speculation for which he continually called himself a cad.
他丝毫看不出弗勒有什么改变，同时他在极力避免自己去追问那些他不知道的事情。 He saw no change in her movements, and loyally refrained from enquiring into the movements he could not see.
但是他那被激发的注意力愈发使他感觉到某种不屑一顾的态度，好像它已成了弗勒一贯信奉的信仰——所有价值观都是平等的，也没有什么价值观是有价值的。 But his aroused attention made him more and more aware of a certain cynicism, as if she were continually registering the belief that all values were equal and none of much value.
虽然威尔弗里德还在伦敦，但是看不见他的人影，大家也不提他。 Wilfrid, though still in London, was neither visible nor spoken of.
“眼不见，耳不闻，心不烦。”好像已经成为了至理名言。 “Out of sight and hearing, out of mind,” seemed to be the motto.
但是这句至理名言对迈克尔丝毫不起作用——他的心中总是有威尔弗里德的影子。 It did not work with Michael—Wilfrid was constantly in his mind.
假如威尔弗里德见不到弗勒，那他怎么能忍受那种可望而不可即的痛苦？ If Wilfrid were not seeing Fleur, how could he bear to stay within such tantalising reach of her?
假如弗勒不想让威尔弗里德留下，那么为什么不打发他走呢？ If Fleur did not want Wilfrid to stay, why had she not sent him away?
如果对旁人隐瞒自己和德赛特已经不是好友了，他觉得也很难。 He was finding it difficult, too, to conceal from others the fact that Desert and he were no longer pals.
好几次他都冲动地想找他说个清楚，但都克制住了。 Often the impetus to go and have it out with him surged up and was beaten back.
可能确实没有什么他不知道的事情，也可能是有事情——并且威尔弗里德还是会说没有。 Either there was nothing beyond what he already knew, or there was something—and Wilfrid would say there wasn’t.
迈克尔无可奈何，一个男人是不会把自己的女人拱手相让的！ Michael accepted that without cavil; one did not give a woman away!
但他想从一起打过仗的战友那里打听实情。 But he wanted to hear no lies from a War comrade.
弗勒和他之间没有发生过口角，他觉得吵架并不会加深对事情的了解，反而使原本脆弱的关系变得更糟。 Between Fleur and himself no word had passed; for words, he felt, would add no knowledge, merely imperil a hold weak enough already.
圣诞节是在蒙特家祖传的庄园里度过的，人们在那里进行丛林打猎。 Christmas at the ancestral manor of the Monts had been passed in covert-shooting.
第二天最后一次驱车外出打猎时，弗勒来了，站在他身旁，手里牵着小叮铃。 Fleur had come and stood with him at the last drive on the second day, holding Ting-a-ling on a lead.
这只中国犬特别兴奋，每次有鸟被打落时，它总是一跃而起，丝毫不受枪声的干扰。 The Chinese dog had been extraordinarily excited, climbing the air every time a bird fell, and quite unaffected by the noise of guns.
迈克尔一边等待着他的猎物——他的技术不怎样——一边看着她那露在灰色皮毛领子外的充满渴望的脸颊。她的身子朝后倾，使劲拉着小叮铃。 Michael, waiting to miss his birds—he was a poor shot—had watched her eager face emerging from grey fur, her form braced back against Ting-a-ling.
打猎对她来说可是件新鲜事，而每当有新鲜刺激的事情时，她总是处在最佳的精神状态。 Shooting was new to her; and under the stimulus of novelty she was always at her best.
当他没打中时，就连她的“哎呀，迈克尔，迈克尔！”他都愿意听。 He had loved even her “Oh, Michaels!” when he missed.
她是这次聚会的成功之处，除了晚上看见她头枕枕头香甜地睡着，白天几乎看不到她的人影。不过，至少在那里，他感觉不到潜在的痛苦。 She had been the success of the gathering, which meant seeing almost nothing of her except a sleepy head on a pillow; but, at least, down there he had not suffered from lurking uneasiness.
他在吸水画纸上给短发加了最后一笔之后，就站了起来。 Putting a last touch to the bobbed hair on the blotting paper, he got up.
那位女子说过，圣保罗大教堂。 St. Paul’s, that girl had said.
他可以散步到那里，去看看比克特。 He might stroll up and have a squint at Bicket.
他可能想起了什么。 Something might occur to him.
他系好蓝色大衣的腰带，看起来很精干。然后，他带着一丝忐忑动身了。 Tightening the belt of his blue overcoat round his waist, he sallied forth, thin and sprightly, with a little ache in his heart.
天气晴朗宜人，他朝东走去，心中竟涌起从未有过的感慨，感慨如今自己活着，活得还很好，并且拥有一份不错的工作。 Walking east, on that bright, cheerful day, nothing struck him so much as the fact that he was alive, well, and in work.
而有那么多的人已经离世、生病，或失业。 So very many were dead, ill, or out of a job.
他走进了科芬园。 He entered Covent Garden.
这是个令人惊异的地方！ Amazing place!
尽管人性有许多弱点，人们数十年以来对科芬园的喜爱却没有濒临灭绝的危险。 A human nature which, decade after decade, could put up with Covent Garden was not in danger of extinction from its many ills.
这是一个给人慰藉的地方——人们但凡在这里走上一圈，就会对世间万事看淡许多。 A comforting place—one needn’t take anything too seriously after walking through it.
广场西起出版社，东至歌剧院，南北两则是川流不息的人群。这里汇集了来自世界各地的蔬菜和水果。 On this square island were the vegetables of the earth and the fruits of the world, bounded on the west by publishing, on the cast by opera, on the north and south by rivers of mankind.
迈克尔行走在卸货的大车、乱丢的纸屑和麦秆中，走在和周围景致不相协调的人群中间，边走边嗅闻着。 Among discharging carts and litter of paper, straw and men out of drawing, Michael walked and sniffed.
科芬园有股特殊的泥土气味，但又不是泥土腐烂的气味！ Smell of its own, Covent Garden, earthy and just not rotten!
即使是在大战中，他也从未见过如此凌乱不堪的地方。 He had never seen—even in the War—any place that so utterly lacked form.
非凡的英国人！ Extraordinarily English!
似乎没人关心这片土壤——赶车的、不务正业的、打包工，还有在遮蔽的货摊里的小贩们——他们也跟阳光、风、水、大地，或者空气——跟这里的一切都毫不相干！ Nobody looked as if they had anything to do with the soil—drivers, hangers-on, packers, and the salesmen inside the covered markets, seemed equally devoid of acquaintanceship with sun, wind, water, earth or air—town types all!
而且——上帝！——他们的脸怪模怪样、形态各异——向前伸着的、歪向一边的、下垂的、肿胀的。 And—Golly!—how their faces jutted, sloped, sagged and swelled, in every kind of featural disharmony.
在这么多不正常的模样中，哪一类才算是典型的英国脸呢？ What was the English type amongst all this infinite variety of disproportion?
一个也没有！ There just wasn’t one!
他来到水果摊前，一堆堆色彩鲜艳、表面光亮的水果静静地摆在那里——来自阳光充足地方的进口货——堆成了同样大小、同样颜色的圆圈。 He came on the fruits, glowing piles, still and bright—foreigners from the land of the sun—globes all the same size and colour.
这些水果令迈克尔垂涎三尺。 They made Michael’s mouth water.
“那才是真正产自阳光充足地方的水果。”他心想。 ‘Something in the sun,’ he thought; ‘there really is.’
看看意大利、阿拉伯、澳大利亚——澳大利亚人来自英格兰，看看现在他们的模样！ Look at Italy, at the Arabs, at Australia—the Australians came from England, and see the type now!
不过——伦敦佬脾气好！ Nevertheless—a Cockney for good temper!
一个人的体型和外貌越匀称正常，这个人越自私！ The more regular a person’s form and features, the more selfish they were!
与土豆相比，那些葡萄柚就自负得多！ Those grape-fruit looked horribly self-satisfied, compared with the potatoes!
他走出广场，脑子里还在想着英国人。 He emerged still thinking about the English.
对！ Well!
现在的英国人是世界上最平庸、最畸形的民族了，可是还有哪个民族能跟他们较量脾气和“厚颜无耻”呢？ They were now one of the plainest and most distorted races of the world; and yet was there any race to compare with them for good temper and for ‘guts’?
但是对于他们而言，在那烟雾弥漫和多变的气候环境中，恰恰需要这种性格——适应环境，现代英国性格的一个典型例子！ And they needed those in their smoky towns, and their climate—remarkable instance of adaptation to environment, the modern English character!
“我可以在任何一个地方认出英国人，”他心想，“但是，从外表体征上来讲，现在可没有一个通用类型了！” ‘I could pick out an Englishman anywhere,’ he thought, ‘and yet, physically, there’s no general type now!’
令人震惊的民族！ Astounding people!
整体看是那么丑陋，却能培养出绝世美人，还有一群与众不同的佳人——就像小巧玲珑的比克特夫人那样；即使大多数人缺乏想象力，但是还是有着数不胜数的诗人才子！ So ugly in the mass, yet growing such flowers of beauty, and such strange sprigs—like that little Mrs. Bicket; so unimaginative in bulk, yet with such a blooming lot of poets!
顺便提一下，威尔弗里德把自己下一卷诗作拿给其他出版社时，不知老丹比会有何感想？换言之，他——这位威尔弗里德的特殊朋友——该如何向老丹比开口？ How would old Danby like it, by the way, when Wilfrid took his next volume to some other firm; or rather what should he—Wilfrid’s particular friend!—say to old Danby?
啊哈！ Aha!
他知道他应该这么说： He knew what he should say:
“对了，先生，您应该宽恕那个偷了《铜币》的年轻人。 “Yes, sir, but you should have let that poor blighter off who snooped the ‘Copper Coins.’
德赛特可一直记着您拒绝了他。” Desert hasn’t forgotten your refusal.”
这是对老丹比和他那永远认为自己正确的想法的有力回击！ One for old Danby and his eternal inthe-rightness!
《铜币》销路很好。 ‘Copper Coin’ had done uncommonly well.
接下来的书可能销路会更好。 Its successor would probably do uncommonly better.
这本书就印证了他——迈克尔——一直说的话：“雏鸟时期”已经过去。 The book was a proof of what he—Michael—was always saying: The ‘cockyolly-bird period’ was passing.
人们重新寻找生活的真谛。 People wanted life again.
西布莉、沃尔特·内津、琳达——只会自视清高却言之无物的人们——已经是气息奄奄了。 Sibley, Walter Nazing, Linda—all those who had nothing to say except that they were superior to such as had—were already measured for their coffins.
这并不意味着他们躺在棺材里的时候会明白这一切，这根本是不可能的！ Not that they would know when they were in them; not blooming likely!
他们会继续得意忘形，看不起那些人！ They would continue to wave their noses and look down them!
“我十分厌恶他们，”迈克尔心想， ‘I’M fed-up with them,’ thought Michael.
“要是弗勒能明白看不起别人是自卑的表现，那该多好！” ‘If only Fleur would see that looking down your nose is a sure sign of inferiority!’
于是，他突然想到，可能她已经明白了。 And, suddenly, it came to him that she probably did.
在弗勒曾经密切交往的一群人中，威尔弗里德只是其中的一个。其他的人与她交往一则是因为——嗯，因为她是弗勒，还有就是弗勒身边总是汇集着时髦的事情。 Wilfrid was the only one of the whole lot she had ever been thick with; the others were there because—well, because she was Fleur, and had the latest things about her.
不久之后，当他们不再时髦时，弗勒自然而然就会抛弃他们。 When, very soon, they were no longer the latest things, she would drop them.
但是她绝不会抛弃威尔弗里德的。 But Wilfrid she would not drop.
不，他肯定弗勒绝没有抛弃而且也绝不会放弃威尔弗里德的。 No, he felt sure that she had not dropped, and would not drop Wilfrid.
他抬头看看。 He looked up.
来到了拉德盖特山街！ Ludgate Hill!
“在圣保罗大教堂附近——卖气球？” “Near St. Paul’s—sells balloons?”
在那里——果然是他——那个可怜的家伙！ And there—sure enough—the poor beggar was!
比克特为了到别处去喝一杯可可，正在把气球里的空气放掉。 Bicket was deflating with a view to going off his stand for a cup of cocoa.
迈克尔想到他要装作偶然遇见，就故意站了一会儿，准备装出诧异的口气。 Remembering that he had come on him by accident, Michael stood for a moment preparing the tones of surprise.
令人遗憾的是，这个可怜的家伙不可能把自己吹到一个五颜六色的气球里，使他从圣保罗大教堂的上空一直飞到彼得那里去。 Pity the poor chap couldn’t blow himself into one of those coloured shapes and float over St. Paul’s to Peter.
他看上去的确像一只可怜虫，使劲地把气球里的空气挤出去。 Mournful little cuss he looked, squeezing out the air!
回忆强烈地涌上他的心头。 Memory tapped sharply on his mind.
气球——在广场上——11月1号——令人愉快的夜晚！ Balloon—in the square—November the first—joyful night!
特别的！ Special!
弗勒！ Fleur!
也许它们带来了好运。 Perhaps they brought luck.
他走过去，用吃惊的语气说：“比克特，是你吗？ He moved and said in an astounded voice: “YOU, Bicket?
你现在做这个生意吗？” Is this your stunt now?”
比克特瞪着那双大眼睛，将目光从一个价值六便士的深褐色气球转移到他身上。 The large eyes of Bicket regarded him over a puce-coloured sixpennyworth.
“蒙特先生！ “Mr. Mont!
我经常想着再能遇见您，先生。” Often thought I’d like to see you again, sir.”
“我也是啊，比克特。 “Same here, Bicket.
你现在没什么生意的话，咱俩一起吃午饭吧。” If you’re not doing anything, come and have some lunch.”
比克特弄瘪了那个气球，随手关上了托盘的盖子，说道：“您说的是真的吗，先生？” Bicket completed the globe’s collapse, and, closing his tray-lid, said: “Reelly, sir?”
“当然啦！ “Rather!
我正想去一家海鲜餐馆。” I was just going into a fish place.”
比克特拿下托盘。 Bicket detached his tray.
“我把这个放在路口清洁工那儿。” “I’ll leave this with the crossing-sweeper.”
他交给清洁工后，就跟在迈克尔身后的一侧走着。 He did so, and followed at Michael’s side.
“比克特，这生意赚钱吗？” “Any money in it, Bicket?”
“勉强维持，先生。” “Bare livin’, sir.”
“这环境怎么样？ “How about this place?
我们吃点儿生蚝吧。” We’ll have oysters.”
比克特用苍白的舌头舔了一下嘴角的唾沫。 A little saliva at the corner of Bicket’s mouth was removed by a pale tongue.
迈克尔坐在了一张铺着白色油布和放着调味瓶架的小桌旁。 At a small table decorated with white oilcloth and a cruet stand, Michael sat down.
“两打生蚝，全套的佐料；另外再来两条新鲜的鳎目鱼，和一瓶夏布利酒。 “Two dozen oysters, and all that; then two good soles, and a bottle of Chablis.
麻烦快一些。” Hurry up, please.”
当系着白围裙的服务员拿着菜单去准备的时候，比克特迟钝地说了句： When the white-aproned fellow had gone about it, Bicket said simply:
“我的上帝啊！” “My Gawd!”
“是啊，比克特，这是个可笑的世界。” “Yes, it’s a funny world, Bicket.”
“是啊，是这样。 “It is, and that’s a fact.
这顿午饭要花费您一镑钱吧。 This lunch’ll cost you a pound, I shouldn’t wonder.
假如我一周挣25先令，那肯定要全花上了。” If I take twenty-five bob a week, it’s all I do.”
“比克特，你说到了痛处。 “You touch it there, Bicket.
我每天都在泯灭自己的良心。” I eat my conscience every day.”
比克特摇摇头。 Bicket shook his head.
“不是的，先生，如果您有钱，那就花吧。 “No, sir, if you’ve got money, spend it.
要是我有钱我也会花的。 I would.
及时行乐吧——能行乐的人不多啊。” Be ‘appy if you can—there yn’t too many that are.”
那个系白围裙的服务员端上来生蚝，请他们享用。 The white-aproned fellow began blessing them with oysters.
他把那些新剖开的端上来，一次三只。 He brought them fresh-opened, three at a time.
迈克尔把鳃去掉，而比克特则狼吞虎咽地吞了下去。 Michael bearded them; Bicket swallowed them whole.
过了一会儿，看着桌上12只空壳，他说： Presently above twelve empty shells, he said:
“先生，这是社会主义者的错误。 “That’s where the Socialists myke their mistyke, sir.
除去看到别人花钱之外，没有什么可以激励我继续活下去。 Nothing keeps me going but the sight of other people spendin’ money.
只要是有点儿运气，我们大家都能获得这种生活。 It’s what we might all come to with a bit of luck.
把世界的生活水平降低到一天一镑钱的水平——他们说，也许还不到一镑钱呢！ Reduce the world to a level of a pound a dy—and it won’t even run to that, they sy!
这还不够好，先生。 It’s not good enough, sir.
我宁愿现在少拿点儿，将来多得点儿。 I’d rather ‘ave less with the ‘ope of more.
没有冒险刺激，生活就平淡无趣了。 Take awy the gamble, and life’s a frost.
祈求好运！” Here’s luck!”
“比克特，你这一席话就像是在劝我当一个资本家。” “Almost thou persuadest me to be a capitalist, Bicket.”
在浅绿色的夏布利酒杯后面，那张有着一双大眼睛的瘦削的脸上泛起了一片红晕。 A glow had come up in the thin and large-eyed face behind the greenish Chablis glass.
“先生，我从内心希望我妻子能在这里。 “I wish to Gawd I had my wife here, sir.
我跟您说过我妻子和她得肺炎的事情。 I told you about her and the pneumonia.
她现在康复了，只是很瘦弱。 She’s all right agyne now, only thin.
她是我亲手描绘出来的理想。 She’s the prize I drew.
我不希望拥有一个不能描绘理想的世界。 I don’t want a world where you can’t draw prizes.
假如当初一切全凭良心和依照个人成就办事的话，我现在肯定不会娶到我的妻子。 If it were all bloomin’ conscientious an’ accordin’ to merit, I’d never have got her.
您明白吗？” See?”
“我也一样啊。”迈克尔心想，又在心里勾勒着那张脸。 ‘Me, too,’ thought Michael, mentally drawing that face again.
“我们每个人都有梦想，我的愿望是得到那只蓝蝴蝶——去澳大利亚中部。 “We’ve all got our dreams; mine’s blue butterflies—Central Austrylia.
社会主义者是不会帮助我去那里的。 The Socialists won’t ‘elp me to get there.
他们设想的天堂从未超出欧洲。” Their ideas of ‘eaven don’t run beyond Europe.”
“谁知道呢！”迈克尔说， “Cripes!” said Michael.
“要融化的黄油吗，比克特？” “Melted butter, Bicket?”
“谢谢您，先生。” “Thank you, sir.”
一阵沉默，两人只是默默地吃着鳎目鱼。 Silence was not broken for some time, but the soles were.
“比克特，你是怎么想起做气球生意的？” “What made you think of balloons, Bicket?”
“你不必做广告，他们自己就给你做广告了。” “You don’t ‘ave to advertise, they do it for you.”
“你看了许多我们做的广告，嗯？” “Saw too much of advertising with us, eh?”
“嗯，先生，我确实经常欣赏书的封面。 “Well, sir, I did use to read the wrappers.
我想说——著作的数量真让人震惊。” Astonished me, I will sy—the number of gryte books.”
迈克尔用手快速捋了捋头发。 Michael ran his hands through his hair.
“书的封面！ “Wrappers!
总是用一个胡子刮得干净的年轻男士吻年轻女子当封面。 The same young woman being kissed by the same young man with the same clean-cut jaw.
比克特，可是又有什么办法呢？ But what can you do, Bicket?
他们一定就要这个。今天早晨我还想破除惯例——我想看看结果如何。” They WILL HAVE IT. I tried to make a break only this morning—I shall see what comes of it.
“我真心希望你别这样做！”他心想，“要是弗勒上了小说封面，效果如何呢！” “‘And I hope YOU won’t!’ he thought: ‘Fancy coming on Fleur outside a novel!’
“就在我离开之前，我的确看出了倾向，”比克特说，“悬崖或者峭壁与两个坐在沙滩上或者草地上的漂亮姑娘画在一起，看起来似乎不知道该如何相处。” “I did notice a tendency just before I left,” said Bicket, “to ‘ave cliffs or landskips and two sort of dolls sittin’ on the sand or in the grass lookin’ as if they didn’t know what to do with each other.”
“是啊，”迈克尔低声说，“我们这样试过了。 “Yes,” murmured Michael, “we tried that.
本来以为那样做会避免落入俗套。 It was supposed not to be vulgar.
但人们很快就厌烦了。 But we soon exhausted the public’s capacity.
现在你要点儿什么呢——奶酪？” What’ll you have now—cheese?”
“谢谢您，先生，我饱了，但是我也不会说不要的。” “Thank you, sir; I’ve had too much already, but I won’t say ‘No.’”
“来两块斯蒂尔顿奶酪。”迈克尔说。 “Two Stiltons,” said Michael.
“先生，德赛特先生好吗？” “How’s Mr. Desert, sir?”
迈克尔脸红了。 Michael reddened.
“哦！ “Oh!
他很好。” He’s all right.”
比克特脸也红了。 Bicket had reddened also.
“我希望——希望您能告诉他，我拿他的书纯粹是一件——一件意外。 “I wish—I wish you’d let him know that it was quite a—an accident my pitchin’ on his book.
对于这件事我一直感到愧疚。” I’ve always regretted it.”
“我想，通常这是偶然发生的，”迈克尔缓慢地说，“当我们拿别人东西时。 “It’s usually an accident, I think,” said Michael slowly, “when we snoop other people’s goods.
我们从来都没想过要这么做。” We never WANT to.”
比克特抬起了头。 Bicket looked up.
“不是的，先生，我不同意。 “No, sir, I don’t agree.
有半数的人是偷窃成性——只是，我自己绝不是那种人。” ‘Alf mankind’s predytory—only, I’m not that sort, meself.”
迈克尔忠厚老实，他也尝试结结巴巴地说：“他也不是那种人。” In Michael loyalty tried to stammer “Nor is he.”
他把烟盒递给比克特。 He handed his cigarette case to Bicket.
“对此我确信无疑，谢谢您，先生。” “Thank you, sir, I’m sure.”
他的眼里噙着泪水，迈克尔心里想：“该死的！ His eyes were swimming, and Michael thought: ‘Dash it!
这真是多愁善感。 This is sentimental.
吻别之后就分手再见吧！” Kiss me good-bye and go!’
他示意那系着白围裙的服务员过来。 He beckoned up the white-aproned fellow.
“给我留个地址，比克特。 “Give us your address, Bicket.
如果你需要衣服的话，我那里富余几件，可以送给你。” If integuments are any good to you, I might have some spare slops.”
比克特在账单背面写下地址，然后吞吞吐吐地说：“我想蒙特太太不会有什么富余的衣服吧。 Bicket backed the bill with his address and said, hesitating: “I suppose, sir, Mrs. Mont wouldn’t ‘ave anything to spare.
我妻子的身高跟我相仿。” My wife’s about my height.”
“我想她会有的。 “I expect she would.
我们会把衣服送来的。” We’ll send them along.”
他看着这个“小人物”嘴唇颤抖，然后就去拿他的大衣了。 He saw the ‘little snipe’s’ lips quivering, and reached for his overcoat.
“如果碰巧有工作机会的话，我会记着你的。 “If anything blows in, I’ll remember you.
再见了，比克特，祝你好远。” Goodbye, Bicket, and good luck.”
因为比克特朝西走，所以迈克尔往东走去，心里反复想着那句名言：“怜悯是扯淡——怜悯是扯淡！” Going east, because Bicket was going west, he repeated to himself the maxim: “Pity is tripe—pity is tripe!”
接着他坐上了公共汽车，车往回开，路过了圣保罗大教堂。 Then getting on a ‘bus, he was borne back past St. Paul’s.
他仔细“观察一番”——就像老福赛特说过的那样——发现比克特正在吹气球，他的脸和身体几乎被那只玫瑰色气球遮住了。 Cautiously ‘taking a lunar’—as old Forsyte put it—he SAW Bicket inflating a balloon; little was visible of his face or figure behind that rosy circumference.
车快到布莱克大街时，他对工作突然产生了一种不可阻挡的反感情绪，索性就一直坐到了特拉瓦尔加广场。 Nearing Blake Street, he developed an invincible repugnance to work, and was carried on to Trafalgar Square.
比克特让他思绪起伏。 Bicket had stirred him up.
这个世界有时简直是太有趣了。 The world was sometimes almost unbearably jolly.
比克特、威尔弗里德，还有鲁尔区！ Bicket, Wilfrid, and the Ruhr!”
感情是胡言乱语！ Feeling is tosh!
怜悯是扯淡！ Pity is tripe!”
他下了公共汽车，经过蓓尔美尔街的两座狮子。 He descended from his ‘bus, and passed the lions towards Pall Mall.
他有必要去“轻蔑”俱乐部找准爵爷吗？ Should he go into ‘Snooks’ and ask for Bart?
没用——他不会在那里找到弗勒的。 No use—he would not find Fleur there.
那其实才是他真正的目的——在白天看见弗勒。 That was what he really wanted—to see Fleur in the daytime.
但是——弗勒在哪儿呢？ But—where?
她有可能在任何地方，也就是说，有可能哪里都找不到她。 She was everywhere to be found, and that was nowhere.
她闲不住。 She was restless.
那是他的过错吗？ Was that his fault?
如果他是威尔弗里德——那她会闲不住吗？ If he had been Wilfrid—would she be restless?
“是的，”他肯定地想着，“威尔弗里德也闲不住。” ‘Yes,’ he thought stoutly, ‘Wilfrid’s restless, too.’
他们都闲不住——所有他熟识的那些人都如此。 They were all restless—all the people he knew.
至少是那些年轻作家们——无论是在生活中还是在文学作品中。 At least all the young ones—in life and in letters.
看看他们写的小说！ Look at their novels!
20部作品里，几乎没有一本能带给人安静之感，缺少让人视书为避风港湾的品质。 Hardly one in twenty had any repose, any of that quality which made one turn back to a book as a corner of refuge.
他们犹如摩托车般冲撞，发出巨响、打滑和飞奔——啊！极为猛烈和娴熟。 They dashed and sputtered and skidded and rushed by like motor cycles—violent, oh! and clever.
他是多么厌恶这种娴熟！ How tired he was of cleverness!
有时他会给弗勒带一份原稿，征求一下她的意见。 Sometimes he would take a manuscript home to Fleur for her opinion.
他记得有一次她曾说过：“迈克尔，这跟生活一模一样，急速行进——不会为了表明什么而在任何地方、在任何事情上喋喋不休地做过久的停留。 He remembered her saying once: “This is exactly like life, Michael, it just rushes—it doesn’t dwell on anything long enough to mean anything anywhere.
当然，作者并不打算把它写成讽刺作品，但是如果你要出版，我建议你在封面上写下一句话：‘此书是对现代生活的强烈讽刺。’” Of course the author didn’t mean it for satire, but if you publish it, I advise you to put: ‘This awful satire on modern life’ outside the cover.”
他们这样做了。 And they had.
至少他们写了一句话：“此书是对现代生活的绝妙讽刺。” At least, they had put: “This wonderful satire on modern life.”
弗勒就像这样！ Fleur WAS like that!
她知道自己闲不住，但就像那部绝妙讽刺作品的作者一样，她丝毫不知道自己正在追逐着、忙碌着，又或者——她已经知道了？ She could see the hurry, but, like the author of the wonderful satire, she didn’t know that she herself veered and hurried, or—did she know?
她是否意识到自己正在生活中冲撞，就像空气中的火焰一样？ Was she conscious of kicking at life, like a flame at air?
他已经到了皮卡迪利大街。突然间，他想起自己已经很久没有去看望她的姑姑了。 He had reached Piccadilly, and suddenly he remembered that he had not called on her aunt for ages.
那倒是可行的。 That was a possible draw.
于是他向格林街走去。 He bent his steps towards Green Street.
“达尔蒂夫人在家吗？” “Mrs. Dartie at home?”
“在家，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
迈克尔吸了一下鼻子。 Michael moved his nostrils.
是弗勒用过的味道，但是他闻不到香水味，只是闻到了燃香的味道。 Fleur used—but he could catch no scent, except incense.
威妮弗雷德燃起线香，通常是因为她想起线香会制造出一种高雅气氛。 Winifred burnt joss-sticks when she remembered what a distinguished atmosphere they produced.
“您贵姓啊？” “What name?”
“蒙特先生。 “Mr. Mont.
我猜我的妻子不在这里吧？” My wife’s not here, I suppose?”
“不在，先生。 “No, sir.
屋里只有瓦尔·达尔蒂夫人。” Only Mrs. Val Dartie.”
瓦尔·达尔蒂夫人！ Mrs. Val Dartie!
嗯，他记起来了，是个长相标致的女人——但是无法取代弗勒！ Yes, he remembered, nice woman—but not a substitute for Fleur!
既然已经通报了，不管怎样，他都得跟着女仆进去了。 Committed, however, he followed the maid.
迈克尔在客厅见到了三个人，其中一位是他的岳父。他一副忧郁沉思的模样，坐在一张帝国时期的椅子上，凝视着压在绯红色圆桌玻璃下的澳大利亚的蓝蝴蝶翅膀。 In the drawing-room Michael found three people, one of them his father-in-law, who had a grey and brooding aspect, and, from an Empire chair, was staring at blue Australian butterflies’ wings under glass on a round scarlet table.
威妮弗雷德已经在房间原有的帝国时期风格的基础上，增添了一些更适合当今时代特征的装饰，使房间看起来更加活泼动感一些。 Winifred had jazzed the Empire foundations of her room with a superstructure more suitable to the age.
她用上流社会习惯的热情方式欢迎迈克尔。 She greeted Michael with fashionable warmth.
他每天忙于和青年诗人打交道，能抽空来作客，真是好极了。 It was good of him to come when he was so busy with all these young poets.
“我想到《铜币》，”她说，“多好的书名啊！——让人着迷的小册子。 “I thought ‘Copper Coin,’” she said—“what a NICE title!—such an intriguing little book.
我从内心认为德赛特先生智慧非凡！ I do think Mr. Desert is clever!
他现在忙什么呢？” What is he doing now?”
迈克尔说：“我不太清楚。”说完便坐在瓦尔夫人旁边的长靠椅上。 Michael said: “I don’t know,” and dropped on to a settee beside Mrs. Val.
由于他之前丝毫不知道福赛特家族长期的矛盾，所以也根本不清楚因为自己的到来而使得气氛有所缓和。 Ignorant of the Forsyte family feud, he was unable to appreciate the relief he had brought in with him.
索姆斯说了一些关于法国人的事，就起身朝窗边走去；威妮弗雷德也跟着过去——他们说话声音很小，似乎很神秘。 Soames said something about the French, got up, and went to the window; Winifred joined him—their voices sounded confidential.
“弗勒好吗？”迈克尔的邻座问道。 “How is Fleur?” said Michael’s neighbour.
“谢谢您，她很好。” “Thanks, awfully well.”
“您喜欢您的房子吗？” “Do you like your house?”
“哦，很喜欢。 “Oh, fearfully.
您不来看看吗？” Won’t you come and see it?”
“我不知道弗勒会不会——” “I don’t know whether Fleur would—?”
“怎么会不呢？” “Why not?”
“哦！ “Oh!
好吧！” Well!”
“她是很容易亲近的。” “She’s frightfully accessible.”
她似乎异常兴致勃勃地看着他，试图想从他的脸上看出什么。他接着说： She seemed to be looking at him with more interest than he deserved, to be trying to make something out from his face, and he added:
“无论是从血缘还是从婚姻角度来说，您都是我们的亲戚，是不是？” “You’re a relation—by blood as well as marriage, aren’t you?”
“是的。” “Yes.”
“那么有什么不可以来的呢？” “Then what’s the skeleton?”
“哦！没有啊。 “Oh! nothing.
我当然要来了。 I’ll certainly come.
只不过——她的朋友太多了。” Only—she has so many friends.”
迈克尔心想：“我喜欢这个女人！” Michael thought: ‘I like this woman!’
“事实上，”他说，“我今天下午来这儿，原以为弗勒在这儿呢。 “As a matter of fact,” he said, “I came here this afternoon thinking I might find Fleur.
我希望她能和您多聊聊天。 I should like her to know you.
现在处处都是爵士音乐，她一定会喜欢文静的人。” With all the jazz there is about, she’d appreciate somebody restful.”
“谢谢您。” “Thank you.”
“您从来没在伦敦居住过吗？” “You’ve never lived in London?”
“我六岁之前在这里住过。” “Not since I was six.”
“我希望她能休息一下——可惜这附近没有沙——沙漠。” “I wish she could get a rest—pity there isn’t a d-desert handy.”
他结巴起来，这个词的发音虽然有所不同——但仍然刺痛了他的心！ He had stuttered; the word was not pronounced the same—still!
他有些窘迫，看着那些蝴蝶。 He glanced, disconcerted, at the butterflies.
“我刚才正好跟一个小伦敦佬说话，他的救赎地就是澳大利亚中部。 “I’ve just been talking to a little Cockney whose S. O. S. is ‘Central Austrylia.’
但您说——咱们有需要拯救的灵魂吗？” But what do you say—Have we got souls to save?”
“我以前一直这样认为，但现在我不敢肯定了——最近有些事触动了我。” “I used to think so, but now I’m not so sure—something’s struck me lately.”
“是什么事呢？” “What was that?”
“嗯，我注意到，任何一个五官不端正的人，要么鼻子歪的，要么眼睛突出的，要么样子与众不同的人，他们总是相信灵魂；而那些五官端正、外貌没有明显缺陷的人，似乎就不关心他们的灵魂。” “Well, I notice that any one at all out of proportion, or whose nose is on one side, or whose eyes jut out, or even have a special shining look, always believes in the soul; people who are in proportion, and have no prominent physical features, don’t seem to be really interested.”
迈克尔的耳朵动了动。 Michael’s ears moved.
“上帝啊！”他说，“有道理！ “By Jove!” he said; “some thought!
弗勒长得漂亮——所以她无忧无虑。 Fleur’s beautifully proportioned—SHE doesn’t seem to worry.
而我长得不好看——所以我忧心忡忡。 I’m not—and I certainly do.
那些在科芬园的人一定有很多灵魂。 The people in Covent Garden must have lots of soul.
您想‘灵魂’是生物体连接松散的结果——一种因为不能进行整体活动而产生的特殊感觉。” You think ‘the soul’s’ the result of loose-gearing in the organism—sort of special consciousness from not working in one piece.”
“是啊，的确如此——我几乎可以断言，就是所谓的通灵能力。” “Yes, rather like that—what’s called psychic power is, I’m almost sure.”
“问一下，您的生活安全吗？ “I say, is your life safe?
按照您的理论，我们正处于一个灵魂极其兴盛的时代。 According to your theory, though, we’re in a mighty soulful era.
我必须仔细考虑一下我的家庭。 I must think over my family.
您的家庭怎么样？” How about yours?”
“福赛特家族！ “The Forsytes!
哦，他们五官再端正不过了。” Oh, they’re quite too well-proportioned.”
“我同意，在我看来，他们没有什么长相特殊的地方。 “I agree, they haven’t any special juts so far as I’ve seen.
法国人的长相也是很紧凑的。 The French, too, are awfully close-knit.
这的确是一种说法，只不过，当然了，大多数人不这样认为。 It really is an idea, only, of course, most people see it the other way.
他们可能会说，灵魂导致了五官不端正——眼睛发亮、鼻子弯曲以及等等一系列说法。如果一个人的灵魂渺小，它是不会妄图摆脱肉体的，那些理发师的头型由此而来。 They’d say the soul produces the disproportion, makes the eyes shine, bends the nose, and all that; where the soul is small, it’s not trying to get out of the body, whence the barber’s block.
我要思考一下这个问题。 I’ll think about it.
感谢您的提示。 Thanks for the tip.
嗯，一定要到我家来。 Well, do come and see us.
再见！ Good-bye!
我想我就不去打扰窗边的两位了。 I don’t think I’ll disturb them in the window.
劳烦您替我跟他们说一声，我得赶紧走了。” Would you mind saying I had to scoot?”
他紧握着那只纤细的戴手套的手，她微笑着答应了。他悄悄溜了出去，心想：“该死的灵魂，她的肉体在哪儿啊？” Squeezing a slim, gloved hand, receiving and returning a smiling look, he slid out, thinking: ‘Dash the soul, where’s her body?’
第四章 Chapter IV
弗勒的肉体 Fleur’s Body
的确，此刻弗勒的肉体处境很困难，这困难的处境正在不断地威胁着她妥协的内心。 Fleur’s body, indeed, was at the moment in one of those difficult positions which continually threaten the spirit of compromise.
此时，她正在威尔弗里德的怀抱中。至少，这一举动足以让她说： It was in fact in Wilfrid’s arms; sufficiently, at least, to make her say:
“别这样，威尔弗里德——你答应过我会守规矩的。” “No, Wilfrid—you promised to be good.”
“守规矩”一词现在竟然还有意义，她如履薄冰的本事确实令人佩服。 It was a really remarkable tribute to her powers of skating on thin ice that the word ‘good’ should still have significance.
整整11周了，这个年轻人一直在欲望的边缘垂死挣扎。即使是现在，弗勒仍然握紧双手挡在他的胸前，还让他“守规矩”，可是他已经两周没见到她了。 For eleven weeks exactly this young man had danced on the edge of fulfilment, and was even now divided from her by two clenched hands pressed firmly against his chest, and the word ‘good’; and this after not having seen her for a fortnight.
她说完这句话后，他就放开了她，一副凶神恶煞的样子，坐在一堆废旧杂物上。 When she said it, he let her go, with a sort of violence, and sat down on a piece of junk.
只是因为他不想再重复了，才忍住没说：“不能这样下去了，弗勒。” Only the sense of damnable iteration prevented him from saying: “It can’t go on, Fleur.”
她何尝不知道呢！ She knew that!
可是情况就是这样！ And yet it did!
这一点始终让他感到诧异。 This was what perpetually amazed him.
一个可怜虫怎么能每周都对她、对自己说：“现在不做就断绝关系！”而其实这两点他都办不到。 How a poor brute could hang on week after week saying to her and to himself: “Now or never!” when it wasn’t either.
他下意识地感觉到在所谓的“现在”实现之前，弗勒自己都不清楚她自己的心思，只有先晾着他了。 Subconsciousness, that, until the word ‘now’ had been reached, Fleur would not know her own mind, alone had kept him dancing.
他对她的感情如此强烈，以至于他快受不了她的犹豫不决了。 His own feelings were so intense that he almost hated her for indecision.
但他错了。 And he was unjust.
并不完全是犹豫不决。 It was not exactly indecision.
弗勒需要威尔弗里德的爱情给她的生活带来额外的丰富和刺激，而不会带来风险和损失。 Fleur wanted the added richness and excitement which Wilfrid’s affection gave to life, but without danger and without loss.
多自然的事啊！ How natural!
而他可怕的热情正是所有麻烦的根源。 His frightful passionateness was making all the trouble.
他那热情既不是出于她的愿望，也不是由于她的过错！ Neither by her wish, nor through her fault, was he passionate!
不过——热情总能给人愉快和美好的感觉。当然，她还隐隐觉得，对情人过于挑剔有悖“时尚”，更何况她的生活缺少一个情人呢。 And yet—it was both nice and proper to inspire passion; and, of course, she had the lurking sense that she was not ‘in the mode’ to cavil at a lover, especially since life owed her one.
威尔弗里德放开手后，她整理了一下自己，说道：“谈点儿有意思的事吧，你最近在写些什么？” Released, she smoothed herself and said: “Talk of something sensible; what have you been writing?”
“这个。” “This.”
弗勒翻了几页。 Fleur read.
她涨红了脸，咬着嘴唇，然后说道： Flushing and biting her lips, she said:
“这个读起来让人很痛苦。” “It’s frightfully bitter.”
“却非常真实。 “It’s frightfully true.
他现在还问你，你是否和我见面吗？” Does HE ever ask you now whether you see me?”
“从来不问。” “Never.”
“为什么？” “Why?”
“我也不知道。” “I don’t know.”
“如果他问起，你怎么作答？” “What would you answer if he did?”
弗勒耸了耸肩。 Fleur shrugged her shoulders.
德赛特平静地说：“不错，这就是你的态度。 Desert said quietly: “Yes, that’s your attitude.
不能这样下去了，弗勒。” It can’t last, Fleur.”
此时，他正站在窗边。 He was standing by the window.
她把稿子放到书桌上，然后朝他走去。 She put the sheets down on his desk and moved towards him.
可怜的威尔弗里德！ Poor Wilfrid!
现在他平静了，她反倒难过起来。 Now that he was quiet she was sorry.
他突然说：“站住! He said suddenly: “Stop!
别动！ Don’t move!
他就在对面街上。” HE’S down there in the street.”
她一边后退，一边喘着气说：“迈克尔! Recoiling, she gasped: “Michael!
哦！ Oh!
