但是怎么——他怎么知道的呢？” But how—how could he have known?”
德赛特冷冷地说：“你对他的了解就这么少吗？ Desert said grimly: “Do you only know him as little as that?
你觉得如果他知道你在这里，他还会站在那儿吗？” Do you suppose he’d be there if he knew you were here?”
弗勒畏缩了一下。 Fleur winced.
“那么，他为什么出现在那儿呢？” “Why IS he there, then?”
“他可能是来找我的。 “He probably wants to see me.
他看上去还在犹豫。 He looks as if he couldn’t make up his mind.
别害怕，我不会让他进来的。” Don’t get the wind up, he won’t be let in.”
弗勒感觉双腿发软，坐了下来。 Fleur sat down; she felt weak in the legs.
那层冰似乎突然薄得可怕——水也冷得吓人。 The ice seemed suddenly of an appalling thinness—the water appallingly cold.
“他看见你了吗？”她说。 “Has he seen you?” she said.
“没有。” “No.”
他脑海里突然闪过一个念头：“如果我是个无赖，我只要向前跨一步，勾一勾手指，就能逼她就范。” The thought flashed through him: ‘If I were a blackguard, I could force her hand, by moving one step and crooking my finger.’
可惜我不是无赖——无论如何，还没坏到那个地步——不然，事情就简单多了！ Pity one wasn’t a blackguard—at all events, not to that point—things would be so much simpler!
“他现在在哪儿？”弗勒问道。 “Where is he now?” asked Fleur.
“离开了。” “Going away.”
她这下放心了，深深吸了口气，说道： In profound relief, she sighed out:
“但是很奇怪，不是吗，威尔弗里德？” “But it’s queer, isn’t it, Wilfrid?”
“你猜他的心里不好受，对吧？” “You don’t suppose he’s easy in his mind, do you?”
弗勒咬着嘴唇。 Fleur bit her lips.
他这是在挪揄她，因为她不会、也不可能爱上他们中的任何一个人。 He was jeering, because she didn’t or couldn’t really love either of them.
这不公平。 It was unjust.
她本应该可以爱的——她已经爱过了！ She COULD have loved—she HAD loved!
威尔弗里德和迈克尔——让他们见鬼去吧！ Wilfrid and Michael—they might go to the deuce!
“我真希望我从没来过这里。”她突然说道，“以后我不会再来了！” “I wish I had never come here,” she said suddenly: “and I’ll never come again!”
他走到门口，打开房门。 He went to the door, and held it open.
“你说的对。” “You are right.”
弗勒一动不动地站在那里，下巴露在皮毛领子外面，一双清澈的双眸紧紧盯着他的脸，双唇紧闭，样子十分反叛。 Fleur stood quite still, her chin on the collar of her fur, her clear-glancing eyes fixed on his face, her lips set and mutinous.
“你认为我是个无情无义的人。”她缓缓地说， “You think I’m a heartless beast,” she said slowly.
“那我就是吧——从现在开始。 “So I am—now.
再见了！” Good-bye!”
他既没和她握手，也没说话，只是鞠了一躬。 He neither took her hand nor spoke, he only bowed.
他的目光非常悲惨。 His eyes were very tragic.
弗勒被羞辱得浑身发抖，走了出去。 Trembling with mortification, Fleur went out.
当她下楼时，她听到了关门声。 She heard the door closed, while she was going down the stairs.
到楼下时，她犹豫地站住了。 At the bottom she stood uncertain.
万一迈克尔又回来了呢！ Suppose Michael had come back!
好像就在对面的美术馆，她第一次遇见他和——乔恩。 Almost opposite was that gallery where she had first met him and—Jon.
穿过街道，溜到那里去吧！ Slip across in there!
如果他还在这条小街口逗留，她就可以心安理得地告诉他，她刚才一直在那里。 If he were still hovering round the entrance of the little street, she could tell him with a good conscience where she had been.
她打探了一下。 She peeped.
他没在！ Not in sight!
她迅速穿过马路，溜进对面的门口里。 Swiftly she slid across into the doorway opposite.
再过一分钟就关门了——正好4点钟！ They would be closing in a minute—just on four o’clock!
她付了一先令，进去了。 She put down a shilling and slipped in.
她一定得看一看——万一！ She must see—in case!
她站在那里环顾四周——是一场个人画展，作者——克劳德·布雷恩斯！ She stood revolving—one-man show, the man—Claud Brains!
她又付了一先令，买了一本目录，边读边往外走。 She put down another shilling for a catalogue, and read as she went out.
“第七号作品。 “No. 7.
担惊受怕的女人。” Woman getting the wind up.”
这本目录写得很详细，她一路轻松地浏览着，然后坐上了出租车。 It told her everything; and with a lighter heart she skimmed along, and took a taxi.
赶在迈克尔之前回家！ Get home before Michael!
她这才觉得放松了，简直太刺激了。 She felt relieved, almost exhilarated.
如履薄冰也不过如此么！ So much for skating on thin ice!
不过这可不太好。 It wasn’t good enough.
威尔弗里德必须离开。 Wilfrid must go.
可怜的威尔弗里德！ Poor Wilfrid!
可是，他不该挪揄她——他了解她吗？ Well, he shouldn’t have sneered—what did he know of her?
谁都不了解她！ Nobody knew anything of her!
她在这个世界上是孤独的。 She was alone in the world.
她把弹簧钥匙插进门厅的门上。 She slipped her latch-key into the hall door.
迈克尔还没回来。 No Michael.
她在客厅的壁炉前坐下，然后拿起一本沃尔特·内津的近作。 She sat down in the drawing-room before the fire, and took up Walter Nazing’s last.
她把一页书读了三遍。 She read a page three times.
每读一遍，对书的内容并没有更深的了解——反而更少了。他这类作家的作品必须一口气读完，然后放在一边，否则开头留给你的第一印象就会在后面的阅读中消失得无影无踪了。可是，威尔弗里德的眼神却浮现在她阅读的文字上。 It meant no more with every reading—it meant less; he was the kind of author who must be read at a gallop, and given away lest a first impression of wind in the hair be lost in a sensation of wind lower down; but Wilfrid’s eyes came between her and the words.
怜悯！ Pity!
没人怜悯她，那么，她为何要怜悯别人呢？ Nobody pitied her; why, then, should she pity them?
何况，正如阿玛贝尔所说，怜悯是“时髦的碳酸饮料”。 Besides, pity was ‘pop,’ as Amabel would say.
这种情况需要刚毅的意志。 The situation demanded cast-iron sense.
可是威尔弗里德的那双眼睛啊！ But Wilfrid’s eyes!
唉——她不会再看见那双眼睛了！ Well—she wouldn’t be seeing them again!
那双眼睛在微笑时或在——更多的时候——渴盼地望着她时，那是多美的双眸啊！此刻，这双美丽的眼睛正停留在她与这些字句之间：“他一本正经却又十分迫切地想要得到她，而她却置身于纷繁复杂、充斥着社交辞令的粉红色甲壳虫中，怡然自得——”可怜的威尔弗里德！ Beautiful eyes when they smiled or when—so much more often—they looked at her with longing, as now between her and the sentence: “Solemnly and with a delicious egoism he more than awfully desired her who snug and rosy in the pink shell of her involuted and so petulant social periphrasis—” Poor Wilfrid!
怜悯是“时髦的碳酸饮料”，可是还有自豪啊！ Pity was ‘pop,’ but there was pride!
难道她要他离开，他会认为她只是由于虚荣在“玩弄他”，就像沃尔特·内津说的美国女人那样吗？ Did she choose that he should go away thinking that she had ‘played him up’ just out of vanity, as Walter Nazing said American women did?
她是这样的吗？ Did she?
如人们所说，如果一个人“冒险成功”，哪怕只有一次——会不会更时尚、更富有戏剧性呢？ Would it not be more in the mode, really dramatic—if one ‘went over the deep end,’ as they said, just once?
当他们身处异地的时候——他在他常常谈起的东方，而她在这个西方——那不就成了一件值得他们两个人怀念的往事了吗？ Would that not be something they could both look back on—he in the East he was always talking of, she in this West?
在那个叫做弗勒的生物体内，这个假设在当时颇为时尚。依照迈克尔认真思考的理论，她如此优美、匀称，是不会有灵魂的。 The proposition had a momentary popularity in that organism called Fleur too finely proportioned for a soul according to the theory which Michael was thinking over.
和流行事物一样，这种想法长不了。 Like all popularities, it did not last.
首先：她愿意这样吗？ First: Would she like it?
她并不认为自己会喜欢。和一个不存在爱情的男人在一起，已经够了。 She did not think she would; one man, without love, was quite enough.
另外，还存在落入威尔弗里德掌控之中的危险。 Then there was the danger of passing into Wilfrid’s power.
他是个有教养的人，但容易冲动。一旦从杯子里吸了一口，他还会轻易放下杯子吗？ He was a gentleman, but he was passionate; the cup once sipped, would he consent to put it down?
但最主要的还是最近两三周里，她怀疑自己可能怀孕了，这让她觉得事情严重了。 But more than all was a physical doubt of the last two or three weeks which awaited verification, and which made her feel solemn.
她起身，用双手抚摸自己的全身，一想到威尔弗里德也是这样抚摸她的，她就明显地畏缩起来。 She stood up and passed her hands all over her, with a definite recoil from the thought of Wilfrid’s hands doing the same.
不！ No!
她要得到他的友谊、爱慕，却不能付出那样的代价。 To have his friendship, his admiration, but not at that price.
突然间，她把他视为安放在红棕色地板上的一枚炸弹，并且在幻想中，她奔过去一把抓住，把他扔到广场上——可怜的威尔弗里德！ She viewed him, suddenly, as a bomb set on her copper floor; and in fancy ran and seized and flung him out into the Square—poor Wilfrid!
怜悯是“时髦的碳酸饮料”！ Pity was ‘pop!’
但是，如果失去了他，她会对感到懊恼；同时她也会失去现代女性观。一天晚上，“潘神教”的宠儿，有着人人称羡的金红色头发的玛乔丽·费拉尔曾经对弗勒解释这个道理：“老朋友，我的目标是要做一个男人十全十美的妻子，另一个男人完美无瑕的情妇，以及第三个人尽善尽美的母亲，所有这些同时进行。 But one might be sorry for ONESELF, losing him; losing too that ideal of modern womanhood expounded to her one evening by Marjorie Ferrar, pet of the ‘panjoys,’ whose red-gold hair excited so much admiration: “My ambition—old thing—is to be the perfect wife of one man, the perfect mistress of another, and the perfect mother of a third, all at once.
这是完全可能的——法国人就是这样做的。” It’s perfectly possible—they do it in France.”
但这等好事真有可能发生吗——即使怜悯是时髦的？ But was it really so perfectly possible—even if pity WAS posh?
如果稍不留神，让迈克尔发现他对威尔弗里德完美无瑕，那她还怎么对迈克尔十全十美呢；如果她每一次对迈克尔十全十美，就相当于往威尔弗里德的心上刺一刀，那她又怎么对威尔弗里德完美无瑕呢？ How be perfect to Michael, when the slightest slip might reveal to him that she was being perfect to Wilfrid; how be perfect to Wilfrid, when every time she was perfect to Michael would be a dagger in Wilfrid’s heart?
再如果——如果她确实怀孕了，而她却在折磨这两个男人，或者对他们信口开河、任意扯谎，那么在这个情况下，她又怎么能成为一个尽善尽美的母亲呢？ And if—if her physical doubt should mature into certainty, how be perfect mother to the certainty, when she was either torturing two men, or lying to them like a trooperess?
这并不像所说的那样完全可能！ Not so perfectly possible as all that!
“我要是个彻头彻尾的法国人就好了！”弗勒陷入沉思…… ‘If only I were all French!’ thought Fleur....
房门咔哒的响声惊醒了她——那个让她成不了彻头彻尾的法国人的人走了进来。 The clicking door startled her—the reason that she was not all French was coming in.
他面色很阴沉，好像是思虑过度。 He looked very grey, as if he had been thinking too much.
他吻了她一下，然后心神不定地坐在壁炉前。 He kissed her, and sat down moodily before the fire.
“在这里过夜吗，爸爸？” “Have you come for the night, Dad?”
“如果可以的话。”索姆斯低声说， “If I may,” murmured Soames.
“生意上的事。” “Business.”
“有什么不愉快的事吗，亲爱的爸爸？” “Anything unpleasant, ducky?”
索姆斯像是受了惊吓似地抬起头来。 Soames looked up as if startled.
“不愉快？ “Unpleasant?
为什么要不愉快呢？” Why should it be unpleasant?”
“我只是从你的表情里猜的。” “I only thought from your face.”
索姆斯咕哝了一声。 Soames grunted.
“这个鲁尔区！”他说， “This Ruhr!” he said.
“我给你带来一幅画。 “I’ve brought you a picture.
中国的！” Chinese!”
“哦，爸爸！ “Oh, Dad!
是幅有趣的！” How jolly!”
“不是有趣的，”索姆斯说，“画的是一只猴子正在吃水果。” “It isn’t,” said Soames; “it’s a monkey eating fruit.”
“那好极了！ “But that’s perfect!
在哪儿？——门厅里吗？” Where is it—in the hall?”
索姆斯点了点头。 Soames nodded.
弗勒打开包装纸，把画取出来，竖在那张翠绿色的长靠椅上，后退了几步，仔细观看。 Stripping the coverings off the picture, Fleur brought it in, and setting it up on the jade-green settee, stood away and looked at it.
画面上，那只大白猿的褐色眼睛令人难忘。看那神情，仿佛是她突然间要从它蜷曲的爪子里夺走那橙子模样的水果似的。再加上那灰蒙蒙的背景、遍地的果皮——整幅画幽暗的主色调之外，有几抹鲜明的色调，立刻给她留下了深刻的印象。 The large white monkey with its brown haunting eyes, as if she had suddenly wrested its interest from the orange-like fruit in its crisped paw, the grey background, the empty rinds all round—bright splashes in a general ghostliness of colour, impressed her at once.
“可是，爸爸，这是一幅杰作啊——我敢肯定它属于一个非常繁盛的时代。” “But, Dad, it’s a masterpiece—I’m sure it’s of a frightfully good period.”
“我不知道。”索姆斯说， “I don’t know,” said Soames.
我得去查一下中国的资料。” “I must look up the Chinese.”
“可是你不该给我，它一定值很多钱呢。 “But you oughtn’t to give it to me, it must be worth any amount.
你应该把它放入你的收藏品里。” You ought to have it in your collection.”
“他们不懂它的价值。”索姆斯说，一丝淡淡的微笑照亮了他的面容， “They didn’t know its value,” said Soames, and a faint smile illumined his features.
“我花了300镑。 “I gave three hundred for it.
放在这里更安全。” It’ll be safer here.”
“那是自然，这儿很安全。 “Of course it’ll be safe.
只是为什么说更安全些呢？” Only why safer?”
索姆斯转身看看那幅画。 Soames turned towards the picture.
“我也说不上来。 “I can’t tell.
可能因为这幅画会出什么事。” Anything may come of this.”
“会发生什么啊，亲爱的爸爸？” “Of what, dear?”
“今晚‘老蒙特’来吗？” “Is ‘old Mont’ coming in to-night?”
“不来，他还在礼宾大厅呢。” “No, he’s at Lippinghall still.”
“嗯，没关系——他已经不中用了。” “Well, it doesn’t matter—he’s no good.”
弗勒紧紧握着他的手。 Fleur took his hand and gave it a squeeze.
“告诉我吧！” “Tell me!”
索姆斯酥痒的心颤动了一下。 Soames’ tickled heart quivered.
她居然想了解他有什么麻烦事！ Fancy her wanting to know what was troubling him!
但是，他做事一向注意分寸，又怕泄露自己的惊恐，因此并没有回答。 But his sense of the becoming, and his fear of giving away his own alarm, forbade response.
“你不会理解这些事的。”他说， “Nothing you’d understand,” he said.
“你打算把它挂在哪儿呢？” “Where are you going to hang it?”
“我想，挂那儿吧，不过，我们得等迈克尔回来再挂。” “There, I think; but we must wait for Michael.”
索姆斯抱怨道： Soames grumbled out:
“我刚才在你姑姑家见到他了。 “I saw him just now at your aunt’s.
他就是那样照顾生意的吗？” Is that the way he attends to business?”
“也许，”弗勒想，“他不过是在回办公室的路上经过那里。 ‘Perhaps,’ thought Fleur, ‘he was only on his way back to the office.
科克大街差不多就位于两个地方中间！ Cork Street IS more or less between!
如果他走到街的尽头，他就会想到去找威尔弗里德，他或许想找他谈谈书的事情。” If he passed the end of it, he would think of Wilfrid, he might have been wanting to see him about books.’
“啊，叮铃来了！ “Oh, here’s Ting!
怎么样啊，宝贝！” Well, darling!”
是那只中国狗，仿佛是天意让它进来的。它望着索姆斯，突然就坐下了，扁平的鼻子朝上，一双眼睛亮晶晶的。 The Chinese dog, let in, as it were, by Providence, seeing Soames, sat down suddenly with snub upturned and eyes brilliant.
“看看你的表情。”它似乎在说，“真让我高兴。 “The expression of your face,” he seemed to say, “pleases me.
老朋友，咱俩都属于过去，可以一起唱赞美诗。” We belong to the past and could sing hymns together, old man.”
“滑稽的小家伙，”索姆斯说，“它总是认得我。” “Funny little chap,” said Soames; “he always knows me.”
弗勒抱起它。 Fleur lifted him.
“来看看这只新猴子，亲爱的。” “Come and see the new monkey, ducky.”
“可别让它舔画。” “Don’t let him lick it.”
小叮铃闻着这块散发着古老气息、难以辨别的丝绸，可是由于脖子上的翠绿色项圈扣得很紧，它的头不得不随着鼻子的动作越抬越高，小小的舌头也伸了出来，试图品味祖国的气息。 Held rather firmly by his jade-green collar and confronted by an inexplicable piece of silk smelling of the past, Ting-a-ling raised his head higher and higher to correspond with the action of his nostrils, and his little tongue appeared, tentatively savouring the emanation of his country.
“这只猴子不错，对吗，亲爱的？” “It’s a nice monkey, isn’t it, darling?”
“不，”小叮铃直截了当地说， “No,” said Ting-a-ling, rather clearly.
“放我下来！” “Put me down!”
它回到地板上，找了一块两条地毯间缝隙的位置，静静地舔着红棕色地板。 Restored to the floor, he sought a patch where the copper came through between two rugs, and licked it quietly.
“奥布里·格林先生来了，夫人！” “Mr. Aubrey Greene, ma’am!”
“哼！”索姆斯说。 “H’m!” said Soames.
这位红光满面的画家静静地走了进来，一头亮发朝后梳着，一双碧绿色的眼睛在四处张望。 The painter came gliding and glowing in; his bright hair slipping back, his green eyes sliding off.
“啊！”他指着地板说， “Ah!” he said, pointing to the floor.
“我就是为这个来的。” “That’s what I’ve come about.”
弗勒惊异地随着他的手指看去。 Fleur followed his finger in amazement.
“叮铃！”她厉声喝道，“不许这样！ “Ting!” she said severely, “stop it!
它就是要舔那红棕色地板，奥布里。” He will lick the copper, Aubrey.”
“可是这是多么纯的中国狗啊！ “But how perfectly Chinese!
它们总是做我们做不了的事。” They do every thing we don’t.”
“爸爸——奥布里·格林来了。 “Dad—Aubrey Greene.
我父亲刚给我拿来这幅画，奥布里——这难道不是一件珍品吗？” My father’s just brought me this picture, Aubrey—isn’t it a gem?”
这位画家一动不动地站着，眼睛定格在那幅画上，连头发也不动了。 The painter stood quite still, his eyes ceased sliding off, his hair ceased slipping back.
“唷！”他说。 “Phew!” he said.
索姆斯站了起来。 Soames rose.
他本以为会听到一句轻率无礼的话，可是，从那口气中他却听出了一种介于敬畏和惊奇之间的意思来。 He had waited for the flippant; but he recognised in the tone something reverential, if not aghast.
“天哪，”奥布里·格林说，“瞧那双眼睛！ “By George,” said Aubrey Greene, “those eyes!
先生，您在哪儿淘的这幅画？” Where did you pick it up, sir?”
“他原属于我堂弟——一个赛马迷。 “It belonged to a cousin of mine—a racing man.
这是他仅有的一幅画。” It was his only picture.”
“不错！ “Good for him!
他一定很有鉴赏力。” He must have had taste.”
索姆斯瞪着眼睛。 Soames stared.
居然说乔治有鉴赏力，这想法让他大为吃惊。 The idea that George should have had taste almost appalled him.
“不，”他灵机一动，接着说，“他喜欢这幅画，因为它能使人不舒服。” “No,” he said, with a flash of inspiration: “What he liked about it was that it makes you feel uncomfortable.”
“一回事！ “Same thing!
对人生的感悟，我从未见过比这更具讽刺性的画作了。” I don’t know where I’ve seen a more pungent satire on human life.”
“我听不懂。”索姆斯冷冷地说。 “I don’t follow,” said Soames dryly.
“为什么，这是多完美的讽喻啊，先生！ “Why, it’s a perfect allegory, sir!
吃掉人生的果实，果皮随便一丢，正在它这么做的时候，被逮住了。 Eat the fruits of life, scatter the rinds, and get copped doing it.
当猴子的眼睛静止不动时，就成了人类悲剧的化身。 When they’re still, a monkey’s eyes are the human tragedy incarnate.
瞧那双眼睛！ Look at them!
它以为那边还有什么东西，可惜拿不到，所以伤心、生气。 He thinks there’s something beyond, and he’s sad or angry because he can’t get at it.
这幅画应该放到大英博物馆去，先生，贴上这个标签：《发现文明》。” That picture ought to be in the British Museum, sir, with the label: ‘Civilisation, caught out.’”
“唔，不行。”弗勒说， “Well, it won’t be,” said Fleur.
“它就挂在这儿，标明《白猿》。” “It’ll be here, labelled ‘The White Monkey.’”
“一回事。” “Same thing.”
索姆斯唐突地说：“愤世嫉俗可没什么好处。 “Cynicism,” said Soames abruptly, “gets you nowhere.
如果您刚才说《发现现代生活》——” If you’d said ‘MODERNITY caught out’—”
“我就是这个意思，先生，可是为什么这么狭隘地理解呢？ “I do, sir; but why be narrow?
您不至于认为这个时代比其他任何时代都差劲吧？” You don’t seriously suppose this age is worse than any other?”
“为什么不呢？”索姆斯说道， “Don’t I?” said Soames.
“我认为，世界早在19世纪80年代就达到了顶峰，以后再不会出现那样的高度了。” “In my belief the world reached its highest point in the ‘eighties, and will never reach it again.”
这位画家瞪着眼睛。 The painter stared.
“这话真有趣。 “That’s frightfully interesting.
那时，我还没出生呢，我想您当时和我现在差不多大吧，先生。 I wasn’t born, and I suppose you were about my age then, sir.
你们相信上帝，而且乘坐公共马车。” You believed in God and drove in DILIGENCES.”
公共马车！ DILIGENCES!
这个词似乎勾起了索姆斯对往昔生活的回忆。 The word awakened in Soames a memory which somehow seemed appropriate.
“没错。”他说，“我还可以给你讲个那时候的故事，和现在的生活完全不一样。 “Yes,” he said, “and I can tell you a story of those days that you can’t match in these.
我小时候，一次和家人在瑞士玩，我的两个妹妹不知从哪里得到了一些黑樱桃。 When I was a youngster in Switzerland with my people, two of my sisters had some black cherries.
她们吃了有五六颗时，发现里面全是小蛆虫。 When they’d eaten about half a dozen they discovered that they all had little maggots in them.
当时在场的一个英国登山者见她们不舒服，就把剩下的樱桃全吃了——大约有两磅——蛆虫和果核也都吃了，就是吃给她们看的。 An English climber there saw how upset they were, and ate the whole of the rest of the cherries—about two pounds—maggots, stones and all, just to show them.
当时的人就是这样的。” That was the sort of men they were then.”
“哦！ “Oh!
爸爸！” Father!”
“哎呀！ “Gee!
他一定是被她们吸引住了。” He must have been gone on them.”
“不。”索姆斯说，“不全是这样。 “No,” said Soames, “not particularly.
他叫波利，留着络腮胡。” His name was Powley; he wore side whiskers.”
“说到上帝和公共马车，我昨天看到一辆双座马车。” “Talking of God and diligences; I saw a hansom yesterday.”
“如果你说你见到上帝，那倒更切题些。”索姆斯心想，但他没说出来。的确，这样想连他自己也感到吃惊，这种事他自己都没见过。 ‘More to the point if you’d seen God,’ thought Soames, but he did not say so; indeed, the thought surprised him, it was not the sort of thing he had ever seen himself.
“您也许不知道，先生，但是现在的人可比战前的人更有信仰——人们已经发现人类不只有肉体。” “You mayn’t know it, sir, but there’s more belief now than there was before the war—they’ve discovered that we’re not all body.”
“哦！”弗勒说道， “Oh!” said Fleur.
“这让我想起来了，奥布里。 “That reminds me, Aubrey.
你认识什么巫师吗？ Do you know any mediums?
可以叫一个到这儿来吗？ Could I get one to come here?
就在我们的地板上，同时让迈克尔站在房门外，那就不可能耍花招了。 On our floor, with Michael outside the door, one would know there couldn’t be any hanky.
那些神秘的通灵人会出来吗？——据说他们更神。” Do the dark seance people ever go out?—they’re much more thrilling they say.”
“招魂术！”索姆斯说， “Spiritualism!” said Soames.
“哼！” “H’mph!”
在半个小时里，他没法把自己的意思表达清楚。 He could not in half an hour have expressed himself more clearly.
奥布里·格林的眼睛溜到了小叮铃身上。 Aubrey Greene’s eyes slid off to Ting-a-ling.
“如果明天下午能把你的哈巴狗借我一个小时左右，我一定想办法试试。 “I’ll see what I can do, if you’ll lend me your Peke for an hour or so tomorrow afternoon.
我会把它牵回来，还会给它一切舒适的享受。” I’d bring him back on a lead, and give him every luxury.”
“你要它做什么？” “What do you want him for?”
“今天，迈克尔给我送来一个不错的小模特。 “Michael sent me a most topping little model today.
可是，你瞧，她就是不笑。” But, you see, she can’t smile.”
“迈克尔？” “Michael?”
“是啊。 “Yes.
完全是新手，不过我已经有了计划了。 Something quite new; and I’ve got a scheme.
她的笑容就像是意大利山谷里的阳光，可是当你让她笑时，她却笑不出来。 Her smile’s like sunlight going off an Italian valley; but when you tell her to, she can’t.
我想，或许你这只哈巴狗能让她笑起来。” I thought your Peke could make her, perhaps.”
“我可以去看看吗？”弗勒说。 “May I come and see?” said Fleur.
“可以，明天你带它过来。不过，如果她能听我的话，那将是‘裸体画’。” “Yes, bring him tomorrow; but, if I can persuade her, it’ll be in the ‘altogether.’”
“啊！ “Oh!
如果我把叮铃借给你，你能给我找个通灵人吗？” Will you get me a seance, if I lend you Ting?”
“能。” “I will.”
“哼！”索姆斯又来一句。 “H’mph!” said Soames again.
通灵人、意大利的阳光，还“裸体画”！ Seances, Italian sunlight, the ‘altogether!’
现在是该回去找埃尔德森并且做些什么的时候了，别等到火烧眉毛时，还在这里闲扯呢。 It was time he got back to Elderson, and what was to be done now, and left this fiddling while Rome burned.
“再见，格林先生。”他说，“我得走了。” “Good-bye, Mr. Greene,” he said; “I’ve got no time.”
“您慢走，先生。”奥布里·格林说。 “Quite, sir,” said Aubrey Greene.
“慢走！”索姆斯心里一边模仿着，一边走出去。 “Quite!” mimicked Soames to himself, going out.
几分钟后，奥布里·格林也告辞了，他在门厅里遇见一位夫人，她正向男仆报自己的姓名。 Aubrey Greene took his departure a few minutes later, crossing a lady in the hall who was delivering her name to the manservant.
弗勒独自与自己的肉体在一起，她又用双手抚摸了全身。 Alone with her body, Fleur again passed her hands all over it.
“裸体画”一词让她意识到戏剧性举动的危险性。 The ‘altogether’—was a reminder of the dangers of dramatic conduct.
第五章 Chapter V
弗勒的灵魂 Fleur’s Soul
“夫人，瓦尔·达尔蒂夫人到了。” “Mrs. Val Dartie, ma’am.”
一个连科克都不会念错的名字竟然触动了她，好像有个指头突然戳痛了她的坐骨神经末梢一样。 A name which could not be distorted even by Coaker affected her like a finger applied suddenly to the head of the sciatic nerve.
霍莉！ Holly!
自从弗勒没能同乔恩结婚的那天起，她就再没见过霍莉。 Not seen since the day when she did not marry Jon.
霍莉！ Holly!
一连串的记忆如潮水般袭来——沃斯顿、唐一家、砾石场、苹果园、河流、罗宾山的小灌木林！ A flood of remembrance—Wansdon, the Downs, the gravel pit, the apple orchard, the river, the copse at Robin Hill!
No!
见到霍莉——并不是件令人愉快的事，而她却说：“你能来这儿真是太好了！” It was not a pleasant sensation—to see Holly, and she said: “How awfully nice of you to come!”
“今天下午，我在格林街遇见你丈夫，他邀我过来的。 “I met your husband this afternoon at Green Street; he asked me.
多漂亮的房子啊！” What a lovely room!”
“叮铃！ “Ting!
来，我给你介绍一下！ Come and be introduced!
这是小叮铃，很不错吧？ This is Ting-a-ling; isn’t he perfect?
因为家里来了只新猴子，它有点儿心烦意乱了。 He’s a little upset because of the new monkey.
瓦尔好吗？还有可爱的沃斯顿也好吗？ How’s Val, and dear Wansdon?
这儿太安静了。” It was too wonderfully peaceful.”
“这儿虽然有点儿偏僻，却很清静。 “It’s a nice backwater.
我倒不讨厌这里。” I don’t get tired of it.”
“还有——”弗勒笑嘻嘻地问道，“乔恩呢？” “And—” said Fleur, with a little laugh, “Jon?”
“他在北卡罗来纳种桃子。 “He’s growing peaches in North Carolina.
英属哥伦比亚不能种。” British Columbia didn’t do.”
“哦！ “Oh!
他结婚了吗？” Is he married?”
“没有。” “No.”
“我猜他会娶个美国人吧。” “I suppose he’ll marry an American.”
“你知道，他还不到22岁呢。” “He isn’t twenty-two, you know.”
“我的天哪！”弗勒说，“我还只有21岁呢？ “Good Lord!” said Fleur: “Am I only twenty-one?
我觉得自己都48了。” I feel forty-eight.”
“那是因为你身处生活的激流中，还接触那么多人——” “That’s living in the middle of things and seeing so many people—”
“可到头来一个也不熟。” “And getting to know none.”
“真的？” “But don’t you?”
“不，不是的。 “No, it isn’t done.
我是说我们大家都彼此称呼教名，可是后来——” I mean we all call each other by our Christian names; but apres—”
“我很喜欢你先生。” “I like your husband very much.”
“哦！是的，迈克尔很可爱。 “Oh! yes, Michael’s a dear.
琼好吗？” How’s June?”
“我昨天见到她了——当然，她又找了一个画家——克劳德·布雷恩斯。 “I saw her yesterday—she’s got a new painter, of course—Claud Brains.
我认为他就是人们常说的旋转派画家。” I believe he’s what they call a Vertiginist.”
弗勒咬着嘴唇。 Fleur bit her lip.
“是啊，这种人很常见。 “Yes, they’re quite common.
我猜琼会认为他是唯一的旋转派画家吧。” I suppose June thinks he’s the only one.”
“嗯，她认为他是个天才。” “Well, she think’s he’s a genius.”
“她真了不起。” “She’s wonderful.”
“是的，”霍莉说，“只要这个世界还存在下去，她就是世上最忠实的人。 “Yes,” said Holly, “the most loyal creature in the world while it lasts.
这很像孵小鸡——只要孵出来就行。 It’s like poultry farming—once they’re hatched.
你还没见过鲍里斯·斯特拉莫洛斯基吧？” You never saw Boris Strumolowski?”
“没有。” “No.”
“嗯，那就别见了。” “Well, don’t.”
“据我所知，他给迈克尔叔叔画了半身像。 “I know his bust of Michael’s uncle.
相当不错。” It’s rather sane.”
“不错。 “Yes.
琼认为那是一件为了混饭吃而粗制滥造的东西，他再也不原谅她了。 June thought it a pot-boiler, and he never forgave her.
当然，它就是一件这样的作品。 Of course it was.
一旦她宠爱的人成了才子，她就去另外找一个。 As soon as her swan makes money, she looks round for another.
她真是个可爱的人。” She’s a darling.”
“是啊。”弗勒轻声说，“我喜欢琼。” “Yes,” murmured Fleur; “I liked June.”
又一连串记忆如潮水般袭来——一家茶叶店、小河、琼的小餐室，还有在格林街的那个地方，她在琼蓝眼睛的注视下换上的结婚礼服。 Another flood of remembrance—from a tea-shop, from the river, from June’s little dining-room, from where in Green Street she had changed her wedding dress under the upward gaze of June’s blue eyes.
她拿起那幅画着猴子的画，并将它举了起来。 She seized the monkey and held it up.
“这不是一幅‘人生’的写照吗？” “Isn’t it a picture of ‘life’?”
如果奥布里·格林没说过这样的话，她还会这样说吗？ Would she have said that if Aubrey Greene hadn’t?
可是在这个时候，这样说似乎十分贴切。 Still it seemed very true at the moment.
“可怜的猴子！”霍莉说道， “Poor monkey!” said Holly.
“我总会为猴子们感到难过。 “I’m always frightfully sorry for monkeys.
但是，我认为这真是一幅了不起的画作。” But it’s marvellous, I think.”
“是的。 “Yes.
我打算把它挂在这儿。 I’m going to hang it here.
如果我能再得到一幅，我就可以把这间房间布置妥当了。这都是因为大家都那么喜欢中国画。 If I can get one more, I shall have done in this room; only people have so got on to Chinese things.
这回真是幸运——有个人去世了——乔治·福赛特，你知道的，那个赛马迷。” This was luck—somebody died—George Forsyte, you know, the racing one.”
“哦！”霍莉轻声说。 “Oh!” said Holly softly.
她仿佛又看见了弗勒结婚时的那个教堂，她的这位年长的男亲戚有双嘲弄人的眼睛，她记得他当时低语道：“她不会中途变卦吧？” She saw again her old kinsman’s japing eyes in the church when Fleur was being married, heard his throaty whisper, “Will she stay the course?”
现在她是否在变呢，这位美丽活泼的姑娘？ And was she staying it, this pretty filly?
“希望她能得到一次休息。 “Wish she could get a rest.
要是附近有一片沙漠就好了！” If only there were a desert handy!”
嗯，这样有关私生活的问题是不能随便问的，霍莉只好转而说些无关痛痒的话。 Well, one couldn’t ask a question so personal, and Holly took refuge in a general remark.
“弗勒，你们这些时髦的年轻人觉得现在的生活如何啊？我长期不在这儿生活，在南非住了20年，现在还觉得不太适应呢。” “What do all you smart young people feel about life, nowadays, Fleur! when one’s not of it and has lived twenty years in South Africa, one still feels out of it.”
“生活！ “Life!
哦！好吧，可以这样说，我们知道大家把生活当作一个谜，我们也不打算猜破它。 Oh! well, we know it’s supposed to be a riddle, but we’ve given it up.
我们只想好好生活，因为我们不相信有任何持久的事情。 We just want to have a good time because we don’t believe anything can last.
但是，我认为我们不清楚怎样得到这样的生活。 But I don’t think we know how to have it.
我们一直在追求，希望得到它。 We just fly on, and hope for it.
当然，有艺术，但是我们多数都不是艺术家；还有，表现主义——迈克尔说它没什么内容。 Of course, there’s art, but most of us aren’t artists; besides, expressionism—Michael says it’s got no inside.
我们把它吹得天花乱坠，但是，我想它确实没什么内容。 We gas about it, but I suppose it hasn’t.
你知道，我见过很多作家和画家，人们都说他们纯属娱乐。” I see a frightful lot of writers and painters, you know; they’re supposed to be amusing.”
霍莉听着，感到很惊讶。 Holly listened, amazed.
谁会想到这位姑娘会洞察一切？ Who would have thought that this girl SAW?
她可能看错了，但不管怎样她都看到了！ She might be seeing wrong, but anyway she saw!
她说：“我敢肯定，你们生活得很快乐吧？” “Surely,” she said, “you enjoy yourselves?”
“嗯，我喜欢收集好东西，招揽有趣的人；我喜欢欣赏一切新鲜的和有价值的东西，至少此刻看上去是这样的。 “Well, I like getting hold of nice things, and interesting people; I like seeing everything that’s new and worth while, or seems so at the moment.
但事情总是这样——没有什么是持久的。 But that’s just how it is—nothing lasts.
你知道，我不是‘潘神教徒’，也不是‘新宗教徒’。” You see, I’m not of the ‘Pan-joys,’ nor of the ‘new-faithfuls.’”
“新宗教徒？” “The new-faithfuls?”
“哦！您不知道吗——这是一种自我调节的信仰疗法，完全不是那种老式的‘上帝好，好上帝！’，而是一种混合疗法，包括意志力、心理分析和信念——如果你认为一夜之间什么都会变好，那么，转天就会变好。 “Oh! don’t you know—it’s a sort of faith-healing done on oneself, not exactly the old ‘God-good, good-God!’ sort; but a kind of mixture of will-power, psycho-analysis, and belief that everything will be all right on the night if you say it will.
想必你一定见过他们。 You must have come across them.
他们非常虔诚。” They’re frightfully in earnest.”
“我知道，”霍莉说，“他们的目光炯炯有神。” “I know,” said Holly; “their eyes shine.”
“我想是这样的。 “I daresay.
我不相信他们——我不相信任何一个人，或者任何事物——不太相信。 I don’t believe in them—I don’t believe in anyone; or anything—much.
一个人怎么能随便相信呢？” How can one?”
“那么朴实的人和辛苦的工作呢？” “How about simple people, and hard work?”
弗勒叹了口气。 Fleur sighed.
“我想大概也是这样吧。 “I daresay.
我要替迈克尔说句话——他可没被宠坏。 I will say for Michael—HE’S not spoiled.
咱们喝茶吧？ Let’s have tea?
喝茶吗，叮铃？”于是她扭亮灯，按了按铃。 Tea, Ting?” and, turning up the lights, she rang the bell.
当这位不速之客离开后，她非常安静地坐在壁炉前。 When her unexpected visitor had gone, she sat very still before the fire.
今天，她差一点儿就成为威尔弗里德的人了。 To-day, when she had been so very nearly Wilfrid’s!
原来乔恩还没结婚！ So Jon was not married!
这样也并不意味着就有什么机会！ Not that it made any odds!
事情的发展并不像书里写的那样。 Things did not come round as they were expected to in books.
可是不管怎样，感情已经过去了！ And anyway sentiment was swosh!
断了吧！ Cut it out!
她把头发往后一捋，拿起榔头和钉子，动手去挂那幅白猿。 She tossed back her hair; and, getting hammer and nail, proceeded to hang the white monkey.
把它挂在两只彩色珍珠贝图案的茶具中间，会显得非常出色。 Between the two tea-chests with their coloured pearl-shell figures, he would look his best.
既然她得不到乔恩，那么无论得到威尔弗里德还是迈克尔，或者两个都得到，或者两个都失去，又有什么关系呢？ Since she couldn’t have Jon, what did it matter—Wilfrid or Michael, or both, or neither?
吃掉手里的橙子，把果皮扔掉！ Eat the orange in her hand, and throw away the rind!
突然间，她发现迈克尔已经在房间里了。 And suddenly she became aware that Michael was in the room.
他静静地走到壁炉前面，站在她的身后。 He had come in very quietly and was standing before the fire behind her.
她迅速瞥了他一眼，说道： She gave him a quick look and said:
“刚才奥布里·格林来过，提起你送过去的一个模特，还有霍莉——瓦尔·达尔蒂夫人——她说她见过你了。 “I’ve had Aubrey Greene here about a model you sent him, and Holly—Mrs. Val Dartie—she said she’d seen you.
哦！爸爸给我们带来了这个。 Oh! and father’s brought us this.
不错吧？” Isn’t it perfect?”
迈克尔没说话。 Michael did not speak.
“有什么事吗，迈克尔？” “Anything the matter, Michael?”
“没有，没什么。” “No, nothing.”
他走到那幅画跟前。 He went up to the monkey.
弗勒审视着他的背影。 From behind him now Fleur searched his profile.
她的直觉告诉她，一定有什么事情。 Instinct told her of a change.
难道他最终还是看到她到威尔弗里德家去了——又从那里出来离开了？ Had he, after all, seen her going to Wilfrid’s—coming away?
“是只猴子！”他说， “Some monkey!” he said.
“顺便问一句，你有什么多余的衣服可以送给一个可怜人的妻子吗——不用太漂亮？” “By the way, have you any spare clothes you could give the wife of a poor snipe—nothing too swell?”
她机械地答道：“有，当然有！”她的脑子却在拼命地转着。 She answered mechanically: “Yes, of course!” while her brain worked furiously.
“那么，把它们找出来好吗？ “Would you put them out, then?
我自己也打算给他凑几件——一起送过去。” I’m going to make up a bunch for him myself—they could go together.”
不错！ Yes!
他今天完全变了个人，好像他身上的发条已经坏了。 He was quite unlike himself, as if the spring in him had run down.
她感觉浑身不舒服。 A sort of malaise overcame her.
迈克尔不高兴了！ Michael not cheerful!
这就像是冬日里的火炉熄灭了一样。 It was like the fire going out on a cold day.
可是，这或许是她第一次感觉到，他的快乐对她而言意义重大。 And, perhaps for the first time, she was conscious that his cheerfulness was of real importance to her.
她看着他抱起小叮铃，坐了下来。 She watched him pick up Ting-a-ling and sit down.
她走到他的背后，弯下身子，直到头发碰触到他的脸颊。 And going up behind him, she bent over till her hair was against his cheek.
可是，他并没有用脸去碰触她的面颊，而是在那里一动不动地坐着，于是她不安起来。 Instead of rubbing his cheek on hers, he sat quite still, and her heart misgave her.
“怎么了？”她撒娇地说。 “What is it?” she said, coaxing.
“没事！” “Nothing!”
她捏着他的耳朵。 She took hold of his ears.
“但是，是有点儿事。 “But there is.
我猜你大概知道我去找过威尔弗里德了。” I suppose you know somehow that I went to see Wilfrid.”
他面无表情地说：“为什么不呢？” He said stonily: “Why not?”
她放开手，站得直直的。 She let go, and stood up straight.
“我只是去告诉他，以后都不见他了。” “It was only to tell him that I couldn’t see him again.”
她觉得这句半真半假的话全是真的。 That half-truth seemed to her the whole.
他突然抬起头，脸上一阵颤抖。他抓住了她的手。 He suddenly looked up, a quiver went over his face; he look her hand.
“好了，弗勒。 “It’s all right, Fleur.
你喜欢怎么样就怎么样吧。 You must do what you like, you know.
这样才公平。 That’s only fair.
我只是午饭吃多了。” I had too much lunch.”
弗勒退到房间中央。 Fleur withdrew to the middle of the room.
“你真是个善人。”她缓缓地说，然后出去了。 “You’re rather an angel,” she said slowly, and went out.
她上楼找衣服去了，感情一片混乱。 Upstairs she looked out garments, confused in her soul.
第六章 Chapter VI
迈克尔受到“惩罚” Michael Gets ‘What-For’
在格林大街探究无果，迈克尔摇摇晃晃地沿着皮卡迪利大街走了回去。他顺从了内心的冲动，想要流连于混乱的中心，于是就走到了科克大街上。 After his Green Street quest Michael had wavered back down Piccadilly, and, obeying one of those impulses which make people hang around the centres of disturbance, on to Cork Street.
他在威尔弗里德家的后街口站了一会儿。 He stood for a minute at the mouth of Wilfrid’s backwater.
“还是算了吧，”他最后想道，“十有八九他不在家，就算他在家，对我而言，这件事好转的可能性也低于5%！” ‘No,’ he thought, at last, ‘ten to one he isn’t in; and if he is, twenty to one that I get any change except bad change!’
他正慢慢地向邦德大街走着，这时一位身材小巧的女士迈着轻快的步子从后街里走了出来。她一边走路一边阅读，一下子就撞上了迈克尔的后背。 He was moving slowly on to Bond Street, when a little light lady, coming from the backwater, and reading as she went, ran into him from behind.
“你怎么都不看路的！ “Why don’t you look where you’re going!
哦！ Oh!
是你？ You?
你不就是和弗勒·福赛特结婚的那个年轻人吗？ Aren’t you the young man who married Fleur Forsyte?
我是她的表姐，琼。 I’m her cousin, June.
我想我刚才还看见她了呢。” I thought I saw her just now.”
她扬了扬手里的目录，那姿势就像是只小鸟在扇动翅膀。 She waved a hand which held a catalogue with a gesture like the flirt of a bird’s wing.
“就在我画廊的对面。 “Opposite my gallery.
她走进一幢房子里去了。我都来不及和她打招呼呢——我还挺想再见见她呢。” She went into a house, or I should have spoken to her—I’d like to have seen her again.”
走进一幢房子里去了！ Into a house!
迈克尔伸手去取他的烟盒。 Michael dived for his cigarette-case.
他紧紧地抓着烟盒，抬起头来。 Hard-grasping it, he looked up.
这位小巧的女士正用她那双蓝色的眼睛在他脸上来回打量，毫不掩饰地探究着。 The little lady’s blue eyes were sweeping from side to side of his face with a searching candour.
“你们在一起幸福吗？”她问道。 “Are you happy together?” she said.
他的额头上冒出了冷汗。 A cold sweat broke out on his forehead.
一时间他心乱如麻——她的生活乱了，他的生活也乱了，这让他很痛苦。 A sense of general derangement afflicted him—hers, and his own.
“您刚才说什么？我没听清楚。”他喘着气说。 “I beg your pardon?” he gasped.
“我希望你们幸福。 “I hope you are.
她本来应该和我弟弟结婚的——不过我希望你们俩能幸福。 She ought to have married my little brother—but I hope you are.
她是个漂亮姑娘。” She’s a pretty child.”
面对这一连串迎头痛击，他懵了。更令他惊讶的是，貌似她根本没有意识到这些话会使他痛苦。 In the midst of a dull sense of stunning blows, it staggered him that she seemed quite unconscious of inflicting them.
他咬着牙，沮丧地问道：“你弟弟是谁？” He heard his teeth gritting, and said dully: “Your little brother, who was he?”
“怎么？ “What!
乔恩——你不认识乔恩吗？ Jon—didn’t you know Jon?
那时他还小，当然她也还小。 He was too young, of course, and so was she.
虽然他们深爱着对方——但是鉴于两家的世仇，他们断了关系。 But they were head over—the family feud stopped that.
唉！都过去了。 Well! it’s all past.
我参加你的婚礼了。 I was at your wedding.
我希望你们幸福。 I hope you’re happy.
你看过克劳德·布雷恩斯在我们画廊办的画展吗？ Have you seen the Claud Brains show at my gallery?
他是个天才。 He’s a genius.
我打算到这儿吃些点心，你也来好吗？ I was going to have a bun in here; will you join me?
你应该去看看他的作品的。” You ought to know his work.”
她在一家甜点店门口停住了。 She had paused at the door of a confectioner’s.
迈克尔把一只手放在胸口。 Michael put his hand on his chest.
“谢谢，”他说，“可是我刚吃过甜点了——实际上吃了两个呢。 “Thank you,” he said, “I have just had a bun—two, in fact.
抱歉了！” Excuse me!”
那位小巧的女士握着他的另一只手。 The little lady grasped his other hand.
“好吧，再见，年轻人！ “Well, good-bye, young man!
很高兴见到你。 Glad to have met you.
你长得虽然不漂亮，但是我喜欢你这张脸。 You’re not a beauty, but I like your face.
代我向那姑娘问好。 Remember me to that child.
你真应该去看看克劳德·布雷恩斯的作品。 You should go and see Claud Brains.
他真的是个天才。” He’s a real genius.”
他一动不动地站在店门前，看着她转身走进店里去了。她的动作轻盈，像在飞一样，在那些已经坐在甜点店里的客人中引起了一阵骚动。 Stock-still before the door, he watched her turn and enter, with a scattered motion, as of flying, and a disturbance among those seated in the pastry-cook’s.
然后他继续朝前走，嘴里叼着根没有点燃的香烟，神情恍惚，就像是一个拳击手——先是侧面挨了一记，接着正面又吃了一拳。 Then he moved on, the cigarette unlighted in his mouth, dazed, as a boxer from a blow which knocks him sideways, and another which knocks him straight again.
弗勒去找威尔弗里德了！——此刻就在楼上，在他的房间里！——也许，在他的怀里！ Fleur visiting Wilfrid—at this moment in his rooms up there—in his arms, perhaps!
他痛苦地呻吟着。 He groaned.
一个戴着新帽子的胖乎乎的年轻人听到这声音连忙走开了。 A well-fed young man in a new hat skipped at the sound.
不可能！ Never!
他绝对无法容忍这件事！ He could never stick that!
他要离开这里！ He would have to clear out!
他以前居然相信弗勒是忠诚的！ He had believed Fleur honest!
两面派！ A double life!
前天晚上她还对他笑呢。 The night before last she had smiled on him.
啊！ Oh!
上帝啊！ God!
他飞快地跑过马路，冲进了格林公园。 He dashed across into Green Park.
刚才过马路的时候，怎么就不站住让车撞死算了？ Why hadn’t he stood still and let something go over him?
还有刚才那疯女人的弟弟——乔恩——家族世仇？ And that lunatic’s little brother—John—family feud?
而自己呢——一个备胎，那时——她选择和他结婚时根本就不爱他——不过是一项权宜之计罢了！ Himself—a pis aller, then—taken without love at all—a makeshift!
他现在想起有天晚上在梅普尔达勒姆她说过的话：“等我知道我不能如愿以偿时，你再来吧。” He remembered now her saying one night at Mapledurham: “Come again when I know I can’t get my wish.”
原来这就是她那无法实现的愿望！ So that was the wish she couldn’t get!
拿我当临时替代品！ A makeshift!
“好，”他想道，“哦！好极了！” ‘Jolly,’ he thought: ‘Oh! jolly!’
这就难怪了！ No wonder, then!
她还有什么好在乎的？ What could she care?
不是这个男人就是那个男人！ One man or another!
可怜的小家伙！ Poor little devil!
她从来没有告诉过他——连一个字都没提过！ She had never let him know—never breathed a word!
她这么做是为了保全她的体面——还是对他的背叛？ Was that decent of her—or was it treachery?
“不，”他心里想，“就算她之前告诉我了，事情也不会有什么变化——我还是会不惜一切代价把她娶回家。 ‘No,’ he thought, ‘if she HAD told me, it wouldn’t have made any difference—I’d have taken her at any price.
她不告诉我还是对的。” It was decent of her not to tell me.’
但是怎么别人也没对他说过呢？ But how was it he hadn’t heard from some one?
家族世仇？ Family feud?
福赛特家族？ The Forsytes!
除了“老福赛特”，他没见过其他的人，可是“老福赛特”却守口如瓶。 Except ‘Old Forsyte,’ he never saw them; and ‘Old Forsyte’ was closer than a fish.
得啦！他已经受到惩罚了！ Well! he had got what-for!
黄昏时分，在公园的空地上，他又痛苦地呻吟了一声。 And again he groaned, in the twilight spaces of the Park.
白金汉宫隐约可见，因为没有点灯，这庞然大物看起来阴沉可怕。 Buckingham Palace loomed up unlighted, huge and dreary.
他终于想起自己的烟了，于是停下来划火柴点烟。等他把烟深深地吸进肺里，他才开始觉得舒服了一点儿。 Conscious of his cigarette at last, he stopped to strike a match, and drew the smoke deep into his lungs with the first faint sense of comfort.
“您能不能给我一支烟，先生？” “You couldn’t spare us a cigarette, Mister?”
一个模糊的人影出现在澳大利亚雕像旁边，那张很正派的脸上写满忧郁，衬得那雕像丰满得令人沮丧！ A shadowy figure with a decent sad face stood beside the statue of Australia, so depressingly abundant!
“当然可以！”迈克尔说，“都给你吧。” “Of course!” said Michael; “take the lot.”
他把烟盒里的烟都倒在那人的手上。 He emptied the case into the man’s hand.
“这烟盒也给你好了——‘威斯敏斯特大教堂赠’——你拿它能换30先令。 “Take the case too—‘present from Westminster’—you’ll get thirty bob for it.
祝你好运！” Good luck!”
他匆匆忙忙地走开了。 He hurried on.
身后传来那人微弱的声音：“您真好，先生！” A faint: “Hi, Mister!” pursued him unavailingly.
同情是不值钱的！ Pity was pulp!
怜悯是无聊的！ Sentiment was bilge!
要他回家去等弗勒——完事后再回来吗？ Was he going home to wait till Fleur had—finished and come back?
他才不呢！ Not he!
他朝切尔西走去，一路上使劲地迈着大步。 He turned towards Chelsea, batting along as hard as he could stride.
灯火通明的商店、阴森森的大伊顿广场、切斯特广场、斯隆广场、国王路——他一路走着，走着！ Lighted shops, gloomy great Eaton Square, Chester Square, Sloane Square, the King’s Road—along, along!
这种性嫉妒带给他的痛苦像鞭笞一般，又像蝎子蜇了一样——比在战壕里呆着还要糟糕——糟透了！ Worse than the trenches—far worse—this whipped and scorpioned sexual jealousy!
没错，要不是那第二个打击，也许他会觉得更糟糕一些呢。 Yes, and he would have felt even worse, but for that second blow.
当他得知弗勒此前爱的是她的堂兄弟之后，他觉得不那么痛苦了。也许在她看来，威尔弗里德也一样，什么都不是。 It made it less painful to know that Fleur had been in love with that cousin, and Wilfrid, too, perhaps, nothing to her.
真可怜！ Poor little wretch!
“唉，现在这游戏算什么？”他心里想。 ‘Well, what’s the game now?’ he thought.
在这恶劣的天气中，在这种压力下——游戏人生？ The game of life—in bad weather, in stress?
这是怎么了？ What was it?
在战时——人们是怎么做的呢？ In the war—what had a fellow done?
人们会想方设法忽视个人的重要性，默默承受、听天由命。那是一种催人泪下的境界——“为了英格兰，虽死犹生”。 Somehow managed to feel himself not so dashed important; reached a condition of acquiescence, fatalism, “Who dies if England live” sort of sob-stuff state.
游戏人生？ The game of life?
有什么不同？ Was it different?
“流血却不屈服”或许是胡说八道，但是——在被人击倒后，你仍然会重新站起来！ “Bloody but unbowed” might be tripe; still—get up when you were knocked down!
集体是伟大的，个人是渺小的！ The whole was big, oneself was little!
应该为了情欲、嫉妒而变得不光明正大吗？就像内津、西布莉和琳达·弗鲁那样吗？ Passion, jealousy, ought they properly to destroy one’s sportsmanship, as Nazing and Sibley and Linda Frewe would have it?
“绅士”这个词是没有价值的吗？ Was the word ‘gentleman’ a dud?
是吗？ Was it?
是保持个人的精神状态呢，还是抓紧时间大声抱怨、打击报复呢？ Did one keep one’s form, or get down to squealing and kicking in the stomach?
“我不知道，”他心里想，“我不知道等我见到她时，我该怎么办——我真的不知道。” ‘I don’t know,’ he thought, ‘I don’t know what I shall do when I see her—I simply don’t know.’
深蓝的夜色降临，法国梧桐光秃秃的，河面宽广，寒气袭人！ Steel-blue of the fallen evening, bare plane-trees, wide river, frosty air!
他转身朝家走去。 He turned towards home.
他哆哆嗦嗦地打开前门，一路哆嗦着走进客厅…… He opened his front door, trembling, and trembling, went into the drawing-room....
等到弗勒上楼去了，就剩他和小叮铃在楼下时，他不知道自己是否还相信她。 When Fleur had gone upstairs and left him with Ting-a-ling he didn’t know whether he believed her or not.
如果她一直对他隐瞒那件事，那么她也能隐瞒其他的事！ If she had kept that other thing from him all this time, she could keep anything!
她听明白他的话了吗：“你喜欢怎么样就怎么样吧，这样才公平。” Had she understood his words: “You must do as you like, that’s only fair?”
他刚才几乎是机械地说出这句话的，但这句话是有道理的。 He had said them almost mechanically, but they were reasonable.
如果她从来没有爱过他，就连一丁点儿也没有，那么他有什么权利期盼呢，他一直是在接受她的救济。 If she had never loved him, even a little, he had never had any right to expect anything; he had been all the time in the position of one to whom she was giving alms.
怎么能强迫一个人一直施舍下去呢？ Nothing compelled a person to go on giving alms.
又怎么能迫使一个人一直接受施舍呢——除非——出于那种要占有的痛苦，痛苦啊，痛苦！ And nothing compelled one to go on taking them—except—the ache of want, the ache, the ache!
“你这个小妖精！ “You little Djinn!
你这个幸运的小家伙！ You lucky little toad!
把你的得意分给我一些——你这个中国来的小家伙！” Give me some of your complacency—you Chinese atom!”
小叮铃抬起它那双靴扣般的大眼睛。 Ting-a-ling turned up his boot-buttons.
“等你像我这样被长期教化之后吧，”两只眼睛像是在说，“现在，先给我挠挠胸口吧。” “When you have been civilised as long as I,” they seemed to say: “In the meantime, scratch my chest.”
于是迈克尔一边给那黄毛的小家伙抓痒，一边想：“振作起来！ And scrattling in that yellow fur Michael thought: ‘Pull yourself together!
在南极遭遇第一场暴风雪时，人们不会去唱：‘我要回家！ Man at the South Pole with the first blizzard doesn’t sing: “Want to go home!
我要回家！’——他坚持住了。 Want to go home!”—he sticks it.
来吧，出发！” Come, get going!’
他把小叮铃放在地板上，然后走向书房。 He placed Ting-a-ling on the floor, and made for his study.
书房里有一些手稿，丹比&温特出版社的审稿人已经说过：“这本书写得不错，值得认真考虑，只是无利可图。” Here were manuscripts, of which the readers to Danby and Winter had already said: “No money in this, but a genuine piece of work meriting consideration.”
迈克尔要做的就是认真考虑这些作品，而丹比要做的则是拒绝出版。他会这样说：“给他（或她）写一封信，说话客气些，就说我们对其作品很感兴趣，但是无法将其出版，很遗憾——希望能拜读您的下一部作品，等等。 It was Michael’s business to give the consideration; Danby’s to turn the affair down with the words: “Write him (or her) a civil letter, say we were greatly interested, regret we do not see our way—hope to have the privilege of considering next effort, and so forth.
怎么样！” What!”
他把台灯打开，拿出一份他已经在看的稿子。 He turned up his reading-lamp and pulled out a manuscript he had already begun.
“没有退路，没有退路；没有退路的人必须获胜，否则就是死路一条； “No retreat, no retreat; they must conquer or die who have no retreat;
没有退路，没有退路；没有退路的人必须获胜，否则就是死路一条！” No retreat, no retreat; they must conquer or die who have no retreat!”
他心里想的全都是《波莉》诗剧中那位黑衣男仆唱的这一叠句！ The black footmen’s refrain from ‘Polly’ was all that happened in his mind.
该死的！ Dash it!
他必须读手里这份稿子！ He must read the thing!
他总算读完了这一章。 Somehow he finished the chapter.
现在他想起来了。 He remembered now.
这份稿子讲的是，主人公小时候曾经看到一个女仆在马路对面的一个房间里换衣服，这件事给他留下了极其深刻的印象，以致他结婚以后仍然不得不痛苦地挣扎在对妻子的忠诚和与妻子的女仆发生不正当关系的斗争中。 The manuscript was all about a man who, when he was a boy, had been so greatly impressed by the sight of a maidservant changing her clothes in a room over the way, that his married life was a continual struggle not to be unfaithful with his wife’s maids.
这种变态心理被人们发现了，于是他准备把这件事说出来。 They had just discovered his complex, and he was going to have it out.
这份手稿的其他部分写的肯定是那是怎么回事。 The rest of the manuscript no doubt would show how that was done.
文中不吝笔墨地描写了所有与肉体相关的具体细节，如果将这些删除，未免显得胆小而又维多利亚式的保守了。 It went most conscientiously into all those precise bodily details which it was now so timorous and Victorian to leave out.
文章写得很好，但是继续读下去却是浪费时间了！ Genuine piece of work, and waste of time to go on with it!
老丹比——极其讨厌弗洛伊德，但是这一次迈克尔却觉得老丹比是正确的。 Old Danby—Freud bored him stiff; and for once Michael did not mind old Danby being in the right.
他把手稿放回抽屉里。 He put the thing back into the drawer.
7点钟了！ Seven o’clock!
要把他听到的关于那个堂兄弟的话告诉弗勒吗？ Tell Fleur what he had been told about that cousin?
为什么要说呢？ Why?
于事无补啊！ Nothing could mend THAT!
要是她说的关于威尔弗里德的那些话是真的就好了！ If only she were speaking the truth about Wilfrid!
他走到窗边——天空繁星点点，地面条纹纵贯，那些庭院和后花园一条一条地平铺在天空下。 He went to the window—stars above, and stripes below, stripes of courtyard and back garden.
“没有退路，没有退路；没有退路的人必须获胜，否则就是死路一条！” “No retreat, no retreat; they must conquer or die who have no retreat!”
这时传来一个声音： A voice said:
“你父亲什么时候到城里来？” “When will your father be up?”
老福赛特！ Old Forsyte!
天啊！ Lord!
天啊！ Lord!
“明天吧，我想是的，先生。 “To-morrow, I believe, sir.
请进！ Come in!
我想，您还没见过我这个书斋吧。” You don’t know my den, I think.”
“没见过，”索姆斯说， “No,” said Soames.
“这里很舒服！ “Snug!
这么多漫画！ Caricatures.
你喜欢这些——没价值的东西！” You go in for them—poor stuff!”
“这可不是现代的，先生——这是一种复古的艺术。” “But not modern, sir—a revived art.”
“取笑自己的邻居——我从来不喜欢这样的东西。 “Queering your neighbours—I never cared for them.
只有当世界一片混乱，人们不愿直视眼前的事物时，这种东西才会流行。” They only flourish when the world’s in a mess and people have given up looking straight before them.”
“天啊！”迈克尔说，“说得太好了。 “By Jove!” said Michael; “that’s good.
您坐一会儿好吗，先生？” Won’t you sit down, sir?”
索姆斯坐了下来，习惯地跷起了二郎腿。 Soames sat down, crossing his knees in his accustomed manner.
瘦削、阴郁、严密——像是一本精装版的天书！ Slim, grey, close—a sealed book, neatly bound!
他的变态心理是什么？ What was HIS complex?
不管是什么，他从来没有透露过。 Whatever it was, he had never had it out.
很难想象他会怎么说出来。 One could not even imagine the operation.
“我不会把我的那幅戈雅拿走的，”他的话很出人意料，“就当那是弗勒的好了。 “I shan’t take away my Goya,” he said very unexpectedly; “consider it Fleur’s.
其实，要是我知道你们对下一代感兴趣的话，我会准备更多东西的。 In fact, if I only knew you were interested in the future, I should make more provision.
依我看来，再过几年，遗产税就会高得吓人。” In my opinion death duties will be prohibitive in a few years’ time.”
迈克尔皱了皱眉头。 Michael frowned.
“先生，让我彻底说清楚吧。我希望您明白，您为弗勒所做的，是为弗勒一个人做的。 “I’d like you to know sir, once for all, that what you do for Fleur, you do for Fleur.
如果我喜欢，我可以坐享其成——吃点儿面包，逢年过节再加点儿奶酪。” I can be Epicurus whenever I like—bread, and on feast days a little bit of cheese.”
索姆斯抬起头来，目光中透着精明。 Soames looked up with shrewdness in his glance.
“这个我知道，”他说，“我一直都清楚这一点。” “I know that,” he said, “I always knew it.”
迈克尔鞠了个躬。 Michael bowed.
“我想，在这个地产不景气的时候，你父亲遭受的打击很沉重吧。” “With this land depression your father’s hard hit, I should think.”
“是啊，他说他在观望肥皂或者是汽车行业的情况，但是要是他继续抵押地产，就这么拖延下去，我也不会觉得吃惊的。” “Well, he talks of being on the look out for soap or cars; but I shouldn’t be surprised if he mortgages again and lingers on.”
“空有头衔却没有领地，”索姆斯说，“是不正常的。 “A title without a place,” said Soames, “is not natural.
他最好等我去世之后，我是说，看看我能留下什么。 He’d better wait for me to go, if I leave anything, that is.
你听我说，我一直在考虑这么一件事。 But listen to me: I’ve been thinking.
你们两人在一起是不是不幸福？因为你们还没有孩子。” Aren’t you happy together, you two, that you don’t have children?”
迈克尔犹豫了一下。 Michael hesitated.
“我想，”他慢吞吞地说，“我们从来没有争吵，或者类似的不和。 “I don’t think,” he said slowly, “that we have ever had a scrap, or anything like it.
我一直——现在也是——很爱很爱她，但是您比我更清楚，我不过是个收拾残局的罢了。” I have been—I am—terribly fond of her, but you have known better than I that I only picked up the pieces.”
“你听谁说的？” “Who told you that?”
“今天——琼·福赛特小姐说的。” “To-day—Miss June Forsyte.”
“那个女人！”索姆斯说， “THAT woman!” said Soames.
“她什么事都要插一脚。 “She can’t keep her foot out of anything.
那不过是小男孩和小女孩过家家——在你们结婚前好几个月就结束了。” A boy and girl affair—over months before you married.”
“但是他们的感情深厚，先生。”迈克尔轻轻地说。 “But deep, sir,” said Michael gently.
“感情深——那种年纪懂什么？ “Deep—who knows at that age?
感情深厚？” Deep?”
说到这里，索姆斯停了一下，“你是个好人——我一直都知道。 Soames paused: “You’re a good fellow—I always knew.
耐心些——眼光放长远点儿。” Be patient—take a long view.”
“好吧，先生。”迈克尔说着，坐在他的椅子上一动不动，“要是我能做到的话。” “Yes, sir,” said Michael, very still in his chair, “If I can.”
“她是我的一切。”索姆斯突然低声说道。 “She’s everything to me,” muttered Soames abruptly.
“也是我的一切——这并不能减轻我的痛苦。” “And to me—which doesn’t make it easier.”
索姆斯眉间的皱纹更深了。 The line between Soames’ brows deepened.
“也许不能缓解痛苦。 “Perhaps not.
但是要坚持下去！ But hold on!
坚持下去，尽可能地温柔！ As gently as you like, but hold on!
她还年轻。 She’s young.
她还不安定，但是不会出什么事的。” She’ll flutter about; there’s nothing in it.”
“他知道另外那件事吗？”迈克尔想。 ‘Does he know about the other thing?’ thought Michael.
“我也有自己的心事，”索姆斯接着说，“但是万一她出了什么事，那我要操的心比我的那些心事要多得多了。” “I have my own worries,” went on Soames, “but they’re nothing to what I should feel if anything went wrong with her.”
迈克尔泛起了一阵同情心，对这个头发灰白、不易冲动的老人，他难得产生这种感觉。 Michael felt a twinge of sympathy, unusual towards that self-contained grey figure.
“我会尽全力的，”他平静地说，“但是我只是一个80多磅的凡人，不是所罗门那样的圣人。” “I shall try my best,” he said quietly; “but I’m not naturally Solomon at six stones even.”
“我不那么肯定，”索姆斯说，“我也没什么把握。 “I’m not so sure,” said Soames, “I’m not so sure.
不管怎样，孩子——对啊，有了孩子就会——有所保——”他没有说下去，所以那个词听来并不确切——！ Anyway, a child—well, a child would be—a—sort of insur—” He baulked, the word was not precisely—!
迈克尔僵住了。 Michael froze.
“关于这个问题，我没什么可说的。” “As to that, I can’t say anything.”
索姆斯站了起来。 Soames got up.
“不，”他若有所思地说，“我不这么认为。 “No,” he said wistfully, “I suppose not.
该穿礼服了。” It’s time to dress.”
穿礼服——吃饭，吃完饭，睡觉——睡着了，做梦！ To dress—to dine, and if to dine, to sleep—to sleep, to dream!
谁知道会是什么样的梦呢！ And then what dreams might come!
在去更衣室的路上，迈克尔遇见了科克，发现他脸拉得很长。 On the way to his dressing-room Michael encountered Coaker; the man’s face was long.
“怎么了，科克？” “What’s up, Coaker?”
“先生，那只小狗刚才在客厅里吐了。” “The little dog, sir, has been sick in the drawing-room.”
“真见鬼，怎么会吐了呢！” “The deuce he has!”
“是的，先生，看起来有人把它单独留在那里了。 “Yes, sir; it appears that some one left him there alone.
它要得到别人的重视，先生。 He makes himself felt, sir.
我常常说：它是一只重要的小狗……” I always say: He’s an important little dog....”
吃晚饭的时候，索姆斯好像懊悔起来，觉得不该给他们提建议，还把两幅价值数千英镑的画送给他们了。他编了一个故事，像是詹姆斯在他的黄金时代讲的那些故事一样。 During dinner, as if visited by remorse for having given them advice and two pictures worth some thousands of pounds, Soames pitched a tale like those of James in his palmy days.
他谈到了法国人——马克的下跌——统一公债的上涨——顽固的画商杜梅特里斯，因为索姆斯看中一张康斯太布尔的天空景色画，杜梅特里斯虽然不想要，但却因为索姆斯不肯付他索要的高价而拒不放手。 He spoke of the French—the fall of the mark—the rise in Consols—the obstinacy of Dumetrius, the picture-dealer, over a Constable skyscape which Soames wanted and Dumetrius did not, but to which the fellow held on just for the sake of a price which Soames did not mean to pay.
他谈到他曾预见英国会因为禁酒令和美国产生矛盾。 He spoke of the trouble which he foresaw with the United States over their precious Prohibition.
美国人是很顽固的。 They were a headstrong lot.
他们一旦开始做一件事，就会不撞南墙不回头。 They took up a thing and ran their heads against a stone wall.
他自己从没喝过什么值得一提的好酒，但是他喜欢那种喝酒的感觉。 He himself had never drunk anything to speak of, but he liked to feel that he could.
美国人想要让他失去这种感觉，那就是专制。 The Americans liked to feel that he couldn’t, that was tyranny.
他们傲慢专横。 They were overbearing.
如果在美国，人人都喝起酒来，他绝不会为此而惊奇的。 He shouldn’t be surprised if everybody took to drinking over there.
至于国际联盟，那天早晨有人吹捧过它。 As to the League of Nations, a man that morning had palavered it up.
它不过是一只不能斗的鸡——浪费金钱去管理那些不必管也能做成的事情，而从来不管那些真正重要的事情，比如消灭布尔什维克主义或是有毒气体之类，还假称这些都是胡说八道。 That cock wouldn’t fight—spend money, and arrange things which would have arranged themselves, but as for anything important, such as abolishing Bolshevism, or poison gas, they never would, and to pretend it was all-me-eye-and-Betty-Martin.
对于一个向来沉默寡言的人来说，说这么多话简直就是破纪录了。两个年轻人觉得这些话很有用，迫切希望他继续说下去，这样他们就能想别的事情了。 It was almost a record for one habitually taciturn, and deeply useful to two young people only anxious that he should continue to talk, so that they might think of other things.
小叮铃的举动是他们谈到的唯一的一个其他话题。 The conduct of Ting-a-ling was the sole other subject of consideration.
弗勒觉得那是红棕色地板造成的。 Fleur thought it due to the copper floor.
索姆斯认为它一定是在广场上捡什么东西吃了——狗总是喜欢捡东西吃的。 Soames that he must have picked up something in the Square—dogs were always picking things up.
迈克尔认为这只是它在发中国式的脾气——抗议没有人注意它的自负。 Michael suggested that it was just Chinese—a protest against there being nobody to watch his self-sufficiency.
“没有退路，没有退路；没有退路的人必须获胜，否则就是死路一条！” “No retreat, no retreat; they must conquer or die who have no retreat!”
弗勒离开以后，他们两个人都感觉无法在同一晚上和对方单独相处第二次，因此索姆斯说：“我还有几笔账要算——我回自己房间去了。” When Fleur left them, both felt that they could not so soon again bear each other’s company, and Soames said: “I’ve got some figures to attend to—I’ll go to my room.”
迈克尔站了起来。 Michael stood up.
“您不喜欢在我的书斋里算吗，先生？” “Wouldn’t you like my den, sir?”
“不了，”索姆斯说，“我必须集中精神才行。 “No,” said Soames, “I must concentrate.
替我向弗勒说晚安。” Say goodnight to Fleur for me.”
迈克尔还在抽烟，低头看着那几只瓷制的西班牙水果。 Michael remained smoking above the porcelain effigies of Spanish fruits.
那只白猿是无法吃掉这些瓷水果，然后扔掉果皮的！ That white monkey couldn’t eat those and throw away the rinds!
他自己人生的果实将来也会像这些瓷水果一样吗？ Would the fruits of his life be porcelain in future?
和弗勒住在同一个屋檐下，却不再亲密？ Live in the same house with Fleur, estranged?
像现在这样和弗勒生活在一起，感觉自己像个陌生人一样，还是个不受欢迎的陌生人？ Live with Fleur as now, feeling a stranger, even an unwelcome stranger?
离开这里，参加空军去，或是成为“拯救儿童”组织的一员？ Clear out, and join the Air Force, or the ‘Save the Children’ corps?
这三条路选哪一条才能最不后悔？ Which of the three courses was least to be deplored?
他那支雪茄的烟灰慢慢地变长了，不受控制地落了下来，随即又长出了新的烟灰。那些瓷水果光鲜亮丽，仿佛在嘲笑他。科克探了一下头，又缩了回去。 The ash of his cigar grew long, dropped incontinent, and grew again; the porcelain fruits mocked him with their sheen and glow; Coaker put his head in and took it away again.
（主人生气了——好样的，主人！）决定已经做好，就等着告诉他了，某个时间，某个地方——那是弗勒的决定，不是他的。 (The Governor had got the hump—good sort, the Governor!) Decision waited for him, somewhere, somewhen—Fleur’s, not his own.
他心里装了太多的痛苦，太乱了，已经没办法想明白了。但是她明白她自己的心。 His mind was too miserable and disconcerted to be known; but she would know hers.
她所知道的情况足以让她自己下决定，怎么处理威尔弗里德和那个堂兄弟，还有她自己的行动和感情。 She had the information which alone made decision possible about Wilfrid, that cousin, her own actions and feelings.
是的，决定会做出来的。然而在这个世界里，同情是无用的，只有中国哲学能派上点儿用场，这个决定又能有多重要呢？ Yes, decision would come, and would it matter in a world where pity was punk and only a Chinese philosophy of any use?
但是，不要在客厅里吐，即使人们都看不到你的重要性，在苦难面前也要坚持不懈！…… But not be sick in the drawing-room, try and keep one’s end up, even if there were no one to see one being important!...
他的卧室兼更衣室里已经基本上一团漆黑，他已经睡着了。 He had been asleep and it was dark, or all but, in his bed-dressing-room.
床边有些白色的东西。 Something white by his bed.
一阵芳香袭来，伴着暖意向他靠过来。他听到一个低低的声音：“是我。 A fragrant faint warmth close to him; a voice saying low: “It’s only me.
让我到你床上去，迈克尔。” Let me come in your bed, Michael.
像个孩子——像个孩子似的！ “Like a child—like a child!
迈克尔伸出他的双臂。 Michael reached out his arms.
雪白和温暖钻进那两臂之间。 The whiteness and the warmth came into them.
他的嘴巴被卷发遮住了，耳边传来她的声音：“如果有——如果有什么的话，我就不会来了，对吗？” Curls smothered his mouth, the voice said in his ear: “I wouldn’t have come, would I, if there’d—if there’d been anything?”
迈克尔的心和她的心贴在一起，疯狂而又迷茫地跳动着。 Michael’s heart, wild, confused, beat against hers.
第七章 Chapter VII
裸体画 The Altogether
那天下午天气很好，托尼·比克特吃饱喝足之后，心情愉快。他的气球卖得很好，于是他怀着胜利的心情动身回家了。 Tony Bicket, replete, was in vein that fine afternoon; his balloons left him freely, and he started for home in the mood of a conqueror.
维多琳的双颊也有了血色。 Victorine, too, had colour in her cheeks.
她听他讲完下午的故事后，也把她的故事讲给他听。 She requited the story of his afternoon with the story of hers.
不过刚才听的是真故事，现在讲的是假故事——她没有提丹比&温特出版社，或是那个笑容圆滑的先生，也没有提柑曼怡酒或者“裸体画”。 A false tale for a true—no word of Danby and Winter, the gentleman with the sliding smile, of the Grand Marnier, or ‘the altogether.’
她并没有良心不安。 She had no compunction.
这是她的秘密，她的惊人之举。如果坐在那里当模特让人作画——或是“裸体画”，这件事她还没拿定主意——能够让她赚到他们的路费的话，那她会告诉他这是她赌马赢来的钱。 It was her secret, her surprise; if, by sitting in or out of ‘the altogether,’ not yet decided, she could make their passage money—well, she should tell him she had won it on a horse.
那天晚上她问道： That night she asked:
“托尼，我是太瘦了吗？”她不止一次提起这件事了， “Am I so very thin, Tony?” more than once.
“我真希望能胖起来。” “I do so want to get fat.”
比克特还在为她没能分享到那顿午餐而难过。他一边轻轻地拍着她，一边说他很快就会让她胖得像发面馒头一样——但是他没有说明怎么做到这一点。 Bicket, still troubled that she had not shared that lunch, patted her tenderly, and said he would soon have her as fat as butter—he did not explain how.
他们一起梦见了蓝色的蝴蝶，醒来后看到的却是煤气灯的冷光以及一顿可可和黄油面包的早餐。 They dreamed together of blue butterflies, and awoke to chilly gaslight and a breakfast of cocoa and bread-and-butter.
Fog!
比克特走出家门还不到十米，就在维多琳的眼前被大雾吞没了。 Bicket was swallowed up before the eyes of Victorine ten yards from the door.
她回到卧室，感到愤愤不平。 She returned to the bedroom with anger in her heart.
谁会在雾天来买气球呢？ Who would buy balloons in a fog?
她什么都愿意干，只要能够不让比克特在这种令人窒息的天气里一直站在外面！ She would do anything rather than let Tony go on standing out there all the choking days!
她又把衣服脱掉了，把浑身上下洗了个干净，万一——！ Undressing again, she washed herself intensively, in case—!
刚洗完不久，房东太太就告诉她，来了一个送信的。 She had not long finished when her landlady announced the presence of a messenger boy.
他带来了一个大大的包裹，上面写着“比克特先生收”。 He bore an enormous parcel entitled “Mr. Bicket.”
里面有张便条。 There was a note inside.
她读道： She read:
“亲爱的比克特，——这里有几件衣服。 “DEAR BICKET,—Here are the togs.
希望你用得上。——迈克尔·蒙特敬礼。” Hope they’ll be useful.—Yours, MICHAEL MONT.”
她用颤抖的声音对送信人说： In a voice that trembled she said to the boy:
“谢谢，这样就行了。这是给你的两便士。” “Thank you, it’s O. K. Here’s twopence.”
等到送信人响亮的口哨声从雾中隐隐传来的时候，她已经欣喜若狂地扑到那堆“衣服”面前了。 When his rich whistle was heard writhing into the fog, she flung herself down before the ‘togs’ in ecstasy.
男女衣服是用薄纸隔开的。 The sexes were divided by tissue paper.
一件蓝色套装、一顶绒帽、几双棕色的鞋子、三双有两个洞的袜子、四件袖口有点儿磨损的衬衣、两条黑白相间的领带、六件不太新的硬领、几块手绢、两件漂亮的厚背心、两条裤子，还有一件棕色带腰带的大衣，上面只有两三个不难看的小污迹。 A blue suit, a velour hat, some brown shoes, three pairs of socks with two holes in them, four shirts only a little frayed at the cuffs, two black-and-white ties, six collars, not too new, some handkerchiefs, two vests beautifully thick, two pairs of pants, and a brown overcoat with a belt and just two or three nice little stains.
她拿起那套蓝色的衣服，在自己的胳膊和腿上比试着，裤腿和袖口只需要收进去两英寸左右就行了。 She held the blue suit up against her arms and legs, the trousers and sleeves would only need taking-in about two inches.
她把它们叠好，堆得像个金字塔似的，然后怯生生地去翻看薄纸下面的衣服。 She piled them in a pyramid, and turned with awe to the spoil beneath the tissue paper.
一件咖啡色的针织衫，钉着透明的黄色小扣子——既不脏也不皱。 A brown knitted frock with little clear yellow buttons—unsoiled, uncreased.
怎么会有人把这么好的一件衣服送人呢！ How could anybody spare a thing like that!
一顶棕色天鹅绒无檐小帽，上面装饰着金褐色的羽毛。 A brown velvet toque with a little tuft of goldeny-brown feathers.
她把它戴上了。 She put it on.
一件颜色稍稍褪掉一点点的粉红色紧身衣，龙骨在腰以上只有三英寸宽，腰以下五英寸宽，有粉红色的丝带，还有吊袜带——正是她梦寐以求的东西。 A pair of pink stays ever so little faded, with only three inches of bone above the waist, and five inches of bone below, pink silk ribbons, and suspenders—a perfect dream.
她忍不住把它们也穿上了。 She could not resist putting them on also.
两双棕色的长筒袜、棕色的鞋子、两件连裤内衣、一件针织短袖衬衣。 Two pairs of brown stockings; brown shoes; two combinations, a knitted camisole.
一件袖子上有一个洞的白色丝质套头衫、一条已经洗过几次的淡紫色亚麻短裙、一条淡粉色的绸裤；在它们下面是一件深棕色的大衣，又长又暖又舒服，钉着黑色大理石般的大纽扣，口袋里还有六条小手绢。 A white silk jumper with a hole in one sleeve, a skirt of lilac linen that had gone a little in the wash; a pair of pallid pink silk pants; and underneath them all an almost black-brown coat, long and warm and cosy, with great jet buttons, and in the pocket six small handkerchiefs.
她深深地吸了一口上面的香气——天竺葵！ She took a deep breath of sweetness—geranium!
她的思绪远远地跳跃开来。 Her mind leaped forward.
有了衣服，有了行头，有了装备——蓝色的蝴蝶——太阳！ Clothed, trousseaued, fitted out—blue butterflies—the sun!
现在就只差买船票的钱了。 Only the money for the tickets wanting.
突然间，她看见自己赤身裸体地站在那个先生面前，任由他用眼睛上下打量。 And suddenly she saw herself with nothing on standing before the gentleman with sliding eyes.
谁在乎这些！ Who cared!
给钱就行！ The money!
在上午剩下的时间里，她亢奋地忙碌着，给托尼把衣服改短了，把袜子上的洞补好了，把磨损的袖口翻转了过来。 For the rest of the morning she worked feverishly, shortening Tony, mending the holes in his socks, turning the fray of his cuffs.
她吃了一块饼干，又喝了一杯可可——这会让人发胖的，然后继续缝补那件白色的丝质套头衫。 She ate a biscuit, drank another cup of cocoa—it was fattening, and went for the hole in the white silk jumper.
1点钟了。 One o’clock.
她慌慌张张地把衣服再次脱了，穿上一件新的连裤内衣、长筒袜，还有那件紧身衣，然后呆呆地停了下来。 In panic she stripped once more, put on a new combination, pair of stockings, and the stays, then paused in superstition.
不！ No!
该穿她自己的衣服，戴自己的帽子——和昨天一样！ Her own dress and hat—like yesterday!
把其他的衣服都留到——！ Keep the rest until—!
她匆匆忙忙去赶公共汽车，觉得忽冷忽热的。 She hastened to her ‘bus, overcome alternately by heat and cold.
也许他会再给她来一杯那种可口的甜酒。 Perhaps he would give her another glass of that lovely stuff.
要是她能够晕晕乎乎的，什么都不在乎就好了！ If only she could go swimmy and not care for anything!
两点整的时候，她到了画室门口，敲了敲门。 She reached the studio as two o’clock was striking, and knocked.
这里既温馨又暖和，比昨天暖和多了。她突然明白这么安排的重要意义了。 It was lovely and warm in there, much warmer than yesterday, and the significance of this struck her suddenly.
因为她看到在壁炉前有一位夫人，还带着一只小狗。 In front of the fire was a lady with a little dog.
“柯林斯小姐——这位是迈克尔·蒙特夫人，她把她的哈巴狗借给我们了，柯林斯小姐。” “Miss Collins—Mrs. Michael Mont; she’s lending us her Peke, Miss Collins.”
那位夫人——和她年纪相仿，非常漂亮——伸出她的手来。 The lady—only her own age, and ever so pretty—held out her hand.
天竺葵！ Geranium!
那么，就是她把自己的衣服——！ This, then, was she whose clothes—!
她握住了那只手，却说不出话来。 She took the hand, but could not speak.
如果这位夫人呆在这里，她绝对不可能脱掉衣服的。 If this lady were going to stay, it would be utterly impossible.
在她面前——这么漂亮的人，穿着这么好看的衣服——不！她做不到！ Before her—so pretty, so beautifully covered—oh! no!
“好了，叮铃，要乖乖的，要讨人喜欢哦。 “Now, Ting, be good, and as amusing as you can.
再见，奥布里！ Goodbye, Aubrey!
希望这幅画能成功！ Good luck to the picture!
再见，柯林斯小姐，这幅画一定会很棒的。” Good-bye, Miss Collins; it ought to be wonderful.”
走了！ Gone!
天竺葵的味道渐渐淡去了，那只小狗在门口嗅来嗅去的。 The scent of geranium fading; the little dog snuffling at the door.
那位眼睛转得溜溜的先生手里拿了两杯酒。 The sliding gentleman had two glasses in his hands.
“啊！”维多琳心里喊道，然后她把那杯酒一饮而尽。 ‘Ah!’ thought Victorine, and drank hers at a gulp.
“现在，柯林斯小姐，您不介意了吧，是吗？ “Now, Miss Collins, you don’t mind, do you!
您在那儿能找到你需要的一切东西。 You’ll find everything in there.
其实这都不重要。 It’s really nothing.
我希望您能趴在这里，手肘撑在地上，头抬起来稍微偏向这个方向；尽量披散着头发，眼睛看着这根骨头。 I shall want you lying on your face just here with your elbows on the ground and your head up and a little turned this way; your hair as loose as it can be, and your eyes looking at this bone.
您要把它想象成潘神或是诸如此类的其他形象。 You must imagine that it’s a faun or some other bit of all right.
这只小狗等会儿开始啃骨头之后，会对您有所帮助的。 The dog’ll help you when he settles down to it.
想象成潘神，明白吗，可不是鹿神哦。” F-a-u-n, you know, not f-a-w-n.”
“明白。”维多琳无力地说。 “Yes,” said Victorine faintly.
“还要再喝点儿酒吗？” “Have another little tot?”
“好的！再来点儿吧。” “Oh! please.”
他把酒拿过来了。 He brought it.
“我很了解您现在的想法，但是您明白的，其实，这种想法很可笑。 “I quite understand; but you know, really, it’s absurd.
您在医生面前是不会介意的。 You wouldn’t mind with a doctor.
这就对了。 That’s right.
看这里，我把这个铃铛放在地上。 Look here, I’ll put this little cow-bell on the ground.
当您摆好姿势之后，摇摇铃铛，我就会走出来。 When you’re in position, give it a tinkle, and I’ll come out.
这将会对您有所帮助的。” That’ll help you.”
维多琳喃喃地说： Victorine murmured:
“您真好。” “You ARE kind.”
“没什么——是我该做的。 “Not at all—it’s natural.
现在可以开始了吗？ Now will you start in?
不会一直都有阳光的。 The light won’t last for ever.
我们说好的，一天15个先令。” Fifteen bob a day, we said.”
维多琳看着他悄悄走到屏障后面去，然后她又看了看那个小铃铛。 Victorine saw him slide away behind a screen, and looked at the little cow-bell.
15个先令！ Fifteen bob!
再来15个先令！ And fifteen bob!
再来15个先令！ And fifteen bob!
许多、许多15个先令，然后——！ Many, many fifteen bobs before—!
但是她坐着的次数不会比托尼站着的次数多的。他就是那样两只脚换着站在那里卖气球。 But not more times of sitting than of Tony’s standing from foot to foot, offering balloons.
这样想着，她高兴起来了。她机械地离开了那个台子，走进模特的房间里去了。 And as if wound up by that thought, she moved like clockwork off the dais, into the model’s room.
那里面也很舒服、温暖，椅子上扔着一件绿色丝绸长袍。 Cosy in there, too; warm, a green silk garment thrown on a chair.
她把自己的衣服脱了。 She took off her dress.
她又为那件漂亮的粉色紧身衣着迷了。 The beauty of the pink stays struck her afresh.
也许这位先生会喜欢呢——不，那样会更糟糕的——！ Perhaps the gentleman would like—no, that would be even worse—!
她听见一阵响声——是小叮铃在抱怨又没人理他了。 A noise reached her—from Ting-a-ling complaining of solitude.
要是她拖拖拉拉地，那她就不会——！ If she delayed, she never would—!
她赶紧把衣服脱了，站在那里看着镜中的自己。 Stripping hastily, she stood looking at herself in a glass.
要是能让镜中这个苗条的、肤色雪白的人走到台子上去，而自己能留在这里，就好了！ If only that slim, ivory-white image could move out on to the dais and she could stay here!
啊！ Oh!
这太可怕了——太可怕了！ It was awful—awful!
她不能——不！她不能。 She couldn’t—no! she couldn’t.
她再次抓住自己最后的一件衣服。 She caught up her final garment again.
15先令！ Fifteen bob!
那可是15先令啊！ But fifteen bob!
她的眼前出现了一个荒凉而又令人心伤的幻象：在一个巨大的穹顶下，渺小的托尼拿着一个个小小的气球！ Before her eyes, wild and mournful, came a vision: Of a huge dome, and a tiny Tony, with little, little balloons in a hand held out!
一些又冷又硬的东西在她的心里凝结，就像是冬天窗户上形成的冰柱。 Something cold and steely formed over her heart as icicles form on a window.
如果他们只肯为他做这些，那么她会为他做得更好！ If that was all they would do for him, she would do better!
她松开了那件衣服，然后混乱而又麻木地“裸体”走了出去。 She dropped the garment; and, confused, numb, stepped forth in the ‘altogether.’
小叮铃从那根骨头上抬起头来，朝她叫着。 Ting-a-ling growled at her above his bone.
她拿起那个铃铛，趴在那里，就像刚才他告诉她的那样，双脚朝上，交叉着。 She reached the cow-bell and lay down on her face as she had been told, with feet in the air, crossed.
她用一只手托着下巴，摇了摇铃铛。 Resting her chin on one hand, she wagged the bell.
它发出来的声音，和她听过的铃铛声音都不一样，那只小狗也叫起来——它看上去确实很好笑！ It made a sound like no bell she had ever heard; and the little dog barked—he did look funny!
“太好了，柯林斯小姐！ “Perfect, Miss Collins!
就这样别动！” Hold that!”
15个先令！再来15个先令！ Fifteen bob! and fifteen bob!
“左边的脚趾再往上翘起来点儿。 “Just point those left toes a bit more.
就是这样！ That’s right!
皮肤的色调美极了！ The flesh tone’s perfect!
上帝啊，为什么一定要先会走才能跑啊！ My God, why must one walk before one runs!
素描是一件令人讨厌的事，柯林斯小姐，人应该只用画笔来画画，而雕塑家是用凿子作画的，至少在他是个米开朗基罗的时候。 Drawing’s a bore, Miss Collins; one ought to draw with a brush only; a sculptor draws with a chisel, at least when he’s a Michelangelo.
您今年多大了？” How old are you?”
“21了。”维多琳嘴里发出的声音在她自己听来好像来自遥远的地方。 “Twenty-one,” came from lips that seemed to Victorine quite far away.
“我32了。 “I’m thirty-two.
据说我们这代人生下来就很老练，因此也就不会再老了。 They say our generation was born so old that it can never get any older.
没有幻想。 Without illusions.
唉！ Well!
从我记事起，我就没什么信仰。 I never had any beliefs that I can remember.
您有吗？” Had you?”
维多琳迷迷糊糊的，理智和意识都不知所踪了。不过这也没关系，他还在喋喋不休： Victorine’s wits and senses were astray, but it did not matter, for he was rattling on:
“我们连自己的祖先都不相信。 “We don’t even believe in our ancestors.
尽管如此，我们又开始效仿他们了。 All the same, we’re beginning to copy them again.
您知不知道一本叫《啜泣的海龟》的书？它可是轰动一时的——完全斯特恩式的，写得很好，纯粹斯特恩式的写法，假情假意的。 D’you know a book called ‘The Sobbing Turtle’ that’s made such a fuss?—sheer Sterne, very well done; but sheer Sterne, and the author’s tongue in his cheek.
简单地说，就那么回事。柯林斯小姐——要是我们都毫无诚意——那可不是个好兆头。 That’s it in a nutshell, Miss Collins—our tongues are in our cheeks—bad sign.
不要紧，我要用这幅画来打败皮尔洛·科西莫。 Never mind; I’m going to out-Piero Cosimo with this.
头往上抬一英寸，还有请把您眼前那绺头发拨开。 Your head an inch higher, and that curl out of your eye, please.
谢谢！ Thanks!
就这样别动！ Hold that!
顺便问一句，您是不是有意大利血统？ By the way, have you Italian blood?
比如说，您母亲姓什么？” What was your mother’s name, for instance?”
“布朗。” “Brown.”
“啊！ “Ah!
姓布朗的人就很难说是哪儿的了。 You can never tell with Browns.
这个姓也许本来是布龙——或者是布鲁诺——很可能是伊比利亚人。 It may have been Brune—or Bruno—but very likely she was Iberian.
很可能在撒克逊入侵后所有活下来的英国人都叫布朗。 Probably all the inhabitants of Britain left alive by the Saxons were called Brown.
但是，事实上，那都是胡说八道。 As a fact, that’s all tosh, though.
从忏悔者爱德华起到现在，柯林斯小姐——不过才30代——我们每个人就有10亿多个祖先，而当时这个岛上总共还不到100万人呢。 Going back to Edward the Confessor, Miss Collins—a mere thirty generations—we each of us have one thousand and seventy-four million, five hundred and seventy-three thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four ancestors, and the population of this island was then well under a million.
就像赛马一样，我们都是近亲繁殖的，但是长得不怎么好看，是不是？ We’re as inbred as racehorses, but not so nice to look at, are we?
我敢说，柯林斯小姐，您长得这么漂亮真该感谢上帝。 I assure you, Miss Collins, you’re something to be grateful for.
蒙特夫人也一样。 So is Mrs. Mont.
她漂亮吧？ Isn’t she pretty?
看看她那只狗？” Look at that dog?”
没错，小叮铃伸直了前腿，皱着鼻子，正在看着她，好像觉得她也是一根骨头。 Ting-a-ling, indeed, with forelegs braced, and wrinkled nose, was glaring, as if under the impression that Victorine was another bone.
“它很滑稽。”她说，感觉声音再一次从远方传来。 “He’s funny,” she said, and again her voice sounded far away.
如果他向蒙特夫人提出请求，她会趴在这里吗？ Would Mrs. Mont lie here if he’d asked her?
如果是她的话，一定很好看！ SHE would look pretty!
但是她不需要这15先令！ But SHE didn’t need the fifteen bob!
“这个姿势舒服吗？” “Comfortable in that position?”
她吓了一跳，小声说： In alarm, she murmured:
“哦！舒服，谢谢您！” “Oh! yes, thank you!”
“够暖和吗？” “Warm enough?”
“哦！暖和，谢谢您！” “Oh! yes, thank you!”
“那就好。 “That’s good.
您把头再抬高一点儿。” Just a little higher with the head.”
维多琳那种极其不自在的感觉慢慢地消失了。 Slowly in Victorine the sense of the dreadfully unusual faded.
托尼不会知道这件事的。 Tony should never know.
只要他不知道，他就不会介意。 If he never knew, he couldn’t care.
她可以一整天都这样趴着——15先令，再来15先令！ She could lie like this all day—fifteen bob, and fifteen bob!
很容易办到的。 It was easy.
她看着那细长的手指迅速地移动着，看着香烟所散发出的青烟。 She watched the quick, slim fingers moving, the blue smoke from the cigarette.
她看着那只小狗。 She watched the little dog.
“想休息一下吗？ “Like a rest?
您忘记带外袍了，我去拿给您。” You left your gown; I’ll get it for you.”
她穿上那件有漂亮垫肩的绿色外袍，坐了起来，把脚从平台边缘伸出来放在地板上。 In that green silk gown, beautifully padded, she sat up, with her feet on the floor over the dais edge.
“抽烟吗？ “Cigarette?
我去煮些土耳其咖啡。 I’m going to make some Turkish coffee.
您最好走动走动。” You’d better walk about.”
维多琳照他说的做了。 Victorine obeyed.
“您就像是从梦里走出来的，柯林斯小姐。 “You’re out of a dream, Miss Collins.
我将来一定把您穿这件衣服的样子画成一幅马修·马里斯式的作品。” I shall have to do a Mathew Maris of you in that gown.”
这种咖啡和她以前喝的咖啡都不一样，给她一种幸福的感觉。 The coffee, like none she had ever tasted, gave her a sense of well-being.
她说： She said:
“它不像咖啡。” “It’s not like coffee.”
奥布里·格林摊开双手。 Aubrey Greene threw up his hands.
“您说对了。 “You have said it.
英国人是很了不起的——从来没有什么能骗得了他们。 The British are a great race—nothing will ever do them in.
如果有什么能毁灭他们的话，那么他们一定早就毁在自己的咖啡里了。 If they could be destroyed, they must long ago have perished of their coffee.
要不要再来点儿？” Have some more?”
“好的。”维多琳说。 “Please,” said Victorine.
杯子里只有一点点了。 There was such a little in the cup.
“准备好了吗，又要开始了？” “Ready, again?”
她躺下了，那件长袍顺势落了下来。 She lay down, and let the gown drop off.
“对，就是这样！ “That’s right!
别动——您躺在长长的绿草丛中，这件绿衣服帮了我的大忙。 Leave it there—you’re lying in long grass, and the green helps me.
可惜这是冬天，要不然我一定去树林中租一块空地。” Pity it’s winter; I’d have hired a glade.”
躺在长长的绿草丛中——也许还有鲜花。 Lying in long grass—flowers, too, perhaps.
她喜欢花。 She did love flowers.
在她小的时候，在诺比顿的外婆家屋后的田野里，她常常躺在草丛里，拿雏菊编花环。 As a little girl she used to lie in the grass, and make daisy-chains, in the field at the back of her grandmother’s lodge at Norbiton.
外婆守着那房子。 Her grandmother kept the lodge.
每年她都要去那里住两周——她非常喜欢乡下。 Every year, for a fortnight, she had gone down there—she had liked the country ever so.
只是那时她身上都是穿着衣服的。 Only she had always had something on.
要是什么都不穿就更美了。 It would be nicer with nothing.
澳大利亚中部有花吗？ Were there flowers in Central Australia?
既然那里有蓝色的蝴蝶，就一定有花！ With butterflies there must be!
沐浴在阳光下——她和托尼——就像在伊甸园一样！…… In the sun—she and Tony—like the Garden of Eden!...
“谢谢。今天就到这里吧。 “Thank you, that’s all for today.
半天——十先令。 Half a day—ten bob.
明天早晨11点钟。 To-morrow morning at eleven.
您是一个顶级的写生模特，柯林斯小姐。” You’re a first-rate sitter, Miss Collins.”
维多琳穿上那件粉红色的紧身衣，心里高兴极了。 Putting on the pink stays, Victorine had a feeling of elation.
她做到了！ She had done it!
托尼绝不会知道！ Tony should never know!
一想到他绝不会知道，她就觉得很开心。 The thought that he never would gave her pleasure.
她再次摆脱了“裸体”的状态，走了出来。 And once more divested of the ‘altogether,’ she came forth.
奥布里·格林站在他的作品前。 Aubrey Greene was standing before his handiwork.
“还没完成，柯林斯小姐，”他说，“我不想打击您。 “Not yet, Miss Collins,” he said; “I don’t want to depress you.
髋骨太高了。 That hip-bone’s too high.
明天会把它修正过来的。 We’ll put it right tomorrow.
原谅我不能和您握手了，我满手都是粉笔末。 Forgive my hand, it’s all chalk.
再见！ Au revoir!
11点钟哦。 Eleven o’clock.
到时我们就不需要这个小家伙了。 And we shan’t need this chap.
别，你别走啊！” No, you don’t!”
原来小叮铃正表现出想和这根大骨头一起走的样子。 For Ting-a-ling was showing signs of accompanying the larger bone.
维多琳笑着离开了。 Victorine passed out smiling.
第八章 Chapter VIII
索姆斯着手处理此事 Soames Takes the Matter up
索姆斯坐在卧室的壁炉前，全神贯注地思考着，直到大本钟敲了12下。 Soames had concentrated, sitting before the fire in his bedroom till Big Ben struck twelve.
他的思绪始终围绕着是否要把这件事和“老蒙特”好好谈一谈。 His reflections sum-totalled in a decision to talk it over with ‘old Mont’ after all.
这个人虽然头脑简单，但却是一个通情达理的人，而且这件事又很棘手。 Though light-brained, the fellow was a gentleman, and the matter delicate.
他上床去睡觉，但到了两点半就醒了。 He got into bed and slept, but awoke at half-past two.
就是这件事！ There it was!
“我不要想它了。”他想，但是马上又开始想了。 ‘I WON’T think of it,’ he thought; and instantly began to.
在与金钱打交道的漫长一生中，他还从未有过这种经历。 In a long life of dealings with money, he had never had such an experience.
绝对诚实地遵守法律——法律本身常常又不是绝对诚实的——是他职业生涯的必备条件。 Perfectly straightforward conformity with the law—itself so often far from perfectly straightforward—had been the sine qua non of his career.
有人说，诚实才是上策。 Honesty, they said, was the best policy.
但是，还有别的上策吗？ But was it anything else?
一个普通的诚实人要使自己一个星期不进合法的教养院是不可能的。 A normally honest man couldn’t keep out of a perfect penitentiary for a week.
但是一个合法的教养院与监狱或破产法庭没有任何关系。 But then a perfect penitentiary had no relation to prison, or the Bankruptcy Court.
遵循诚实就是要远离那两个机构。 The business of working honesty was to keep out of those two institutions.
到目前为止，他还没遇到过什么困难。 And so far he had never had any difficulty.
除了领取酬劳和喝茶之外，董事的职责是什么？ What, besides the drawing of fees and the drinking of tea, were the duties of a director?
这就是问题所在。 That was the point.
如果他没有尽到职责，他要负多大的责任呢？ And how far, if he failed in them, was he liable?
董事的职责就是要绝对诚实。 It was a director’s duty to be perfectly straightforward.
但是如果一个董事真的绝对诚实，他就做不成董事了。 But if a director were perfectly straightforward, he couldn’t be a director.
这是显而易见的。 That was clear.
首先，他将不得不告诉股东们，他没有做任何应该得到酬劳的事情。 In the first place, he would have to tell his shareholders that he didn’t anything like earn his fees.
那么他在董事会里都做了些什么呢？ For what did he do on his Boards?
哦，他就坐着，签签名，发发言，以及通过那些由于业务的总趋势所决定的必须通过的事情。 Well, he sat and signed his name and talked a little, and passed that which the general trend of business decided must be passed.
他提过什么倡议吗？ Did he initiate?
极其罕见。 Once in a blue moon.
他进行过核算吗？ Did he calculate?
没有，他只看核算的结果。 No, he read calculations.
他检查过支出和收入吗？ Did he check payments out and in?
没有，那是审计人员做的。 No, the auditors did that.
还有方针政策！ There was policy!
这是个令人感到安慰的词，但是——绝对诚实地讲——董事的主要职责就是不要干涉现行的方针政策。 A comforting word, but—to be perfectly straightforward—a director’s chief business was to let the existing policy alone.
就以他自己为例吧！ Take his own case!
如果他履行了自己的职责，那么他就会停止这项国外保险业务，他在一听到这项业务时就本能地产生了怀疑——那时也就刚入董事会还不到一个月，或者，如果停止不了这项业务，他就辞职。 If he had done his duty, he would have stopped this foreign insurance business which he had instinctively distrusted the moment he heard of it—within a month of sitting on the Board, or, having failed in doing so, resigned his seat.
但是他没有这么做。 But he had not.
情况一直在好转啦！ Things had been looking better!
时机还不成熟，等等！ It was not the moment, and so forth!
如果他真的像一个绝对诚实的董事那样履行自己的职责，那他就绝不会成为天佑再保险公司的董事，因为在接受董事会的这个职务之前，他会更加仔细地调查这家公司的方针政策。 If he had done his duty as a perfectly straightforward director, indeed, he would never have become a director of the P. P. R. S., because he would have looked into the policy of the Society much more closely than he had before accepting a position on the Board.
但是为了名声、威望以及不能对收到的礼物吹毛求疵——事情就变成了这个样子！ But what with the names, and the prestige, and not looking a gift horse too closely in the mouth—there it had been!
要做到绝对诚实，他现在就应该挨个通知股东们，说：“我的放任政策已经使你们损失了二十多万英镑。 To be perfectly straightforward, he ought now to be circularising the shareholders, saying: “My laissez-faire has cost you two hundred odd thousand pounds.
为了你们的利益，我已经将这笔钱放在了受托人那里，同时我正在起诉其他的董事，要求他们赔偿这笔款项中他们应负责的份额。” I have lodged this amount in the hands of trustees for your benefit, and am suing the rest of the directors for their quotas of the amount.”
但是他不打算这么做，因为——呃——没有人这么做过，而且其他的董事不会喜欢这种做法。 But he was not proposing to do so, because—well—because it wasn’t done, and the other directors wouldn’t like it.
总而言之，你等着股东们发现这一混乱情况，而你又希望他们不会发现。 In sum: You waited till the shareholders found out the mess, and you hoped they wouldn’t.
事实上，就如同政府一样，你把问题搞乱，然后尽力为自己创造最有利的局面。 In fact, just like a Government, you confused the issues, and made the best case you could for yourselves.
索姆斯想到了爱尔兰，不由得心生安慰：上一届政府让全国陷入到爱尔兰的混乱之中，最后因为结束了这种原本绝对不应该发生的情况而广受赞誉！ With a sense of comfort Soames thought of Ireland: The late Government had let the country in for all that mess in Ireland, and at the end taken credit for putting an end to what need never have been!
还有和平、空军、农业以及埃及——他们必须面对的五个最重要的问题——每一个问题他们都是在自找麻烦！ The Peace, too, and the Air Force, and Agriculture, and Egypt—the five most important issues they’d had to deal with—they had put the chestnuts into the fire in every case!
但是他们承认了吗？ But had they confessed to it?
他们才不会呢。 Not they.
没人承认。 One didn’t confess.
有人说：“在那时，政策问题使之势在必行。” One said: “The question of policy made it imperative at the time.”
或者，更好的办法是，什么也不说，光指望英国人的品行。 Or, better still, one said nothing; and trusted to the British character.
索姆斯将下巴放在床单上，感到了暂时的解脱。 With his chin resting on the sheet, Soames felt a momentary relief.
上一届政府才不会出汗到弄湿他们自己的床单呢——他们才不会——对此他确信无疑！ The late Government weren’t sweating into THEIR sheets—not they—he was convinced of it!
他盯着壁炉里即将燃尽的余火，心中思考着现实中的不平等和不公正。 Fixing his eyes on the dying embers in the grate, he reflected on the inequalities and injustices of existence.
看看政界和商界的那些家伙们，他们的一生都在冒险，并因此加官晋爵。 Look at the chaps in politics and business, whose whole lives were passed in skating on thin ice, and getting knighted for it.
他们泰然自若。 They never turned a hair.
再看看他自己，40年来第一次毛线，就痛苦得要命。 And look at himself, for the first time in forty years on thin ice, and suffering confoundedly.
有一种蒙蔽大众的完美的热潮，一种避免行政行为后果的完美的热潮，然而他这个深谙世故、精通法律的人，却对那些热潮一无所知，而且——而且还为此感到高兴。 There was a perfect cult of hoodwinking the public, a perfect cult of avoiding the consequences of administrative acts; and here was he, a man of the world, a man of the law, ignorant of those cults, and—and glad of it.
由于根深蒂固的谨慎和某种自豪感——这种性格也不无优点，索姆斯对于管理英国公众事务的粗鄙的诚实标准避而远之。 From engrained caution and a certain pride, which had in it a touch of the fine, Soames shrank from that coarse-grained standard of honesty which conducted the affairs of the British public.
在任何涉及金钱的问题上，他是且一向是固执己见、不肯让步的。 In anything that touched money he was, he always had been, stiff-necked, stiff-kneed.
钱就是钱，一英镑就是一英镑，要假装钱不是钱，又要保持自尊心，那是不可能的。 Money was money, a pound a pound, and there was no way of pretending it wasn’t and keeping your self-respect.
他从床上起来，喝了点儿水，做了几次深呼吸，又跺了跺脚。 He got up, drank some water, took a number of deep breaths, and stamped his feet.
前几天不知是谁说的，从来没有过什么事情能让他损失五分钟的睡眠。 Who was it said the other day that nothing had ever lost him five minutes’ sleep.
那家伙一定具有像公牛一样的血液循环，或者具有吹牛大王的天赋。 The fellow must have the circulation of an ox, or the gift of Baron Munchausen.
他拿起一本书。 He took up a book.
但是他的脑子翻来覆去地想着他的财产可以变现成多少钱。 But his mind would only turn over and over the realisable value of his resources.
除了他的藏画之外，他断定他的财产不会少于25万英镑，而且只有弗勒一个孩子——她已经多少做了些准备。 Apart from his pictures, he decided that he could not be worth less than two hundred and fifty thousand pounds, and there was only Fleur—and she already provided for more or less.
他的妻子有她自己的安置费，她可以靠这笔钱在法国生活得很好。 His wife had her settlement, and could live on it perfectly well in France.
至于他自己——他有什么在乎的？ As for himself—what did he care?
在他的俱乐部里找一个房间，离弗勒不远——他一样过得很快活，或许会更快活！ A room at his club near Fleur—he would be just as happy, perhaps happier!
于是他突然发现自己已经找到了摆脱烦恼和焦虑的途径。 And suddenly he found that he had reached a way out of his disturbance and anxiety.
他想象着那些牵强附会的事情，面对着自己财产的损失，他终于驱逐了心魔。 By imagining the far-fetched, by facing the loss of his wealth, he had exorcised the demon.
那本《啜泣的乌龟》，他一个字也没有看，从他手中掉了下来。他睡着了…… The book, ‘The Sobbing Turtle,’ of which he had not read one word, dropped from his hand; he slept....
刚一吃过午饭，他就去“轻蔑”俱乐部和“老蒙特”见面。 His meeting with ‘Old Mont’ took place at ‘Snooks’ directly after lunch.
进去的时候，他朝大厅里的行情收录带瞥了一眼，上面记录着马克又一次大跌了。 The tape in the hall, at which he glanced on going in, recorded a further heavy drop in the mark.
正如他所想的那样：这东西正在变得一文不值！ Just as he thought: The thing was getting valueless!
准男爵坐在那里，小口地抿着咖啡，神情活泼地看着索姆斯，那样子简直让人反感。 Sitting there, sipping coffee, the baronet looked to Soames almost offensively spry.
他肯定什么都不知道呢！ Two to one he had realised nothing!
“嗯！”索姆斯想，“就像乔里恩叔叔过去常说的那样，我要吓一吓他那脆弱的神经！” ‘Well!’ thought Soames,’ as old Uncle Jolyon used to say, I shall astonish his weak nerves!’
于是他开门见山地开始了。 And without preamble he began.
“你好吗，蒙特？ “How are you, Mont?
马克一文不值了。 This mark’s valueless.
你知道，由于埃尔德森那宝贵的国外方针政策，我们已经使天佑再保险公司损失了大约25万英镑。 You realise we’ve lost the P. P. R. S. about a quarter of a million by that precious foreign policy of Elderson’s.
我不敢肯定人们不会因为我们冒了不合理的风险而起诉我们。 I’m not sure an action won’t lie against us for taking unjustifiable risk.
我来这里见你就是为了这件事。” But what I’ve come to see you about is this.”
他把和职员巴特菲尔德面谈的情况详细说了一遍，他看着倾听者的眉毛，以这样一句话结尾：“你怎么看？” He retailed the interview with the clerk, Butterfield, watching the eyebrows of his listener, and finished with the words: “What do you say?”
劳伦斯爵士，从脚开始全身都在颤抖，固定好他的单片眼镜。 Sir Lawrence, whose foot was jerking his whole body, fixed his monocle.
“那一定是幻觉，我亲爱的福赛特！ “Hallucination, my dear Forsyte!
我认识埃尔德森一辈子了。 I’ve known Elderson all my life.
我们一起在温切斯特呆过。” We were at Winchester together.”
又来了！ Again!
又来了！ Again!
哦！ Oh!
上帝啊！ Lord!
索姆斯慢慢地说： Soames said slowly:
“仅凭那一点你是判断不出什么的。 “You can’t tell from that.
有一个和我一起在莫尔伯勒呆过的人，带着伙食团的资金和他的上校的老婆跑了，后来在智利做番茄罐头发了财。 A man who was at Marlborough with me ran away with his mess fund and his colonel’s wife, and made a fortune in Chili out of canned tomatoes.
问题在于：如果这个年轻人说的是真的，那我们就落在了一个坏蛋的手中。 The point is this: If the young man’s story’s true, we’re in the hands of a bad hat.
这可不行，蒙特。 It won’t do, Mont.
你可不可以去和他交涉一下，看看他对这件事怎么说？ Will you tackle him, and see what he says to it?
你也不希望那种事情发生在你身上。 You wouldn’t like a story of that sort about yourself.
我们一起去好吗？” Shall we both go?”
“好的，”劳伦斯爵士突然说， “Yes,” said Sir Lawrence, suddenly.
“你说得对。 “You’re right.
我们一起去，福赛特。 We’ll both go, Forsyte.
我不喜欢这种事，但是我们要一起去。 I don’t like it, but we’ll both go.
他应该听一听这件事。” He ought to hear it.”
“现在就去吗？” “Now?”
“现在就去。” “Now.”
他们一本正经地戴上大礼帽，然后出发了。 With solemnity they assumed top hats, and issued.
“我想，福赛特，我们坐出租车去吧。” “I think, Forsyte, we’ll take a taxi.”
“好的。”索姆斯说。 “Yes,” said Soames.
一路上，出租车缓慢地驶过两座狮子，然后朝着堤岸疾驰而去。 The cab ground its way slowly past the lions, then dashed on down to the Embankment.
