现在，这个名字令迈克尔在自豪之余产生不安，是因为老福赛特不停地对他说他不知道——他说不出来——那个年轻人，还有他所说的那个关于埃尔德森的故事是怎么回事，他们没有任何进展…… The uneasy part of the pride inspired in Michael now by the name was due to old Forsyte’s continually saying to him that he didn’t know—he couldn’t tell—there was that young man and his story about Elderson, and they got no further....
“早上好，先生。 “Good morning, sir.
您能抽出五分钟时间吗？” Can you spare me five minutes?”
“进来吧，巴特菲尔德。 “Come in, Butterfield.
《二重唱》遇到麻烦了吗？” Bunkered with ‘Duet’?”
“没有，先生。 “No, sir.
我已经卖出去40部了。 I’ve placed forty already.
是另外一件事。” It’s another matter.”
年轻人看了看关上的门，离迈克尔更近了点儿。 Glancing at the shut door, the young man came closer.
“我正按照名单上的字母顺序在进行工作。 “I’m working my list alphabetically.
昨天的客户是字母E开头的。” Yesterday I was in the E’s.”
他压低了声音， His voice dropped.
“埃尔德森先生。” “Mr. Elderson.”
“哦！”迈克尔说， “Phew!” said Michael.
“你可以把他跳过不理。” “You can give HIM the go-by.”
“实际上，我并没有这么做，先生。” “As a fact, sir, I haven’t.”
“什么！ “What!
你已经和他交过手了吗？” Been over the top?”
“是的，先生。 “Yes, sir.
昨天晚上。” Last night.”
“干得好，巴特菲尔德！ “Good for you, Butterfield!
发生什么事了？” What happened?”
“我没有报上自己的名字，先生——我只是递上了公司的名片。” “I didn’t send my name in, sir—just the firm’s card.”
迈克尔觉得这个年轻人的声音中和面孔上都带有一种人性本有的阴谋。 Michael was conscious of a very human malice in the young man’s voice and face.
“然后呢？” “Well?”
“埃尔德森先生那时正在喝酒，先生。 “Mr. Elderson, sir, was at his wine.
我去之前就已经想好了，所以一开始就装成和他素不相识的样子。 I’d thought it out, and I began as if I’d never seen him before.
让我吃惊的是——他居然听从了我的建议！” What struck me was—he took my cue!”
“他没有把你踢出去？” “Didn’t kick you out?”
“远非如此，先生。 “Far from it, sir.
他还立刻说道：‘在我名下记上两部。’” He said at once: ‘Put my name down for two copies.’”
迈克尔开心地笑道： Michael grinned.
“你们两个都够大胆的。” “You both had a nerve.”
“不，先生。实际情况就是这样。 “No, sir; that’s just it.
埃尔德森先生进退两难。 Mr. Elderson got it between wind and water.
他一点儿也不喜欢这样。” He didn’t like it a little bit.”
“我不明白。”迈克尔说。 “I don’t twig,” said Michael.
“因为我是这个公司的员工，先生。 “My being in this firm’s employ, sir.
他知道您是公司的合伙人，也是福赛特先生的女婿，对吗？” He knows you’re a partner here, and Mr. Forsyte’s son-inlaw, doesn’t he?”
“不错，他知道。” “He does.”
“这样，先生，您看出其中的关联了吧——有两个董事相信我——不相信他！ “Well, sir, you see the connection—two directors believing me—not HIM. That’s why I didn’t miss him out.
正因为如此，我才没有把他从名单中剔除。 I fancied it’d shake him up.
我想这会让他大吃一惊的。 I happened to see his face in the sideboard glass as I went out.
我离开的时候刚好从餐柜的镜子里看到他的脸。 HE’S got the wind up all right.”
迈克尔咬咬自己的食指，有点儿同情埃尔德森，觉得他就像一只后腿被蜘蛛网的第一缕蛛丝缠上的苍蝇一样。 Michael bit his forefinger, conscious of a twinge of sympathy with Elderson, as for a fly with the first strand of cob-web round his hind leg.
“谢谢你，巴特菲尔德。”他说道。 “Thank you, Butterfield,” he said.
那个年轻人走后，他坐在那里，拿把裁纸刀戳着吸墨水纸。 When the young man was gone, he sat stabbing his blotting-paper with a paper-knife.
这是什么古怪的“阶级”感？ What curious ‘class’ sensation was this?
也许只是对猎物的同情心，或是一种对事情终归会真相大白的战栗？ Or was it merely fellow-feeling with the hunted, a tremor at the way things found one out?
因为，无疑，这是确凿的证据。他会把这情况告诉他父亲和“老福赛特”。 For, surely, this was real evidence, and he would have to pass it on to his father, and ‘Old Forsyte.’
埃尔德森的神经肯定崩溃了，不然的话，他会说：“你这无耻的恶棍——给我滚出去！” Elderson’s nerve must have gone phut, or he’d have said: “You impudent young scoundrel—get out of here!”
显然，这才是一个无辜者唯一正确的欢迎词，也是一个罪人唯一可取的问候。 That, clearly, was the only right greeting from an innocent, and the only advisable greeting from a guilty man.
唉！ Well!
人有时候会胆怯的——即使是最有胆量的人也一样。 Nerve did fail sometimes—even the best.
他刚刚改过的校样就是证明： Witness the very proof-sheet he had just corrected:

比克特年轻的妻子，斯托伯特小说的封面女郎，奥布里·格林的模特——！ Bicket’s girl wife, whose face they had used on Storbert’s novel, the model for Aubrey Greene’s—!

蜡黄色的脸颊上泛起了淡淡的红晕，手指抚弄着那双旧手套的指尖，唇齿间显露着不确定，但是眼神却很坚定——真是个不同寻常的姑娘！ A slight flush in those sallow cheeks, fingers concerned with the tips of the worn gloves, lips uncertain; but the eyes steady—really an uncommon girl!

“是的。 “Yes.
但是作品见报了——昨晚我丈夫在报上看到了。当然，他还不知道我的事。” But it’s got into the papers—my husband saw it there last night; and of course, he doesn’t know about me.”
哎呀！ Phew!
为什么要把这个姑娘卷进来呢？ For what had he let this girl in?

那幅画更像我了！ That’s even much more like me!
很可能他会去找格林先生。 He might go on to Mr. Greene.

这可是一个很正派的职业呢。” It can be quite a respectable profession.”
维多琳把双手放在胸口。 Victorine’s hands moved up to her breast.

“‘尊敬的詹姆士·福加特爵士——我们已经充分考虑了您这部非常有趣的——呃——作品。 “‘DEAR SIR JAMES FOGGART,—We have given the utmost consideration to your very interesting—er—production.
我们认为，您就当前英国与世界其他国家关系的现状，发表了观点明确的看法，此见解对于一切——呃——有识之士极具价值。然而，我们觉得并没有足够的——呃——有识之士来使此书得以出版，除非我社赔本出版。 While we are of opinion that the views so well expressed on the present condition of Britain in relation to the rest of the world are of great value to all—er—thinking persons, we do not feel that there are enough—er—thinking persons to make it possible to publish the book, except at a loss.
至于——呃——所谓英国应该在整个帝国范围内调整市场、人口、供需，以寻求解决之道的论点，表述如此坦白，只怕会，激怒所有政党。我们还认为您所提出的将大量儿童移居国外，使其免受英国城市生活污染的计划，也只会惹恼工人阶级。因为他们对于国外的情况一无所知，特别反对让他们的子女到别的国家去。’” The—er—thesis that Britain should now look for salvation through adjustment of markets, population, supply and demand, within the Empire, put with such exceedingly plain speech, will, we are afraid, get the goat of all the political parties; nor do we feel that your plan of emigrating boys and girls in large quantities before they are spoiled by British town life, can do otherwise than irritate a working-class which knows nothing of conditions outside its own country, and is notably averse to giving its children a chance in any other.’”
“我要把这些都写进去吗，蒙特先生？” “Am I to put that, Mr. Mont?”
“是的，不过语气要婉转些。 “Yes; but tone it in a bit.

“好的。 “Yes.
只是，蒙特先生——我之前以为您是个社会主义者。 Only, Mr. Mont—I thought you were a Socialist.
这个看起来就像是——请原谅我这么问？” This almost seems—forgive my asking?”
“佩伦小姐，我最近才意识到自己那社会主义者的标签已经‘掉了'。 “Miss Perren, it’s struck me lately that labels are ‘off.’
在这年头，一切都悬在空中，缥缈不定，一个人能成什么事？ How can a man be anything at a time when everything’s in the air?
看看那些自由党。 Look at the Liberals.
因为自由贸易，他们已经无法全面地认清时局；工党也不行，因为他们要征收资本税；保守党为了贸易保护主义，也是一样。他们全都被种种口号弄得头昏脑胀的！ They can’t see the situation whole because of Free Trade; nor can the Labour Party because of their Capital levy; nor can the Tories because of Protection; they’re all hag-ridden by catchwords!
老詹姆士·福加特爵士的看法完全正确，但是没人去听他的话。 Old Sir James Foggart’s jolly well right, but nobody’s going to listen to him.
如果有人出版了他的书，那就是在浪费纸张。 His book will be waste paper if anybody ever publishes it.
现在，全世界都不真实了，佩伦小姐，而我们国家是所有国家中最不切实际的一个。” The world’s unreal just now, Miss Perren; and of all countries we’re the most unreal.”
“为什么，蒙特先生？” “Why, Mr. Mont?”
“为什么？ “Why?
还不是因为我们是所有民族中最墨守成规的，至今还坚信那些曾经使我们比任何其他国家都更糟糕的东西。 Because with the most stickfast of all the national temperaments, we’re holding on to what’s gone more bust for us than for any other country.
无论如何，丹比先生既然让我写这封信，就是为了让我开心一些。 Anyway, Mr. Danby shouldn’t have left the letter to me, if he didn’t mean me to enjoy myself.
哦！我们处理这件事的时候——我还得拒绝哈罗德·马斯特的新书。 Oh! and while we’re about it—I’ve got to refuse Harold Master’s new book.
这是个错误，但是他们不肯接受。” It’s a mistake, but they won’t have it.”
“为什么不呢，蒙特先生？ “Why not, Mr. Mont?
《啜泣的海龟》可是一部成功之作啊！” ‘The Sobbing Turtle’ was such a success!”
“唉，在这部新作里，马斯特先生有了新的想法，这使得他非说点儿什么不可。 “Well, in this new thing Master’s got hold of an idea which absolutely forces him to say something.
温特先生说那些热情拥护《啜泣的海龟》的人们，称其为一部了不起的艺术之作，那么他们一定会因此而对新作不满的。而且丹比先生称此书是对人性的践踏。 Winter says those who hailed ‘The Sobbing Turtle’ as such a work of art, are certain to be down on this for that; and Mr. Danby calls the book an outrage on human nature.
因此，我们对此无能为力。 So there’s nothing for it.
来吧，咱们试着这么写： Let’s have a shot:
“‘尊敬的马斯特先生，——在您酣畅地表现您的主题时，您显然没有意识到您已经毁了自己的表演。 “‘MY DEAR MASTER,—In the exhilaration of your subject it has obviously not occurred to you that you’ve bust up the show.
在《啜泣的海龟》一书中，您和乐队中的一半是完全合拍的，而那——呃——是最喧闹的一半。 In ‘The Sobbing Turtle’ you were absolutely in tune with half the orchestra, and that—er—the noisiest half.
您具有迷人的古风，也冷酷得不可动摇。 You were charmingly archaic, and securely cold-blooded.
但是，现在，看看您走到哪儿去了，看看您做了什么？ But now, what have you gone and done?
您把最后一个马克萨斯人选定为主角，还把他放在伦敦城里！ Taken the last Marquesan islander for your hero and put him down in London town!
这部作品是尖锐的讽刺，是对人生实实在在的批判。 The thing’s a searching satire, a real criticism of life.
我确信您并不想成为现代派，也不想在现实中寻根究底，但是您的主题已经远离您的一贯风格了。 I’m sure you didn’t mean to be contemporary, or want to burrow into reality; but your subject has run off with you.
您是知道的，冷嘲热讽和冷酷无情是完全不同的，更不用说您不得不放弃的那种古风了。 Cold acid and cold blood are very different things, you know, to say nothing of your having had to drop the archaic.
当然，我个人认为这部新作远胜于《啜泣的海龟》，那虽然是件精巧的小作品，但是无法让人们激动起来。 Personally, of course, I think this new thing miles better than ‘The Sobbing Turtle,’ which was a nice little affair, but nothing to make a song about.
不过，我既不是大众读者，也不是评论家。 But I’m not the public, and I’m not the critics.
那些年轻而阅历欠缺的人会因这部作品中缺乏现代感而不满，他们会说您是在说教；那些年老而阅历丰富的人会说您尖刻而又消极；而那些普通读者会将您写的马克萨斯人的故事当真，因此怨恨您把这个形象塑造得比他们优秀。 The young and thin will be aggrieved by your lack of modernity, they’ll say you’re moralising; the old and fat will call you bitter and destructive; and the ordinary public will take your Marquesan seriously, and resent your making him superior to themselves.
您看，前途堪忧啊。 The prospects, you see, are not gaudy.
您觉得我们该把这样一本书卖给谁呢？ How d’you think we’re going to ‘get away’ with such a book?
好啦，我们不打算出版了！ Well, we’re not!
这是公司的命令。 Such is the fiat of the firm.
我不同意这么做。 I don’t agree with it.
我真想明天就出版它，但是出版社硬要这么做，我也没办法。 I’d publish it tomorrow; but needs must when Danby and Winter drive.
所以，我个人表示万分抱歉，谨将这部真正的杰作寄还。 So, with every personal regret, I return what is really a masterpiece.
“‘此致敬礼！ “‘Always yours,
“‘迈克尔·蒙特’” “‘MICHAEL MONT.’”
“知道吗，佩伦小姐，我觉得这些话不需要润色加工了吧？” “D’you know, Miss Perren, I don’t think you need translate that?”
“我觉得很难润色加工。” “I’m afraid it would be difficult.”
“好吧，那么，请把另一封信润色一下好了。 “Right-o, then; but do the other, please.
我要带我的妻子去看画展，四点回来。 I’m going to take my wife out to see a picture; back by four.
对了！要是有个叫比克特的小伙子，他以前在这儿工作过，要求见我，随时都可以让他上来。但是你得提前告诉我一声。 Oh! and if a little chap called Bicket, that we used to have here, calls any time and asks to see me, he’s to come up; but I want warning first.
你告诉楼下的人好吗？” Will you let them know downstairs?”
“好的，蒙特先生。 “Yes, Mr. Mont.
哦！会不会——刚才那个曼纽丽小姐就是斯托伯特的小说的封面女郎呢？” Oh! didn’t—wasn’t that Miss Manuelli the model for the wrapper on Mr. Storbert’s novel?”
“她就是，佩伦小姐。是我一个人发现她的。” “She was, Miss Perren; alone I found her.”
“她的容貌很是引人注目，是不是？” “She’s very interesting-looking, isn’t she?”
“恐怕她是独一无二的吧。” “She’s unique, I’m afraid.”
“我想她不必担心这个。” “She needn’t mind that, I should think.”
“那可不一定。”迈克尔一边戳着他的吸墨水纸，一边说。 “That depends,” said Michael; and stabbed his blotting-paper.
第三章 Chapter III
《林中仙女的午后》 ‘Afternoon of a Dryad’
弗勒的体态还是那么优雅，并没有因为怀着孩子而臃肿起来，尽管那个被迈克尔称为“第十一代准男爵”的小家伙还有两个月左右就要降生了。 Fleur was still gracefully concealing most of what Michael called ‘the eleventh baronet,’ now due in about two months’ time.
她似乎在进行身心两方面的自我调节，以便能够安静而顽强地把这个小继承人生下来。 She seemed to be adapting herself, in mind and body, to the quiet and persistent collection of the heir.
迈克尔知道，从一开始，她就遵照她母亲的指示一直在影响胎儿的性别。每天晚上睡觉前以及每天早晨醒来后，她都对自己反复地说：“一天又一天，在每一个方面，他都越来越男性化了。”她寄希望以此能够影响自己的潜意识，因为如今人们都说事情的进程是由潜意识控制的。同时她极力避免说：“我会生一个男孩的。”因为人们认为，这样说会引起一种反应，反而容易生出个女孩来。 Michael knew that, from the first, following the instructions of her mother, she had been influencing his sex, repeating to herself, every evening before falling asleep, and every morning on waking the words: “Day by day, in every way, he is getting more and more male,” to infect the subconscious which, everybody now said, controlled the course of events; and that she was abstaining from the words: “I WILL have a boy,” for this, setting up a reaction, everybody said, was liable to produce a girl.
迈克尔发现，她越来越频繁地向她母亲求助，就好像她的法国血统或是她体内更顺从自然的那一面，已经控制住这个与肉体生长相关的过程了。 Michael noted that she turned more and more to her mother, as if the French, or more naturalistic, side of her, had taken charge of a process which had to do with the body.
她经常坐着索姆斯的车到梅普尔达勒姆去，而她的母亲也经常到南广场来。 She was frequently at Mapledurham, going down in Soames’ car, and her mother was frequently in South Square.
安妮特那漂亮的仪表、喜欢黑色蕾丝的癖好，向来令迈克尔满意。他从来没有忘记在那段希望渺茫的求婚日子里，她对他的支持和鼓励。 Annette’s handsome presence, with its tendency to black lace was always pleasing to Michael, who had never forgotten her espousal of his suit in days when it was a forlorn hope.
尽管他依旧觉得自己还只是在弗勒的心房门口，而且还要准备屈居“第十一代准男爵”之下，但是自从威尔弗里德走了以后，他的心情还是轻松了不少。 Though he still felt only on the threshold of Fleur’s heart, and was preparing to play second fiddle to ‘the eleventh baronet,’ he was infinitely easier in mind since Wilfrid had been gone.
于是他怀着一份欢喜、一份爱慕，看着她把慢慢地积攒来的力气集中在一个不受时代限制的目标上，集中在一个不会过时的过程上。 And he watched, with a sort of amused adoration, the way in which she focussed her collecting powers on an object that had no epoch, a process that did not date.
在奥布里·格林的亲自带领下，这一行人早早地吃了午饭，离开了南广场，前去杜梅特里斯画廊参观他的画展。 Personally conducted by Aubrey Greene, the expedition to view his show at the Dumetrius Gallery left South Square after an early lunch.
“你的林中仙女今天早晨来找我了，奥布里，”迈克尔在出租车里说， “Your Dryad came to me this morning, Aubrey,” said Michael in the cab.
“她让我恳求你，如果她的丈夫跑去指责你画他的妻子的话，请你代为掩饰一下。 “She wanted me to ask you to put up a barrage if by any chance her husband blows round to accuse you of painting his wife.
看来他已经看到这幅画的复制品了。” It seems he’s seen a reproduction of the picture.”
“嗯！”画家小声地说，“弗勒，我要这样做吗？” “Umm!” murmured the painter: “Shall I, Fleur?”
“当然了，奥布里，必须！” “Of course you must, Aubrey!”
奥布里·格林笑着转向了迈克尔。 Aubrey Greene’s smile slid from her to Michael.
“好吧，他叫什么名字？” “Well, what’s his name?”
“比克特。” “Bicket.”
奥布里·格林两眼盯着空中，慢慢地小声念叨： Aubrey Greene fixed his eyes on space, and murmured slowly:
“一个叫做比克特的年轻的丈夫， “An angry young husband called Bicket
生气地说：‘转过身去，我要踢你一脚； Said: ‘Turn yourself round and I’ll kick it;
你画了我的老婆， You have painted my wife
赤身裸体，栩栩如生。 In the nude to the life,
格林先生，你认为这样做光明正大吗？’” Do you think, Mr. Greene, it was cricket?’”
“哎呀！ “Oh!
奥布里！” Aubrey!”
“别闹了！”迈克尔说，“我是认真的。 “Chuck it!” said Michael, “I’m serious.
她是个很有勇气的小人儿。 She’s a most plucky little creature.
她挣到了他们两人需要的钱，又不失体面。” She’s made the money they wanted, and remained respectable.”
“据我所知，的确如此。” “So far as I’m concerned, certainly.”
“嗯，我也这么认为。” “Well, I should think so.”
“为什么，弗勒？” “Why, Fleur?”
“你不是个色狼，奥布里！” “You’re not a vamp, Aubrey!”
“实际上，她激发了我对美的感受。” “As a matter of fact, she excited my aesthetic sense.”
“她可受不了某些唯美主义者！”迈克尔说。 “Much that’d save her from some aesthetes!” muttered Michael.
“而且，她是普特尼人。” “Also, she comes from Putney.”
“这才是你真正的理由。 “There you have a real reason.
那么，要是比克特突然跑来问你，你会替她掩饰了？” Then, you WILL put up a barrage if Bicket blows in?”
奥布里·格林一只手放在心口： Aubrey Greene laid his hand on his heart.
“都记在这里了！” “And here we are!”
由于第十一代准男爵带来的不便，迈克尔选择趁着奥布里·格林的普通观众吃午饭的时间来参观。 For the convenience of the eleventh baronet Michael had chosen the hour when the proper patrons of Aubrey Greene would still be lunching.
在画廊里徘徊的只有一个头发蓬乱的年轻人和三个面色青白的小姑娘。 A shock-headed young man and three pale-green girls alone wandered among the pictures.
画家立刻带领他们来到他的那幅杰作面前，然后众人在那幅画前适宜地呆立了几分钟。 The painter led the way at once to his masterpiece; and for some minutes they stood before it in a suitable paralysis.
过早开口称赞是绝对不行的；称赞得太晚也同样不得体；过分的恭维会使人不快；冷淡地说“很好——确实很好！”又会让人失望。 To speak too soon in praise would never do; to speak too late would be equally tactless; to speak too fulsomely would jar; to mutter coldly: “Very nice—very nice indeed!” would blight.
直截了当地说：“唉，老朋友，说实话，我一点儿也不喜欢它。”这会惹他发火的。 To say bluntly: “Well, old man, to tell you the truth, I don’t like it a little bit!” would get his goat.
最后，迈克尔轻轻捏了弗勒一下，于是她说： At last Michael pinched Fleur gently, and she said:
“这幅画真迷人，奥布里，而且画得非常像——至少——” “It really is charming, Aubrey; and awfully like—at least—”
“我们也就能看出这些来。 “So far as one can tell.
不过，说实在的，老朋友，你一举成名了。 But really, old man, you’ve done it in once.
不论如何，恐怕比克特也是这么想的。” I’m afraid Bicket will think so, anyway.”
“管他呢！”画家说道， “Dash that!” muttered the painter.
“你觉得色彩方面如何？” “How do you find the colour values?”
“刚刚好，尤其是肌肤的颜色。你觉得呢，弗勒？” “Jolly fine; especially the flesh; don’t you think so, Fleur?”
“没错，但是我更喜欢那边上的阴影再深一些。” “Yes; only I should have liked that shadow down the side a little deeper.”
“是吗？”画家低声说，“也许吧！” “Yes?” murmured the painter: “Perhaps!”
“你抓住了精神实质，”迈克尔说， “You’ve caught the spirit,” said Michael.

不知道那些批评家会对你作出什么评论。” I don’t know what the critics will do to you.”
奥布里·格林笑了： Aubrey Greene smiled.
“这就是这幅画最糟糕的一面。 “That was the worst of her.
她激起了我的灵感。 She led me on.
有想法真是要命啊。” To get an idea’s fatal.”

“当然不了，只是人家不那么说罢了。” “Of course not; only one doesn’t say so.”
“时机选得很好，不必再对克里伦咖啡馆那帮人唯唯诺诺。 “Time we did, instead of kow-towing to the Cafe C’rillon.
我说，头发画得很好，脚趾也很好——当你看着它们的时候，它们甚至会弯曲。” I say, the hair’s all right, and so are the toes—they curl as you look at ‘em.”
“而且没有把大腿画成一条条、一块块的肌肉，这让人看了才舒服。 “And it IS a relief not to get legs painted in streaky cubes.
那些日光兰让人想起莱昂纳多的那幅《岩间圣母》中的那些花朵，奥布里。” The asphodels rather remind one of the flowers in Leonardo’s ‘Virgin of the Rocks,’ Aubrey.”

你得淡化这一点。” You’ll have to live that down.”
“对了！ “Oh!
奥布里，我父亲看过这幅画了。 Aubrey, my father’s seen it.
我相信他已经上钩了。 I believe he’s biting.
你说过的一句话给他留下了深刻的印象——是关于我们那幅《白猿》的，你还记得吗？” Something you said impressed him—about our white monkey, d’you remember?”
奥布里·格林摊开双手。 Aubrey Greene threw up his hands.
“哎呀！ “Ah!
那幅《白猿》——画成那个样子！ That white monkey—to have painted that!
吃了果子，果皮丢满地，然后用你的眼睛问这是怎么回事。” Eat the fruit and chuck the rinds around, and ask with your eyes what it’s all about.”
“有教育意义！”迈克尔说，“小心啊，老朋友！ “A moral!” said Michael: “Take care, old man!
好了！ Well!
我们叫的出租车来了。 Our taxi’s running up.
走吧，弗勒，让奥布里自己反省去吧。” Come along, Fleur; we’ll leave Aubrey to his conscience.”
再次坐在出租车里，他牵着她的手臂说： Once more in the cab, he took her arm.
“那个可怜的小家伙，比克特！ “That poor little snipe, Bicket!
要是画中人是你的话，我也会像他一样来这里的！” Suppose I’d come on YOU as he’ll come on his wife!”

“哦！你有，比这美多了。尽管她已经够美的了，我必须说。” “Oh! yes; much nicer; though she looks nice enough, I must say.”
“那么为什么在如今这个思想解放的年代里，比克特还要介意？” “Then why should Bicket mind, in these days of emancipation?”
“为什么？ “Why?
天啊，亲爱的！ Good Lord, ducky!
你不是以为比克特——！ You don’t suppose Bicket—!
我的意思是，我们这些已经解放了思想的人惯于认为我们就是全世界了——可是，我们不是！我们是多出来的闹哄哄的一小撮人。 I mean, we emancipated people have got into the habit of thinking we’re the world—well! we aren’t; we’re an excrescence, small, and noisy.
我们高谈阔论，仿佛旧的价值观和偏见都已经消失了，但实际上，你知道的，它们并没有消失，就像那些别墅和小灰房子都还在一样。” We talk as if all the old values and prejudices had gone; but they’ve no more gone, really, you know, than the rows of villas and little grey houses.”

如果思想真的解放了，那人们可以坚持下去。但是思想并没有解放。 If emancipation were true, one could stick it; but it’s not.
和30年前相比，现在的改观连百分之十都不足。” There isn’t ten per cent. difference between now and thirty years ago.”

30年前还没有你。” You weren’t alive.”

我们这帮人自以为是整块桌布，其实只是桌布边缘的流苏。 Our lot think they’re the tablecloth, but they’re only the fringe.
你知道吗，我们国家只有15万人曾经听过一次贝多芬的交响乐？ D’you know, only one hundred and fifty thousand people in this country have ever heard a Beethoven Symphony?
你觉得会有多少人认为老贝已经过时了？ How many, do you suppose, think old B. a back number?
四千两百万人中大概有五千人这么想吧。 Five thousand, perhaps, out of forty-two millions.
这样怎么能称得上是解放呢？” How’s that for emancipation?”
看到她合上了双眼，他就停下来不说了。 He stopped, observing that her eyelids had drooped.
“我在想，迈克尔，我想把我卧室的窗帘换成蓝色的。 “I was thinking, Michael, that I should like to change my bedroom curtains to blue.
我昨天在哈顿商店看到那个颜色了。 I saw the exact colour yesterday at Harton’s.
据说蓝色对精神有影响力——现在的窗帘实在太花哨了。” They say blue has an effect on the mind—the present curtains really are too jazzy.”
第十一代准男爵！ The eleventh baronet!

要是有作用的话，把天花板换成蓝色的也行。” Have a blue ceiling if it helps.”

不过我觉得我会把地毯也换了的，哈顿商店有一款浅灰蓝色的，很可爱的。” But I think I’ll change the carpet, too; there’s a lovely powder blue at Harton’s.”
“那就买下来吧。 “Then get it.
你想现在就去那儿吗？ Would you like to go there now?
我可以坐地铁回办公室的。” I can take the Tube back to the office.”
“是的，我想最好现在去一趟。 “Yes, I think I’d better.
要不然可能就买不到了。” I might miss it.”
迈克尔把头探出去喊道： Michael put his head out of the window.
“去哈顿商店！” “Harton’s, please!”
然后又戴上他的帽子，看着她。 And, replacing his hat, he looked at her.
解放了的人！ Emancipated!
唉！ Phew!
第四章 Chapter IV
比克特的下午 Bicket’s afternoon
差不多就在那个时候，比克特又走进了起居室，放下托盘。 Just about that moment Bicket re-entered his sitting-room and deposited his tray.
整个上午，他在圣保罗大教堂的影子下面重新体验了一把公众假日。 All the morning under the shadow of St. Paul’s he had re-lived Bank Holiday.
虽然腿和脚特别累，但是他还是心里痒痒的。 Exceptionally tired in feet and legs, he was also itching mentally.
他本指望时不时地看一看那张几乎和维本人一模一样的图片。 He had promised himself a refreshing look from time to time at what was almost like a photo of Vic herself.
但他却把这幅图片弄丢了！ And he had lost the picture!
然而他并没有从口袋里拿出过任何东西——只是把大衣挂了起来。 Yet he had taken nothing out of his pockets—just hung his coat up.
究竟是在车站拥挤的人群中挤掉了呢，还是没有把它放进口袋里掉在了车厢里了呢？ Had it joggled out in the crush at the station, or had he missed his pocket opening and dropped it in the carriage?
而且他还想去看看那幅原画。 And he had wanted to see the original, too.
他记得那家画廊的名字是以“杜”开头的，于是在吃午饭的时候他花了一个半便士去查找那个名字。 He remembered that the Gallery began with a ‘D,’ and at lunch-time squandered a penny-halfpenny to look up the names.
外国名字，他可以确定——那幅画是裸体的。 Foreign, he was sure—the picture being naked.
“杜梅特里斯？” ‘Dumetrius?’
哈！ Ah!
回到他卖气球的地方，他碰上了点儿好运气。 Back at his post, he had a bit of luck.
他已经好几个月没有见到的“那位市议员”，走了过来。 ‘That alderman,’ whom he had not seen for months, came by.
直觉使他立刻说道：“希望您身体健康，先生。 Intuition made him say at once: “Hope I see you well sir.
我永远不会忘记您的恩惠。” Never forgotten your kindness.”
那位“市议员”原本一直凝视着上方，仿佛看到了圣保罗大教堂的穹顶上有一只喜鹊，此时好像抽筋了似的，停了下来。 The ‘alderman,’ who had been staring up as if he saw a magpie on the dome of St. Paul’s, stopped as though attacked by cramp.
“恩惠？”他说，“什么恩惠？ “Kindness?” he said; “what kindness?
哦！气球！ Oh! balloons!
它们对我毫无用处！” They were no good to me!”
“是的，先生，我敢肯定。”比克特谦卑地说。 “No, sir, I’m sure,” said Bicket humbly.
“喏，给你！”这位“市议员”咕哝着说，“以后别再指望我会给你钱。” “Well, here you are!” muttered the ‘alderman’; “don’t expect it again.”
半个克朗！ Half-a-crown!
整整半个克朗！ A whole half-crown!
比克特的目光追随着那个匆匆离去的身影。 Bicket’s eyes pursued the hastening form.
“好运气！”他轻轻地对自己说，然后开始收拾起托盘， “Good-luck!” he said softly to himself, and began putting up his tray.
“我要回家歇歇脚，然后带着维去看看那幅画。 “I’ll go home and rest my feet, and tyke Vic to see that picture.
我们两个人一起看着那幅画一定很有趣。” It’ll be funny lookin’ at it together.”
但是她没有在家。 But she was not in.
他坐下来，抽了一支烟。 He sat down and smoked a fag.
她出去了，他感到有些委屈，毕竟这是他第一次下午休息。 He felt aggrieved that she was out, this the first afternoon he had taken off.
当然她也不能整天呆在家里！ Of course she couldn’t stay in all day!
但是——！ Still—!
他等了20分钟，然后穿上迈克尔送的衣服和鞋。 He waited twenty minutes, then put on Michael’s suit and shoes.
“我要一个人去看那幅画，”他想， ‘I’ll go and see it alone,’ he thought.
“这样只花一半的钱。 ‘It’ll cost half as much.
我想他们收六个便士吧。” They charge you sixpence, I expect.’
他们收了他一个先令——一个先令！ They charged him a shilling—a shilling!
这是他一天收入的四分之一，去看一幅画！ One fourth of his day’s earnings, to see a picture!
他羞怯地走了进去。 He entered bashfully.
有几位女士，身上散发着香气，慢吞吞地说着话，但是相貌比不上维。 There were ladies who smelled of scent and had drawling voices but not a patch on Vic for looks.
其中一个，在他身后，说： One of them, behind him, said:
“瞧！ “See!
那就是奥布里·格林本人！ There’s Aubrey Greene himself!
那就是大家谈论的那幅画——《林中仙女的午后》。” And that’s the picture they’re talking of—’Afternoon of a Dryad.’”
她们从他身边经过，继续朝前走去。 They passed him and moved on.
比克特跟在后面。 Bicket followed.
在房间的尽头，从她们的衣服和展品目录之间，他瞥见了那幅画。 At the end of the room, between their draperies and catalogues, he glimpsed the picture.
他的额头上冒出了一层细小的汗珠。 A slight sweat broke out on his forehead.
几乎和真人一样大，在花朵和穗状的草丛中，那张脸扭过来朝他微笑——完全就是维的肖像！ Almost life-size, among the flowers and spiky grasses, the face smiled round at him—very image of Vic!
难道世界上会有人和她长得一模一样？ Could some one in the world be as like her as all that?
这个想法让他恼火，就像一个收藏家发现一件独一无二的藏品有了复制品一样恼火。 The thought offended him, as a collector is offended finding the duplicate of an unique possession.
“这幅画棒极了，格林先生。 “It’s a wonderful picture, Mr. Greene.
太有代表性了！” What a type!”
一个没戴帽子，梳着整齐的背头的年轻人回答道： A young man without hat, and fair hair sliding back, answered:
“这是一个新发现，不是吗？” “A find, wasn’t she?”
“哦！太完美了！完全是森林女神的气质。太神秘了！” “Oh! perfect! the very spirit of a wood nymph; so mysterious!”
这话是对维说的！ The word that belonged to Vic!
这太可恶了。 It was unholy.
她躺在那里让所有人观看，只因某个可恶的女人和她长得相像！ There she lay for all to look at, just because some beastly woman was made like her!
一股怒气涌上比克特的喉咙，使他的脸颊发烫，随之而来的是一种奇怪的肉体上的妒忌。 A kind of rage invaded Bicket’s throat, caused his checks to burn; and with it came a queer physical jealousy.
那个画家！ That painter!
他有什么权利去画一个和维那么相像的女人——一个不在乎像那样躺着的女人！ What business had he to paint a woman so like Vic as that—a woman that didn’t mind lyin’ like that!
他们聚在那里谈论什么明暗对比、异教信仰，还有一个名叫莱昂纳多的家伙！ They and their talk about cahryscuro and paganism, and a bloke called Leneardo!
他们那该死的慢吞吞的腔调和把戏！ Blast their drawling and their tricks!
他试图走开，但是走不开，他被那幅肖像迷住了，它竟然和他一直认为只属于他自己的那个人异乎寻常地相似。 He tried to move away, and could not, fascinated by that effigy, so uncannily resembling what he had thought belonged to himself alone.
为了一个“巧合”而感到如此难受真是愚蠢，但是他真恨不得把玻璃砸碎，把那个身体割裂成碎片。 Silly to feel so bad over a ‘coincidence,’ but he felt like smashing the glass and cutting the body up into little bits.
那几位女士和那个画家继续向前走去，留下他一个人站在那幅画前。 The ladies and the painter passed on, leaving him alone before the picture.
他并不十分在乎自己独自一人。 Alone, he did not mind so much.
那张脸像是带着悲哀而落寞的表情，而且——而且带着挑逗的微笑。 The face was mournful-like, and lonely, and—and teasing, with its smile.
它使你魂牵梦萦——它的确如此！ It sort of haunted you—it did!
“哦！”比克特想，“我还是回家去找维吧。 ‘Well!’ thought Bicket, ‘I’ll get home to Vic.
毕竟，幸亏我没有带她来看像她自己一样的人。 Glad I didn’t bring her, after all, to see herself-like.
如果我是一个市议员，我就把这个该死的东西买下来，然后烧掉！” If I was an alderman, I’d buy the blinkin’ thing, and burn it!’
而就在那边，在入口处的门厅里，站在那里和一个“外国佬”说话的——正是他的那位“市议员”！ And there, in the entrance-lobby, talking to a ‘dago,’ stood—his very own ‘alderman!’
比克特十分惊异地停下了脚步。 Bicket paused in sheer amazement.
“这个画家的声望越来越高了，福赛特先生，”他听到这个外国佬说，“他的画的价格正在上涨。” “It’s a rithing name, Mr. Forthyte,” he heard the Dago say: “hith prithes are going up.”
“这些全都很好，杜梅特里斯，但是这年头不是人人都花得起这笔钱——总而言之，太精美了！” “That’s all very well, Dumetrius, but it’s not everybody’s money in these days—too highly-finished, altogether!”
“好吧，福赛特先生，我给您打九折。” “Well, Mr. Forthyte, to YOU I take off ten per thent.”
“打八折我就买了。” “Take off twenty and I’ll buy it.”
那个外国佬的肩膀耸得比他那双多毛的耳朵还要高——的确是这样，还有那种微笑！ That Dago’s shoulders mounted above his hairy ears—they did; and what a smile!
“福赛特先生！ “Mithter Forthyte!
八五折，先生！” Fifteen, thir!”
“好吧，我投降了。不过，你要把它送到南广场我女儿家里——你知道门牌号的。 “Well, you’re doing me; but send it round to my daughter’s in South Square—you know the number.
画展什么时候结束？” When do you close?”
“后天，先生。” “Day after tomorrow, thir.”
原来如此！ So!
维的仿制品已经归那位“市议员”所有了，是吗？ The counterfeit of Vic had gone to that ‘alderman,’ had it?
比克特小声说了一句粗鲁的话，然后溜了出去。 Bicket uttered a savage little sound, and slunk out.
他怀着一种古怪的心情走着。 He walked with a queer feeling.
他是不是没必要这么紧张呢？ Had he got unnecessary wind up?
毕竟，那不是她。 After all, it wasn’t her.
但是他已经知道了有另外一个女人也可以那样微笑，留着黑色的短发，发梢卷曲，而且全都卷曲得一模一样！ But to know that another woman could smile that way, have frizzy-ended short black hair, and be all curved the same!
他看着每一个经过的女人的脸——那么不同，完全不像维的脸！ And at every woman’s passing face he looked—so different, so utterly unlike Vic’s!
当他到家的时候，她正站在房屋的中间，嘴唇对着一只气球。 When he reached home she was standing in the middle of the room, with her lips to a balloon.
在她的周围，地板上、椅子上、桌子上、壁炉架上，全都是他那些被吹大了的气球存货。气球一个接一个地从她的唇边漂浮起来，选择它们各自休息的地方：褐色的、绿色的、橙色的、紫色的、蓝色的，它们的颜色使这个昏暗的小地方充满了生气。 All around her, on the floor, chairs, table, mantelpiece, were the blown-out shapes of his stock; one by one they had floated from her lips and selected their own resting-places: puce, green, orange, purple, blue, enlivening with their colour the dingy little space.
他所有的气球都被吹大了！ All his balloons blown up!
而她穿着自己最好的衣服，站在那里，微笑着，神情既奇怪又激动。 And there, in her best clothes, she stood, smiling, queer, excited.
“这究竟是怎么啦！”比克特说。 “What in thunder!” said Bicket.
她掀起裙子下摆，噼噼啪啪地从长筒袜的上端取出了几张钞票，递到他跟前。 Raising her dress, she took some crackling notes from the top of her stocking, and held them out to him.
“瞧！ “See!
64英镑，托尼！ Sixty-four pounds, Tony!
我已经全部拿到了。 I’ve got it all.
咱们可以走了。” We can go.”
“什么！” “WHAT!”
“我灵机一动——就去找那个送给我们衣服的蒙特先生，他把这笔钱预付给我们了。 “I had a brain wave—went to that Mr. Mont who gave us the clothes, and he’s advanced it.
有朝一日，咱们可以把钱还给他。 We can pay it back, some day.
难道这不是个奇迹吗？” Isn’t it a marvel?”
比克特的眼睛，吃惊得像兔子的眼睛似的，看着她的微笑，兴奋的红晕，一种奇怪的感觉贯穿他的全身，仿佛这一切都是在故意欺骗他似的！ Bicket’s eyes, startled like a rabbit’s, took in her smile, her excited flush, and a strange feeling shot through all his body, as if THEY were taking HIM in!
她不像维！ She wasn’t like Vic!
不！ No!
突然，他觉得她搂住了他，觉得她那湿润的嘴唇贴在了他的嘴唇上。 Suddenly he felt her arms round him, felt her moist lips on his.
她抱得那么紧，他一动也不能动。 She clung so tight, he could not move.
他的头发晕了。 His head went round.
“终于成功了！ “At last!
终于成功了！ At last!
这不是很好吗？ Isn’t it fine?
吻我，托尼！” Kiss me, Tony!”
比克特吻了她，他的头晕是真的，但是暂时压抑在这后面的那种感觉是多么的不真实啊！ Bicket kissed; his vertigo was real, but behind it, for the moment stifled, what sense of unreality!...
不知是在夜晚之前，还是在夜里，怀疑第一次来袭——幽灵一般地，轻轻地敲打着，颤动着，萦绕心头——然后，在破晓时分，刺穿了他的灵魂，使他变得僵硬。 Was it before night, or in the night, that the doubt first came—ghostly, tapping, fluttering, haunting—then, in the dawn, jabbing through his soul, turning him rigid.
那笔钱——那幅画——那张丢了的报纸——那种不真实的感觉啊！ The money—the picture—the lost paper—that sense of unreality!
她告诉他的这个故事！ This story she had told him!
这种事情有可能吗？ Were such things possible?
蒙特先生为什么预付那笔钱？ Why should Mr. Mont advance that money?
她去见过他——那是肯定的。那个房间，那位秘书，她对佩伦小姐的描述，你也挑不出错来。 She had seen him—that was certain; the room, the secretary—you couldn’t mistake her description of that Miss Perren.
那么，为什么会有这么强烈的怀疑呢？ Why, then, feel this jabbing doubt?
那笔钱——那么一大笔钱！ The money—such a lot of money!
他不会是和蒙特先生——决不会——他是个绅士！ Not with Mr. Mont—never—he was a gent!
哦！ Oh!
他真下流，竟然会有那种想法——还是关于维的！ Swine that he was, to have a thought like that—of Vic!
他转过身背对着她，试着入睡。 He turned his back to her and tried to sleep.
但是一旦你有了那样一种想法——还能睡着吗？ But once you got a thought like that—sleep?
不！ No!
她那张在气球中间的脸，她那种遮挡他的视线和弄昏他的头脑的方式——是为了使他不能思考，不能探究这件事，不能问她问题！ Her face among the balloons, the way she had smothered his eyes and turned his head—so that he couldn’t think, couldn’t go into it and ask her questions!
在隐隐约约的怀疑、痛苦、不确定、一阵阵的希望和对“澳大利亚”的幻想的折磨下，比克特起床时面容憔悴。 A prey to dim doubts, achings, uncertainty, thrills of hope, and visions of ‘Austrylia,’ Bicket arose haggard.
“嗯，”他一边喝着可可，吃着人造黄油面包，一边说，“我必须去见见蒙特先生，必须去。” “Well,” he said, over their cocoa and margarined bread: “I must see Mr. Mont, that’s certain.”
他直视着她的脸，又突然说道：“维？” And suddenly he added: “Vic?” looking straight into her face.
她回望着他——坦然，是的，很坦然。 She answered his look—straight, yes, straight.
哦！他真是太下流了！…… Oh! he was a proper swine!...
当他离开家的时候，维多琳一动不动地站在那里，双手按着胸口。 When he had left the house Victorine stood quite still, with hands pressed against her chest.
她比他睡得还要少。 She had slept less than he.
她安静得像一只老鼠，反反复复地在想：“我欺骗了他吗？ Still as a mouse, she had turned and turned the thought: ‘Did I take him in?
是吗？” Did I?’
如果不是——那又是什么？ And if not—what?
她拿出那些买到了——或者卖掉了？他们的幸福的钞票，然后又数了一遍。 She took out the notes which had bought—or sold?—their happiness, and counted them once more.
这时一种不公平的感觉在她心中燃烧起来。 And the sense of injustice burned within her.
难道她愿意像那样站在男人们面前吗？ Had she wanted to stand like that before men?
难道在这件事情中她不是始终都堂堂正正的吗？ Hadn’t she been properly through it about that?
哎，她本来在三个月之前就可以从那个雕塑家那里拿到这60英镑，他对她如痴如狂，或者——他自己也是这么说的！ Why, she could have had the sixty pounds three months ago from that sculptor, who was wild about her; or—so he said!
但是她坚持了下来。是的，她坚持了下来。 But she had stuck it; yes, she had.
托尼真的没有什么可以针对她的——即使他全都知道了。 Tony had nothing against her really—even if he knew it all.
她这样做全都是为了他——哦！大部分是——为了日复一日风雨无阻地卖气球的他！ She had done it for him—Well! mostly—for him selling those balloons day after day in all weathers!
如果没有她，他们将仍然处于困境之中，而且冬天又要来了，再加上失业——报纸上是这么说的——情况会越来越糟！ But for her, they would still be stuck, and another winter coming, and unemployment—so they said in the paper—to be worse and worse!
再次被困在大雾和寒冷中！ Stuck in the fogs and the cold, again!
啊！ Ugh!
她的胸口有时还是不太舒服，而他经常嗓子嘶哑。 Her chest was still funny sometimes; and he always hoarse.
还有这简陋狭小的房间，还有这张床，小得只要她一动就会弄醒他。 And this poky little room, and the bed so small that she couldn’t stir without waking him.
托尼为什么要怀疑她？ Why should Tony doubt her?
因为他的确在怀疑她——她感觉到了，从他那声“维？”中听出来的。 For he did—she had felt it, heard it in his “Vic?”
蒙特先生能够使他信服吗？ Would Mr. Mont convince him?
托尼很聪明！ Tony was sharp!
她的头耷拉了下来。 Her head drooped.
一切都不公平！ The unfairness of it all!
有些人手上拥有一切，就像蒙特先生那位漂亮的妻子！ Some had everything to their hand, like that pretty wife of Mr. Mont’s!
如果有人试图找到一条出路，寻求新的机会——那么——那么——就会发生这种事情！ And if one tried to find a way and get out to a new chance—then—then—this!
她把头发往后一甩。 She flung her hair back.
托尼必须相信——他应该相信！ Tony MUST believe—he should!
如果他不相信，那就让他去调查吧。 If he wouldn’t, let him look out.
她没有做任何羞耻的事情！ She had done nothing to be ashamed of!
没有，确实没有！ No, indeed!
于是她带着怀揣幸福上路、一直向前走的渴望，拿出了她的旧铁皮箱，开始小心翼翼地把东西放进去。 And with the longing to go in front and lead her happiness along, she got out her old tin trunk, and began with careful method to put things into it.
第五章 Chapter V
迈克尔的劝告 Michael Gives Advice
迈克尔仍然坐在那里，修改着《赝品》的校样。 Michael still sat, correcting the proofs of ‘Counterfeits.’
除了“杰里科”之外，这些校样没有地方可送。 Save ‘Jericho,’ there had been no address to send them to.
东方这么辽阔，而威尔弗里德又没有留下任何线索。 The East was wide, and Wilfrid had made no sign.
现在弗勒还会想起威尔弗里德吗？ Did Fleur ever think of Wilfrid now?
在他的印象里，她不会。 He had the impression that she did not.
而威尔弗里德——哦，可能他也已经渐渐地把她忘了。 And Wilfrid—well, probably he was forgetting her already.
即使是激情也需要一点儿营养。 Even passion required a little sustenance.
“有一位福赛特先生要见您，先生。” “A Mr. Forsyte to see you, sir.”
书国幽灵！ Apparition in bookland!
“啊！请他进来。” “Ah Show him in.”
索姆斯带着怀疑的神情走了进来。 Soames entered with an air of suspicion.
“这就是你的办公室？”他说， “This your place?” he said.
“我顺路过来告诉你一声，我已经把小格林的画买下来了。 “I’ve looked in to tell you that I’ve bought that picture of young Greene’s.
你有地方挂它吗？” Have you anywhere to hang it?”
“我想应该有，”迈克尔说， “I should think we had,” said Michael.
“那幅画好极了，先生，不是吗？” “Jolly good, sir, isn’t it?”
“嗯，”索姆斯咕哝着说，“目前来看，是很好。 “Well,” muttered Soames, “for these days, yes.
他会成名的。” He’ll make a name.”
“他非常欣赏您送给我们的那幅白猿。” “He’s an intense admirer of that White Monkey you gave us.”
“啊！ “Ah!
我一直在研究中国画。 I’ve been looking into the Chinese.
如果我继续买——”索姆斯停住不说了。 If I go on buying—” Soames paused.
“它们真有些解药的味道，不是吗，先生？ “They ARE a bit of an antidote, aren’t they, sir?
那幅《人间天堂》！ That ‘Earthly Paradise!’
还有那些鹅——它们似乎毫不介意你去数它们的羽毛，不是吗？” And those geese—they don’t seem to mind your counting their feathers, do they?”
索姆斯没有回答，显然他在想：“这些画第一次出现在市场上的时候，我怎么竟会把它们错过了呢！” Soames made no reply; he was evidently thinking: ‘How on earth I missed those things when they first came on the market!’
然后，他举起伞，指点着，仿佛在图书交易市场上似的，问道： Then, raising his umbrella, and pointing it as if at the book trade, he asked:
“小巴特菲尔德——他干得怎么样？” “Young Butterfield—how’s he doing?”
“啊！ “Ah!
我正要告诉您呢，先生。 I was going to let you know, sir.
他昨天来找我，并且告诉我两天前他见过埃尔德森。 He came in yesterday and told me that he saw Elderson two days ago.
他去向他推销我父亲的一本限量版的书，埃尔德森什么也没说就买了两本。” He went to sell him a copy of my father’s ‘Limited’; Elderson said nothing and bought two.”
“他竟然会这样做！” “The deuce he did!”
“巴特菲尔德觉得他的到访使他紧张不安。 “Butterfield got the impression that his visit put the wind up him.
埃尔德森当然知道我在这家公司里，而且是您的女婿。” Elderson knows, of course, that I’m in this firm, and your son-inlaw.”
索姆斯皱了皱眉头。 Soames frowned.
“我不确定，”他说，“那些睡着的狗—— “I’m not sure,” he said, “that sleeping dogs—!
哦，我现在就到那里去。” Well, I’m on my way there now.”
“提一下那本书，先生，看看埃尔德森有什么反应。 “Mention the book, sir, and see how Elderson takes it.
您自己要不要买一本？ Would you like one yourself?
名单上有您的名字。 You’re on the list.
E字头，F字头——巴特菲尔德今天就会去找您了。 E, F—Butterfield should be reaching you today.
这样省得您拒绝。 It’ll save you a refusal.
就是这本——装帧很精美。 Here it is—nice get-up.
一个基尼。” One guinea.”
“《二重奏》，”索姆斯念道， “‘A Duet,’” read Soames.
“关于什么的？ “What’s it about?
音乐吗？” Musical?”
“不完全是。 “Not precisely.
是关于老夫子和狄西这两个幽灵之间的彼此嘲弄！” A sort of cat-calling between the ghosts of the G. O. M. and Dizzy!”
“我不是一个爱看书的人。”索姆斯说。 “I’m not a reader,” said Soames.
他抽出一张钞票， He pulled out a note.
“你们为什么不把价格定为一英镑呢？ “Why didn’t you make it a pound?
这是一个先令。” Here’s the shilling.”
“非常感谢，先生。我敢肯定，我父亲一想到您也买了一本，一定会非常高兴的。” “Thanks awfully, sir; I’m sure my father’ll be frightfully bucked to think you’ve got one.”
“是吗？”索姆斯说着，脸上带着一丝无力的微笑， “Will he?” said Soames, with a faint smile.
“你在这里做出过什么业绩吗？” “D’you ever do any WORK here?”
“嗯，我们试着挣点儿不太好挣的小钱。” “Well, we try to turn a doubtful penny.”
“你们能挣到多少钱？” “What d’you make at it?”
“就我个人而言，大约一年500英镑。” “Personally, about five hundred a year.”
“就这么多？” “That all?”
“是的，但是我怀疑我应得的报酬是否会超过300英镑。” “Yes, but I doubt if I’m worth more than three.”
“嗯！ “H’m!
我原以为你已经忘了你的社会主义了。” I thought you’d got over your Socialism.”
“我想我已经忘了，先生。 “I fancy I have, sir.
它似乎和我的地位不相称。” It didn’t seem to go with my position.”
“是不相称，”索姆斯说， “No,” said Soames.
“弗勒看起来很好。” “Fleur seems well.”
“是的，她好极了。 “Yes, she’s splendid.
她在玩库埃那种把戏，你知道的。” She does the Coue stunt, you know.”
索姆斯盯着他。 Soames stared.
“那是因为她母亲的缘故，”他说，“我可说不上来。 “That’s her mother,” he said; “I can’t tell.
再见！ Good-bye!
哦！ Oh!
我想知道，‘惹毛了他’这句话是什么意思？” I want to know; what’s the meaning of that expression ‘got his goat?’”
“‘惹毛了他？’ “‘Got his goat?’
哦，使他发怒，如果您知道这句话的意思，那还是我出生以前所用的词呢。” Oh, raised his dander, if you know what that means, it was before my time.”
“我明白了，”索姆斯说，“那么，我的理解是对的。 “I see,” said Soames; “I had it right, then.
好啊！” Well!”
他转过身。 He turned.
他的背影非常优雅和真实。 His back was very neat and real.
背影从门口消失了，那种轮廓鲜明的感觉似乎也随之消失了。 It vanished through the doorway, and with it seemed to go the sense of definition.
迈克尔拿起校样，读了两首诗。 Michael took up the proofs, and read two poems.
像奎宁一样苦涩！ Bitter as quinine!
诗中所包含的不安情绪——字面以外的思慕之情！ The unrest in them—the yearning behind the words!
没有一点儿中国式的东西！ Nothing Chinese there!
毕竟，那些老一辈的人——比如老福赛特，还有他的父亲，虽然方式各有不同——都已经安定下来了。 After all, the ancients—like Old Forsyte, and his father in a very different way—had an anchor down.
“这是怎么回事呢？”迈克尔想， ‘What is it?’ thought Michael.
“我们怎么了？ ‘What’s wrong with us?
我们敏捷而又聪明，非常自信而又不满足。 We’re quick, and clever, cocksure, and dissatisfied.
要是有什么事情能让我们充满热情，或者惹恼我们就好了！ If only something would enthuse us, or get OUR goats!
我们抛弃了宗教、传统、财产、怜悯，我们用来代替它们的——是什么呢？ We’ve chucked religion, tradition, property, pity; and in their place we put—what?
美好的事物？ Beauty?
天啊！ Gosh!
看看沃尔特·內津，还有克里伦咖啡馆！ See Walter Nazing, and the Cafe C’rillon!
然而——我们一定在追求什么东西！ And yet—we must be after something!
更好的世界？ Better world?
看起来不像。 Doesn’t look like it.
来世？ Future life?
或许我们应该‘研究一下’唯灵论，就像老福赛特说的。 Suppose I ought to “look into” spiritualism, as Old Forsyte would say.
但是——一半在这个世界，一半在那个世界——如果那些灵魂比我们更不安定，那才奇怪呢！” But—half in this world, half in that—deuced odd if spirits are less restive than we are!’
走向什么——那么，这一切将走向什么呢？ To what—to what, then, was it all moving?
“该死！”迈克尔想着，站了起来，“我要口授一条广告！” ‘Dash it!’ thought Michael, getting up, ‘I’ll try dictating an advertisement!’
“请你进来一下好吗，佩伦小姐？ “Will you come in, please, Miss Perren?
为德赛特的新书拟一个广告——在行业杂志上：‘丹比&温特出版社即将出版《赝品》，其作者为上一出版季的杰出作品《铜币》的作者。’ For the new Desert volume—Trade Journals: ‘Danby and Winter will shortly issue ‘Counterfeits,’ by the author of ‘Copper Coin,’ the outstanding success of the last publishing season.
我不知道今年有多少个出版商对多少本书这样宣扬过，佩伦小姐？ I wonder how many publishers have claimed that, Miss Perren, for how many books this year?
‘这些诗显示出所有情绪的光彩，而且是在技巧上超过了这位年轻作家第一本书的又一力作。’ ‘These poems show all the brilliancy of mood, and more than the technical accomplishment of the young author’s first volume.’
怎么样？” How’s that?”
“情绪的光彩，蒙特先生？ “Brilliancy of mood, Mr. Mont?
您这样认为吗？” Do you think?”
“不。但是不这么说，我还能怎么说呢？ “No. But what am I to say?
‘所有的痛苦和悲观？’” ‘All the pangs and pessimism?’”
“哦，不！ “Oh, no!
但是或许可以说：‘所有措辞的光彩，情绪上的奇异和变化。’” But possibly: ‘All the brilliancy of diction, the strangeness and variety of mood.’”
“很好。 “Good.
不过这样要多花钱。 But it’ll cost more.
就说：‘所有的奇异光彩’,一句话就表达出来了。 Say: ‘All the brilliant strangeness’; that’ll ring their bells in once.
我们都热衷于‘奇异的事物’，但是我们得不到它——荒诞的事物，是的，但不是奇异的事物。” We’re nuts on ‘the strange,’ but we’re not getting it—the outre, yes, but not the strange.”
“德赛特先生肯定明白——” “Surely Mr. Desert gets—”
“是的，有时候；但是几乎没有别人了。 “Yes, sometimes; but hardly any one else.
要做到奇异，你必须有胆量，如果你能谅解我的措辞，佩伦小姐。” To be strange, you’ve got to have guts, if you’ll excuse the phrase, Miss Perren.”
“当然，蒙特先生。 “Certainly, Mr. Mont.
那个年轻人比克特正等着要见您呢。” That young man Bicket is waiting to see you.”
“他在等着我，是吗？”迈克尔说着，掏出一支香烟， “He is, is he?” said Michael, taking out a cigarette.
“给我点儿时间准备一下，佩伦小姐，然后叫他上来。” “Give me time to tighten my belt, Miss Perren, and ask him up.”
“善意的谎言，”他想，“来吧！” ‘The lie benevolent,’ he thought; ‘now for it!’
比克特上次来到这个房间里时表情非常痛苦，这次进来时却带有一种麻木的神情。 The entrance of Bicket into a room where his last appearance had been so painful, was accomplished with a certain stolidity.
迈克尔背靠着壁炉站着，抽着烟。比克特的背后是一捆现代小说，上面写着“这部伟大的新作”。 Michael stood, back to the hearth, smoking; Bicket, back to a pile of modern novels, with the words “This great new novel” on it.
迈克尔点点头。 Michael nodded.
“你好，比克特！” “Hallo, Bicket!”
比克特点点头。 Bicket nodded.
“您身体一向可好，先生？” “Hope you’re keeping well, sir?”
“非常好，谢谢你。” “Frightfully well, thank you.”
然后是一阵沉默。 And there was silence.
“哦，”迈克尔终于说道，“我想你是为了预付给你妻子的那点儿钱而来的吧。 “Well,” said Michael, at last, “I suppose you’ve come about that little advance to your wife.
没关系，不用着急。” It’s quite all right; no hurry whatever.”
当他说这番话的时候，他就意识到那个“小可怜”极其心烦意乱。 While saying this he had become conscious that the ‘little snipe’ was dreadfully disturbed.
他的眼睛里有一种非常奇怪的神情，那双大眼睛像虾的眼睛一样，看上去仿佛突出在身体其他部分的前面。 His eyes had a most peculiar look, those large, shrimp-like eyes which seemed, as it were, in advance of the rest of him.
他赶紧接着说： He hastened on:
“我自己也相信澳大利亚。 “I believe in Australia myself.
我相信你是完全正确的，比克特，而且你们走得越早越好。 I think you’re perfectly right, Bicket, and the sooner you go, the better.
她看起来并不太强壮。” She doesn’t look too strong.”
比克特咽了咽唾沫。 Bicket swallowed.
“先生，”他说，“我一直觉得您是一个绅士，这件事真的很难开口。” “Sir,” he said, “you’ve been a gent to me, and it’s hard to say things.”
“那就别说了。” “Then don’t.”
比克特的脸颊涨得通红，那苍白、憔悴的脸上透出一种奇怪的表情。 Bicket’s cheeks became suffused with blood: queer effect in that pale, haggard face.
“事情不是你想的那样，”他说,“我是来请求你告诉我真相的。” “It isn’t what you think,” he said: “I’ve come to ask you to tell me the truth.”
突然他从口袋里掏出一样东西，迈克尔看出来那是一张弄皱了的小说封面。 Suddenly he whipped from his pocket what Michael perceived to be a crumpled novel-wrapper.
“这是我来的时候从楼下柜台上的一本书上拿下来的。 “I took this from a book on the counter as I came by, downstairs.
你看！ There!
这是不是我的妻子？” Is that my wife?”
他把它递了过来。 He stretched it out.
迈克尔惊愕地看到那是斯托伯特的小说的封面。 Michael beheld with consternation the wrapper of Storbert’s novel.
撒一个事先已经决定的善意的谎言是一码事——否认眼前这件事是另一码事！ One thing to tell the lie benevolent already determined on—quite another to deny this!
比克特不容他考虑。 Bicket gave him little time.
“我从您的脸上已经看出来她是了，”他说， “I see it is, from your fyce,” he said.
“这一切究竟是什么意思？ “What’s it all mean?
我要知道真相——我一定要知道！ I want the truth—I must ‘ave it!
这一切快把我弄疯了。 I’m gettin’ wild over all this.
如果那上面是她的脸，那么画廊里的就是她的身体了——奥布里·格林，同一个名字。 If that’s ‘er fyce there, then that’s ‘er body in the Gallery—Aubrey Greene; it’s the syme nyme.
这一切究竟是什么意思？” What’s it all mean?”
他的脸已经变得几乎令人生畏了，他的伦敦口音变得更重了。 His face had become almost formidable; his cockney accent very broad.
“她在‘搞什么名堂’？ “What gyme ‘as she been plyin’?
你一定得告诉我，我才离开这里。” You gotta tell me before I go aht of ‘ere.”
迈克尔把脚后跟并拢。 Michael’s heels came together.
他平静地说： He said quietly.
“冷静点儿，比克特。” “Steady, Bicket.”
“冷静！ “Steady!
如果是你妻子你能冷静吗！ You’d be steady if YOUR wife-!
所有那些钱！ All that money!
你从来没有预支过钱——你从来没有给过她——从来没有！ YOU never advanced it—you never give it ‘er—never!
别跟我说你给了！” Don’t tell me you did!”
迈克尔拿定了主意。 Michael had taken his line.
不撒谎了！ No lies!
“我借给她十英镑凑成了一个整数——就是这么回事。其余的钱都是她自己挣的——光明正大地挣的。你应该为她感到骄傲。” “I lent her ten pounds to make a round sum of it—that’s all; the rest she earned—honourably; and you ought to be proud of her.”
比克特的嘴张得很大。 Bicket’s mouth fell open.
“骄傲？ “Proud?
那她是怎么挣的？ And how’s she earned it?
骄傲！ Proud!
我的上帝啊！” My Gawd!”
迈克尔冷冷地说： Michael said coldly:
“做模特。 “As a model.
我亲自把她介绍给我的朋友，格林先生，就是你和我一起吃午饭的那天。 I myself gave her the introduction to my friend, Mr. Greene, the day you had lunch with me.
我想，你以前听说过模特吧？” You’ve heard of models, I suppose?”
比克特用双手撕掉那张封面，碎片散落在地板上。 Bicket’s hands tore the wrapper, and the pieces fell to the floor.
“模特！”他说，“画家们——是的，我听说过他们——这群猪！” “Models!” he said: “Pynters—yes, I’ve ‘eard of ‘em—Swines!”
“他们和你一样都不是猪，比克特。 “No more swine than you are, Bicket.
请不要侮辱我的朋友。 Be kind enough not to insult my friend.
镇定点儿，伙计，抽支烟吧。” Pull yourself together, man, and take a cigarette.”
比克特猛地推开了递过来的烟盒。 Bicket dashed the proffered case aside.
“我——我——那么爱她，”他激动地说，“而她却这样对我！” “I—I—was stuck on her,” he said passionately, “and she’s put this up on me!”
他发出一种出自肺腑的呜咽声。 A sort of sob came out of his lungs.
“你那么爱她。”迈克尔说，他的语调里带着讽刺， “You were stuck on her,” said Michael; his voice had sting in it.
“而当她为你尽了最大努力时，你却否定了她——是这样吗？ “And when she does her best for you, you turn her down—is that it?
你认为她喜欢这样吗？” Do you suppose she liked it?”
比克特突然捂住了脸。 Bicket covered his face suddenly.
“我应该知道什么呢？”他捂着脸咕哝着说。 “What should I know?” he muttered from behind his hands.
一股怜悯之情在迈克尔的心里涌起。 A wave of pity flooded up in Michael.
怜悯！ Pity!
废话！ Blurb!
他冷淡地说：“等你完全镇定下来，比克特。 He said drily: “When you’ve quite done, Bicket.
你是否还记得你曾经为她做过的事情？” D’you happen to remember what YOU did for HER?”
比克特露出脸来，发狂地瞪着眼睛。 Bicket uncovered his face and stared wildly.
“你从来没有告诉过她吗？” “You’ve never told her that?”
“没有，但是如果你不镇定下来，我一定会告诉她的。” “No; but I jolly well will if you don’t pull yourself together.”
“现在，我才不在乎你去告诉她呢——像那样躺着，给世界上所有的男人看！ “What do I care if you do, now—lyin’ like that, for all the men in the world!
60英镑！ Sixty pound!
光明正大！ Honourably!
你以为我会相信吗？” D’you think I believe that?”
他的声音里透着凄凉。 His voice had desolation in it.
“啊！”迈克尔说， “Ah!” said Michael.
“你不相信只是因为你愚昧无知，就像你说到的猪一样愚昧无知。 “You don’t believe simply because you’re ignorant, as ignorant as the swine you talk of.
一个女孩子能做到她所做的事情并且十分坦率，我对她没有丝毫的怀疑。 A girl can do what she did and be perfectly honest, as I haven’t the faintest doubt she is.
你只要看着她，听一听她谈论这件事的语气。 You’ve only to look at her, and hear the way she speaks of it.
她这样做是因为她不忍看到你卖气球。 She did it because she couldn’t bear to see you selling those balloons.
她这样做是为了让你脱离贫困的生活，给你们俩一个机会。 She did it to get you out of the gutter, and give you both a chance.
现在你得到了这个机会，你却这样地发脾气。 And now you’ve got the chance, you kick up like this.
真该死，比克特，想开一点儿吧！ Dash it all, Bicket, be a sport!
假如我把你为她做的事情告诉她——你认为她会大喊大闹吗？ Suppose I tell her what you did for her—d’you think she’s going to squirm and squeal?
她不会！ Not she!
你这样是该死的人之常情，她那样也是该死的人之常情。你可别忘了这一点！” It was damned human of you, and it was damned human of her; and don’t you forget it!”
比克特又使劲地咽了咽唾沫。 Bicket swallowed violently again.
“你说得轻巧，”他阴沉地说，“这事没发生在你身上。” “It’s all very well,” he said, sullenly; “it ‘asn’t ‘appened to you.”
迈克尔立刻感到很痛苦。 Michael was afflicted at once.
不！ No!
这事没发生在他身上！ It hadn’t happened to him!
然后他想到了威尔弗里德在这里的那些日子里，他对弗勒的种种怀疑。 And all his doubts of Fleur in the days of Wilfrid came hitting him.
“喂，比克特，”他说，“你怀疑你妻子的感情吗？ “Look here, Bicket,” he said, “do you doubt your wife’s affection?
整件事情就是这样。 The whole thing is there.
我只见过她两次，但是我不明白你怎么会怀疑她。 I’ve only seen her twice, but I don’t see how you can.
如果她不爱你，当她知道可以在这里赚大钱，而且只要她愿意就可以尽情享受的时候，她为什么还想要去澳大利亚？ If she weren’t fond of you, why should she want to go to Australia, when she knows she can make good money here, and enjoy herself if she wants?
我可以为我的朋友格林担保。 I can vouch for my friend Greene.
他非常正派，而且我知道他做事是非常光明磊落的。” He’s dashed decent, and I KNOW he’s played cricket.”
但是，他一边观察着比克特的脸色，一边想：其余那些为她写生的人是不是也一样非常正派呢？ But, searching Bicket’s face, he wondered: Were all the others she had sat to as dashed decent?
“喂，比克特！ “Look here, Bicket!
我们有时候都会碰上这种事情。这是对我们的考验。 We all get up against it sometimes; and that’s the test of us.
你必须信任她，没有其他的办法。” You’ve just GOT to believe in her; there’s nothing else to it.”
“把自己展示给全世界的人看！” “To myke a show of herself for all the world to see!”
这句话似乎是从他那枯瘦的喉咙里挣扎着说出来的。 The words seemed to struggle from the skinny throat.
“我昨天看到那幅画被一个面色红润的市议员买去了。” “I saw that picture bought yesterday by a ruddy alderman.”
迈克尔听到这句对“老福赛特”的描述，忍不住咧嘴笑了。 Michael could not conceal a grin at this description of ‘Old Forsyte.’
“事实上，”他说，“那幅画是我岳父买来作为礼物送给我们的，就挂在我们家里。 “As a matter of fact,” he said, “it was bought by my own father-inlaw as a present to us, to hang in our house.
而且，听着，比克特，它是一件精品。” And, mind you, Bicket, it’s a fine thing.”
“啊！”比克特喊道，“它是一件精品！ “Ah!” cried Bicket, “it IS a fine thing!
钱！ Money!
是钱买了她。 It’s money bought her.
钱可以买到任何东西。 Money’ll buy anything.
它还能把你的心从你的胸膛里买走。” It’ll buy the ‘eart out of your chest.”
迈克尔想：“我不可能侥幸成功了！ And Michael thought: ‘I can’t get away with it a bit!
解放的代价是什么？ What price emancipation?
他从来没有听说过希腊人！ He’s never heard of the Greeks!
即使听说过，他也会觉得他们是一群生活放荡的外国人罢了。 And if he had, they’d seem to him a lot of loose-living foreigners.
我必须放弃。” I must quit.’
这时，他突然看到眼泪从那双虾一样的眼睛中流了出来，沿着凹陷的双颊流了下去。 And, suddenly, he saw tears come out of those shrimp’s eyes, and trickle down the hollowed cheeks.
他觉得心里很乱，赶忙说道： Very disturbed, he said hastily:
“等你离开这里，你就不会再想起这件事了。 “When you get out there, you’ll never think of it again.
岂有此理，比克特，你要做一个男子汉！ Hang it all, Bicket, be a man!
她这样做是出于好意。 She did it for the best.
如果我是你，我绝不会向她透露我已经知道了。 If I were you, I’d never let on to her that I knew.
如果我告诉她。你是怎样偷那些《铜币》的，她也一定会这么做的。” That’s what she’d do if I told her how you snooped those ‘Copper Coins.’”
比克特握紧了拳头——这个动作和眼泪在一起很奇怪；然后，他一声不吭，转身，拖着脚步走了出去。 Bicket clenched his fists—the action went curiously with the tears; then, without a word, he turned and shuffled out.
“哦，”迈克尔想，“给予劝告显然不是我的特长！ ‘Well,’ thought Michael, ‘giving advice is clearly not my stunt!
可怜的小家伙！” Poor little snipe!’
第六章 Chapter VI
赦免 Quittance
比克特眼睛模糊，跌跌撞撞地沿着斯特兰德大街走去。 Bicket stumbled, half-blind, along the Strand.
他天生好脾气，但这次精神上的打击让他心里很难受，而且头昏脑胀。 Naturally good-tempered, such a nerve-storm made him feel ill, and bruised in the brain.
阳光和行走使他慢慢地恢复了一些思考能力。 Sunlight and motion slowly restored some power of thought.
他已经知道了真相。 He had got the truth.
可这就是事实的全部真相吗？ But was it the whole and nothing but the truth?
她能做到赚了那笔钱却没有—— Could she have made all that money without—?
如果他能相信这一点，那么，或许——远离这个人们只需花一先令就能看到她裸体的国家——他或许就可以忘记这件事。 If he could believe that, then, perhaps—out of this country where people could see her naked for a shilling—he might forget.
但是——那笔钱啊！ But—all that money!
而且，这些钱即便都是“光明正大地”挣来的，像蒙特先生所言，根本不知道她的裸体已经给多少男人看了多少天了。 And even if all earned ‘honourable,’ as Mr. Mont had put it, in how many days, exposed to the eyes of how many men?
他在街上大声呻吟起来。 He groaned aloud in the street.
一想到回家见她——想到争吵，想到假如真的吵架，他也许会了解到其他事情，想到这些他就痛苦不堪。 The thought of going home to her—of a scene, of what he might learn if there WERE a scene, was just about unbearable.
但是——必须这样做，他想。 And yet—must do it, he supposed.
他更愿忍受站在圣保罗大教堂下面，站在排水沟旁，叫卖气球。 He could have borne it better under St. Paul’s, standing in the gutter, offering his balloons.
一辈子第一次空闲，像个十足的“市议员”无所事事却掏钱去看什么十足的艳女！ A man of leisure for the first time in his life, a blooming ‘alderman’ with nothing to do but step in and take a ticket to the ruddy butterflies!
而且这空闲还要归功于一个男人无法释怀的事情，想到这些他忍无可忍！ And he owed that leisure to what a man with nothing to take his thoughts off simply could not bear!
那钱还不如是他从商店里偷来的。 He would rather have snaffled the money out of a shop till.
这样要比这种阴暗、恶魔般的、性欲上的妒忌戳刺在心里的感受好一些。 Better that on his soul, than the jab of this dark fiendish sexual jealousy.
“做个男子汉！” ‘Be a man!’
说得简单！ Easy said!
“冷静！ ‘Pull yourself together!
她这么做全是为了你！” She did it for you!’
他百倍地希望她从来没做过。 He would a hundred times rather she had not.
黑修道士桥！ Blackfriars Bridge!
纵身一跳，在那泥浆中结束自己的一生？ A dive, and an end in the mud down there?
但你会浮上来三次，人们会把你救上来，而且还得把你抓起来——还是一无所获——甚至当想到维会去认尸，明白自己都做了些什么时，也没有一丝的快感。 But you had to rise three times; they would fish you out alive, and run you in for it—and nothing gained—not even the pleasure of thinking that Vic would see what she had done, when she came to identify the body.
不管怎么说，死了就是死了，死后他将永远不会知道她会有什么想法的！ Dead was dead, anyway, and he would never know what she felt post-mortem!
他眼睛望着前方，步履艰难地走过桥面。 He trudged across the bridge, keeping his eyes before him.
小沟街——她得肺炎那阵子，他经常是匆忙地奔下桥，回到她的身边！ Little Ditch Street—how he used to scuttle down it, back to her, when she had pneumonia!
他还会再有这样的感觉吗？ Would he never feel like that again?
他大步经过窗子，走了进去。 He strode past the window, and went in.
维多琳依然弯腰在那收拾着褐色铁皮箱。 Victorine was still bending over the brown tin trunk.
她直起腰，脸上显露着冷漠、疲惫的神色。 She straightened herself, and on her face came a cold, tired look.
“嗯，”她说，“我看出来你已经知道了。” “Well,” she said, “I see you know.”
比克特只需两步就可跨进这个小屋。 Bicket had but two steps to take in that small room.
他走了两步，双手放在她的肩膀上。 He took them, and put his hands on her shoulders.
他把脸凑近，那双又大又紧张的眼睛审视着她的眼睛。 His face was close, his eyes, so large and strained, searched hers.
“我知道你已经把裸体展现给全伦敦的人了。现在我想知道的是——其余的事情！” “I know you’ve myde a show of yerself for all London to see; what I want to know is—the rest!”
维多琳目不转睛地看着他。 Victorine stared back at him.
“其余的事情！”她说——那不是发问，而是将刚才的话重复了一遍，语气和声调似乎不包含任何意义。 “The rest!” she said—it was not a question, just a repetition, in a voice that seemed to mean nothing.
“对！”比克特声音嘶哑地说，“其余的事情——嗯？” “Ah!” said Bicket hoarsely; “The rest—Well?”
“如果你认为还有‘其余的事情’，那就够了。” “If you think there’s a ‘rest,’ that’s enough.”
比克特突然把手拿开。 Bicket jerked his hands away.
“噢！看在上帝的份上，别再故弄玄虚了。 “Aoh! for the land’s sake, daon’t be mysterious.
我已经快要疯了！” I’m ‘alf orf me nut!”
“我看出来了，”维多琳说，“而且我还看出来：你不是以前我认为的那种人。 “I see that,” said Victorine; “and I see this: You aren’t what I thought you.
你以为我愿意做这种事情吗？” D’you think I liked doing it?”
她撩起衣服，拿出一沓钞票来。 She raised her dress and took out the notes.
“给你！ “There you are!
你可以不带我，一个人去澳大利亚吧。” You can go to Australia without me.”
比克特嘶哑地吼道：“把你留给那些该死的画家吗？” Bicket cried hoarsely: “And leave you to the blasted pynters?”
“我留给我自己。 “And leave me to meself.
把钱拿走！” Take them!”
比克特退缩到门口，恐怖地瞪着那沓钞票。 But Bicket recoiled against the door, staring at the notes with horror.
“我不要！” “Not me!”
“好啦，我肯定不会留着它们。 “Well, I can’t keep ‘em.
我挣这些钱是为了让你摆脱困难。” I earned them to get you out of this.”
接着是一段长时间的沉默，那沓钞票就放在两人中间的桌子上，虽然有点儿油腻但还是挺清爽的——这就是企盼已久、梦寐以求的解脱的方法，就是沐浴在阳光下共享幸福的方法。 There was a long silence, while the notes lay between them on the table, still crisp if a little greasy—the long-desired, the dreamed-of means of release, of happiness together in the sunshine.
钱就放在那里，两个人谁也不愿意拿！ There they lay; neither would take them!
那怎么办？ What then?
“维，”比克特终于嘶哑着嗓子低声说，“你发誓从来没让他们碰过你！” “Vic,” said Bicket at last, in a hoarse whisper, “swear you never let ‘em touch you!”
“是的，我发誓。” “Yes, I can swear that.”
她说此话时还在微笑——她的那种微笑啊！ And she could smile, too, saying it—that smile of hers!
如何相信她——这么长时间，一直瞒着他，直到最后还在撒谎！ How believe her—living all these months, keeping it from him, telling him a lie about it in the end!
他一屁股坐在桌旁的椅子上，双手抱着头。 He sank into a chair by the table and laid his head on his arms.
维多琳转过身用一根旧绳子捆箱子。 Victorine turned and began pulling an old cord round the trunk.
他听到轻微的捆箱子声，抬起头来。 He raised his head at the tiny sound.
那么她真的要离开这里！ Then she really meant to go away!
他眼看着他的生活被毁掉，人去楼空犹如汉普斯蒂荒地上的椰子壳，他的伦敦人精神一下子垮了。 He saw his life devastated, empty as a cocoanut on Hampstead Heath; and all defence ran melted out of his cockney spirit.
泪水夺眶而出。 Tears rolled from his eyes.
“在你生病的时候，”他说，“我为你偷过东西。 “When you were ill,” he said, “I stole for you.
我就是因为这个才被解雇的。” I got the sack for it.”
她猛地转过身来。 She spun round.
“托尼——你从来没告诉过我！ “Tony—you never told me!
你偷了什么？” What did you steal?”
“书。 “Books.
你所有额外的营养品都是靠这些书买来的。” All your extra feedin’ was books.”
她站在那里盯着他好久，然后默默地伸出双手。 For a long minute she stood looking at him, then stretched out her hands without a word.
比克特抓住这双手。 Bicket seized them.
“现在我什么都不在乎了，”他喘着气说，“所以要丢下我，维，只要你爱我！” “I don’t care about anything,” he gasped, “so ‘elp me, so long as you’re fond of me, Vic!”
“我也不在乎了。 “And I don’t neither.
噢！托尼，我们离开这儿吧！离开这个令人难过的小屋，离开这个令人难过的国家。 Oh! let’s get out of this, Tony! this awful little room, this awful country.
让我们离开这一切！” Let’s get out of it all!”
“好的。”比克特说，把她的手放在自己的眼睛上。 “Yes,” said Bicket; and put her hands to his eyes.
第七章 Chapter VII
调查埃尔德森 Looking into Elderson
索姆斯离开丹比&温特出版社后，心里想着两件事：埃尔德森和《白猿》。 Soames had left Danby and Winter divided in thought between Elderson and the White Monkey.
像弗勒猜测的一样，他一直记着奥布里·格林看到从乔治·福赛特的那堆废品中抢救出来的那幅画时说的一番话。 As Fleur surmised, he had never forgotten Aubrey Greene’s words concerning that bit of salvage from the wreck of George Forsyte.
“吃掉人生的果实，果皮随便一丢，正在它这么做的时候，被逮住了。” “Eat the fruits of life, scatter the rinds, and get copped doing it.”
他觉得这句话同样适用于商业买卖中。 His application of them tended towards the field of business.
国家依然靠着那点儿资本过活。 The country was still living on its capital.
随着运输业和欧洲市场的萎靡衰退，他们却还在源源不断地进口他们无力支付的食物。 With the collapse of the carrying trade and European markets, they were importing food they couldn’t afford to pay for.
在他看来，他们会作茧自缚，而且不久就要犯事。 In his opinion they would get copped doing it, and that before long.
英国的信誉没的可说，而且堪称是世界的奇迹，但是总不能无节制地靠奇迹过日子啊。 British credit was all very well, the wonder of the world and that, but you couldn’t live indefinitely on wonder.
航运业没有生意，企业处处亏损，失业的人成群结队，这才糟糕啊！ With shipping idle, concerns making a loss all over the place, and the unemployed in swarms, it was a pretty pair of shoes!
很快，即便是保险业也会受到牵连影响的。 Even insurance must suffer before long.
也许埃尔德森已经注意到这些现象了，才会及时中饱私囊。 Perhaps that chap Elderson had foreseen this already, and was simply feathering his nest in time.
如果一个人迟早被抓住，那为何伪装得老老实实呢？ If one was to be copped in any case, why bother to be honest?
这明显就是玩世不恭，面对这些，索姆斯身上具有的福赛特气质是绝对容忍不了的。但是它却一再显现。 This was cynicism so patent, that all the Forsyte in Soames rejected it; and yet it would keep coming back.
破产已成大局，何须再为节俭、远见、诚实而劳神费心呢？ In a general bankruptcy, why trouble with thrift, far-sightedness, integrity?
甚至连那些保守党人都不再愿意称自己是保守党了，似乎这个词是那么幼稚可笑，他们清楚确实已经没有什么值得他们去保守了。 Even the Conservatives were refusing to call themselves Conservatives again, as if there were something ridiculous about the word, and they knew there was really nothing left to conserve.
“吃掉果实，果皮随便一丢，正在它这么做的时候，被逮住了。” “Eat the fruit, scatter the rinds, and get copped doing it.”
那位年轻的画家讲了一句聪明的话——是啊，而且他的画也聪明，虽然杜梅特里斯开价过高——像往常一样！ That young painter had said a clever thing—yes, and his picture was clever, though Dumetrius had done one over the price—as usual!
弗勒会把画挂在什么地方呢？ Where would Fleur hang it?
要是挂在门厅，他肯定不感到惊讶——那里光线好。而且他们结识的那帮人是不会对裸体画反感的。 In the hall, he shouldn’t be surprised—good light there; and the sort of people they knew wouldn’t jib at the nude.
奇怪——所有那些裸体画都去哪里了！ Curious—where all the nudes went to!
你从来没欣赏过裸体画——就像从来没见过谚语里提到的死驴一样！ You never saw a nude—no more than you saw the proverbial dead donkey!
一时间索姆斯勾勒出一幅几匹奄奄一息的驴驮着那些裸体画，正从世界的边缘走下来的景象。 Soames had a momentary vision of dying donkeys laden with pictures of the nude, stepping off the edge of the world.
他不想再胡思乱想，就放眼望去，恰巧看到圣保罗大教堂，就在眼前。 Refusing its extravagance, he raised his eyes, just in time to see St. Paul’s, as large as life.
那个卖气球的穷小子今天倒不在那里！ That little beggar with his balloons wasn’t there today!
嗯——他也没什么可给他的！ Well—he’d nothing for him!
顺着这个思路他的思维转到他这次出行的目的——天佑再保险公司和那半年度的账目。 At a tangent his thoughts turned towards the object of his pilgrimage—the P. P. R. S. and its half-year’s accounts.
在他的建议下，他们取消了那笔德国的批发生意——这令他们整整亏损了23万镑。 At his suggestion, they were writing off that German business wholesale—a dead loss of two hundred and thirty thousand pounds.
期中的股息不会发了，但即便是这样，他们也还得将一笔借记转到下半年度的账目中。 There would be no interim dividend, and even then they would be carrying forward a debit towards the next half-year.
嗯！还是应该把蛀牙立刻拔掉处理一下。那些股东们在开全体股东大会之前还有六个月的时间去慢慢适应。 Well! better have a rotten tooth out at once and done with; the shareholders would have six months to get used to the gap before the general meeting.
对此，他自己早已习惯，他们到时也会习惯的。 He himself had got used to it already, and so would they in time.
股东们除非受了惊吓，否则他们可不会随便惹事的——他们可是一群长期忍受苦难的人！ Shareholders were seldom nasty unless startled—a long-suffering lot!
在董事会的会议室里，那个老办事员依然还在把大墨水瓶的墨水灌到小墨水瓶里去。 In the board room the old clerk was still filling his inkpots from the magnum.
“经理在吗？” “Manager in?”
“在，先生。” “Yes, sir.”
“转告一声我已经来了，可以吗？” “Say I’m here, will you?”
老办事员出去了。 The old clerk withdrew.
索姆斯看了看钟表。 Soames looked at the clock.
12点了！ Twelve!
一道细小的斜阳照射到护墙板和地板上。 A little shaft of sunlight slanted down the wainscotting and floor.
房间里除了有一只青蝇和钟表的滴答声以外，再无其他有生气的东西了，甚至连份日报也没有。 There was nothing else alive in the room save a bluebottle and the tick of the clock; not even a daily paper.
索姆斯看了看那只青蝇。 Soames watched the bluebottle.
他回想自己的孩提时代，他更喜欢绿蝇和青蝇，而不是那些普通的苍蝇，因为它们有鲜艳的颜色。 He remembered how, as a boy, he had preferred bluebottles and green-bottles to the ordinary fly, because of their bright colour.
这是个教训。 It was a lesson.
那些外表过分华丽的东西和那些才华横溢的人都是危险的。 The showy things, the brilliant people, were the dangerous.
看看恺撒和那位金贵的意大利诗人——他叫什么名字来着！ Witness the Kaiser, and that precious Italian poet—what was his name!
还有他们自己的这位难以琢磨的人物！ And this Jack-o’-lantern of their own!
如果埃尔德森在个人生活方面很出色，他是不会感到惊讶的。 He shouldn’t be surprised if Elderson were brilliant in private life.
为什么这个家伙还没来啊？ Why didn’t the chap come?
是不是那次和年轻人巴特菲尔德见面让他踌躇了。 Was that encounter with young Butterfield giving him pause?
那只青蝇慢慢爬上窗户，嗡嗡地掉下来，又慢慢地爬上去，阳光偷偷地照进来落在地板上。 The bluebottle crawled up the pane, buzzed down, crawled up again; the sunlight stole inward along the floor.
这间会议室犹如真空一般，似乎彰显着保险业的原则：“一切维持现状。” All was vacuous in the board room, as though embodying the principle of insurance: “Keep things as they are.”
“我可不能老在这儿等着。”索姆斯一边想着，一边朝窗口走去。 ‘Can’t kick my heels here for ever,’ thought Soames, and moved to the window.
在那条通向河边的宽阔大街上，阳光照射的街上有几个行人和一辆运啤酒的汽车，但在大街尽头的主干道上，车辆行人川流不息，喧哗吵闹。 In that wide street leading to the river, sunshine illumined a few pedestrians and a brewer’s dray, but along the main artery at the end the traffic streamed and rattled.
伦敦！ London!
一个怪异的地方！ A monstrous place!
全都上了保险了！ And all insured!
“30年后这里会变成什么样？”他想。 ‘What’ll it be like thirty years hence?’ he thought.
想到那时伦敦还是伦敦，可是自己却已不在，无法看见了！ To think that there would be London, without himself to see it!
他为这个地方感到悲哀，为他自己感到悲哀。 He felt sorry for the place, sorry for himself.
甚至老格雷德曼也会去世的。 Even old Gradman would be gone.
他想那些保险公司会处理后事，但是他自己不知道罢了。 He supposed the insurance societies would look after it, but he didn’t know.
这时，他突然感觉埃尔德森来了。 And suddenly he became aware of Elderson.
这个家伙看上去洋洋得意，穿着一身套装，胸前还带着一朵康乃馨。 The fellow looked quite jaunty, in a suit of dittoes and a carnation.
“福赛特先生，您在思考将来吗？” “Contemplating the future, Mr. Forsyte?”
“没有。”索姆斯说。 “No,” said Soames.
这个家伙怎么会清楚他的心思呢？ How had the fellow guessed his thoughts?
“很高兴您能来。 “I’m glad you’ve come in.
这给了我一个感谢您对公司所付出的辛劳的机会。 It gives me a chance to say how grateful I am for the interest you take in the concern.
难得啊。 It’s rare.
经理的工作可真是寂寞。” A manager has a lonely job.”
他是不是在嘲笑什么？ Was he mocking?
他看上去一副非常敏捷而又不可一世的样子。 He seemed altogether very spry and uppish.
轻松快乐的神情总是令索姆斯怀疑——通常来说这里面肯定有原因。 Light-heartedness always made Soames suspicious—there was generally some reason for it.
“如果每一位董事会成员都像您一样认真地对待工作，那我就可以睡得心安了。 “If every director were as conscientious as you, one would sleep in one’s bed.
我不妨跟您说，您没进董事会之前，我从董事会成员那儿得到的帮助——嗯——简直微乎其微。” I don’t mind telling you that the amount of help I got from the Board before you came on it was—well—negligible.”
奉承！ Flattery!
这家伙一定是想岔开话题！ The fellow must be leading up to something!
埃尔德森继续说： Elderson went on:
“我可以跟您说一些不能跟别人说的话：福赛特先生，公司业务的确不容乐观。 “I can say to you what I couldn’t say to any of the others: I’m not at all happy about business, Mr. Forsyte.
英国马上就会发现自己的真正处境了。” England is just about to discover the state she’s really in.”
索姆斯感觉到自己曾经的想法得到了令人惊讶的证实。 Faced with this startling confirmation of his own thoughts, Soames reacted.
“在我们未受到损害之前，抱怨是没用的，”他说，“英镑的价值还是较高的。 “No good crying out before we’re hurt,” he said; “the pound’s still high.
我们依旧坚挺。” We’re good stayers.”
“我担心将会处于困境。 “In the soup, I’m afraid.
如果不采取一些应急措施——我们将会束手无策。 If something drastic isn’t done—we SHALL stay there.
而任何的应急措施，就像你所知道的那样，都意味着在你获益之前必定经过瓦解和长期的歉收。” And anything drastic, as you know, means disorganisation and lean years before you reap reward.”
这家伙怎么能够一边说着这样的言论，同时又看起来像一枚新便士，红光满面呢？ How could the fellow talk like this, and look as bright and pink as a new penny?
这证实了索姆斯的推测，他并不在乎发生了什么。 It confirmed the theory that he didn’t care what happened.
于是，索姆斯突然间决定要试探一下。 And, suddenly, Soames resolved to try a shot.
“说到长期歉收——我倒想说，我觉得咱们有必要召开一次股东大会，分析这笔德国买卖的全部亏损情况。” “Talking of lean years—I came in to say that I think we must call a meeting of the shareholders over this dead loss of the German business.”
说这话时他低头看着地板，说完又迅速抬起头来。 He said it to the floor, and looked quickly up.
结果令人失望。 The result was disappointing.
经理那双浅灰色的眼睛碰到他的目光，毫无反应。 The manager’s light-grey eyes met his without a blink.
“我早就料到您会提出这个意见。”他说。 “I’ve been expecting that from you,” he said.
“该死的早就料到！”索姆斯心想，因为这个想法是他刚刚才想到的。 ‘The deuce you have!’ thought Soames, for it had but that moment come into his mind.
“无论怎样，都要召开一次，”经理继续说，“不过我担心董事会不喜欢这种做法。” “By all means call one,” went on the manager; “but I’m afraid the Board won’t like it.”
索姆斯忍住没有说出：“我也不喜欢。” Soames refrained from saying: ‘Nor do I.’
“福赛特先生，股东们也不会喜欢的。 “Nor the shareholders, Mr. Forsyte.
根据以往的经验，我发现告诉他们不愉快的事情越少，对大家越有好处。” In a long experience I’ve found that the less you rub their noses in anything unpleasant, the better for every one.”
“也许吧，”索姆斯因为听到了与之对立的言论而变得倔强，说道，“但这完全是逃避事实的陋习。” “That may be,” said Soames, stiffening in contrariety; “but it’s all a part of the vice of not facing things.”
“福赛特先生，我想您将来不会埋怨我没有面对事实吧。” “I don’t think, Mr. Forsyte, that you will accuse ME of not facing things, in the time to come.”
将来！ Time to come!
现在，这家伙说这话是什么意思？ Now, what on earth did the fellow mean by that?
“嗯，我将在下次董事会上提出讨论此事。”他说。 “Well, I shall moot it at the next Board,” he said.
“太棒了！”经理说， “Quite!” said the manager.
“没有什么能够比得上把事情开诚布公地讲出来，不是吗？” “Nothing like bringing things to a head, is there?”
又是那种难以形容的嘲笑，似乎他在袖口里揣着绝招妙计。 Again that indefinable mockery, as if he had something up his sleeve.
索姆斯机械地看看那家伙的袖口——洗烫得很漂亮，上面有一条蓝色的条纹；他又看看他那洁白亚麻细布的背心，还有那条鸟眼花纹的领带——简直就是一个花花公子。 Soames looked mechanically at the fellow’s cuffs—beautifully laundered, with a blue stripe; at his holland waistcoat, and his bird’s-eye tie—a regular dandy.
他还要再攻击他一次！ He would give him a second barrel!
“顺便说一句，”他说，“蒙特写了本书。 “By the way,” he said, “Mont’s written a book.
我买了一本。” I’ve taken a copy.”
毫无反应！ Not a blink!
他只微露出牙齿，或许——是假的，毫无疑问！ A little more show of teeth, perhaps—false, no doubt!
“我买了两本——可怜的、亲爱的蒙特！” “I’ve taken two—poor, dear Mont!”
索姆斯有一种溃败的感觉。 Soames had a sense of defeat.
这个家伙把自己武装得像一只螃蟹，光滑得像一张西班牙式的桌子。 This chap was armoured like a crab, varnished like a Spanish table.
“好的，”他说，“我得走了。” “Well,” he said, “I must go.”
经理伸出手来。 The manager held out his hand.
“福赛特先生，再见。 “Good-bye, Mr. Forsyte.
我非常感激您。” I’m so grateful to you.”
这家伙竟然真的紧握他双手。 The fellow was actually squeezing his hand.
索姆斯头脑混乱地向外走去。 Soames went out confused.
他的手被别人这样紧握倒是罕见的！ To have his hand squeezed was so rare!
用握手来削弱他的意志。 It undermined him.
或许用握手预示这次完美的表演圆满结束。 And yet, it might be the crown of a consummate bit of acting.
他说不清了。 He couldn’t tell.
不管怎样，相比以前，他更加不愿提议召开股东大会了。 He had, however, less intention even than before of moving for a meeting of the shareholders.
不，不！ No, no!
刚才只是想激一下他，结果却失败了。 That had just been a shot to get a rise; and it had failed.
不过巴特菲尔德那一下肯定是击中了！ But the Butterfield shot had gone home, surely!
如果他真是清白的，埃尔德森一定会提起那个年轻人拜访他是多么厚颜无耻。 If innocent, Elderson must certainly have alluded to the impudence of the young man’s call.
然而竟无法激怒这样一个可恶的家伙，反而让他戏弄了一番！ And yet such a cool card was capable of failing to rise, just to tease you!
不！ No!
不行——就像人们现在说的那样。 Nothing doing—as they said nowadays.
他还是跟以前一样，让人抓不到一点儿把柄，而且说实话，反而为此很高兴。 He was as far as ever from a proof of guilt; and to speak truth, glad of it.
这样的丑闻，除了让整个公司、董事们和大家难堪之外，没有什么意义。 Such a scandal could serve no purpose save that of blackening the whole concern, directors and all.
人们向来漠不关心，从来不停下来思考，或者分清是非得失。 People were so careless, they never stopped to think, or apportion blame where it was due.
提高警觉，一切顺其自然！ Keep a sharp eye open, and go on as they were!
树敌结怨没有好处！ No good stirring hornets’ nests!
他一边入神地想着，一边走着，突然有人对他说： He had got so far in thought and progress, when a voice said:
“福赛特，幸会！ “Well met, Forsyte!
你是来找我吗？” Are you going my way?”
“老蒙特”此时正从“轻蔑”俱乐部的台阶上走下来！ “Old Mont,” coming down the steps of ‘Snooks’!
“我不清楚。”索姆斯说。 “I don’t know,” said Soames.
“我正要离开这儿去飞机俱乐部吃午饭。” “I’m off to the Aeroplane for lunch.”
“那个新流行的地方吗？” “That new-fangled place?”
“出名了，你知道吗，福赛特——出名了。” “Rising, you know, Forsyte—rising.”
“我刚见埃尔德森了。 “I’ve just been seeing Elderson.
他买了两本你写的书。” He’s bought two copies of your book.”
“上帝！ “Dear me!
可怜的家伙！” Poor fellow!”
索姆斯淡淡地笑了笑。 Soames smiled faintly.
“这正是他形容你的话！ “That’s what he said of you!
可是你猜，是谁把你写的书卖给他的？ And who d’you think sold them to him?
是年轻人巴特菲尔德。” Young Butterfield.”
“他还活着？” “Is he still alive?”
“他今天早晨还活着。” “He was, this morning.”
劳伦斯爵士的表情扭曲了一下： Sir Lawrence’s face took on a twist:
“福赛特，我一直在想。 “I’ve been thinking, Forsyte.
人家告诉我埃尔德森有两个女人。” They tell me Elderson keeps two women.”
索姆斯瞪着双眼。 Soames stared.
这个说法很有吸引力，可以说明一切。 The idea was attractive; would account for everything.
“福赛特，我妻子说他养得太多了。 “My wife says it’s one too many, Forsyte.
你觉得呢？” What do you say?”
“我？”索姆斯说， “I?” said Soames.
“我只知道这家伙镇定自若。 “I only know the chap’s as cool as a cucumber.
我要进去了。 I’m going in here.
再见！” Good-bye!”
不要奢望从这位男爵身上得到一丝帮助，他对任何事情都不上心。 One could get no help from that baronet fellow; he couldn’t take anything seriously.
两个女人！ Two women!
埃尔德森这样的年纪！ At Elderson’s age!
这是何等的生活啊！ What a life!
世界上总有一类人，不能从一而终——过着冒险的生活。 There were always men like that, not content with one thing at a time—living dangerously.
这对他来说是不可思议的。 It was mysterious to him.
你可以对他进行反复观察，但是丝毫察觉不出什么。 You might look and look into chaps like that, and see nothing.
然而，他们就是那个样子！ And yet, there they were!
他穿过门厅，走进那间鉴赏家会员们吃午餐的房间里。 He crossed the hall, and went into the room where connoisseurs were lunching.
他从服务台拿了一张菜单，叫了一打牡蛎，但忽然想起这个月不是一年中最后一季的月份，想到这里，便把牡蛎改成了炸鳎目鱼。 Taking down the menu at the service table, he ordered himself a dozen oysters; but, suddenly remembering that the month contained no “r,” changed them to a fried sole.
第八章 Chapter VIII
举债出逃 Levanted
“不，亲爱的，大自然快‘完’了！” “No, dear heart, Nature’s ‘off’!”
“何出此言呢，迈克尔？” “How d’you mean, Michael?”
“唉，看看我们得到的几部描写‘大自然’的小说。 “Well, look at the Nature novels we get.
以科尼什山崖或约克郡荒野为背景，写一些依样画葫芦的东西——你曾经去过约克郡荒野吗？只要你见过，就会对它印象深刻的，还有达特穆尔高原特色的东西。 Sedulous stuff pitched on Cornish cliffs or Yorkshire moors—ever been on a Yorkshire moor?—it comes off on you; and the Dartmoor brand.
天哪！ Gosh!
达特穆尔高原，一切激情的来源——你曾经去过达特穆尔高原吗？ Dartmoor, where the passions come from—ever been on Dartmoor?
唉，你知道的，他们不是从那里来的。 Well, they don’t, you know.
还有南海的那伙人！ And the South Sea bunch!
啊，瞧啊，看啊！ Oh, la, la!
那些诗人，那些口若悬河、语无伦次的家伙，离大自然还远得很呢。 And the poets, the splash-and-splutter school don’t get within miles of Nature.
当然，乡村傻瓜派稍微好一些。 The village idiot school is a bit better, certainly.
毕竟，老华兹华斯创立了自然派，不过它是一帖镇静剂。 After all, old Wordsworth made Nature, and she’s a bromide.
当然，还有以小写字母“n”开头的原始的自然派，如果接触到那种自然派的话，你就要用毕生的精力来保全生命——至于我们胡扯的这个‘大自然’，它已经领了许可证，调制得恰到好处，并且装进瓶里了。 Of course, there’s raw nature with the small ‘n’; but if you come up against that, it takes you all your time to keep alive—the Nature we gas about is licensed, nicely blended and bottled.
不过就当代的风格而言，它还不够时髦。” She’s not modern enough for contemporary style.”
“哦！好吧，不管怎样，咱们还是去河边吧，迈克尔。 “Oh! well, let’s go on the river, anyway, Michael.
我们可以在‘棚屋’里喝点儿茶。” We can have tea at ‘The Shelter.’”
他们刚到被迈克尔称作“这个称心如意的住处”，弗勒就俯身向前，碰碰他的膝盖，说道： They were just reaching what Michael always called ‘this desirable residence,’ when Fleur leaned forward, and, touching his knee, said:
“我对你还没有你对我的一半好呢，迈克尔。” “I’m not half as nice to you as you deserve, Michael.”
“天啊，亲爱的！ “Good Lord, darling!
我觉得你对我很好。” I thought you were.”
“我知道我很自私，特别是现在。” “I know I’m selfish; especially just now.”
“那只是第十一代准男爵的缘故。” “It’s only the eleventh baronet.”
“是，这是一个重大的责任。 “Yes; it’s a great responsibility.
我只希望他将来能像你。” I only hope he’ll be like you.”
迈克尔把船浮到了码头上，把双桨放入船内，然后，在她身边坐下。 Michael slid in to the landing-stage, shipped his sculls, and sat down beside her.
“如果他像我，我应该否认他是我的孩子。 “If he’s like me, I shall disown him.
儿子总是像母亲的。” But sons take after their mothers.”
“我指的是在性格方面。 “I meant in character.
我希望他活得快快乐乐而不浮躁，同时还要拥有真爱人生的情感。” I want him frightfully to be cheerful and not restless, and have the feeling that life’s worth while.”
迈克尔望着她的双唇——它们正在颤动；凝视她的脸颊，在午后的阳光下，脸颊呈现出棕褐色；然后，他侧身弯下去，把自己的脸贴在她的脸上。 Michael stared at her lips—they were quivering; at her cheek, slightly browned by the afternoon’s sunning; and, bending sideways, he put his own against it.
“他一定会是快乐的小家伙，我敢肯定。” “He’ll be a sunny little cuss, I’m certain.”
弗勒摇摇头。 Fleur shook her head.
“我不希望他贪婪或以自我为中心。你知道那是我血统里有的。 “I don’t want him greedy and self-centred; it’s in my blood, you know.
我知道这是丑恶的，但是我无能为力。 I can see it’s ugly, but I can’t help it.
你怎么能做到不这样呢？” How do you manage not to be?”
迈克尔用另一只手弄乱了自己的头发。 Michael ruffled his hair with his free hand.
“现在的阳光可以么，晒不晒，亲爱的？” “The sun isn’t too hot for you, is it, ducky?”
“不晒，说真的，迈克尔——你怎么做到的？” “No. Seriously, Michael—how?”
“我其实是这样的人。想想我追你时的样子。 “But I AM. Look at the way I want you.
什么都挡不住我。” Nothing will cure me of that.”
她用脸颊轻轻压了他的脸颊一下，这给了他鼓励，于是他接着说： A slight pressure of her cheek on his own was heartening, and he said:
“你还记得那天晚上吗？就是你从花园里出来，发现我就在这儿的一条小船里？ “Do you remember coming down the garden one night, and finding me in a boat just here?
那天你走后，我就头朝下倒立着，让自己头脑清醒一下。 When you’d gone, I stood on my head, to cool it.
当时我处于困境中，以为自己没希望了——”他停住了。 I was on my uppers; I didn’t think I’d got an earthly—” He stopped.
不！ No!
他不想唤起她对往事的回忆，但就是那天晚上，她说：“等我知道我无法实现自己的愿望时再来吧！” He would not remind her, but that was the night when she said: “Come again when I know I can’t get my wish!”
那个未曾相识的表哥！ The unknown cousin!
弗勒平静地说： Fleur said quietly:
“我对你太不好了，迈克尔，但是我当时非常不开心。 “I was a pig to you, Michael, but I was awfully unhappy.
都过去了。 That’s gone.
终于过去了，现在，除了我自己的性情之外，没什么问题了。” It’s gone at last; there’s nothing wrong now, except my own nature.”
迈克尔认为现在不是表露情感的时候，于是说道： Conscious that his feelings betrayed the period, Michael said:
“噢！那就好！ “Oh! if that’s all!
喝点儿茶怎么样？” What price tea?”
他们手挽手走上草坪。 They went up the lawn arm-inarm.
家里没人——索姆斯在伦敦，安妮特出去参加园游会了。 Nobody was at home—Soames in London, Annette at a garden party.
“我们在阳台上喝茶，好吗？”弗勒说。 “We’ll have tea on the verandah, please,” said Fleur.
迈克尔坐在那里，感觉到了从未有过的快乐。他不禁承认万物各有各的价值，那是大自然悄悄投射下的阳光，还有石竹花和玫瑰的香气以及白杨树丛中的叹息声。 Sitting there, happier than he ever remembered being, Michael conceded a certain value to Nature, to the sunshine stealing down, the scent of pinks and roses, the sighing in the aspens.
安妮特的宠物鸽子正咕咕地叫着，在静静流淌的河流那边，白杨树耸立在较远的河流两岸。 Annette’s pet doves were cooing; and, beyond the quietly-flowing river, the spires of poplar trees rose along the further bank.
但是，毕竟，因为有这位他如此深爱的姑娘在身边，他才会欣赏眼前的一切，而且，还因为他第一次感觉到她似乎不想从他身边飞走投入到其他人或其他事的怀抱。 But, after all, he was only enjoying them because of the girl beside him, whom he loved to touch and look at, and because, for the first time, he felt as if she did not want to get up and flutter off to some one or something else.
奇怪的是，除了他自己之外，还有一个人使这个世界变得不再重要，好像“拆穿了”整个“西洋镜”——这个人就是他的妻子！ Curious that there could be, outside oneself, a being who completely robbed the world of its importance, ‘snooped,’ as it were, the whole ‘bag of tricks’—and she one’s own wife!
其实仔细想想，这真是件奇妙的事！ Very curious, considering what one was!
他听见她说： He heard her say:
“当然，母亲是个天主教徒；只不过，和父亲一起住在这儿，她才不再举行仪式了。 “Of course, mother’s a Catholic; only, living with father down here, she left off practising.
她甚至都不太管我了。 She didn’t even bother me much.
我一直在想，迈克尔——我们应该对孩子做些什么呢？” I’ve been thinking, Michael—what shall we do about HIM?”
“顺其自然吧。” “Let him rip.”
“我不知道。 “I don’t know.
一定要教他些什么，因为要去学校的。 He must be taught something, because of going to school.
你知道的，那些天主教徒真的能从他们的宗教信仰中有所收获。” The Catholics, you know, really do get things out of their religion.”
“是的，他们是盲目接受。如今这是唯一符合逻辑的事。” “Yes; they go it blind; it’s the only logical way now.”
“我认为一个人没有宗教信仰会对什么事都不在乎。” “I think having no religion makes one feel that nothing matters.”
迈克尔忍住没说这句话：“我们可以把他培养成太阳崇拜者。”而是改口说： Michael suppressed the words: ‘We could bring him up as a sun-worshipper,’ and said, instead:
“依我看，无论教他什么，都只能在他具有独立思考能力之前进行，之后他自己就会做适合自己的事。” “It seems to me that whatever he’s taught will only last till he can think for himself; then he’ll settle down to what suits him.”
“可是你是怎么看的呢，迈克尔？ “But what do YOU think about things, Michael?
你可不比我认识的任何一个人差啊。” You’re as good as any one I know.”
“哦！”迈克尔感到特别荣幸，低声道：“真是这样吗？” “Gosh!” murmured Michael, strangely flattered: “Is that so?”
“你怎么想的？ “What DO you think?
我是认真的！” Be serious!”
“嗯，亲爱的，从教义上说什么也没有——当然，这是说我没有宗教信仰。 “Well, darling, doctrinally nothing—which means, of course, that I haven’t got religion.
我认为一个人必须正大光明——不过这只是道德标准。” I believe one has to play the game—but that’s ethics.”
“可是，一个人除了自己之外就没有别的依靠了，也没什么好处吧？ “But surely it’s a handicap not to be able to rely on anything but oneself?
如果从某个宗教信仰中还能得到什么，那么，还是有信仰的好。” If there’s something to be had out of any form of belief, one might as well have it.”
迈克尔觉得好笑，但是没有表现出来。 Michael smiled, but not on the surface.
“对于第十一代准男爵，你喜欢怎样培养就怎样培养吧，总之，我支持你。 “You’re going to do just as you like about the eleventh baronet, and I’m going to abet you.
但是，就他的血统而言——我认为他多少带有怀疑论者的特点。” But considering his breeding—I fancy he’ll be a bit of a sceptic.”
“但我不想他成为这样的人。 “But I don’t WANT him to be.
我宁愿他生活舒适，信仰宗教等等。 I’d rather he were snug, and convinced and all that.
怀疑论者只会使人不安定。” Scepticism only makes one restless.”
“他身上没有白猿的气息吗？ “No white monkey in him?
啊！ Ah!
我想知道！ I wonder!
我觉得这很难说。 It’s in the air, I guess.
唯一的办法就是从小教育他要关心他人，越早越好，如果有必要，可以用拖鞋打。” The only thing will be to teach him a sense of other people, as young as possible, with a slipper, if necessary.”
弗勒看了他一眼，笑了起来。 Fleur gave him a clear look, and laughed.
“是的。”她说，“母亲常这样做，可是父亲不同意。” “Yes,” she said: “Mother used to try, but father wouldn’t let her.”
过了8点，他们才回到家。 They did not reach home till past eight o’clock.
“不是你父亲在这里，就是我父亲在这里。”迈克尔在门厅里说，“那儿有一顶古老不堪的帽子。” “Either your father’s here, or mine,” said Michael, in the hall; “there’s a prehistoric hat.”
“是我爸爸的。 “It’s Dad’s.
他那顶是灰色衬里的。 His is grey inside.
准爵爷的那顶是浅黄色的。” Bart’s is buff.”
不出所料，他们在那间中国式的房间里发现了索姆斯，他手里握着一封拆开的信，小叮铃在他的脚旁。 In the Chinese room Soames indeed was discovered, with an opened letter, and Ting-a-ling at his feet.
他一言不发地把信递给了迈克尔。 He held the letter out to Michael, without a word.
信上没有日期，也没有地址。迈克尔读道： There was no date, and no address; Michael read:
“亲爱的福赛特先生——烦请您在下周二的会议上告知董事会，我已经脱身而去，不承担可能因我的过错给公司带来的损失了。 “DEAR MR. FORSYTE.—Perhaps you will be good enough to tell the Board at the meeting on Tuesday that I am on my way to immunity from the consequences of any peccadillo I may have been guilty of.
您收到这封信时，我已经到达那里了。 By the time you receive this, I shall be there.
我一直认为人生的秘密和做生意一样，就是知道什么时候不该停下来。 I have always held that the secret of life, no less than that of business, is to know when not to stop.
对我起诉没有用，因为你们逮不到我，我相信你们在法律上是这么说的吧，同时我也没留下任何财产。 It will be no use to proceed against me, for my person will not be attachable, as I believe you call it in the law, and I have left no property behind.
如果您想把我逼得走投无路，那我对您的策略不敢苟同。 If your object was to corner me, I cannot congratulate you on your tactics.
从另一方面说，如果您鼓动那个年轻人来访问我，作为您继续追究此事的一个警告，那我除了几天前见到您时对您表示感谢以外，我还愿意再次向您表示感谢。 If, on the other hand, you inspired that young man’s visit as a warning that you were still pursuing the matter, I should like to add new thanks to those which I expressed when I saw you a few days ago.
“相信我，亲爱的福赛特先生， “Believe me, dear Mr. Forsyte,
“您忠实的， “Faithfully yours,
“罗伯特·埃尔德森。” “ROBERT ELDERSON.”
迈克尔高兴地说： Michael said cheerfully:
“愉快的解脱！ “Happy release!
现在您会感到安全些了，先生。” Now you’ll feel safer, sir.”
索姆斯用手摸了摸脸，显然是想把脸上的表情抹掉。 Soames passed his hand over his face, evidently wiping off its expression.
“这件事情我们以后再谈吧。”他说， “We’ll discuss it later,” he said.
“这条狗一直和我做伴。” “This dog’s been keeping me company.”
此时，迈克尔很敬佩他。 Michael admired him at that moment.
很显然，他怕弗勒不舒服，才硬把苦水往肚里咽。 He was obviously swallowing his ‘grief,’ to save Fleur.
“弗勒有点儿累了。”他说， “Fleur’s a bit tired,” he said.
“我们到河上去了，还在‘棚屋’喝了茶。夫人不在家。 “We’ve been on the river, and had tea at ‘The Shelter’; Madame wasn’t in.
我们马上吃晚饭吧，弗勒。” Let’s have dinner at once, Fleur.”
