弗勒已经把小叮铃抱起来了，还和它保持一段距离，这样它贪婪的舌头不至于碰到她的脸。 Fleur had picked up Ting-a-ling, and was holding her face out of reach of his avid tongue.
“很抱歉，让您久等了，爸爸。”她在小叮铃的黄色皮毛后面低声说道，“我去梳洗一下就行，不换衣服了。” “Sorry you’ve had to wait, Dad,” she murmured, behind the yellow fur; “I’m just going to wash; shan’t change.”
她走之后，索姆斯伸手来拿信。 When she had gone, Soames reached for the letter.
“真是乱七八糟!”他抱怨道， “A pretty kettle of fish!” he muttered.
“这事结局会怎样，我也说不好！” “Where it’ll end, I can’t tell!”
“但这不就是结局吗，先生？” “But isn’t this the end, sir?”
索姆斯瞪着眼睛。 Soames stared.
这些年轻人！ These young people!
他陷入这种境地，面对一桩公众热议的丑事，会造成什么样的后果，他也不清楚——也许会让他在伦敦身败名裂，倾家荡产。而他们却把这似乎当作—— Here he was, faced with a public scandal, which might lead to he didn’t know what—the loss of his name in the city, the loss of his fortune, perhaps; and they took it as if—!
他们没有责任感——一点儿没有！ They had no sense of responsibility—none!
在鉴赏家俱乐部收到这封信后，他父亲的预测最恶劣情况的能力以及詹姆士神经质的悲观主义，都在他的脑海里激荡着。 All his father’s power of seeing the worst, all James’ nervous pessimism, had come to the fore in him during the hour since, at the Connoisseur’s Club, he had been handed that letter.
只是因为詹姆士沿袭了他们这代人行事更加“拘谨”的特质，所以在弗勒离开房间后，他仍未表露出一丝忧郁。 Only the extra ‘form’ of the generation that succeeded James saved him, now that Fleur was out of the room, from making an exhibition of his fears.
“你爸爸在城里吗？” “Your father in town?”
“我想是的，先生。” “I believe so, sir.”
“好！” “Good!”
他并未因此松了口气。 Not that he felt relief.
准男爵也是个不负责任的家伙——把他弄进那个董事会里！ That baronet chap was just as irresponsible—getting him to go on that Board!
这全是因为他们从小混迹于那些轻率、无可救药的人，一起长大，才闹出这档事，他们根本不知道财富来之不易。 It all came of mixing with people brought up in a sort of incurable levity, with no real feeling for money.
“既然埃尔德森已经举债出逃了，”他说，“就不得不把整件事揭露出来。 “Now that Elderson’s levanted,” he said, “the whole thing must come out.
他的自供状就在我手里——” Here’s his confession in my hand—”
“为什么不把它撕掉，先生，就说埃尔德森患了肺结核呢？” “Why not tear it up, sir, and say Elderson has developed consumption?”
这个年轻人做什么事都表现出不认真的态度，这让索姆斯像吃了不消化的布丁一样苦恼不堪。 The impossibility of getting anything serious from this young man afflicted Soames like the eating of heavy pudding.
“你认为那样做是光明正大的吗？”他厉声说道。 “You think that would be honourable?” he said grimly.
“抱歉，先生！”迈克尔头脑清醒了一些，说道， “Sorry, sir!” said Michael, sobered.
“有什么我可以帮忙的吗？” “Can I help at all?”
“有。丢掉你轻率处事的态度，不能让弗勒听到有关此事的任何风吹草动。” “Yes; by dropping your levity, and taking care to keep wind of this matter away from Fleur.”
“我一定做到。”迈克尔真诚地说，“我向您保证。 “I will,” said Michael, earnestly: “I promise you.
我会像荷兰牡蛎那样把这件事密封住。 I’ll Dutch-oyster the whole thing.
您打算采取什么方针呢？” What’s your line going to be?”
“我得召集股东，向大家解释这笔靠不住的买卖。 “We shall have to call the shareholders together and explain this dicky-dealing.
他们很可能会因此大闹一场。” They’ll very likely take it in bad part.”
“我不明白他们为什么要闹。 “I can’t see why they should.
您有什么办法吗？” How could you have helped it?”
索姆斯嗤之以鼻。 Soames sniffed.
“人生中，报酬和应得的赏罚之间没有什么联系。 “There’s no connection in life between reward and your deserts.
如果大战还没教会你这个，那么没什么事情会让你明白了。” If the war hasn’t taught you that, nothing will.”
“哦。”迈克尔说，“弗勒就要下来了。 “Well,” said Michael, “Fleur will be down directly.
请您原谅，我们有机会再谈吧。” If you’ll excuse me a minute; we’ll continue it in our next.”
直到弗勒上床睡觉了，他们才有机会继续谈。 Their next did not occur till Fleur had gone to bed.
“好了，先生。”迈克尔说，“我猜我爸爸应该在飞机俱乐部呢。 “Now, sir,” said Michael, “I expect my governor’s at the Aeroplane.
他到那冥想世界末日去了。 He goes there and meditates on the end of the world.
如果你们明天召开董事会的话，用不用我给他打个电话？” Would you like me to ring him up, if your Board meeting’s tomorrow?”
索姆斯点点头。 Soames nodded.
他自己是睡不好觉了——为什么就让“老蒙特”睡个安稳觉呢？ He himself would not sleep a wink—why should ‘Old Mont’?
迈克尔朝那个中式茶柜走去。 Michael went to the Chinese tea chest.
“准爵爷吗？ “Bart?
我是迈克尔。 This is Michael.
老福——我岳父在这呢，他遇到一件讨厌的事…… Old For—my father-inlaw is here; he’s had a pill....
不，是埃尔德森。 No; Elderson.
您能否来听听？ Could you blow in by any chance and hear?...
他一会儿就来，先生。 He’s coming, sir.
我们是在这等呢，还是上楼去我的书房？” Shall we stay down, or go up to my study?”
“在楼下吧。”索姆斯轻声说，他盯着那只白猿， “Down,” muttered Soames, whose eyes were fixed on the white monkey.
“我不知道我们会落到什么地步。”他突然又说了一句。 “I don’t know what we’re all coming to,” he added, suddenly.
“先生，如果我们知道的话，我们会很无聊的。” “If we did, sir, we should die of boredom.”
“这是为你自己辩护。 “Speak for yourself.
一切都靠不住！ All this unreliability!
我真不知道之后的生活会变成什么样。” I can’t tell where it’s leading.”
“也许还有某个地方，先生，那里既不是天堂，也不是地狱。” “Perhaps there’s somewhere, sir, that’s neither heaven nor hell.”
“一个他那样年纪的人！” “A man of HIS age!”
“和我爸爸同龄，这是个坏家伙，我想。 “Same age as my dad; it was a bad vintage, I expect.
如果您参加过大战，先生，您会永远乐观向上的。” If you’d been in the war, sir, it would have cheered you up no end.”
“的确！”索姆斯说。 “Indeed!” said Soames.
“战争把车轴都卸掉了——这我承认。但是，我的天哪！当你面临极大困难时，它确实能让你有更大的勇气。” “It took the linch-pins out of the cart—admitted; but, my Lord! it did give you an idea of the grit there is about, when it comes to being up against it.”
索姆斯瞪着眼睛。 Soames stared.
这小子是不是想借克服悲观主义而教训他一顿？ Was this young fellow reading him a lesson against pessimism?
“看看那天那个年轻人巴特菲尔德吧。”迈克尔继续说，“他果断地去找了埃尔德森！ “Look at young Butterfield, the other day,” Michael went on, “going over the top, to Elderson!
看看您给我们买的那幅‘裸体’画里做模特的姑娘！ Look at the girl who sat for ‘the altogether’ in that picture you bought us!
她是我们以前雇佣的一个包装工的老婆，那个包装工因偷书而被开除了。 She’s the wife of a packer we had, who got hoofed for snooping books.
她当裸体画模特挣了一笔钱，却从未失掉自己的尊严。 She made quite a lot of money by standing for the nude, and never lost her wicket.
他们靠这笔钱到澳大利亚去了。 They’re going to Australia on it.
对了，再看看那个小偷本人，他为了让她能在患过肺结核后活下去才去偷书的，结果沦落到卖气球的境地。” Yes, and look at that little snooper himself; he snooped to keep her alive after pneumonia, and came down to selling balloons.”
“我不明白你在讲些什么东西。”索姆斯说。 “I don’t know what you’re talking about,” said Soames.
“就是坚韧的勇气，先生。 “Only grit, sir.
您刚才说不知道我们会沦落到何种地步。 You said you didn’t know what we were coming to.
嗯，看看那些失业的人！ Well, look at the unemployed!
世界上有没有一个国家失业的人能像他们在这里一样如此坚韧呢？ Is there a country in the world where they stick it as they do here?
我常常为自己是个英国人而感到勇气倍增呢。 I get awfully bucked at being English every now and then.
您呢？” Don’t you?”
这句话触动了索姆斯内心的某些东西，但是，他丝毫没有表露出来，他依旧凝视着白猿。 The words stirred something deep in Soames; but, far from giving it away, he continued to gaze at the white monkey.
这畜生的双眼不安定，无人性，却又如此通人情，愤怒而悲哀！ The restless, inhuman, and yet so human, angry sadness of the creature’s eyes!
“那双眼睛一点儿眼白也没有！”索姆斯心想，“原因就在于此吧，我想！” ‘No whites to them!’ thought Soames: ‘that’s what does it, I expect!’
而乔治却喜欢把这幅画挂在床的对面！ And George had liked that picture to hang opposite his bed!
嗯，乔治有勇气——临死还讲笑话：十足的英国人，乔治！ Well, George had grit—joked with his last breath: very English, George!
所有福赛特家的人都是十足的英国人！ Very English, all the Forsytes!
老乔里恩叔叔和他对付股东们的办法；斯悦辛，笔挺地坐在蒂莫西家的那把小扶手椅里，这使他的身材显得更加臃肿，嘴里说着：“所有这些小娃娃们！”他仿佛又听到了这句话；还有尼古拉叔叔，埃尔德森那家伙就像是他的翻版，其实他不配，因为尼古拉机敏、好色，但绝没有一点儿不诚实。 Old Uncle Jolyon, and his way with shareholders; Swithin, upright, puffy, huge in a too little arm-chair at Timothy’s: ‘All these small fry!’ he seemed to hear the words again; and Uncle Nicholas, whom that chap Elderson reproduced as it were unworthily, spry and all-there, and pretty sensual, but quite above suspicion of dishonesty.
还有老罗杰和他那古怪的脾气，以及德国羊肉！ And old Roger, with his crankiness, and German mutton!
还有他的父亲，詹姆士——他是多么能坚持，尽管他身材瘦弱得像一根芦秆，但还是一再坚持了！ And his own father, James—how he had hung on, long and frail as a reed, hung on and on!
还有蒂莫西，靠统一公债维持生活，活了一百岁呢！ And Timothy, preserved in Consols, dying at a hundred!
在老一辈英国人的身上，尽管有些可笑的作风，但是他们拥有勇气和身体。 Grit and body in those old English boys, in spite of their funny ways.
这时，似乎唤起了索姆斯体内隔代遗传的意志力。 And there stirred in Soames a sort of atavistic will-power.
他想看看，他们也想看看——事情就是如此！ He would see, and they would see—and that was all about it!
一辆出租车的刹车声使他从沉思中惊醒。 The grinding of a taxi’s wheels brought him back from reverie.
“老蒙特”大摇大摆地走进来，毋庸置疑，他还和以前一样头脑简单。 Here came ‘Old Mont,’ tittuppy, and light in the head as ever, no doubt.
索姆斯没有把手伸过去，而是把埃尔德森的那封信递给他。 And, instead of his hand, Soames held out Elderson’s letter.
“你的那位宝贝同学举债出逃了。”他说。 “Your precious schoolfellow’s levanted,” he said.
劳伦斯爵士把信读了一遍，吹了声口哨。 Sir Lawrence read it through, and whistled.
“你怎么想，福赛特——君士坦丁堡吗？” “What do you think, Forsyte—Constantinople?”
“更可能是蒙特卡洛。”索姆斯沮丧地说， “More likely Monte Carlo,” said Soames gloomily.
“秘密佣金——这不是一个可引渡的罪名。” “Secret commission—it’s not an extraditable offence.”
准男爵古怪别扭的样子溢于言表，这让他有了一点儿快感。——毕竟，这家伙也感觉到这事情的严重性了。 The odd contortions of that baronet’s face were giving him some pleasure—the fellow seemed to be feeling it, after all.
“我倒认为他是想避开那两个女人才出走的，福赛特。” “I should think he’s really gone to escape his women, Forsyte.”
这家伙真是不可救药！ The chap was incorrigible!
索姆斯使劲耸了耸肩膀。 Soames shrugged his shoulders almost violently.
“你最好能明白。”他说，“事情已经被搞糟了。” “You’d better realise,” he said, “that the fat is in the fire.”
“不过可以肯定，我亲爱的福赛特，自从法国人侵占了鲁尔之后，局势一直就是这样。 “But surely, my dear Forsyte, it’s been there ever since the French occupied the Ruhr.
埃尔德森已经出逃了，我们再任命其他人吧。 Elderson has cut his lucky; we appoint some one else.
此外还有什么呢？” What more is there to it?”
索姆斯有一种感觉，自己好像老实过头了。 Soames had the peculiar feeling of having overdone his own honesty.
如果一个正派的人，第九代准男爵，都看不出埃尔德森自白中的暗示，那么是不是真的有暗示这回事呢？ If an honourable man, a ninth baronet, couldn’t see the implications of Elderson’s confession, were they really there?
任何混乱或绯闻都有必要吗？ Was any fuss and scandal necessary?
老天为证，他不希望这样！ Goodness knew, HE didn’t want it!
他悲伤地说： He said heavily:
“我们现在已经掌握了一个诈骗犯的确凿证据，我们还了解到埃尔德森在成交生意中获得了非法佣金，然而股东们却因此蒙受了极大损失。 “We now have conclusive evidence of a fraud; we KNOW Elderson was illegally paid for putting through business by which the shareholders have suffered a dead loss.
我们怎么能瞒住这个事实不让大家知道呢？” How can we keep this knowledge from them?”
“但是损失已经造成了，福赛特。 “But the mischief’s done, Forsyte.
他们知道了又有什么用呢？” How will the knowledge help them?”
索姆斯皱起了眉头。 Soames frowned.
“我们处于受信托的地位。 “We’re in a fiduciary position.
我不准备冒隐瞒不报的风险。 I’m not prepared to run the risks of concealment.
如果我们隐瞒不报，我们就是这件事的从犯了。 If we conceal, we’re accessory after the fact.
这件事随时都有可能被泄露出去。” The thing might come out at any time.”
如果只是出于谨慎，而不是忠诚，那他也没辙了。 If that was caution, not honesty, he couldn’t help it.
“我觉得如果能保全埃尔德森的名誉是最好了。 “I should be glad to spare Elderson’s name.
我们曾经在——” We were at—”
“这我知道。”索姆斯冷冷地说。 “I’m aware of that,” said Soames, drily.
“可是这件事有什么泄露出去的危险呢，福赛特？ “But what risk is there of its coming out, Forsyte?
埃尔德森不会提的，如果你不提小巴特菲尔德的话，他也不会说的。 Elderson won’t mention it; nor young Butterfield, if you tell him not to.
那些付佣金的人当然更不会提的。 Those who paid the commission certainly won’t.
这样，除了我们三人之外，再没人知道了。 And beyond us three here, no one else knows.
不管怎样，我们似乎不会从这件事上得到好处吧。” It’s not as if we profited in any way.”
索姆斯沉默不语了。 Soames was silent.
这个论据有点儿似是而非。 The argument was specious.
当然，要他为埃尔德森做的事受罚，完全不合情理！ Entirely unjust, of course, that he should be penalised for what Elderson had done!
“不。”他突然说，“这样不行。 “No,” he said, suddenly, “it won’t do.
违反了法律，那你就不知道将来会落到什么下场了。 Depart from the law, and you can’t tell where it’ll end.
股东们已经蒙受了损失，他们有权知道董事们知道的一切事实。 The shareholders have suffered this loss, and they have the right to all the facts within the directors’ knowledge.
或许会有能为他们做出赔偿的办法。 There might be some means of restitution they could avail themselves of.
我们无法判断。 We can’t judge.
说不定他们会提出一个补救的办法。” It may be they’ve a remedy against ourselves.”
“如果是那样的话，福赛特，我和你站在一起。” “If that’s so, Forsyte, I’m with you.”
索姆斯感到很厌烦。 Soames felt disgust.
蒙特根本不配摆出一副豪侠的样子，却不去计算一下损失，如果有损失，需要为此负担的话，也不会落在蒙特身上，因为他的土地已经被抵押了，反而债务会落在自己的身上，因为他的财产很容易变成现款。 Mont had no business to put it with a sort of gallantry that didn’t count the cost; when the cost, if cost there were, would fall, not on Mont, whose land was heavily mortgaged, but on himself, whose property was singularly realisable.
“好吧。”他冷冷地说，“明天可要记住这件事。 “Well,” he said, coldly, “remember that tomorrow.
我准备上床睡觉了。” I’m going to bed.”
在楼上，他站在打开的窗子旁，他并未感到自己做了一件善事，但是他享受着安宁带来的快乐。 At his open window upstairs he felt no sense of virtue, but he enjoyed a sort of peace.
他采取了自己的方针，就照这样去办！ He had taken his line, and there it was!
第九章 Chapter IX
索姆斯毫不在乎 Soames Doesn’t Give a Damn
收到埃尔德森那封信后的一个月里，索姆斯老了不少。 During the month following the receipt of Elderson’s letter, Soames aged more than thirty days.
他已经迫使充满怀疑的董事会接受了他提出的揭露事实真相的方针，同时还发出了召开特别会议的通知。正如23年前，为了争取与伊琳离婚，他不得不在大庭广众面前颜面扫地一样，这一回他寝食难安，害怕众人是非不分的目光。 He had forced his policy of disclosure on a doubting Board, the special meeting had been called, and, just as, twenty-three years ago, pursuing divorce from Irene, he had to face the public eye, so now he suffered day and night in dread of that undiscriminating optic.
法国人有一句谚语：“不在场的人总是错的！”但是，索姆斯对这句话持怀疑态度。 The French had a proverb: “Les absents ont toujours tort!” but Soames had grave doubts about it.
埃尔德森不会出席这次股东大会了，但是——除非是他犯了很大错误——即便是他亲自出席，也会备受责备。 Elderson would be absent from that meeting of the shareholders, but—unless he was much mistaken—he himself, who would be present, would come in for the blame.
法国人靠不住。 The French were not to be relied on.
他为弗勒的担忧，同时为公众的看法感到不安，吃不好，睡不好，感觉很不舒服。 What with his anxiety about Fleur, and his misgiving about the public eye, he was sleeping badly, eating little, and feeling below par.
安妮特曾经劝他去看看医生。 Annette had recommended him to see a doctor.
大概就是因为这个，他才不去的。 That was probably why he did not.
索姆斯对医生给别人看病很有信心，但是医生们从来没有——他说——为他做过任何事，可能因为到目前为止，还没有什么事情可做。 Soames had faith in doctors for other people; but they had never—he would say—done anything for HIM, possibly because, so far, there had not been anything to do.
安妮特由于自己的建议未被接受，同时又发现他越来越难以接近，就给了他一本论述库埃的书。 Failing in her suggestion, and finding him every day less sociable, Annette had given him a book on Coue.
他匆匆看过后，本想把这本书丢在火车上，可这个理论，不管它如何不合理，不知为什么总是缠着他。 After running it through, he had meant to leave it in the train, but the theory, however extravagant, had somehow clung to him.
毕竟，弗勒正在用此疗法，而且这又没花你一分钱，这里面讲的或许有点儿道理！ After all, Fleur was doing it; and the thing cost you nothing: there might be something in it!
或许有道理。 There was.
那天夜里，他默念了25遍自己会越来越好之后，竟然睡得酣畅淋漓，他的鼾声甚至打扰了隔壁房间里的安妮特，让她无法入睡。 After telling himself that night twenty-five times that he was getting better and better, he slept so soundly that Annette, in the next room, hardly slept at all.
“你知道吗，我的朋友。”吃早饭时，她说，“昨天夜里你的鼻鼾声很响，我连鸡叫声都没听见。” “Do you know, my friend,” she said at breakfast, “you were snoring last night so that I could not hear the cock crow.”
“你为什么要听见鸡叫声呢？”索姆斯说。 “Why should you want to?” said Soames.
“好了，没关系——只要你晚上睡得好就行。 “Well, never mind—if you had a good night.
是不是我给你的那本小书《库埃》让你睡得那么香呢？” Was it my little Coue who gave you that nice dream?”
索姆斯怕鼓励《库埃》，也怕鼓励她，所以他避而不答。然而好像有种神奇的力量，他好像并不介意别人说什么了。 Partly from fear of encouraging Coue, and partly from fear of encouraging her, Soames avoided a reply; but he had a curious sense of power, as if he did not care what people said of him.
“今天晚上接着这么干。”他心想。 ‘I’ll do it again to-night,’ he thought.
“你知道，”安妮特接着说，“你的性格恰好适合库埃疗法，索姆斯。 “You know,” Annette went on, “you are just the temperament for Coue, Soames.
等你治好了忧虑的老毛病，你的身体就会胖起来。” When you cure yourself of worrying, you will get quite fat.”
“胖！”索姆斯看了看她的曲线， “Fat!” said Soames, looking at her curves.
“我宁可留一把胡子。” “I’d as soon grow a beard.”
肥胖和胡须总是与法国人联系在一起。 Fatness and beards were associated with the French.
他必须得好好照顾自己，如果他继续练这个——呃——人们会叫它什么呢？ He would have to keep an eye on himself if he went on with this—er—what was one to call it?
无聊的玩意一词实在不足以表达这一过程，甚至书中还要求你在一小段绳子上打25个结，这是地道的法国式做法，就像数念珠祷告似的！ Tomfoolery was hardly the word to conciliate the process, even if it did require you to tie twenty-five knots in a bit of string: very French, that, like telling your beads!
他只用手指来计数。 He himself had merely counted on his fingers.
他深信自己的力量，这种感觉一路维持到伦敦。他深信，只要他愿意，即使他坐在风口浪尖也无所谓，他也深信弗勒一定会母子平安的，至于在天佑再保险公司里——十之八九他的名字不会再出现在大会的任何报告中。 The sense of power lasted all the way up to London; he had the conviction that he could sit in a draught if he wanted to, that Fleur would have her boy all right; and as to the P. P. R. S.—ten to one he wouldn’t be mentioned by name in any report of the proceedings.
早午饭之后，他在喝咖啡时又做了25次祈祷，便动身到城里去了。 After an early lunch and twenty-five more assurances over his coffee, he set out for the city.
这次董事会，刚好在股东特别大会前一周举行，实际上是一场预演。 This Board, held just a week before the special meeting of the shareholders, was in the nature of a dress rehearsal.
对质的种种细节必须安排好，索姆斯主要关注保护那些与个人无关的方针。 The details of confrontation had to be arranged, and Soames was chiefly concerned with seeing that a certain impersonality should be preserved.
他完全反对公开以下事实，即年轻人巴特菲尔德的告发和埃尔德森的那封信都是透露给他本人的。 He was entirely against disclosure of the fact that young Butterfield’s story and Elderson’s letter had been confided to himself.
应该采用措辞“一个董事会成员”。 The phrase to be used should be a “member of the Board.”
他认为没必要进一步声明了。 He saw no need for anything further.
至于解释，当然应该向董事长和资格最老的董事福坦诺勋爵询问了。 As for explanations, they would fall, of course, to the chairman and the senior director, Lord Fontenoy.
然而，他却发现董事会却认为他是提出这件事最适合的人选。 He found, however, that the Board thought he himself was the right person to bring the matter forward.
他们说——除了他之外，没人具有和他们接触的机会以及提供具有说服力的证据；董事长会简要介绍一下此事，然后请索姆斯提供他所知的证据。 No one else—they said—could supply the personal touch, the necessary conviction; the chairman should introduce the matter briefly, then call on Soames to give the evidence within his knowledge.
福坦诺勋爵强烈要求这样做。 Lord Fontenoy was emphatic.
“这事全仰仗您了，福赛特先生。 “It’s up to you, Mr. Forsyte.
要不是您的话，埃尔德森今天还坐在这里呢。 If it hadn’t been for you, Elderson would be sitting there today.
从开始到现在，他一直都害怕您，我希望您没做什么。 From beginning to end you put the wind up him; and I wish the deuce you hadn’t.
这真是一件麻烦事儿。 The whole thing’s a confounded nuisance.
他是个聪明人，我们会想他的。 He was a very clever fellow, and we shall miss him.
我们的新经理可比不上他。 Our new man isn’t a patch on him.
如果他私下里确实捞了几千镑，那也是从德国佬那拿的。” If he did take a few thou. under the rose, he took ‘em off the Huns.”
这只老豚鼠！ Old guinea-pig!
索姆斯尖声说道： Soames replied, acidly:
“难道他为了这几千镑可以让股东们失掉25万镑吗？ “And the quarter of a million he’s lost the shareholders, for the sake of those few thou.?
请问这是小事吗？” Bagatelle, I suppose?”
“嗯，说不定它会变成一笔赚钱的生意呢，第一年就是这样的。 “Well, it might have turned out a winner; for the first year it did.
我们都会把赌注压在输者的身上。” We all back losers sometimes.”
索姆斯一一打量他们的面孔。 Soames looked from face to face.
他们并不赞成把此事闹大，而且从他们的表情来看，除了“老蒙特”之外，他感觉到每个人都对他有怨恨之情。 They did not support this blatant attitude, but in them all, except perhaps ‘Old Mont’s,’ he felt a grudge against himself.
他们的表情似乎在说：“你没来董事会之前，从没发生过这类事情。” Their expressions seemed to say: ‘Nothing of this sort ever happened till you came on the Board.’
他扰乱了他们的安逸，所以他们并不喜欢他。 He had disturbed their comfort, and they disliked him for it.
他们是一帮不公道的家伙！ They were an unjust lot!
他固执地说： He said doggedly:
“你们都把这件事踢给我，是不是？ “You leave it to me, do you?
很好！” Very well!”
他这句话要表达什么意思——或者他是否有什么意思要表达，他自己也不清楚，不过之后，就连那只“老豚鼠”也客气些了。 What he meant to convey—or whether he meant to convey anything, he did not know; but even that ‘old guinea-pig’ was more civil afterwards.
然而，从董事会出来以后，他已经感觉不到任何力量了。 He came away from the Board, however, without any sense of power at all.
下周二，他就要在公众面前现眼了。 There he would be on Tuesday next, bang in the public eye.
弗勒因为不舒服一直躺在床上，他去看过她之后，就直接回家了，心里有种被出卖的感觉。 After calling to enquire after Fleur, who was lying down rather poorly, he returned home with a feeling of having been betrayed.
看来，这种打25个结的心理疗法不适合他。 It seemed that he could not rely, after all, on this fellow with his twenty-five knots.
不管他现在的状态变得有多好，他的女儿、他的名誉，可能还有他的财产，显然都不是那个下意识所能控制的。 However much better he might become, his daughter, his reputation, and possibly his fortune, were not apparently at the disposition of his subconscious self.
吃晚饭时，他默不作声，吃完就到楼上的画廊去了，仔细考虑一下整件事情。 He was silent at dinner, and went up afterwards to his picture gallery, to think things over.
他在打开的窗前，站了半个小时，在这夏日的傍晚，独自一人。在窗前站的时间越长，他就越意识到这三件事其实是一回事、。 For half an hour he stood at the open window, alone with the summer evening; and the longer he stood there, the more clearly he perceived that the three were really one.
如果不是为了女儿，他还计较什么名誉和财产呢？ Except for his daughter’s sake, what did he care for his reputation or his fortune?
他的名誉！ His reputation!
这帮蠢货——如果他们看不出他在力所能及的范围内表现出来的谨慎和诚实——那他们就无药可救了！ Lot of fools—if they couldn’t see that he was careful and honest so far as had lain within his reach—so much the worse for them!
他的财产——嗯，他最好还是马上再给弗勒和她的孩子一笔财产，以防意外。再给五万镑。 His fortune—well, he had better make another settlement on Fleur and her child at once, in case of accidents; another fifty thousand.
啊！只要她能顺利分娩就好！ Ah! if she were only through her trouble!
现在是时候让安妮特进城到她那里去了，还有一种人们称作半麻醉无痛分娩的方法。 It was time Annette went up to her for good; and there was a thing they called twilight sleep.
可千万不能让她受苦啊！ To have her suffering was not to be thought of!
夜晚悄悄降临，太阳隐没在熟悉的树林后。索姆斯紧紧握着窗框的双手已被露水打湿了，他闻到了青草伴着河水的香气。 The evening lingered out; the sun went down behind familiar trees; Soames’ hands, grasping the window-ledge, felt damp with dew; sweetness of grass and river stole up into his nostrils.
此刻，苍茫的天色逐渐暗淡，天空中繁星点点。 The sky had paled, and now began to darken; a scatter of stars came out.
他在这里住过很长一段时间，陪弗勒度过整个童年时光——这是他一生中最美好的时光。尽管如此，卖掉这处房产也不会让他伤心。 He had lived here a long time, through all Fleur’s childhood—best years of his life; still, it wouldn’t break his heart to sell.
他的心已经飞向伦敦了。 His heart was up in London.
卖了它？ Sell?
这未免太心急了。 That was to run before the hounds with a vengeance.
不——不！事情还没到那个地步！ No—no!—it wouldn’t come to THAT!
他离开窗户，打开电灯，第一千零一次巡视自己的藏画。 He left the window and, turning up the lights, began the thousand and first tour of his pictures.
弗勒结婚以来，他买进好几件便宜货，而且没把钱浪费在追赶那些时髦的作品上。 He had made some good purchases since Fleur’s marriage, and without wasting his money on fashionable favourites.
他也做过几笔好买卖。 He had made some good sales, too.
在他画廊里的那些画，要是没算错的话，值七万到十万镑。同时，若将时不时地卖出所获的利润算进去，这些画的成本还不到两万五千镑——一生的业余爱好有这样的成果总算不赖，更不用说其中的乐趣了！ The pictures in this gallery, if he didn’t mistake, were worth from seventy to a hundred thousand pounds; and, with the profits on his sales from time to time, they stood him in at no more than five-and-twenty thousand—not a bad result from a life’s hobby, to say nothing of the pleasure!
当然，他本来可能会对其他事物产生兴趣——如蝴蝶、摄影、考古，或者书籍首发本，或者在某项运动中下赌注而后收获结果。但他从未对自己选择收藏画而后悔。 Of course, he might have taken up something else—butterflies, photography, archaeology, or first editions; some other sport in which you backed your judgment against the field, and collected the results; but he had never regretted choosing pictures.
他才不后悔呢！ Not he!
自己花的钱，可以给别人看更多东西，自己还能从中取得更大的名声、更多的利润，同时也会冒更大的风险！ More to show for your money, more kudos, more profit, and more risk!
这种想法使他有点儿吃惊。他是因为要承担风险才喜欢画吗？ The thought startled him a little; had he really taken to pictures because of the risk?
风险对他而言向来是没有吸引力的，至少到目前为止他还没认识到这一点。 A risk had never appealed to him; at least, he hadn’t realised it, so far.
是不是他的“潜意识”在这件事上起过一些作用呢？ Had his ‘subconscious’ some part in the matter?
他突然坐下来，闭上眼睛。 He suddenly sat down and closed his eyes.
再来一遍那玩意试试看。那天早晨，有过一种“毫不在乎”的愉快感觉，他记得以前从来没有过这种感觉！ Try the thing once more; very pleasant feeling, that morning, of not “giving a damn”; he never remembered having it before!
他一直觉得担心是必要的——像是一种对最恶劣情况的保险。但是担心令人疲惫，毫无疑问，令人疲惫。　 He had always felt it necessary to worry—kind of insurance against the worst; but worry was wearing, no doubt about it, wearing.
把灯关了！ Turn out the light!
书里说，必须要放松。 They said in that book, you had to relax.
此刻，这个房间朦胧而幽暗，星光透过窗口洒落在屋内，索姆斯静静地坐在安乐椅上，一动不动。 In the now dim and shadowy room, with the starlight, through many windows, dusted over its reality, Soames, in his easy chair, sat very still.
只有他嘴唇在颤抖，发出一种轻微深沉的嗡嗡声：“越来越胖。” A faint drone rose on the words: “fatter and fatter” through his moving lips.
“不，不。”他想，“念错了！” ‘No, no,’ he thought: ‘that’s wrong!’
于是他又发出嗡嗡声。 And he began the drone again.
他的指尖在数着念句的次数；念了又念——他要给这种疗法一个好机会。 The tips of his fingers ticked it off; on and on—he would give it a good chance.
但愿自己不必忧虑担心了！ If only one needn’t worry!
念了又念——“越来越好！” On and on—“better and better!”
但愿——！ If only—!
他的嘴唇停止了颤动；他那灰白的脑袋垂在胸前，陷入了下意识。 His lips stopped moving; his grey head fell forward into the subconscious.
此时，悄然射入的星光洒在他身上，有点儿虚无缥缈。 And the stealing starlight dusted over him, too, a little unreality.
第十章 Chapter X
但是不冒险 But Takes No Chances
迈克尔根本不了解伦敦城，于是他本着老制图员的精神：“警惕那些你不了解的地方”，穿过家禽街的边缘，走向那个最神圣的地方——卡斯考特、金森和福赛特事务所。 Michael knew nothing of the City; and, in the spirit of the old cartographers: “Where you know nothing, place terrors,” made his way through the purlieus of the Poultry, towards that holy of holies, the offices of Cuthcott, Kingson and Forsyte.
他此刻的状态适合思考问题，因为他刚刚在克里伦咖啡馆和西伯莱·斯旺用过午饭。 His mood was attuned to meditation, for he had been lunching with Sibley Swan at the Cafe C’rillon.
他认识所有在那里用餐的客人——有七个人甚至比老西伯还要入时——只有一个俄国人除外，他太新潮了竟然不懂法语，以至于没有人能和他交谈。 He had known all the guests—seven chaps even more modern than old Sib—save only a Russian so modern that he knew no French and nobody could talk to him.
迈克尔看着他们吃光了所有的东西，看到只要有人提起任何一个尚在人世的人时，那个俄国人就会像一个病婴似的闭上眼睛…… Michael had watched them demolish everything, and the Russian closing his eyes, like a sick baby, at mention of any living name....
“继续吧！”他想道，有几个他最喜欢的人物已经在混乱的讨论中被否定了， ‘Carry on!’ he thought, several of his favourites having gone down in the melee.
“中伤吧！调侃吧！ ‘Stab and bludge!
等着身后留名吧。” Importance awaits you at the end of the alley.’
但是他一直忍着，直到他要走的时候才把这些无礼的话说出来。 But he had restrained his irreverence till the moment of departure.
“西伯，”他站起来说，“这里的这些家伙都是死人——天气这么热他们怎么能出来活动呢？” “Sib,” he said, rising, “all these chaps here are dead—ought they to be about in this hot weather?”
“你说的是什么话？”在一帮人基本上都尴尬无语的时候，西伯莱·斯旺突然喊道。 “What’s that?” ejaculated Sibley Swan, amidst the almost painful silence of the chaps.
“我是说——他们都还活着——所以他们都该见鬼去！” “I mean—they’re alive—so they MUST be damned!”
他躲过一块扔过来的巧克力，夺门而出，结果那块巧克力打中了那个俄国人。 And avoiding a thrown chocolate which hit the Russian, he sought the door.
出门后，他若有所思地自语道：“这帮家伙，真是好样的！ Outside, he mused: ‘Good chaps, really!
自以为才高八斗，其实连一半都没有。 Not half so darned superior as they think they are.
扔那一下倒是有人情味——打中那个俄国佬的鼻子了。 Quite a human touch—getting that Russian on the boko.
呼！ Phew!
真热啊！” It’s hot!’
在伊顿和哈罗比赛的第一天，在堤岸公交车的顶层上，迈克尔觉得整个凉爽夏天消失了的暑热都集中到一起了，闪烁在自己身上、行人的草帽上、因流汗而苍白的脸上、川流不息的其他公交车上；闪烁在那些生意人、警察、店员、卖报纸的、卖花边的、卖跳动玩具的人的身上；闪烁在运货马车和出租车上以及文字和电报上、世界上最大的混合体的所有混乱上——世上种种万物在一种看不见的本能的作用下，都调整到只差分毫了。 On that first day of the Eton and Harrow match all the forfeited heat of a chilly summer had gathered and shimmered over Michael, on the top of his Bank ‘bus; shimmered over straw hats, and pale, perspiring faces, over endless other ‘buses, business men, policemen, shopmen at their doors, sellers of newspapers, laces, jumping toys, endless carts and cabs, letterings and wires, all the confusion of the greatest conglomeration in the world—adjusted almost to a hair’s-breadth, by an unseen instinct.
迈克尔瞪着眼看着，也疑惑着。 Michael stared and doubted.
如果人人都忙于自己的事业，全神贯注于自己的工作，事情有可能发展成那样吗？ Was it possible that, with everyone pursuing his own business, absorbed in his own job, the thing could work out?
成群的蚂蚁也不会比这里更热闹，或是看上去比这里更混乱。 An ant-heap was not busier, or more seemingly confused.
你会说，忙碌的人们有如有生命的电线一般穿来穿去，穿去穿来——难分难解地纠结在一起，然而，生活以及生活所需的秩序却以某种方式幸存了下来！ Live wires crossed and crossed and crossed—inextricable entanglement, you’d say; and yet, life, the order needful to life, somehow surviving!
“忙碌的人们显奇迹！”他想道，“现代都市生活！” ‘No slouch of a miracle!’ he thought, ‘modern town life!’
可是，生活貌似突然停止了，仿佛是被西伯莱·斯旺之类的超人以无情的天命为由毁灭了，因为出现在他眼前的是一条死胡同。 And suddenly it seemed to cease, as if demolished by the ruthless dispensation of some super Sibley Swan; for he was staring down a cul-de-sac.
胡同两边都是些单调的房子，新刷的浅黄色，极其相似。路的尽头还是一幢单调的浅黄色的房子，跟其他的没什么两样。通向它的这条灰色的路，没有行人走过的痕迹，也没有马车或是汽油的痕迹，没有汽车、马车、警察、小贩、猫咪、苍蝇或是蜜蜂。 On both sides, flat houses, recently re-buffed, extraordinarily alike; at the end, a flat buff house, even more alike, and down to it, grey virgin pavement, unstained by horse or petrol; no cars, cats, carts, policemen, hawkers, flies, or bees.
没有人类生活的迹象，只是每一扇敞开的门的左右两边都挂着法律事务所的招牌。 No sign of human life, except the names of legal firms to right and left of each open doorway.
“‘卡思考特、金森和福赛特，宣誓公证人：请上二楼。’” “‘Cuthcott, Kingson and Forsyte, Commissioners for Oaths: First Floor.’”
“大英律例！”迈克尔一边想着，一边踏上了宽阔的石头台阶。 ‘Rule Britannia!’ thought Michael, ascending wide stone steps.
按照引导，他走进了那房间，看到一个老人从转椅里站了起来。那个老人有一张狮子狗似的脸，花白胡须，穿着黑色羊驼毛外套，在宽大的腰身外面还罩着一件宽大的荷兰亚麻马甲。 Entering the room to which he had been ushered, he saw an old and pug-faced fellow with a round grizzled beard, a black alpaca coat, and a roomy holland waistcoat round his roomy middle, who rose from a swivel chair.
“啊！”他说道，“我想您是迈克尔·蒙特先生吧。 “Aoh!” he said, “Mr. Michael Mont, I think.
我一直在等您呢。 I’ve been expecting you.
等会儿索姆斯来了以后，用不了太长时间就能办好。 We shan’t be long about it, after Mr. Forsyte comes.
他刚到那边拐角处去了。 He’s just stepped round the corner.
迈克尔太太身体还好吧？” Mrs. Michael well, I hope?”
“谢谢，还好——” “Thanks; as well as—”
“是啊，您在担心她。 “Ye-es: it makes you anxious.
请坐吧。 Take a seat.
也许您想看看那份草稿吧？” Perhaps you’d like to read the draft?”
说完，他便用那肥大的手递给坐在他对面的迈克尔几张大页纸。 Thus prescribed for, Michael took some foolscap from a pudgy hand, and sat down opposite.
他一只眼看着老头，另一只眼看着草稿，从容地读着。 With one eye on the old fellow, and the other on the foolscap, he read steadily.
“这看起来有点儿意思。”他最后说。 “It seems to mean something,” he said at last.
他看见那胡须下面老人的嘴张大了，就像青蛙看见苍蝇时咧着大嘴一样，于是他赶紧弥补自己的口误。 He saw a gape, as of a frog at a fly, settle in the beard; and hastened to repair his error.
“在没有其他事发生的前提下计算将要发生的事，就像是在登记赛马赌注一样。” “Calculating what’s going to happen if something else doesn’t, must be rather like being a bookmaker.”
他立刻感觉到自己这句话并没有弥补之前的失言。 He felt at once that he had not succeeded.
因为他听到对方生气地说： There was a grumpy mutter:
“我们这儿可不浪费时间。 “We don’t waste our time, ‘ere.
原谅我失陪了，我还有事要忙。” Excuse me, I’m busy.”
迈克尔懊悔地坐在那里，看着他在长长的一页条目上做标记。 Michael sat, compunctious, watching him tick down a long page of entries.
他就像一只老狗一样，趴在大门外，不让人靠近屋子，警告人们别惹麻烦。 He was like one of those old dogs which lie outside front doors, keeping people off the premises, and notifying their fleas.
就这样过了近五分钟的绝对寂静之后，索姆斯走了进来。 After less than five minutes of that perfect silence Soames came in.
“哦，你来了?”他说。 “You’re here, then?” he said.
“是的，先生。我觉得最好按照您说的那个时间来。 “Yes, sir; I thought it best to come at the time you mentioned.
多么凉爽舒服的房间啊！” What a nice cool room!”
“你看过这个了吗？”索姆斯指着那份草稿问道。 “Have you read this?” asked Soames, pointing to the draft.
迈克尔点了点头。 Michael nodded.
“看明白了吗？” “Did you understand it?”
“看懂些要点吧，我是这么想的。” “Up to a point, I think.”
“这五万块钱的利息，”索姆斯说，“是给弗勒的，直到她的最大的孩子年满21岁。如果是儿子，那么此后的本金就全归他了。 “The interest on THIS fifty thousand,” said Soames, “is Fleur’s until her eldest child, if it’s a boy, attains the age of twenty-one, when the capital becomes his absolutely.
如果是女儿，那么弗勒终身都享有这份收益的一半，其余的收益等这个孩子年满21岁或是出嫁时，再给她，这一半本金归这个孩子合法生育的孩子或孩子们所有，等他们成年或是成亲时，大家均分。 If it’s a girl, Fleur retains half the income for life, the rest of the income becomes payable to the girl when she attains the age of twenty-one or marries, and the capital of that half goes to her child or children lawfully begotten, at majority or marriage, in equal shares.
另一半本金则归入弗勒的财产，可以根据她的遗嘱或是根据无遗嘱的法律来处理。” The other half of the capital falls into Fleur’s estate, and is disposable by her will, or follows the laws of intestacy.”
“您订立得很清楚。”迈克尔说。 “You make it wonderfully clear,” said Michael
“等一下！”索姆斯说， “Wait!” said Soames.
“如果弗勒没有孩子——” “If Fleur has no children—”
迈克尔吃了一惊。 Michael started.
“什么事都有可能，”索姆斯严肃地说，“而我的经验告诉我，没有防范到的事恰恰是会意外发生的事。 “Anything is possible,” said Soames gravely, “and my experience is that the contingencies not provided for are those which happen.
在这种情况下，所有收益归她终身所有，本金也归她，等她死的时候按她的意愿处理。 In such a case the income of the whole is hers for life, and the capital hers at death to do as she likes with.
如果未能处理，这笔财产就交给她关系最近的亲属。 Failing that, it goes to the next of kin.
对于预先支取等情况，也有相应条款规定。” There are provisions against anticipation and so forth.”
“她是不是应该立一份新的遗嘱呢？”迈克尔问道，觉得自己额头上都出汗了。 “Ought she to make a fresh will?” asked Michael, conscious of sweat on his forehead.
“不必，除非她自愿。 “Not unless she likes.
她现在的遗嘱会把这个包括进去的。” Her present will covers it.”
“需要我做什么事情吗？” “Have I to do anything?”
“不需要。我要你在我签字之前了解其中的要义，仅此而已。 “No. I wanted you to understand the purport before I sign; that’s all.
把那份契约给我，格雷德曼，再叫威克森进来，好吗？” Give me the deed, Gradman, and get Wickson in, will you?”
迈克尔看到那个老人从抽屉里拿出一张印有铜版雕刻的字迹和印章的羊皮纸，亲切地看了看，然后放在了索姆斯面前。 Michael saw the old chap produce from a drawer a fine piece of parchment covered with copper-plate writing and seals, look at it lovingly, and place it before Soames.
老人离开房间后，索姆斯低声说： When he had left the room, Soames said in a low voice:

但是，不管发生什么事情，依我所见，这份契约都应该订立。” But, whatever happens, so far as I can see, this ought to stand.”
“您真是太好了，先生。” “It’s awfully good of you, sir.”
索姆斯点了点头，拿出一支钢笔试了试能不能写出字来。 Soames nodded, testing a pen.
“我担心我刚才得罪了您那位老办事员，”迈克尔说，“我非常喜欢他那副神情，但是我刚才不小心把他比作赛马赌注登记经纪人了。” “I’m afraid I’ve got wrong with your old clerk,” said Michael; “I like the look of him frightfully, but I accidentally compared him to a bookmaker.”
索姆斯笑了。 Soames smiled.

现在，这种人不多了。” There aren’t many, nowadays.”
迈克尔纳闷了：一个快60岁的人，能被称为“有个性的人”吗？这时，那个“有个性的人”回来了，还带来了一个穿深色衣服、面色苍白的人。 Michael was wondering: Could one be a ‘character’ under the age of sixty?—when the ‘character’ returned, with a pale man in dark clothes.
索姆斯把鼻子朝旁边儿撇了一下，马上说道： Lifting his nose sideways, Soames said at once:

我把它交出，作为我行动及契约凭证。” I deliver this as my act and deed.”
他签下了自己的名字，然后站了起来。 He wrote his name, and got up.
那个面色苍白的人和格雷德曼也签了名，然后那个人就离开了。 The pale person and Gradman wrote theirs, and the former left the room.
这时大家都很满意，没有说话。 There was a silence as of repletion.

“是的。 “Yes.
我想让你看着我把它存入银行，和结婚时的财产赠与书放在一起。 I want you to see me deposit it at the bank with the marriage settlement.
我就不回来了，格雷德曼！” Shan’t come back, Gradman!”

我选他们是因为他们年轻。 I chose them youngish.
小小罗杰在战争中受过伤——他现在什么也不做。 Very young Roger was wounded in the war—he does nothing.
小小尼古拉斯现在是律师。” Very young Nicholas is at the Bar.”

他负担不起的，他是个求稳的人。 He can’t afford it; he’s a steady chap.

要是女孩呢？” And if it’s a girl?”

你们预计他到底什么时候出生呢？” When exactly do you expect it?”

这世界上多一个人或是少一个人——有什么关系呢？” One more person in the world or one more out of it—what does it matter?”

关系可大了！” It matters frightfully!”
