哎呀！ Oh!
我太热了！” I’m so hot!”
迈克尔犹豫了一下，然后出去了。 Michael hovered a moment, and went out.
该死的热天，让她那么烦心！ Damn the heat, upsetting her like this!
他看见索姆斯站在那幅白猿前面。 He found Soames standing in front of the white monkey.
“如果我是你的话，就把它摘下来，”他喃喃说道，“等孩子生了再挂出来。” “I should take this down, if I were you,” he muttered, “until it’s over.”
“为什么，先生？”迈克尔吃惊地问。 “Why, sir?” asked Michael, in surprise.
索姆斯皱了皱眉头。 Soames frowned.
“那一双眼睛啊！” “Those eyes!”
迈克尔走到那幅画前。 Michael went up to the picture.
是啊！ Yes!
这幅画是那种让人一见就难以忘怀的类型！ He was a haunting kind of brute!
“可是这是很棒的作品啊，先生。” “But it’s such top-hole work, sir.”
索姆斯点头认可了。 Soames nodded.
“从艺术上来说，是的。 “Artistically, yes.
但是在这个关头，凡是她看到的东西你都得小心再小心。” But at such times you can’t be too careful what she sees.”
“我认为您是对的。 “I believe you’re right.
我们一起把它取下来吧。” Let’s have him down.”
“我来托住它。”索姆斯一边说，一边托着画的底部。 “I’ll hold him,” said Soames, taking hold of the bottom of the picture.
“抓紧了吗？ “Got him tight?
好的—— Right-o.
行了！” Now!”
“就说我想鉴别一下它是什么年代的。”当把这幅画放到地板上的时候，索姆斯说。 “You can say I wanted an opinion on his period,” said Soames, when the picture had been lowered to the floor.
“这有什么好怀疑的，先生——现代的！” “There can hardly be a doubt of that, sir—the present!”
索姆斯瞪着眼睛。 Soames stared.
“什么？ “What?
啊！ Oh!
你是说——？ You mean—?
啊！ Ah!
哎呀！ H’m!
别让她知道这东西还在家里面。” Don’t let her know he’s in the house.”
“不会的。我会锁起来的。” “No. I’ll lock him up.”
迈克尔搬起了画， Michael lifted the picture.
“先生，请您帮我开一下门好吗？” “D’you mind opening the door, sir?”
“我到喝茶的时间再回来，”索姆斯说， “I’ll come back at tea-time,” said Soames.
“这样看起来就像我把画带走了。 “That’ll look as if I’d taken him off.
过些日子，你可以把画再挂起来。” You can hang him again, later.”
“好的。 “Yes.
可怜的家伙！”迈克尔说着，把那幅画带去关禁闭了。 Poor brute!” said Michael, bearing the monkey off to limbo.
第十一章 Chapter XI
大自然露出了本来面目 With a Small ‘n’
到了周一的晚上，等弗勒上床睡觉以后，迈克尔和索姆斯两人坐着倾听伦敦的喧嚣。因为天气闷热，那间中式的房间敞开了窗户，声音就是从那里传进来的。 On the night of the Monday following, after Fleur had gone to bed, Michael and Soames sat listening to the mutter of London coming through the windows of the Chinese room opened to the brooding heat.
“据说战争泯灭了人类的情感，”索姆斯突然说道，“这是真的吗？” “They say the war killed sentiment,” said Soames suddenly: “Is that true?”
“在某种程度上说，是真的，先生。 “In a way, yes, sir.
我们经历了那么多的现实，不想要更多的感情了。” We had so much reality that we don’t want any more.”
“我不明白你的意思。” “I don’t follow you.”
“我是说人们只对现实才有感觉。 “I meant that only reality really makes you feel.
因此，要是你假装世上没有现实，那么你也就不必对什么有感觉了。 So if you pretend there IS no reality, you don’t have to feel.
从某种程度上来讲，这是很好的解答。” It answers awfully well, up to a point.”
“啊！”索姆斯说， “Ah!” said Soames.
“她母亲明天早晨过来，住在这儿。 “Her mother comes up tomorrow morning, to stay.
下午两点半我去参加天佑再保险公司的股东大会。 This P. P. R. S. meeting of mine is at half-past two.
晚安！” Good-night!”
迈克尔站在窗前，看着热气在广场上空凝聚成了乌云。 Michael, at the window, watched the heat gathered black over the Square.
他把手伸出窗外，接到了几滴温热的雨点。 A few tepid drops fell on his outstretched hand.
一只猫从街灯下面偷偷溜过去，消失在一片阴影中，那阴影如此厚重，以至于那里似乎像是蛮荒之地。 A cat stole by under a lamp-post, and vanished into shadow so thick that it seemed uncivilised.
“老福赛特”提出的那个关于伤感之情的问题很怪异，而且他居然会问起这样的问题来！ Queer question of ‘Old Forsyte’s’ about sentiment; odd that he should ask it!
“奇怪到了一定程度！ ‘Up to a point!
但是我们不都怪得超过这个程度了吗？”他想道。 But don’t we all get past that point?’ he thought.
看看威尔弗里德，还有他自己——经历了战争之后，他们认为如果除了吃喝之外还有其他重要的事情，那就是在亵渎神明，因为明天可能就没命了。即便是内津、马斯特这样没上过战场的人，战后也有这样的感觉。 Look at Wilfrid, and himself—after the war they had deemed it blasphemous to admit that anything mattered except eating and drinking, for tomorrow they died; even fellows like Nazing, and Master, who were never in the war, had felt like that ever since.
哎，威尔弗里德已经亲身体验到了痛苦，而他自己也虚惊一场，而且他愿意打赌——除了零零散散个别冷血的家伙之外——他们早晚也会和他俩一样体验痛苦或是虚惊。 Well, Wilfrid had got it in the neck; and he himself had got it in the wind; and he would bet that—barring one here and there whose blood was made of ink—they would all get it in the neck or wind soon or late.
哎呀，他倒是愿意由自己来替弗勒承受痛苦和风险，不要再让她承受了！ Why, he would cheerfully bear Fleur’s pain and risk, instead of her!
但是如果什么事情都不重要的话，他为何会有这样的感觉呢？ But if nothing mattered, why should he feel like that?
从窗边转过身来，他靠在翠绿色长椅那用油漆漆过的后背上，注视着两个中式茶柜之间的那块空白墙壁。 Turning from the window, he leaned against the lacquered back of the jade-green settee, and stared at the wall space between the Chinese tea-chests.
“老头子”把白猿取下来真是考虑得太周到了！ Jolly thoughtful of the ‘old man’ to have that white monkey down!
画中的畜生很有影响力——象征着这个世界的精神状态：没有信仰，没有信念！ The brute was potent—symbolic of the world’s mood: beliefs cancelled, faiths withdrawn!
该死！不仅年轻人——就连老人——都是这种心境！ And, dash it! not only the young—but the old—were in that temper!
“老福赛特”就是这样，要不然他也不会害怕那只白猿的眼神，对了，还有自己的父亲，还有埃尔德森，还有其他的人都是这样。 ‘Old Forsyte,’ or he would never have been scared by that monkey’s eyes; yes, and his own governor, and Elderson, and all the rest.
不论老幼——对什么都没有真正的信仰！ Young and old—no real belief in anything!
然后——迈克尔的心里忽然涌起一股反感，像一群鹧鸪振翅飞过似的。 And yet—revolt sprang up in Michael, with a whirr, like a covey of partridges.
除了自己之外，还有别的人或是某个原则比自己还要重要，这的确是件要紧的事——确确实实是的！ It DID matter that some person or some principle outside oneself should be more precious than oneself—it dashed well did!
那么，情感，并没有泯灭——信仰、信念也没有泯灭，这都是一回事。 Sentiment, then, wasn’t dead—nor faith, nor belief, which were the same things.
它们也许只是在蜕壳，逐渐变成蛹，最后变成——蝴蝶。 They were only shedding shell, working through chrysalis, into—butterflies, perhaps.
信念、情感、信仰可能已经转入地下了，但是它们还在，甚至在“老福赛特”和自己身上。 Faith, sentiment, belief, had gone underground, possibly, but they were there, even in ‘Old Forsyte’ and himself.
他很想把那幅白猿再挂起来。 He had a good mind to put the monkey up again.
无需夸大它的影响力…… No use exaggerating his importance!...
糟糕！ By George!
闪电了！ Some flare!
一道锯齿形的亮光划破了黑暗的夜空。 A jagged streak of vivid light had stripped darkness off the night.
迈克尔走过去，把窗户关上。 Michael crossed, to close the windows.
头顶突然炸开了一阵响雷，接着就下雨了，倾盆大雨。 A shattering peal of thunder blundered overhead; and down came the rain, slashing and sluicing.
他看到有人在跑，黑漆漆的，像一个影子从深蓝色的银幕前跑过。在另一道闪电的映照下，他看到那个人突然变得苍白而有内涵，脸上混杂着欢喜和焦急，仿佛在说：“该死的，把我淋湿了！” He saw a man running, black, like a shadow across a dark blue screen; saw him by the light of another flash, suddenly made lurid and full of small meaning, with face of cheerful anxiety, as if he were saying: “Hang it, I’m getting wet!”
接着又是一阵狂乱的雷鸣！ Another frantic crash!
“弗勒！”迈克尔想着，他咣当一声关上了最后一扇窗户，然后跑上楼去。 ‘Fleur!’ thought Michael; and clanging the last window down, he ran upstairs.
她坐在床上，年轻的小脸圆圆的，受了惊吓。 She was sitting up in bed, with a face all round, and young, and startled.
“畜生！”他心里想——战场的枪炮声和天空的雷电在他脑子里混在一起，“它们把她吵醒了！” ‘Brutes!’ he thought—guns and the heavens confounded in his mind: ‘They’ve waked her up!’
“别害怕，亲爱的！ “It’s all right, darling!
只是打雷了！ Just another little summer kick-up!
你刚才睡着了？” Were you asleep?”
“我正做梦呢！” “I was dreaming!”
他感到她的手在他的手中攥得紧紧的，脸色因突然的紧张而变得苍白，好像还带着愤怒。 He felt her hand clutching within his own, saw a sudden pinched look on her face, with a sort of rage.
真背运！ What infernal luck!
“小丁在哪儿呢？” “Where’s Ting?”
角落里没有狗。 No dog was in the corner.
“一定躲在床底下了！ “Under the bed—you bet!
想让它到床上去吗？” Would you like him up?”
“不必了。让它呆在那儿吧，它怕打雷。” “No. Let him stay; he hates it.”
她把头靠在他胳膊上，迈克尔用手堵着她的另一只耳朵。 She put her head against his arm, and Michael curled his hand round her other ear.
“我从来都不怎么喜欢雷声！”弗勒说，“现在它——让我难过！” “I never liked thunder much!” said Fleur,” and now it—it hurts!”
在弗勒的头发上方，迈克尔的脸温柔得都变形了。 High above her hair Michael’s face underwent the contortions of an overwhelming tenderness.
雷声不断，有一个仿佛就在他们头顶炸响，吓得弗勒把脸埋进他的怀里去了。他乘势坐在床上，紧紧地搂住了她。 One of those crashes which seem just overhead sent her face burrowing against his chest, and, sitting on the bed, he gathered her in, close.
“真希望快点儿结束。”她的声音闷闷地从双唇间传了出来。 “I wish it were over,” came, smothered, from her lips.
“马上就好了，亲爱的，它来得太突然了！” “It will be directly, darling; it came on so suddenly!”
但是他明白她说的并不是这场雷雨。 But he knew she didn’t mean the storm.
“要是我能熬过这一关，我会待你完全不同的，迈克尔。” “If I come through, I’m going to be quite different to you, Michael.”
遇上这种事，难免会焦虑，但是那句话，“要是我能熬过去”却将迈克尔的心揪了起来。 Anxiety was the natural accompaniment of such events, but the words, “If I come through” turned Michael’s heart right over.
一个这么年轻、美丽的人哪怕是处于一丝濒临死亡的危险，这都让人难以置信，她为此而担心，这更是难以置信的痛苦了！ Incredible that one so young and pretty should be in even the remotest danger of extinction; incredibly painful that she should be in fear of it!
他以前从来没有意识到这一点。 He hadn’t realised.
在这件事情上，她一直是那么镇静，那么平淡。 She had been so calm, so matter-of-fact about it all.
“别这么说！”他喃喃地说，“你当然可以熬过去。” “Don’t!” he mumbled; “of course you’ll come through.”
“我害怕。” “I’m afraid.”
她说话的声音小小的、闷闷的，但是这句话让人很难过。 The sound was small and smothered, but the words hurt horribly.
大自然露出了本性，迫使她——这个他深爱的姑娘——害怕了！ Nature, with the small ‘n,’ forcing fear into this girl he loved so awfully!
大自然在她的小脑瓜上面肆无忌惮地制造噪音。 Nature kicking up this godless din above her poor little head!
“亲爱的，你会接受半麻醉分娩，不会有什么感觉的。然后就像下雨一样，一会儿就过去了。” “Ducky, you’ll have twilight sleep and know nothing about it; and be as right as rain in no time.”
弗勒把自己的手抽了出来。 Fleur freed her hand.
“要是对孩子不好的话，就别用了。 “Not if it’s not good for him.
会对孩子有影响吗？” Is it?”
“我想不会，亲爱的，我会弄清楚的。 “I expect so, sweetheart; I’ll find out.
你怎么会想起——？” What makes you think—?”
“只是因为这不是自然生产。 “Only that it’s not natural.
我想要个合适的做法。 I want to do it properly.
抓紧我的手，迈克尔。 Hold my hand hard, Michael.
我——我不想当傻瓜。 I—I’m not going to be a fool.
啊！ Oh!
有人敲门——去看看。” Some one’s knocking—go and see.”
迈克尔把门开了一条缝。 Michael opened the door a crack.
索姆斯站在那里——很奇怪——他穿着蓝色的睡衣和红色的拖鞋！ Soames was there—unnatural—in a blue dressing gown and scarlet slippers!
“她还好吗？”他小声问道。 “Is she all right?” he whispered.
“是的。还好。” “Yes, yes.”
“这会儿这么闹，可不能让她自己呆着。” “In this bobbery she oughtn’t to be left.”
“不会的，先生。当然不会让她一个人呆着。 “No, sir, of course not.
我会睡在沙发上的。” I shall sleep on the sofa.”
“有需要的话，叫我一声。” “Call me, if anything’s wanted.”
“我会的。” “I will.”
索姆斯的目光从他身上越过，向屋里张望了一下。 Soames’ eyes slid past, peering into the room.
他喉头一紧，仿佛要说什么，却又没说出口。 A string worked in his throat, as if he had things to say which did not emerge.
他只是摇了摇头，转身走了。 He shook his head, and turned.
因为穿着睡衣，他那瘦削的身影显得比平时还要长，走过他送给他们的那几张日本版画，向走廊那边走去。 His slim figure, longer than usual, in its gown, receded down the corridor, past the Japanese prints which he had given them.
迈克尔再次把门关好，站在那里望着床。 Closing the door again, Michael stood looking at the bed.
弗勒已经躺下去了，眼睛闭着，嘴唇在动。 Fleur had settled down; her eyes were closed, her lips moving.
他踮着脚尖悄悄地走了回去。 He stole back on tiptoe.
雷声渐渐向南去了，仿佛后悔似的断断续续地发出隆隆声。 The thunder, travelling away south, blundered and growled as if regretfully.
迈克尔看到她眼睑在颤动，嘴唇却停了下来，一会又动了起来。 Michael saw her eyelids quiver, her lips stop, then move again.
“库埃的心理暗示！”他心里想。 ‘Coue!’ he thought.
他躺在床角的沙发上，他可以从那里悄悄地抬起身子看着她。 He lay down on the sofa at the foot of the bed, whence, without sound, he could raise himself and see her.
他起身很多次。 Many times he raised himself.
她已经睡着了，安静地呼吸着。 She had dropped off, was breathing quietly.
雷声变弱了，闪电也感觉不到了。 The thunder was faint now, the flashes imperceptible.
迈克尔闭上了眼睛。 Michael closed his eyes.
最后一阵低语让他又看了她一眼。她枕着高高的枕头，灯光被细心地遮住了。 A faint last mutter roused him to look at her once more, high on her pillows by the carefully shaded light.
年轻——真年轻！ Young—young!
苍白无色，像是朵蜡制的花！ Colourless, like a flower in wax!
脑子里没有什么计划，也没有畏惧——安安静静的！ No scheme in her brain, no dread—peaceful!
要是她能保持这样，然后一觉醒来，事情都过去了，那就好了！ If only she could stay like that and wake up with it all over!
他看了看旁边。 He looked away.
从镜子里看，她在远远的那一边，模模糊糊的；再看看右边，也是一样。 And there she was at the far end, dim, reflected in a glass; and there to the right, again.
在这间漂亮的房间里，她仿佛躺在他的周围，守护着他的心灵。 She lay, as it were, all round him in the pretty room, the inhabiting spirit—of his heart.
这会儿安静极了。 It was quite still now.
透过那些浅灰蓝色窗帘的缝隙，他可以看到几颗星星。 Through a chink in those powder-blue curtains he could see some stars.
大本钟敲1点钟了。 Big Ben chimed one.
他大概睡着了，起码是打了个盹儿，还做了一会儿梦。 He had slept, perhaps, dozed at least, dreamed a little.
一个微弱的声音吵醒了他。 A small sound woke him.
一只很小的狗，黄色的，尾巴垂着，卑微而又不引人注意，正慢慢地横穿这个房间，朝远远的角落走去。 A very little dog, tail down, yellow, low and unimportant, was passing down the room, trailing across it to the far corner.
“啊！”迈克尔想着，又闭上了眼睛，“是它啊！” ‘Ah!’ thought Michael, closing his eyes again: ‘You!’
第十二章 Chapter XII
股东的严峻考验 Ordeal by Shareholder
第二天，迈克尔到飞机俱乐部去。在那里，经过一番修饰显得格外潇洒的劳伦斯爵士正在休息室里等待，迈克尔想：“好一个老准爵爷！他已经打扮好准备上断头台了！” Repairing, next day, to the Aeroplane Club, where, notably spruce, Sir Lawrence was waiting in the lounge, Michael thought: ‘Good old Bart! he’s got himself up for the guillotine all right!’
“那条白色的拷边会把血显现出来的！”他说， “That white piping will show the blood!” he said.
“老福赛特今天早上很整洁，但是不俗气。” “Old Forsyte’s neat this morning, but not so gaudy.”
“啊！ “Ah!
‘老福赛特’怎么样？ How is ‘Old Forsyte’?
情绪好吗？” In good heart?”
“这可不方便问他，先生。 “One doesn’t ask him, sir.
您自己觉得怎么样？” How do you feel yourself?”
“和过去我在伊顿和温彻斯特比赛前的心情一模一样。 “Exactly as I used to before the Eton and Winchester match.
我想我要在吃午饭的时候喝点儿香迪啤酒。” I think I shall have shandy-gaff at lunch.”
他们坐下之后，劳伦斯爵士接着说： When they had taken their seats, Sir Lawrence went on:
“我记得在科伦坡看到一个人因为谋杀而受审，那个可怜的家伙可真够垂头丧气的。 “I remember seeing a man tried for murder in Colombo; the poor fellow was positively blue.
我认为过去我最得意的时候，迈克尔，是沃尔特·罗利再次向我索要衬衫的时候。 I think my favourite moment in the past, Michael, is Walter Raleigh asking for a second shirt.
顺便说一句，那时候的朝臣们身上是否长虱子，这个问题至今还没有定论。 By the way, it’s never been properly settled yet whether the courtiers of that day were lousy.
你想吃点儿什么，亲爱的年轻人？” What are you going to have, my dear fellow?”
“冷牛肉、盐渍核桃和醋栗馅饼。” “Cold beef, pickled walnuts, and gooseberry tart.”
“这些东西非常适合你。 “Excellent for the character.
我要吃咖喱，这里的龙头鱼非常不错。 I shall have curry; they give you a very good Bombay duck here.
我很确信我们会被解雇的，迈克尔。 I rather fancy we shall be fired, Michael.
‘我们已经被人出卖了！’这向来是法国人特有的说法，但是恐怕我们也逐渐抱有这种态度了。 ‘Nous sommes trahis!’ used to be the prerogative of the French, but I’m afraid we’re getting the attitude, too.
黄色报刊是起了作用的。” The Yellow Press has made a difference.”
迈克尔摇了摇头。 Michael shook his head.
“我们是这样说的，但是并没有这样做。风气太不稳定了。” “We say it, but we don’t act on it; the climate’s too uncertain.”
“这话听起来很深刻。 “That sounds deep.
这个咖喱看起来很不错——你要不要也换成咖喱？ This looks very good curry—will you change your mind?
老福坦诺有时候也到这儿来，他并不了解内情。 Old Fontenoy sometimes comes in here; he has no inside.
如果我们被赶了出去，事情对他来说就严重了。” It’ll be serious for him if we’re shown the door.”
“真奇怪，”迈克尔突然说，“贵族头衔怎么还很受欢迎。 “Deuced rum,” said Michael suddenly, “how titles still go down.
一点儿也不能相信他们做生意的能力。” There can’t be any belief in their business capacity.”
“这是名誉地位，亲爱的年轻人——善良的英国老绅士。 “Character, my dear fellow—the good old English gentleman.
毕竟，这是有点儿道理的。” After all, there’s something in it.”
“我想，先生，在股东们中这更像是一种复杂情结。 “I fancy, sir, it’s more a case of complex in the shareholders.
在他们小时候，父母就把有爵位的贵族指给他们看了。” Their parents show them a lord when they’re young.”
“股东，”劳伦斯爵士说，“这个词涉及面很广泛。 “Shareholders,” said Sir Lawrence; “the word is comprehensive.
他们是谁，他们是干什么的，他们什么时候成为股东的？” Who are they, what are they, when are they?”
“今天下午，”迈克尔说，“我可要好好看看他们。” “This afternoon,” said Michael, “and I shall have a good look at them.”
“他们不会让你进去的，亲爱的。” “They won’t let you in, my dear.”
“不让进？” “No?”
“当然不让进了。” “Certainly not.”
迈克尔皱了皱眉头。 Michael frowned.
“哪家报纸，”他说，“一定不会派代表来呢？” “What paper,” he said, “is sure not to be represented?”
劳伦斯爵士发出马嘶般的笑声。 Sir Lawrence gave his whinnying laugh.
“《田野报》，”他说，“《马与猎犬报》、《园丁周报》。” “The Field,” he said; “The Horse and Hound; The Gardener’s Weekly.”
“我就以他们的名义溜进去。” “I’ll slide in on them.”
“我希望你会看到我们宁死不屈。”劳伦斯爵士突然严肃地说。 “You’ll see us die game, I hope,” said Sir Lawrence, with sudden gravity.
他们一起乘出租车去开会，但是在到达宾馆门口之前就分开了。 They took a cab together to the meeting, but separated before reaching the door of the hotel.
迈克尔重新考虑之后，决定不以报社的名义混进去，他在走廊里找了个位置，在此等待机会。 Michael had thought better of the Press, and took up a position in the passage, whence he could watch for a chance.
穿着黑色西服的矮胖的人们不断从他身边经过，脸上明显带着一种午餐吃了大比目鱼、大块肉和奶酪的神情。 Stout men, in dark suits, with a palpable look of having lunched off turbot, joints, and cheese, kept passing him.
他注意到每个人都递给看门人一张纸。 He noticed that each handed the janitor a paper.
“我也递给他一张纸，”他想，“然后冲进去。” ‘I’ll hand him a paper, too,’ he thought, ‘and scoot in.’
他看到几个更加矮胖的人，便躲藏在其中两个人中间，走进门口，左手拿着一张“假冒的”通知。 Watching for some even stouter men, he took cover between two of them, and approached the door, with an announcement of ‘Counterfeits’ in his left hand.
他越过身边的一个大人物把它递过去，就迅速坐在一个位子上。 Handing it across a neighbouring importance, he was quickly into a seat.
他看到看门人在门口探了一下头。 He saw the janitor’s face poked round the door.
“不，我的朋友，”迈克尔想，“如果你能从股东中分辨出谁是冒牌货，你就不会做这份工作了！” ‘No, my friend,’ thought Michael, ‘if you could tell duds from shareholders, you wouldn’t be in that job!’
他发现面前有一份报告，就拿了起来，眼睛却看着别的东西。 He found a report before him, and holding it up, looked at other things.
这个房间在他看来似乎是由一个车站候车室改建成的音乐厅。 The room seemed to him to have been got by a concert-hall out of a station waiting-room.
房间里面有一个平台，上面摆着一张长桌子，桌子后面有七把空椅子，桌子上面放着七只墨水瓶，里面插着七只鹅毛笔。 It had a platform with a long table, behind which were seven empty chairs, and seven inkpots, with seven quill pens upright in them.
“鹅毛笔！”迈克尔想，“我想，这只是象征性的——他们都使用钢笔！” ‘Quills!’ thought Michael; ‘symbolic, I suppose—they’ll all use fountain-pens!’
平台后面的中央有一扇门，在门前的下方，有一张桌子，四个人坐在那里，拨弄着笔记本。 Back-centre of the platform was a door, and in front, below it, a table, where four men were sitting, fiddling with notebooks.
“管弦乐队。”迈克尔想。 ‘Orchestra,’ thought Michael.
他把注意力转向八到十排的股东。 He turned his attention to the eight or ten rows of shareholders.
他们看上去还是老样子，他也说不上来为什么。 They looked what they were, but he could not tell why.
他们的脸虽然长得各式各样，但是都带有一种神态，仿佛在等待他们明知自己不会得到的东西。 Their faces were cast in an infinity of moulds, but all had the air of waiting for something they knew they would not get.
他们过着什么样的生活，或者说他们的生活怎样造就了他们？ What sort of lives did they lead, or did their lives lead them?
几乎所有的人都留着小胡子。 Nearly all wore moustaches.
他左右两边的邻座就是他夹在他们中间溜进来的那两个矮胖的股东。他俩的耳朵都有大耳垂，脖子甚至比后脑勺还要粗。 His neighbours to right and left were the same stout shareholders between whom he had slipped in; they both had thick lobes to their ears, and necks even broader than the straight broad backs of their heads.
这给他留下了深刻的印象。 He was a good deal impressed.
他注意到在座之中还零星坐着一两位女士和牧师。 Dotted here and there he noticed a woman, or a parson.
几乎没有什么人在交谈，由此他推测出没有人认识自己的邻座。 There was practically no conversation, from which he surmised that no one knew his neighbour.
他觉得如果在某个地方有一条狗的话，会使这个场合显得人性化。 He had a feeling that a dog somewhere would have humanised the occasion.
他正在沉思着室内那种在绿色的底色上点缀着巧克力色并镶嵌着金色的色彩搭配，这时平台后面的那扇门突然打开了，七个穿着黑色外套的人陆续走了进来，微微鞠躬之后，就坐在了鹅毛笔后面的位子上。 He was musing on the colour scheme of green picked out with chocolate and chased with gold, when the door behind the platform was thrown open, and seven men in black coats filed in, and with little bows took their seats behind the quills.
他们使他想到了正在翻身上马的人，或者将要弹钢琴的人——都有许多小的调整动作。 They reminded him of people getting up on horses, or about to play the piano—full of small adjustments.
那个——坐在董事长右边的——应该是老福坦诺，他的脸完全是由各种特征组成的。 That—on the Chairman’s right—would be old Fontenoy, with a face entirely composed of features.
迈克尔有一种奇怪的幻想：一个头戴白色大礼帽的小家伙坐在大脑里面，八马齐驱地驾驭着这些特征。 Michael had an odd conceit: a little thing in a white top-hat sat inside the brain, driving the features eight-inhand.
之后的那张面孔好像直接是从1850年的女王陛下政府的一张画里出来的，粉红色的圆脸、高鼻梁、小嘴巴，还有一小撮白色的络腮胡子。而在右边的尽头有一张面孔，它的下巴和眼睛仿佛钻进了迈克尔背后那面墙之外的一个谜题里面去了。 Then came a face straight from a picture of Her Majesty’s Government in 1850, round and pink, with a high nose, a small mouth, and little white whiskers; while at the end on the right was a countenance whose jaw and eyes seemed boring into a conundrum beyond the wall at Michael’s back.
“法律！”他想。 ‘Legal!’ he thought.
他的目光又绕了回来仔细观察董事长。 His scrutiny passed back to the Chairman.
选举出来的？ Chosen?
他是——或者不是？ Was he—or was he not?
一个留着胡子的人，在董事长的左边稍靠后一点儿的地方，已经在用一种又快又单调的嗓音照本宣科。 A bearded man, a little behind on the Chairman’s left, was already reading from a book, in a rapid monotonous voice.
那一定是秘书在放他的志哀礼炮。 That must be the secretary letting off his minute guns.
在他前面的显然是新任的经理，在经理的左边，迈克尔看到了自己的父亲。 And in front of him was clearly the new manager, on whose left Michael observed his own father.
劳伦斯爵士右眼上的黑色单镜片框钩微微上扬，他的嘴巴缩拢在修剪整齐的小胡子下面。 The dark pothooks over Sir Lawrence’s right eye were slightly raised, and his mouth was puckered under the cut line of his small moustache.
他看上去简直就像个东方人，机敏而又沉稳。 He looked almost Oriental, quick but still.
他用左手的拇指和食指捏着他那玳瑁色边框的单片眼镜。 His left hand held his tortoiseshell-rimmed monocle between thumb and finger.
“还不太适应这种场面呢！”迈克尔想，“可怜的老准爵爷！” ‘Not quite in the scene!’ thought Michael; ‘poor old Bart!’
现在他的目光来到了这一排最后一个人的身上。 He had come now to the last of the row.
“老福赛特”坐在那里，完全就像全世界只有他孤身一人似的。他的一个嘴角垂下来，一个鼻孔拉上去，在迈克尔看来，他那副超然的样子十分迷人，然而他又不是置身事外的。 ‘Old Forsyte’ was sitting precisely as if alone in the world; with one corner of his mouth just drawn down, and one nostril just drawn up, he seemed to Michael quite fascinatingly detached; and yet not out of the picture.
在他那依然匀称的身材里，只有一只漆皮的靴子似乎轻微地动着，表明他是活的。他全神贯注，完全尊重会议程序，然而，对其又有一种奇怪的轻视。他就像是一座现实的雕塑，而塑造它的人发现其中几乎没有什么宝贵的现实。 Within that still neat figure, whereof only one patent-leather boot seemed with a slight movement to be living, was intense concentration, entire respect for the proceedings, and yet, a queer contempt for them; he was like a statue of reality, by one who had seen that there was precious little reality in it.
“他让我倒胃口，”迈克尔想，“但是——该死——我忍不住有点儿佩服他！” ‘He chills my soup,’ thought Michael, ‘but—dash it!—I can’t help half admiring him!’
现在董事长站了起来。 The Chairman had now risen.
“他是”——迈克尔想，“不，他不是——是——不——我分辨不出来！” ‘He IS’—thought Michael; ‘no, he isn’t—yes—no—I can’t tell!’
他几乎无法专心听董事长说的话，因为他正在想他究竟是不是选举出来的，尽管他非常清楚这个问题无关紧要。 He could hardly attend to what the Chairman said, for wondering whether he was chosen or not, though well aware that it did not matter at all.
董事长不慌不忙地继续说下去。 The Chairman kept steadily on.
由于思想不集中，迈克尔只听到了只言片语：“欧洲局势——被误导的方针政策——法国人——完全出乎意料——揭露出来的情况——经理——马上就会向你们解释这些不幸的情况——大家关注的公司未来——没有理由担心——” Distracted, Michael caught words and words: “European situation—misguided policy—French—totally unexpected—position disclosed—manager—unfortunate circumstances shortly to be explained to you—future of this great concern—no reason to doubt—”
“废话，”迈克尔想，“他是——可是——！” ‘Oil,’ thought Michael, ‘he is—and yet—!’
“现在我要请公司的董事之一，福赛特先生，向你们直接讲述这件令人痛心的事情。” “I will now ask one of your directors, Mr. Forsyte, to give you at first hand an account of this painful matter.”
迈克尔看到索姆斯，脸色苍白而从容不迫，从胸前的口袋中掏出一张纸，然后站了起来。 Michael saw Soames, pale and deliberate, take a piece of paper from his breast-pocket, and rise.
他这是挺身而出吗？ Was it to the occasion?
“我把事实简单向大家汇报一下，”他说话的声音让迈克尔想起了一种调制的干葡萄酒， “I will give you the facts shortly,” he said in a voice which reminded Michael of a dry, made-up wine.
“一月十一日那天，本公司雇佣的一名职员来见我——” “On the eleventh of January last I was visited by a clerk in the employ of the Society—”
由于非常熟悉这些细节，迈克尔没有怎么仔细听，而是注视着股东们的反应。 Familiar with these details, Michael paid them little attention, watching the shareholders for signs of reaction.
他看不出任何迹象，突然他想到他们为什么要留胡子：他们不能相信自己的嘴巴！ He saw none, and it was suddenly borne in on him why they wore moustaches: They could not trust their mouths!
性格就在嘴巴里。 Character was in the mouth.
胡子是在人们不再四处走动的时候流行起来的，就像那个老公爵，说：“这就是我的性格，你们爱怎么想就怎么想吧！” Moustaches had come in when people no longer went about, like the old Duke, saying: “Think what you damned well like of my character!”
当然，在战前，不留胡子的光嘴巴曾经试图再次流行起来，但是由于年长的人、股东以及工人阶级的原因，它们流行起来的机会很小或根本就没有机会！ Mouths had tried to come in again, of course, before the war; but what with majors, shareholders, and the working classes, they now had little or no chance!
他听到索姆斯说：“在这种情况下，我们得出的结论是，除了静待观望形势之外，，没有别的办法。” He heard Soames say: “In these circumstances we came to the conclusion that there was nothing for it but to wait and see.”
迈克尔看到那些胡子突然颤动了一下，就像一阵风吹过草地。 Michael saw a sudden quiver pass over the moustaches, as might wind over grass.
“措辞不当，”他想，“我们都犯过这种错误，但是我们都不能容忍别人提起它。” ‘Wrong phrase,’ he thought; ‘we all do it, but we can’t bear being reminded of it.’
“但是，六个星期之前，”他听到索姆斯拖长了声音，“一件意外的事情似乎警告了你们的前任经理，使他知道劳伦斯爵士和我对他仍然抱有怀疑，因为我收到了他的一封来信，信中实际上承认了他在德国业务中收受了秘密佣金，并要求我通知董事会，他已经出国了，并且没有留下任何财产。 “Six weeks ago, however,” he heard Soames intone, “an accidental incident seems to have warned your late manager that Sir Lawrence and I still entertained suspicions, for I received a letter from him practically admitting that he had taken this secret commission on the German business, and asking me to inform the Board that he had gone abroad and left no property behind him.
我们已经尽力对这番陈述进行了核实。 This statement we have been at pains to verify.
在这种情况下，我们别无选择，只能把大家召集起来，并把事实摆在你们面前。” In these circumstances we had no alternative but to call you together, and lay the facts before you.”
一直没有丝毫变化的声音停止了陈述；迈克尔看到他的岳父又恢复了超然的状态——就像一只鹳鸟单腿站立着，正准备用嘴去啄食寄生虫，不会引起更加强烈的孤寂感了。 The voice, which had not varied an iota, ceased its recital; and Michael saw his father-inlaw return to his detachment—stork on one leg, about to apply beak to parasite, could have inspired no greater sense of loneliness.
“太像日德兰海战的第一次战况报告了！”他想，“他提到了所有的损失，但是一次也没有打动人们的心。” ‘Too like the first account of the battle of Jutland!’ he thought: ‘He mentioned all the losses, and never once struck the human note.’
接下来是一阵停顿，就像某人在还没有找到大门之前，面对着栅栏而感到的尴尬一样沉寂。 A pause ensued, such as occurs before an awkward fence, till somebody has found a gate.
迈克尔迅速地观察了一下董事会成员们的脸。 Michael rapidly reviewed the faces of the Board.
只有一张脸表现出了一点儿生气。 Only one showed any animation.
这张脸掩盖在一张手帕后面。 It was concealed in a handkerchief.
一阵擤鼻子的声音打破了沉寂。 The sound of the blown nose broke the spell.
两个股东立刻站了起来——其中一个就是迈克尔右边的邻座。 Two shareholders rose to their feet at once—one of them Michael’s neighbour on the right.
“索德利先生。”董事长说，于是另外那个股东坐了下来。 “Mr. Sawdry,” said the Chairman, and the other shareholder sat down.
迈克尔的邻座响亮地清了清嗓子，把他那张生硬的红脸转向索姆斯。 With a sonorous clearing of the throat, Michael’s neighbour turned his blunt red face towards Soames.
“我想问您一下，先生，当您第一次听到这个消息的时候，为什么没有通知董事会？” “I wish to ask you, sir, why you didn’t inform the Board when you first ‘eard of this?”
索姆斯微微起身。 Soames rose slightly.
“我相信您一定很清楚，如果没有充分的证据，这种告发行为是会引起刑事诉讼的吧？” “You are aware, I presume, that such an accusation, unless it can be fully substantiated, is a matter for criminal proceedings?”
“不，这是可以获得豁免权的。” “No; it would ha’ been privileged.”
“在各位董事之间，也许是这样，但是任何消息的泄露都会使我们负有责任。 “As between members of the Board, perhaps; but any leakage would have rendered us liable.
这只不过是一件口说无凭的事情罢了。” It was a mere case of word against word.”
“也许劳伦斯·蒙特爵士会告诉我们他对这件事的看法吧？” “Perhaps Sir Lawrence Mont will give us ‘is view of that?”
迈克尔的心开始跳动起来。 Michael’s heart began to beat.
他父亲站在那里的姿态带有一种轻松愉快的样子。 There was an air of sprightliness about his father’s standing figure.
“你一定记得，先生，”他说，“埃尔德森先生多年以来一直深受我们的信任，他是一个绅士，而且，就我个人而言，我是他的老同学，出于一般的忠诚，我更倾向于相信他的话，而——呃——把这件事记在心里。” “You must remember, sir,” he said, “that Mr. Elderson had enjoyed our complete confidence for many years; he was a gentleman, and, speaking for myself, an old schoolfellow of his, I preferred, in common loyalty, to give his word preference, while—er—keeping the matter in mind.”
“哦！”迈克尔的邻座说，“关于被蒙在鼓里，董事长有什么话要说吗？” “Oh!” said Michael’s neighbour: “What’s the Chairman got to say about bein’ kept in the dark?”
“在一种微妙的形势下，我们大家对于董事同僚们的态度，先生，是非常满意的。 “We are all perfectly satisfied, sir, with the attitude of our co-directors, in a very delicate situation.
请您注意一下，在这笔不幸的保险业务上，损害已经造成了，所以没有必要过分性急。” You will kindly note that the mischief was already done over this unfortunate assurance, so that there was no need for undue haste.”
迈克尔看到他的邻座的脖子变得更红了。 Michael saw his neighbour’s neck grow redder.
“我不同意这种说法，”他说， “I don’t agree,” he said.
“‘静待观望形势’——如果能立刻把他抓住，我们可能已经把那笔佣金从他身上挖出来了。” “‘Wait and see’—We might have ‘ad that commission out of him, if he’d been tackled promptly.”
说完他就坐了下来。 And he sat down.
他还没来得及坐到红木椅子上，刚才那个被拦住的股东就突然跳了起来。 He had not reached mahogany before the thwarted shareholder had started up.
“伯特利尔先生。”董事长说。 “Mr. Botterill,” said the Chairman.
迈克尔看到一个又瘦又窄的脑袋，长毛的脖子上有两处凹陷，背部微微前倾，就像一个医生正在听诊胸部。 Michael saw a lean and narrow head, with two hollows in a hairy neck, above a back slightly bent forward, as of a doctor listening to a chest.
“那么，先生，听了您的话我的理解是，”他说，“这两位董事代表了董事会的总体态度，而董事会甘愿让一个可疑的人继续担任经理。 “I take it from you, then, sir,” he said, “that these two directors represent the general attitude of the Board, and that the Board were content to allow a suspected person to remain manager.
在您最左边的那位先生——福赛特先生，我想是——说到过一件意外的事情。 The gentleman on your extreme left—Mr. Forsyte, I think—spoke of an accidental incident.
如果没有那件事，很显然，我们仍然会处于一个无耻之徒的掌握之中。 But for that, apparently, we should still be in the hands of an unscrupulous individual.
这件事情的种种迹象非常令人不安。 The symptoms in this case are very disquieting.
这其中似乎存在严重的过度自信。最近出现的这个事例，我们必须谨记在心。 There appears to have been gross over-confidence; a recent instance of the sort must be in all our minds.
承保国外业务的方针政策显然是那位经理出于自己的目的而发起的。 The policy of assuring foreign business was evidently initiated by the manager for his own ends.
我们因此遭受了严重的损失。 We have made a severe loss by it.
而我们这些股东们面临的问题似乎是，一个对这样一个人给予信任，并且在引起他们的怀疑之后还继续给予他信任的董事会，究竟是不是管理这个重要的公司的合适人选。” And the question for us shareholders would seem to be whether a Board who placed confidence in such a person, and continued it after their suspicions were aroused, are the right people to direct this important concern.”
在这段发言的整个过程中，迈克尔越听火气越大。 Throughout this speech Michael had grown very hot.
“‘老福赛特’说得对，”他想，“毕竟他们快要走投无路了。” ‘“Old Forsyte” was right,’ he thought; ‘they’re on their uppers after all.’
他左边的邻座突然发出一阵嘎吱嘎吱的声音。 There was a sudden creak from his neighbour on the left.
“托尔比先生。”董事长说。 “Mr. Tolby,” said the Chairman.
“这是一件严重的事情，这件事，先生们。 “It’s a seerious matter, this, gentlemen.
我提议董事会退席，我们留下来讨论这件事情。” I propose that the Board withdraw, an’ leave us to discuss it.”
“我赞成。”迈克尔右边的邻座说。 “I second that,” said Michael’s neighbour on the right.
迈克尔察看着董事会那一长排人，看到在排尾那张孤寂的脸上闪过一丝认出他的神情，于是他咧嘴笑着打招呼。 Searching the vista of the Board, Michael saw recognition gleam for a second in the lonely face at the end, and grinned a greeting.
董事长正在说话。 The Chairman was speaking.
“如果你们希望这样，先生们，我们乐于遵命。 “If that is your wish, gentlemen, we shall be happy to comply with it.
请赞成这个提议的人举一下手好吗？” Will those who favour the motion hold up their hands?”
所有的人都举起了手，除了迈克尔，还有因在专心谈话而没有听到这个请求的两位女士，以及坐在迈克尔正前方的一个股东，他一动也不动，好像死了一样。 All hands were held up, with the exception of Michael’s, of two women whose eager colloquy had not permitted them to hear the request, and of one shareholder, just in front of Michael, so motionless that he seemed to be dead.
“通过。”董事长说，然后就从座位上站了起来。 “Carried,” said the Chairman, and rose from his seat.
迈克尔看到他的父亲正在微笑，他在和“老福赛特”说着话，两个人都站了起来。 Michael saw his father smiling, and speaking to ‘Old Forsyte’ as they both stood up.
他们都陆续退了出去，然后那扇门就关上了。 They all filed out, and the door was closed.
“无论发生什么事情，”迈克尔想，“我一定要保持镇定，否则我会闯祸的。” ‘Whatever happens,’ Michael thought, ‘I’ve got to keep my head shut, or I shall be dropping a brick.’
“新闻界也请退席吧。”他听到有人说。 “Perhaps the Press will kindly withdraw, too,” he heard some one say.
那四位记者都动了动下巴，仿佛是在询问他们是否没有特权似的，只见他们合上了笔记本。 With a general chinny movement, as if enquiring their rights of no one in particular, the four Pressmen could be seen to clasp their notebooks.
当他们那几张苍白勉强的脸消失之后，股东们中间掀起了一阵骚乱，就像一群鸭子后面有一条狗追赶了上来似的。 When their pale reluctance had vanished, there was a stir among the shareholders, like that of ducks when a dog comes up behind.
迈克尔立刻看出了原因。 Michael saw why, at once.
他们彼此都背对着背。 They had their backs to each other.
一个股东说： A shareholder said:
“或许提议董事会退席的托尔比先生可以担当主席。” “Perhaps Mr. Tolby, who proposed the withdrawal, will act as Chairman.”
迈克尔左边的邻座呼吸开始变得沉重起来。 Michael’s left-hand neighbour began breathing heavily.
“好啊！”他说， “Right-o!” he said.
“哪一位要发言，请示意我。” “Any one who wants to speak, kindly ketch my eye.”
这时每一个人都开始和邻座的人交谈起来，仿佛是要在发言之前立刻获得一种平静的分寸感。 Everyone now began talking to his neighbour, as though to get at once a quiet sense of proportion, before speaking.
托尔比先生呼吸如此沉重，使得迈克尔都能感受到他呼出的一阵阵气浪。 Mr. Tolby was breathing so heavily that Michael felt a positive draught.
“呃，先生们，”他突然说，“这样不行啊！ “‘Ere, gentlemen,” he said suddenly, “this won’t do!
我们不需要太正式，但是我们必须保持点儿秩序。 We don’t want to be too formal, but we must preserve some order.
我自己来给讨论开个头吧。 I’ll open the discussion myself.
嗯，我不想当着董事会的面把话说得太直白，以免伤了他们的感情。 Now, I didn’t want to ‘urt the feelin’s of the Board by plain speakin’ in their presence.
但是，正如刚才那里的某一位先生所说的：公众必须保护自己以防骗子欺诈，并且防止松懈懒散。 But, as Mr. What’s-’is-name there, said: The public ‘as got to protect itself against sharpers, and against slackness.
我们大家都知道前些日子发生了什么事情，以及以后在其他公司还会发生什么事情，除非我们股东自己照顾自己。 We all know what ‘appened the other day, and what’ll ‘appen again in other concerns, unless we shareholders look after ourselves.
那么，首先，我要说的是：凡是和德国佬有关的事情，他们根本就不应该碰。 In the first place, then, what I say is: They ought never to ‘ave touched anything to do with the ‘Uns.
其次，我要说他们表现出拙劣的判断力。 In the second place, I say they showed bad judgment.
第三，我要说他们的关系太亲密了。 And in the third place I say they were too thick together.
在我看来，我们应该提议投不信任票。” In my opinion, we should propose a vote of no confidence.”
与许多模糊不清的声音混杂着一起的“说得好，说得好！”的叫喊声，，突然被一声响亮的“反对”打破了，这是那个好像死了一样的股东喊出来的。 Cries of: “Hear, hear!” mixed with indeterminate sounds, were broken sharply by a loud: “No!” from the shareholder who had seemed dead.
迈克尔对他充满了好感，尤其是当他仍然好像死了一样一动不动时，这种好感便越发强烈了。 Michael’s heart went out to him, the more so as he still seemed dead.
随着这个否定的喊声，站起来一位瘦削文雅的、留着灰白色小胡子的股东。 The negative was followed by the rising of a thin, polished-looking shareholder, with a small grey moustache.
“但愿您能原谅我这么说，先生，”他开始说道，“在我看来，您的建议似乎是一种甚为勉强的评判。 “If you’ll forgive my saying so, sir,” he began, “your proposal seems to me very rough-and-ready justice.
我很想知道，如果您是董事会的成员，您将会如何处理这种局面。 I should be interested to know how you would have handled such a situation if you had been on the Board.
谴责别人是非常容易的！” It is extremely easy to condemn other people!”
“说得好，说得好！”迈克尔说，他对自己的声音感到惊讶。 “Hear, hear!” said Michael, astonished at his own voice.
“发生了这种事情，”这位文雅的股东继续说，“去责备董事会是很容易的，但是，我自己作为一个董事而言，我很想知道，如果我不信任经理，又该信任谁。 “It is all very well,” the polished shareholder went on, “when any thing of this sort happens, to blame a directorate, but, speaking as a director myself, I should be glad to know whom one is to trust, if not one’s manager.
至于国外保险业务的方针政策，我们已经在两次股东大会上研究过了，而且我们由此获利已经差不多两年了。 As to the policy of foreign insurance, it has been before us at two general meetings; and we have pocketed the profit from it for nearly two years.
我们可曾对此提出过反对吗？” Have we raised a voice against it?”
那个死了一样的股东喊了一声“反对！”，那声音如此响亮，以至于迈克尔几乎要拍拍他的脑袋表示赞许。 The dead shareholder uttered a “No!” so loud that Michael almost patted his head.
那个颈部和背部像一个医生似的股东站起来回答了。 The shareholder, whose neck and back were like a doctor’s, rose to answer.
“我不同意刚才那位发言人对这个事件的判断。 “I differ from the last speaker in his diagnosis of the case.
我们姑且承认他所说的一切，同时从更加广泛的角度来看它。 Let us admit all he says, and look at the thing more widely.
布丁好不好吃，要吃了才知道。 The proof of pudding is in the eating.
当一个政府在判断上出现了严重的错误，选民一旦感受到了它的后果，就会反对它。 When a Government makes a bad mistake of judgment, the electorate turns against it as soon as it feels the effects.
这是对于行政管理的一种非常合情合理的遏制。这种做法可能是差强人意的，但却是两害取其轻的做法。 This is a very sound check on administration; it may be rough and ready, but it is the less of two evils.
董事会支持自己的判断，当它失败了，它应该付出代价。 A Board backs its judgment; when it loses, it should pay.
我认为，托尔比先生作为我们的非正式的董事长，提议投不信任票或许是有违议事规程的。如果一定要那样做的话，我自己很乐于对此投同样的不信任票。” I think, perhaps, Mr. Tolby, being our informal Chairman, was out of order in proposing a vote of no confidence; if that be so, I should be happy to do so, myself.”
那位死了一样的股东这次喊出的“反对！”如此响亮，以至于大家都停下来等他发言，然而，他还是一动不动。 The dead shareholder’s “No!” was so resounding this time that there was a pause for him to speak; he remained, however, without motion.
迈克尔两边的邻座都站了起来。 Both of Michael’s neighbours were on their feet.
他们在迈克尔的头顶上互相谦让了一下，之后托尔比先生坐了下来。 They bobbed at each other over Michael’s head, and Mr. Tolby sat down.
“索德利先生。”他说。 “Mr. Sawdry,” he said.
“请注意，先生们，”索德利先生说，“女士们，在我看来，这件事得采取妥协的办法。 “Look ‘ere, gentlemen,” said Mr. Sawdry, “and ladies, this seems to me a case for compromise.
那些了解经理的董事们应该离开，但是我们可以到此为止。 The Directors that knew about the manager ought to go; but we might stop at that.
我前面的这位先生一直说‘反对’。 The gentleman in front of me keeps on saying ‘No.’
让他告诉我们他的意见。” Let ‘im give us ‘is views.”
“反对。”那位死了一样的股东说，但是声音不那么响亮了。 “No,” said the dead shareholder, but less loudly.
“如果一个人不提出自己的意见，”索德利先生接着说，差一点儿坐到迈克尔的身上，“我认为，他就不应该打岔。” “If a man can’t give ‘is views,” went on Mr. Sawdry, nearly sitting down on Michael, “‘c shouldn’t interrupt, in my opinion.”
前排的一个股东现在完全转过身来，面对着会场。 A shareholder in the front row now turned completely round so that he faced the meeting.
“我认为，”他说，“再讨论下去就是浪费时间。很显然，我们即使没有三种意见，也有两种。 “I think,” he said, “that to prolong this discussion is to waste time; we are evidently in two, if not three, minds.
我们这个国家的一切事务目前都是按照委任信托制度进行的。这可能是好的，但也可能是不好的——但是情况就是这样。 The whole of the business of this country is now conducted on a system of delegated trust; it may be good, it may be bad—but there it is.
你不得不信任某个人。 You’ve got to trust somebody.
现在，关于这件特定的事情，到目前为止，我们没有理由不信任董事会。而且，在我看来，董事会之前也没有理由不信任前任经理。 Now, as to this particular case, we’ve had no reason to distrust the Board, so far; and, as I take it, the Board had no previous reason to distrust the late manager.
目前提出诸如投不信任票之类的明确措施，我认为那样太过分了。我觉得我们应该把董事会成员叫进来，听一听他们必须给我们什么保证，以防将来再发生类似的事情。” I think it’s going too far, at present, to propose anything definite like a vote of no confidence; it seems to me that we should call the Board in and hear what assurances they have to give us against a repetition of anything of the sort in the future.”
这番温和的发言所引起的反响是如此错综复杂，迈克尔无法听出他们的意思。 The sounds which greeted this moderate speech were so inextricable that Michael could not get the sense of them.
接下来的发言情况就不同了。 Not so with the speech which followed.
那是右边的一个股东讲的，他长着浅红色的头发，淡淡的睫毛，胡子修剪得整整齐齐，脸刮得很干净。 It came from a shareholder on the right, with reddish hair, light eyelashes, a clipped moustache, and a scraped colour.
“我一点儿也不反对把董事会成员们叫进来，”他用一种十分嘲弄的声调说，“并且要当着他们的面投不信任票。 “I have no objection whatever to having the Board in,” he said in a rather jeering voice, “and passing a vote of no confidence in their presence.
有一个问题还没有人提到，就是如果我们把他们赶出去，我们还能让他们对这笔损失承担多大的责任。 There is a question, which no one has touched on, of how far, if we turn them out, we could make them liable for this loss.
这个问题现在还不清楚，但是如果我们愿意抓住这次机会的话，这会是一个很公平的机会。 The matter is not clear, but there is a good sporting chance, if we like to take it.
反之，如果我们不把他们赶出去，即使我们想抓住机会，我们显然也抓不住了。” Whereas, if we don’t turn them out, it’s obvious we can’t take it, even if we wish.”
此番发言给人们留下的印象和以前所有的发言完全不同。 The impression made by this speech was of quite a different order from any of the others.
这之后是一阵沉默，仿佛终于有人说出重要的话了。 It was followed by a hush, as though something important had been said at last.
迈克尔盯着托尔比先生。 Michael stared at Mr. Tolby.
这个矮胖子那相当突出的浅色圆眼睛充满了深邃的思考。 The stout man’s round, light, rather prominent eye was extraordinarily reflective.
“当鲑鱼看到蜉蝣的时候，”迈克尔想，“它们的眼睛一定是这个样子。” ‘Trout must look like that,’ thought Michael, ‘when they see a mayfly.’
托尔比先生突然站了起来。 Mr. Tolby suddenly stood up.
“好吧，”他说，“叫他们进来！” “All right,” he said, “‘ave ‘em in!”
“好。”那个死了一样的股东说。 “Yes,” said the dead shareholder.
没有人表示反对。 There was no dissent.
迈克尔看到有人站了起来，登上平台。 Michael saw some one rise and ascend the platform.
“通知记者们！”托尔比先生说。 “Let the Press know!” said Mr. Tolby.
第十三章 Chapter XIII
索姆斯陷入绝境 Soames at Bay
当董事们离开会场，关上门之后，索姆斯找了一个窗户，尽可能来消化在开会前吃的那顿午饭。 When the door had closed behind the departing directors, Soames sought a window as far as possible from the lunch eaten before the meeting.
“葬礼中剩下的残羹冷炙，呃，福赛特？”他的耳边有一个声音说， “Funeral baked meats, eh, Forsyte?” said a voice in his ear.
“我想我们的气数已尽了。 “Our number’s up, I think.
可怜的老马瑟吉尔看起来非常沮丧。 Poor old Mothergill’s looking very blue.
我想他应该要求第二件衬衫了！” I think he ought to ask for a second shirt!”
索姆斯的执拗脾气开始发作了。 Soames’ tenacity began wriggling within him.
“这件事需要着手解决，”他喃喃地说，“董事长不是做这件事的合适人选！” “The thing wants tackling,” he grumbled; “the Chairman’s not the man for the job!”
让人想起老乔里恩叔叔啊！ Shades of old Uncle Jolyon!
他一定能迅速解决这件事！ He would have made short work of this!
这需要强有力的手腕。 It wanted a masterful hand.
“这是警告我们大家，福赛特，不要讲忠诚了。 “Warning to us all, Forsyte, against loyalty!
这不合时宜。 It’s not in the period.
啊！ Ah!
福坦诺！” Fontenoy!”
索姆斯意识到有一个比他高的人在旁边。 Soames became conscious of features rather above the level of his own.
“哦，福赛特先生，你满意了吧？ “Well, Mr. Forsyte, hope you’re satisfied?
这可真是该死的一团糟！ A pretty damned mess!
如果我是董事长，我决不会退席。 If I’d been the Chairman, I’d never have withdrawn.
要时刻看住你的猎犬，蒙特。 Always keep hounds under your eye, Mont.
目光一离开，它们就会袭击你！ Take it off, and they’ll go for you!
真希望我能拿着鞭子跑到他们中间去，我要抽那两个哈巴狗脸似的胖家伙——他们是存心这样做的！ Wish I could get among ‘em with a whip; I’d give it those two heavy pug-faced chaps—they mean business!
除非您有什么锦囊妙计，福赛特先生，否则我们就完蛋了。” Unless you’ve got something up your sleeve, Mr. Forsyte, we’re dished.”
“我会有什么妙计？”索姆斯冷冷地说。 “What should I have up my sleeve?” said Soames coldly.
“真该死，先生，是你把栗子放进火里去的，应该由你把它们取出来。 “Damn it, sir, you put the chestnuts in the fire; it’s up to you to pull ‘em out.
我可承受不起这笔酬劳费的损失！” I can’t afford to lose these fees!”
索姆斯听到劳伦斯爵士喃喃地说：“太粗鲁了，我亲爱的福坦诺！”于是他恶毒地说： Soames heard Sir Lawrence murmur: “Crude, my dear Fontenoy!” and said with malice:
“也许你损失的不只是你的酬劳费！” “You may lose more than your fees!”
“不可能！ “Can’t!
也许明天他们就会成立鹰庭，承担我的损失。” They may have Eaglescourt tomorrow, and take a loss off my hands.”
那双苍老的眼睛里突然燃起了同情的闪光：“国家把你逼得走投无路，把你剥得只剩骨头，还指望你无偿地为他们提供公共服务。 A gleam of feeling burned up suddenly in the old eyes: “The country drives you to the wall, skins you to the bone, and expects you to give ‘em public service gratis.
办不到，蒙特——办不到！” Can’t be done, Mont—can’t be done!”
索姆斯转过身去，他完全不想说话，就像一个人站在敞开的墓穴前面，看着一口棺材慢慢地放下去。 Soames turned away; he had an utter disinclination for talk, like one standing before an open grave, watching a coffin slowly lowered.
他那一贯正确的名声就这样完了——完了！ Here was his infallibility going—going!
他不抱任何幻想。 He had no illusions.
这件事会刊登在各家报纸上，他以出众的决断力而闻名的声誉一去不复返了！ It would all be in the papers, and his reputation for sound judgment gone for ever!
真痛苦！ Bitter!
福赛特家的人再也不会说“索姆斯说——”了。老格雷德曼再也不会用那双像老狗一样忠诚的眼睛追随着他了，尽管有时候有些勉强，但是始终服从他那一贯正确的判断。 No more would the Forsytes say: “Soames says—” No more would old Gradman follow him with eyes like an old dog’s, grudging sometimes, but ever submitting to infallibility.
这将使那个老家伙大为震惊。 It would be a nasty jar for the old fellow.
他那些生意上的熟人——毕竟，现在不太多了！——再也不会用羡慕而尊敬的目光注视他了。 His business acquaintances—after all, they were not many, now!—would no longer stare with envious respect.
他不知道这些反响会不会传到杜梅特里斯以及绘画市场上！ He wondered if the reverberations would reach Dumetrius, and the picture market!
唯一的安慰是：不必让弗勒知道。 The sole comfort was: Fleur needn’t know.
弗勒！ Fleur!
啊！ Ah!
但愿她能平安顺利地生产！ If only her business were safely over!
他的脑子里有一会儿只想着这件事，其他的什么都不想。 For a moment his mind became empty of all else.
接着，眼前的事情又突然一下子充满了他的脑子。 Then with a rush the present filled it up again.
为什么他们讲话的时候都好像房间里有一具死尸似的呢？ Why were they all talking as if there were a corpse in the room?
哦！ Well!
确实有——就是他那一贯正确的死尸！ There was—the corpse of his infallibility!
至于金钱上的损失——那似乎是次要的、遥远的、难以置信的——就像来世一样。 As for monetary loss—that seemed secondary, remote, incredible—like a future life.
蒙特说过一些关于忠诚的话。 Mont had said something about loyalty.
他不知道这件事和忠诚有什么关系！ He didn’t know what loyalty had to do with it!
但是如果他们认为他会示弱的话，那他们就大错特错了。 But if they thought he was going to show any white feather, they were extremely mistaken.
他的心中涌起了犀利的勇气。 Acid courage welled up into his brain.
股东们，董事们——他们或许会咆哮怒吼并挥舞着拳头，但他不会任人摆布的。 Shareholders, directors—they might howl and shake their fists; he was not going to be dictated to.
他听到一个声音说： He heard a voice say:
“请你们进来好吗，先生们？” “Will you come in, please, gentlemen?”
他又在那支他从未用过的鹅毛笔前坐了下来，他注意到全场一片沉寂——股东们在等着董事们发言，而董事们在等着股东们发言。 Taking his seat again before his unused quill, he noticed the silence—shareholders waiting for directors, directors for shareholders.
“真希望我能拿着鞭子跑到他们中间去！” “Wish I could get among ‘em with a whip!”
这是那个“老豚鼠”说的放肆话，但是不知怎么的，很有表现力！ Extravagant words of that ‘old guinea-pig’s,’ but expressive, somehow!
最后，董事长讽刺地说，他的声音总是让索姆斯想起一种上面浇过油的生沙拉： At last the Chairman, whose voice always reminded Soames of a raw salad with oil poured over it, said ironically:
“哦，先生们，我们在等各位的指示呢。” “Well, gentlemen, we await your pleasure.”
坐在迈克尔旁边的那个红脸矮胖子站了起来，张开了他那哈巴狗似的嘴。 That stout, red-faced fellow, next to Michael, stood up, opening his pug’s mouth.
“简单地说，董事长先生，我们一点儿也不满意。但是在我们做出任何决议之前，我们想要听一听你们有什么要说的。” “To put it shortly, Mr. Chairman, we’re not at all satisfied; but before we take any resolution, we want to ‘ear what you’ve got to say.”
就在索姆斯的下面，一个人跳了起来，补充道：“我们想要知道，先生，你们能向我们做出什么样的保证，以避免今后再发生这种事情。” Just below Soames, some one jumped up and added: “We’d like to know, sir, what assurances you can offer us against anything of this sort in the future.”
索姆斯看到董事长在微笑——那个家伙没有真正的骨气！ Soames saw the Chairman smile—no real backbone in that fellow!
“从道理上讲，先生，”他说，“什么保证也没有！ “In the nature of things, sir,” he said, “none whatever!
你总不至于认为，如果我们已经知道了我们的经理不值得我们信任，我们还会继续让他担任这个职务吧！” You can hardly suppose that if we had known our manager was not worthy of our confidence, we should have continued him in the post for a moment!”
索姆斯想：“这样说可不行——他的话自相矛盾了！” Soames thought: ‘That won’t do—he’s gone back on himself!’
果然，另外那一个哈巴狗脸似的家伙看出了这一点！ Yes, and that other pug-faced chap had seen it!
“关键就在这里，先生，”他说，“你们中间有两个人的确知道，然而，这个家伙之后又干了几个月，为他自己牟利，竭尽全力地欺骗公司，我觉得这不足为奇。” “That’s just the point, sir,” he was saying: “Two of you DID know, and yet, there the fellow was for months afterwards, playin’ ‘is own ‘and, cheatin’ the Society for all he was worth, I shouldn’t wonder.”
此时他们一个接一个地都在叫嚷： One after another, they were yelping now:
“你们自己说过的话算不算数？” “What about your own words?”
“你们应承过会集体负责的。” “You admitted collective responsibility.”
“你们说过，你们对于董事同僚们在这件事情上的态度是非常满意的。” “You said you were perfectly satisfied with the attitude of your co-directors in the matter.”
真是一群疯狗！ Regular pack!
索姆斯看到董事长低下头，好像要摇头的样子，老福坦诺在喃喃自语，老马瑟吉尔在擤鼻子，梅里克在耸着他那瘦削的肩膀。 Soames saw the Chairman incline his head as if he wanted to shake it; old Fontenoy muttering, old Mothergill blowing his nose, Meyricke shrugging his sharp shoulders.
突然他观察他们的视线被挡住——劳伦斯爵士在中间站了起来。 Suddenly he was cut off from view of them—Sir Lawrence was standing up between.
“请允许我说一句话！ “Allow me a word!
就我自己而言，董事长试图慷慨地承担明显应该由我负起的责任，对此我不能接受。 Speaking for myself, I find it impossible to accept the generous attempt of the Chairman to shoulder a responsibility which clearly rests on me.
如果我在没有公开我们的怀疑这一点上做出了错误的判断，那么我应该受到处罚，而且我认为如果我向大会提交辞呈，那将会使——呃——局势明朗一点儿。” If I made a mistake of judgment in not disclosing our suspicions, I must pay the penalty; and I think it will clear the—er—situation if I tender my resignation to the meeting.”
索姆斯看到他微微鞠了一躬，把他的单片眼镜架在眼睛前，然后坐了下来。 Soames saw him give a little bow, place his monocle in his eye, and sit down.
这番话引起了阵阵私语——是赞成、惊讶、反对，还是佩服呢？ A murmur greeted the words—approval, surprise, deprecation, admiration?
这件事做得很勇敢。 It had been gallantly done.
索姆斯不相信勇敢的行为——总有一点儿炫耀的意思。 Soames distrusted gallantry—there was always a dash of the peacock about it.
他感到莫名其妙的愤怒。 He felt curiously savage.
“我，很显然，”他说着，站了起来，“是另一个被指控的董事。 “I, apparently,” he said, rising, “am the other incriminated director.
很好！ Very good!
这件事从头至尾，我觉得除了尽了我的职责之外，我没有做过任何事情。 I am not conscious of having done anything but my duty from beginning to end of this affair.
我确信我没有做出错误的判断。 I am confident that I made no mistake of judgment.
而且我认为，如果我受到处罚，那是完全不公正的。 And I consider it entirely unjust that I should be penalised.
在我加入董事会之前，股东们已经毫无异议地接受了这项方针政策，现在他们因遭受了损失就发起脾气来，要拿我当替罪羊，即便他们不这样做，我也已经够担心和焦虑的了。 I have had worry and anxiety enough, without being made a scapegoat by shareholders who accepted this policy without a murmur, before ever I came on the Board, and are now angry because they have lost by it.
多亏了我，这项方针政策才被放弃了：多亏了我，你们才不再让一个骗子当经理。 You owe it to me that the policy has been dropped: You owe it to me that you have no longer a fraudulent person for a manager.
还是多亏了我，你们今天才被召集到一起，对这件事作出判断。 And you owe it to me that you were called together today to pass judgment on the matter.
我一点儿也不想变得沉默寡言。 I have no intention whatever of singing small.
但是这件事还有另外一方面。 But there is another aspect to this affair.
对于那些不重视我的服务的人，我不准备继续为他们效劳了。 I am not prepared to go on giving my services to people who don’t value them.
我无法容忍今天下午他们表现出来的这种态度。 I have no patience with the attitude displayed this afternoon.
如果这里有任何一个人对我不满的话，那就让他去起诉好了。 If any one here thinks he has a grievance against me, let him bring an action.
如果有必要的话，我很乐意把这场官司打到上议院去。 I shall be happy to carry it to the House of Lords, if necessary.
我这一辈子非常熟悉这座城市，我可不习惯遭到怀疑，或者与背信弃义的人有来往。 I have been familiar with the City all my life, and I have not been in the habit of meeting with suspicions and ingratitude.
如果这就是当今的风俗的话，那我对这座城市熟悉得也够久了。 If this is an instance of present manners, I have been familiar with the City long enough.
我不向大会提交辞呈，我这就辞职。” I do not tender my resignation to the meeting; I resign.”
他向董事长鞠了个躬，把椅子往后一推，固执地走到门口，打开门就走了出去。 Bowing to the Chairman, and pushing back his chair, he walked doggedly to the door, opened it and passed through.
他寻找他的帽子。 He sought his hat.
他毫不怀疑，他已经使他们那脆弱的神经大为震惊！ He had not the slightest doubt but that he had astonished their weak nerves!
那些哈巴狗脸似的家伙们张着嘴！ Those pug-faced fellows had their mouths open!
他很想看一看他引起了什么反应，但是再把门打开是有失尊严的。 He would have liked to see what he had left behind, but it was hardly consistent with dignity to open the door again.
他转而拿起一块三明治，背朝着房门，戴着帽子，开始吃了起来。 He took a sandwich instead, and began to eat it with his back to the door and his hat on.
他觉得几个月以来从没有这么轻松过。 He felt better than he had for months.
一个声音说： A voice said:
“‘接下来的议程不会使他感兴趣了！’ “‘And the subsequent proceedings interested him no more!’
我以前不知道，福赛特，你竟是这样一位演说家！ I’d no idea, Forsyte, you were such an orator!
你击中了他们的要害！ You gave it ‘em between the eyes!
从来没有见过一个会议如此令人震惊！ Never saw a meeting so knocked out!
哦，你把他们的怨恨全部集中在你自己身上，从而拯救了董事会。 Well, you’ve saved the Board by focussing their resentment entirely on yourself.
这样做非常英勇，福赛特！” It was very gallant, Forsyte!”
索姆斯一边吃着三明治，一边愤愤地说： Soames growled through his sandwich:
“绝无此事！ “Nothing of the sort!
你也不干了吗？” Are you out, too?”
“是的。 “Yes.
我坚决要辞职。 I pressed my resignation.
我离开的时候，那个红脸的家伙正在提议对董事会投信任票——他们会通过的，福赛特——他们会通过的！ That red-faced fellow was proposing a vote of confidence in the Board when I left—and they’ll pass it, Forsyte—they’ll pass it!
顺便说一下，他们还说到了有关经济责任的问题！” Something was said about financial liability, by the way!”
“是吗？”索姆斯冷酷地微笑着说，“那一招不管用。 “Was there?” said Soames, with a grim smile: “That cock won’t fight.
他们唯一的机会就是提出董事会创办国外保险业务是越权行为。如果这个问题在公开大会上提出之后，他们重新确认了董事会，那他们就完蛋了。 Their only chance was to claim against the Board for initiating foreign assurance ultra vires; if they’re re-affirming the Board, after the question’s been raised in open meeting, they’re dished.
没有任何理由可以起诉你和我，说我们没有公开我们的怀疑——那是肯定的。” Nothing’ll lie against you and me, for not disclosing our suspicions—that’s certain.”
“我承认，这的确让我如释重负，”劳伦斯爵士叹了一口气说道， “A relief, I confess,” said Sir Lawrence, with a sigh.
“这是你一生中最精彩的演讲，福赛特！” “It was the speech of your life, Forsyte!”
索姆斯非常明白这一点，但他摇了摇头。 Perfectly well aware of that, Soames shook his head.
除了害怕在报纸上见到自己的名字以外，他开始觉得自己做得太过分了。 Apart from the horror of seeing himself in print, he was beginning to feel that he had been extravagant.
发脾气总是不对的！ It was always a mistake to lose your temper!
他的嘴角露出一丝苦笑。 A bitter little smile came on his lips.
没有一个人，甚至蒙特，会明白他受到了多么不公平的待遇。 Nobody, not even Mont, would see how unjustly he had been treated.
“哦，”他说，“我要走了。” “Well,” he said, “I shall go.”
“我想我要等一会儿，福赛特，听一听结果如何。” “I think I shall wait, Forsyte, and hear the upshot.”
“结果？ “Upshot?
他们会任命另外两个傻瓜，然后互相奉承一番。 They’ll appoint two other fools, and slaver over each other.
股东们！ Shareholders!
再见吧！” Good-bye!”
他朝门口走去。 He moved to the door.
经过英格兰银行的时候，他有一种离开了自己的生活的感觉。 Passing the Bank of England, he had a feeling of walking away from his own life.
他的聪明、他的判断力、他处理问题的方式——都遭到了中伤！ His acumen, his judgment, his manner of dealing with affairs—aspersed!
他们不喜欢，好吧——到此为止吧！ They didn’t like it; well—he would leave it!
看他以后还多管闲事！ Catch him meddling, in future!
这和现代事物的状态是完全一致的。 It was all of a piece with the modern state of things.
过一天算一天，而稳健的人却被逼上绝路！ Hand to mouth, and the steady men pushed to the wall!
对这种人而言，一英镑就是一英镑，不是一堆乱七八糟的机会和纸张。 The men to whom a pound was a pound, and not a mess of chance and paper.
这种人知道，对国家有利的事情就是严格、直接地管理好自己的事物。 The men who knew that the good of the country was the strict, straight conduct of their own affairs.
现在不需要这种人了。 They were not wanted.
他们会一个接一个地被人冷落——正如他现在所遭受的那样——而得宠的却是那些捉摸不定的人、革命家、不安分守己的人，或者是那些聪明但不讲道德的人，就像埃尔德森那样。 One by one, they would get the go-by—as he had got it—in favour of Jack-o’-lanterns, revolutionaries, restless chaps, or clever, unscrupulous fellows, like Elderson.
这已经成为一种风气了。 It was in the air.
贪得无厌取代了普通的诚实。 No amount of eating your cake and wanting to have it could take the place of common honesty.
他不知不觉地转弯走进了家禽街。 He turned into the Poultry before he knew why he had come there.
哦，他不妨立刻告诉格雷德曼，今后他必须运用自己的判断力了。 Well, he might as well tell Gradman at once that he must exercise his own judgment in the future.
在后街口处他停留了一会儿，仿佛要把那虚幻的景象印在脑子里。 At the mouth of the backwater he paused for a second, as if to print its buffness on his brain.
他要辞去他所接受的委托，连同私人委托一起辞去！ He would resign his trusts, private and all!
他可不打算在家中被人耻笑。 He had no notion of being sneered at in the family.
但是突然的一波回忆几乎使他惊慌失措。 But a sudden wave of remembrance almost washed his heart into his boots.
在楼上后面的那个房间里——有过多少故事啊：执行信托书、续订租赁合同、出售房屋、决策投资，不知有多少次因为财产管理得当而暗自得意！ What a tale of trust deeds executed, leases renewed, houses sold, investments decided on—in that back room up there; what a mint of quiet satisfaction in estates well managed!
啊！好吧！ Ah! well!
他还要继续管理他自己的财产。 He would continue to manage his own.
至于别人的，现在，他们必须自己去照顾了。 As for the others, they must look out for themselves, now.
面对周围的这种风气，这样一来他们就会有好日子过了。 And a precious time they’d have of it, in face of the spirit there was about!
他慢慢地走上石阶。 He mounted the stone steps slowly.
在福塞特事务所里，面对他的是不同寻常的东西——不是格雷德曼，而是，在那张又大又旧的桌子上，有一个熟透的大西瓜，旁边还有一个草袋。 In the repository of Forsyte affairs, he was faced by the unusual—not Gradman, but, on the large ripe table, a large ripe melon alongside a straw bag.
索姆斯闻了闻。 Soames sniffed.
这东西闻起来很香。 The thing smelled delicious.
他拿着它对着光看。 He held it to the light.
它那黄中透绿的色彩，它那网状的线条——完全是中国式的！ Its greeny yellow tinge, its network of threads—quite Chinese!
难道老格雷德曼像那只白猿一样，要把瓜皮到处乱扔吗？ Was old Gradman going to throw its rind about, like that white monkey?
他手里还拿着这个西瓜，这时一个声音说： He was still holding it when a voice said:
“噢！ “Aoh!
我没想到您今天会来，索姆斯先生。 I wasn’t expecting you today, Mr. Soames.
我正打算早点儿走呢，我的妻子搞了一个小聚会。” I was going early; my wife’s got a little party.”
“原来是这样！”索姆斯说着，把那个西瓜重新放回到桌子上， “So I see!” said Soames, restoring the melon to the table.
“这会儿没有什么事情要你去做，我只是来告诉你，替我起草一份辞去福赛特信托的辞职信。” “There’s nothing for you to do at the moment, but I came in to tell you to draw my resignations from the Forsyte trusts.”
这个老家伙脸上的表情如此怪异，索姆斯忍不住笑了。 The old chap’s face was such a study that he could not help a smile.
“你可以把在蒂莫西那里的职位给我保留着，但是其余的必须辞掉。 “You can keep me in Timothy’s; but the rest must go.
小罗杰能料理这些事。 Young Roger can attend to them.
反正他也无事可做。” He’s got nothing to do.”
一个粗鲁的、极力反对的声音说道：“哎呀！ A gruff and deprecating: “Dear me!
他们会不乐意的！”这激怒了索姆斯。 They won’t like it!” irritated Soames.
“那他们必须得忍耐着点儿！ “Then they must lump it!
我要休息一下。” I want a rest.”
他不打算解释原因——格雷德曼自己可以在《金融时报》上，或者不管他订的什么报纸上看到。 He did not mean to enter into the reason—Gradman could read it for himself in the Financial News, or whatever he took in.
“那么我就不会经常见到您了，索姆斯先生。蒂莫西先生的信托向来就没有什么事情。 “Then I shan’t be seeing you so often, Mr. Soames; there’s never anything in Mr. Timothy’s.
哎呀！ Dear me!
我完全被搞糊涂了。 I’m quite upset.
难道您妹妹的也不保留了吗？” Won’t you keep your sister’s?”
索姆斯看着这个老家伙，心中激起了内疚——如往常一样，只要有被人赏识的迹象，他就会这样。 Soames looked at the old fellow, and compunction stirred within him—as ever, at any sign that he was appreciated.
“哦，”他说，“把她的也给我留下。当然，关于我自己的事务我还是要保留的。 “Well,” he said, “keep me in hers; I shall be in about my own affairs, of course.
再见，格雷德曼。 Good afternoon, Gradman.
那个西瓜不错。” That’s a fine melon.”
他没有再等他说话。 He waited for no more words.
这个老家伙！ The old chap!
虽然他看起来很健壮，但不管怎样，他总有离开的那天！ HE couldn’t last much longer, anyway, sturdy as he looked!
哦，他们会发现很难与其相比！ Well, they would find it hard to match him!
走到家禽街的时候，他决定去格林街看一看威尼费雷德——非常奇怪，他竟突然怀念起公园巷附近一带，怀念起过去无忧无虑的日子，怀念起在詹姆斯和艾米丽的庇护下，他那风华正茂的青少年时代。 On reaching the Poultry, he decided to go to Green Street and see Winifred—queerly and suddenly homesick for the proximity of Park Lane, for the old secure days, the efflorescent privacy of his youth under the wings of James and Emily.
现在对他来说，只有威尼弗里德一个人代表着过去，她那可靠的性格从来没有改变过。 Winifred alone represented for him now, the past; her solid nature never varied, however much she kept up with the fashions.
他看到了她，衣着显得有点儿年轻，喝着中国茶，虽然她并不喜欢——但是有什么办法呢，别的茶都“太普通”了！ He found her, a little youthful in costume, drinking China tea, which she did not like—but what could one do, other teas were ‘common!’
她养了一只鹦鹉。 She had taken to a parrot.
鹦鹉现在又流行起来了。 Parrots were coming in again.
这只鸟发出了一阵非常讨厌的吵闹声。 The bird made a dreadful noise.
不知是受了鹦鹉的影响还是中国茶的影响——这种茶，是按照英国的方式泡制的，是中国人为了迎合外国人的口味而种植的一种品牌，总是使他感到不舒服——他很快就把整件事都告诉了她。 Whether under its influence or that of the China tea—which, made in the English way, of a brand the Chinese grew for foreign stomachs, always upset him—he was soon telling her the whole story.
等他说完了，威尼弗雷德愉快地说： When he had finished, Winifred said comfortably:
“嗯，索姆斯，我认为你干得很漂亮，他们活该如此！” “Well, Soames, I think you did splendidly; it serves them right!”
索姆斯知道他的叙述一定已经呈现了公众所不了解的事实真相，他喃喃地说： Conscious that his narrative must have presented the truth as it would not appear to the public, Soames muttered:
“这一切都很对；但是你会在金融报纸上看到完全不同的说法。” “That’s all very well; you’ll find a very different version in the financial papers.”
“哦！但是没有人会看那些报纸。 “Oh! but nobody reads them.
我就不担心。 I shouldn’t worry.
你做库埃吗？ Do you do Coue?
如此一个让人舒服的小人儿，索姆斯，我去听过他的讲座。 Such a comfortable little man, Soames; I went to hear him.
这东西有时候相当沉闷，但是它确实是最时髦的东西。” It’s rather a bore sometimes, but it’s quite the latest thing.”
索姆斯不说话了——他从来不承认自己的弱点。 Soames became inaudible—he never confessed a weakness.
“还有，”威尼弗雷德问，“弗勒的那件小事怎么样了？” “And how,” asked Winifred, “is Fleur’s little affair?”
“‘小事！’”一个声音在他的头顶上附和着。 “‘Little affair!’” echoed a voice above his head.
那只鸟！ That bird!
它正紧紧地抓着锦缎窗帘，脖子上下移动着。 It was clinging to the brocade curtains, moving its neck up and down.
“波利！”威尼弗雷德说，“别淘气！” “Polly!” said Winifred: “don’t be naughty!”
“索姆斯！”那只鸟叫道。 “Soames!” said the bird.
“那是我教它的。 “I’ve taught him that.
它是不是很可爱？ Isn’t he rather sweet?”
“不可爱，”索姆斯说， “No,” said Soames.
“要是我就把它关起来。它会弄坏你的窗帘的。” “I should shut him up; he’ll spoil your curtains.”
下午的烦心事突然又在他的心里翻腾起来了。 The vexation of the afternoon had revived within him suddenly.
生活是什么，不就是鹦鹉学舌吗？ What was life, but parrotry?
人们能看到什么真正的真理？ What did people see of the real truth?
他们只是互相重复说过的话，就像许多股东一样，或者从《骗子日报》上找到他们宝贵的观点。 They just repeated each other, like a lot of shareholders, or got their precious sentiments out of The Daily Liar.
只要有一个人带头，就会有一百个人跟上去，就像羊群一样！ For one person who took a line, a hundred followed on, like sheep!
“你留下来吃饭吧，亲爱的！”威尼弗雷德说。 “You’ll stay and dine, dear boy!” said Winifred.
好的！他要吃饭。 Yes! he would dine.
也许她有西瓜呢？ Had she a melon, by any chance?
他不愿意回到南广场，和他的妻子面对面地坐着。 He’d no inclination to go and sit opposite his wife at South Square.
十有八九弗勒不会下楼来的。 Ten to one Fleur would not be down.
至于小迈克尔——这家伙一下午都在那里，目睹了事情的全部经过。他不想把这件事再经历一遍。 And as to young Michael—the fellow had been there that afternoon and witnessed the whole thing; he’d no wish to go over it again.
他正在洗手准备吃饭，这时一个女仆在外面说： He was washing his hands for dinner, when a maid, outside, said:
“有人打电话找您，先生。” “You’re wanted on the ‘phone, sir.”
电话里传来了迈克尔的声音，又紧张又沙哑： Michael’s voice came over the wire, strained and husky:
“是您吗，先生？” “That you, sir?”
“是我。 “Yes.
什么事？” What is it?”
“弗勒。 “Fleur.
今天下午3点就开始了。 It began this afternoon at three.
我一直在找您。” I’ve been trying to reach you.”
“什么？”索姆斯喊道， “What?” cried Soames.
“情况怎么样？ “How?
快说啊！” Quick!”
“他们说一切正常。 “They say it’s all normal.
但是这真可怕。 But it’s so awful.
他们说很快就好了，唔。” They say quite soon, now.”
声音突然断了。 The voice broke off.
“天啊！”索姆斯说， “My God!” said Soames.
“我的帽子！” “My hat!”
到了前门口，那个女仆问：“您还回来吃饭吗，先生？” By the front door the maid was asking: “Shall you be back to dinner, sir?”
“吃饭！”索姆斯咕哝着，走了出去。 “Dinner!” muttered Soames, and was gone.
他急急忙忙地向前走，几乎是在跑着，眼睛寻找着出租车。 He hurried along, almost running, his eyes searching for a cab.
当然，一辆也没有！ None to be had, of course!
一辆也没有！ None to be had!
在伊昔姆俱乐部对面他找到了一辆，经过昨夜的暴风雨，今天天气晴朗，所以车篷敞开着。 Opposite the ‘Iseeum’ Club he got one, open in the fine weather after last night’s storm.
那场暴风雨啊！ That storm!
他本来应该知道的。 He might have known.
比她的预产期提前了十天。 Ten days before her time.
他究竟为什么不直接回去，或者至少打个电话告诉他们他要去哪里？ Why on earth hadn’t he gone straight back, or at least telephoned where he would be?
那天下午他所经历的一切都烟消云散了。 All that he had been through that afternoon was gone like smoke.
可怜的孩子！ Poor child!
可怜的小东西！ Poor little thing!
半麻醉分娩法怎么样？ And what about twilight sleep?
为什么他没有早点儿到那里？ Why hadn’t he been there?
他本来可以的——大自然！ He might have—nature!
该死！ Damn it!
大自然——仿佛连她都不能放过似的！ Nature—as if it couldn’t leave even her alone!
“赶快！”他探出身子说，“车钱加倍！” “Get on!” he said, leaning out: “Double fare!”
车子经过鉴赏家俱乐部、白金汉宫和白厅，经过所有那些把大自然无法控制的禁区，头发灰白、气喘吁吁的索姆斯就坐在那里，深深地沉浸在原始的情感之中。 Past the Connoisseurs, and the Palace, and Whitehall; past all preserves whence nature was excluded, deep in the waters of primitive emotion Soames sat, grey, breathless.
经过大本钟——8点整！ Past Big Ben—eight o’clock!
五个小时！ Five hours!
已经有五个小时了！ Five hours of it!
“让它过去吧！”他大声咕哝道，“让它过去吧，上帝！” “Let it be over!” he muttered aloud: “Let it be over, God!”
第十四章 Chapter XIV
焦虑不安 On the Rack
当他的岳父向董事长鞠躬退席的时候，迈克尔很想大喊一声“好！”但是他克制住了。 When his father-inlaw bowed to the Chairman and withdrew, Michael had restrained a strong desire to shout: “Bravo!”
谁会想到这个“老头”会如此大发雷霆呢？ Who’d have thought the ‘old man’ could let fly like that?
他已经彻底地“惹恼了他们”。 He had ‘got their goats’ with a vengeance.
经过很长一段时间混乱的叫喊声，他的邻座索德利先生终于能够发言了。 Quite an interval of fine mixed vociferation followed, before his neighbour, Mr. Sawdry, made himself heard at last.
“既然与此事有牵连的董事已经辞职了，我愿意提议对董事会的其他董事投信任票。” “Now that the director implicated has resigned, I shall ‘ave pleasure in proposing a vote of confidence in the rest of the Board.”
迈克尔看到他的父亲站了起来，有点儿做作，面带微笑，向董事长鞠了一躬。 Michael saw his father rise, a little finicky and smiling, and bow to the Chairman.
“我就当我的辞职也被接受了。如果您允许的话，我就和福赛特先生一起退席了。” “I take my resignation as accepted also; if you permit me, I will join Mr. Forsyte in retirement.”
有人在说： Some one was saying:
“我赞成投信任票。” “I shall be glad to second that vote of confidence.”
迈克尔擦过索德利先生的膝盖，向门口走去。 And brushing past the knees of Mr. Sawdry, Michael sought the door.
他从那里看到几乎每一个人都举手赞成投信任票。他心里想：“扔给这些股东们吧！”他走出了这家旅馆。 From there he could see that nearly every hand was raised in favour of the vote of confidence; and with the thought: ‘Thrown to the shareholders!’ he made his way out of the hotel.
出于体谅他们的心情，迈克尔没有去寻找那两位老人。 Delicacy prevented him from seeking out those two.
他们保全了尊严，但是那些卑鄙小人得到了其余的一切。 They had saved their dignity; but the dogs had had the rest.
他急急忙忙地向西走去，心里想着做到公正是多么艰难。 Hurrying west, he reflected on the rough ways of justice.
当然，股东们也有抱怨的理由，为了满足他们的公平感，就得有人受到惩罚。 The shareholders had a grievance, of course; and some one had to get it in the neck to satisfy their sense of equity.
他们选中了老福赛特，而他在所有人当中，是最不应该受到谴责的。至于准爵爷，如果他能保持缄默，他们一定会把他归入信任票之列的。 They had pitched on Old Forsyte, who, of all, was least to blame; for if Bart had only held his tongue, they would certainly have lumped him into the vote of confidence.
这一切都很自然，但很不合逻辑。现在已经4点了！ All very natural and illogical; and four o’clock already!
《赝品》今天出版！ ‘Counterfeits!’
在这天，他对威尔弗里德以往的感情在心里又变得强烈起来。 The old feeling for Wilfrid was strong in him this day of publication.
一个人必须为他自己的书尽一切力量——可怜的老朋友！ One must do everything one could for his book—poor old son!
绝不能失败。 There simply must not be a frost.
拜访了两位大书商之后，他就去了自己的俱乐部，并把自己关在电话间里。 After calling in at two big booksellers, he made for his club, and closeted himself in the telephone booth.
在过去人们“坐着出租车到处跑”。 In old days they ‘took cabs and went about.’
如今打电话要快一些——是吗？ Ringing-up was quicker—was it?
历经无穷的烦恼之后，他找到了西伯莱、内津、厄普夏、马斯特以及其他六个被选定的人。 With endless vexations, he tracked down Sibley, Nazing, Upshire, Master, and half-a-dozen others of the elect.
他用了一种经过深思熟虑的、可能打动他们的声调。 He struck a considered note likely to move them.
这本书——他说——一定会“惹恼那些保守派和废物们”，不过它需要鉴赏家们稍微鼓吹一下。 The book—he said—was bound to ‘get the goat of the old guard and the duds generally’; it would want a bit of drum-beating from the cognoscenti.
他向每一个人发出请求，让对方觉得唯有对方的赞扬才是至关重要的。 To each of them he appealed as the only one whose praise really mattered.
“如果你还没有评论过这本书，老朋友，请您评论一下好吗？ “If you haven’t reviewed the book, old chap, will you?
当然，您是最重要的。” It’s you who count, of course.”
而且他会对每一个人补充说：“我一点儿也不在乎这本书能否卖出去，但是我的确希望老威尔弗里德能够得到他应有的赞誉。” And to each he added: “I don’t care two straws whether it sells, but I do want old Wilfrid to get his due.”
而且他是认真的。 And he meant it.
在电话间里的那一个小时里，作为出版商的迈克尔死去了，作为朋友的迈克尔生龙活虎。 The publisher in Michael was dead during that hour in the telephone booth, the friend alive and kicking hard.
他出来的时候满头大汗，筋疲力尽。这时已经是5点半了。 He came out with sweat running down his forehead, quite exhausted; and it was half-past five.
“喝杯茶——然后回家！”他想。 ‘Cup of tea—and home!’ he thought.
他6点钟到了家门口。 He reached his door at six.
小叮铃，一点儿也不显眼，畏缩在门厅远端的角落里。 Ting-a-ling, absolutely unimportant, was cowering in the far corner of the hall.
“怎么了，老朋友？” “What’s the matter, old man?”
楼上传来的声音回答了他，这声音使他毛骨悚然——一阵又长又低沉的呻吟声。 A sound from above, which made his blood run cold, answered—a long, low moaning.
“哦，上帝！”他喘息着，跑上楼去。 “Oh, God!” he gasped, and ran upstairs.
在房门口安妮特遇见了他。 Annette met him at the door.
他意识到她在说法语，在喊他“亲爱的”，还有几句话是“3点钟的时候… He was conscious of her speaking in French, of being called “mon cher,” of the words “vers trois heures....
医生说不用担心——一切都很好。” The doctor says one must not worry—all goes for the best.”
那种呻吟声又来了，房门在他面前关上了，她走了。 Again that moan, and the door shut in his face; she was gone.
迈克尔仍然站在小地毯上，浑身直冒冷汗，指甲深深地掐进掌心里。 Michael remained standing on the rug with perfectly cold sweat oozing from him, and his nails dug deep into his palms.
“这就是一个人怎样成为父亲的！”他想，“这就是我怎样成为儿子的！” ‘This is how one becomes a father!’ he thought: ‘This is how I became a son!’
那呻吟声啊！ That moaning!
留在这里，他受不了，离开这里，他也受不了。 He could not bear to stay there, and he could not bear to go away.
也许还得好几个钟头呢！ It might be hours, yet!
他不断重复地对自己说：“不必担心——不必担心！” He kept repeating to himself: “One must not worry—must not worry!”
说得容易！ How easily said!
毫无意义！ How meaningless!
他的大脑、他的心，正在寻求安慰，他突然想到他可能会遇到最奇怪的安慰。 His brain, his heart, ranging for relief, lighted on the strangest relief which could possibly have come to him.
假如这个即将出生的孩子，不是他的——而是——而是威尔弗里德的，那么他在这里，在门外，会有什么感觉呢？ Suppose this child being born, had not been his—had been—been Wilfrid’s; how would he have been feeling, here, outside this door?
这可能——这可能很容易就是这个样子——因为现在，没有什么东西是神圣的！ It might—it might so easily have been—since nothing was sacred, now!
除了——是的，就是那种比自己还要宝贵的东西——就是那正在里面的呻吟声。 Nothing except—yes, just that which was dearer than oneself—just that which was in there, moaning.
他站在小毯子上实在忍受不了，便走下楼去。 He could not bear it on the rug, and went downstairs.
他在红棕色地板上走来走去，嘴里叼着雪茄，心里怀着模糊而又难以控制的极度痛苦。 Across and across the copper floor, a cigar in his mouth, he strode in vague, rebellious agony.
为什么生孩子会是这样？ Why should birth be like this?
而答案是：它不是这样的——在中国就不是这样的！ And the answer was: It isn’t—not in China!
他一直怀有一切都不重要的信条——然而却遇上了这样的事情！ To have the creed that nothing mattered—and then run into it like this!
以这样的代价产生的事物，一定是重要的，也应该是重要的。 Something born at such a cost, must matter, should matter.
必须注意到这一点！ One must see to that!
迈克尔的大脑停止了思考，他站在那里，仔细地听着。 Speculation ceased in Michael’s brain; he stood, listening terribly.
什么声音也没有！ Nothing!
他在楼下也忍不住了，又跑上楼来。 He could not bear it down there, and went up again.
一开始没有声音，然后又是一阵呻吟声！ No sound at first, and then another moan!
这一次他逃进自己的书房里，在房间里兜圈子，眼睛看着奥布里·格林的那几幅漫画。 This time he fled into his study, and ranged round the room, looking at the cartoons of Aubrey Greene.
他一幅也看不进去，突然他想起了“老福赛特”。 He did not see a single one, and suddenly bethought him of ‘Old Forsyte.’
应该告诉他！ He ought to be told!
他打电话到“鉴赏家俱乐部”、“利姆夫俱乐部”以及他父亲的几个俱乐部，说不定开完会后他们一起上那里去了。 He rang up the ‘Connoisseurs,’ the ‘Remove,’ and his own father’s clubs, in case they might have gone there together after the meeting.
所有的地方他都扑空了。 He drew blank everywhere.
现在已经7点半了。 It was half-past seven.
这件事还要持续多长时间呢？ How much longer was this going on?
他回到卧室门口，什么也听不见。 He went back to the bedroom door; could hear nothing.
然后他又下楼来到门厅。 Then down again to the hall.
这时，小叮铃正卧在前门旁边。 Ting-a-ling was lying by the front door, now.
“烦死了！”迈克尔想，他一边捶着背，一边机械地清理着信箱。 ‘Fed-up!’ thought Michael, stroking his back, and mechanically clearing the letter-box.
只有一封信——威尔弗里德的笔迹！ Just one letter—Wilfrid’s writing!
他把信拿到楼梯脚下，他用一半的心思读着信，另一半则在琢磨——于是这样徘徊到楼上去了。 He took it to the foot of the stairs and read it with half his brain, the other half wondering—wandering up there.
“亲爱的蒙特，我明天就要动身，试着去穿越阿拉伯半岛了。 “DEAR MONT,—I start tomorrow to try and cross Arabia.
我想万一我过不去的话，你或许愿意收到我的一封信。 I thought you might like a line in case Arabia crosses me.
我已经恢复了理智。 I have recovered my senses.
这里的空气对于任何一种情感而言都太清新了。放逐的激情很快就变得令人厌恶了。 The air here is too clear for sentiment of any kind; and passion in exile soon becomes sickly.
很抱歉我以前给你带去了那么多的烦恼。 I am sorry I made you so much disturbance.
战后我回到英国，无所事事，写了些幼稚无聊的东西给那些聪明的年轻女性和肚子里有点儿墨水的人看，这是一个错误。 It was a mistake for me to go back to England after the war, and hang about writing drivel for smart young women and inky folk to read.
可怜的老英格兰——她正处于一个困难时期。 Poor old England—she’s in for a bad time.
向她问好，也向你问好。 Give her my love; the same to yourselves.
你永远的， “Yours ever,
威尔弗里德·德赛特。 “WILFRID DESERT.
附言——如果你已经把我留下的东西出版了，请将版税转交于家父。——威·德。” “P. S.—If you’ve published the things I left behind, send any royalties to me care of my governor.—W. D.”
迈克尔的一半心思在想：“哦，那样就对了！ Half Michael’s brain thought: ‘Well, that’s that!
这本书今天出版！” And the book coming out today!’
奇怪！ Queer!
威尔弗里德说得对不对呢——这一切是不是一个彻底的骗局呢——舞文弄墨的潮流？ Was Wilfrid right—was it all a blooming gaff—the inky stream?
人们只是在加重英国的弊病吗？ Was one just helping on England’s sickness?
他们大家应不应该都骑上骆驼，一直骑到日落呢？ Ought they all to get on camels and ride the sun down?
然而，书里有安慰和消遣的东西，这正是人们所需要的！ And yet, in books were comfort and diversion; and they were wanted!
英国必须继续前进——继续前进！ England had to go on—go on!
“没有退路，没有退路，没有退路的人必须获胜，否则就是死路一条……” ‘No retreat, no retreat, they must conquer or die who have no retreat!’...
上帝啊！ God!
那个声音又来了！ There it was again!
他飞快地跑回楼上，双手捂着耳朵，眼睛像发疯一样。 Back he flew upstairs, with his ears covered and his eyes wild.
那个声音停止了，安妮特出来找他。 The sounds ceased; Annette came out to him.
“她的父亲，亲爱的，想办法找到她的父亲！” “Her father, mon cher; try to find her father!”
“我找过了——找不到！”迈克尔气喘吁吁地说。 “I have—I can’t!” gasped Michael.
“试试格林街——达尔迪夫人那里。 “Try Green Street—Mrs. Dartie.
勇敢点儿！ Courage!
一切正常——快好了，现在。” All is normal—it will be quite sewn, now.”
当他打电话到格林街，终于得到回音之后，他打开书房的门，坐在那里等着“老福赛特”到来。 When he had rung up Green Street and been answered at last, he sat with the door of his study open, waiting for ‘Old Forsyte’ to come.
他的余光看到他的裤腿上烧了一个圆圆的洞——他甚至连烧焦的气味都没闻到，甚至没有意识到自己在抽烟。 Half his sight remarked a round hole burnt in his trouser leg—he hadn’t even noticed the smell; hadn’t even realised that he had been smoking.
他必须振作起来，迎接这位“老头”。 He must pull himself together for the ‘old man.’
他听到门铃响了，便跑下楼去开门。 He heard the bell ring, and ran down to open.
“怎么样？”索姆斯说。 “Well?” said Soames.
“还没生呢，先生。 “Not yet, sir.
上楼到我的书房去吧。 Come up to my study.
那里比较近。” It’s nearer.”
他们肩并肩地走上楼去。 They went up side by side.
老人整齐而斑白的头发，两眼之间深深的皱纹，双眼仿佛凝视着隐藏在它们后面的痛苦，这一切使迈克尔镇定了下来。 That trim grey head, with the deep furrow between the eyes, and those eyes staring as if at pain behind them, steadied Michael.
可怜的老人家！ Poor old chap!
他也在“为此担心”呢！ He was ‘for it,’ too!
他们俩都“处于困境”了！ They were both on ‘their uppers!’
