我这里有白兰地。” I’ve got brandy here.”
“好的，”索姆斯说， “Yes,” said Soames.
“什么都行。” “Anything.”
他们手里拿着白兰地，半举着杯子，耳朵倾听着——手猛地往上一抬，喝了下去。 With the brandies in their hands, half-raised, they listened—jerked their hands up, drank.
他们都是无意识的，就像由一根绳子牵着的两个木偶似的。 They were automatic, like two doll figures worked by the same string.
“抽烟吗，先生？”迈克尔说。 “Cigarette, sir?” said Michael.
索姆斯点点头。 Soames nodded.
他点着香烟却并没有放进嘴里，他们倾听着，之后将香烟放进嘴里，拿出来，喷出烟雾。 With the lighted cigarettes just not in their mouths, they listened, put them in, took them out, puffed smoke.
迈克尔把右胳膊紧紧地放在自己的胸前。 Michael had his right arm tight across his chest.
索姆斯的左胳膊也是如此。 Soames his left.
就这样，他们肩并肩地坐着，构成了一幅图案。 They formed a pattern, thus, side by side.
“真难熬，先生。 “Bad to stick, sir.
抱歉！” Sorry!”
索姆斯点点头。 Soames nodded.
他紧紧地咬着牙。 His teeth were clenched.
突然他的手放松了。 Suddenly his hand relaxed.
“听！”他说。 “Listen!” he said.
许多声音——不同的声音——非常混乱！ Sounds—different—confused!
迈克尔的手抓住了什么东西，紧紧地握着。那东西冰冷枯瘦——那是索姆斯的手。 Michael’s hand seized something, gripped it hard; it was cold, thin—the hand of Soames.
他们就这样坐着，手握着手，眼睛盯着门口，谁也不知道过了多长时间。 They sat thus, hand in hand, staring at the doorway, for how long neither knew.
突然门口的光线变暗了，一个穿着灰色衣服的人站在那里——安妮特！ Suddenly that doorway darkened; a figure in grey stood there—Annette!
“一切顺——顺利！ “It is all r-right!
是个儿子！” A son!”
第十五章 Chapter XV
风平浪静 Calm
第二天早上，迈克尔从酣睡中醒来，他的第一个念头就是：“弗勒回来了！” On waking from deep sleep next morning, Michael’s first thought was: ‘Fleur is back!’
随后他记起来了。 He then remembered.
他在她的房门口低声问道：“都还好吗？”护士对他有力地点了点头。 To his: “O. K.?” whispered at her door, he received an emphatic nod from the nurse.
在兴奋的期待中，他保持着足够的现代观念在想：“别再废话了！ In the midst of excited expectation he retained enough modernity to think: ‘No more blurb!
安安静静地去吃早饭吧！” Go and eat your breakfast quietly!’
在餐厅里，索姆斯正在用一种鄙视的神情看着他面前的那个磕开了的鸡蛋。 In the dining-room Soames was despising the broken egg before him.
迈克尔进来的时候，他抬头看了一眼，然后就把脸埋在了杯子里。 He looked up as Michael entered, and buried his face in his cup.
迈克尔完全明白，他们曾手握手地坐着！ Michael understood perfectly; they had sat hand in hand!
他还看到在他的盘子旁边打开的那份报纸是金融刊物。 He saw, too, that the journal opened by his plate was of a financial nature.
“有关于股东大会的消息吗，先生？ “Anything about the meeting, sir?
您的那篇演讲读起来一定津津有味！” Your speech must read like one o’clock!”
索姆斯发出一小声奇怪的声音，把报纸递给了他。 With a queer little sound Soames held out the paper.
标题写着：“激烈的会议——两名董事辞职——投信任票。” The headlines ran: “Stormy meeting—resignation of two directors—a vote of confidence.”
迈克尔粗略地浏览下去，直到他看到： Michael skimmed down till he came to:
“与此事有关的一位董事，福赛特先生，在一篇相当长的讲话中，说他不打算变得沉默寡言。 “Mr. Forsyte, the director involved, in a speech of some length, said he had no intention of singing small.
他反对股东们的行为，他不习惯受到怀疑。 He deprecated the behaviour of the shareholders; he had not been accustomed to meet with suspicions.
他提出了辞职。” He tendered his resignation.”
迈克尔放下了报纸。 Michael dropped the sheet.
“天啊！”他说——“‘有关的——怀疑。’ “By Jove!” he said—”Involved—suspicions.’
他们把事情弄颠倒了，好像——！” They’ve given it a turn, as though—!”
“这些报纸！”索姆斯说着，又继续吃鸡蛋。 “The papers!” said Soames, and resumed his egg.
迈克尔坐了下来，剥掉香蕉皮。 Michael sat down, and stripped the skin off a banana.
“‘他真是视死如归啊，’”他想，“可怜的老头！” ‘“Nothing became him like his death,”’ he thought: ‘Poor old boy!’
“哦，先生，”他说，“我当时在场，我所能说的是：只有您和我的父亲两个人让我尊敬。” “Well, sir,” he said, “I was there, and all I can say is: You and my father were the only two people who excited my respect.”
“是吗！”索姆斯说着，放下了他的勺子。 “That!” said Soames, putting down his spoon.
迈克尔感觉到他想一个人呆一会儿，于是他吞下那只香蕉，到书房去了。 Michael perceived that he wished to be alone, and swallowing the banana, went to his study.
他在等着被召唤的同时，给他爸爸打了一个电话。 Waiting for his summons, he rang up his father.
“昨天还好吧，先生？” “None the worse for yesterday, sir?”
劳伦斯爵士的声音又清晰又尖细，声调相当高。 Sir Lawrence’s voice came clear and thin, rather high.
“更穷了，但也更聪明了。 “Poorer and wiser.
情况怎么样？” What’s the bulletin?”
“非常好。” “Top-hole.”
“替我们向母子俩问好。 “Our love to both.
你母亲想知道他有没有头发？” Your mother wants to know if he has any hair?”
“我还没有看到他呢。 “Haven’t seen him yet.
我正要去呢。” I’m just going.”
的确，安妮特正在门口召唤他呢。 Annette, indeed, was beckoning him from the doorway.
“她想让你把小狗带过来，亲爱的。” “She wants you to bring the little dog, mon cher.”
迈克尔抱着小叮铃，踮着脚尖，走了进去。 With Ting-a-ling under his arm, and treading on tiptoe, Michael entered.
第十一代准男爵！ The eleventh baronet!
在她俯着的头下面，他看起来不太起眼。 He did not seem to amount to much, beneath her head bent over him.
她头发的颜色的确比较深！ And surely her hair was darker!
他走到床边，恭敬地抚摸着。 He walked up to the bed, and touched it reverently.
弗勒抬起头，露出正在使劲吮吸她的小手指的婴儿。 Fleur raised her head, and revealed the baby sucking vigorously at her little finger.
“他不就是一只猴子吗？”她那微弱的声音说道。 “Isn’t he a monkey?” said her faint voice.
迈克尔点点头。 Michael nodded.
明显是只猴子——但不是白色的——那是关键问题！ A monkey clearly—but whether white—that was the question!
“你怎么样，亲爱的？” “And you, sweetheart?”
“现在好了，但是那时——”她吸了一口气，她眼睛的颜色变深了，“丁，看啊！” “All right now, but it was—” She drew her breath in, and her eyes darkened: “Ting, look!”
这只中国狗，鼻孔微微地翕动着，在迈克尔的胳膊下往后缩。 The Chinese dog, with nostrils delicately moving, drew backward under Michael’s arm.
他的全部举动都表现出一种无所不知的评论。 His whole demeanour displayed a knowing criticism.
“小狗嘛，”他仿佛在说，“我们在中国也是这样的。 “Puppies,” he seemed to say, “we do it in China.
我保留意见！” Judgment reserved!”
“多么明亮的眼睛啊！”迈克尔说，“我们不必告诉它，这是医生从切尔西带来的。” “What eyes!” said Michael: “We needn’t tell HIM that this was brought from Chelsea by the doctor.”
弗勒发出极为微弱的笑声。 Fleur gave the tiniest laugh.
“把它放下吧，迈克尔。” “Put him down, Michael.”
迈克尔把它放下来，然后它就跑到自己的角落里去了。 Michael put him down, and he went to his corner.
“我不能说话，”弗勒说，“但是我非常想说话，好像我已经好几个月没有说话了。” “I mustn’t talk,” said Fleur, “but I want to, frightfully; as if I’d been dumb for months.”
“就像我的感觉一样，”迈克尔想，“她好像离开了，去了某个地方，彻底离开了。” ‘Just as I felt,’ thought Michael, ‘she’s been away, away somewhere, utterly away.’
“就像是被抑制住了，迈克尔。 “It was like being held down, Michael.
好几个月都身不由己。” Months of not being yourself.”
迈克尔温柔地说：“是啊！这一过程太漫长了！ Michael said softly: “Yes! the process IS behind the times!
他有头发吗？ Has he got any hair?
我母亲想知道。” My mother wants to know.”
弗勒露出了第十一代准男爵的头，上面覆盖着一层深色的绒毛。 Fleur revealed the head of the eleventh baronet, covered with dark down.
“就像我祖母的头发，但是它会变浅的。 “Like my grandmother’s; but it’ll get lighter.
他的眼睛会变成灰色的。 His eyes are going to be grey.
哦！还有，迈克尔，关于教父教母怎么办？ Oh! and, Michael, about godparents?
艾莉森，当然啦——但是男的呢？” Alison, of course—but men?”
迈克尔稍微思考了一下回答道： Michael dwelled a little before answering:
“我昨天收到了威尔弗里德的来信。 “I had a letter from Wilfrid yesterday.
你想让他做吗？ Would you like him?
他还在国外，但是我可以在教堂里代表他拿海绵。” He’s still out there, but I could hold the sponge for him in church.”
“他恢复过来了吗？” “Is he all right again?”
“他是这么说的。” “He says so.”
他看不懂她眼中的表情，但是她的嘴唇微微撅了起来。 He could not read the expression of her eyes, but her lips were pouted slightly.
“好的，”她说，“而且我认为一个就够了，你觉得呢？ “Yes,” she said: “and I think one’s enough, don’t you?
我的教父从来没有给过我什么。” Mine never gave me anything.”
“我的一个教父给了我一本圣经，另一个给了我一顿责骂。 “One of mine gave me a bible, and the other gave me a wigging.
那么，就威尔弗里德吧。” Wilfrid, then.”
说着他朝她俯下身。 And he bent over her.
她的眼睛似乎向他表达了一丝略带讽刺的歉意。 Her eyes seemed to make him a little ironic apology.
他吻了吻她的头发，就匆忙离开了。 He kissed her hair, and moved hurriedly away.
索姆斯站在门口，等着轮到他。 By the door Soames was standing, awaiting his turn.
“只能呆一分钟，先生。”护士说。 “Just a minute only, sir,” the nurse was saying.
索姆斯走到床边，站在那里看着他的女儿。 Soames walked up to the bedside, and stood looking at his daughter.
“爸爸，亲爱的！” “Dad, dear!”
迈克尔听到她说。 Michael heard her say.
索姆斯只是摸了摸她的手，点了点头，仿佛是在对这个婴儿表示赞许，然后就走了出来，但是，在镜子里，迈克尔看到他的嘴唇在颤抖。 Soames just touched her hand, nodded, as if implying approval of the baby, and came walking back, but, in a mirror, Michael saw his lips quivering.
再次回到一楼，他有一种强烈的想唱歌的渴望。 On the ground floor once more, he had the most intense desire to sing.
这样不行，于是，他走进那个中式的房间，站在那里凝视着阳光普照的广场。 It would not do; and, entering the Chinese room, he stood staring out into the sunlit square.
天啊！ Gosh!
活着真好！ It was good to be alive!
可以敞开心扉，但你无法逃避生活！ Say what you liked, you couldn’t beat it!
人们可能会对生活嗤之以鼻，看不起它；人们可以相信未来或者过去，但是——他只能拥有现在！ They might turn their noses up at life, and look down them at it; they might bolster up the future and the past, but—give him the present!
“我要把那幅白猿再挂起来！”他想， ‘I’ll have that white monkey up again!’ he thought.
“我要趁它使我沮丧之前再好好看看这只畜生！” ‘I’ll see the brute further before he shall depress me!’
他走到楼梯下面的小房间里，然后，从用防蛀虫纸和牛皮纸包裹着的四对窗帘下面，拿出了那幅画。 He went out to a closet under the stairs, and, from beneath four pairs of curtains done up in moth-preserver and brown paper, took out the picture.
在微弱的灯光下，他把那幅画拿得远一点儿去看。 He held it away from him in the dim light.
这只畜生的眼睛啊！ The creature’s eyes!
一切都在那双眼睛里！ It was all in those eyes!
“没关系，老家伙！”他说，“你上去吧！” “Never mind, old son!” he said: “Up you go!”
于是他把它带到那个中国式的房间里去了。 And he carried it into the Chinese room.
索姆斯在那里。 Soames was there.
“我打算把它再挂起来，先生。” “I’m going to put him up again, sir.”
索姆斯点点头。 Soames nodded.
“我把线挂上去，请您拿一下好吗？” “Would you hold him, while I hook the wire?”
索姆斯拿着这幅画。 Soames held the picture.
迈克尔回到红棕色地板上，说： Returning to the copper floor, Michael said:
“好了，先生！”然后退后一步观画。 “All right, sir!” and stood back.
索姆斯和他站在一起。 Soames joined him.
他们肩并肩地一起注视着这只白猿。 Side by side they contemplated the white monkey.
“得不到他要的，它是不会高兴的，”最后迈克尔说，“唯一的问题是，你看，它不知道那东西究竟是什么。” “He won’t be happy till he gets it,” said Michael at last: “The only thing is, you see, he doesn’t know what IT is.”
